DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, April 1, or the 4th day of the third month of the Year of the Dog according to the lunar calendar. The following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1572: The Dutch War for Independence from Spain begins.
1578: William Harvey, British physician and anatomist who discovered the circulation of blood, is born.
1815: Prince Otto Eduard Leopold von Bismarck, Prussian statesman and first chancellor of the German Empire, is born.
1908: Japan puts into practice a six-year compulsory primary education system.
1924: Adolf Hitler is sentenced by a court to five years in jail for high treason. He was released on Dec. 20.
1924: The Republic of China's Central News Agency is established in Canton by the ruling Kuomintang.
1930: Yen Hsi-shan, Feng Yu-hsiang and Li Tsung-jen revolt against the ROC National Government.
1938: The Emergency National Congress of the Kuomintang in Wuchang elects Chiang Kai-shek as its director-general and decides to organize a People's Political Council and a "Three Principles of the People" Youth Corps.
1940: The Nationalist government issues a circular to all levels of the nation's governments to call Dr. Sun Yat-sen the "National Father of the Republic of China."
1945: U.S. forces invade the Japanese island of Okinawa.
1959: The Dalai Lama arrives in India from Tibet.
1960: The United State launches Tiros I, its first weather satellite.
1965: King Hussein of Jordan appoints Prince Hassan, his younger brother, as his heir.
1968: Ma Ssu-tsung, former president of mainland China's "National Music Academy," and his wife arrive in Taipei from the United States.
1975: Cambodian President Lon Nol flees to Indonesia as Khmer Rouge guerrillas close in on Phnom Penh.
1976: President Yen Chia-kan visits the Taiwan Machinery Show at the grounds of the China External Trade Development Council.
1984: Chang Gung Memorial Hospital completes the first human pancreas transplant in Asia.
1986: The new Value Added Tax (VAT) system is inaugurated in Taiwan.
1989: Namibia gains independence from South Africa.
1992: President George Bush pledges that the United States will help finance the 24-billion dollar international aid fund for the former Soviet Union.
1995: President Lee Teng-hui starts a four-day visit to the United Arab Emirates and Jordan.
1996: Britain proposes slaughtering 15,000 of its cattle every week for the next six years in order to fight mad cow disease.
1996: Japan's Mitsubishi Bank and Tokyo Bank merge to become one of the world's largest banks, Tokyo-Mitsubishi Bank.
1998: Israel accepts a United Nations resolution calling for its withdrawal from south Lebanon.
2000: Acting Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan says that he expects the party will rise again by winning the elections for legislators and county magistrates in two years and by regaining the presidency in 2004.
2001: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou presents a "Key to Taipei" to Tibetan spiritual leader Dalai Lama, saying that "the city always welcomes you and is always opened to you."
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A wise and good man is easy to serve, but difficult to please. If you go beyond your duty to please him, he will not be pleased. But in his employment of men, he always takes into consideration their capacity. A fool, on the other hand, is easy to please, but difficult to serve. If you go beyond your duty to please him, he will be pleased. But in his employment of men, he expects them to be able to do everything."

DOC.HEADLINE: COA REFUSES TO ALLOW CHINA'S GIFT PANDAS TO ENTER TAIWAN(repeat)

TEXT.P: A task force of the Council of Agriculture (COA) rejected on Friday applications by two civic groups to import a pair of giant pandas offered by China to Taiwan as a gift.

The task force said after a meeting -- its third deliberation on the issue -- that its members had formed a consensus whereby under the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES), they cannot issue certificates at present to permit the two pandas to enter Taiwan.
The two civic groups requesting permission to host the pandas are the Taipei City Zoo and the Leofoo Village Theme Park in Hsinchu County.
While a closure is under construction at the Taipei City Zoo to house the pandas, the zoo in Taichung City, central Taiwan, is also building a closure in its bid to host the pandas.

Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, who was in eastern Taiwan to stump for a candidate of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) in a by-election for Taitung County magistrate in his capacity as KMT chairman, said he was unsurprised by the COA's decision because there were indications beforehand the DPP government would not permit the pandas to enter.

President Chen Shui-bian has described the panda offer as part of China's "united front" tactics against Taiwan, while COA Vice Chairman Lee Chien-chuan also said recently that Taiwan would accept the pandas only if China recognized Taiwan as a country.
Asked whether he believed political forces had intervened in the decision, Ma said it was "obvious to everyone."
Noting the two pandas China offered to Taiwan are not wild animals but were raised in a closure, Ma said in this case the wildlife conservation law does not apply.
He said he will meet with city officials and executives at the Taipei City Zoo to see whether there is a solution to the issue.

Meanwhile, Taichung Mayor Jason Hu said the Taichung City Government will try to obtain China's permission to let the city's zoo host the pandas and then file an application with the COA for permission for their entry.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO REGRET OVER RETIRING FROM FOREIGN SERVICE: E.U. REP
DOC.DATELINE: Brussels, March 31 (CNA) (By P.C. Tang and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Outgoing Republic of China Representative to the European Union Chen Chien-jen said Friday he feels no regret that he will soon retire from his 40-year diplomatic career, a plan that has been postponed for several years.

Minister of Foreign Affairs Huang Chih-fang confirmed a few days ago that Chen will retire from his post soon but did not disclose the name of his successor. Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs Michael Ying-mao Kau has been designated as Chen's replacement, according to media reports.

Chen told the Central News Agency that he had planned to retire in 2000 and 2004 but opted to prioritize national interests over his personal plans after President Chen Shui-bian asked him to stay on.
"There was a feeling of regret in my heart that I could not live a carefree life. This feeling will be made up for now that my public service career will soon come to an end, " Chen said.

The diplomat, a member of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) who previously served as minister of foreign affairs when the party was in power, was appointed by the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) government as the country's representative to the United States in 2000. He had intended to retire when he stepped down from that post in 2004 but later accepted the appointment of E.U. representative.

On the most unforgettable event of his foreign service career, Chen said it is hard for him to forget the process of bilateral talks with the U. S. government after the severance of diplomatic relations between the ROC and the United States.
However, being able to participate in the establishment of diplomatic relations with Nicaragua and Palau were pleasant experiences, he went on.
As to the government's bids to participate in the World Health Organization, Chen noted that the idea was put forward 10 years ago when he was vice minister of foreign affairs.

Chen said he and then-Minister of Foreign Affairs John Chang, considering the difficulties involving Taiwan's bid to join the United Nations, decided to promote the WHO bid, in the belief that WHO participation carries less political sensitivity.

With Taiwan's efforts over the past 10 years and the importance of including Taiwan in the WHO having been highlighted by the outbreaks of SARS and bird flu, there should be progress this year in promoting the bid, Chen predicted.
On his plans after retiring, Chen said he is thinking about writing his memoirs and releasing a CD that he recorded in the 1990s of him singing Mandarin, Taiwanese and English songs.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ECONOMY CANNOT BE DEPENDENT ON CHINA: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Saturday it is bad that Taiwan's economy is growing over-dependent on China and that management of Taiwan's investment in China cannot be neglected, as China is trying to annex Taiwan.
According to Chen, China is not a "normal" country and wants to annex Taiwan, so Taiwan has to be careful when making contacts with China.

"It is not that we cannot go to China to do business, but we have to manage the political and commercial risks. Be it proactive management, effective management, or risk management, we cannot neglect it," he said.
Chen made the remarks at a ceremony marking the third anniversary of the Ketagalan Institute, which Chen established in 2003 to nurture the country's future leaders.

He said people should not interpret his New Year's Day message of "active management, effective opening" as simply tightening cross-strait economic policies, and that the policies are not simply a black-and-white issue of opening up or restricting.

"If some people must go to China to do business, then we should come up with management methods that do not pose a threat to national security and do not hurt the country's overall interests, " he said. He also urged the public to offer feasible ideas to the government for reference.

Chen said there is a "blind spot" in some people's thinking for Taiwan's economic growth as they feel China is the ultimate and only solution for Taiwan's economy and consider it vital for Taiwan to consent to direct cross-strait links and do business in China.

He said Taiwan must insist on its economic independence and added that China is not the only option. He said that according to a recent U.S. congressional investigation, Taiwan has invested US$280 billion in China, 50 percent of the US$560 billion the whole world has invested in China.

"Isn't this a bit too much? Isn't this over the top?" Chen asked. "Taiwan's economy being so heavily dependent on China is not a good thing. It is risky and worrying. China wants to annex us and we are dependent on it for our economy. Are we not aware that we are leaning toward China too much?," he asked.

DOC.HEADLINE: PARLACEN PRESIDENT TO VISIT TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Central American Parliament (Parlacen) President Julio Palacios is scheduled to lead a delegation that will arrive in Taiwan April 3, Ministry of Foreign Affairs officials said Saturday.
Members of the delegation include vice presidents Leopoldo Navarro from Nicaragua, Nelson Licona from Honduras, Julio Cesar Grijalva from El Salvador and Miriam Cabral from the Dominican Republic.

During their five-day stay in Taiwan, President Chen Shui-bian will confer the Order of Brilliant Star with Special Grand Cordon on Palacios, who is from Panama, while Palacios will decorate Vice President Annette Lu, the officials said.

The Central American delegates will call on Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng, Vice Premier Tsai Ing-wen and Minister of Foreign Affairs Huang Chih-fang. They will also visit the Peitou garbage incinerator in Taipei City, the Taipei World Trade Center, Taipei 101 -- the world's tallest building, the National Palace Museum and the Taroko National Park.

The Parlacen is a regional organization established in 1991 with its member nations including Guatemala, El Salvador, Honduras, Nicaragua, Panama and the Dominican Republic. The Republic of China became a permanent observer of the Parlacen in 1999 due to its close diplomatic relations with many countries in Central America.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT URGES THE PUBLIC TO PREPARE FOR BIRD FLU

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian urged the public to be prepared and to cooperate with the government in the event of a bird flu outbreak.
He pointed out that experts have said bird flu will definitely break out and that it is just a matter of time.

"We cannot be negligent. That is why I have raised the response programs to bird flu to national security level. The government is mobilizing every department and agency and we dare not become lax. I hope the public will work with the government, " he said.
Chen made the remarks during the anniversary of the opening of the Ketagalan Institute, which Chen established in 2003 to nurture the country's future leaders.

Chen predicted that if bird flu should break out, it will affect Taiwan 10 times worse than the SARS outbreaks of 2003. He said that in 1918, when the world had its first major bird flu pandemic in which the virus made the jump from animals to humans, 25,000 Taiwanese people died out of the whole population of 3 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT DREAMS FOR TAIWAN AS NORMAL AND GREAT COUNTRY

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Saturday that he has a dream to turn Taiwan into a normal and great country and that he believes democracy will defeat the authoritarian regime in China.

"I have a dream... of insisting on turning Taiwan into a normal, complete, developed, beautiful and great country. This is also a common dream shared by everyone. It is not impossible for Taiwan to become such a country," he said.
Chen said that although many people have made sacrifices and paid a high price for Taiwan's democracy, "we did not withdraw and we did not give up."
Chen made the remarks during the anniversary of the opening of the Ketagalan Institute, which Chen established in 2003 to nurture the country's future leaders.

Chen said Taiwan is not against China or its people, but against the Communist Party of China's authoritarian regime. He added that the regime oppresses democracy, freedom, human rights, and peace, and is the greatest threat to peace and stability in the Taiwan Strait and the Asia-Pacific region.
"I believe democracy can defeat authoritarianism and we need to have faith, no matter what happens," he said.
He further said that the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) should focus on China, which is Taiwan's real opponent.

He said the Taiwanese people need to be aware of China's hostility and he also praised the Taiwanese people for carrying out the spirit of "sons of Taiwan" to keep pressing forward and not withdrawing from challenges. Chen was described by his supporters as a "son of Taiwan" when he was first elected President.

"I am not competing with KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou and the DPP is not competing with the KMT. Our opponent is on the other side of the Taiwan Strait -- we are competing with Chinese President Hu Jintao and the Communist Party of China, " he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOST PEOPLE NOT SATISFIED WITH SOCIAL ORDER: INPR SURVEY

TEXT.P: Most of the respondents to a recent survey carried out by the non-governmental Institute for National Policy Research (INPR) are dissatisfied with the country's social order, while a major portion expressed pessimism over a government promise in March to improve law and order within six months, according to the poll results released Saturday.
The survey was conducted March 26-27 through telephone interviews and gathered 1,027 valid samples with a margin of error of 3 percent.
The results show that 80.98 percent of the respondents expressed dissatisfaction with the current social order, with just 15.89 percent describing themselves as satisfied.
Some 80 percent said they acquire information about the country's crime situation from newspapers and television.

According to the survey results, "attempted fraud" was the most serious public order problem, with 79.94 percent of the respondents saying they had been accosted by scammers in the past month. Around 28.23 percent had been victims of theft, while 13.51 percent had been robbed in the past month.

Asked about their feelings about the seriousness of the social order problems, 83.79 percent said the biggest problem threatening social order is that of debt collection by violence, followed by illegal drugs, fake diet products, kidnapping and illegal firearms.
Most of the respondents suggested the drug problem be the top priority to be dealt with, according to the survey.

Asked about the performance of the police, more than half of those polled said police officers are too weak to enforce the law, while 56.54 percent said the willingness of the police to take bribes is the most serious problem in the police force.

DOC.HEADLINE: CIVIC GROUP SETS UP CHILD SAFETY HOTLINE

TEXT.P: The Jing Chuan Child Safety Foundation established Saturday an 0800580515 hotline for the public to report child abuse and other cases that jeopardize the safety of children.
Foundation officials noted that negligence was responsible for as high as 99 percent of child injury incidents in 2005.
As 59 percent of the child injury cases occurred at home, the officials noted that allowing children to stay home alone can easily lead to accidents.
First among the top-10 news stories involving child safety last year compiled by the foundation was the death of a three-year-old boy who was tattooed and tortured by his mother's friend.

Other news items on the list include the death of a four-year-old girl who was abused by her drunken father; the death of a five-year-old girl who fell from her apartment when her mother was out; a fire triggered by three children playing with fire while home alone; the beating up of a boy by his father in public; the injury of a two-year-old child by an automatic car window; and the drowning of a one-year-old child who fell into a bucket.

Rounding out the list are the death of a primary school child who fell off a fence; the suffocation of a three-year-old boy left unattended in a kindergarten bus; and the death of a two-year-old girl who was hit by her father while reversing his car.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEPARTURE OF INDIVIDUAL MEMBERS WILL NOT KILL DPP: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Saturday that every party member is indispensable to the party, yet no-one is so great that the party will die without him, referring to ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Legislator Lin Wuei-chou, who resigned his party membership earlier this week.
Lin announced his party resignation Thursday, accusing all Taiwan's political parties of being all show with no substance.

Chen said that a party member should not take the passive approach and leave the party when he is disappointed, but should instead take part in party affairs to change, transform and elevate the party,

"Everyone is important, and every member is indispensable for every party. Yet no-one, including myself, is important enough to kill off the party should he leave. If I leave the party, it is me who dies, but the DPP will not die. The DPP will carry on, " Chen said.
Chen made the remarks during a ceremony marking the third founding anniversary of the Ketagalan Institute, a school Chen established in 2003 to nurture the country's future leaders.

Chen said democracy is not without problems, but is still the best political system in the world. He said even communist authoritarian regimes have parties, and all democratic countries have parties. According to Chen, having political parties signifies taking responsibility.
"Let us be frontline soldiers for Taiwan's democracy, and gardeners for Taiwan's political parties," Chen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: STRIKING THAI WORKERS RETURN TO WORK

TEXT.P: Thai workers hired by the Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp. (KRTC) returned to work Saturday after going on strike the previous day complaining about poor quality food, increased medical insurance payments and various other problems.

The return to work of the 600 striking laborers living in a dormitory in Kangshan, Kaohsiung County, followed a mediation session with KRTC officials, who also agreed to treat the Thai workers' absence from work as a day off instead of docking their pay.

But the officials also warned them that if they went on strike again or failed to report to work for three consecutive days, they would be fired and repatriated according to the terms of their contracts.
Other KRTC Thai workers living in two dormitories in different locations did not take part in the strike.
Thai workers get seven days off per month and receive a basic salary of NT$15,840 (US$486), with additional overtime pay.

Thai workers also rioted last August in protest against what they called harsh treatment at the hands of a management firm commissioned by the KRTC. the riot led to a probe that revealed a suspected network of graft and corruption that implicated several high-ranking officials, including a former close aide of President Chen Shui-bian.
The KRTC has since taken over the management of its more-than 1,700 Thai laborers and has improved their living conditions considerably.
The meals have also been improved, with the Thai laborers being allowed to form a committee to map out their weekly menus.

DOC.HEADLINE: FARMERS', FISHERMEN'S COOPERATIVES OVERDUE LOAN RATIO FALLS TO 10.58%

TEXT.P: The average overdue loan ratio of the 278 credit cooperatives run by farmers' and fishermen's associations nationwide declined to 10.58 percent in February, down 0.08 percentage points over the previous month, according to tallies released Saturday by the Council of Agriculture (COA).

As of the end of February, the combined assets of the credit cooperatives totalled NT$1.5873 trillion, an increase of NT$1.8 billion compared with the previous month. The net assets value amounted to NT$83.3 billion, up NT$600 million over the previous month, while loans receivable amounted to NT$605.9 billion, up NT$2 billion over the previous month.
The overdue loans amounted to NT$64.1 billion as of the end of February, down NT$300 million over the previous month.

COA officials said the overdue loan ratio in the sector has fallen from a high of 19.33 percent in 2001 thanks to the government's efforts to write off the overdue loans of domestic banking institutions.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER REITERATES RESOLVE TO IMPROVE LAW AND ORDER

TEXT.P: Taipei, April 1 (CAN) Premier Su Tseng-chang reiterated Saturday his resolve to improve social order and urged cooperation between central and local governments to achieve this end.
The premier made the call on the sidelines of a ceremony to honor police officers who had just helped crack a heist in Taipei County.

Su reaffirmed his determination in the face of the latest poll results that show 40 percent of the respondents are satisfied with his performance against 36 percent who are dissatisfied, and that 33 percent are confident about his pledge to improve law and order against 60 percent who have no confidence.

Su, a two-time Taipei county magistrate, cited his own experience in his first term when he said that the dirty and chaotic situation of one county thoroughfare was improved within three months, with 12 major roads improved in a year. With resolve, all differences can be overcome, Su said, adding that he had to fire an environmental protection chief at the time.

Su, who has put his political career on the line by vowing to quit premiership if social order is not significantly improved within six months, said that "it is the shame of a government if it cannot let its people live and work in a safe environment."

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP FACTIONS AGREE WITH PRESIDENT'S CALL TO HELP PARTY

TEXT.P: Most ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) factions agreed Saturday with President Chen Shui-bian's call earlier in the day for party members to serve as "gardeners of the party."
Chen issued the call at a ceremony to mark the third anniversary of the opening of the Ketagalan Institute, which Chen established in 2003 to nurture the country's future leaders.

Chen said democracy is "representative politics " and "party politics." In a political party, no-one is dispensable, but neither is anyone so great that his withdrawal from the party would cause it to collapse.
He urged DPP members to serve as "frontline soldiers" defending Taiwan's democracy, while trying to regain their confidence in the party.

Political observers regarded the remarks as Chen's response to Legislator Lin Wei-chou, who quit the DPP on Thursday, leaving the DPP as only the second-largest party in the legislature with 87 seats compared to the opposition Kuomintang's 88.

Echoing Chen's call, Legislator Lee Wen-chung of the DPP's New Tide Faction suggested that those who are disappointed with the party make efforts to promote party reforms. Leaving the party ranks to be an independent will not help anything, he said.

However, Lee also suggested that Chen, who is a former chairman of the DPP, should conduct some self-examination and heart-searching now that so many people doubt the party's ability to run the country.
Meanwhile, Legislator Hsu Kuo-yung of the DPP's Welfare State Alliance said that DPP Chairman Yu Shyi-kun has decided to hold a party meeting in April to discuss party reforms.
There are reforms ongoing in the party, Hsu said, criticizing Lin for quitting without first contributing to the reforms.

DOC.HEADLINE: SMALLER CLASSES COULD RESOLVE TEACHER OVER-SUPPLY PROBLEM: LEGISLATOR

TEXT.P: A legislator of the main opposition Kuomintang said Saturday that the Ministry of Education (MOE) should promote smaller classes in elementary and junior high schools to deal with the problem of an over-supply of teachers.
Lee Ching-an made the remark at a news conference in Taipei on how to cope with the problem. Also on hand was Wu Chung-tai, managing director of the National Teachers' Association.
According to Lee, the problem is the result of a gradually decreasing number of students every year, due to Taiwan's declining birth rate.

Quoting MOE tallies, Lee said that in 2005, the number of licensed teachers reached more than 18,000 but only some 2,000 of them, or 10.9 percent, were hired. The 2005 figures were far lower than the 37.7 percent in 1994 and the 78.9 percent in 1997.

DOC.HEADLINE: COAST GUARD ARRESTS 12 CHINESE ATTEMPTING TO ENTER TAIWAN ILLEGALLY

TEXT.P: Coast guard officers arrested 12 illegal Chinese immigrants on a fishing vessel Saturday off the coast of Fangyun in Changhua County, central Taiwan.

The Coast Guard Administration (CGA) had deployed special patrols around northern Taiwan over the past few days after receiving tipoffs that a human smuggling ring was preparing to ship illegal Chinese immigrants into Taiwan.
Early Saturday morning, a patrol boat spotted the Tsai Ting Lai -- a plastic raft registered in the southern county of Chiayi -- five nautical miles off the coast, and ordered it to stop.
However, the raft sped up to try to escape and after a 15-minute chase, the patrol boat stopped and boarded the raft, on which CGA personnel discovered the illegal immigrants -- 11 men and one woman.
The raft was then towed to Hsinchu, where the Chinese, who had paid 30,000 yuan each for the trip to Taiwan, were taken to Taoyuan for interrogation.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WANTS TO SIGN FTA WITH U.S. BY NEXT JUNE: DEPUTY ENVOY
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, March 31 (CNA) (By Wennie Chi and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan looks forward to signing a free trade agreement (FTA) with the United States before the expiration of the U.S. Trade Promotion Authority (TPA) next June, Taiwan's deputy representative in Washington, D.C. said Friday.

Speaking at a seminar on Capitol Hill, Stanley Kao said a Taiwan-U.S. FTA would bring enormous benefits to both countries and that Taiwan is always ready to negotiate relevant terms with the United States.

Hopefully, Kao said, an FTA can be fleshed out before the TPA -- an act that authorizes the U.S. administration to sign bilateral and multilateral agreements with foreign governments to promote free trade without prior congressional approval -- expires in June 2007.
It marked the first time that Taiwan has ever explicitly spelled out a desired timetable for signing an FTA with the United States.

The seminar was organized by the Association on Third World Affairs, a non-governmental organization, to discuss issues regarding free and fair trade. Participants at the seminar included Angelos Pangratis, European Union deputy ambassador to the U.S., Roberto Abdenur, Brazilian ambassador to the U.S., and diplomatic mission chiefs of many other countries stationed in Washington.

Emphasizing that an FTA is critical to both sides, Kao said the United States would see a more-than 100 percent growth in its auto, rice, fish and other foodstuff exports to Taiwan after the signing of such an accord.

On the whole, Kao said, the annual U.S. exports to Taiwan would post an estimated 16 percent growth from the present level should an FTA take effect. In dollar terms, he added, annual U.S. exports to Taiwan would increase by US$6.6 billion.

For Taiwan, Kao said, the FTA would have a "locomotive effect" that might prompt other countries to follow suit. Because of China's diplomatic embargo against Taiwan, Kao went on, Taiwan is facing the threat of being marginalized in the Asia-Pacific region and having a hard time forging bilateral ties with major countries around the world.

Describing the signing of FTAs with major countries around the world as being imperative to sustain Taiwan's competitiveness, Kao said Taiwan is well-prepared for FTA talks with the United States at any time.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CANDIDATE WINS TAITUNG COUNTY MAGISTRATE BY-ELECTION

TEXT.P: Kuang Li-Chen, the main opposition Kuomintang's (KMT's) candidate and ex-wife of former Taitung County Magistrate Wu Chun-li, won the Taitung county magistrate by-election Saturday.
Kuang, who was pitted against three independent candidates, expressed her appreciation to her supporters and said she will do her best to live up to their expectations.
She also pledged to develop Taitung into a "tourism and cultural county."
Kuang won 42,578 votes, far ahead of her nearest rival, who managed to garner only 19,228 ballots.
The result dealt a further blow to the beleaguered Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , which lost a legislative by-election in Chiayi County last month.
A DPP official expressed "regret and disappointment" over the result, saying that it is "the re-election of the corrupt Wu." The KMT now controls 15 out of Taiwan's 23 cities and counties.

Tsai Huang-liang, director of the DPP's Department of Culture and Information Affairs, said KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou, who campaigned for Kuang, should be held responsible for the failure of an "anti- corruption" campaign in the by-election.
The by-election was made necessary after Wu tendered his resignation to the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) in January.

Wu won the Dec. 3 magistrate election but was barred from taking office because he had been sentenced to a jail term in a second court trial on corruption charges. Wu appealed the MOI's decision to the Taipei Administrative Court but was turned down.

Wu, who was warned by the MOI that he could not serve in the post even if elected during his campaigning prior to the Dec. 3 election, tried to keep his post at first by appointing Kuang as his deputy. He even divorced Kuang to sidestep the restriction against a magistrate selecting a relative or spouse as deputy.
The Taitung county government was turned into a farce at one point, with dual leaders -- Kuang and another deputy sent by the MOI -- serving the vacancy left by Wu.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN PROVIDES MEDICAL ASSISTANCE TO SWAZILAND

TEXT.P: A government-funded organization reported Saturday that it has cooperated with the Chunghua Christian Hospital in central Taiwan to send a medical team to tour Swaziland in southern Africa.
The International Cooperation and Development Fund (ICDF) said that the nine-person team was led by Wei Chih-tao, superintendent of the Chunghua Christian Hospital.

The team has since March 26 toured remote villages in Swaziland where medical supplies are scarce, carrying with them vitamins, toothpaste and toothbrushes, as well as medical equipment, the ICDF officials said.
The officials said they also collected more than 2,000 second-hand toys through the Internet for distribution to the children of the villages. The team will remain in Swaziland until April 5.

DOC.HEADLINE: STRONG QUAKE JOLTS SOUTHEASTERN TAIWAN, CAUSES MINOR DAMAGE

TEXT.P: A strong earthquake rocked southeastern Taiwan Saturday evening, shaking buildings but no serious damage or injuries being immediately reported.

The magnitude-6.4 earthquake, which struck around 6 p.m., was centered 5.5 kilometers east of Peinan, Taitung County, at a depth of 10 kilometers, the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) said. An aftershock measuring 4.7 on the Richter scale hit the same area shortly afterward, the bureau added.

The quake caused cracks to some houses and gas leaks in the Taitung area. Some motorcyclists sustained minor injuries as their vehicles crashed because of the tremor. Many panicked people ran out their houses and were reluctant to enter their homes even nearly an hour after the shock. some phone lines were cut off in eastern Taiwan.
The earthquake was felt in most of the island because it was centered relatively close to the surface, CWB officials said.

Earthquakes occurred frequently in Taiwan, which lies on a seismically active stretch of the Pacific basin. One of Taiwan's worst-recorded quakes occurred Sept. 21, 1999. The 9-21 temblor, measuring 7.3 on the Richter scale, killed more than 2,400 people and left tens of thousands homeless.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGENDARY ARTIST MAX LIU REMEMBERED IN EXHIBITION AND ANIMATION

TEXT.P: For fine art lovers in Taiwan, Max Liu never left. A memorial exhibition and a underway animation are trying to make the legacy of the famous Taiwanese painter who passed away four years ago live on for many more years to come.

A total of 30 never-before-seen color paintings are being displayed in a month-long memorial exhibition starting Saturday in Capital Art Center (CAC) to commemorate Max Liu, one of the most celebrated painters in Taiwan modern art.

An animation which features an adventure of Liu and animal figures, his favorite painting theme, are also under way. The film that reflects Liu's love of animal and adventure is due to be released in 2008.

"As passionate as he has always been for painting, Liu was even more dedicated to giving lectures. He said that a painting can only be owned by one person, but a good speech can make much more impact to people, " CAC President York Hsiao recollected in the opening ceremony.
"He has never been an artist who looks for making money from his works. What he cares is what art can do and impact people's life, " said Hsiao.
Lin Ding-san, Liu's student at Chung-yuan Christian University and an architect, decided to remember his mentor in a different way, launching an animation project in 2002.

"It's a story that talks about Mr. Liu and all these animals he painted go on to a journey and save an island from environmental crisis. This is a best way to remember him and carry on his legacy to the next generation, " Lin said.

Max Liu (1912-2002) was an engineer throughout the first 38 years of his life. Picking up his paint and brush at 39 years-old, Liu's career as an artist boomed in the next 50 years. An adventurous and open-minded man, Liu spent a large part of the 1970s, 1980s and 1990s traveling around the world, learning cultures and studying the art.
Later in his life, Liu also devoted himself in environmental protection and many charity programs.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLL: MOST PEOPLE NOT OPTIMISTIC ABOUT PREMIER'S PLEDGE TO FIGHT CRIME

TEXT.P: The results of a poll released Saturday show that 60 percent of the respondents are not optimistic about a pledge made by Premier Su Tseng-chang to improve social order within six months, although Su received the highest approval rating among high-ranking government officials.

"The results show that people are willing to give Su time to achieve his pledge, but most people realize that it will be hard to reduce crime in six months, " Tamkang University Professor Shih Cheng-feng said of the poll, which was conducted by the Institute of Public Opinion of Shih Hsin University.
Su declared March 15 that he will step down and quit politics for good if the people do not feel Taiwan's social order has improved within the next six months.

The poll results show that Su received a 40 percent approval rating, which is higher than Cabinet's 30 percent and President Chen Shui-bian's 19 percent. However, only 33 percent of the respondents expressed confidence that Su will be successful in reducing crime in six months.

Su will face a major challenge as government officials "above and under him" -- the president and the Cabinet -- both have lower approval ratings than him, said Yu Chi-lik, a professor at Shih Hsin University.
Guns and drugs were voted by respondents as the top priority in the crime crackdown. Fraud came in second, while safety of women and children ranked third.
The poll also found that the top three ministries with the highest approval ratings are the Consumer Protection Commission, the Environmental Protection Administration and the Fair Trade Commission.
A total of 1,099 valid samples were collected from March 26-28 in the telephone poll, which had a margin of error of 2.96 percentage points.

DOC.HEADLINE: EUROPEAN ACADEMICS FORM NEW ASSOCIATION ON TAIWAN STUDY
DOC.DATELINE: Paris, March 31 (CNA) (By Lo Yuan-shaw and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Academics from major European countries, including Britain, Germany, Finland, Sweden, France and the Netherlands, have formed anew association dedicated to promoting research on subjects related to Taiwan.
Association members met in Paris Thursday and Friday to discuss the new organization's charter, membership qualifications and operational rules.
The decision to form the new association was inspired by a Taiwan study project at the University of London's School of Oriental and African Studies (SOAS).
It was decided at the inaugural meeting that the association will hold its second meeting in Stockholm, Sweden next year.

During the two-day Paris meeting, the participants also presented and discussed 32 papers on a broad range of Taiwan-related subjects in political, economic, social, cultural, literary, folk music and anthropological fields.

The papers were selected from more than 140 entries, said Chang Mao-kuei, a researcher at Taiwan's most prestigious academic body Academia Sinica and a sociology professor at National Taiwan University who traveled to Paris to attend the seminar.
Chang said the themes and viewpoints presented in all those papers were relevant, updated and insightful. Chang said he was impressed by European scholars' emphasis on research quality.

During the seminar, the participants also exchanged information on Taiwan-related study projects in major European countries. In Britain, the SOAS launched its Taiwan study project in 2000 and the school now offers master's study program. The London School of Economics and Political Science has offered Taiwan culture courses for five years.

In France, there has been an interdisciplinary research team composed of academics from major French universities. The team now focuses its research on two directions -- legacy/memory as well as Taiwan's localization and globalization. There is also a newly launched Taiwan study project at University Lyon. Germany's Bochum University and Ruhr University have installed Taiwan research projects specializing in literary and cultural studies.

DOC.HEADLINE: 37 INDIVIDUALS SUSTAIN MILD INJURIES IN TAITUNG EARTHQUAKE

TEXT.P: Thirty-seven people were mildly injured when a strong earthquake jolted Taitung in southeastern Taiwan Saturday evening, officials at a central emergency response center said.

Only one injury occurred in the southern port city of Kaohsiung where a wall at an unused military barracks collapsed, while all the other injured people resided in Taitung. Only one of the injured was hospitalized for treatment of bone fractures.

The magnitude-6.4 earthquake, which struck at 6: 02 p.m., was centered 5.5 kilometers east of Peinan, Taitung County, at a depth of 10 kilometers, the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) said. A total of 36 aftershocks were recorded in the Taitung area within four hours after the first earthquake. Eight of the aftershocks, including one measuring 4.8 on the Richter scale, were felt in the Taitung region.

The central government immediately set up an emergency response center to assist the Taitung County Government in post-quake rehabilitation work. The center was staffed by officials from the Ministry of Economic Affairs, the Ministry of the Interior's airborne fire squadron, the Department of Health and the Ministry of Transportation and Communications.
The quake caused cracks to some houses and 10 gas leaks were reported in the Taitung area. Some motorcyclists sustained minor injuries as their vehicles crashed because of the tremor.

A total of 7,200 households suffered a blackout, but power supply was resumed eight minutes after the earthquake. Many panicked people ran out their houses and were reluctant to enter their homes even nearly an hour after the shock.
The earthquake was felt in most of the island because it was centered relatively close to the surface, CWB officials said.

Earthquakes occurred frequently in Taiwan, which lies on a seismically active stretch of the Pacific basin. One of Taiwan's worst-recorded quakes occurred Sept. 21, 1999. The 9-21 temblor, measuring 7.3 on the Richter scale, killed more than 2,400 people and left tens of thousands homeless.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR APRIL 2 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Sunday, April 2:
10:00, Premier Su Tseng-chang will tell stories for children at a gathering at Shuanglien Church in Taipei.
10:30, Presidential Office Secretary-General Tan Sun Chen will attend a locally grown farm produce promotion activity at the Presidential Office plaza.
10:30, Government Information Office Minister Cheng Wen-tsang will attend a CTS general manager changeover ceremony.
10:30, PFP Legislator Chang Hsien-yao will leave for Shanghai for a visit.
14:00, Vice President Annette Lu will attend a seminar on Taiwan-China relations to be held National Chunghsing University in Taichung.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, April 2, or the fifth day of the third month of the Year of the Dog according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
742: Charlemagne, King of the Franks and founder of the first empire in Western Europe after the fall of Rome, is born. His court at Aix-le-Chapelle becomes the center of the Carolingian Renaissance.
1792: The first silver dollar of the new U.S. currency is struck in Philadelphia by the Bank of the United States.
1801: Britain's Admiral Horatio Nelson, aboard the HMS Elephant, sinks the pro-French Danish fleet off its home port of Copenhagen.
1805: Hans Christian Andersen, the Danish writer of fairy tales including "The Emperor's New Clothes" and "The Ugly Duckling," is born.
1840: Emile Zola, the French realist novelist whose books include "Therese Raquin," "Nana," "Germinal," and " La Terre," is born.
1872: Samuel Finley Breese Morse, the American painter and inventor who refined and patented the telegraph and developed the telegraphic code that bears his name, dies at the age of 81.
1902: The first U.S. movie theater is opened in Los Angeles, California.
1912: The provisional Senate of the Republic of China resolves to move the seat of the government to Beijing.
1917: Thomas Woodrow Wilson, the 28th president of the United States and the winner of the 1919 Nobel Peace Prize, summons a special session of Congress to declare war on Germany. At the Paris Peace Conference in 1919, he included the establishment of the League of Nations in the Treaty of Versailles.
1922: Soviet leader Nikolai Lenin appoints Joseph Stalin as general secretary of the Communist Party.
1938: The Spanish Civil War ends with General Franco's fascists as the victors.
1947: The United Nations Security Council votes to appoint the United States as the trustee for Pacific Islands formerly held by the Japanese.
1951: General Dwight Eisenhower assumes command of all allied armies in Europe and the Western Mediterranean area.
1953: Karl L. Rankin becomes American ambassador to the ROC.
1954: The ROC Legislative Yuan passes the Extradition Law.
1965: The ROC government declares that "protocols" signed recently by the Beijing regime with Afghanistan are illegal and not binding on China.
1971: Garuda Indonesia Airlines makes its maiden flight to Taipei.
1973: Brig. Gen. Majed Al Haj Hassan and two other members of a Jordanian military goodwill mission arrive in Taipei for a 10-day visit.
1974: Georges Pompidou, president of France, dies at the age of 62.
1974: Madame Gloria de Lopez Arellana, the first lady of Honduras, arrives in Taipei for a six-day visit.
1981: ROC President Chiang Ching-kuo is re-elected chairman of the Kuomintang by acclamation at the 12th National Congress in Taipei.
1982: Argentine military forces invade the British Falkland Islands.
1983: Chang Da-chien, a noted Chinese painter, dies in Taipei at the age of 85.
1991: Diego Maradona, star of Napoli soccer team, flies home to Argentina hours before being banned from every sporting activity in Italy after failing a dope test.
1996: Lech Walesa, Poland's first post-war democratic president, resumes his old job as an electrician at the Gdansk shipyard.
1997: U.S. House of Representatives Speaker Newt Gingrich meets with ROC President Lee Teng-hui during a four-hour visit to Taipei. Gingrich praises Taiwan's political progress and economic achievements.
1997: The Statute Governing Relations with Hong Kong and Macau is promulgated by President Lee Teng-hui to go partially into effect on July 1, 1997 for Hong Kong, and in 1999 for Macau.
2000: ROC President-elect Chen Shui-bian denies that he sent an American scientist as special envoy to mainalnd China to discuss cross-strait relations with Beijing leaders.
2001: Exiled Tibetan spiritual leader the Dalai Lama says in Taipei that he wants to pursue "a genuine autonomy" for Tibet, not independence. He makes the remarks while delivering a speech at the Legislative Yuan.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A wise man is dignified, but not proud. A fool is proud, but not dignified."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Sunday are as follows:
The China Times: Finance Ministry requests NT$4.1 billion from Taipei County government for not using state-own estate properly.
The United Daily News: Chiefs of urban or rural townships give subordinates promotions generously
The Liberty Times: Economical criminal Liang Poh-hsiun returns from overseas exile to serve jail terms.
The Taiwan Daily: Democratic Progressive Party's leading rival is China.
The Central Daily News: KMT candidate wins by-election of Taitung county chief.
The China Post: Strong quake jolts eastern Taiwan, 42 people injured.
The Taipei Times: Chen urges DPP to work together

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Manila Bulletin: WB plans to resume program lending to RP
The World Bank said plans to resume program loans to the Philippines, mostly aimed at funding reforms in specific sectors, due to Manila's improved fiscal position.
The Philippine Daily Inquirer: Meralco monopoly over
IT'S now open season in the power sector. Under pressure to lower electricity rates, the Manila Electric Co. has finally agreed to allow other power producers to supply the electricity requirements of its large industrial and commercial customers who consume at least 1 megawatt (MW) a month.
The Philippine Star: 'GMA to step down in 2010 with or without Cha-cha'
President Arroyo will step down at the end of her term in 2010 whether or not her initiative to amend the Constitution succeeds, administration officials said yesterday.
The Manila Times: Palace adds fuel to Cha-cha train
MALACANANG on Saturday continued to build up momentum for the" Charter-change train, "saying politicians can't stop constitutional amendments, because it is the people clamoring for change.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Japan Times: Man says he threw boy from 15th floor
A 41-year-old man told police Saturday he threw a 9-year-old boy to his death from the 15th floor of a condominium in Kawasaki on March 20.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Los Angeles Times: Migrant Issue Divides GOP.
As massive pro-immigrant rallies have grabbed center stage in Southern California, the state's congressional delegation remains sharply divided over what to do about illegal immigration, with many Republicans--including those from districts with substantial Latino populations--holding firm in support of a get-tough approach.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Attacking Iran May Trigger Terrorism; Experts Wary of Military Action Over Nuclear Program.
As tensions increase between the United States and Iran, U.S.intelligence and terrorism experts say they believe Iran would respond to military strikes on its nuclear sites by deploying its intelligence operatives and Hezbollah teams to carry out terrorist attacks worldwide.

DOC.HEADLINE: IRISH 'GAELFORCE DANCE' TO PERFORM APRIL 21-22

TEXT.P: "Gaelforce Dance," an Irish tap dance group, is to perform at the Taipei International Convention Center April 21-22, presenting the story of two brothers involved in a plot of passion, tragedy and triumph.
Michael Durkan, producer and director of the dance group, said the dance they will perform in Taiwan is about love, hate, hope and repression and is presented through dance, music, songs and drama.
Gaelforce Dance tells the story of two lovers, Lorcan and Aisling, who are unaware of the forbidden passion that will erupt between them, leading their community into a cauldron of hate.
After its performance in Taipei, the group will continue its Taiwan tour in Chungli, Kaohsiung and Chiayi.

DOC.HEADLINE: ENVIRONMENTALLY FRIENDLY TOMB SWEEPING DAY URGED BY EPA

TEXT.P: The Environmental Protection Agency under the Executive Yuan urged the public Sunday not to burn too much paper "ghost money" or incense, and to set off as few firecrackers as possible while honoring ancestors for the sake of environmental protection.

With the April 4 Tomb Sweeping Day drawing near, the agency said in a press release that burning ghost money which represents cash in the afterworld, incense sticks and firecrackers all cause significant air and noise pollution, not to mention the fire hazards they present.
This problem is especially serious in densely-populated areas and on Tomb Sweeping Day when Taiwanese visit family graves to honor their ancestors or go to temples where funeral urns are stored.

The agency appeals to the public to change the way in which they remember their ancestors by using less ghost money, incense sticks and firecrackers, preferably refraining from their use altogether or calling in garbage collectors to burn them at incinerators.
The agency said local garbage collectors around the island had burned more than 1,500 tons of paper ghost money on behalf of temples and individuals last year.

Noting what matters in worshipping past ancestors is sincerity, the press release encouraged people to burn virtual spirit money, incense and firecrackers online which does not contribute toward air pollution.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHAIRMAN ENCOURAGES YOUTH CORPS MEMBERS

TEXT.P: Main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou encouraged a party youth corps led by Legislator Lin Yi-shih Sunday to possess vision, innovation, passion and action in order to best serve the country and its people.

Ma made the comment at a ceremony marking Lin's inauguration as leader of the KMT youth corps, who was publicly elected among party members last week. Lin will automatically become of the party's vice chairman for a year -- the youngest in KMT history.

Urging KMT youth corps members to put "moral standards" high on their political agenda, Ma said that political figures must insist on having some moral principles when engaging in political activities.
"That is something that political players should never touch from the very beginning, " he noted, adding that "a party without morals will soon step down even if it is in power."

"Political figures must bear in mind the notions of clean politics, administrative efficiency and people's needs right from the first day of their career, " Ma said, pointing out that non-KMT members are also welcome to take part in the youth corps which aims to provide young men and women a platform to develop their abilities through service, sharing and contribution.

Although the KMT is in power in 15 of Taiwan's cities and counties out of a total of 23 and therefore governs 70 percent of the country's population and 68 percent of its territory, Ma called on all party members to be more humble, responsible and prudent when serving the people.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU CHAIRMAN PINS HOPES ON CHEN-MA MEETING

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian and main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou should seek common ground on Taiwan's sustainable development and national identity when they meet for talks Monday, opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union Chairman Su Ching-chiang said Sunday.
Su urged the two men to mend their differences and build a consensus on those two key fronts, and to immediately put their agreements into action for the sake of the national interest.
Chen and Ma should sincerely exchange opinions on issues of major national concern and refrain from merely staging "a show of political idols," he said.
Su expressed the hope that the Chen-Ma meeting would help thaw the political impasse between the "pan green" and "pan blue" camps and said that his party is happy that the two would be meeting.

Ma returned Wednesday from a 10-day, five-city tour of the United States, where he was accorded a high-profile reception and met with senior U.S. officials, including Deputy Secretary of State Robert Zoellick. The KMT chairman has widely been viewed as a strong contender to win in the 2008 presidential elections.
Su criticized Ma as failing to speak up for Taiwan's people against China during his U. S. visit.

Su claimed that Ma "made a fool of himself and the rest of the world" when he said that "one China" refers to the Republic of China and argued that he did not point out that China has more than 800 missiles pointing at Taiwan on his U.S. visit.

Su also asked Ma to provide a clear explanation of his policy in handling the KMT's ill-gotten property assets, arguing the KMT incumbent has been selling off the party's assets at a quicker pace than his predecessor Lien Chan, who is now KMT honorary chairman.
Ma took over the KMT chairmanship in August last year in the party's first direct vote among party members.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN-MA MEETING 'NORMAL IN A DEMOCRACY': PRESIDENTIAL AIDE

TEXT.P: As opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou is scheduled to meet with President Chen Shui-bian Monday, a presidential senior aide said Sunday that such meetings are just a normal part of communications in a democracy.

Tan Sun Chen, Presidential Office secretary -general, said the president was delighted to have the chance to meet with Ma, who claimed he would like to make some "conscientious suggestions" to the president following Ma's high-profile visit to the United States, Taiwan's chief ally.
As to what topics the two leaders would discuss, Tan Sun Chen said he did not know.
"We will all know as the meeting will be made public from beginning to end," he added.
He advised political pundits not to show excessive concern over the meeting as it might "make things look unnatural."

Ma reiterated that he will be making "suggestions, " not "reporting" to the president about his U.S. tour. He also denied that he was seeking "endorsements" from People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong or Legislative Speaker Wang Jin-pyng prior to meeting with the president.
Ma said he was meeting with Soong Sunday because Soong had asked him to get answers to some questions, answers he said he would forward to Soong.
As his meeting with Chen will be broadcast, Ma said there was no need to spend too much time or energy "rehearsing" for it.

Still, some PFP stalwarts reminded Ma that he must use caution when dealing with Chen Shui-bian, whom they said had not acted in good faith in previous meetings with Ma's predecessor Lien Chan and the PFP's Soong.

Lien claimed he felt cheated after Chen's Democratic Progressive Party government announced the suspension of a fourth nuclear power plant's construction in Kungliao, Taipei County, soon after their meeting in 2000, during which Lien urged Chen to demonstrate continuity in government policy.

Soong has filed a slander suit against Chen, accusing him of alleging and failing to show evidence to support the allegation that Soong met with a senior Chinese official in the U.S. in early 2005, in advance of a much-reported meeting between Chen and Soong.
Lu Hsueh-chang, convener of the PFP's legislative caucus, urged Ma to achieve "some results" from the meeting with Chen with regard to cross-Taiwan Strait ties.

For instance, Lu suggested, the president's "five-noes" policy pledging not to change the status quo across the Strait could be implemented through a PFP-initiated bill for maintaining the status quo and promoting cross-strait peace.

Liu Wen-hsiung, a PFP lawmaker, said he expected little to be achieved in the upcoming Ma-Chen meeting as "Ma is not as knowledgeable as Soong," whose meeting with Chen produced nothing but a lawsuit.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA LINKS TO BE DISCUSSED IN PFP LAWMAKER'S SHANGHAI VISIT

TEXT.P: Opposition People First Party (PFP) lawmaker Chang Hsien-yao, who also serves as head of the party's central policy center, led a group of PFP-affiliated Kaohsiung City councilors Sunday on a trip to Shanghai in an effort to open discussions for cross-strait links between the two cities.
Chang and five other Kaohsiung City councilors are scheduled to meet with Shanghai Mayor Han Zheng to observe the host city's infrastructure.
The Taiwanese delegation, which returns on Thursday, will propose a draft bill on direct links between Kaohsiung and Shanghai in order to boost the port city's economy.

Chang said in a previous interview that this visit to Shanghai is an implementation of one of the agreements reached during a meeting in Beijing last year between PFP Chairman James Soong and Chinese President Hu Jintao to step up regular trade and economic exchanges across the Taiwan Strait.
According to Chang, direct transport links between both cities should be implemented in three stages.

First, direct shipping links between ports in Kaohsiung and Yangshan and direct air links between Kaohsiung International Airport and Pudung Airport should be implemented for a trial period of a year.

Second, direct air links should be established between Kaohsiung International Airport and five Chinese airports, and direct shipping services linking Kaohsiung port to five Chinese ports for a year trial; and third, both air and shipping links between Kaohsiung and China should be set up.
Chang also said a referendum must be held during the the year-end Kaohsiung mayoral election in order to determine public opinion on whether to establish air and sea direct links with Shanghai.

However, in reference to Chang's planned trip to Shanghai, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Vice Chairman W.F. Huang said last Friday at a news conference that any political party or private sector group must abide by the Republic of China's laws while engaging in cross-strait activities that require government authorization.

With regard to the PFP group's visit to Shanghai, Huang said that any agreement reached between unauthorized private groups from Taiwan and the Chinese side regarding the Taiwan people's rights or government power are invalid.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER STRESSES CHILDREN'S RIGHT TO LIVE

TEXT.P: "As long as you are alive there is hope, " Premier Su Tseng-chang said while reading a story to a group of children Sunday.

Acting as a teacher at a local Sunday school, the premier urged the country's parents to "live and let live," urging them to "persist to subsist" when faced with hardship and not to take their children's lives in the event they take their own.

Parents should not consider their children as possessions, Su said, adding that children once born are entitled to live, a right which should not be stolen from them by anyone, even their parents, the premier said.

He said the Ministry of the Interior will work together with local governments to offer financial aid to needy families and individuals in hopes that no one will commit suicide simply because they cannot afford to live.

The Sunday school was organized by a local children's rights organization to mark the group's publication of an illustrated book, "Don't Take Me Away, " written to raise public awareness about children's right to live.
The organizers said suicide became one of Taiwan's top ten causes of death last year, and the incidence of parents who kill their children before taking their own lives is widespread in Taiwan.
More than 70 percent of child victims in these cases are under the age of 10 and apparently forced to die along with their parents, the organizers said.
As recently as Sunday, a grandmother in Anting, Tainan county, attempted suicide along with her two grandchildren by burning charcoal in her room.
One of her grandchildren died from asphyxiation, the other who did not suffocate was killed by the grandmother, who cut an artery in his wrist.
The grandmother, who was rescued, said afterward she was tired of living in poverty and with two grandchildren, one of whom was mentally retarded and the other "very intractable."

DOC.HEADLINE: CONVICT WANTED FOR ECONOMIC CRIMES RETURNS TO 'FACE THE LAW'

TEXT.P: A convict who fled the country for three years after the Taiwan High Court sentenced him to one year in prison for illegally taking out loans was taken into custody upon arrival at CKS International Airport from Hong Kong late Sunday night.

News media in Taiwan devoted widespread coverage to the return of Liang Po-hsun because he vowed at a press conference in Shanghai March 27 that when he returned to Taiwan, he would reveal evidence to prove that in 2002, Chen Che-nan, then deputy secretary-general of the Presidential Office, took NT$6 million from him but failed to fulfill a promise to get him off the legal hook.
Chen denied in a statement a week ago that he had ever taken any money from Liang and called Liang's allegation "absurd."

Liang, 50, a former vice chairman of the Bank of Overseas Chinese, was convicted in November 2002 for using his influence to borrow NT$5.3 billion illegally from several branches of the bank through dummy accounts in 1996-97. While applying for a deferred prison sentence in March 2003, he absconded abroad and has remained at large in China, Hong Kong, Japan and South Africa.
He was also sentenced to one year and two months in a separate case for committing forgery in real estate deals while he was chairman of the Hsinchiehchung Construction Co.
Agents from the Bureau of Investigation, who handcuffed Liang and whisked him off from the airport, indicated that Liang will begin serving his prison terms Monday after being questioned.
Liang is also wanted for questioning by the public prosecutors offices in Taipei, Taichung, Changhua and Tainan in relation to 11 alleged offenses.

During his brief encounter with the media at the airport, Liang said he had returned to Taiwan mainly because he wanted to "face the law." He stressed he was not using his return to help any political parties with their election campaigns, nor was he trying to deal a blow to Chen. He added, however, he has "absolutely strong" evidence against Chen.

Prior to the 2004 presidential election, Liang made the same allegation that Chen took NT$6 million from him in two separate checks but failed to help him settle his legal cases as promised. The Taipei Public Prosecutors Office investigating the case questioned several witnesses, including Liang's father and secretary, and closed the case after concluding there was no direct evidence to prove Chen had taken the bribes.
The bureau's agents said they would not rule out the possibility of reopening the case if Liang could produce new, concrete evidence.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP URGES PRESIDENT TO RELEASE POWER TO EXECUTIVE YUAN

TEXT.P: Chang Hsien-yao, lawmaker and head of the opposition People First Party's central policy center, urged the president Sunday to release some of his power to the Executive Yuan and to loosen his control over it.

Chang made the statement at a news conference upon his departure for a visit to Shanghai, in reference to the upcoming meeting between President Chen Shui-bian and Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou.

Chang said he doubted that existing confrontation between ruling and opposition parties could be resolved through just a single meeting. However, he said he expected the president to lend an ear to the people's wishes on reform and to opposition parties' desire that he adopt a milder approach in his policies.

The meeting between Chen and Ma on Monday would be meaningful if the president could release some of his power to the Executive Yuan and loosen his control over it, Chang said. Otherwise, another situation of political unstability will be set off the day after tomorrow, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Kidnaped 18-month-old baby killed.
The 18-month-old baby kidnaped March 2 in Parma city under his parent's eyes was killed two days after his kidnaping, the police said. The body of little Tommasso Onofri was discovered Saturday at an abandoned farm house. Two suspects who confessed the crime were arrested.

DOC.HEADLINE: WHAT TO EXPECT FROM CHEN-MA MEETING?By S.C. ChangCNA Staff Writer

TEXT.P: If history is any guide, not much can be expected from a much-anticipated meeting scheduled for Monday between Taiwan's president and the chairman of its largest opposition party, the Kuomintang (KMT).

In October 2000, then KMT Chairman Lien Chan met with President Chen Shui-bian at the Presidential Office in a gesture to articulate the KMT's concerns about Taiwan. During that public meeting, Lien urged Chen to demonstrate continuity in government policy, including the building of the nation's fourth nuclear power plant.

But soon after the meeting, Chen's Cabinet announced the suspension of the construction project, leaving a befuddled Lien to complain that he had been cheated. Distrust between the nation's "pan-blue alliance" and "pan-green camp" has since been on the rise.

People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong's meetings with Chen, which began Oct. 19, 2000, produced even worse results, ranging from jeers at Soong for "seeking a government office" to Soong's filing a slander suit against Chen, charging him with alleging and failing to produce evidence to support the allegation that Soong met in secret with a senior Chinese official in the U.S. in early 2005.

The last meeting between Chen and Soong, in Feb. 2005, produced a ten-point agreement, none of which has served as a bridge to narrow the gap between ruling and opposition parties. A striking irony was that the meeting was conducted with the all-too-obvious background of two Chinese characters, Cheng Hsin -- roughly translated as "good faith" or "honesty and integrity."

With this backdrop, several scenarios may occur in the meeting between President Chen Shui-bian and Chairman Ma Ying-jeou, who claimed upon returning from a high-profile visit to the U.S. last week that he would make "conscientious suggestions" for the president to "pursue good fortune and avoid disaster" for the country.

In the first scenario, Chen would make all efforts to demonstrate statesmanship, "accepting" Ma's honest suggestions -- at the urging of his U.S. hosts -- about stabilizing cross-Taiwan Strait relations and not giving Taiwan the negative international image of "troublemaker" in the region's strategic affairs.
But as history shows, the meeting may ultimately turn out to be a slap in the face for Ma as Chen may deny he had accepted Ma's "peace promotion" proposals with regard to Taiwan's China policy.
As Ma could not possibly be short-sighted enough not to have learned a lesson from his predecessor Lien Chan and the PFP's James Soong, the first scenario is unlikely to occur Monday.

A second scenario would be Ma going out of his way to "present" to Chen the KMT's best policy proposals, not only about managing cross-strait ties but about managing the economy as well. It is commonly believed the KMT has more know-how about managing the economy than the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).
Again, Ma cannot be so "magnanimous" as to share with his political rival the KMT's "ace card" for winning back power of the government in 2008.

On the practical side, the scheduled meeting may not last long enough to cover "non-essential" topics like the economy and social issues such as health care and education. Therefore, the second scenario is also quite unlikely to happen.

The public is left with a third and most likely scenario: Little will be achieved through the meeting at the Presidential Office, with Chen and Ma greeting each other with seemingly warm handshakes, shoulder patting and all the other standard protocols, with little else substantive beyond that.

The DPP hoped the meeting will mark the beginning of cooperation among Taiwan's political parties. And yet, as distrust between the ruling and opposition remains deep, even Ma himself has publicly said no one should expect much from Monday's meeting.

Ma plans to make "polite" suggestions to Chen; indeed, they are suggestions he already enumerated whilst visiting the U.S. and earlier in Europe -- proposals with which Chen is already quite familiar. Ma might repeat to Chen U.S. warnings against "pushing the envelope" too far by going ahead with a DPP plan to write a new Constitution for Taiwan, which may be perceived as changing the status quo in the Taiwan Strait.

Chen might "humbly" listen to Ma's polite suggestions and honest warnings, without agreeing with Ma on the issues being raised, much less doing anything about them. Instead, Chen will most likely push ahead with his "constitutional re-engineering" project.

Besides, in Taiwan's "color only" politics, a "pan-green" camp leader cannot possibly change his ideological stance to that of the "pan-blues." If he did, he would become the DPP's bete noire, and it would be tantamount to committing political suicide.

So Taiwan will continue to be plagued by a clash of two vastly different visions of its future -- one calling for independence from China, the other trying to make peace with its giant neighbor while seeking possible "eventual unification" with it. Chen and Ma will return to their respective camps, preparing for a duel in 2008 under the battle cry of "let the people decide."

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER DENIES MEDIA ALLEGATION OF PRESIDENT'S DISPLEASURE

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang said Sunday that he and President Chen Shui-bian maintain good communications and that allegations about the president's displeasure with the so-called lack of interaction between the Executive Yuan and the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) are inaccurate, even "too far from the truth."
Su said he had spent a long time speaking on the phone with President Chen yesterday (Saturday).

"I let the president know everything he has to know about what I am doing at the Executive Yuan. I informed him of the Taitung earthquake situation last night so that he didn't have to worry about it," he said.
Su added that he and the president discuss many subjects whenever they meet or by telephone, and that their conversations on important topics can be quite lengthy.
Su said the media reports about the country and the president are often negative and inaccurate, which is unfair and harmful to the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUTHORITIES WARY OF FAKE TIBETAN LAMAS IN TAIWANBy Flor WangCNA staff writer

TEXT.P: The number of fake Tibetan lamas from China applying to enter Taiwan using forged documents is on the rise, prompting the attention of Taiwan's law enforcement and national security authorities.

Police and security authorities suspect that a number of unlawful organizations in Taiwan have been providing assistance to fake Tibetan lamas in entering Taiwan, taking advantage of a loophole in Taiwan's law enforcement.

Although a majority of Tibetan monks in Taiwan are sincerely devoted to preaching and behaving well, many have been arrested on charges of illegal activities related to fraud, human or drug trafficking and sex offenses, government officials said.

Some lamas conceal their true identity as Chinese agents and engage in subversion here by luring influential figures from the political and business sectors, posing a threat to national security, a national security official pointed out.

Tibetan Buddhism is widespread in Taiwan and the government offers handsome incentives for Tibetan lamas to preach here, coinciding with the trend of more Tibetan or Chinese people seeking to enter Taiwan and reside in the country through all possible means.

It was reported that 140 Tibetans were invited by the Mongolian and Tibetan Affairs Commission to visit Taiwan in September 2001 but overstayed their visa, and were allowed by Taiwan's government to reside here on a case-by-case basis.
After the news was leaked, the incidence of Tibetans seeking to enter Taiwan on a doctored Nepalese passport has seen a marked increase.

As of the end of last year, some 300 Tibetan monks or people who had overstayed their entry visa in Taiwan were waiting for amnesty by the government to obtain a resident permit, government statistics showed.

Meanwhile, some overseas ROC representative offices also found that more and more Tibetans and Chinese from western Qinghai province -- under the guise of being Tibetan lamas -- have been attempting to apply for a visa to "preach" in Taiwan by using a counterfeit Nepalese passport, which is easily obtained.

Since Macau, India and Singapore allow visitors from Nepal to enter without a visa, many people from China first get a residence permit in Nepal and then acquire a passport before applying for a visa to enter Taiwan as a lama with ROC outposts in Macau, India and Singapore, Taiwanese diplomats said.
According to the ROC representative office in Singapore, it has received more than 210 such applications since November last year, with some 10 percent found to have been forged.

In an effort to prevent illegal elements from entering Taiwan, the ROC representative office in Singapore has created a standard process for verifying visa applications, requiring applicants to submit certificates issued by temples and recommendation letters by Tibetan Buddhist priests, as well as religious identity documents and oral exams in spoken Tibetan or Nepalese languages.

Despite all these measures, the screening mechanisms have been far from effective, the Taiwanese diplomats said, urging the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, National Police Agency, National Security Bureau and immigration authorities to step up inter-agency communications and set up an inter-ministerial fast response databank.
They also proposed the government follow the example of Hong Kong by denying visa applications by passport holders from countries like Nepal where fake passports are easy to get.

Hong Kong stopped issuing entry visas to Nepalese passport holders in June 2005 for the same reason -- after a noticeable number of Chinese attempting to enter Hong Kong with a counterfeit Nepalese passport were detected, they noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT URGES KMT HEAD TO 'TELL EVERYTHING' ABOUT U.S. VISIT

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu said Sunday she hoped the meeting of the nation's two "most powerful" political leaders Monday would "create a new situation" for Taiwan, but she also urged the opposition leader to "tell the president everything" about his recent visit to the United States.

Addressing a seminar at Taichung's Chung Hsing University, Lu urged Ma to tell President Chen Shui-bian everything about his "meetings behind closed doors" with U.S. officials, from which even Taiwan's top envoy in Washington was barred.

This would be a chance for all people in Taiwan to check Ma's credibility and competency as a presidential candidate for 2008, including his knowledge of the impending crisis between Taiwan and China, she said.
"Was he [Ma] speaking for Taiwan? While abroad, did he show any respect toward the leader of Taiwan? These are democratic practices commonly respected by all here in Taiwan," she said.

She gave an "overall positive" score of Ma's performance during his 10-day visit, urging people not to "look negatively" upon Ma's U.S. tour, during which she said Ma had raised Taiwan's profile internationally.

However, Lu said Ma talked a lot about peace while acting "too cautiously" and failed to promote Taiwan's democratic achievements for fear of offending China and scuttling his possible meetings with U.S. officials.

Meanwhile, the spokesman for the ruling Democratic Progressive Party expressed hope the Chen-Ma meeting would mark the beginning of cooperation among political parties after the two leaders exchanged views on major issues involving the nation's development.

Tsai Huang-lang said the DPP expects the two leaders to create a positive atmosphere for reconciliation and exchanging views on arms purchase, Control Yuan members' nominations and other major issues.

DOC.HEADLINE: GRANDMA KILLS TWO GRANDSONS, SLITS OWN WRIST
DOC.DATELINE: Tainan, southern Taiwan, April 2 (CNA) (By Han Nai-kuo)

TEXT.P: A 55-year-old grandmother killed her two grandsons early Sunday morning before slitting her own wrist in an attempt to commit suicide. She remains in stable condition after emergency workers rushed her to the hospital.
Wu Shu-hui, who previously suffered a minor stroke, had been taking care of her two grandsons, 7 and 8, since her son divorced and went to Keelung to seek employment.

Neighbors said the elder grandson was mentally retarded, and that it was probably stress from living conditions and heavy financial pressures that caused her to decide to end the lives of the two children and her own.

Wu burned charcoal in her bedroom early Sunday morning after her two grandsons went to bed. The younger boy died from carbon monoxide inhalation, but the elder grandson woke up and shook his grandmother, attempting to wake her. Realizing the elder grandson was still alive, she used a knife to stab the boy to death before slitting her own wrist.
