New York Times: Civilians in Iraq Flee Mixed Areas as Killings Rising
Tens of thousands of Iraqis are fleeing from mixed Shiite-Sunni areas, with the killing of Iraqi civilians rising. The nature of the Iraq war has been changing since at least the late autumn, when political friction between Sunni Arabs and Shiite Arabs rose even as American troops began implementing a long-term plan to decrease their street presence. But the killing accelerated after the bombing on Feb. 22 of a revered Shiite shrine, which unleashed a wave of sectarian bloodletting.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO DEVELOP TECHNOLOGY TO PRODUCE ELECTRICITY WITH BIOGAS
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 2 (CNA) (By N.K. Han and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: The government has drawn up a plan to develop technology for producing electricity with biogas by 2008, according to a report by the Council for Economic Planning and Development under the Executive Yuan.

The council said a "bio-economy" will soon develop when biotechnology is employed to explore bio-friendly resources to develop a healthier and sustainable economy, adding that the technology to turn agricultural and animal waste into electricity should take priority in the government's bio-economy program.

Agricultural and animal waste, such as plants, animal manure and food leftovers can be converted into a biogas that is an inflammable mixture of methane, carbon dioxide and other gases -- and used to heat water for generating electricity.

By turning waste into electricity, the council said the technology cleans the environment by disposing of waste while providing the world with renewable energy, a measure that is urgently needed as the world's fossil fuels are being rapidly depleted; let alone greenhouse gases and acid rain created by the consumption of fossil fuels, which pollute the environment.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOG FORCES KINMEN AIRPORT TO CANCEL TAIWAN FLIGHTS

TEXT.P: Heavy fog forced Kinmen's Shangyi Airport to cancel almost all flights to and from Taiwan Sunday, stranding over 1,000 passengers including those from Xiamen, China who planned to return to Taiwan for tomb-sweeping rituals.

The airport was all misty since early morning as visibility was less than 500 m, much worse than the minimum requirement of 1,200 m. The fog did not clear up until 4: 47 p.m., when the visibility improved to 1,500 m.
As most airlines have canceled the day's flights, only 229 passengers were lucky enough to board two flights, one for Taipei and the other for Kaohsiung.
Throughout the day, of the 64 scheduled flights, only four were completed, meaning 94 percents of the flights were canceled.

In Matsu, a Sunday flight to Mawei, Fijian province of China, was launched for the first time, increasing the weekly two-way flights to 12. Currently, one flight each is flown from Matsu and Mawei Monday through Friday.
Lienchiang County Government in Matsu said it hopes to increase another two-way flights for Saturday, and eventually doubling the daily flights to four per day.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, April 3, or the sixth day of the third month of the Year of the Dog according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1859: The Hsiahai Chenghwang Temple, one of the oldest temples in Taiwan, is formally inaugurated in Taipei.
1881: Alcide de Gasperi, the Italian statesman who became prime minister in 1945 and led Italy during its successful post-war reconstruction, is born.
1882: Jesse James, head of the notorious outlaw James Gang and mastermind of countless bank and train robberies, is gunned down by Robert Ford, one of his own gang, at his home in St. Joseph, Missouri.
1897: German composer Johannes Brahms dies in Vienna at the age of 64. His works, which blended classical tradition with the new romantic impulse, include concertos, symphonies, chamber music, and choral compositions.
1898: Henry Luce, the American publisher who founded Time, Life, and Fortune magazines, is born.
1903: Chou Jung, author of "The Revolutionary Army," dies in jail in Shanghai at the age of 21.
1922: Joseph Stalin is appointed general secretary of the Soviet Communist Party.
1930: Helmut Kohl, the German chancellor who stayed in power for a record 16 years until his defeat by Gerhard Schroeder in 1998, is born.
1933: Four Britons in two Westland biplanes make the first flight over the peak of Mount Everest in the Himalayas.
1946: Directed by the Soviet Union, the so-called "Inner Mongolian Autonomy Movement Committee," is established in Chengteh, Jehol Province.
1948: US President Harry Truman signs the Marshall Plan, allocating US$6 billion in aid to 16 European countries to help reconstruction after World War II.
1962: President and Mme. Philbert Tsiranana of the Republic of Madagascar arrive in Taipei for a six-day state visit.
1964: The Dalai Lama establishes a Tibetan office in New York.
1971: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Republic of China issues a statement severing diplomatic relations with the Republic of Cameroon.
1973: The International Federation of Asian and Western Pacific Contractors Association opens its 12th convention in Taipei.
1975: S. K Chow, ROC minister of state, leaves for Riyadh to express the condolences of the Chinese government in the death of King Faisal.
1975: The Free China Relief Association marks its 25th anniversary.
1975: The ROC Control Yuan passes a resolution impeaching Hsu Chi-wei, commissioner of the Department of Education under the Taiwan Provincial Government.
1976: An 11-member Japanese Diet mission including former Prime Minister Nobusuke Kishi, arrives in Taipei to mark the first anniversary of the death of President Chiang Kai-shek.
1976: Dr. Montanaro, Paraguayan minister of the Interior, arrives in Taipei for Chiang's memorial services.
1982: Bueno Aires celebrates the invasion of the Falkland Islands while the United Nations says Argentina must pull out.
1991: Martha Graham, American dancer and choreographer, dies at the age of 97. A central figure in modern dance, she founded the Dance Repertory Theatre in New York City in 1930.
1992: Two weeks after a non-communist parliament is elected, Albanian President Ramiz Alia resigns.
1996: A plane carrying US Commerce Secretary Ron Brown crashes in stormy weather on a hillside outside Dubrovnik, Croatia, killing all 33 aboard.
2000: Kuomintang Secretary-General Lin Fong-cheng says that the KMT has agreed to let Defense Minister Tang Fei serve as President-elect Chen Shui-bian's premier in his "personal capacity."
2001: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian and visiting Liberian President Charles Taylor signed a joint communique Tuesday calling on all nations to resolve international differences through dialogue, negotiations and other peaceful means.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A man of strong, resolute, simple character approaches closely the true moral character."

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP EXPECTS RECONCILIATION AND COOPERATION FROM CHEN-MA MEETING

TEXT.P: Tsai Huang-liang, director of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP) Department of Culture and Information Affairs, said Monday that reconciliation and cooperation are expected from the meeting between President Chen Shui-bian and opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou.
Tsai said the DPP hopes the meeting, set for Monday afternoon, will mark the beginning of cooperation between the ruling and opposition parties.

He also expressed the party's expectation that the meeting will facilitate reconciliation and that the discussion will focus on important issues related to the country's development, including the arms procurement bill, cross-Taiwan Strait relations and national security issues.

DOC.HEADLINE: MND PLANNING TO EXTEND ANNUAL TRAINING PERIOD FOR RESERVE SOLDIERS

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MND) is planning to extend the annual educational training period for reserve soldiers by one day to three-and-a-half days to meet actual needs, MND officials said Monday.

Reporting at the Legislative Yuan on the progress in the separation of the active forces' and reserves forces' systems, which is part of the ongoing reform of the armed forces, the MND officials said that the annual educational training period for reserve soldiers will be increased to three-and-a-half days while that for reserve officers will remain at three-and-a-half days to five days.
Meanwhile, in a planned revision to the Military Service Act, the maximum draft age for reserve service will be lowered from 40 to 35, the officials said.

If this revision is passed and implemented, the number of reserve soldiers will be reduced to some 2.9 million from the current level of 3.4 million, substantially lessening the MND's management burden, the officials claimed.

According to the MND officials, there are currently about 410,000 men listed as the reserve forces, mostly Army infantry officers and soldiers responsible for combat, combat support or logistics support missions in the event of war.

Noting that the weapon systems and related equipment for the reserve forces are not on par with those for active forces, the MND officials said more funds will need to be allotted in the ministry's annual budget toward replacing old weapons and equipment and training reserve soldiers and officers in how to use the new equipment in order to upgrade the reserve forces' preparedness.

More than a quarter of those eligible for the Government's financial goodies package staked their claims on the first day of the sign-up period.
About 600,000 -- or 26 percent -- of the 2.3 million Singaporeans who qualify for the Progress Package signed up on Saturday, said Mr Rymond Lim, Minister in the Prime Minister's Office and Second Minister for Finance and Foreign Affairs yesterday.
The Lianhe Zaobao: Thailand's elections close in peaceful, Thaksin may win more than 50% of the ballots.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT TO PROVIDE EMERGENCY SUBSIDY TO POOR CHILDREN: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang said Monday the government will provide an emergency monthly subsidy of NT$3,000 (US$92) to children in impoverished families.
Premier Su made the remarks while attending an activity related to children protection sponsored by the Ministry of the Interior.

Su said that if a family is listed as impoverished, the MOI will provide each child in the family with a monthly subsidy of NT$3,000 for six months. The government will provide the subsidy for up to one year at most, he added.
It is estimated that 15,000 children will benefit from the program, Su said.

The premier noted that rapid social changes have brought many problems, adding that he felt "saddened" to learn about a spate of cases involving abused children and parents in financial distress taking their own lives as well as their children's.

The MOI will start to screen high-risk families with the aim of preventing such tragic incidents in the future, he said, adding that the ministry is expected to appropriate NT$135 million for the screening.
He also expressed the hope that people will extend their love and care to impoverished families in their community.

Interior Minister Lee Yi-yang said that 30 percent of the funding for the emergency subsidy program for poor children will be provided by local governments, with the central government shouldering the remaining 70 percent. The ministry will also help local governments add more social workers to their staff, Lee said.

Lee said that Taiwan currently has 189 social workers and that he hopes the number can be boosted by 323. He said that it has been tentatively planned that the central government will provide 40 percent of the funds needed to employ the additional social workers, with the local governments shouldering the remaining 60 percent.
He said that as long as the local governments agree, the emergency subsidy program and the plan to hire more social workers can kick off immediately.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW TAIPEI DEPUTY MAYOR SWORN IN

TEXT.P: Former Secretary-General of Taipei City Government Chen Yuh-chang was sworn in as the new deputy mayor Monday, replacing Yeh Chin-chuan who resigned to fully devote his time to running for the Kuomintang's (KMT) nomination to run in the year-end Taipei mayoral election.
Chen was one of a group of municipal officials who were sworn in at a joint swearing-in ceremony presided over by Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou.
Ma said all those being sworn in are experienced in municipal affairs, adding that the new team will ensure that the city's operations will run smoothly.
Upon his resignation, Yeh said that he has mixed emotions because he is leaving the city government in an attempt to come back and work again with the staff with whom he is used to working.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN UNDER DIRECT CHINESE AVIAN FLU THREAT: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Monday that Taiwan is under direct threat of avian flu spreading from China, which is the largest "hot zone" of avian flu risk in the world.

Aided by the seasonal travel of migratory birds, Chen said, bird flu has spread across continents and has affected nearly 50 countries so far, with over 100 people having perished as the result of the virulent H5N1 strain of the virus.

Taiwan, which is separated from China by only the narrow Taiwan Strait and which maintains close private exchanges with that country, will bear the full brunt of a possible pandemic of bird flu originating from China, where cases of H5N1 infection in humans and even deaths have been reported over the past two years, Chen said.

Unfortunately, he went on, China has spared no effort to obstruct Taiwan's bids to join the World Health Organization and has boycotted Taiwan's cooperation with other countries in bird flu-fighting efforts -- moves that run counter to the universal value of "health care knows no borders" and cause incalculable damage to Taiwan's 23 million people.
Chen made the remarks when he addressed the opening of the 2006 Asian Pacific Regional Conference of the International Hospital Federation (IHF) at the Taipei International Convention Center.

He pointed out that over the past five decades, Taiwan has achieved an economic miracle, carried out democratization, raised the people's standard of living and promoted the development of health care systems and related business.

Taiwan's health care domain is of an internationally recognized high standard and the country has been assessed by the Economist Intelligence Unit as the "second most healthy country" in the world, Chen added.

Taiwan has contributed significantly to the world's health care efforts by taking part in numerous international disaster rescue and relief work efforts and medical aid missions, he said, adding that Taiwan is able and willing to make bigger contributions to the world with its commendable medical expertise and skills plus compassion for all the peoples around the globe.

In the future, he said, Taiwan will continue to demonstrate its medicare strength and try to win greater international recognition in the hope that leaders and pioneers in the world's medical sector will speak for Taiwan so as to prevent Taiwan from being shut out of the world's disease-prevention network.
Nearly 800 hospital representatives and medical leaders from 20-odd countries are taking part in the pan-regional meeting of the world's second-largest unofficial medical organization.

Discussions at the April 2-5 meeting will cover topics including applications of information technology, which when appropriately applied has great potential in medicine, nursing and management; medical assistance to poor communities and countries; and how hospitals and health services can better prepare for facing catastrophes caused by natural forces such as tsunami, epidemics and pandemics, according to IHF Director-General Per-Gunnar Svensson.
Issues such as Taiwan's health insurance system, its experience in fighting severe acute respiratory syndrome, and its work and accomplishments in overseas medical aid will also be discussed.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW MOFA DEPUTY MINISTER SWORN IN

TEXT.P: Chang Siao-yue was sworn in as the new deputy minister of foreign affairs Monday, becoming the first woman in Taiwan history to hold the post.

Chang was also Taiwan's first female ambassador, becoming ambassador to St. Christopher and Nevis in 1997. Before becoming the deputy foreign minister, Chang served as Taiwan's representative to Holland, from where she returned Sunday.
At the swearing-in ceremony, Chang encouraged her colleagues to engage in diplomatic work with "enthusiasm" and "easiness."
She also said that although everyone is very busy in the ministry, the working environment is very relaxed, and the ministry is like one big happy family.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Berlusconi-Prodi last duel prior to elections.
Premier Silvio Berlusconi and opposition leader Romano Prodi will hold their second televised debate tonight, their last duel in the run-up to the April 9 elections. The taxation and fiscal issues are expected to be main topics of discusssions.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened high and closed higher Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 46.79 points to close at 6,660.76.
The bourse opened at 6,627.32 and fluctuated between 6,672.11 and 6,615.98 during trading. A total of 3.26 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$100.29 billion (US$3.08 billion).

Five of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with paper and pulp issues moving up the most at 1.8 percent, followed by machinery and electronics shares at 1.1 percent, foodstuff issues at 0.9 percent, construction issues at 0.4 percent and plastics and chemicals shares at 0.2 percent.
The three other major stock categories lost ground, with textile stocks moving down the most at 0.7 percent, followed by cement stocks at 0.4 percent and banking and financial shares at 0.3 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 604 to 290, with 155 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: RECREATION THERAPY HELPS YOUNG BRAIN TUMOR PATIENTS FACE TREATMENT

TEXT.P: "Recreation therapy" has proved successful in helping young brain tumor patients at Taipei Veterans General Hospital (TVGH) find an outlet for the unease and fear they face in the process of receiving medical treatment, a physician at the hospital said Monday.

Children suffering from brain tumors usually have to endure a great deal of physical and psychological stress in the long-term treatment process, including surgery and follow-up radiotherapy that normally lasts between five and seven weeks, said Chen Yi-wei, a doctor in the hospital's Cancer Center.

"It's impossible for young patients under the age of 12 not to have feelings of fear and unease after staying in hospital for such a long period of time, " Chen said, noting that most of the patients have to be given tranquilizers or sleeping pills before facing the traumatic experience of undergoing radiotherapy.
Over time, patients build up a resistance to such drugs, thus making them feel more uncomfortable during the treatment process, he said.

To help the sick children, the hospital introduced recreational therapy six months ago. With the cooperation of the National Science Council and Taipei Physical Education College, physicians at the cancer center prescribed recreational activities, such as painting or playing computer games, to their young patients.

Chen said that a total of 13 brain tumor patients aged between 3 and 12 accepted the recreational therapy treatment on an experimental basis. Doctors found that nearly half of the patients did not require tranquilizers to calm them down before undergoing radiotherapy.

Chen noted that each of the patients in the recreational therapy program were first given a professional assessment on the degrees of their fear and anxiety, with the results being used in prescribing a suitable form of recreational therapy for each patient.

DOC.HEADLINE: DIPLOMATS FACE TREMENDOUS DIFFICULTIES OVERSEAS: MOFA HEAD

TEXT.P: Minister of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) Huang Chih-fang said Monday that while the public sees that diplomats are paid well, the difficulties and pressures diplomats face overseas have been ignored.
"Is there another government agency that needs to be responsible for Taiwan's official diplomatic relations with other countries? " Huang asked.

"If there are any changes in the country's diplomatic relations, the amount of pressure on our diplomats is tremendous. Some ambassadors even cannot sleep well at night because of the pressures," he said.

Huang made the remarks while taking questions from the press during the reception for new MOFA Vice Minister Chang Siao-yue. Huang's statement served as a response to a local media report that diplomats are being paid more for doing the same thing as the employees that the Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) has sent overseas. TAITRA is a semi-official non-profit organization promoting foreign trade.

Huang said that the report was "unfair" to diplomats, noting that the public only sees how well diplomats are paid but that the tasks diplomats face overseas are unimaginably difficult, adding that the public should consider the price diplomats pay for their high salaries.

"In Africa, for example, diplomats and their families face the threat of malaria, while in South America, they could get robbed or shot, or their residences, located near the presidential office and the ministry of the interior, could be affected if their is a coup," he said.

When asked whether Taiwan's diplomats in the United States and Europe are enjoying better lives than their colleagues in Africa and South America, Huang said that there are still major problems, such as children's education issues.

"After diplomats' children start education in a certain country, when the parents are being transferred to another culture and another education system, it becomes a torture for both parents and children," he said.

Huang said that he has seen that diplomats sent to the United States have had to leave their children behind in the U.S. for education when (they get transferred to another post) and their children are too old to adopt another education system. "Very often, the whole family can only get together during Christmas," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: SLOVAKIA SOLICITS TAIWAN TOURISTS

TEXT.P: An official mission from the Slovak Republic sponsored a workshop in Taipei Monday to promote tourism in the country, located in the heart of Europe and blessed with medieval castles, spas, crystal and wine.
It was the first time an official Slovakian delegation had visited to promote tourism since domestic travel agencies began organizing tours to Slovakia last year for the first time.

Members of the Slovakian delegation included Jan Bratko, Slovakia's representative in Taiwan, and Vladimir Grezo, the official in charge of culture and information in the Slovakian capital of Bratislava.

Officially, the Slovak Republic came into existence in 1993. Slovakia was a sovereign member of the Austro-Hungarian Empire until 1918, when it was integrated with Czech into a single country called the Czechoslovak Federation

For most Taiwan people, Slovakia is a strange and far-away country, but in fact, Bratislava is only about one hour by road from the Austrian capital of Vienna. Slovakia's geographic convenience has prompted China Airlines -- the largest international air carrier in Taiwan -- to open a Taiwan-Slovakia service soon after it opened its Taipei-Vienna route.

According to Wang Yi-ling, the owner of a Taiwan travel agency, Slovakia is not only proud of its natural resources and production, including the famous Swarovski crystal, Tokaj wine -- a drink loved by French King Louis XIV -- and medical spas, the country has civilized people, good social order and well-established public transportation networks, making it one of the best choices in the whole of Europe for backpackers.

DOC.HEADLINE: ABORIGINAL TV MAY BE OUT OF BUSINESS IF BUDGET FREEZE NOT LIFTED

TEXT.P: The Aboriginal Television Channel may be put out of business by the end of May if a freeze of its annual budget imposed by the legislature in January is not lifted soon, a ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislator said Monday.

DPP Legislator Lee Chen-nan quoted Walis Pelin, minister of the Council of Indigenous Peoples, as saying during a report to the DPP legislative caucus that two-thirds of the annual budget, totaling NT$297 million, for 2006 has been frozen by the opposition-controlled legislature since January.
If the NT$198 million budget remains frozen, the TV channel, which became formally operational in January 2005, will not be able to maintain its operations after May, said Walis.
The freeze also threatens to compromise the building of 37 cultural centers for aboriginal people around the country, Walis told the DPP lawmakers.
He appealed to the DPP lawmakers to help turn the case around at a legislative meeting scheduled for Thursday.

The opposition-controlled legislature froze the TV channel's budget in January in the midst of bickering over the organic law of the National Communications Commission (NCC) and considerations that broadcast policy and program designs of the Aboriginal TV Channel overlap with those of the Public Television Channel.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET DENIES REPORTS ABOUT NUCLEAR POWER PLANT BUDGET SNUB

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan has not rejected a supplementary budget request for the continued construction of the country's fourth nuclear power plant, Government Information Office Minister Cheng Wen-tsang said Monday.

Cheng was responding to media reports that under the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) policy of a nuclear-free Taiwan, the progress of construction of the nuclear power plant at Kungliao, Taipei County, has not been running smoothly because related budget failed to get sufficient support from the Executive Yuan.

State-owned Taiwan Power Company (Taipower), which is in charge of construction of the plant, requested the Executive Yuan to appropriate a supplementary budget of NT$54.3 billion in January, but the request was rejected in February, the reports claimed. With money fast running out, construction could come to a halt next month at the earliest, according to the reports.

Cheng termed the reports erroneous, saying that a financial advisory group under the Executive Yuan is still reviewing whether the supplementary budget is reasonable, as well as looking at the safety aspects of nuclear power and of the actual construction.

The Executive Yuan has also asked Taipower and the Ministry of Economic Affairs to review the country's energy policy, Cheng said. In the event that the completion of the fourth nuclear power plant lags behind schedule, causing power shortages, Taipower should also map out middle- and long-term alternative plans, Cheng said.
The Executive Yuan originally approved a budget of NT$169.7 billion for the plant, but it suspended construction work in October 2000, leading to billions of dollars of losses.

After months of political turbulence, the work resumed after a suspension of 110 days. The delay, coupled with the increased generation capacity of the two units in the power plant, could cause the investment to balloon to NT$243 billion, making it the most expensive nuclear power plant in the world, according to the reports.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER PRESIDENT OFFERS SETTLEMENT TO PFP HEAD OVER LIBEL SUIT

TEXT.P: Former President Lee Ten-hui is willing to reach a settlement with opposition People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong over a lawsuit Soong filed last year against Lee for defamation, Lee's attorney said Monday.

Wellington Ku made the offer on behalf of Lee at the Taiwan High Court, which opened a second trial of the case that day. The Taiwan High Court first opened the trial March 2, with the judge suggesting a settlement between the two parties concerned.

According Ku, Lee said that he is willing to accept the judge's settlement proposal and will publish a statement in a newspaper to clarify his alleged remarks about Soong and make public his terms for a settlement. Ku said that he had submitted the statement to the judge and will wait for Soong's response.

Lee lost the suit to Soong after the Taipei District ruled in November last year that Lee must pay NT$10 million to Soong and make an apology in nine local newspapers in compensation for damaging Soong's reputation by alleging in public that the PFP chairman played mahjong the night of April 10, 2004, ignoring opposition "pan blue" supporters who were protesting in the streets against what they called an unfair presidential election.
Lee argued that he did not identify Soong in the remarks and said that he would appeal.

Soong, served as then Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan's running mate in the March 20, 2004 presidential election. They lost by a narrow margin to the ruling Democratic Progressive Party ticket of President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT URGED TO STEP UP FOREIGN TALENT RECRUITMENT EFFORTS

TEXT.P: Lawmakers from the ruling and opposition parties demanded Monday that the government step up its efforts to recruit hi-tech talent from overseas in view of fierce competition from neighboring countries.

Lawmakers Hung Wei-cher and Kuo Chun-ming of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, as well as Lee Jih-chu and Tsao Shou-min of the main opposition Kuomintang, issued the call during an interpellation session at the legislative Technology and Information Committee after officials from the National Science Council (NSC) , the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, the Ministry of Economic Affairs and the Mainland Affairs Council reported on the issue.

Citing the successes enjoyed by Singapore and South Korea, the lawmakers said that the government should offer more handsome incentives to lure foreign talent, including providing residence permits and education for their children, along with Taiwan's other advantages.
As Taiwan is interested in exploring ties with India, the government could consider opening offices there to assit Taiwan companies in hunting for Indian hi-tech elite, Kuo said.

Lee also urged the government to further delve into the possibility of introducing hi-tech and other professional foreign nationals. Taiwan lags well behind South Korea in this field, she pointed out.
According to Lee, South Korea, where the average per-capita income is at about the same level as Taiwan, has so far attracted more than 10,000 foreign hi-tech workers, far ahead of Taiwan's 1,000.

She said that the government should conduct a study on foreign white-collar workers' conditions and the ease with which they adapt to life in Taiwan, to serve as a reference for future government policy making.

Citing earlier surveys carried out by the NSC, NSC Vice Minister Yang Tuen-her said that young hi-tech professionals care about most career development prospects in the workplace, while senior executives pay greatest attention to their children's education.

While South Korea focuses its efforts on wooing talent from China, India, Southeast Asian countries and Russia based on a recruitment program initiated in 2003, Singapore grants tax reductions for companies' spending on foreign manpower recruitment and offers housing, high salaries and training programs for foreign workers, according to Yang.

Currently, there are about 300 Indian hi-tech workers employed in Taiwan, while Singapore hires a much larger number of professionals from India due to the country's high per-capita income, Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Shih Yen-shiang said, noting that this is a real problem for the government when trying to lure hi-tech talent from abroad.

DOC.HEADLINE: KRTC TO STOP HIRING THAI WORKERS AFTER JULY 2007

TEXT.P: After the planned partial launch of the Kaohsiung mass rapid transit system in southern Taiwan in July 2007, the Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp. (KRTC) will not hire any more Thai laborers, KRTC officials said Monday.

The KRTC started to bring in Thai laborers in June 2003 to help build the system, with their numbers currently estimated at 1,511, compared with 1,717 in August 2005, when they rioted against what they called harsh and inhumane treatment by a management firm commissioned by the KRTC.

The riot led to a substantial improvement in the living conditions of the Thai workers, as well as an extensive corruption probe that has implicated officials right up to a former senior aide of President Chen Shui-bian.

KRTC officials said the present focus of the MRT work is laying the rails, which relies heavily on the Thai laborers. With the partial launch of the MRT system, the number of Thai laborers required will continue to decrease.

They said the number of Thai laborers will be decreased by 200 per month starting late this year or early next year. After rail-laying work is completed in July, the number will be lowered further, they added.
Unless repairs to a tunnel that caved in last December have not been completed by July 2007, the KRTC will stop hiring Thai laborers altogether.

The officials said that after the completion of the rail-laying work, the focus will shift to plumbing and renovation of the train stations, which will require local laborers and technicians as the main workforce.

Two hundred aboriginal people are also employed by the KRTC, the officials added, which they said conforms to the requirement by the Kaohsiung city government that the KRTC hire a certain ratio of aboriginal people.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained ground against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Monday, increasing NT$0.126 to close at NT$32.586.
A total of US$970 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$32.560 and fluctuated between NT$32.441 and NT$32.600.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES HIGHER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Monday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for April moved up 77 points to close at 6,638, with 3,043 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for May increased 57 points to finish at 6,620, with 604 contracts traded, while June futures gained 63 points to end at 6,588, with 26 contract transactions. September futures increased 64 points to close at 6,400, with 58 contracts traded, while December futures moved up 58 points to finish at 6,376, with 11 contract transactions.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Monday at 6,561 for April, 6,563 for May, 6,525 for June, 6,336 for September and 6,318 for December.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mostly higher.

April TE futures increased 3.85 points to close at 295.5, with 5,923 contracts traded, while May TE futures gained 4.05 points to finish at 294.6, with 83 contract transactions. June TE futures moved up 1.75 points to end at 290.6, with one contract traded.
No transactions were recorded for September and December.

April TF futures decreased one point to finish at 873, with 1,472 contracts changing hands, while May TF futures lost 0.8 points to close at 872, with 16 contracts traded. June TF futures moved up 3.2 points to end at 871, with six contract transactions, while September TF futures moved down 6.8 points to close at 854, with 16 contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for December.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT GOADS KMT TO SNATCH 'ONE CHINA' INTERPRETATION FROM PRC

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian challenged the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Monday to reach an agreement with Beijing on what the KMT claims is a "1992 consensus" under which Taiwan can interpret "one China" as "the Republic of China."

During a two-hour dialogue with KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou at the Presidential Office, Chen urged Ma to ask KMT Honorary Chairman Lien Chan to "snatch that right to interpret the meaning of 'one China'" from Chinese President Hu Jintao when Lien visits Beijing later this month.
If the KMT can achieve that, and the two sides of the Taiwan Strait agree on one China, with each side free to interpret its meaning, "I will absolutely respect it," Chen said.
In response, Ma said he would ask Lien to forward Chen's message to the Chinese leadership in an attempt to "seek a breakthrough" in Taiwan-China relations.

"One China, " cross-strait ties, the government's arms purchase bill and other "ideological" issues -- in the form of the necessity of changing the Constitution rather than economic and social issues -- were the focus of the rare debate between the nation's two most powerful political leaders.

Chen's challenge originated from Ma's suggestion that the Chen administration initiate a dialogue with China based on the so-called "1992 consensus" reached in Hong Kong by delegates from Taipei and Beijing, to reach a deal on practical matters such as allowing Chinese tourists into Taiwan and setting up direct transportation links between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

Chen chided Ma for asking him to base a formal negotiation on "something that simply does not exit." Chen cited what he claimed were "authoritative" sources to prove his point that there is no such thing as the "1992 consensus, " a phrase that KMT Legislator Su Chi, who once served as Mainland Affairs Council chairman, has admitted to coining.

But Chen said he does not deny that talks did take place in Hong Kong between Taiwan and China in late 1992, in which China insisted that the so-called "one China" refers to the People's Republic of China, while the KMT keeps fooling itself -- and the world -- that it has won an "oral agreement" from China that the two sides are free to interpret what "one China" means in their own ways.
Ma told Chen not to be too "technical" with regard to terminology and assured him that China will likely accept the principle of "one China, with each side free to interpret its meaning."

"If China does not accept that, it will be its own fault, " Ma said, noting that only when neither side denies the other's existence can dialogue begin. He called on Chen to at least "give it a try" to seize the opportunity to launch a dialogue with China.
An unimpressed Chen urged Ma not to be naive about China, which he claimed will never change its "one China" position of looking at Taiwan as part of the PRC because its Constitution says so.

Ma called on the president to talk with China on a wide range of topics, including the possibility of signing what he called a "modus vivendi" on Taiwan's international participation and a 30- to 50-year interim agreement on cross-strait peace and cooperation, ideas that he broached during a recent visit he made to the United States.
Again, Chen was not convinced, claiming that as China is not trustworthy and will not honor its agreements, Taiwan must be "very cautious" in dealing with the Chinese leaders.

Ma responded by saying that if such an agreement can be signed, "we certainly must figure out ways to bind China to it. If one party to an agreement fails to honor it, so can the other party," he added.

When Ma challenged Chen to tell the people of Taiwan whether the National Unification Council (NUC), whose function has been "ceased" -- although the U.S. thinks it has just been put in abeyance -- is still there or not.

Chen for his part called on Ma not to be too "literal" with the meaning of words. "I wanted to abolish the NUC, " Chen stressed, adding that after to-and-froing with the U.S., "we finally decided to cease its function, not suspend or terminate it, just cease its function."
Chen said the council no longer has any budget, its staff have been sent back to their original units and that therefore, the NUC no longer exists.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXPERT URGES WEST NOT TO `MISINTERPRET' DPP'S ELECTION DEFEATS
DOC.DATELINE: New York, April 3 (CNA) (By Eric Tseng and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Former Executive Yuan Secretary-General Liu Shih-fang urged China and the West not to "misinterpret" the major setback Taiwan's ruling party suffered in the 2005 local elections as a sign that Taiwan will move towards unification with China or renounce independence.

Liu made the call Sunday while delivering a speech at the Chinese Cultural Center of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in New York. Liu, who heads a private society on cross-Taiwan Strait economic and political research, took a one-year fellowship at the Brookings Institution in Washington, D.C. in 2004.

Liu attributed the defeat of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), which won only six out of 23 city and county government posts in the "three-in-one" elections Dec. 3, 2005, to several factors, including the series of corruption scandals that has tarnished the ruling party's image, the efforts of the opposition Kuomintang and the People First Party -- both of which form the "pan-blue alliance" -- to seek consolidation, and frequent Cabinet personnel changes that have led to poor administrative efficiency.

Liu suggested that the DPP take immediate steps to address the problems lest they endanger the party's ability to survive. However, she also said that the victory of the "pan-blue alliance" in the local elections does not mean Taiwan supports unification.

Talking about China's military threat against Taiwan, the former government official said Taiwan has to defend itself, but added that the true meaning of self-defense is not "just to enhance defensive power."

"The most important thing is that Taiwan has to maintain democracy, " Liu said, explaining that democracy is the pride of Taiwan and claiming that it is the reason Taiwan enjoys support from the United States.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'MODUS VIVENDI' PROPOSAL MAY NOT HAVE U.S. SUPPORT: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian claimed Monday that main opposition Kuomintang Chairman Ma Ying-jeou's proposal to sign a cross-Taiwan Strait peace agreement is similar to one proposed by a former U.S. official that received no support from the administration of former U.S. President Bill Clinton.
Chen made the remarks during a high-profile meeting with Ma at the Presidential Office. The meeting was proposed by Ma after his return from a 10-day visit to the United States.

Chen described Ma's proposal under the model of "modus vivendi" -- a temporary agreement between contending parties prior to a final settlement -- as being similar to that of an interim agreement proposed by former U.S. National Security Council (NSC) official Kenneth Lieberthal, who suggested a 30-year cross-strait agreement in which Taiwan would not seek independence and China would not use force against Taiwan.
But Chen said Lieberthal's proposal had prerequisites and envisioned the eventual unification of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.
"Even so, Beijing opposed such a proposal," Chen said, adding that he doubted if China would accept Ma's proposal, which also has the existence of the Republic of China as a premise.

Chen said he asked James B. Steinberg, a former deputy national security adviser under Clinton administration as well as Lieberthal's superior, about the latter's proposal, but learned that then-U.S.President Bill Clinton had not supported Lieberthal's ideas, because "China is unreliable, and who can guarantee that it will honor its promise for 30 or 50 years?"
The president also said that during Clinton's visit to Taiwan in February 2005, Clinton reiterated his opinion.
Clinton was quoted as having suggested that Taiwan should be itself and should not accept an interim agreement that would be unfavorable to Taiwan.
However, Ma pointed out that times have changed and he suggested that Chen look at things "from a new perspective."

Ma noted that former KMT Chairman Lien Chan signed a five-point agreement with Chinese President Hu Jintao during his visit to China last May in which both sides expressed willingness to sign a peace agreement without mentioning eventual unification.

Ma said that if the conditions for a cross-strait peace agreement are good, it will be helpful to Taiwan's security. If the other side does not abide by the agreement, the agreement will not exist and the situation will return to the present.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAO CHILDREN FROM ORCHID ISLAND VISIT DOH

TEXT.P: A group of indigenous Tao tribe children from Orchid Island visited the Department of Health (DOH) Monday, where they were cited as "Little Angels" in helping the public gain knowledge in public health issues such as epidemic control and drug abuse prevention.

The visit by 43 schoolchildren forms a three-day program through April 4 hosted by the Cabinet-level DOH, which aims to educate children, in particular those from remote areas, to protect themselves from drug abuse and the spread of epidemics such as avian flu, which has troubled many countries in Asia, a DOH official said.
Accompanied by six teachers, the 43 children arrived in Taipei from the remote Orchid Island, located off the southeastern county of Taitung.

As more than half of the children's parents work in Taipei, they hoped to meet with their fathers or mothers here, along with paying a visit to Taipei 101 Tower -- the world's highest skyscraper, eating hamburgers and meeting with several hosts of TV children's programs, the DOH official said, adding that they fulfilled all wishes except meeting their parents due to a tight schedule.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Sectarian Strife Fuels Gun Sales in Baghdad
Iraq has long been awash in guns. But after the bombing of a sacred Shiite shrine in Samarra in late February, sectarian tensions exploded, and more Iraqis than ever have been buying, carrying and stockpiling weapons, adding an unnerving level of firepower to Baghdad's streets.
Wall Street Journal: System Reboot, Hurd's Big Challenge at H-P: Overhauling Corporate Sales
Just weeks after arriving at Hewlett-Packard Co. as chief executive a year ago, Mark Hurd began hearing the complaints about H-P's corporate sales force. Sensing a fundamental problem, Hurd dug into H-P's sales structure. He found that there were 11 layers of management between him and a customer -- far too many and too slower to cut a deal -- and thus lost many bids. Hurd is taking on his biggest management challenges: overhauling H-P's vast corporate sales force H-P's corporate sales.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN-MA MEETING MARKED BY WIDELY DISPARATE VIEWS

TEXT.P: If Chinese leader Hu Jintao accepts the principle of "one China, with each side of the Taiwan Strait free to interpret its meaning, " President Chen Shui-bian said Monday he will "absolutely respect it" during a televised meeting with opposition Kuomintang Chairman Ma Ying-jeou during which few points of consensus were reached.
The meeting took place after Ma's recent U.S. visit, and was expected to be dominated by a controversial multi-billion dollar arms deal with the U.S.

During the two-hour meeting at the Presidential Office, Chen and Ma spent much of the time communicating their points of view about Taiwanese identity, cross-strait affairs, the "one China" policy, the "1992 consensus, " Chinese missiles targeting Taiwan and arms procurement.

Chen said Taiwan should reach a consensus about foreign and mainland affairs and that the common enemy of both parties is Communist China. Ma put forth suggestions about improving cross-strait relations, discussing Chen's "Five Noes" commitment and Ma's own "Five Do's."
At a swearing-in ceremony six years ago, President Chen made five promises, among them that he would not declare independence or change the nation's title.

Chen said, "As long as the Chinese Communist regime does not intend to use force against Taiwan, I promise that during my term I will not declare independence, will not change the name of the country, will not push for the incorporation of a special state- to-state model of cross-strait relations in the Constitution and will not push for a referendum on the independence-unification issue that will change the status quo. Nor will there be any question of abolishing the National Unification Guidelines or the National Unification Council."

Instead of "Five Noes, " Ma proposed "Five Do's" during his U.S. trip. He said the measures would help improve relations between Taiwan and China by resuming cross-strait dialogue and establishing a tentative peace framework or "modus vivendi" if his party wins the presidency in 2008.

Other steps to be taken by the KMT include enhancing cross-strait economic and trade ties, negotiating with Beijing on issues involving Taiwan's international participation and promoting cross-strait cultural and educational exchanges, said Ma.
The meeting between the two leaders was their first since Ma won the chairmanship of the Kuomintang (KMT) last August. Ma requested the meeting after returning from the U.S. March 29.

Although both claimed they were looking forward to an opportunity to share views and experiences, they emerged from the meeting with widely disparate positions about cross-strait relations and China policy.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'ORGANIC PORK' AVAILABLE ON MARKET NOT OFFICIALLY CERTIFIED: COA

TEXT.P: The so-called "organic pork" or "organic fishery products" circulating in the local market are all self-proclaimed with no official certification, the Council of Agriculture (COA) said Monday.

The Cabinet-level council has so far not certified any fishery or aquacultural products or livestock products as organic, COA officials said, adding that all so-called "organic pork" or "organic fish" available on the local market are self-proclaimed.

According to the officials, the COA has authorized four organic agriculture promotion organizations to certify some farm produce as "organic products, " but the operations have not covered any fishery or animal husbandry items.

At present, the officials said, the four authorized foundations are responsible for monitor and certify a total of 1,335 hectares of farmland specializing in organic agricultural production, including rice, vegetables, fruits and tea. Only qualified "organic products" are allowed to carry the COA-certified "CAS"
The COA has conducted regular field surveys and spot market inspections to ensure that all "CAS"-labeled organic products meet its standards and requirements.
Three sets of regulations have been put into force to govern production and management of organic farm produce and CAS certifying operations, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT: PRESIDENT FAILS TO DISTINGUISH BETWEEN 'CPC' AND 'CHINA'

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian does not seem to realize that although the Communist Party of China (CPC) poses a threat to Taiwan, mainland China presents an opportunity for Taiwan, an opposition Kuomintang (KMT) legislator said Monday.
Su Chi, who once served as chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council, made the comment after Chen's live, televised meeting with KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou at the Presidential Office.

On Chen's rejecting Ma's suggestion to reopen cross-Taiwan Strait dialogue on the basis of the "1992 consensus" on grounds that such a consensus simply does not exist, Su said the president had failed to grasp the "delicate points" of cross-strait relations.

When it comes to cross-strait relations, a critical point is that many things can be done when both sides do not "deny the existence of the other, " said Su, who has previously admitted he coined the term "1992 consensus" so that both sides would continue dialogue after Chen became Taiwan's president in 2000.

Because Chen's government has not realized the difference between "the Communist Party of China" and "mainland China," the government's policy over the past six years has led to "growing threats posed by the CPC" and "growing opportunities offered by mainland China, " he said.

Because the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) government led by Chen has only perceived the CPC's threats while failing to see mainland China's opportunities and has adopted a confrontational policy toward China, its policy has led to a deadlock in cross-strait relations, angering the U.S. and making the world uneasy, Su said.
He said if the DPP government were competent, it would have helped the Taiwanese people "resist Communist threats" on one hand while "seizing opportunities in China" on the other.

Instead, he noted, the Chen administration has created tensions in cross-strait relations and caused Taiwanese people to lose opportunities in China, resulting in Taiwan's marginalization and the suffering of its people.
Su said when China and Taiwan agreed on "one China," neither side was forcing the other to accept its own definition of the term, and the key was in "not denying the existence of the other side."

As long as China does not deny or challenge Taiwan's claim to be "one China" or remains silent over this, things will be okay, he said, regretting that the president "still has not come to realize the delicate points in the cross-strait relationship."

Shuai Hua-min, another KMT lawmaker, said Ma has proposed a step-by-step policy toward peace between Taiwan and China, while Chen has proposed a disorderly policy toward war, causing Taiwan to waste too much of its time and energy on unproductive political debate.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT, KMT CHAIRMAN DIFFER ON HOW TO AVOID DISASTER FOR TAIWAN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian and main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou agreed during their meeting at the Presidential Office Monday that Taiwan's interests should always come first in whatever the ruling and opposition parties do, but disagreed on how to "seek good fortune and avoid disaster" for Taiwan.

In his first meeting with the president since he became KMT chairman in August last year, Ma, who also serves as Taipei mayor, said the KMT's way of seeking good fortune and avoiding disaster for Taiwan is to lay out an "open, pragmatic" policy toward mainland China by sticking to the "five noes" pledge -- made by President Chen in his inaugural speech in 2000 and reaffirmed by him in 2004 when he began to serve a second term -- plus the KMT's "five do's."

In his May 2000 inaugural speech, Chen said that as long as China promises not to use military force against Taiwan, he will not declare Taiwan independence, will not change the official name of the country, will not include the"state-to-state"theory in the Constitution, will not promote a referendum to change the cross-Taiwan Strait status quo, and will not abolish the Guidelines for National Unification and the National Unification Council (NUC).

As for the "five do's," Ma suggested the government resume talks with the Chinese mainland; work toward a peace accord under which both sides of the Taiwan Strait agree that neither will move toward independence or unification for 30-50 years; set up military confidence building mechamisms; try to achieve a modus vivendi on Taiwan's participation in international organizations; and step up cross-strait cultural and educational exchanges.

Ma stressed that the issue of Taiwan independence versus unification with China should be set aside, and that both the government and the opposition parties should instead focus on improving people's livelihood and finding a way out of Taiwan's isolation in the international arena, and creating a "win-win" situation for both Taiwan and the mainland.
While agreeing with Ma that Taiwan should "seek good fortune and avoid disaster," Chen charted a different course of achieving that goal.

He explained that he was not moving toward Taiwan independence, and that measures adopted by the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) government were all intended to protect Taiwan's democratic way of life -- measures such as insisting on giving the people the right to determine important issues through a referendum, allowing the NUC and the National Unification Guidelines to cease functioning, and pushing for constitutional reform.
The president stressed that no political parties should determine the future for Taiwan's 23 million people, and that it is up to the people to decide what they want.

The two-hour meeting, televised live, was held at Ma's request because he wanted to make some suggestions to the president after his recent visit to the United States. Their discussion also touched on such issues as the gridlock in the legislature concerning military procurement from the United States and whether it was necessary to end the NUC and its guidelines.

Although their dialogue was conducted in a congenial atmosphere, the meeting apparently ended with neither side bending to the other on any given issues. The president and the KMT chairman, however, agreed that whenever necessary, they will hold similar discussions again in future.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT WILL NOT RULE OUT FURTHER CONSTITUTIONAL REFORM

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian told main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou Monday that with the public's support, he will consider taking further steps to amend the Constitution or even draft a new Constitution.

At their two-hour meeting at the Presidential Office televised live to the nation, the president said the current Constitution is based on the premise hat the Republic of China's territory covers the whole of China, and an no longer reflect the reality in Taiwan.

He explained that Taiwan's people now choose their own president through direct elections, while in the past, presidents of the Republic of China on Taiwan were chosen indirectly by a National Assembly that would also represent the Chinese people across the Taiwan Strait.

Noting the Constitution has been amended seven times -- once in 2005 after Chen began to serve his second term and six times when Lee Teng-hui was president and KMT chairman -- Chen said he will take further steps for constitutional reform when conditions in Taiwan are ripe.
Urging the president to safeguard the Constitution, Ma reminded Chen that he had pledged his allegiance to the Constitution twice in his 2000 and 2004 presidential inaugural addresses.
"The people are really not interested in any more constitutional reform," Ma said, adding that the government should now focus on improving the people's livelihood.

The meeting was the first between the president and Ma since Ma, who also serves as Taipei mayor, became KMT chairman in August last year. The meeting was held at Ma's request because he wanted to make some suggestions to the president after coming back last week from a 10-day visit to the United States.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN-MA MEETING HELPS TAIWAN'S POLITICS DEVELOP IN RATIONAL WAY: SU

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang lauded a meeting between President Chen Shui-bian and main opposition Kuomintang Chairman Ma Ying-jeou Monday as being "conducive to Taiwan's politics developing in a rational way."
Chen and Ma held a rare public meeting Monday that highlighted their differences over relations with rival China and opposing views on a multibillion-dollar U.S. arms procurement package.
Despite their disparate opinions, Su said the Chen-Ma dialogue showed that both sides are looking forward to Taiwan's sustainable development.

Against this backdrop, Su said ruling and opposition camps should strive to forge a consensus and a common ground on major policy issues, particularly those related to the economy and people's livelihood.

Su said he keenly hoped the legislative caucuses of the ruling and opposition parties would end their political standoff and work together to promote bills conducive to economic development and the betterment of people's lives.

DOC.HEADLINE: GROUND BROKEN FOR CENTRAL TAIWAN SCIENCE PARK ADMINISTRATION CENTER

TEXT.P: National Science Council (NSC) Minister Chen Chien-jen presided Monday over a ground-breaking ceremony for the administration center of the Central Taiwan Science Park.

Chen said the Central Taiwan Science Park has been making strong progress over the past two years and that its performance is even better than that of the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park and the Southern Taiwan Science Park.

The administration center will include two buildings, one of which provides services to companies at the park and which is scheduled to be completed in December, while the other, housing administration affairs, will be completed next June.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN-MA MEETING HELPS TO EASE POLITICAL STANDOFF: PRESIDENTIAL OFFICE

TEXT.P: The Presidential Office said Monday that the two-hour meeting between President Chen Shui-bian and main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou held earlier the same day would help ease the domestic political standoff.
Chen and Ma held a rare public meeting that highlighted their differences over relations with rival China and opposing views of a multibillion-dollar U.S. arms procurement package.
A Presidential Office spokesman said it was only natural that Chen and Ma held different views about major policy issues because they belong to different political parties.

"We believe this kind of dialogue will contribute toward social harmony and a cooling-off of domestic political wrangling. We hope similar meetings can take place regularly in future to facilitate communications between ruling and opposition parties," the spokesman said.
However, Ma said he was concerned about Chen's statements during their two-hour discussion.

"It seems to me the president will go ahead with his plan to draft a new constitution and continue to deny the existence of the '1992 consensus, '" Ma said, adding that he was also worried whether Chen would back off other promises in the "five noes" pledge following the recent cessation of the National Unification council.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, April 4, or the seventh day of the third month of the Year of the Dog according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1581: Sir Francis Drake, who in 1580 became the first Englishman to circumnavigate the globe, is knighted in London by Queen Elizabeth I. The English naval hero later became vice admiral of the fleet that destroyed the Spanish Armada in 1588.
1617: John Napier, the Scottish mathematician who invented logarithms and introduced the use of the decimal point in writing numbers, dies at the age of 67.
1841: William Henry Harrison, the ninth president of the United States, dies of pneumonia at the age of 68 after only one month in office.
1900: Prince Edward, heir to the throne of England, narrowly escapes death when a teenage anarchist fires two shots at the prince who is on a train in a Brussels station.
1905: An earthquake rocks Lahore, then part of British India, killing some 19,000 people.
1932: The Republic of China observes its first Children's Day. Children have the day off from school.
1942: Japanese forces sink three British warships in the Bay of Bengal.
1949: The foreign ministers of Belgium, Britain, Canada, France, Holland, Luxembourg, Norway, Denmark, Iceland, Italy, Portugal and the United States sign the North Atlantic Treaty in Washington to protect Western nations from Soviet aggression.
1950: The Chinese Refugees Relief Association is inaugurated.
1967: Australian Prime Minister Harold E. Holt arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1968: Dr. Martin Luther King, the American civil rights leader who won the 1964 Nobel Peace Prize, is assassinated at a motel in Memphis, Tennessee. His eloquence and commitment to nonviolent tactics formed the foundation of the civil rights movement of the 1950's and 1960's.
1973: The Republic of China and the Khmer Republic conclude a temporary air transport agreement with an exchange of notes in Phnom Penh.
1974: The 21-member women's national basketball team returns after a tour of the United States and Brazil. The team won 24 games and lost six.
1974: The Republic of China suspends diplomatic relations with Botswana.
1974: U.S. Ambassador Walter P. McConaughy and his wife leave Taipei for retirement. He is succeeded by Ambassador Leonard Unger.
1976: Chinese at home and abroad mark the first anniversary of the passing of President Chiang Kai-shek with solemn ceremonies, tributes and prayers.
1979: Zulfikar Ali Bhutto, Pakistan's former president who was deposed by Gen. Zia ul-Haq in 1977, is hanged in Rawalpindi for the alleged murder of a political opponent.
1980: ROC President Chiang Ching-kuo presides over a ceremony marking the inauguration of the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall.
1983: The United States grants political asylum to Hu Na, a noted tennis player from mainland China.
1989: The Ministry of Education approves the applications of three mainlanders to visit Taiwan.
1990: Communist China's legislature approves the Basic Law, the constitution that will govern Hong Kong after it reverts to Chinese sovereignty in 1997.
1990: Britain publishes a bill to grant citizenship to up to 225,000 Hong Kong residents in the run-up to the colony's handover to mainland China in 1997.
1994: A communist Chinese court sentences Si Yang, a reporter at Hong Kong's Ming Pao newspaper, to 12 years in prison for "stealing and probing national secrets."
1999: At the conclusion of a weeklong visit to Taiwan, prominent mainland Chinese dissident Wang Dan urges Beijing to abandon threatening Taiwan with military aggression.
2000: Paraguayan President Luis Gonzalez Macchi reiterates that his country's stance of supporting the Republic of China in international forums will never change.
2001: Tibetan spiritual leader, the Dalai Lama, meets with opposition People First Party Chairman James Soong in Taipei to exchange views on issues of mutual concern.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A gentleman must be sympathetic, obliging and affectionate: sympathetic and obliging to his friends and affectionate to the members of his family."

DOC.HEADLINE: PRO-TAIWAN INDEPENDENCE GROUPS PROTEST KMT CHIEF'S STATEMENT
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 3 (CNA) (By Jorge Liu and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Two pro-Taiwan independence organizations in the United States issued a joint statement Monday to express indignation at main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou's recent remarks regarding the United States' obligation to help defend Taiwan in the event of a Chinese military attack.

In an interview with United Press International on March 28, 2006, Ma said that U.S. officials had told him during his visit to Washington, D.C. that the United States would have no obligation to intervene in a military conflict between Taiwan and China if Taiwan's government did anything to spark the conflict.
Ma, who doubles as Taipei mayor, recently concluded a 10-day visit to the United States.

Terri Giles, executive director of the Los Angeles-based Formosa Foundation, said that he found it "curious that a United States official confided in the Taipei mayor and leader of Taiwan opposition party that the United States considers Taiwan to be the problem, since it is China who has undermined the status quo."
He said that China has deployed almost 800 missiles aimed at Taiwan and has repeatedly threatened to use force against the democratic and sovereign island.

"The Chinese Communist leadership has systematically isolated Taiwan from the rest of the international community, passed an anti-secession law and continued a rapid military buildup in recent years that is largely focused on intimidating Taiwan and seizing the island if intimidation fails," he said.
"China's provocative actions represent a major change in the status quo and a serious military threat to Taiwan," he continued.

C.T. Lee, president of the Washington, D.C.-based Formosan Association for Public Affairs (FAPA) , said that the association condemns Ma's statement, adding that his "reckless assertion must be music to the ears of the Chinese government."
It could be used as justification for China to declare a democratic act by the Taiwanese government as the spark for war, Lee continued.
"We are gravely concerned that the Mayor's statement will only embolden China to believe that the United States has severely curtailed any commitment to defend Taiwan," said Giles.

The Formosa Foundation and FAPA each call upon the U.S. to confirm its adherence to the letter and spirit of the Taiwan Relations Act of 1979, which forms the foundation for the U.S. commitment to help defend Taiwan in the event of an attack by China, Lee said.
"We hope that the United States government will reinforce its commitment to support Taiwan and its democracy and expressly condemn any statements that suggest otherwise," he continued.

DOC.HEADLINE: HONG KONG NEWSPAPERS EXPRESS DIFFERENT VIEWS ON 'CHEN-MA' MEETING
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, April 4 (CNA) (By Lo Kin-fai, Lin Yu-kuo & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Two Hong Kong Chinese-language newspapers expressed different views Tuesday on the historic meeting between the two most influential politicians in Taiwan -- President Chen Shui-bian and opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou, held a day earlier in Taipei.

The Ming Pao Daily News said in a commentary that the two politicians didn't arrive at any consensus on the issues they talked about during their meeting, claiming the two-hour "Chen-Ma" dialogue wouldn't have any impact on the current politic situation in Taiwan.

The daily said the two political leaders seemed about even during their debates on various issues, including the "one-China" principle, cross-Taiwan Strait relations, and the arms procurement bill that has been stalled in the legislature for over a year.

The Ming Pao indicated that the "Ma Ying-jeou phenomenon" emerged on the political stage in Taiwan after the KMT chief, who also serves as Taipei mayor, concluded a high-profile visit to the United States last week. Most members of Taiwan's ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) seem to believe "no one in the DPP can compete with Ma in the presidential election in 2008," the newspaper said
Meanwhile, the Oriental Daily News described in its commentary the meeting as a "high-level show of democracy, " which might be able to inspire the leadership on the other side of the strait.

However, the newspaper also commented that the Chen-Ma meeting turned into a television debate between Taiwan's two major political parties, which built a "mirage" of inter-party cooperation. It said that both sides took advantage of the meeting to build up support for their respective parties' candidates in the year-end mayoral elections in Taipei and Kaohsiung as well as for their parties ahead of the 2008 presidential election.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'CHEN-MA MEETING IS A GOOD START': LEGISLATIVE SPEAKER

TEXT.P: Legislative speaker Wang Jin-pyng said Tuesday that the meeting between President Chen Shui-bian and main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou Monday afternoon is a good start in Taiwan's political arena.
Noting that having differences of opinion is only natural in a democracy, Wang said that "exchanging views, however different, is much better than not talking at all."

During their two-hour meeting at the Presidential Office, Chen and Ma discussed a wide variety of issues regarding the country's future, including constitutional reform, cross-Taiwan Strait relations, and the arms procurement bill which has been stalled in the legislature for over a year.
Wang said he hopes Chen and Ma will think more about the people's welfare and try to find some common ground for the benefit of the country.

Meanwhile, Premier Su Tseng-chang said he supports President Chen's statement made during the meeting that he would respect the "one China, different interpretations" principle only if Chinese President Hu Jintao were to publicly declare his acceptance of the principle.
The premier said it would be good if China could make a unequivocal statement about its acceptance of the principle.
