DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: DeLay to Resign From Congress; Associates Say Reelection Fears, Not Criminal Probe, Led to Republican's Decision.
Rep. Tom DeLay (R-Tex.) , a primary architect of the Republican majority who became one of the most powerful and feared leaders in Washington, told House allies last night that he will give up his seat rather than face a reelection fight that appears increasingly unwinnable, the paper said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC DEDICATED TO DEVELOPING SUSTAINABLE TIES WITH PACIFIC ALLIES: MOFA

TEXT.P: Taiwan is dedicated to developing sustainable relations with its diplomatic allies in the South Pacific with the aim of creating a "win-win situation, " a Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) spokesman said Tuesday.

Michel Lu made the remarks in response to a recent report by the Australian Senate claiming that the diplomatic battle between Taiwan and China in the South Pacific has contributed to corruption in countries in the region.

Lu said that Taiwan's diplomatic relations with South Pacific states have mainly focused on the sustainable development of bilateral relations. Taiwan has, based on its experience, engaged in cooperation in human resources, public construction, and agricultural and fishery technology, Lu added.
"All the projects we are promoting can be subject to public scrutiny," he added.

He said that Taiwan's allies in the South Pacific envy Taiwan's achievements over the past five decades and that they realize that Taiwan is sincere in having long-term and sustainable relations with them.
However, China's approach has been different, Lu said. Beijing has pulled out all the stops in trying to deter South Pacific countries from establishing or maintaining diplomatic ties with Taiwan.

Lu's words came as Chinese Premier Wen Jiabao arrived in Fiji the same day to attend an economic forum -- the first China-Pacific Island Countries Economic Development and Cooperation Forum -- slated for April 5-6.

The conference, co-sponsored by China and Fiji, is aimed at boosting bilateral cooperation between China and Pacific island nations in travel, environmental protection, education, fisheries, public health and legal affairs.

MOFA officials said that China provided Fiji with some US$1.17 million in funds to help organize the conference. Since early this year, China has offered more than US$13 million in aid to Fiji as part of its "checkbook diplomacy," they said.

Despite China's efforts to woo Taiwan's six diplomatic allies in the region -- namely Nauru, Palau, the Marshall Islands, the Solomon Islands, Kiribati and Tuvalu -- all six countries have said that they will not take part in the conference.

DOC.HEADLINE: 51% OF PARENTS UNAWARE OF INTERNET CONTENT RATING SYSTEM: POLL

TEXT.P: A civic group urged the government, Internet content providers and parents Tuesday to take action to protect children who use the Internet, in the wake of a survey showing that 51 percent of Taiwan parents have no idea what the Internet content rating system is.

The survey was conducted by the Cyber Angel's Pick, an affiliated group of the I-Link Community Services Association, on 1,200 parents Jan. 5-15. It has a margin of error of plus or minus 2.88 percentage points.

According to the results of the survey, 40 percent of children browse the Internet without parental supervision, and children who live together with their parents and grandparents have a better idea about Internet safety and content rating.
Huang Wei-wei, president of Cyber Angel's Pick, suggested that the government seek to improve children's Internet safety by setting up a child online protection committee.

Also, the National Communications Commission should meet regularly with Internet content providers and the Taiwan Internet Content Rating Promotion Foundation to work out measures to encourage the content providers to comply with the rating system, Huang said.

Meanwhile, opposition Kuomintang Legislator Lai Shyh-bao said he will promote the enactment of a children's online privacy protection act to prevent the collection of children's personal information by criminals through online game Web sites.
Lai said he will also propose a piece of legislation to punish the operators of Web sites encouraging suicide in order to protect the safety of teenagers and children.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed higher Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 4.84 points to close at 6,665.6.
The bourse opened at 6,679.82 and fluctuated between 6,684.1 and 6,651.96 during trading. A total of 3.06 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$100.78 billion (US$3.09 billion).

Six of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with construction issues moving up the most at 1.9 percent, followed by paper and pulp issues at 1.7 percent, textile stocks at 0.8 percent, cement stocks and banking and financial shares both at 0.7 percent, and plastics and chemicals shares at 0.2 percent.
The two other major stock categories lost ground, with machinery and electronics shares losing at 0.2 percent and foodstuff issues dropping 0.1 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 438 to 437, with 172 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Berlusconi announces tax exemption for citizen's first house.
Premier Silvio Berlusconi announced Monday that he will abolish the municipal tax on immovable property (ICI) for the first house that a citizen has. Berlusconi made the announcement in the second and last televised debate with opposition leader Romano Prodi. He said that the citizen's first house is sacred.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT HEAD CALLS FOR PRESIDENT'S ATTENTION TO PEOPLE'S LIVELIHOODS

TEXT.P: Main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou called Tuesday for the president to pay greater attention to people's livelihoods, saying that he met President Chen Shui-bian Monday out of concern for Taiwan.
Ma, who is also mayor of Taipei, made the remarks while fielding questions from Taipei city councilors during an interpellation session at the Taipei City Council.

Although many of the opposition "pan blue alliance" supporters were not content with his meeting with Chen, Ma said that he had done so in hopes of pushing the president to focus more on economic issues that would improve people's lives by building better relations with China.

Even if his meeting with Chen failed to produce concrete results, it was good that they had met in a cordial atmosphere, Ma said, pointing out that he would not mind if his public approval ratings declined following the meeting.
He also stressed that the United States was not behind his decision to meet with the president and that the United States had not asked him to relay any messages to Chen.
The KMT's legislative caucus Tuesday praised Chairman Ma's moral courage for holding a meeting with President Chen in defiance of supporters' opinions.

Pan Wei-kang, a KMT legislative caucus whip, made the comment at a news conference. Pointing out that she did not think Ma should have met with Chen by any means, Pan said that she still wanted to praise Ma for doing so. Ma did a good job in highlighting the KMT's and his own stance on issues related to Taiwan-China relations and people's livelihoods during the meeting, she said.
KMT Legislator Chiu I also lauded Ma's performance as an opposition leader, saying that the KMT chairman had "done the right thing" in adopting a tougher position toward the president.

According to survey results published by a local daily newspaper, Ma's public approval ratings dropped from 67 percent to 58 percent following Monday's Chen-Ma meeting -- just a few days after his return from a U.S. visit March 29. Some 44 percent of opposition pan blue supporters expressed objections to the Chen-Ma meeting, while 38 percent agreed with it.
Meanwhile, Chen's public approval ratings have hovered around 20 percent, but his public disapproval ratings fell to 57 percent from 63 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA GRANTS LANDING VISA TREATMENT TO SLOVAKIAN VISITORS

TEXT.P: Visitors from the Slovak Republic have been granted a 30-day landing visa upon arrival in Taiwan since April 1, Wang Yu-yuan, director of the European Affairs Department under the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA), said Tuesday.
Speaking at a regular news briefing, Wang said that the measure forms part of the government's drive to double tourist arrivals by 2008 amid friendly bilateral Taiwan-Slovakia relations.
Taiwan also offers landing visa treatment to visitors from the Czech Republic, Poland and Hungary, while visitors from 18 other European countries enjoy visa-free privileges when visiting Taiwan.

Taiwan opened a representative office in Slovakia in Aug. 2003, while Slovakia set up its representation in September the same year. Annual two-way Taiwan-Slovakia trade reach an average of US$200 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEBATE ENDS OVER BROADCASTER'S SLANDER SUIT AGAINST PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Taipei District Court heard a debate Tuesday over a lawsuit filed by broadcaster Jaw Shau-kong against President Chen Shui-bian and Premier Su Tseng-chang for having insinuated that Jaw was "a ghost" in October 2004. The court is scheduled to hand down a decision on April 18.

The suit was filed after Chen quoted a poem, lamenting "How desolate are we humans as ghosts abound!" to express displeasure over Jaw's news commentary charging him with wasting taxpayer money on consolidating diplomatic ties.
Then Presidential Office Secretary General Su Tseng-chang also chided Jaw as "the black sheep of the media."

Jaw told the court that Chen and Su were highly placed politicians who should have shown greater tolerance to media criticism than other people, and yet they had used stern language to attack his character. He also complained that the two were showing contempt for the law by being absent from Tuesday's debate.

Ku Li-hsiung, Chen's legal council, said Su had to use strong language to counter charges that had damaged the president's dignity and the country's foreign relations. Still, in his press releases, Su didn't use the term "the black sheep of the media," Ku said.

As for the president citing what Jaw claimed was an "insinuating" poem, Ku said the president was merely airing his personal grievances about being misunderstood in spite of his hard work to promote Taiwan's foreign relations.
Ku also explained that according to law, defendants can request that a lawyer attend a court hearing on their behalf, and that the defendant's absence does not signify disrespect for the court.

Ku hoped that Jaw would withdraw his suit to match President Chen's decision not to appeal an earlier court ruling on Chen's suit against Jaw. Jaw said he will not drop his suit until Chen apologizes publicly in the newspapers.
Chen sued Jaw, People First Party Legislator Liu Wen-hsiung and former lawmaker Tsai Chung-han for defamation by alleging that he gave a cash gift to Panama's President Mireya Moscoso.
The court in January ruled that Liu and Tsai must run a newspaper ad to publicly apologize to Chen, but threw out Chen's complaint about Jaw.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU TO HOLD ROUND TABLE ON GENDER EQUALITY APRIL 8

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) is organizing a round table meeting April 8 that aims to incorporate a gender equality provision in the TSU's version of a new constitution for Taiwan, a TSU spokeswoman said Tuesday.

Chiang Yueh-chin, TSU's director of women's affairs, said once the draft provision on gender equality is completed, her party will seek the endorsement of Vice President Annette Lu. The TSU is part of the "pan-green" camp.

Chiang said the TSU will hold two round table meetings, one April 8 in Taipei and the other April 22 in Kaohsiung, to discuss the relation between women and the constitution, and the significance of incorporating women's issues into it.

Chiang added that women seldom have the opportunity to express themselves during the drafting of a new constitution, and she hopes the round table meetings would allow more women's voices to be heard and that a draft gender equality provision would be included in the TSU's version of a new constitution.
The TSU plans to release their version of the constitution May 14, Mother's Day, and to bring it to the top of Taiwan's highest mountain, Jade Mountain, on Father's Day Aug. 8.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN VISITS SICK MOTHER IN HOSPICE

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian Tuesday extended his personal sympathies by paying a visit to a terminally ill mother in a hospice at Chung Shan Medical University Hospital in the central city of Taichung.

A story published by media last month about five impoverished children sharing a bowl of noodles caught the public's attention -- and Chen's -- out of concern for the five children's livelihood and that of their very sick mother, Wu Huei-pin, who is under hospice care after cervical cancer ravaged her health.
The seven-member family is currently supported by a meager income which Wu's husband, Wei Po-yen, earns from sporadic work chopping bamboo.

Inquiring after Wu's health, Chen gave his word he would help find good families able to offer temporary care to her children -- one daughter and four sons, with the eldest a fourth grader in elementary school and the youngest aged four.
Chen also presented Wu with a "red envelope" as a gift and a greeting card to cheer the patient.

The March news report indicated the young Weis often suffered hunger while taking turns attending their mother at the hospital. One day, a nurse, who couldn't bear to see the children hungry, invited three of them to have some noodle soup. Out of politeness, the three shared one bowl of soup and saved some for their other brothers and their mum.
According to Chou Hsi-cheng, head of the Chung Shan hospice care department, Wu is currently in stable condition but requires morphine to reduce the pain.

With a strong will to live, Wu told President Chen she had not come to the hospital to wait for her death but to seek a cure, because she believes she is being treated by a team of highly professional physicians and health care personnel.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU PROMISES TO DISCIPLINE LAWMAKER OVER DISCRIMINATORY REMARKS

TEXT.P: An opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) caucus whip said Tuesday that a TSU legislator had made improper remarks about Vietnamese brides of Taiwanese residents, and that the party "will discipline him for sure."

David Huang made the remarks after several women and human rights groups, including the Alliance for Human Rights Legislation for Immigrants and Migrants, the Awakening Foundation and Taiwan Association for Human Rights, went to the TSU headquarters to lodge a protest against TSU Legislator Liao Pen-yen's remarks.

Liao alleged that U.S. forces launched biochemical warfare during the Vietnam War, leading to the births of many deformed children, and that the government should physically examine Vietnamese brides of Taiwanese citizens to determine if they had "residual biochemical agents in them."

Faced with charges by outraged civic groups of Liao being "a racist" and "a fascist," the TSU issued a statement to say Liao's remarks were indeed "inappropriate," and that they had led to widespread misunderstanding.
"These are Liao's personal remarks, but the TSU will openly apologize to all foreign spouses of Taiwanese citizens and to the general public," the statement said.
Huang also said the party's stance remains in line with that of the immigrants' alliance and that the party will now study the matter before meting out discipline.
"We will probably suspend his rights for two months, and there may also be other options for recourse," he said.

Huang expressed the hope the public would not misinterpret one individual's remarks as representing the party, adding that the "legislative caucus will do some serious self-examination and pledge an anti-discriminatory stance."

DOC.HEADLINE: MOE PLEDGES TO REDUCE PHYSICAL BURDEN ON SCHOOL CHILDREN

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Education will carry out measures such as providing school lockers to reduce the physical burden on primary school children from carrying heavy schoolbags, Deputy Education Minister Wu Tsai-shun said Tuesday.
Wu made the remarks while briefing a group of Taiwan Solidarity Union legislators, who raised the issue of overweight schoolbags.

During the meeting, the legislators measured a schoolbag on site and found that it was as heavy as 15 kilograms. In addition to necessities such as a water canteen, a pencil case, coloring pencils and textbooks, the bag was stuffed with reference books handed out by cram schools, which most Taiwanese students attend after school.

Wu said to address the problem, the ministry has ordered education authorities in 25 counties and cities around the country to install lockers in primary schools and demanded that teachers follow their class schedules so that students would not have to bring unnecessary textbooks to school.
Also, the ministry will promote a book loan program starting in the 2006-2007 academic year, Wu said.
He urged parents and teachers to examine children's schoolbags on a daily basis and to ask them to take out unnecessary materials in order to reduce the burden.

DOC.HEADLINE: DAMAGED WARSHIP TOWED BACK FROM PALAU

TEXT.P: A Navy warship which was damaged on a training mission near Palau March 20 has been towed back to the Tsoying Navy base in Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan, a spokesman for the Ministry of National Defense said Tuesday.
Liu chih-chien said the warship, Cheng-Ho, has been towed back all the way from the South Pacific state by two Navy tugboats under the escort of one of the country's Lafayette class missile frigates.
As much as it was a successful rescue mission, Liu said, the voyage is an invaluable experience for the Navy, which rarely tugs back a vessel the size of Cheng-Ho from a country as distant as Palau.
As a matter of fact, Liu said, the Navy went out of its way to find cable capable of pulling the 4,100-ton warship.

Cheng-Ho is one of a fleet of warships that departed from Kaohsiung, early March for a training mission to Palau. It arrived in Palau March 20, but struck an unknown object underwater while being led into Malakal harbor by a local pilot.
A survey afterward revealed the blades of its propeller were damaged and could only sail at 5 miles per hour after some repairs were made on the spot.
The cause of the accident is still under investigation.
As a scene of heavy naval battles during the World War II, the sea floor around Palau is littered with the wrecks of warships, which present risks to passing ships.

Cheng-Ho is one of eight guided missile frigates built by Taiwan on the pattern of US Perry-class frigates in 1990s. Its claim to fame was in 1998 when it rammed into another warship at the Tsoying Navy Base, seriously damaging its own bow.

DOC.HEADLINE: PAN-BLUE ALLIANCE BLOCKS ARMS PROCUREMENT BILL 50TH TIME

TEXT.P: The government's arms procurement bill was blocked again -- the 50th time to be exact -- in the Legislative Yuan's Procedure Committee Tuesday by the opposition "pan-blue" alliance which enjoys a slight majority in the legislature.

The president's nominations of Control Yuan members was also forced out of the legislative agenda, after hopes of political harmony arose with the meeting between President Chen Shui-bian and opposition Kumointang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou Monday.

The KMT and its "pan-blue alliance" ally the People First Party (PFP) also shot down nearly 40 legislative proposals put forth by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and its "pan-green camp" ally, the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU).
The Procedure Committee set a legislative schedule for April 11 to review the qualifications of the nation's top prosecutor nominee, Hsieh Wen-ding.

On the same day, a legislative session will also deal with amendments to the Statute of the Special Committee on the Investigation into the Truth of the 319 Shooting Incident, as well as the reform of the pension system for civil servants. Legislative Speaker Wang Jin-pyng will convene a consultation meeting of political parties on the Special Committee statute April l7, KMT caucus whip Tseng Yung-chuan said.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Tuesday, decreasing NT$0.114 to close at NT$32.472.
A total of US$898 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$32.586 and fluctuated between NT$32.465 and NT$32.705.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES MIXED ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were mixed Tuesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for April moved down eight points to close at 6,630, with 2,1774 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for May remained unchanged at 6,620 with 376 contracts traded, while June futures lost five points to end at 6,582, with 13 contract transactions. September futures increased six points to close at 6,406, with 74 contracts traded, while December futures moved up 13 points to finish at 6,383, with six contract transactions.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Tuesday at 6,638 for April, 6,620 for May, 6,587 for June, 6,400 for September and 6,370 for December.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mostly higher.

April TE futures decreased 0.65 points to close at 294.85, with 4,464 contracts traded, while May TE futures lost 0.6 points to finish at 294, with 65 contract transactions. June TE futures moved down 0.15 points to end at 292.2, with two contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for September and December.

April TF futures increased 6.2 points to finish at 879.2, with 2,546 contracts changing hands, while May TF futures gained 8.2 points to close at 880, with 23 contracts traded. June TF futures moved up six points to end at 877, with six contract transactions, while September TF futures moved up four points to close at 861, with 12 contract transactions. December TF futures gained 22.8 points to end at 862, with one contract transaction.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO PROTEST TO JAPAN OVER TIAOYUTAI DISPUTE

TEXT.P: The government will protest to Japan through diplomatic channels over the inclusion of the Tiaoyutai islands as part of Japan's territory by Japanese school textbooks, Premier Su Tseng-chang said Tuesday.
Su said the move by Japan violates the sovereignty of the Republic of China.
The premier made the remarks during an interpellation session at the Legislative Yuan when he was asked about the issue by opposition Kuomintang Legislator Chu Feng-chi.
Chu suggested that the government issue a news statement to the Japanese government to express its protest.

DOC.HEADLINE: ANOTHER MEETING WITH PRESIDENT WILL HINGE ON AGENDA: KMT CHIEF

TEXT.P: Main opposition Kuomintang Chairman Ma Ying-jeou said Tuesday whether there will be another meeting with President Chen Shui-bian would "hinge on the agenda as well as timing."
Ma made the remarks one day after his high-profile, 130-minute meeting with the president at the Presidential Office focusing on cross-strait relations and political issues.
Ma said he and the president had clearly expressed their views in Monday's talks, and that if the two couldn't communicate on certain points, there was "no need for more talks."

But a legislative caucus whip of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party expressed hope for another meeting, and that the focus of the next meeting should be on discussing issues related to economic development.

Chen Chin-jun said the DPP legislative caucus hopes a new Chen-Ma meeting would discuss economic policies so as to stabilize the political situation and assuage animosity between the two rival parties.

"If both parties can forge a consensus on the development of the nation's economy, finances and sustainable development, then ruling and opposition parties can work together to formulate related economic development bills," Chen Chin-jun said.
Chen Chin-jun noted that during Monday's Chen-Ma meeting, both expressed stances on many issues while little consensus was reached.
After all, most of the issues depend on how Chinese President Hu Jintao will respond, Chen Chin-jun said.

The legislator was referring to Ma's request that cross-strait talks resume based on the "1992 consensus," -- or a tacit agreement on "one China, different interpretations" between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait. The president said he would only respect the so-called "1992 consensus" if Hu publicly announces that Beijing accepts the agreement of one China with each side having different interpretations of what 'one China" means.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO PROGRESS ON CHINA-VATICAN TIES: MOFA

TEXT.P: The Vatican and China did not engage in any official talks on establishing diplomatic relations during their latest contact, a Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) official said Tuesday.

According to Wang Yu-yuan, director-general of the MOFA's Department of European Affairs, high-ranking Vatican officials have promised to inform Taiwan if the Holy See starts talks on establishing diplomatic ties with Beijing.

The Vatican -- the only European country to maintain diplomatic relations with Taiwan -- has been trying to improve its relations with China and has maintained on-and-off contact with Beijing, Wang noted.

Wang said freedom of religion has been the main problem hampering the establishment of Vatican-China diplomatic relations because the Vatican is concerned about the rights of Catholics in China, which does not recognize the authority of bishops and other officials appointed by the Catholic church.

Wang said that since 1992, the Vatican has mentioned plans to "move its embassy" from Taipei to Beijing and that China has put forth several conditions on the establishment of diplomatic ties with the Vatican, including that it must not interfere with China's internal affairs and must sever diplomatic ties with Taiwan.
The matter is at a standstill because the Vatican has refused to compromise on some of these conditions, Wang said.
On reports that the pope is planning to visit Asia, Wang said he had not heard of any such plans.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPOWER PURCHASES URANIUM FROM AUSTRALIA FOR FIRST TIME

TEXT.P: Taiwan Power Company (Taipower) will start receiving delivery of uranium from Australia at the end of this year, Taipower officials said Tuesday.

The officials said the company has signed contracts with BHP Billiton and Energy Resources of Australia to purchase 200,000 pounds and 500,000 pounds of uranium per year, respectively, from each company.
After delivery, the uranium will be sent to the United States to be made into nuclear fuel rods that will be used as a source of nuclear energy in domestic reactors.

The officials said Taipower currently appropriates a budget of around NT$4 billion (US$122.69 million) annually for its nuclear fuel budget. It has purchased uranium mines from various other countries, including Canada, France, the United States and Africa.
This is the first time that Taipower has brought uranium mines from Australia.

DOC.HEADLINE: MND TO BUILD HOUSING UNITS IN MILITARY CAMPS TO RETAIN SERVICEMEN

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense plans to build large numbers of housing units in military camps throughout Taiwan as an incentive to encourage servicemen to remain in uniform, Minister of National Defense Lee Jye disclosed Tuesday.

Answering questions during an interpellation session at the Legislative Yuan, Lee said the plan, to be finalized in a couple of months, will allow military families to live in these housing units, so that armed forces personnel can take care of both their duties and their dependents.
Lee also noted that some retired servicemen and their dependents are still without a home of their own, despite government efforts to help them.

He said the ministry will propose an amendment to the relevant law to help those servicemen who are financially under-privileged to obtain bank loans and purchase new housing units built on the sites of original villages for military families.

DOC.HEADLINE: ARMS PROCUREMENT PROPOSAL NOT DELAYED: MND

TEXT.P: The U.S. government did not quote a price until 2004 for the weapons it decided to sell to Taiwan in 2001, said the Ministry of National Defense (MND) Tuesday, stressing that it had not delayed a proposal for arms procurement.

The MND held a press conference to respond to questions about delays in introducing the arms procurement bill that were raised by the opposition Kuomintang Chairman Ma Ying-jeou during his meeting with President Chen Shui-bian Monday.

The MND did not propose the arms deal nine days before the recess of a Legislative Yuan session with a view to having it passed during that session, Vice Admiral Liang Kung-kai, director general of the MND's Strategic Planning Department, said.
He said that instead of a special budget, MND has changed its plan to acquire the three major items through regular annual budgets.

For this year, the MND has proposed a NT$5.6 billion addendum budget for the arms procurement package which will be presented to the Legislative Yuan after being approved by the Executive Yuan, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRC RECOGNITION OF ROC WOULD BE GOOD: PREMIER

TEXT.P: If Beijing "were to recognize us as the Republic of China, it would be great, " Premier Su Tseng-chang said Tuesday.

Replying to a question from opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Legislator Chu Feng-chih at the legislature, Su said that if China agreed to what Taiwan calls "one China, with both sides of the Taiwan Strait free to interpret its meaning, " that would be "a major breakthrough" and the government would support it.
However, Su went on, it is unfortunate that the People's Republic of China has never recognized Taiwan's definition of "one China" as "the Republic of China."

If Beijing were to recognize the principle of "one China, with each side free to interpret its meaning, " that would mean the two sides of the strait are equal and that Taiwan and China could get along with each other on an equal footing, "and that is the greatest expectation of the government," said the premier.

During a meeting with KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou a day earlier, President Chen Shui-bian challenged the opposition party to urge Chinese President Hu Jintao to declare that his government recognizes the principle of "one China, with both sides of the strait free to interpret its meaning."
As KMT Honorary Chairman Lien Chan is to visit China and will likely meet with Hu later this month, Chen called on Ma to request that Lien forward the message to Hu, to which Ma agreed.

Chen expressed confidence that if asked, Hu will never declare that Beijing's "one China" -- the PRC, which governs China and claims sovereignty over Taiwan -- could be interpreted as the ROC governing Taiwan.
If Hu agrees to the principle of "one China, with both sides of the strait free to interpret its meaning, I will absolutely respect it," said Chen.

However, Chang Jung-kung, deputy executive director of the KMT's Central Policy Committee, said Chen himself does not believe in that principle and has even tried to deny the ROC version of "one China." That being the case, he questioned how Lien could possibly forward such an insincere message to Hu.

Since Chen is not sincere about "one China, " much less so about "one China, with both sides free to interpret its meaning, " he is in no position to ask Lien to do something that even Chen himself does not believe in, Chang added.

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG CITY GOVERNMENT COMMITTEE TO HELP REDUCE SUICIDE RATE

TEXT.P: The Kaohsiung city government will form an interdepartmental committee to coordinate efforts in reducing the number of suicides in the city, acting Kaohsiung Mayor Yeh Chu-lan disclosed Tuesday.

Yeh said members of the the Spiritual Health Committee will include the chiefs of all related city government departments, who will work with civic groups to offer help such as counselling services to the city's residents, and that she herself will serve as convener of the committee.

According to statistics released by the Cabinet-level Department of Health, suicide has been the ninth major cause of death in Taiwan for the past eight consecutive years, and that in 2003 and 2004, Kaohsiung City ranked ninth among the top 10 cities in Taiwan in terms of high suicide rates.

Yeh said she ordered the establishment of the committee because Kaohsiung is transforming into a metropolis whose residents are susceptible to various forms of stress, as well as other complications that might prompt the fragile or depressed to kill themselves.
She added that the city government must take timely measures to maintain the spiritual health of the city's residents.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOE TO INTEGRATE AFTER-SCHOOL PROGRAMS FOR PRIMARY STUDENTS

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Education (MOE) will integrate existing after-school programs for primary students to better supervise the quality of such programs, officials said Tuesday.

According to Deputy Education Minister Chou Tsan-der, all after-school programs will be supervised by education authorities and local schools can either operate the programs by themselves or outsource them to the private sector.
The targets of the programs will be schoolchildren aged between 6 and 12 and the services provided by the programs will include care and guidance on school work.
Any private operators who plan to launch such programs will have to pass a review by the education authorities and obtain a license, Chou said.

To meet the needs of working parents who cannot care for their children, after-school programs are available at various primary schools in Taiwan. There are also more than 1,000 private operators running such programs, which at the moment are supervised by social affairs authorities.
Chou that said in the future, private language schools and cram schools can apply to launch after-school programs, but the programs must be separated from other provided cram programs.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHILD'S MIND GREATEST NATURAL ASSET ON EARTH: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Tuesday feels great pain when he hears of child abuse or cases in which parents murder their children before taking their own lives, because the mind of a child is the greatest asset on earth.
Chen made the remarks during an inspection tour of the Nantou Education and Nursing Institute under the Ministry of the Interior in central Taiwan.

Acknowledging that 9,897 child abuse cases were reported around Taiwan in 2005, Chen said he has always been saddened by the plight of abused or maltreated children and that it is especially painful to learn about incidents involving parents in financial straits taking their own lives along with those of their children.

Chen said parents should love and treasure their kids because their inquisitive minds are the greatest natural assets in the world. He exhorted parents, particularly those in financial distress, to have the courage to persist and not give up.
As Tuesday marked the nation's Children's Day, Chen said his administration is determined to offer better welfare services for disadvantaged children.

He said the Interior Ministry has activated a high-risk family screening mechanism to protect young children from abuse and maltreatment. A total of 2,843 children and adolescents have benefited from this domestic violence and abuse prevention mechanism, Chen said.

The government has also decided to earmark NT$135 million for an emergency subsidy program for abused children and teenagers this year, marking a three-fold growth from last year's funding. Under the project, the government will offer NT$3,000 in subsidies to each abused child, a move that will benefit 15,000 disadvantaged children.

The Nantou institute, which provides shelter, rehabilitation, education, job training and supportive work opportunities for seriously mentally challenged children, was seriously damaged in the devastating 9-21 earthquake of 1999 but has been rebuilt from ruins.

Chen expressed delight to see the children living enriched lives in the newly rebuilt compound, which boasts beautiful gardens and courtyards, and humane and family-style living quarters, as well as modern rehabilitation and education facilities.

A group of mentally challenged children living at the institute performed a traditional dragon dance to welcome Chen's arrival. They had taken great pains to learn and practice the dance in preparation for the performance. Chen said he was moved by their performance and presented a big "red envelope" with cash inside as a gift to them.
While touring a workshop in the complex, Chen dressed in a work jacket, hat and mask and joined mentally challenged students in rolling dough and making cake.

Chen gave generous praise for all the students at the institute for their perseverance in overcoming their disabilities. He also expressed his tribute and admiration for the faculty members for their devotion in educating and training the students to live independently and hold down jobs.

DOC.HEADLINE: EU'S ATTITUDE TOWARD TAIWAN'S WHO BID MAY BE BETTER THIS YEAR

TEXT.P: Wang Yu-yuan, the director of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs' (MOFA) Department of European Affairs said Tuesday that the European Union's (E.U.) attitude toward Taiwan's bid to join the World Health Organization (WHO) this year should be better than last year.
Wang said the E.U. is going to hold a meeting on East Asian affairs Wednesday and that the issue of Taiwan's WHO bid could be on the agenda for discussion.

Wang explained that this year, the E.U. should be more positive about the issue of Taiwan's bid to enter the WHO because Taiwan has been tirelessly lobbying E.U. countries on the issue, and both sides understand each other's position quite well. Wang added that the E.U. is supportive of Taiwan playing a more concrete role in the global fight against avian flu.
According to Wang, the E.U. seems to be positive about Taiwan's WHO bid, but the final results are still unknown.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT POISED TO PUSH FOR CONSTITUTIONAL REFORMS

TEXT.P: The government is poised to initiate a constitutional reform drive despite anticipating difficulties, Ng Chiau-tong, executive director of the Hand-in-Hand To Protect Taiwan Alliance, quoted Presidential Secretary-General Tan Sun Chen as saying Tuesday.

Ng made the remarks at a news conference following a meeting held by the alliance earlier the same day in which Chen and Lee Chun-i, head of a constitutional reform task force under the Presidential Office, attempted to explain the government's stance regarding the issue -- one of the promises made by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) before it came to power in 2000.

According to Ng, Chen made it clear that the government will still launch its constitutional reform drive, although it is a highly difficult task that needs to be approved by three-quarters of lawmakers and endorsed by the public in a referendum.
Chen was quoted by Ng as saying that the government is determined to carry out the mission and that it is achievable as long as people throw their support behind the government.

Lee said during the meeting that he is hopeful that a draft version of new constitutional provisions can be referred to the Legislative Yuan in September this year to allow the legislature to vote on the draft in the first half of the next year.

Lawmakers would have time to discuss the draft -- two legislative sessions -- before voting on it, Lee said, adding that should the draft gain legislative approval, it could be put forth in a referendum for the public to vote on by the end of 2007 following a six-month period of publicity by the government.
In addition to the DPP, Lee said, the Taiwan Solidarity Union and the academic sector will also put forward their own draft versions of new constitutional provisions.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT TO HOLD SUSTAINABLE ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT CONFERENCE

TEXT.P: The government is planning to hold a sustainable economic development conference that political party and business leaders, as well as delegates from environmental protection and social welfare groups, will be welcome to attend, officials said Tuesday.
If the opposition parties do not participate, "we will be disappointed, but the conference will go on as scheduled, " Vice Premier Tsai Ing-wen said.

Premier Su Tseng-chang said he would like to meet with main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou to extend an invitation and discuss economic and social issues with him. "But he has just met with the president. If I invite him now, I could be accused of trying to stage a show," Su added.
Responding to Su's remarks, Ma said that if the premier has an idea, he should "just do it."
According to Tsai, the conference will be held in stages, with the preparatory stage lasting from April 17 to May 5 and panel discussions scheduled for May 5 through June 9.

As Taiwan's economy is affected by a number of regional factors, she said she would not rule out the possibility of holding "regional conferences" prior to the plenary meeting scheduled for after mid-June when the current session of the legislature ends.

DOC.HEADLINE: WELFARE GROUP ADVOCATES CONCEPT OF 'PUT CHILDREN FIRST'

TEXT.P: A welfare group held a press conference Tuesday -- Children's Day -- in which it named 2006 as "The Year of Putting Children First" and urged the public to focus on the rights of children.

The Child Welfare League Foundation (CWLF) submitted four demands calling for more attention to be paid to children rights and more national budget to be appropriated for children. The press conference was also attended by Minister of the Interior Lee Yi-yang.

The Ministry of the Interior (MOI) has decided to subsidize "high-risk families" by providing each child in such families with NT$ 3,000 per month, Lee said, adding that the MOI also plans to boost the number of social worker in Taiwan from 189 to 508.
Wang Yu-min, head of the CWLF, also asked that more children-friendly television programs be created and that Children's Day be reinstated as a national holiday.
In addition, the CWLF called for improvements to the educational environment and healthcare system for children, with parenting education designed to prevent child abuse.

DOC.HEADLINE: CO-PROSPERITY FUND AVAILABLE FOR CENTRAL AMERICAN ALLIES

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan is expected to approve the remaining NT$5 billion of a government fund to assist Taiwan's diplomatic allies in Central America develop their economies, Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng said Tuesday.
Wang made the remarks during a seminar in which a delegation of visiting Central American parliamentarians participated.
According to Wang, the Legislative Yuan will approve the use of the money in June so that it can be disposed of in the second half of this year.

Combined with NT$2.5 billion that was approved earlier, the total amount of NT$7.5 billion allocated for the "Co-prosperity Fund" will be available for carrying out development projects in cooperation with Central American diplomatic partners, he went on.

The Executive Yuan's Development Fund generated NT$5 billion and the International Cooperation and Development Fund under the Ministry of Foreign Affairs contributed NT$2.5 billion to create the fund.

Its establishment was announced by President Chen Shui-bian last year during a visit to Nicaragua to attend a summit of the Republic of China and Central American countries and the Dominican Republic.

The fund was set up with the aim of helping Central American diplomatic partners develop their economies with Taiwan's development experience, Wang said, adding that it also encourages Taiwan companies to invest in the region, where they can take advantage of a free trade agreement between the United States and countries in the region.

The Legislative Yuan has asked the Council for Economic Planning and Development and the Ministry of Economic Affairs to come up with sound development projects in Central America to make the region more attractive to potential Taiwan investors, Wang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT'S REMARKS ON CONSTITUTION CRITICIZED AS 'SELF-CONTRADICTORY'

TEXT.P: Two pro-independence activists criticized President Chen Shui-bian Tuesday for telling opposition Kuomintang Chairman Ma Ying-jeou at a meeting the previous day that the Constitution of the Republic of China has been "indigenized" and deals with only "one Taiwan."

Huang Chao-tang, chairman of the World United Formosans for Independence, noted that in his two-hour meeting with Ma, the president said that the nation's Constitution, which has been amended seven times, has already been "indigenized or Taiwanized."
Huang said that it is "a bit too far-fetched" for the president to claim that the Constitution now deals with only "one Taiwan," instead of "one China."

Liu Yi-teh, deputy secretary-general of the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union -- an ally of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party in the "pan-green camp" -- said the president's remarks show that either he does not understand the Constitution, or he was trying to win support from members of the "pan-green camp."
"President Chen's remarks are self-contradictory, because if the Constitution were already about only one Taiwan, why would he still want to push for more constitutional reforms?" he asked.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT RECEIVES MEDAL OF HONOR FROM PARLACEN

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu received a medal of honor from the Central American Parliament (Parlacen) Tuesday for her contribution to promoting public interests, social justice, elimination of inequality and regional integration in Central America.

Parlacen Speaker Julio Palacios, who is visiting Taipei at the head of a delegation of Central American parliamentarians, conferred the Order of Francisco Morazan on Lu in a ceremony at the Presidential Office.

Palacios said the honor was conferred on Lu because of her three noble characteristics -- rationality, lenience and humanism. He also lauded Lu for her dedication to public service, regional integration and cooperation, as well as the elimination of poverty and inequality.

For her part, Lu said she was grateful for the Parlacen's recognition of her life-long efforts at promoting peace, democracy and human rights. The decoration also symbolizes the friendly relationship between Taiwan and the Central American Parliament, she added.

Lu said she has invited Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng and Palacios to jointly push for the establishment of a Democratic Pacific Parliamentary Alliance that will be composed of Parlacen members and parliamentarians from all the 28 member countries of the Democratic Pacific Union, a non-governmental organization which was formally inaugurated last August under Lu's promotion. On hand to witness the decoration ceremony were Wang, Vice Foreign Affairs Minister Huang Lung-yuan and many ruling Democratic Progressive Party lawmakers and business executives.

DOC.HEADLINE: NUMBER OF INTERNATIONAL FLIGHT PASSENGERS UP: DGBAS

TEXT.P: The number of passengers travelling through Taiwan's airports totalled 6.93 million in the first two months of this year, down 0.7 percent from the year-earlier level, the Directorate General of Budgets, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) said Tuesday.

Among them, the number of passengers on international flights accounted for 3.73 million, marking an 8 percent year-on-year increase. However, domestic flight passengers fell 10.9 percent compared to the same period last year, totalling 2.79 million passengers.
The number of transit passengers accounted for 410,000, up 4.6 percent from the year-earlier level.
In related news, the DGBAS said there were 27 million people travelling via Taiwan's railway and 58 million Mass Rapid Transit (MRT) passengers during the same period.

DeLay Is Quitting Race and House, Officials Report
Representative Tom DeLay has decided to leave the U.S. Congress, House officials said Monday night. His decision was first reported Monday by MSNBC and by Time magazine on its Web site. Wall Street Journal: Once-Tiny Cerberus Leads Purchase That Brings GM An Eventual $14 Billion Private Equity's Growing Role
Last week at the Four Seasons Hotel in New York, Cerberus Capital Management LP's leader, Stephen Feinberg, made his final pitch for a much bigger deal: a controlling stake in one of the crown jewels of General Motors Corp., its giant General Motors Acceptance Corp. lending arm. Cerberus, a fast-growing fund that now manages US$18 billion of investors' money, is pouring a huge chunk into the GMAC deal.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR MAY VISIT U.S. AGAIN IN JUNE

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou may visit the United States again in June if Taipei manages to win the top award of a global competition for wireless broadband Internet connectivity, a city government official said Tuesday.

Taipei ranked among the top seven cities around the world in terms of wireless broadband connectivity in a competition sponsored by the Intelligent Community Forum, a non-governmental organization dedicated to promoting broadband economy.
By the end of June, 90 percent of Taipei citizens will get wired through broadband connectivity, the official said.
If Taipei manages to the top award in June, the official said, the city government will not rule out the possibility of having Mayor Ma travel to New York to receive the trophy in person.
Ma, who doubles as chairman of the main opposition Kuomintang, just concluded a 10-day visit to the United States that took him to major U.S. cities, including Washington, D.C. and New York.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, April 5, or the eighth day of the third month of the Year of the Dog according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1725: Giovanni Casanova, Italian adventurer famous for his amorous conquests, is born.
1793: President George Washington approves plans for new public buildings and roads in the American capital city.
1827: Joseph Lister, British surgeon and discoverer of antiseptic agents, is born. He demonstrated in 1865 that carbolic acid was an effective antiseptic.
1895: Oscar Wilde, the author of the highly successful plays "The Importance of Being Earnest" and "Lady Windemere's Fan," sues the Marquess of Queensberry for libel.
1896: The first modern Olympic Games begin in Athens.
1900: Spencer Tracy, American actor who won an Oscar two years in a row for "Captain Courageous" (1937) and "Boys Town" (1938), is born.
1915: Jack Johnson, the first black world heavyweight boxing champion, losses his title to the "Great White Hope" Jess Willard.
1916: Gregory Peck, American actor noted for both his fine film performances and his work for humanitarian causes, is born.
1941: Allied forces recapture Addis Ababa in Ethiopia during World War II.
1949: The Chinese national government begins talks with Chinese Communists.
1950: The Executive Yuan grants Taiwan authority to carry out self-government by popular elections in counties and cities within two months.
1951: Julius and Ethel Rosenberg are sentenced to death in the United States for giving away atomic weapons secrets to the Soviet Union.
1954: More than 14,000 Chinese Communist POW's in Korea who refused to return to the Chinese mainland take their oath to join the ROC armed forces.
1955: British Prime Minister Sir Winston Churchill announces his resignation. He is succeeded by Foreign Secretary Sir Anthony Eden.
1960: The film "Ben Hur" wins 10 Oscars.
1964: Douglas MacArthur, American general who served as U.S. chief of staff and commanded the Allied forces in the South Pacific during World War II, dies at the age of 84. He commanded U.N. forces in Korea until a conflict over strategy led to his dismissal by President Harry S. Truman.
1975: President Chiang Kai-shek passes away in Taiwan at the age of 89.
1976: Howard Robard Hughes, American film producer, aviator, and multimillionaire, dies at the age of 71. He founded Hughes Aircraft Corporation, broke the air speed record in 1935, and flew around the world in record time in 1938.
1976: The National Youth Commission reports helping some 31,000 youths find jobs since its establishment 10 years earlier.
1982: The British task force to oust Argentinian forces from the Falkland Islands sets sail.
1988: Arab gunmen seize a Kuwait Airways Boeing 747 flying from Bangkok to Kuwait. The 111 hostages aboard were freed on April 20 when the hijackers surrendered in Algiers.
1989: A political pact between the independent trade union federation Solidarity and the government of Wojciech Jaruzelski ends Communist rule in Poland.
1990: The Republic of China reestablishes diplomatic relations with the Kingdom of Lesotho. Peking (Beijing) severs ties with Lesotho two days later.
1991: President George Bush orders U.S. Air Force transport planes to begin dropping supplies to Kurdish refugees in northern Iraq.
1994: Israel begins to withdraw from the Gaza Strip.
1998: Japan's 3,911 meter-long Akashi Kaikyo Bridge, the world's longest suspension bridge linking the main islands of Honshu and Shikoku, is opened to traffic.
2000: Democratic Progressive Party Chairman Lin I-hsiung pays a visit to James Soong, chairman of the newly founded People First Party, to seek PFP support for the abolition of the upcoming National Assembly election.
2001: President Chen Shui-bian holds amiable talks with the Dalai Lama, the exiled Tibetan spiritual leader, in a landmark encounter at the Presidential Office.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A good honest man, after educating the people for seven years, will be able to lead them to war."

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. APPLAUDS CHEN-MA MEETING: ROC REP
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 4 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The recent meeting between President Chen Shui-bian and opposition Kuomintang Chairman Ma Ying-jeou has won applause in Washington, Taiwan's representative to the United States said Tuesday.
David Ta-wei Lee said Washington has been informed of the details of the meeting by the Taipei office of the American Institute in Taiwan.

The U.S. government hopes there will be more interaction between Taiwan's ruling and opposition parties over the next two years to facilitate the formation of consensus on economic and cross-Taiwan Strait issues, Lee said.
Lee was responding to a question from the press, after a ceremony in which he decorated U.S. Congressman Henry Hyde (R-Ill.) with the Order of Brilliant Star with Grand Cordon.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S DEMOCRACY A MODEL FOR REST OF WORLD: U.S. CONGRESSMAN
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 4 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin and Taijing Wu)

TEXT.P: U.S. Congressman Henry Hyde said Tuesday that Taiwan's democracy is a model for the rest of the world to follow.

Hyde, a member of the U.S. House of Representatives' International Relations Committee, made the remarks while being presented with the Order of the Brilliant Star with Grand Cordon by David Ta-wei Lee, Taiwan's top envoy to the U.S., on behalf of President Chen Shui-bian.

Noting that Taiwan has experienced the peaceful transition of power from one party to another, Hyde said this proves that democracy is applicable everywhere in the world. He added that the example of Taiwan is of great help to the rest of the world on the path toward democratization.
Hyde, who has publicly announced that he will not seek another term, also said he supports the signing of a free trade agreement between the United States and Taiwan.
Meanwhile, Lee said that Hyde, who played an instrumental role in drafting and passing the Taiwan Relations Act, has been a strong supporter of Taiwan for decades.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP CAUCUS HEAD HOPES FOR 2ND CHEN-MA MEETING

TEXT.P: The head of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislative caucus on Wednesday expressed the hope that opposition Kuomintang Chairman Ma Ying-jeou will meet President Chen Shui-bian again before long to facilitate the formation of consensus on Taiwan's economic development.

DPP legislative party whip Chen Ching-chun said he hopes that Ma will accept invitations either to a second "Chen-Ma meeting" or a supra-party sustainable economic development conference that the administration is planning aimed at settling differences and working out new economic policies.

Chen Ching-chun said that in the face of increasing globalization and China's rise, it is imperative for Taiwan's ruling and opposition parties to work in concert so that consensus on economic development policies can be reached.

He said the first "Chen-Ma meeting, " held at the Presidential Office Monday, marked "the beginning of a constructive competition between rival parties." He called for Ma to meet Chen again or take part in the economic development conference under planning to "seek remedial measures to help rev up Taiwan's economy."

Chen Ching-chun also said he hopes that Ma will present the Kuomintang's own version on how to reinvigorate Taiwan's economy in the shortest possible period to pave the way for the convening of a sustainable economic development conference in mid-June with party delegates and business and trade leaders participating.
He urged Ma to respond without delay, saying that "Ma may not be in a hurry because of considerations of the 2008 presidential election, but the country cannot wait any longer."

President Chen met with Ma Monday for an unprecedented meeting during which the two leaders talked about a wide range of topics, including the definition of the controversial "one China" policy and the cessation of the National Unification Council and its guidelines.
After the meeting, Chen's approval ratings soared by 11 percentage points, while Ma's dropped by nine percentage points, according to a local television poll.

DOC.HEADLINE: PERSONALITY TESTS POPULAR IN JOB INTERVIEWS: POLL

TEXT.P: More Taiwan businesses are relying on personality tests than on professional tests in screening inexperienced job candidates, according to the results of a recent survey.
Thirteen percent of businesses responding to the survey give personality tests to fresh graduates during job interviews, compared with 5.4 percent which give professional tests.

By industry, personality tests and presentation are more commonly used by the financial industry than other industries, while the technological industry prefers thesis review, written tests on professional subjects and onsite work.
Mass interviews are most commonly used in the service industry. Intelligence tests and foreign language tests are preferred by the manufacturing industry.
The survey was conducted by the magazine Career between March 8-17 on 260 human resource officers from the top 1,000 businesses in the country.
The survey shows that compared with last year, 50 percent of the businesses will recruit a similar number of fresh graduates this year.

While 40 percent of the businesses in the service industry will increase their job openings for fresh graduates this year, businesses in the financial industry see the most significant decrease in their job openings.

Seventy-seven percent of the businesses said the starting salaries they offer for fresh graduates this year are similar to the year-earlier levels. The ratio of businesses that will raise their starting salaries is the highest in the technological industry, and the ratio of businesses that will lower their starting salaries is the highest in the financial sector.
On the educational background of the job candidates, 69 percent of the businesses said they are hiring more fresh graduates with a master's degree.
Meanwhile, 22 percent of the businesses said they will hire fresh graduates in the form of temporary employment this year, with the technological industry seeing the highest ratio at 29 percent.
