DOC.HEADLINE: ICDF TO SEND 24 VOLUNTEERS TO 11 COUNTRIES

TEXT.P: The International Cooperation and Development Fund (ICDF) will send 24 long-term volunteers to 11 countries this year to provide help in Chinese-language teaching and health related activities, a spokesman said.
The ICDF spokesman said it is the first time that the ICDF is sending volunteers to Ecuador in South America and to Kiribati in the central Pacific.

The group of volunteers includes a retired bank manager, a Taiwan Power Co. engineer, school teachers and others. They will be sent abroad between April and May after undergoing 16 days of training, the spokesman added.

ICDF CHairman Huang Chih-fang, who concurrently serves as minister of foreign affairs, said that since the overseas voluntary program was launched 10 years ago, it has won lots of praise from other countries and has helped them enhance their national competitiveness.

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG FURNITURE MAKERS ACCUSE CHINA OF DUMPING

TEXT.P: Angry at what they call a "deluge of "shoddy, counterfeit and low-priced" Chinese furniture into Taiwan, furniture makers in the Kaohsiung area will launch a series of protests and form their own "trust" against what they claim to be dumping by China.

Wang Kun-hsiang, chairman of the Kaohsiung Furniture Industrial Association, said Chinese furniture and home accessories have been flooding into the Taiwan market and have grabbed a more than 50 percent share of the market, posing a great threat to Taiwan's furniture industry.
Wang said the "made in China" furniture and home accessories are denounced particularly because they are sold at lower-than-normal prices and most of the Chinese exports are "copycat" products.

He said that in addition to launching a series of protests against the Chinese dumping, the Kaohsiung Furniture Industrial Association will organize all of its member companies into an alliance to promote sales of domestically-produced "high-quality" furniture.

This marks the second time in less than one month that a Taiwan industry has accused China of dumping. Taiwan towel makers, mostly from the central county of Yunlin, took to the streets in March to denounce the deluge of cheap Chinese products entering Taiwan.

A public hearing is scheduled to be held April 7 under the sponsorship of the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) on the results of investigations into Chinese toweling imports and the Taiwan makers' outcry.

After investigations into the Taiwan towel makers' complaints about Chinese dumping, members of the investigation commission under the MOEA reached a conclusion last month that local towel makers have been harmed by the flood of cheap Chinese products entering the local market.
Taiwan towel makers have demanded that the government increase its customs duty on Chinese toweling imports from the current level of 10.5 percent to 50 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: SALES OF IMPORTED CARS DOUBLE IN MARCH

TEXT.P: Despite a decline in Taiwan's car market, sales of imported cars remained brisk in March, according to tallies released Wednesday.
A total of 6,116 imported cars were sold in the Taiwan market in March, more than double the figure recorded in the previous month.
The year-on-year fall in total car sales expanded from 17.8 percent in February to 30 percent in March.

In March, the top six brands of locally assembled or manufactured cars were Toyota, China Motor, Yulon, Ford, Mazda and Suzuki, in that order. The top six imported car brands were Volkswagen, Toyota, Mercedes Benz, BMW, Suzuki and Mazda.

The top 10 locally assembled or manufactured car models in March were Toyota Altis, Toyota Vios, Toyota Wish, Nissan Sentra, Suzuki Swift, Toyota Camry, Honda CR-V, Mitsubishi Lancer, Ford Escape and Mazda 3.

The top 10 imported car models in the same month were Volkswagen Golf, Lexus RX, Toyota Previa, Mercedes Benz E-Class, Mercedes Benz S-Class, Volkswagen Passat, Mazda 6, Lexus IS250, BMW 3 series and Mazda MPV.
While the number of Mercedes Benz E-Classes and Mercedes Benz S-Classes sold in March totalled 518, a total of 813 Volkswagen Golfs and Volkswagen Passats were sold during the same period.

In March, 1,084 Volkswagen cars were sold, up 34 percent from the same time last year. The brand seized a 17.7 percent share of the Taiwan market and remained the most popular imported car brand in the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP SHOULD UNVEIL DISCOURSE ON PARTY POLICY, DIRECTION: DPP CAUCUS

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) should unveil a discourse on the party's policy and direction, a whip of the DPP in the Legislative Yuan said Wednesday.

Chen Chin-jun made the remarks amid reports that the DPP, in order to reverse the impression of its lackluster performance over the years, is preparing to unveil the party's first discourse in six years.
According to Chen, since the DPP first took over the helm of the nation in 2000, its performance and the results of reforms have been far better than that of the previous Kuomintang administration.
"But since the DPP has had no comprehensive discourse to defend its policy, it has been misunderstood by the people," he claimed.

He noted that the DPP has faced an opposition-dominated legislature and repeated boycotts over the past six years, so much so, he claimed, that its administrative achievements have been "deliberately smeared."
"Under such circumstances, the public harbors misunderstandings about the party, causing the party's popularity to slip to a new low," he said.
"We should sort out the results achieved by the DPP so as to clearly explain them to the public, " Chen said, adding that "the matter is too important to procrastinate over any longer."
The DPP, the Executive Yuan and the DPP legislative caucus should use plain language to let the public understand what the party has done over the years, he added.
The discourse will become the major reference of the party in coming elections, DPP sources said.

DPP Secretary-General Lin Chia-lung, Minister without Portfolio Lin Hsi-yao and Government Information Office Minister Cheng Wen-tsang held an organizational meeting Tuesday to exchange views and delegate the work involved.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT-DPP SUMMIT UNNECESSARY: KMT SPOKESWOMAN

TEXT.P: Leaders of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) should first try to forge common ground within the party on major national polices before seeking to hold meetings with opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou, KMT spokeswoman Cheng Lee-wen said Wednesday.

Claiming that the DPP's predicament lies in President Chen Shui-bian's "reckless" approach in dealing with major issues, leaving no room for full discussion among the party elite, Cheng said that the DPP should build consensus on issues of major concern in the first place before reaching out to other parties.
DPP Chairman Yu Shyi-kun and Premier Su Tseng-chang have displayed an interest in meeting the KMT chairman after Ma met the president Monday.

Claiming that the hopes of Yu and Su to hold meetings with the KMT chairman is a clear reflection of the DPP's worry about the future, Cheng said that Ma met Chen mainly to share his experiences from his recent U.S. visit with the aim of helping amend sharp differences between the ruling and opposition camps and preventing the government from being crippled.

Asked whether Ma will attend a national conference on sustainable economic growth to be convened by the Executive Yuan, Cheng quoted Ma as stressing that the government should "just do it" instead of merely playing lip service to the issue.

"It is unnecessary to hold a KMT-DPP summit for the time being, " Cheng said, suggesting that the DPP implement the outcome of the first national economic development conference in its efforts to revive Taiwan's economy. The KMT has no plans to take part in a KMT-DPP summit, she added.

Cheng called a recent drop in Ma's public approval rating following the Chen-Ma meeting a "short-term phenomenon " and described it as a "natural development" because many "pan blue alliance" supporters were opposed to the idea of Ma meeting Chen.

Following the April 3 Chen-Ma meeting, the KMT chairman's public approval ratings fell to 58 percent from a peak of 67 percent in recent months after he returned from the United States March 29, according to the results of a recent public opinion survey. Meanwhile, Chen's public approval rating has been hovering at around just 20 percent, but his disapproval rating fell after the Chen-Ma meeting.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR HOPEFUL PROMOTES 'GREEN' FUNERALS

TEXT.P: Former Taipei Deputy Mayor Yeh Chin-chuan expressed hope Wednesday that more people will buy into what he called "environmentally friendly" concepts about funerals and burials in densely populated Taiwan.

Yeh, who is running in the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) primary for the party's nomination in the year-end mayoral election, released his campaign platform on environmentally friendly funeral services that include tree burials, ash-spreading burials and sea burials.

As the population is aging and the space available in public cemeteries is shrinking, Yeh said that if elected, he will propose a project to build large ossuaries in northern and southern areas of Taipei City.
Bones from existing cemeteries will be placed in the two ossuaries and the evacuated cemeteries will be turned into parks, he said.
He also proposed building what are known in Taiwan as "five-star funeral homes" that offer professional funeral services so that the bereaved do not have to make the arrangements themselves.
"We're not encouraging luxurious and extravagant funeral services. Rather, we would like to see such services rendered in good order and in a dignified manner," Yeh said.
These two proposals are aimed at "modernizing" Taiwan's funeral and burial traditions, bringing them more into conformity with "green" concepts that include respecting the dignity of life, he added.

With regard to reports that some funeral homes are competing so furiously with each other for business that they are damaging the interests of bereaved families, Yeh said he will put forth a reform program centered on improving the business environment.

Rules and regulations will be drafted in which the rights and obligations of hospitals, funeral homes and families of the deceased are clearly defined and the bereaved will have total freedom to choose a professional service provider, according to Yeh.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN EXPORTS TO SOUTH KOREA UP 27 PERCENT IN FIRST TWO MONTHS

TEXT.P: Taiwan exported US$1.02 billion-worth of products and services to South Korea between Jan. 1 and Feb. 28 this year, up 27 percent over the year-earlier level, the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) reported Wednesday.

According to the latest MOEA tallies, the amount of Taiwan's foreign trade stood at US$62.9 billion in the January-February period, with exports totaling US$32.31 billion and imports amounting to US$30.59 billion, representing a growth of 14 percent and 15.3 percent, respectively, over the figures posted in the same period of 2005.
As a result, the country secured a trade surplus of US$1.73 billion in the first two months of this year, marking a decline of US$90 million from the year-earlier level, MOEA officials said.

As the result of spiraling crude oil prices and Taiwan's soaring imports, Taiwan's two-way trade posted a deficit of US$600 million in February -- the first of its kind in 13 months, the officials said.

China and Hong Kong as a whole remained the largest export outlet for Taiwan in the two-month period, accounting for 38.9 percent of Taiwan's exports, while Japan was the largest import source for Taiwan in the same period, supplying 23.1 percent of Taiwan's imports.

While the exports to South Korea marked the greatest growth in Taiwan's export trade to the world, the imports from the six Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) countries -- Singapore, Indonesia, Malaysia, the Philippines, Thailand and Vietnam -- marked the greatest growth in all imports from around the world in the period.
Taiwan imported US$3.516 billion-worth of products and services from these six countries in the first two months, up 18.7 percent from the year-earlier level, the MOEA officials reported.

Among Taiwan's major trading partners, China (including Hong Kong) and the United States remained Taiwan's main sources of trade surplus in the January-February period. Taiwan enjoyed a trade surplus of US$8.91 billion with China and a surplus of US$1.4 billion with the United States in the period.

Taiwan suffered a trade deficit of US$4.53 billion with Japan and a trade deficit of US$1.28 billion with South Korea in the first two months, making these two countries the top sources Taiwan's trade deficit.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER PREMIER TO DELIVER SPEECH AT HARVARD APRIL 19

TEXT.P: Former Premier Frank Hsieh is scheduled to deliver a speech April 19 at Harvard University's John F. Kennedy School of Government to mark the end of his term studying there.
He has also been invited by an association of Taiwanese expatriates to deliver another speech April 23 in Los Angeles.

Hsieh left for the United States March 7 to spend some time as a visiting research fellow at the Kennedy School after he stepped down from his post as premier. He is scheduled to return to Taiwan April 28.

Former Government Information Office (GIO) Minister Pasuya Yao, and Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislators Kao Chien-chih and Hsu Kuo-yung will fly to the United States to attend Hsieh's Harvard speech.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Berlusconi criticized for using offensive word.
Premier Silvio Berlusconi was criticized for using an offensive word to describe opposition voters. Explaining his recent campaign promise of property tax exemption at a conference of retailers, Berlusconi said that he did not believe that Italians would be such "coglioni" to vote against their own interests. Coglioni literally means testicles, but it is also used as an insult to mean moron.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Moscow Times: Gazprom to Triple Price for Belarus
Gazprom will at least triple the price of gas to Belarus by next year, Gazprom deputy chairman Alexander Ryazanov said Tuesday, upping the stakes in the state gas giant's longtime struggle for control of Belarus' pipeline infrastructure. ( By ChangHung-kuang)

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWANESE, FRENCH SCIENTISTS HONORED WITH AWARD IN PARIS
DOC.DATELINE: Paris, April 4 (CNA) (By Lo Yuan-hsao and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Chen Cheng-hsuan, director of the Center for Condensed Matter Science at National Taiwan University and Christian Colliex, a researcher of the French National Center of the Scientific Research, were presented with the Taiwan-France Science & Technology Award in Paris Tuesday.

In a ceremony presided over by Wu Maw-kuen, an academic of Taiwan's Academia Sinica and former chief of the National Science Council (NSC), and Edouard Brezin, president of the French Academy of Science at the Institute de France Academia, cited the two winners for their cooperation in developing electron microscopes with supreme-resolution.

Noting that electron microscopes are vital tools for measuring nanomaterials, Wu said the progress the two winners have made in the application of electron microscopy will contribute to the development of nanotechnology.
Chen said he was glad to work with Colliex, who he met 30 years ago when he was at Cornell University in New York for post-doctoral studies.

A Taiwan official said on the sidelines of the ceremony that in the cooperation, the Taiwan research team provided state-of-the-art equipment and monochromators, while the French team offered well-developed software.

The Taiwan-France Science & Technology Award, the seventh of its kind, was sponsored by the French Academy of Science and the NSC, with the purpose of honoring Taiwanese and French scientists with innovative spirit and promoting scientific exchanges between the two countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: STATE PROSECUTOR-GENERAL NOMINEE SHOULD BE CONFIRMED: DPP CAUCUS

TEXT.P: The state public prosecutor-general nominated by President Chen Shui-bian should be approved by the Legislative Yuan next week, a caucus whip of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said Wednesday.

Ker Chien-ming said Hsieh Wen-ting has excellent capability, integrity and credentials and that he is sure the nominee will get support from legislators across the party spectrum when the legislature meets to screen his nomination next Tuesday.
The opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU), an ally of the DPP, said the party's legislative caucus "currently supports Hsieh's nomination."

David Huang, a TSU legislative whip, said Hsieh has every qualification needed by a state public prosecutor-general, citing his integrity, professionalism, credentials, administrative neutrality and resolve.
Hsieh is "impeccable" in every aspect, Huang said, adding that the TSU legislative caucus will give him full support but will continue to monitor him.
But the opposition Kuomintang and People First Party were not so affirmative in their endorsements.
Pan Wei-kang, a KMT whip in the legislature, said the legislative caucus will meet next Monday to discuss Hsieh's confirmation.

Pan noted that society has high expectations of the first state public prosecutor-general to be appointed under new regulations to independently exercise his power to probe possible corruption of high-ranking officials, including the president and heads of the five branches of the government. The legislative caucus has to discuss the matter cautiously, she added.
Pan agreed that Hsieh's qualifications are good, but added that whether he can resist partisan or political pressure remains to be seen.
Lu Hsueh-chang, a legislative caucus whip of the People First Party, said the party will have to discuss Hsieh's confirmation prior to the screening next Tuesday.
Lu said the party has no problem with Hsieh's "qualifications or integrity, " but will have to listen to the views of the caucus members before making a final decision.

The legislature passed a revised law early this year that offers legislators a say in the appointment of the state public prosecutor-general and allows for the establishment of a special investigation division under the Supreme Prosecutors Office to look into corruption cases involving high-ranking officials.
Prior to the revisions, the president had full authority to appoint the nation's top prosecutor. Under the revised law, the president's nomination now requires the legislature's confirmation.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'U-TAIWAN' TO BOOST TAIWAN'S GDP TO OVER NT$16 TRILLION BY 2010

TEXT.P: A "u-Taiwan" project, aimed at developing a ubiquitous network society, is expected to boost the country's gross domestic product (GDP) to more than NT$16 trillion (US$492.76 billion) by 2010, the Institute for Information Industry (III) said Wednesday.
According to the III, the "u-Taiwan" project is built upon the framework established under the "e-Taiwan" and "m-Taiwan" projects.

Under the "u-Taiwan" project, the government will increase its investment in public infrastructure to advance the development of new hardware such as second-generation handheld devices and telematics, which will sustain the growth of the country's information and communications industry, the III said.
The institute pointed out that similar projects are also being carried out in Japan and South Korea.

The Japanese government has predicted that its "u-Japan" project will help expand the Japan market for network-related products to NT$26.3 trillion in 2010 and will create a combined production value of NT$36.2 trillion for the home electrical appliance, ubiquitous network, manufacturing, transportation, financial and insurance industries, according to the III.
By 2010, the "u-Japan" project is expected to have created direct production valued at NT$134.7 trillion and indirect production valued at NT$183.3 trillion, it added.

Meanwhile, the South Korean government expects its "u-Korea" project to boost the production value of the country's information technology industry from NT$7.2 trillion in 2004 to NT$11.41 trillion by 2007, to increase the workforce in the industry from 1.28 million in 2004 to 1.5 million by 2007, and to expand the export volume of IT products from US$74.7 billion in 2004 to US$110 billion by 2007, the III said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN CRUDE OIL IMPORTS SOAR 119.6 PERCENT IN 1ST TWO MONTHS

TEXT.P: The cost of Taiwan's crude oil imports, worth some US$4.049 billion between Jan. 1 and Feb. 28 this year, saw a whopping increase of 119.6 percent over the year-earlier level as a result of spiraling crude oil prices, the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) reported Wednesday.

Crude oil imports constituted 13.2 percent of Taiwan's import trade in the January-February period as the second-largest import item, second only to the import of electronic products, which accounted for 19.3 percent of Taiwan's import trade in the two-month period with a value of US$5.905 billion, MOEA officials said.
Taiwan's imports of capital goods as a whole, including machinery and aircraft, amounted to US$5.041 billion in the first two months, marking a decline of 9.5 percent from the year-earlier level.

Meanwhile, according to the latest MOEA tallies, Taiwan exported US$8.792 billion-worth of electronic products in the January-February period, marking growth of 26.6 percent over the figure posted in the same period of 2005. The figure also constituted 27.2 percent of Taiwan's export trade in the period, making electronic products the country's major foreign exchange earner.

Exports of optoelectronic products totaled US$2.816 billion in the first two months, up 87.6 percent over the year-earlier level, while exports of electrical machinery amounted to US$1.782 billion, up 36.8 percent, MOEA officials said.

Nevertheless, they added, exports of information technology and telecommunications products, iron, steel and related products declined in the January-February period compared with the figures posted in the same period of 2005.

According to the MOEA tallies, the amount of Taiwan's foreign trade stood at US$62.9 billion in the January-February period, with exports totaling US$32.31 billion and imports amounting to US$30.59 billion, representing growth of 14 percent and 15.3 percent, respectively, over the figures posted in the same period of 2005.
As a result, the country secured a trade surplus of US$1.73 billion in the first two months of this year, which was a decline of US$90 million from the year-earlier level, MOEA officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENTIAL PLANE ON TEST FLIGHT AFTER NEW COATING

TEXT.P: The nation's presidential plane, also known locally as Air Force One, had a test flight at the Chiang Kai-shek International Airport Wednesday after getting a new coat of paint.
The blue and white that used to be the livery of the presidential plane has been replaced with a livery of light green on the underside, with red, white, blue and brown for the rest of the aircraft.

The plane has also had a fuel saving gadget installed, although the effect will only be apparent on flights of over two hours. As most of the plane's flights are mostly around just one hour, the effects of the device would appear to be limited.
The interior of the Boeing 737-8AR has also been changed to give four VIP seats, 16 business class seats and 96 economy class seats.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO RUSH TO ACCEPT 'RESPECTIVE EXPLANATIONS' OF 'ONE CHINA': DPP

TEXT.P: The government of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) might "respect" and "acknowledge" the "1992 consensus" broached by the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT), but this does not mean that it will "accept" it until the DPP has made a final decision on the issue, DPP spokesman Tsai Huang-liang said Wednesday.

Tsai made the remarks during a meeting with local reporters who questioned him about a claim made by President Chen Shui-bian during an April 3 meeting with KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou that he would respect the so-called "1992 consensus, with respective interpretations of 'one China, '" if the Communist Party of China (CPC) proclaims that it also recognizes the "respective interpretations" attached to the "one China" precondition.

Demanding that the KMT first check with the CPC to make sure that the "separate interpretations of one China" agreement really did exist in the so-called "1992 consensus" and whether the CPC accepts it, Tsai said that the KMT has the responsibility to verify the issue -- the conclusion of a 1992 meeting that then ruling KMT government officials said that they had reached with their Chinese counterparts in Hong Kong.
Tsai argued that there is no need for the DPP to decide whether to accept the "separate interpretations of 'one China, '" as China has yet to recognize the agreement.
Chen's clarification of his stance toward the "separate interpretations of 'one China'" statement during his Monday meeting with Ma has touched a delicate nerve within the pro-independence DPP.
It was reported that leaders from the DPP's various factions asked DPP Chairman Yu Shyi-kun during a Tuesday meeting what the president meant by using the word "respect" in that context.

According to a Beijing dispatched story published Wednesday by the Singapore-based Lianhe Zaobao, Chinese academics familiar with cross-Taiwan Strait relations said that Beijing had already given tacit consent to the "respective explanations of 'one China'" agreement -- which they claimed is the so-called "1992 consensus."

A 1993 meeting between the leaders of the Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundation and the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait was held in Singapore upon the basis of that agreement, the Chinese scholars said, adding that Chinese President Hu Jintao's meetings last year in Beijing with then KMT Chairman Lien Chan and People First Party Chairman James Soong were also conducted based on that agreement.
But they predicted that Beijing will not respond to Chen's most recent challenge.

DOC.HEADLINE: BREAKTHROUGH ANNOUNCED IN MANUFACTURING TFT-LCDS

TEXT.P: A breakthrough in TFT-LCD manufacturing technology was announced Wednesday by the Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI) in Hsinchu.

The technology, titled "plasma processing and system technology for LC alignment, " is particularly suitable for the manufacturing of large panels, according to Lee Chin-yang, an reseacher of ITRI Mechanical Industry Research Laboratories and director of the program.
It will enable the production of panels with resolutions so high that they can be used in medical equipment, Lee said.

Furthermore, Lee went on, the manufacturing process does not generate dust or static, which undermine the quality of the product. Rather, it will shorten the manufacturing process, enhance the yield rate and thereby save on production costs.
In order to develop the new technology, Lee said, the project has has already yielded two patents, with another six patents under application.

DOC.HEADLINE: GRAMMY-WINNING MUSICIANS TO STAGE TAIWAN CONCERT

TEXT.P: Classical music lovers will have an opportunity to enjoy a concert by three Grammy Award winners in May, organizers announced Wednesday.

Pianist Yefim Bronfman, violinist Gil Shaham and cellist Truls Mork will perform two concerts. The first, slated for May 24, will be at Chi-teh Hall in the southern city of Kaohsiung, while the second will be at the National Concert Hall in Taipei May 25.
The opportunity to see the three international musicians perform together is rare, said an official from Management of New Arts (MNA), which is organizing the event.

American violinist Gil Shaham, who is of Israeli descent, has performed with well-known orchestras such as the Berlin Philharmonic, the Philadelphia Philharmonic and the New York Philharmonic. He won the prestigious Avery Fisher career grant and is a 1998 Grammy winner.

Russian-American pianist Yefim Bronfman, who first visited Taiwan in 1997, is a 1996 Grammy Award winner in classical music performance, while Trulas Mork, from Norway, is regarded as one of the best cellists under the age of 50. He won a Grammy in 2002.
They will perform works by Tchaikovsky and Schubert in the concerts.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-SOUTH KOREA ECONOMIC RACE TAKES NEW TWIST

TEXT.P: The economic race between Taiwan and South Korea took a new twist in 2005, with South Korea overtaking Taiwan in per capita gross domestic product (GDP) for the first time.

While government officials hastily attributed the change mainly to a greater appreciation of the Korean won against the U.S. dollar compared to the rise in the new Taiwan dollar's exchange rate with the greenback during the year, local economists said the government should not overlook South Korea's rapid economic growth and should instead work out effective strategies to catch up.

According to a recent statistical report issued by the Bank of Korea (BOK), South Korea's economic growth rate was roughly estimated at 4 percent for 2005, slightly lower than the 4.7 percent registered in 2004. Nevertheless, its per capita GDP reached US$16,291, marking an impressive 14.8 percent year-on-year increase.

In comparison, Taiwan's per capita GDP amounted to US$15,271 in 2005, up 7 percent from the previous year's level but going from about US$100 ahead of South Korea in terms of per capita GDP in 2004 to falling behind by US$1,020.

Hu Sheng-cheng, chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development, said a major reason for the reversal lies in the fluctuation of currency exchange rates. In 2005, the Korean won appreciated 11.8 percent against the greenback, while the new Taiwan dollar rose a mere 3.9 percent.

Hu said currency exchange rate changes have nothing to do with a country's competitiveness and only reflect international capital movement during a specific period. Therefore, he said, it might be too soon to conclude that Taiwan has lost its economic race with South Korea based solely on figures for a single year.
"We need to have a broader perspective when making a judgment, " he argued.
Nonetheless, Hu acknowledged that South Korea is a respectable competitor judging from its shinning economic development and trade performance.

Noting that major international economic institutions tend to use purchasing power parity (PPP) to measure a country's per capita GDP, Hu said such a measurement, which excludes inflation and currency fluctuation rates, can more accurately gauge per capita national income and general living standards.

Quoting statistics compiled by the Swiss International Institute of Management and Development (IMD) , Hu said Taiwan's PPP-based per capita GDP reached US$24,676 in 2004, far higher than South Korea's US$18,686.

In 2005, Hu said, Taiwan's economic growth rate was slightly higher than South Korea's while its 2.3 percent inflation rate was lower than South Korea's 2.8 percent. Against this backdrop, Hu said he believes Taiwan will continue to lead South Korea in terms of PPP-based per capita GDP, indicating that Taiwanese people enjoy a higher living standard than South Koreans.

Liang Kuo-yuan, director of the private think tank Polaris Research Institute, said the won's appreciation was only one of the reasons behind South Korea's overtaking Taiwan in per capita GDP in 2005.

"We cannot ignore South Korea's robust economic growth potential. In the wake of the 1997-98 Asian economic fiasco, South Korea's per capita GDP once dropped to US$7,400, but the country has managed to regain momentum and emerge as a new economic power and even surpass Taiwan following a series of sweeping economic reforms. It's true that within the South Korean economy lurks some problems, such as unbalanced development. But we cannot afford to overlook the vitality of its growth," Liang said.
Judging from the growth in Taiwan's labor force and labor productivity, Liang said Taiwan's annual economic growth rate should have been able to reach 4.5 percent.

"However, we were unable to attain that level of growth because of our failure to catch some good growth opportunities, " Liang lamented, ascribing Taiwan's slower-than-expected economic growth rates in recent years to a number of factors, including policy vacillation, the political standoff between ruling and opposition camps and a conservative policy toward cross-Taiwan Strait commercial exchanges.

Chu Yun-peng, head of National Central University's Taiwan Economic Development Research Center, echoed Liang's view, saying that South Korea has scored enormous success in product branding, global marketing and control of key components.

"South Korea has emerged as the second largest source of Taiwan's trade deficit after Japan. I'm not surprised by its overtaking Taiwan in terms of per capita GDP in 2005. With South Korea's towering ambition, I think that country is likely to surpass Taiwan even in terms of PPP-based per capita GDP in the near future, " Chu said, adding that the government should not be complacent with a moderate growth and should map out forward-looking economic development policy to accelerate growth.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Massachusetts Sets Health Plan for Nearly All
Massachusetts is poised to become the first state to provide nearly universal health care coverage with a bill passed overwhelmingly by the legislature Tuesday that Gov. Mitt Romney says he will sign. The bill does what health experts say no other state has been able to do: provide a mechanism for all of its citizens to obtain health insurance. It accomplishes that in a way that experts say combines methods and proposals from across the political spectrum, apportioning the cost among businesses, individuals and the government.
Wall Street Journal: Daewoo Makes Cars Quickly And Has Low Labor Costs; The Antithesis of Detroit Managers Scrounge Furniture
As General Motors Corp. struggles in the U.S., the world's largest auto maker is increasingly relying on a once- bankrupt Korean outfit to help it recover. Last year, for the first time ever, GM sold more vehicles outside North America than it did in its home market. GM Daewoo accounted for 13 percent of the total and in the process helped make GM the top car maker in China. In a sign of the Korean company's newfound prowess, GM has handed the GM Daewoo Auto & Technology Co some big projects, including responsibility for developing the framework for GM's new small cars.

DOC.HEADLINE: BETEL NUT TAX SHOULD BE AT LEAST NT$0.1 PER NUT: ACADEMIC

TEXT.P: If the government is to impose a betel nut tax, it should be at least NT$0.1 per nut, an academic said Wednesday.
Lee Chou-lun, an associate professor at China Medical University, gave the figure in his report, "An estimate on a reasonable tax on betel nuts based on medical losses."

Concerned by the fact that the habit of betel nut chewing has been identified as a major factor behind the development of oral cancer, the DOH is mulling levying a tax on betel nuts. The DOH's Bureau of Health Promotion commissioned Lee for the study.
If the DOH has its way, it is estimated an additional tax revenue of NT$3.5 billion will go into the nation's coffers, Lee said.

Lee's study compared 3,000 people, including those who chew betel nuts but have not developed cancer and those who do not chew them. The in- and out-patient records between 1998 and 2004 showed that for every betel nut chewed, medical expenditures increase NT$0.1.

Lee noted that his estimate was based on those who chew betel nuts but have not developed cancer. For those who have already developed cancer, the medical expenditures must be even higher, he said. For this reason, the betel nut tax should be at least NT$0.1.

Judging from the fact that on average, people chew betel nuts for 15 years, during which they consume around 130,000 betel nuts based on an estimate of 24 per day. So betel nut chewers will have to pay an extra NT$72 per month on average, he said.
He said that if a betel nut tax is imposed, it could generate an additional NT$3.54 billion in tax revenue, or one percent of national health insurance spending.

If national health insurance spending of around NT$986 million over five years on oral, larynx and esophageal cancers -- which are all related to betel nut chewing -- are also included, it will ease the financial burden on the national health insurance system.
In addition, after levying betel nut tax for one year, Lee estimated that it would cut down the incidence of betel nut chewing by 1.33 percent, saving around NT$600 million in medical costs.
Although Lee has proposed an estimate of NT$0.1 in tax per betel nut, the Bureau of Health Promotion said it has not yet set a date for imposing the tax.

Bureau officials said they will first focus on regulating betel nut marketing, formulating legislation, conducting inter-agency coordination as well as stepping up a public awareness campaign on the dangers of betel nut chewing before talking about imposing a betel nut tax.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMIC CONFERENCE TO APPROACH DIRECT 'THREE LINKS' ISSUE

TEXT.P: A conference on Taiwan's sustainable economic growth to be held between May and June this year will discuss the issue of direct trade, mail and transportation links with China -- commonly known as "three links, " a government official said Wednesday.
But the direct links issue cannot be resolved in only one conference, the official said, adding that it will require negotiations with China.

According to the official, the conference on Taiwan's sustainable economic growth will focus on three major issues: perfecting Taiwan's social security system, enhancing its long-term economic competitiveness and outlining its global marketing and cross-strait trade strategies.
The conference will discuss Taiwan's economic development within a structure of globalization and considering the influence of the China factor.

According to the official, preparations for the conference will be divided into several stages. The first part will take place April 6-17, in which government departments will discuss amongst themselves the issues that will be brought up at the conference.

In the second stage, scheduled for April 17-May 5, preparations will focus on mapping out conference operational rules and the roster of participants. In the third stage from May 5 through June 9, panel discussions will be held. And a plenary session will be held June 16 or June 17.

The official said the conference, organized by the Executive Yuan and aimed at solving long-term and structural economic problems, is different from the Economic Development Advisory Conference (EDAC) held by the Presidential Office in 2001, which dealt with short-term problems.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT LAWMAKER CALLS FOR TIMETABLE FOR DIRECT CROSS-STRAIT AIR LINKS

TEXT.P: The government should lay out a timetable for opening direct air links across the Taiwan Strait, an opposition Kuomintang lawmaker said Wednesday.

Legislator Ting Shou-chung, an outspoken advocate of direct cross-strait air links, made the call after media reports said the Cabinet intends to flesh out a detailed plan for "frequent cross-strait chartered passenger flights" to be discussed at a conference on Taiwan's sustainable economic development scheduled for mid-June.

Noting that chartered flights cannot have a stable supply of passengers, Ting said the government should focus on preparations for opening scheduled flights across the Taiwan Strait to benefit a large number of Taiwan people with business interests in China.
Ting also suggested that the Cabinet unveil a timetable for opening direct cross-strait air links to speed up the realization of that goal.

"The business sector has long been pushing for opening regular direct cross-strait flight services to facilitate a revamp of the local economy. The government should not drag its foot for ideological cause. Otherwise, Taiwan might lose its chips in negotiations with China and been marginalized eventually amid the current wave of global economic integration," Ting said.

Meanwhile, Cabinet spokesman Cheng Wen-tsang denied reports that the Cabinet would discuss a plan for "opening frequent direct cross-strait chartered flights" at the planned economic "sustainability" conference.

Cheng said the issue regarding cross-strait chartered flights cannot be decided unilaterally by Taiwan. "We must first forge a cross-party consensus and then negotiate with China, " Cheng said, adding that it's premature to go into any detail about the cross-strait chartered flight plan.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR APRIL 6 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Thursday, April 6:
10:00, President Chen Shui-bian will confer the Order of Brilliant Star with Special Grand Cordon on visiting Parlacen Speaker Julio Palacios Sambrano at the Presidential Office.
10:30, The Ministry of Foreign Affairs will hold a news briefing.
14:30, Premier Su Tseng-chang will attend an avian flu prevention drill at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport's arrival lounge.
16:00, Vice President Annette Lu will meet with a delegation of U.S. scholars on cross-strait affairs.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO DIRECT CROSS-STRAIT FLIGHTS FOLLOWING ECONOMIC CONFERENCE

TEXT.P: Government Information Office (GIO) Minister Cheng Wen-tsang denied media reports Wednesday that "frequent direct cross-Taiwan Strait chartered flights" will be launched following a conference on Taiwan's economic growth that will be held between May and June.
Cheng pointed out that Taiwan cannot decide unilaterally whether to launch chartered flights to China, and said that such thing cannot be decided in a single conference.
He added that cross-strait trade policies will also be discussed in the conference, but a cross-party consensus must be forged first.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT MAY MULL ARMS BILL AFTER BUSH-HU MEETING: PARTY OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: The main opposition Kuomintang may consider a long-stalled arms procurement package after Chinese President Hu Jintao's visit to the United States later this month, a party official said Wednesday.

Tseng Yung-chuan, executive director of the KMT's policy coordination department, was responding to media reports that the KMT "would not passively accept" the arms procurement package broached by the United States and would come up with a new list of weapons to be included in the package.
"It's just a personal idea of KMT Legislator-at-large Su Chi," Tseng said, adding that the KMT has yet to reach an intraparty consensus on the issue.

At the moment, Tseng said, the party is inclined to wait until after a meeting between Hu and U.S. President George W. Bush at the White House later this month. Issues regarding Taiwan are certainly to be raised in the upcoming Bush-Hu meeting.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMIC CONFERENCE TO APPROACH DIRECT 'THREE LINKS' ISSUE(repeat)

TEXT.P: A conference on Taiwan's sustainable economic growth to be held between May and June this year will discuss the issue of direct trade, mail and transportation links with China -- commonly known as "three links, " a government official said Wednesday.
But the direct links issue cannot be resolved in only one conference, the official said, adding that it will require negotiations with China.

According to the official, the conference on Taiwan's sustainable economic growth will focus on three major issues: perfecting Taiwan's social security system, enhancing its long-term economic competitiveness and outlining its global marketing and cross-strait trade strategies.
The conference will discuss Taiwan's economic development within a structure of globalization and considering the influence of the China factor.

According to the official, preparations for the conference will be divided into several stages. The first part will take place April 6-17, in which government departments will discuss amongst themselves the issues that will be brought up at the conference.

In the second stage, scheduled for April 17-May 5, preparations will focus on mapping out conference operational rules and the roster of participants. In the third stage from May 5 through June 9, panel discussions will be held. And a plenary session will be held June 16 or June 17.

The official said the conference, organized by the Executive Yuan and aimed at solving long-term and structural economic problems, is different from the Economic Development Advisory Conference (EDAC) held by the Presidential Office in 2001, which dealt with short-term problems.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO DIRECT CROSS-STRAIT FLIGHTS FOLLOWING ECONOMIC CONFERENCE(repeat)

TEXT.P: Government Information Office (GIO) Minister Cheng Wen-tsang denied media reports Wednesday that "frequent direct cross-Taiwan Strait chartered flights" will be launched following a conference on Taiwan's economic growth that will be held between May and June.
Cheng pointed out that Taiwan cannot decide unilaterally whether to launch chartered flights to China, and said that such thing cannot be decided in a single conference.
He added that cross-strait trade policies will also be discussed in the conference, but a cross-party consensus must be forged first.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, April 6, or the ninth day of the third month of the Year of the Dog according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1199: Richard I, king of England known as "The Lion-Hearted," dies at the age of 42 from an infected wound received while besieging Chaluz Castle during the Crusades. He was captured in Austria in 1192 and held as a prisoner by Holy Roman Emperor Henry VI until England ransomed him in 1194.
1789: George Washington is unanimously elected the first president of the United States.
1814: French Emperor Napoleon Bonaparte is forced to abdicate unconditionally.
1868: Japanese Emperor Meiji establishes the Charter Oath, which was to change the form of government. He also promises an assembly.
1890: Anthony Fokker, Dutch-born American aircraft designer and manufacturer who revolutionized aerial warfare by synchronizing a front-mounted machine gun with the rotations of a propeller, is born.
1896: A modern version of the ancient Olympic Games is opened in Athens, initiated by French aristocrat Baron Pierre de Coubertin, whose goal was to stimulate interest in physical fitness and promote understanding between nations.
1913: The provisional Senate of the Republic of China is dissolved.
1917: President Woodrow Wilson signs a resolution entering the United States into World War I on the side of Great Britain and France.
1933: The Ministry of Finance of the Republic of China orders the implementation of a yuan currency system instead of the tael currency system.
1935: Emperor Henry Pu Yi of Manchukuo, a puppet regime installed by the Japanese, visits Japan.
1938: The ROC armed forces score a major victory over Japan in the battle of Taierchuang, killing more than 30,000 Japanese troops.
1941: German bombers raid Belgrade, killing some 2,500 people. Hundreds of buildings were destroyed during the attack, including the National Library with its countless medieval manuscripts.
1945: U.S. naval forces score a major victory against the Japanese at Kyushu.
1953: Scrap bombs explode on a hillside in Nanshihchiao, Taipei County, killing or injuring more than 300 people.
1963: The Executive Yuan proclaims December 25 "Constitution Day" and a national holiday.
1965: The United States launches Early Bird I, the first commercial communications satellite, from Cape Kennedy, Florida.
1968: Pierre Trudeau becomes prime minister of Canada, succeeding Lester B. Pearson.
1975: Yen Chia-kan, vice president of the Republic of China since 1966, takes the oath of office as the nation's second constitutional president.
1976: Millionaire recluse Howard Hughes dies in a plane while being flown to a hospital, leaving a fortune of US$2 billion.
1976: Premier Chiang Ching-kuo renews his call to communist cadres and mainland China military personnel to rise up against the Maoist regime following the April 5 riots at Tienanmen Square in Beijing.
1993: Two mainland Chinese youths, Liu Bao-zai and Huang Shu-kang, hijack a Southern Airlines' Boeing 757 passenger plane to Taiwan.
1994: A missile hits a plane as it attempts to land in Rwanda, killing all people onboard, including President Cyprien Ntaryamira of Burundi and President Jubenal Habyarimana of Rwanda.
1998 Citicorp merges with Travelers Group Inc., becoming the largest corporation in the world in terms of assets. The new firm is worth more than US$70 billion.
1999: Indonesian President B.J. Habibie assures visiting ROC Economics Minister Wang Shih-kang that his administration will take all necessary measures to protect Taiwan investors in Indonesia.
2000: Republic of China President-elect Chen Shui-bien says that the administration under his leadership will honor all accords and commitments that have already been inked with foreign countries.
2001: Tibetan spiritual leader, the Dalai Lama, calls on former Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui and expresses his gratitude for Lee's promotion of increased Taiwan-Tibet exchanges during his term in office.
2004: Lithuanian President Rolandas Paksas is impeached by the Parliament, making him the first European popularly elected president to step down due to impeachment.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "To allow people to go to battle without first instructing them is to betray them."

DOC.HEADLINE: JUDICIAL CHIEF: DEPUTY TO EXPLAIN MOTEL AFFAIR

TEXT.P: Judicial Yuan President Weng Yueh-sheng said Thursday he believes his deputy Cheng Chung-mo will explain what really happened in a reported incident involving Cheng and a woman professor in a suburban Taipei motel Sunday.

As to whether Cheng will resign over the matter, Weng said Cheng, who is also a grand justice, will attend a scheduled meeting of grand justices Thursday during which Cheng will explain how he will handle the incident.
Following the incident being reported by the media, demands have been made by both ruling and opposition politicians and civic groups that the vice president of the Judicial Yuan step down.

Cheng, 69, told the media that he took the woman to a motel because she was not feeling well. However, according to newspaper reports, the assistant professor of National Yunlin University of Science and Technology, through a colleague, denied that she had been to a motel with Cheng.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLICE CRACK DOWN ON CYBERCRIME

TEXT.P: The Criminal Investigation Bureau has uncovered 422 cybercrime cases in its latest crackdown operation, with more than 400 suspects facing prosecution, officials said Thursday.

The three-day operation launched early this week was targeted at Internet-related criminal activities such as cyber pornography, online trading scams, online gambling, online piracy, illegal online games and unlawful telecommunications operations, the officials said.
Of the cybercrime cases uncovered in the operation, online trading scams accounted for the largest number, with 189 cases and 154 suspects, they said.

Coming in second was cyber pornography, with 126 cases and 127 suspects. Others included 53 cases involving online games, with 61 suspects; 48 cases of online piracy, with 50 suspects; and two cases of unlawful telecommunications operations, with 14 suspects, they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHENG TO HANDLE MOTEL AFFAIR 'AT EARLIEST POSSIBLE TIME'

TEXT.P: Judicial Yuan Vice President Cheng Chung-mo said Thursday he will handle "in the most appropriate way at the earliest possible time" a reported incident involving him and a woman professor at a suburban Taipei motel.

Calls for Cheng, who is also a grand justice, to resign from both posts have been increasing since the media reported Wednesday that he took the woman to a motel and stayed there for 70 minutes Sunday.

The first thing he did after arriving at his office Thursday was to talk with his immediate boss, Judicial Yuan President Weng Yueh-sheng, who said Cheng will explain the matter at a grand justices meeting later in the day.

DOC.HEADLINE: JUDICIAL YUAN VICE PRESIDENT TENDERS RESIGNATION

TEXT.P: Judicial Yuan Vice President Cheng Chung-mo, who concurrently serves as a grand justice, offered to resign from both posts Thursday in the wake of reports that he took a young woman to a motel.

President Arroyo does not plan to follow in the footsteps of Thai Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra, who decided to step down amid allegations of corruption, said her chief political adviser, Gabriel Claudio.

The House approved campaign finance legislation last night that would benefit Republicans by placing strict caps on contributions to nonprofit committees that spent heavily in the last election while removing limits on political parties' spending coordinated with candidates, the paper said.

DOC.HEADLINE: LIEN TO MEET HU IN BEIJING APRIL 16: KMT OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Lien Chan, former chairman of Taiwan's main opposition Kuomintang (KMT), is set to meet Chinese President Hu Jintao April 16 in Beijing, a local newspaper reported Thursday.

The Ta Kung Pao daily quoted KMT Policy Committee Director Tseng Yung-chuan as saying in Taipei that Lien will head a 60-strong KMT delegation to attend a forum with the Chinese Communist Party in Beijing April 14 and will lead his entourage to have public talks with Hu.
According to Tseng, Hu will meet Lien and his delegation after the forum on cross-Taiwan Strait economy and trade.
Tseng said that another closed-door meeting between Lien and Hu is still being planned for April 15 or 16 which would be their second meeting since April last year.
The delegation will include 29 KMT legislators, as well as other lawmakers of the "pan-blue alliance," according to Tseng.

Prominent businesspeople who serve on the KMT Central Standing Committee, such as Jeffery Koo, chairman of the Chinatrust Financial Holding, Deputy Chairman of Cosmos Bank Hsu Hsien-jung, Uni-President Group Chairman Kao Chin-yen and others, will also be part of the delegation.

DOC.HEADLINE: SUBSIDY FUNDS FOR LOCAL GOVERNMENTS TO BE PAID ON TIME: MOI

TEXT.P: Deputy Finance Minister Chen Shuh promised Thursday that the central government will pay its subsidy funds for local governments on time, in the wake of a media report that 17 localities are so hard up that they face difficulties paying their staff.

Chen told the Legislative Yuan's Budget and Financial Accounts Committee that although the central government is just as cash-strapped, the Ministry of Finance (MOI) will pay out any funds due to the local governments as scheduled.

Chen said that Tainan County and Taipei County are the two localities that are having the most serious indebtedness problems and that the MOI is planning to revise related laws to raise the indebtedness ceiling of local governments.
According to the report, 17 counties and cities around the country could not support their own personnel expenditures last year owing to a lack of financial resources.

The top five localities having the most serious problems were Changhua County, which posted a deficit of NT$7.65 billion; Taichung County, with a deficit of NT$7.01 billion; Tainan County, registering a deficit of NT$5.61 billion; Nantou County, with a deficit of NT$5.11 billion; and Pingtung County, which posted a deficit of NT$4.77 billion, the report said.

Also responding to the report, Cabinet spokesman Cheng Wen-tsang said the Cabinet will try to work out a solution to the problems after the MOI and Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics have investigated the matter.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT TO KEEP PUSHING FOR HOLDING OF FTA TALKS WITH U.S.: MOFA

TEXT.P: Although there may be some delays in progress toward the holding of talks between Taiwan and the United States on the establishment of a free trade agreement (FTA) , the government will continue to do its best to push for the holding of such talks, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs said Thursday.

Local media reported Thursday the United States will not hold FTA talks with Taiwan in the near future and quoted Assistant U.S. Trade Representative for China Affairs Timothy P. Stratford as saying that the U.S. business community is not actively pushing the government to discuss a free trade pact with Taiwan and that the U.S. government does not have extra staff to deal with this issue at the moment.

"Negotiations on a major issue may slow down or may have some delays at some stage, but there is no reason that we should give up after encountering some difficulties if we are very clear about what our goal is," ministry spokesman Michel Lu said.

Lu said that the difficulties Taiwan is facing now lie in U.S. administrative procedures, as the U.S. government may have difficulties finding time to deal with this issue. However, he added that there is no need for pessimism and that the government will continue with its efforts.

He further said that many heavyweight U.S. politicians are also urging the Bush administration to hold FTA talks with Taiwan as soon as possible, adding that such an agreement would be beneficial to both parties as well as to U.S.-Taiwan bilateral ties.

DOC.TEXT: Los Angeles Times: L.A.County OKs 'Historic' Homeless Plan. Signaling a major shift in its homeless policy ,the Los Angeles County Board of Supervisors approved a $100-million plan Tuesday to reduce the concentration of homeless services in skid row by establishing five centers across the county that would provide temporary shelter and social services for transients.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed higher Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 95.22 points to close at 6,760.82.
The bourse opened at 6,724.97 and fluctuated between 6,760.82 and 6,710.68 during trading. A total of 3.44 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$115.07 billion (US$3.56 billion).

Seven of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with machinery and electronics shares moving up the most at 1.6 percent, followed by plastics and chemicals shares at 1.5 percent, textile stocks at 1.4 percent, banking and financial shares at 1.3 percent, foodstuff issues at 1 percent, paper and pulp issues at 0.7 percent, and cement stocks at 0.3 percent.
The one other major stock category lost ground, with construction issues moving down at 0.1 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 713 to 204, with 134 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWANESE IN RUSSIA URGED TO AVOID SKINHEADS

TEXT.P: Taiwanese visiting or residing in Russia have been cautioned to avoid local skinheads, an official of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs said Thursday.

Tseng Ching-yuan, director of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs' West Asian Affairs Department, said that the country's representative office in Moscow has advised Taiwanese in that country to be vigilant about their personal safety following an attack by skinheads on a Taiwanese student residing in St. Petersburg. The student, surnamed Chen, was not seriously injured in the attack.

Tseng said skinheads are radical groups in Russia who do not welcome the presence of foreigners. Most skinheads are street-wandering youngsters wearing leather jackets who attack foreigners, but they mostly do not belong to any specific gang.

He said the U.S. ambassador to Russia and other countries' diplomatic envoys jointly expressed their concern to the Russian foreign ministry in 2004 about skinheads' xenophobic behavior which poses a threat to foreigners.
The skinhead problem seemed then to be milder in Moscow following Russian police's frequent patrols, but they sometimes still attack foreigners in other cities, Tseng said.
He added that as Adolf Hitler's birth anniversary falls on April 20 and Vladimir Lenin's falls on April 22, skinhead activities are more frequent during this month.

DOC.HEADLINE: WOMAN IN 'MOTEL AFFAIR' CALLS FOR END TO RUMOR-MONGERING

TEXT.P: A woman professor reportedly involved in a "suburban Taipei motel affair" that is dogging Judicial Yuan Vice President Cheng Chung-mo called for an end to rumor-mongering Thursday. Cheng has offered to resign over the incident.

Wang Mei-hsin, an assistant professor at National Yunlin University of Science and Technology, said she is a science scholar who is sincere and honest but slow of speech, "and it is difficult for me to reach a perfect equilibrium in social and political sciences."
She claimed that there are "different versions of the incident in Taipei" which have yet to be cleared up, and she would like to remain silent "so that things will not become even more complicated."
"What has happened in Taipei is totally beyond my comprehension," she told reporters, "and I just want to develop my career in my profession."
In a brief statement, she noted that she would like to make contributions in pharmaco-economy, cosmetics, biomedicine and integrating intellectual property and science and technology law.
Chang Kuo-hua, director of the graduate institute where Wang teaches, said he and other colleagues will help her tide over the difficult time and "see what we can do after things have cleared up."
Chang earlier quoted Wang as denying that she went to the reported motel with Cheng on Sunday.
In a related development, Cheng issued a statement saying he was resigning as vice president of the Judicial Yuan as well as a grand justice.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Berlusconi forced to abandon TV appearance plan.
Premier Silvio Berlusconi was forced to abandon a planned TV appearance on his private TV network Mediaset Wednesday after strong protests from the opposition camp. The opposition slammed the planned lone guest on the Wednesday night show "Terra" as a violation of the country's electoral law.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEEP-SEA WATER RESOURCES DEVELOPMENT PROJECT TO COMMENCE THIS YEAR

TEXT.P: A project for the commercial development of Taiwan's deep-sea water resources will begin this year under the guidance of the Council of Agriculture (COA) , COA Minister Su Jia-chyuan said Thursday.

Fielding questions at the Legislative Yuan, Su said that the COA plans to spend some NT$900 million (US$27.7 million) on the research and development of deep-sea water resources over four years beginning this year.

Su said the deep-sea regions in Taiwan's exclusive economic zone off the island's east coast can be used to cultivate high-value fishery products by taking advantage of the waters' cleanliness, low temperatures, and richness in minerals and other valuable substances.

Su made the remarks in response to a question raised by opposition Kuomintang Legislator Huang Chien-ting who inquired about the Taitung branch of the COA-sponsored National Aquatic Germplasm Center's work progress. The deep-sea water development project is the centerpiece of the Taitung branch's operations.
Huang said that Taiwan, like Japan, is surrounded by waters that provide convenient and economic opportunities for the sustainable development of environmentally-friendly products.

He noted that Japan's deep-sea water resources contributed 600 billion yen (US$5.1 billion) to the country's economy in 2003, with products ranging from beer and cosmetics to nutritional food supplements and medicines.

Experts have estimated that Taiwan could also produce NT$80 billion (US$2.46 billion) to NT$100 billion worth of similar products a year by developing and exploiting its deep-sea water resources, Huang said.

TAIEX Index futures for May rose 105 points to finish at 6,725, with 967 contract transactions, while June futures moved up 96 points to close at 6,692, with 28 contracts traded.
