DOC.HEADLINE: PARTIES MAKE DIFFERENT COMMENTS ON GRAND JUSTICE'S RESIGNATION

TEXT.P: "Pan-green" political parties Thursday gave Judicial Yuan Vice President Cheng Chun-mo high marks for resigning over a suspected extramarital affair while "pan-blue" parties demanded that he apologize for lying.

Cheng, who is also a grand justice, offered to resign from the two posts after the media widely reported that he and a woman professor went to a motel in suburban Taipei together and stayed for more than an hour on Sunday.
Cheng said he decided to quit the posts because his private social life had been "exaggerated" to the extent that the dignity of judicial authorities has been seriously jeopardized.
The ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP) legislative caucus lauded Cheng for "having courageously admitted to mistakes and shouldered responsibility by resigning."
Chen Ching-chun, caucus secretary-general, said Cheng might have acted imperfectly by failing to admit his wrongdoing at the earliest possible time.
After all, he has resigned, Chen said, urging the public not to interfere too aggressively in Cheng's privacy.

Because a grand justice is expected to be "absolutely loyal like a queen to her king, " Cheng should explain in detail what really happened on Sunday when he and the reported woman were together, said the DPP politician.
"Our society simply cannot tolerate a grand justice telling lies," he added.
The DPP's "pan-green camp" ally, the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU), praised Cheng for having "made the wisest choice" by quitting the two critically important public offices.

"A grand justice must demand the highest moral requirements of himself," said Huang Shih-chuo, TSU legislative caucus convener, who noted that the alleged motel affair was not a legal incident, but a moral one.

The opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) were not so generous with their comments on Cheng's decision to step down, with the KMT demanding that the council of grand justices investigate whether Cheng had acted improperly or lied, or both.

Judicial Yuan President Weng Yueh-sheng should apologize to the public for one of the grand justices having acted improperly, and Cheng himself owes the public an apology for having lied, said Pan Wei-kang, secretary-general of the KMT's legislative caucus.
Pan's deputy, Lei Chien, called on people to express their concern about who will replace Cheng as a grand justice, an important post that she said should never become a political tool.

The PFP's legislative caucus claimed that Cheng's behavior has shown he's no longer fit for the post of grand justice, who is a "guardian deity of the Constitution" and whose moral integrity must be impeccable.

Lee Hung-chun, PFP legislative caucus secretary-general, said Cheng probably lied when he said his female companion needed to stop at a motel to use the toilet since there were many gas stations and shopping malls along the way.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHANGHAI TRADING COMPANY ORDERS 20,000KG FRUIT FROM CHANGHUA

TEXT.P: A Shanghai fruit trading company announced Thursday that it has placed an order for 20,000 kilograms of produce from farmers in Changhua, central Taiwan, claiming that fruit grown here is of a superior quality.

The fruit order consists principally of guava and starfruit. Lin Chih-hung, manager of the Shanghai-based Chi-Koo company that placed the order, said Taiwanese fruit consistently fetches a high price in Shanghai.

Lin said Shanghai consumers aggressively demand Taiwanese starfruit and guava because it tastes better than the fruit grown in China. Plus, he added, selling fruit to China will augment the income of Taiwanese farmers.
Changhua County Magistrate Cho Po-yuan, said there have been difficulties in exporting Taiwanese fruit to China in the past because there hasn't been a proper distribution channel in place.
Taiwanese fruit is directly delivered to their Chinese clientele, Lin said, also adding that the company's customers are mostly at the top of the social ladder.
Lin added that Chinese consumers no longer desire Chinese fruit once they have taken a bite of those grown in Taiwan, because fruit from across the Taiwan Strait is sweeter and juicier.

DOC.HEADLINE: JUDICIAL YUAN VICE PRESIDENT DENIES ALLEGED SEX SCANDAL

TEXT.P: Judicial Yuan Vice President Cheng Chung-mo, who doubles as a grand justice, denied media reports alleging he was having an extramarital affair with a young woman as he offered to resign from both posts Thursday.
In a statement, Cheng said the exaggeration of his personal social life by the media has "seriously undermined the reputation of the judiciary."
Cheng apologized to the officials who had nominated him, to legislators who had endorsed his nomination and to all those who have supported him.

Cheng made the move amid legislators' calls for his resignation, following reports that he took a woman to a motel in Wuku, Taipei County Sunday and stayed there for 70 minutes. The woman was identified by local media as 38-year-old Wang Mei-hsin, an assistant professor at the Graduate School of Science and Technology Law at National Yunlin University of Science and Technology.
Cheng claimed Wednesday that he and Wang had visited the motel to use the toilet because Wang had felt sick to her stomach.

Cheng said he had met Wang at her residence that day to offer assistance on some legal issues, and later drove her to a biotechnology center in Taipei City to submit materials concerning her job application at the center.
After that, Cheng said, Wang suggested they go for a joyride, which was the reason they ended up in Wuku.
However, Chang Kuo-hua, director of the graduate institute where Wang teaches, told media on the same day that Wang had denied she went to the motel with Cheng Sunday.
Local media described Cheng's clarification as being "full of suspicions" and said the details were "in violation of common sense," and accused Cheng of lying about the matter.
At a news conference held on the incident Thursday, Cheng stressed that he would not lie to anyone and that "honesty" was his family's guiding principle.
Cheng said he was surprised at the media reports and wondered if Taiwan's society had "fallen ill."

Claiming that he had offered to help Wang because he thinks she is talented and can contribute to the country's bio-tech sector, Cheng said he could not understand why such a simple matter would have become so complicated.
Also Thursday, Wang called for an end to what she called "rumor-mongering."
Noting that there are "different versions of the incident in Taipei" which have yet to be cleared up, Wang said she would like to remain silent "so that things will not become even more complicated."

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar dropped against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Thursday, losing NT$0.143 to close at NT$32.329.
A total of US$1.17 billion changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$32.472 and fluctuated between NT$32.3 and NT$32.575.

DOC.HEADLINE: GRAND JUSTICES URGED TO TAKE MOTEL INCIDENT SERIOUSLY

TEXT.P: Judicial Yuan President Weng Yueh-sheng said Thursday that reports of its vice president Cheng Chung-mo going with a woman professor to a suburban Taipei motel Sunday have had far-reaching effects on the image of the judiciary and its grand justices, who must "take the incident seriously."

Following media reports of the incident, demands were made by both ruling and opposition politicians and civic groups for Cheng to step down from both posts as vice president and grand justice, which he did Thursday.

Before Cheng tendered his resignation over the matter, Weng chaired a meeting of grand justices during which Cheng explained how he would handle the incident. Most of the grand justices indicated they respected Cheng's explanations.
"The incident is a serious matter, which must be taken seriously by all of us," Weng Yueh-sheng told the meeting.

Asked if any of the grand justices challenged Cheng's explanations, Judicial Yuan Secretary-General Fan Kuang-chun said the issue had been discussed among the grand justices, whose statements he was not in a position to quote.

Cheng, 69, told media he took the woman to a motel because she was feeling unwell. However, according to newspaper reports, the woman, an assistant professor at National Yunlin University of Science and Technology, denied through a colleague that she had gone to a motel with Cheng.
(Timothy Hwang)

DOC.HEADLINE: BUDGET FREEZE ON ABORIGINAL TV LIFTED

TEXT.P: A freeze on the Aboriginal Television Channel's annual budget imposed in January by the opposition-controlled legislature was lifted Thursday.

The end of the freeze was apparently a great relief not just for the station's employees, but also for Walis Pelin, minister of the Council of Indigenous Peoples, who warned several days ago that the channel would be put out of business by the end of May if the freeze were not lifted soon.
Also, aboriginal Legislator Kao-Chin Su-mei questioned the fairness of the Hakka Television Channel receiving a much higher annual budget than Aboriginal TV.
Kao-Chin also questioned the appropriateness of giving Aboriginal TV's annual budget to the private Eastern Multimedia Group, which in turn produces all programs aired by Aboriginal TV.

Kao-Chin demanded that the Council of Indigenous Peoples come up with a plan to help secure Aboriginal TV's independence. Otherwise, she said, the channel should be disbanded and its annual budget should be used to hire another station to produce better programs.

Meanwhile, Legislator Chen Hsiu-hui from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party said that the best policy to allow Aboriginal TV to maintain its independence would be to free the channel from the influence of legislators. Chen said there has been too much influence-peddling by legislators seeking to pressure the station into employing their friends, relatives and supporters.

The freeze on two other budget items concerning the Council of Indigenous Peoples -- the budget for the building and maintenance of 37 aboriginal museums islandwide and the budget for the development of modern aboriginal communities -- were also lifted during the session of the Legislative Yuan Home and Nations Committee Thursday.

Later in the session, a proposal submitted by seven members of the Home and Nations Committee also passed into a resolution demanding the Executive Yuan use the Second Reserve Fund to beef up the Council of Indigenous Peoples's annual budget so that the council's budget can be on par with that of the Hakka Television Channel.

DOC.HEADLINE: NATIONAL OPEN UNIVERSITY INAUGURATES ONLINE COURSES

TEXT.P: The National Open University, which is devoted to long-distance education, announced Thursday that it has posted all of its courses on the Internet and thereby converted itself into an online university capable of providing education to any student, in any place and at any time.

Liu Shui-shen, the university's president, told a news conference that his school has bidden farewell to the time when its students must turn on the radio or TV at a specific time in order to listen to a lecture.

Thanks to a program co-developed by his institution and Chunghwa Telecom Co., Liu said now students can log into the university's Web site through their computer and watch video programs, listen to audio tapes or read Web pages at their convenience.
The students can conduct their studies at their own pace and stop and restart as they wish, something that is impossible in traditional classroom teaching, Liu said.
Each online lecture consists of a syllabus, an introduction and a quiz and comes complete with complementary course materials and a discussion forum for students, Liu said.

Students are encouraged to discuss their questions during studies with teachers online. If an online teacher is unavailable, the student can post their questions on the Web site and the university's instructors will offer responses within 12 hours, Liu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: HIGH-TECH CRIME PREVENTION CENTER FORMED UNDER CIB

TEXT.P: A scientific crime prevention center was formed Thursday by the Criminal Investigation Bureau (CIB) under the National Police Agency (NPA) to stamp out diverse forms of high-tech crime, NPA Director-General Hou You-yi said.
Hou noted that with the rapid development of information technology, criminal rings are also taking advantage of the new benefits posed by the information superhighway.
High-tech methods used by criminal rings are challenging the investigative capabilities of the police, Hou said, stressing that "problems brought on by science should be resolved by science."

Hou went on to say a new building for the center, which is under construction, will be completed in three years. The modernized building will have a laboratory for international standard forensic identification to combat high-tech crime.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATIVE SPEAKER OPEN TO 'TWO-IN-ONE' ELECTION PROPOSAL

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng said Thursday that he is open to a proposal by the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) on holding the December 2007 legislative election and the March 2008 presidential election simultaneously if a consensus is built on the issue between ruling and opposition camps.

The proposal seems beneficial to the KMT, which gained seats over the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) in the "three-in-one" local elections late last year, but the DPP's attitude will be key in whether the proposal can be put into practice, Wang told reporters.

Wang added that he would throw his support behind the proposal should both ruling and opposition parties back the idea. It is important that such a proposal, based upon a social consensus, is allowed to really help the country reduce waste and lower the risk of social disorder, he said, noting that the nation's overall interests should take precedence over partisan gains.

KMT legislative caucus whip Pan Wei-kang called for support from the various major political parties on grounds that holding the two elections simultaneously will help save spending and social resources.

The "two-in-one" election proposal will benefit the entire nation rather than just the KMT, she claimed, opining that doing so will also coincide with the DPP's stance in favor of holding fewer elections to avoid wasting resources.

KMT lawmaker Wu Yu-sheng, who initiated the proposal, said that both President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu have publicly called for a reduction in the number of elections. It is an issue that meets the public's expectations while being consistent with the DPP's stance, he argued.

Admitting that combining the legislative and presidential elections would be more beneficial to the KMT, Wu said that it is not the key point in this case and stressed that it is unfair to target the KMT when discussing the issue.
He urged the ruling DPP to support his proposal as the KMT did in backing former Premier Frank Hsieh's idea of holding the "three-in-one" local elections late last year.

DPP legislative caucus whip Chen Chin-jun responded later in a news conference he called at the Legislative Yuan that President Chen, if backed by public consensus, would "respect" and "cooperate" on the "two-in-one election" proposal in the interest of the nation's long-term development.
According to Chen, DPP members remain sharply divided over the issue at the present time.

Lu Hsueh-chang, a People First Party (PFP) legislative caucus whip, said that his party is not opposed to establishing a sound election system that is in line with the Constitution, but called for greater caution.
Lu questioned whether in the future, the president should also step down if he dissolved the Legislative Yuan -- Taiwan's parliament.
Taiwan Solidarity Union legislative caucus whip David Huang said that he suspected the KMT's initiative was aimed at expanding its voter base.
Huang said that it would be meaningless if it were necessary to hold a snap parliamentarian election should the president dissolve the Legislative Yuan.
The KMT's "two-in-one" election proposal is merely an electioneering strategy which he said was useless in helping build a healthy constitutional system.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Fossil Called Missing Link From Sea to Land Animals
Scientists have discovered fossils of a 375- million-year-old fish, a large scaly creature not seen before, that they say is a long-sought missing link in the evolution of some fishes from water to a life walking on four limbs on land. In two reports today in the journal Nature, a team of scientists led by Neil H. Shubin of the University of Chicago say they have uncovered several well-preserved skeletons of the fossil fish in sediments of former streambeds in the Canadian Arctic, 600 miles from the North Pole. The skeletons have the fins, scales and other attributes of a giant fish, four to nine feet long. But on closer examination, the scientists found telling anatomical traits of a transitional creature, a fish that is still a fish but has changes that anticipate the emergence of land animals -- and is thus a predecessor of amphibians, reptiles and dinosaurs, mammals and eventually humans.
Wall Street Journal: Higher Learning In Religion Studies, Universities Bend To Views of Faithful
In 1993, the Mormon church excommunicated D. Michael Quinn, one of the world's foremost authorities on the faith, whose writings had frequently contradicted the church's traditional history. Although Mormon studies is a fast-growing academic discipline, Quinn -- a former professor at Mormon-run Brigham Young University and the author of six books on Mormon history -- can't find a job. Quinn's struggles reflect the rising influence of religious groups over the teaching of their faiths at secular colleges, despite concerns about academic freedom. U.S. universities have usually hired religious-studies professors regardless of whether they practiced or admired the faiths they researched. But some universities are bending to the views of private donors and state legislators by hiring the faithful. Some professors at the state universities that rejected Quinn say fear of offending Mormons played a role. Deans at the universities deny that.

DOC.HEADLINE: COA LAUNCHES TEA DRINKING FESTIVAL APRIL 7

TEXT.P: The Council of Agriculture (COA) is launching a national "Tea Drinking Day" April 7 and is encouraging everyone to try sipping Taiwanese tea at one of the farms where it is cultivated.
According to the COA, people interested in drinking this refreshing beverage can visit tea farms featuring a special flag raised for the occasion.

The tea-drinking festivity lasts until the end of June and also includes providing free, tasty tea for people at several government agencies, where Taiwan-grown tea will also be sold for an attractive price.

Tea will also be served free of charge at 10 train stations around Taiwan: Taipei, Taoyuan, Hsinchu, Taichung, Chiayi, Tainan, Kaohsiung, Taitung, Hualien and Ilan so that Taiwanese tea can reach a larger number of aficionados.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW U.K. ARTIST LAUNCHES EXHIBITION IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: A British artist who specializes in telematic arts is holding an exhibition in Taipei to bring remote participants together in a shared "telepresent environment" and reflect his resident experience in Taiwan, exhibition organizers said Thursday.

Paul Sermon, who was invited by Taipei Artist Village (TAV) for a 10-week stay as a resident artist, launched his "telematic" exhibition titled "Headroom" at the Xinyi Public Assembly Hall, running from April 4-20.
"Headroom is a juxtaposition of my experience in Taipei, " said Sermon, who arrived in Taiwan Feb. 27.

Sermon said he arrived in Taiwan with a "blank canvas, " not really having any idea in mind about what project to work on. After some visits and an observation that lasted for several weeks, he came up with the Headroom idea.

Sermon won the Golden Nica at the Prix Ars Electronica in Austria in 1991. His work "Telematic Dreaming 05" was part of "Climax-The Highlights of Arts Electronica" at the National Museum of Fine Arts in Taichung last year.
He will stay in Taipei and work on more exhibition projects until May 6.
The exhibition is co-organized by the British Council, the Taipei Cultural Foundation and the TAV.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO SEND BIRD FLU MEDICAL CORPS TO BURKINA FASO

TEXT.P: Taiwan will dispatch a medical corps along with medications for bird flu to Burkina Faso as soon as Friday for relief action, Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs Michael Ying-mao Kau said Thursday.
According to international media reports, Burkina Faso confirmed three bird flu cases in poultry Monday and notified the World Health Organization Tuesday.
Meanwhile, Minister of Foreign Affairs Huang Chih-fang will visit Chad in mid-April to conduct the annual briefings of overseas missions in Africa, Kau said.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATIVE YUAN DEPUTY SPEAKER VISITS SOUTH KOREA

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Legislative Yuan Deputy Speaker David J.C. Chung met with Kim Duk-kyu, deputy speaker of South Korea's National Assembly, in Seoul Thursday in an attempt to promote Taiwan-South Korea parliamentary exchanges.

During their meeting, Chung, who is currently on a five-day visit to South Korea, said he highly admired Kim's contributions toward the country's political, democratic and economic developments and also appreciated his efforts to promote Taiwan-South Korea ties.
It was hoped that relations between Taiwan and South Korea can be further strengthened, Chung said.

In response, Kim said he would help boost parliamentary exchanges between the two countries. Kim further said that he hoped Taiwan and China could set up "a paradigm of co-prosperity" by carrying out talks to ease differences and to step up the cross-strait peace process.
Chung is slated to return to Taiwan April 9.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER DETERMINED TO IMPROVE ECONOMY, SOCIAL ORDER

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang said Thursday that he regards improving the economy and social order, offering better care for the less privileged and fighting against corruption as the Cabinet's top four priorities.
Su made the remarks during an award ceremony for a group of 33 excellent architects.
The premier stressed that a sound economy will attract more investment and that better social order will elevate the happiness of the people.

In addition to offering low-interest rate loans to people planning to buy houses, Su also expressed hope that builders will construct more low-priced houses, which he said will make it easier for young people to afford their own houses.
Besides, Su added, the government will complete as soon as possible urban planning and regulations governing architects in order to attract more foreign investment in this area.

In response to allegations that the National Property Bureau's (NPU) recent selling of state-owned land to business groups might involve illegal profiteering, Su said that he completed several public construction projects during his six-year stint as Taipei county magistrate and he defended the NPU under the Ministry of Finance by claiming that there will be no profiteering during the sale of the plots if they are subject to open bidding.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATION ON SENSITIVE TECHNOLOGY PROTECTION STALLS IN COMMITTEE

TEXT.P: The sensitive scientific technology protection bill hit a snag in the Legislative Yuan Thursday when a meeting held by the Sci-Tech and Information Committee to deliberate the bill failed to make any progress.

The committee called the meeting to begin clause-by-clause consideration of the bill, but could not finish its examination of the language in Clause One because of a volatile debate among legislators of different political parties who were each sticking to their strongly held but divergent views.

As a result, Legislator Lee Jih-chu, a co-convener of the committee who chaired the meeting, had no choice but to dismiss the meeting. Lee, of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT), said she will try to seek consensus on the bill among the committee members, beginning by communicating with KMT legislators.

She said she had thought the draft version of the bill, sponsored by 56 legislators, would best represent the KMT's stance, but was surprised when some KMT legislators on the committee expressed reservations over the legislation.

KMT Legislator Lee Yong-ping said that while she does not object to the legislation, she believes the bill should be considered only under the premise that it will not affect Taiwan's competitive edge by triggering fear among Taiwan's industries and prompting them to move their production bases to China and elsewhere.

Another KMT legislator, Ting Shou-chung, insisted that consideration of the bill should be suspended. He said the KMT should not give the people the impression it is assisting the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and its ally, the Taiwan Solidarity Union, in their attempts to tighten control on Taiwan's economic and trade relations with China.
Currently, there are six different versions of the sensitive scientific technology protection bill, with the one introduced by the KMT legislative caucus having the largest number of sponsors.

The bill was first proposed by the Cabinet in April last year in an attempt to prevent the export of sensitive technologies to China without government approval after Beijing enacted its Anti-Secession Law, which provides for the use of force against Taiwan if China decides Taiwan is moving toward independence.

DOC.HEADLINE: BIRD LOVERS ENCOURAGED TO WATCH BIRDS OF PREY ON KUANYIN MOUNTAIN

TEXT.P: The Wild Bird Society of Taipei said Thursday that bird lovers should grasp the opportunity in April to see the various birds of prey that migrate past Taiwan on their way north.

A spokesman for the society said that Kuanyin mountain, beside the Tansui river in Bali, Taipei County, is an ideal site for watching the migrating birds of prey and that the society will hold free guided tours on four Sundays from April 9 at a tourist center in Bali to let bird lovers understand the species that frequent the area and their habitats.

He said that at least 12 species of migratory raptors can be seen in the area of Kauanyin mountain in April, including buzzards, the common kestrel, the Chinese sparrowhawk, the grey-faced buzzard eagle, the Oriental honey buzzard, the Japanese sparrowhawk, the osprey, the peregrine falcon, the northern sparrowhawk and the northern goshawk.

Those interested in seeing the birds should bring a pair of binoculars, sunglasses, water and a hat, the spokesman said, adding that the Wild Bird Society of Taipei will provide free bus services between the bird watching sites and the ferry port at Bali.

DOC.HEADLINE: VP PUSHES FOR EARLY IMPLEMENTATION OF 'GOOD HOUSEKEEPING PROJECT'

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu pushed Thursday for the early implementation of the "Good Housekeeping Project" so that qualified housekeepers can be produced via an examination mechanism to benefit society.

Addressing a workshop held at the Presidential Office on women's unemployment and employment services to women, Lu claimed that Taiwan would be able to import far fewer foreign workers if the Good Housekeeping Project is carried out quickly and efficiently.
Lu said housekeeping can be a respectable career with high social values if the housekeepers are publicly screened via an examination mechanism and have received professional training.

Lu said that while a great number of Taiwan families need to hire housekeepers to help run their families, there are also a great number of women who need to seek employment to support their families.
Under these circumstances, Lu claimed, the Good Housekeeping Project -- put forth by her late last year and endorsed by President Chen Shui-bian -- will serve both needs.

She said that of Taiwan's 11.2 million female population, about 4.2 million are career women or working women. Of the 4.2 million working women, 2.05 million have college or higher education. There are also some 400,000 married couples in Taiwan who are both working and some 557,000 people who have families with elderly or handicapped members.
All these groups of people need the help of housekeepers, providing at least 1 million job openings for career housekeepers, according to Lu.

Meanwhile, she added, there are some 400,000 women who are not working after getting married or having children and there are some 560,000 single-parent families, most of them are of the mother-child composition.
Members of these groups may need to seek employment working as housekeepers, she speculated.

DOC.HEADLINE: HONG KONG URGED TO OPEN LIAISON OFFICE IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: A Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) official in charge of Hong Kong affairs urged the Hong Kong authorities Thursday to open a liaison office in Taipei the sooner the better for the benefit of the special administrative region's residents.
Tsai Chih-chung, director of the MAC's Department of Hong Kong and Macau Affairs, called for the Hong Kong authorities not to impose any preconditions on the establishment of such an office.

Tsai said that by establishing an office in Taiwan, the Hong Kong authorities could better serve its people and engage in closer exchanges with Taiwan in many sectors, as Taiwan-Hong Kong exchanges have become increasingly close with more Hong Kong people coming to Taiwan for tourism or study.

The number of visits to Hong Kong by Taiwan citizens has increased year on year, with the figure standing at 2.6 million in 2003, increasing to 3.32 million in 2004 and 3.9 million in 2005, Tsai said.

To serve the people of Hong Kong and Macau and to facilitate the visits to these two regions by Taiwan citizens, the MAC established a Hong Kong affairs bureau and a Macau affairs bureau -- known as the Chung Hwa Travel Service in Hong Kong and the Taipei Economic and Cultural Center in Macau -- several years ago, Tsai added.
These two agencies are also the Taiwan offices responsible for handling emergencies, Tsai noted.
He said the number of emergencies has also risen over the past three years, with 831 in 2003, soaring to 2,220 in 2004 and 3,092 in 2005.

Tsai made the remarks in response to an inquiry by a reporter who quoted an unnamed Hong Kong media outlet as reporting Thursday that Stephen S.L. Lam, secretary of Hong Kong's Constitutional Affairs Bureau, has said that Hong Kong will establish a liaison office in Taiwan only after Taiwan opens direct trade, postal and transportation links with China, commonly known as the "direct three links."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WANTS MEANINGFUL PARTICIPATION IN WHO: FOREIGN MINISTRY

TEXT.P: Taipei, April 6 (CAN) Taiwan is striving for "meaningful participation" in the World Health Organization (WHO), to be included in the organization's alert and response network and to attend all professional and technical seminars, Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs Michael Ying-mao Kau said Thursday.

Taiwan has made bids to join the WHO over the past decade that have failed due to China's strong objections. This year, Taiwan continues to its bid to become an observer in the World Health Assembly (WHA), the supreme decision-making body for the WHO.
"The focus this year is meaningful participation in the WHO... but so far, we have yet to reach meaningful, pragmatic or systematic participation, " Kau told the Central News Agency.

Kau said that if the WHO members respond to Taiwan's intention for meaningful participation this year, then Taiwan will not push for a vote on the floor on its application for WHA membership in May, but if international community shies away from supporting Taiwan, then Taiwan will again push for a vote.

Kau defined "meaningful participation" as Taiwan's inclusion in the WHO's Global Outbreak Alert and Response Network, a mechanism for the rapid identification, confirmation and response to outbreaks of international importance.

He said Taiwan also wants to participate in all WHO professional and technical seminars. While Taiwan participated in about half of those seminars in 2005, Kau said the degree of Taiwan's participation was "not satisfactory." Further, Taiwan also wants to become involved in events held by WHO's regional offices, he said.

Meanwhile, Taiwan is still striving for the universal application of the International Health Regulations, which aim to prevent, protect against, control and provide a public health response to the international spread of disease and avoid unnecessary interference with international traffic and trade.
Besides "meaningful participation" in the WHO, Kau said, Taiwan still wants to become an observer in the WHA.
Kau, who went to Europe last month to seek European countries' support for Taiwan's membership of the WHO, said that some European countries are very supportive of Taiwan's stance.
However, as a diplomat told him that "Europe is an elephant with 25 legs, " Kau said that for the European Union to reach a consensus on Taiwan's WHO efforts remains a challenge.
Talking about Taiwan's bid to become a WHA observer this year, he said the government will adopt a "strong and positive" approach.

"If Taiwan continues to be a good boy, then others would continue to take us for granted, and we get nowhere, " Kau said. He said the government this year is considering setting up balloons with strong slogans above the WHO secretariat to attract attention and embarrass the WHO.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT STATUS QUO ALWAYS CHANGING: FOREIGN MINISTRY

TEXT.P: Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs Michael Ying-mao Kau said Thursday that the status quo in cross-Taiwan Strait relations is dynamic rather than unchangeable, and that good relations will only come with efforts from both sides.
Kau noted that China has increased the number of missiles aimed at Taiwan from 200 to 800, while Taiwan has changed from an authoritarian regime to a democratic one.

"The concept of maintaining status quo is wrong -- we should be maintaining peace and stability and that is a more concrete way to phrase it, " he said during an interview with the Central News Agency.

Kau said the international community should not bow to China just because they want to invest there and should not over-appease China. Using Hitler as an example, he said that if the international community had stood firm against Hitler in the 1930s, World War II might not have broken out.
He said that China is a rising powerhouse and that it is the responsibility of the international community to guide China to become a peaceful country.

Asked about the National Unification Council issue, Kau said the government should not make policies to limit the people's choices and that the choice of unification or independence is up to the people.

"We need to be pragmatic -- we cannot provoke China and affect peace and stability in the Taiwan Strait and we cannot sacrifice Taiwan's democracy, " said Kau, who went to Europe last month to explain Taiwan's stance on the issue.

Kau pointed out that European Union has a different footing from Taiwan and that it wants Taiwan and China to get along with each other and avoid provocation, although it also understands that good relations will come only with efforts from both sides.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S INFLATION RATE REACHES 1.35 PERCENT IN Q1 2006

TEXT.P: Taiwan's consumer price index (CPI) rose 0.41 percent in March over the same period last year, with the year-on-year CPI increase amounting to 1.35 percent in the first quarter of 2006, the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) reported Thursday.

Meanwhile, the wholesale price index (WPI) gained 2.02 percent in March compared to the same period last year, with the year-on-year WPI increase registering 1.81 percent in the first quarter of 2006, according to the DGBAS.
DGBAS officials said the inflation rate of 0.41 percent in March is the lowest single-month level since February 2004, mainly due to the decline in vegetable and fruit prices.

In 2005, the inflation rate climbed 2.3 percent, the highest level over the last five years, owing to skyrocketing vegetable and fruit prices as a result of crop damages caused by a string of typhoons that blew through Taiwan between July and September last year.
The DGBAS forecast the CPI will pick up 1.7 percent for the whole of 2006.

DOC.HEADLINE: FIREWORKS, MUSIC FESTIVAL KICKS OFF PENGHU TOURIST SEASON

TEXT.P: The upcoming 2006 Penghu Fireworks and Music Festival that starts a four-month long tourist season that organizers hope will draw even more tourists this year to the island county, which enjoys rich tourism and recreational resources, Penghu County Magistrate Wang Chien-fa said Thursday at a press conference.

The festival combining fireworks over the sea and music performances will officially start April 15. After the conclusion of the first phase June 18, the second phase will take place from July 29-Aug. 4.
There will be fireworks displays and live performances every two days during the first phase, while a seven-day music festival is the focus of the second phase, organizers said.

More than 300,000 tourists visited Penghu during the festival last year, Wang said. With the Penghu county government organizing the event for the first time in the event's four-year history, Wang expressed confident that the number of tourists will hit an all-time high.

Originally an idea from a travel Web site after the 2003 Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome outbreak scared off tourists from Taiwan, the festival has seen success during the past three years and has become an integral part of Penghu's tourism projects.
To attract more visitors, domestic airlines will also help out with special deals on long-weekend breaks as well as reduced-price tickets.
The Penghu islands, also known as the Pescadores, are an archipelago in the Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT APPROVES JUDICIAL YUAN DEPUTY HEAD'S RESIGNATION

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian has approved Judicial Yuan Vice President Cheng Chung-mo's resignation over a suspected extramarital affair, a Presidential Office spokesman said Thursday.

Cheng, who doubles as a grand justice, offered to resign from the two posts earlier in the day after the media widely reported that he and a woman professor went to a motel in suburban Taipei together and stayed there for more than an hour on Sunday.

Judicial Yuan President Weng Yueh-sheng immediately forwarded Cheng's resignation letter to Chen, who approved the resignation, said Lee Nan-yang, director of the Presidential Office's Public Affairs Department.
Lee said Chen had yet to decide whether to name a candidate to fill the posts left vacant by Cheng's resignation.

Under current constitutional provisions, only grand justices are eligible to serve as Judicial Yuan president or vice president and the president can only appoint a grand justice with the consent of the Legislative Yuan.

As the Judicial Yuan Organic Law does not prescribe that vacancies in the Judicial Yuan vice president and grand justice roster must be filled, Lee said Chen is still mulling whether to come up with a grand justice nominee for legislative confirmation or just to select a candidate from among the 13 incumbent grand justices to serve as Judicial Yuan vice president.
"The president must make a comprehensive review before a final decision can be made," Lee said.

Cheng Chung-mo, 66, issued a news statement early in the day that he had offered his resignation to the head of the Judicial Yuan, Taiwan's highest judicial body. As a grand justice, he supervises the court system and helps to interpret the Constitution.
Cheng said he would resign from both jobs, claiming that the motel event "has been misreported and exaggerated by the media and has damaged the reputation of the judiciary."

A local newspaper reported Wednesday that Cheng drove a woman to what is known as a "love hotel" and escorted her out 70 minutes later. Cheng, a married man, denied having an affair with the woman, identified as 38-year-old Wang Mei-hsin, an assistant law professor at National Yunlin University of Science and Technology in southern Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEVEL OF TAIWAN FOREX RESERVES SOUND: ECONOMIST

TEXT.P: Although Taiwan does not sit on top of the world's highest level of foreign exchange reserves, the size of the country's forex reserves remains sound, according to a local economist.

Despite the fact that Taiwan's forex reserves have been amassing at a slower pace in recent years as a result of a decreasing trade surplus and a steady but not drastic capital outflow due to investment overseas, the country still holds a relatively high amount of forex reserves, said Chu Hao-min, a professor at National Chengchi University.
Chu opined that Taiwan's forex reserves will remain relatively stable as long as the country's current account and capital account do not show large amounts of capital outflows.

According to statistics made public by Taiwan's Central Bank of China (CBC) early this week, Taiwan holds the world's third largest amount -- US$257.05 billion -- in forex reserves as of the end of March, coming after only China and Japan. The figure represents a slight growth of US$72 million over the February level.
CBC Governor Perng Fei-nan has said that Taiwan's forex reserves remain at a sound level even compared with China's in view of the sharp difference in size of the two country's economies.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA CHIEF SECRETARY SAID TO BE NEW ENVOY TO SOUTH KOREA

TEXT.P: Minister of Foreign Affairs Huang Chih-fang refused to confirm or deny Thursday a media report that Chen Yeong-cho, secretary-general of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, has been tipped to serve as the nation's representative to South Korea.

Huang told reporters after meeting with Francesco R. Bitti, president of the International Tennis Federation, that the ministry has indeed chosen a replacement to succeed Lee Tsai-fang as head of the Taipei mission in Seoul.
But he said it would be inappropriate to reveal the identity of the replacement before the completion of all administrative formalities.
According to the media reports, Chen will be Taiwan's next representative in Seoul in the absence of formal diplomatic ties.

Chen is a career diplomat whose previous overseas missions include head of the nation's representative office in Johannesburg, South Africa and ambassador to Liberia. He has also served as deputy head of the ministry's Information and Cultural Affairs Department.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO ADVANCE TIES WITH SOUTH PACIFIC ALLIES: MOFA

TEXT.P: Taiwan's six diplomatic allies in the South Pacific remain unmoved by China's money diplomacy and the government is poised to iron out measures to further enhance bilateral ties with them, Minister of Foreign Affairs Huang Chih-fang said Friday.

Huang made the remarks while answering questions from reporters after Chinese Premier Wen Jiabao announced a preferential loan valued at 3 billion yuan over three years to promote a series of cooperative ventures in agriculture, fisheries and energy with South Pacific island nations at the end of the first China-Pacific Island Countries Economic Development and Cooperation Forum from April 4.

Despite China's efforts to entice the six countries -- Kiribati, Nauru, Palau, the Marshall Islands, the Solomon Islands and Tuvalu -- to take part in the forum, they did not do so, thanks to solid bilateral relations with Taiwan, Huang said, adding that the government will come up with concrete measures to further step up two-way links with these countries.
According to the foreign minister, Taiwan's good relations with the six countries are based on successful bilateral joint ventures that make up the backbone of their economies.
Dismissing a widespread assumption that Taiwan and China are engaged in a "diplomatic battle" in the South Pacific, Huang said that "we don't mean to do so with any country in the world."

But he declined to confirm media speculation that President Chen Shui-bian will visit Nauru in July, saying only that the president hopes to visit all Taiwan's diplomatic allies before he ends his tenure in May 2008.

DOC.HEADLINE: REPORT ON HEALTH OF VIETNAMESE BRIDES TO BE READY IN TWO MONTHS

TEXT.P: The National Health Research Institutes (NHRI) accepted a suggestion from an opposition legislator Thursday to study the health of Vietnamese women married to Taiwanese men and present a report in two months.

Legislator Ho Tsai-feng, of the main opposition Kuomintang, requested that the NHRI look into the issue so as to clear the name of Vietnamese brides after Liao Pen-yen, a legislator of the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU), voiced concern that the women might still carry residue of herbicides sprayed by U.S. military forces during the Vietnam War.

Liao later apologized for his remarks after angry civic groups joined Vietnamese brides in Taiwan to stage a protest against him. The TSU has also apologized and promised to discipline Liao for his "inappropriate" remarks.
Liang Keng-yi, acting head of the NHRI, promised that the NHRI will study the issue and present a report by June 6.
The NHRI is a non-profit foundation established by the government in 1995 for the purpose of conducting medical research and improving health care.

The TSU lawmaker expressed his fear based on reports that between 1962 and 1971, U.S. military forces sprayed some 20 million gallons of herbicides over South Vietnam, with Agent Orange accounting for much of the total sprayed. Laboratory tests have found that the chemical can cause birth defects in animals.

In March 2005, a lawsuit was filed in the United States on behalf of 4 million Vietnamese who claimed to have suffered persistent respiratory and reproductive problems as a result of being contaminated by Agent Orange. They were seeking compensation from 30 U.S. chemical companies for providing the Pentagon with the toxic defoliant.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH KEEPS WATCHFUL EYE ON FEVER IN CHINA'S HENAN PROVINCE

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) is keeping a watchful eye on an outbreak of fever in China's Henan Province, a health official said Thursday.

Shih Wen-yi, deputy director of the DOH's Center for Disease Control, said the DOH has asked the Chinese authorities to provide sufficient information about reports that a group of people in Henan have developed fever.

"At the moment, we have scant information about the fever situation there. Given Taiwan's geographical proximity to China and the close civilian exchanges across the Taiwan Strait, we must keep alert to any epidemic situation in China," Shih said.

According to Shih, the World Health Organization has also pushed China to give a detailed report on the public health situation in the Henan region. Amid global concerns about the spread of the deadly H5N1 strain of avian influenza, Shih said the DOH has been remaining vigilant and has worked out contingency measures.

Meanwhile, relevant government units held a joint epidemic control drill at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport's domestic flight apron Thursday to practice operational procedures in the event of a passenger aboard an incoming flight showing suspicious symptoms of avian influenza.
The drill covered 11 operations, including passengers immigration, fever screening, quarantine notice, identity verification, luggage inspection and customs clearance.

Premier Su Tseng-chang, DOH Minister Hou Sheng-mao and senior officials from various government agencies traveled to the airport to see for themselves the whole process of the epidemic prevention drill.

Su said epidemic control is like a war that requires team work, discipline and smooth logistic support. He urged central and local government units to cooperate closely in disease prevention and as the epidemic control network tolerates no holes or ruptures.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET HOLDS SPECIAL MEETING ON ECONOMIC STIMULUS STRATEGY

TEXT.P: The Cabinet called a special meeting of economic and financial officials Thursday to discuss new strategy to stimulate domestic demand and boost investment with a view to sustaining the nation's economic growth.

The meeting, presided over by Premier Su Tseng-chang, focused on weighing measures for mitigating the possible negative impact on private consumption of the swelling credit card debts which have prodded local banks to tighten the individual consumer credit line.

Speaking at the meeting, Hu Sheng-cheng, chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development, said the council will organize an inter-department meeting next week to map out strategies to ensure that the local economy keeps a 4.5 percent growth rate this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, April 7, or the 10th day of the Third month of the Year of the Dog according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1348: Charles IV, king of Bohemia, founds Prague University, the first university in central Europe.
1827: John Waller, a chemist in northern England, sells the first matches, which he invented.
1928: Chiang Kai-shek resumes the Northward Expedition at the order of the National Government.
1932: A National Emergency Conference in Loyang decides on continued resistance against Japanese aggression.
1934: Mahatma Gandhi suspends his campaign of civil disobedience against British rule in India.
1945: The Yamato, Japan's largest battleship, is sunk by U.S. aircraft carrier warplanes.
1947: Henry Ford, American car manufacturer, dies at the age of 84. He developed a gasoline-powered automobile in 1893, founded the Ford Motor Company in 1903, and mass-produced the Model T from 1908 to 1927.
1948: The World Health Organization (WHO) is founded in Geneva.
1953: Dag Hammarskjold, Swedish diplomat and political leader who won the 1961 Nobel Peace Prize posthumously, succeeds Trygve Lie as secretary-general of the United Nations.
1954: Jackie Chan, Hong Kong movie star who is noted for his action films, is born.
1963: The Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia is set up with Marshal Tito as president for life.
1969: Traffic courts are set up in Taipei City and other locations around Taiwan to begin handling traffic violation cases.
1976: Simon Kuznets, 1971 Nobel Prize winner for economics, arrives in Taipei for a three-week-visit.
1976: The Communist Party of China's Political Bureau decides at a meeting to appoint Hua Guofeng as premier and to depose Deng Xiaoping as deputy premier after riots in Beijing.
1976: Hishan M. Nazer, Saudi Arabian minister of planning, arrives in Taipei for a six-day visit.
1978: U.S. President Jimmy Carter backpedals on building the Neutron bomb.
1979: The International Olympic Committee decides the ROC can retain its membership while admitting Communist China as a new member.
1981: Voters in the Philippines approve a new constitution, giving President Ferdinand Marcos sweeping powers.
1987: U.S. President Ronald Reagan announces that American diplomats will not occupy the new embassy in Moscow until he is sure that it is secure against Soviet eavesdropping.
1989: Cheng Nan-jong, the person in charge of the "Era of Freedom" magazine, immolates himself after refusing arrest for involvement in an insurrection case.
1989: The Chinese Taipei Olympic Committee announces that ROC athletic teams and organizations will participate in international sports events held on the mainland under the name "Chinese Taipei."
1990: Communist China launches a U.S.-made telecommunications satellite into orbit.
1998: Indonesia and the International Monetary Fund agree on a package of measures to get a US$43 billion bailout package on track.
1999: Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission Minister Chiao Jen-ho urges the government to step up its international publicity drive to buttress global awareness of the Republic of China.
2000: Almost two-dozen founding members of the hard-line Independence Party announce their decision to drop out of the party because they say that the party has completed its mission.
2001: Tibetan spiritual leader, the Dalai Lama, receives a set of CNA file photos, including one showing he in the arms of his mother along with his father and his elder brother.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "When there is justice and order in the government of the country, to think only of pay is dishonorable. When there is no justice and order in the government of the country, to think only of pay is also dishonorable."

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT TO ATTEND COLLEGE SPORTS MEET OPENING CEREMONY

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian is scheduled to attend the opening Friday of the 2006 National University Games to be held at the National Yunlin University of Science and Technology in the southern Taiwan.
Around 12,000 athletes from 164 colleges and universities are taking part in a total of 11 events at the five-day sports meet.
The torch-lighting at the opening ceremony in the evening will feature a blimp, solar-powered vehicle and other high-tech creative touches.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN PRESENTS WOODBALL GAME EQUIPMENT TO DENMARK
DOC.DATELINE: Berlin, April 6 (CNA) (By Lin Yu-li and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's representative in Denmark gave a batch of woodball game equipment to the national athletic and sports committee of Denmark Thursday to help promote the sport in the Scandinavian country.

Chang Ping-nan presented the gift -- including 50 9.5 cm-diameter wooden balls, 50 mallet-shaped clubs, 25 scoring gates and a number of tee boxes -- to Knud Bjorn, vice chairman of the Danish national athletic and sports committee during a ceremony held in Copenhagen Thursday.

Woodball, which was invented by Taiwan citizen Wong Ming-hui in 1990, has become an internationally known sport following a series of international competitions being held in Taiwan and abroad over the past 15 years.

Bjorn, who visited Taiwan at the invitation of Wong -- chairman of the Chinese Taipei Woodball Association and the Federation of International Woodball Associations -- for an international woodball competition last November, accepted the gift with gratitude.

Bjorn said during the ceremony that he will see to it that woodball is promoted in Denmark and that exchanges in other athletic and sports categories, including gymnastics, between the two countries will also be enhanced.
He said the assistance from the Taiwan representative office in Denmark is essential for boosting bilateral sports exchanges in the future.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVERSEAS TAIWANESE MEDICAL GROUP URGES EU TO SUPPORT TAIWAN'S WHO BID
DOC.DATELINE: Brussels, April 6 (CNA) (By P.C. Tang and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: A group comprised of Taiwanese medical workers in Europe called on the European Union Thursday to support Taiwan's bid to participate as an observer in the World Health Assembly (WHA) -- the highest decision-making body of the World Health Organization (WHO).

During a news conference held in the Belgian capital, leading members of the European Federation of Taiwan Health Alliance, including Chang Lian-tze, Lee Hung-yao, Yeh Hsueh-yuan and Huang Li-teh, asserted that it is unfair for the WHO to exclude Taiwan.

Chang said that Taiwan is being blocked from entering the WHO for political reasons and that the organization should not allow health issues to be overridden by politics, urging EU nations to help Taiwan take part as an observer in the next WHA annual meeting slated for May.
Lee said Taiwan's exclusion violates the WHO's principle of universality and also threatens the health of the people of Taiwan and the rest of the world.

As Taiwan is not a WHO member, it cannot obtain information with regard to the prevention and control of major infectious diseases, and even if some countries intend to cooperate with Taiwan, they face pressure from China, Lee pointed out.
Even during the SARS outbreak in 2003, Taiwan was not offered any immediate assistance from the WHO, Lee said.

Further illustrating the unfair treatment received by Taiwan, Yeh noted that while Taiwan has so far remained free of H5N1 bird flu cases, the country was classified as an H5N1-affected area in maps published by the WHO last month because the WHO considers Taiwan part of China, where H5N1 cases have been reported.

Although the European Parliament passed a resolution in 2003 urging the EU nations to support Taiwan's bid to gain observer status at the WHA, the resolution continues to be ignored by the EU, Yeh said.
Huang said that in light of the increase in international travel and economic activities, Taiwan must not be shut out of the world health system.
Meanwhile, Taiwan's representative to the European Union Chen Chien-jen said what Taiwan is asking for is to be treated fairly and reasonably by the world.

With Taiwan's efforts over the past 10 years, the United States and Japan have openly expressed their support for Taiwan's WHO bid, while the European Union has become more sympathetic towards Taiwan, Chen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP URGES KMT TO PROTECT TAIWAN'S INTERESTS AT BEIJING FORUM

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) urged the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Friday to protect Taiwan's interests at the upcoming economic forum between the KMT and the Chinese Communist Party to be held in Beijing.

Tsai Huang-liang, director of the DPP Department of Culture and Information, called for the forum-goers, including KMT Honorary Chairman Lien Chan and 29 KMT legislators, not to "dwarf Taiwan's sovereignty" and not to infringe upon the Taiwan government's administrative authority during talks with the Chinese communists.

Tsai suggested that the KMT members and lawmakers tell the Chinese authorities to take back the illegal Chinese immigrants currently being detained in Taiwan as soon as possible as the country's three detention centers are overcrowded and cost over NT$100 million (US$3.08 million) a year to operate.
Tsai further suggested that the KMT forum-goers ask the Chinese authorities to apprehend major Taiwan criminals and fugitives in hiding in China and repatriate them back to Taiwan to face justice.
The DPP spokesman also suggested that they ask the Beijing leadership to stop undermining Taiwan's bid to join the World Health Organization as an observer.
The KMT-CCP forum is set to be held in Beijing April 14 and may be followed by a meeting between Lien Chan and Chinese President Hu Jintao, which would be their second meeting since April last year.

In addition to 29 KMT lawmakers and a number of KMT party officials, members of Lien's 60-strong delegation will also include prominent businesspeople who serve on the KMT Central Standing Committee, such as Jeffery Koo, chairman of the Chinatrust Financial Holding and Kao Chin-yen, chairman of the Uni-President Group.
