DOC.HEADLINE: BETEL NUT CHEWING RELATED TO UPPER DIGESTIVE TRACT CANCERS: STUDY

TEXT.P: Betel nut chewing is not only the leading cause of oral cancer in Taiwan, it also increases the risk of getting other forms of cancer, according to the results of the latest study by the National Health Research Institutes (NHRI) released Friday.
Currently, there are around 70,000 new cancer cases reported in Taiwan every year. Cases related to betel nut chewing account for between six and eight percent of that total.

About 30 out of every 100,000 men in Taiwan develop oral cancer, ranking the country third in the world in this respect. Moreover, the average age when men with oral cancer pass away is 53, or ten years younger than men with other forms of cancer.
The NHRI said that according to its most recent study, carried out in cooperation with the Kaohsiung Medical University, betel nut chewing is also linked to pharynx, larynx and asophageal cancers.

Ker Ying-chin, director of the NHRI's Division of Environmental Health and Occupational Medicine, said that arecoline, a major alkaloid found in betel nut, may cause upper digestive tract cancers such as pharynx, larynx and asophageal cancers.
The study showed that the risk of betel nut chewers getting pharynx cancer is 7.7 times greater than that for other people.

Cigarette smoking and drinking are cited as the leading causes of larynx cancer and asophageal cancer, with the risks multiplying if one smokes, drinks and chews betel nuts. The pharynx incidence ratio increases 96.9 fold, the risk of developing larynx cancer increases 40.3 fold, and the risk of developing asophageal increases 195 fold, according to the study.

Ker noted that betel nut chewing over a long period could also cause liver cancer or sclerosis of the liver. He urged betel nut chewers to undergo regular oral examinations, adding that the best thing to do is to give up the habit altogether.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR CANDIDATE URGES GOV'T TO PREPARE BETTER AGAINST BIRD FLU

TEXT.P: The government should ban poultry slaughter in traditional markets and accelerate drug and vaccine development efforts to better prepare Taiwan for a bird flu outbreak, a Taipei mayoral candidate said Friday.

Yeh Chin-chuan, a former Taipei deputy mayor who resigned from the post last month in order to focus on running in the year-end mayoral election, said that bird flu will certainly appear in Taiwan sooner or later, urging the government to allocate funds for bird flu prevention measures instead of only allotting funds for relief purposes.

"It would be pretty idiotic if the government were only to reimburse people after bird flu breaks out. It would feel like the government were spending money to buy coffins for the people and not spending any money to save patients," Yeh said.
Yeh is a public health expert who made a name for himself during the SARS outbreak in 2003 when he helped the Taipei City Government bring the outbreak under control.

He urged the government to ban the practice of killing live chickens at traditional food markets and to encourage poultry vendors to purchase their chickens from professional butcheries instead. He also suggested that the government reimburse poultry vendors for the refrigerators, freezers and display equipment they will need to purchase to make the change.
He also urged the government to stock up on enough Tamiflu to treat 10 percent of the population by the end of the year and to develop vaccines within three years.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT REAFFIRMS PLEDGE FOR NEW CONSTITUTION

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian reaffirmed Friday his promise to render a new constitution for Taiwan that is "timely, relevant and viable" before his term ends in 2008.
The president said the idea of drafting a new constitution for Taiwan was put forth by the late democratic activist Deng Nan-jung and that he has always kept this idea in mind.

Chen made the remarks while addressing a ceremony commemorating the 17th anniversary of the death of Deng, who burned himself to death in 1989 in protest against the former Kuomintang government's suppression of freedom of speech.
According to the president, Deng had proposed many ideas and objectives to promote democracy and freedom in Taiwan, and the best way to remember him is to stick to democracy and freedom.

Chen said the movement promoted by Deng to redress the miscarriage of justice in the 228 Incident, his efforts to uncover scandals involving the military, as well as his public discussion of Taiwan independence contributed greatly to the liberation of Taiwan society.

There is much room for improvement in the government's efforts to deal with the heritage of the past authoritarian era, because the complicated problems accumulated over the past five decades cannot be solved in a short period of time, he said.

Despite the challenges, such as the internal disparity over national identity and China's threat to invade Taiwan, the government will not give up on its ongoing efforts to deepen the country's democracy, he said.

On freedom of speech, the president said that although some people think that the freedom of speech enjoyed by the people in Taiwan is excessive in light of the release of some irresponsible remarks, the government will not compromise in its efforts to allow 100 percent freedom of speech in the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN MISSION TO HELP BURKINA FASO FIGHT BIRD FLU

TEXT.P: The Taiwan International Health Action (Taiwan IHA) task force will send a delegation to Burkina Faso to help the African nation control a bird flu outbreak, Ministry of Foreign Affairs officials said Friday.
Taiwan will also provide Burkina Faso with medical supplies such as protective gowns, gloves, masks and disinfectant, the officials said.

They said that although Taiwan is not a member of the World Health Organization, the country will fulfill its responsibility as a member of the global village and will continue to participate in international efforts in disease prevention and control, health cooperation and emergency humanitarian relief.
The Taiwan IHA will offer all necessary assistance as long as there is a need in the international community, they said.
The Taiwan IHA is an inter-ministerial task force set up by the government to take part in international health relief efforts.

DOC.HEADLINE: REGULATIONS ON COVERING NEWS AT CKS AIRPORT TO BE EASED: MOI

TEXT.P: If major policies or public interests are involved, restrictions on covering news at the Chiang Kai-shek (CKS) International Airport will be eased, Vice Interior Minister Yen Wan-chin said Friday.

Yen made the remarks in response to media reports that the Aviation Police Bureau ignored the newly promulgated news coverage rules by allowing local reporters to enter the CKS Airport's control area Thursday to cover Premier Su Tseng-chang's inspection of an avian flu-fighting drill there.

According to the new regulations put into practice March 1, all reporters have to apply 48 hours in advance for permission to work at the controlled area of the airport, but the restrictions do not apply in the event of major incidents.

Yen said that the ministry is reviewing its regulations on news coverage at the airport, adding that if it is the government taking the initiative, or news related to the nation's "major policies or public interest, " then the government will invite the media to cover news at the airport with no "48-hour" restrictions.
Yen noted that Thursday's drill was an important training drill in an effort to keep the disease out of Taiwan.

He noted that the prevention of avian flu is a major policy. Because the news coverage applications were not completed in time, it was decided to allow all reporters access to the airport to cover the drill.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ECONOMY TO EXPAND NO LESS THAN 4.5 PERCENT THIS YEAR: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang predicted Friday that Taiwan's economic growth will top 4.5 percent this year, while the unemployment rate will decline to below 4 percent.

Fielding questions at the Legislative Yuan, Su vowed that his administrative team will accord equal importance to efforts to rev up the economy, improve public order and boost diplomatic relations with the rest of the world without partiality.

Su made the vow in response to opposition Kuomintang Legislator Hsu Shu-po's interpellation. Hsu claimed that despite the overnment's management policy, Taiwan's economic reliance on China has become increasingly serious.

Hsu quoted Bureau of Foreign Trade statistics as indicating that Taiwan's two-way trade with China increased to the tune of US$57 billion in 2005, a trend he claimed could not be reined back with any kind of management policy.

Noting that the economy, social order and diplomacy are inextricably linked, Hsu lamented that because Taiwan has continuously been blocked from joining the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) and has made no headway in efforts to develop free trade harbor zone partnerships with Japan and South Korea, its economy has unavoidably been affected and while the domestic economy has flattened out, public order has also deteriorated.
In response, Su said the government will not be daunted by slow progress in developing closer ties with ASEAN and will make continued efforts to realize its major policy goals.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed higher Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 21.12 points to close at 6,781.94.
The bourse opened at 6,758.82 and fluctuated between 6,802.94 and 6,722.39 during trading. A total of 3.41 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$121.6 billion (US$3.76 billion).

Five of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with machinery and electronics shares moving up the most at 0.5 percent, followed by banking and financial shares at 0.3 percent, and cement stocks, textile stocks and construction issues all at 0.2 percent.
The three other major stock categories lost ground, with foodstuff issues and paper and pulp issues both moving down at 0.4 percent, and plastics and chemicals shares dropping 0.2 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 463 to 424, with 159 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PROSECUTOR REFUSES COMMENT ON 'TOXIC SUBSTANCE' REPORT

TEXT.P: A prosecutor refused Friday to comment on a news report that residue of a rare toxic substance was found in the body of the only fatality in a train derailment on the South Link railway line March 17.

Chung Chung-hsiao of the Kaohsiung District Prosecutors' Office told the media that a clear explanation of the death of Chen Shi Hong Shen will be made after the completion of an investigation into the case, which began with the train accident and led to the suicide of Chen Shi's husband, Lee Shuang-chuan.
Lee committed suicide March 23 after being suspected of plotting the derailment to kill his third wife, who he had imported from Vietnam, so that he could claim life insurance for her.

Meanwhile, Minister of Justice Shih Mao-lin said that anyone involved in the investigation who discloses details of the investigation before it is finalized will be disciplined, referring to the news report disclosing the results of Chen Shi's autopsy.
Shih said he did not know how the autopsy results were released and demanded that the local prosecutors' office find out who leaked the information.

According to a firefighter who was on the scene at the train detriment, Chen Shi did not appear to be injured when he saw her sitting on the rails after crawling out of an overturned carriage. She was sent to hospital believed to be suffering from shock, where she later died, the firefighter said.
The derailment of the express train with more than 200 passengers aboard was caused by sabotage.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT ADVOCATES `SPIRITUAL PURGING'

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu unveiled Friday an idea to promote a campaign she described as pursuing "spiritual purging and a high-class life" to counter the popular gossip culture in Taiwan society.
Lu made the remarks while giving a speech on "technological human rights and technological diplomacy" during a symposium at the National Yunlin University of Science and Technology.
According to Lu, the protection of privacy is insufficient in Taiwan, while the media emphasizes their readers' or viewers' "right to know."
However, Lu said, readers and viewers also have the right to tell the media what images they do not want to see and what reports they do not want to read.

Lu said that in light of the lack of any sense of technological ethics in the country, she will promote the concepts of "respecting the gods, cherishing the earth, loving the people and seeking the truth, goodness and beauty."

Lu suggested that Taiwan take advantage of its technological edge to make greater contributions to mankind, which she said is the purpose of her proposal that the country should attach equal importance to industrial production, life and the environment.

DOC.HEADLINE: CAA TO REVIEW SHARP DECLINE IN FLIGHTS AT HENGCHUN AIRPORT

TEXT.P: A Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) official promised Friday that he will review a sharp decline in the number of weekly flights serving the Hengchun airport in southern Taiwan.
CAA Deputy Director-General Lin Hsin-teh made the pledge in response to questioning by Legislator Liao Wan-ju of the opposition Kuomintang.

Liao said that since the airport was inaugurated in 2004 at a cost of NT$530 million (US$16.3 million) , the number of flights has dropped to just three from a peak of 35 flights per week, which she claimed is not enough to meet the needs of the 6 million tourists who visit the area's Kending National Park each year.

CAA officials said privately that while they could push for an increase in the number of flights, the carriers have been lukewarm to CAA suggestions because there is no market for extra flights, in addition to which there are often windy conditions at the airport, especially in winter.

DOC.HEADLINE: AGENTS SEIZE NT$100 MILLION-WORTH OF SMUGGLED GUNS, DRUGS
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 7 (CNA) (By Timothy Hwang and S.C. Chang)

TEXT.P: The Taipei office of the Ministry of Justice Investigation Bureau (MJIB) intercepted a shipment of smuggled guns and drugs with a street value of over NT$100 million near the Chiang Kai-shek International Airport Friday.
MJIB agents arrested Liao Ching-ming, who was suspected of having connections with foreign gangsters, and said they would crack the smuggling ring.
The investigators confiscated 3 kg of heroin, a Spanish-made handgun and 158 bullets hidden in a car molding at a cargo holding area near the airport.
They added that over the past month, they had uncovered three other cases of smuggling guns and drugs together.
The MJIB said it suspects that gangsters from the United States and Hong Kong are involved in the illegal trading of drugs and guns in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: COLLAGEN EXTRACTED FROM PIG SKIN HITS MARKET

TEXT.P: A locally made collagen extracted from pig skin has hit the market and is claimed to be better than imported collagen, according to a surgeon at the Tri Service General Hospital in Taipei.

Dr. Chen Tien-mu, director of the Plastic Surgery Department of the Tri Service General Hospital said Friday that the locally made collagen is safer than its foreign counterparts, which are mainly derived from cow skin and therefore vulnerable to mad cow disease.
Collagen is a protein often used in cosmetic surgery to reinforce skin strength and elasticity.
Chen said the home-made collagen, which has already been certified by the European Union as a medical implant, is also cheaper than imported products.
Chen said his department has given the collagen to 49 patients in the last six months and has found it to be more effective when injected into the skin than when applied topically or orally.

Injecting 1 cc of collagen under a wrinkle through a fine needle, Chen said, will remove even smile lines around the mouth, which are the deepest wrinkles on the face. The effect can last for one year, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: CPC DEFICIT SOARS AS CRUDE OIL PRICES SPIRAL

TEXT.P: The deficit of Taiwan's state-run Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC) has been deteriorating since the beginning of this year as a result of spiraling international crude oil prices, the CPC president said Friday.

Chen Pao-lang recapped at a swearing-in ceremony that the company suffered a cumulative deficit of NT$13.8 billion (US$424.6 million) in crude oil imports in the first three months of this year, with the deficit totaling NT$3.246 billion in January, NT$6.084 billion in February and NT$4.5 billion in March.
Chen was presiding over a ceremony to mark the swearing-in of Chuang Chueh-an as chairman of the Taiwan Petroleum Workers Union.

Chen said the CPC has been striving to expand its business operations territory by engaging in various investment projects over the past several years. However, he said, CPC's looming deficit due to skyrocketing crude oil prices is putting these investment projects at risk of compromise.
The growing deficit is also affecting the revenue of the national coffers, since CPC is one of the main revenue contributors, Chen said.

For his part, Chuang said CPC processes and distributes about 75 percent of the petroleum and diesel products that Taiwan consumes. Unlike the private Formosa Oil, CPC is a major supplier of oil products domestically and has to import crude oil to meet those needs. Even worse, Chuang claimed, CPC has continued to keep a cap on domestic oil prices in compliance with government policy.

Noting that CPC's losses represent a dent in the national coffers that in turn will be translated into losses for the public, Chuang suggested that the administration consider raising oil prices across the board to reflect the principle of "the users pay."

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER ACKNOWLEDGES TAIWAN'S ECONOMY LAGS BEHIND SOUTH KOREA'S

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang admitted Friday that Taiwan's economy has in recent years not grown as fast as those of such rapidly rising countries as South Korea and China.

He made the remarks in reply to opposition People First Party (PFP) Legislator Ko Shu-min, who asked him about his views on the fact that in 2005, South Korea's per capita GDP surpassed that of Taiwan for the first time.
South Korea registered a per capita GDP of US$16,291 last year, compared with Taiwan's US$15,271.
However, Taiwan's economy is still growing, Su said, adding that "the most important thing for the government is to make the people feel the economy is developing at a faster pace and progressing."
He did not specify how the government is making the economy "develop faster" so the people can "feel" it.

DOC.HEADLINE: MILITARY SALUTE CEREMONY TO HONOR FOREIGN LEADERS TO RELOCATE

TEXT.P: A military salute ceremony to honor foreign national leaders will be relocated to the square in front of the Presidential Office from the square at the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall complex, officials said Friday.

Officials of the Presidential Office's Department of Public Affairs said the relocation takes into consideration the practice of other allies, which often hold the ceremony near the public office of the head of state.

In addition, the square in front of the Presidential Office is appropriate to highlight the solemn nature of the ceremony and facilitates the itinerary arrangement, as before and after the military salute ceremony, there are meetings between the leaders of Taiwan and whichever foreign leader is being honored.

The officials said that in the past, the ceremony is often relocated to the National Concert Hall at the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall complex if the weather is inclement, but from now on, the venue will change to a hall on the second floor of the Presidential Office in the event of rain.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES HIGHER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Friday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for April moved up 24 points to close at 6,751, with 3,4751 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for May increased 23 points to finish at 6,748, with 1,581 contracts traded, while June futures gained 38 points to end at 6,730, with 127 contract transactions. September futures increased 40 points to close at 6,545, with 26 contracts traded, while December futures moved up 78 points to finish at 6,558, with 49 contract transactions.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Friday at 6,727 for April, 6,725 for May, 6,692 for June, 6,505 for September and 6,480 for December.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mostly higher.

April TE futures increased 0.95 points to close at 301.2, with 5,268 contracts traded, while May TE futures gained 0.85 points to finish at 300.05, with 83 contract transactions. June TE futures moved up 2.35 points to end at 300, with one contract traded, while September TE futures lost 0.7 points to end at 291.25, with two contract contractions.
No transactions were recorded for December.

April TF futures increased 1.4 points to finish at 891.2, with 1,410 contracts changing hands, while May TF futures gained five points to close at 892, with 49 contracts traded. September TF futures moved up 3.6 points to end at 874.6, with two contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for June and December.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Friday, decreasing NT$0.001 to close at NT$32.328.
A total of US$1.12 billion changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$32.350 and fluctuated between NT$32.300 and NT$32.364.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOCTORS RETURN FROM MEDICAL AID MISSION IN SWAZILAND

TEXT.P: Changhua Christian Hospital President Wei Chih-tao, who returned Taiwan two days ago from a medical aid mission to Swaziland, expressed the hope Friday that he will be offered more chances to provide medical aid to needy people in other countries.

Wei was the leader of a medical team co-organized by the hospital and the state-financed International Cooperation and Development Fund to provide medical treatment services in remote areas of Swaziland, one of Taiwan's diplomatic allies in Africa.

The team of nine physicians, set off March 26 and returned April 5. The goal of the mission was to give Swazi villagers services, including health care and medical treatment, and informing them of the importance of AIDS control and prevention.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP REITERATES OPPOSITION TO ARMS PURCHASE AT 'EXORBITANT PRICES'

TEXT.P: The opposition People First Party (PFP) reiterated Friday its strong objection to any military procurement plan that would require Taiwan to pay "exorbitant prices."

PFP spokesman Hsieh Kung-pin told reporters that the PFP will not allow military procurement legislation to pass the Legislative Yuan because doing so might be seen as the opposition's endorsement of President Chen Shui-bian's recent decision to scrap the National Unification Council and the National Unification Guidelines.

Hsieh acknowledged that PFP Chairman James Soong reminded Ma Ying-jeou, chairman of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) , at a meeting earlier this week that the opposition should not allow the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) government's military procurement plan to pass the legislature.
"The PFP's position has never changed," he said, adding that "the PFP has always insisted that any military procurement plan must be based on the maximum interests of the Taiwan people."

Hsieh claimed that concessions by the opposition on the military procurement plan at this stage will not do any good for Taiwan's security aand credibility because the international community might take them to mean that Taiwan is no longer committed to maintaining the status quo in the Taiwan Strait.
The PFP spokesman said no other country can make the decision for Taiwan on the types and amounts of weapons it should acquire as a way to demonstrate Taiwan's determination to defend itself.
He suggested that the DPP should not use U.S. reaction to the matter to apply pressure on the opposition in an attempt to get the legislation passed in the Legislative Yuan.

Hsieh made the remarks after DPP legislators William Lai and Winston Dang claimed that Soong's objection to the military procurement plan was the main reason why Ma failed to explain to U.S. officials during his recent visit to the United States how the KMT intends to resolve the issue.

Lai and Dang, who visited the United States after Ma's visit, said they learned from a conversation with former U.S. Deputy Secretary of State Richard Armitage that Ma did not "deliver an envelope" on the arms purchase plan "because of someone" and that after pursuing the subject further with Armitage, they got the impression that Soong was that "someone."

DOC.HEADLINE: SONY AIMS TO BE DOMINANT AGAIN WITH ORGANIZATIONAL REFORM

TEXT.P: With unprecedented personnel changes and a total organizational reform, Sony Corp. aims to emerge from a slump and regain dominance in the electronics, entertainment and mobile fields, Sony President Ryoji Chubachi said at a press conference Friday in Taipei.

Sony last year named American Howard Stringer as its chairman, a new development in Japanese conglomerates, and decided to re-focus on three "core positions" in trying to build itself once again into a dominant global leader, Chubachi said prior to the "2006 Sony Fair" exhibition.

"We vowed to provide products from a customer standpoint, to maintain Sony's advantage in technology and to focus on the 'frontline operation' -- given that Sony has always been a manufacturing company, " said Chubachi, who started at the company as an engineer in 1977 and became president in June 2005.

Combining Stringer's expertise in business operation and Chubachi's technology background, Sony has been doing well with its Bravia televisions, digital cameras and camcorders since last year after losing the MP3 battle to Apple's iPod.

Looking ahead, Sony plans to develop Asian "localized markets" under the globalization theme, Chubachi said. It has set up a Research and Development (R&D) Center in Taiwan and will probably increase procurement from Taiwan's LCD panel manufacturers.

"Taiwan is an important market and development base for Sony. Hopefully, with Taiwan's technology and manufacturing expertise, Sony can push forward the local market, " said Sony Taiwan President Kenji Sakai.

Sony will release a wide range of new products in the second half of 2006, including the long-awaited PlayStation 3 and VAIO computers, and will keep promoting the new generation "blue-ray DVD" technology, Chubachi said.

DOC.HEADLINE: NATIONAL CAMPAIGN ENCOURAGES JOY OF READING

TEXT.P: A national campaign was launched by the Council of Cultural Affairs (CAA) and other sponsors to encourage more people to cultivate reading habits in Taiwan, amidst a modern trend of spending less time on reading books.

The 2006 National Reading Campaign was officially launched Friday at a book exhibition displaying a collection of 63 works of literature, the campaign's theme this year. The books were selected and recommended by the CAA.

In addition to the book exhibition in Kingstone Bookstores islandwide from April 7-May 19, an essay competition and a cloze test will be held. Writers will also visit campuses for speeches from April 17-June 17 to advocate the importance of reading.
"Statistics show Taiwanese college students spend only one hour a day reading, which is sad as far as I'm concerned," said CAA Vice Chairman Wu Chin-fa, who is also an author.

"Great writers are the architects of society's souls, which is why we have selected literature as the theme for the campaign. When you face a crossroads in life, the wisdom found in books can save your soul," Wu said.
"As a writer, I would say that reading is far more enjoyable than writing," said Hsu Hui-chih, whose poetry is among the exhibition's selected publications.
"Literature reflects the diversity of human nature. The beauty of literature is that it's not science and it helps you to learn more about people," Hsu said.
This is the third consecutive year that CAA has organized a national reading campaign.

DOC.HEADLINE: MND INSISTS ON SEEKING COMPENSATION FROM FRANCE OVER LAFAYETTE DEAL

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MND) will continue the litigation procedures for financial compensation from France over the Lafayette frigate procurement deal back in the early 1990s, a ministry official said Friday.

MND spokesman Wu Chi-fang was referring to an appeal filed by the navy with a court of international commercial arbitration in Paris in 2003 demanding the French defense contractor refund Taiwan US$500 million in illegal kickback paid for the Lafayette deal plus US$99 million in reputation damages.

His remarks came after a local newspaper claimed earlier the same day that the MND has been unable to produce sufficient evidence to back its allegation that Thales, the French company that sold the six Lafayette-class frigates to Taiwan in the 1990s, had violated the contract terms by paying out kickbacks for the deal. The report said Thales has denied the kickback payout charge and has instead filed a counter appeal demanding Taiwan pay US$199 million in reputation damages.

Wu said the media report was sheer speculation. "As the case is still under judicial scrutiny, it's inappropriate for the MND to reveal any evidence the navy has secured, " Wu said, adding that the French firm's counter appeal is just part of its negotiation strategy.

Taiwan struck the US$2.8 billion Lafayette deal with France in 1991, with a ban on any kickback payout. But allegations about illegal commission payouts surfaced after the death of naval Capt. Yin Ching-feng in late 1993 under suspicious circumstances. Yin is widely believed to have been murdered when he was about to blow the whistle on colleagues who were allegedly taking kickbacks from the deal.

After years of investigation, the government is ready to file a lawsuit for the return of a huge slush fund frozen in Swiss banks that is believed to be made up of illegal kickbacks from the Lafayette deal.

Outgoing State Public Prosecutor-General Wu Ying-chao told CNA earlier this year that a special prosecutorial panel investigating the high-profile kickback scandal has authored a 70-page report on the kickback refund lawsuit.
"The report clearly lists the individuals to be asked to refund, the amount of kickbacks each of them has to refund and the offenses each has committed, as well as other related matters," Wu said.

According to Wu, Andrew Wang, the agent in Taiwan for the French defense contractor that sold the frigates to Taiwan, is not the only target to be asked to refund the illegal kickbacks. Nevertheless, he would not reveal the identity of any other defendant nor the amount of the refunds sought.
"The special panel is still putting the final touches on the paperwork," Wu said.

A spokesman for the special investigation panel said that as the refund suit must follow Switzerland's civil suit procedures, the report was sent in January to Swiss lawyers retained by Taiwan to handle the lawsuit.

"The Swiss lawyers have suggested that we prepare some additional information and data. We have thus added seven more pages to the report and are studying follow-up procedural issues with the Swiss lawyers, " the spokesman said, adding that a French formal lawsuit will be filed with the Swiss Judicial Department later this year.
Under a bilateral judicial aid agreement, the Swiss government handed over to Taiwan a collection of bank files suspected of links to the Lafayette kickback scandal last November.

"After poring over the six cases of files brought back from Switzerland, we discovered that each time our government made a payment installment for the frigates, a sum roughly equivalent to 18 percent of the payment would 'coincidently' be remitted into bank accounts owned by Wang or members of his family, "the spokesman said." We suspect that the remittances were illegal kickbacks."

The Swiss files show that frozen deposits in the Wang family's bank accounts top 900 million Swiss francs (about NT$23 billion) . Even after the family's legal assets are deducted, the amount that Taiwan intends to reclaim would still be astronomical.

It might take three to five years to conclude the lawsuit, the spokesman said, adding that Taiwan might still seek judicial aid from several other relevant countries, including France and Luxembourg, to back its request for Switzerland to return the money.

Moreover, the spokesman said, the lawsuit will be very expensive. According to a preliminary estimate, the cost of retaining foreign lawyers alone could exceed NT$100 million. "The Ministry of Justice must appropriate budget for the lawsuit," he added.

The files brought back from Switzerland include 46 bank accounts under the names of Wang, his three sons and Wang's company, all of whose accounts have been frozen by the Swiss Federal Court. Wang is the key suspect in the scandal.

The files, which are written in English, French and German, also include a number of previously hidden overseas bank accounts related to the US$2.8 billion Lafayette deal, as well as information about relevant capital flows in Switzerland, judicial authorities said, adding that the Swiss court files clearly document deposit times and destinations of the capital.
Wang has been charged in absentia with murder, corruption, money laundering and fraud.

DOC.HEADLINE: COURT ASKED TO DETAIN FORMER PRESIDENTIAL AIDE ON SUSPICION OF FRAUD

TEXT.P: The prosecution asked the court to detain Chen Che-nan, former deputy secretary general of the Presidential Office, on suspicion of fraud Friday.

The former senior aide to President Chen Shui-bian was queseioned after prosecutors charged Yang Chen-feng, a sauna business owner, with perjury. Yang was released on NT$800,00 bond and banned from leaving the country.

Chen and Yang were involved in a political contribution and influence-peddling scandal in which Liang Po-hsun, a bankrupt former chairman of a construction company, accused Chen of taking NT$7.11 million in bribes from him.
Liang, a wanted economic criminal, recently returned from Shanghai, China, claiming he would "prove everything with solid evidence" about the scandal.

The prosecution, on instructions from Premier Su Tseng-chang, stepped up the investigation into Liang's allegations that through Yang, he gave Chen three checks in political donations plus a cash gift (on the occasion of the funeral of Chen's mother) totalling NT$7.11 million in exchange for his services in lawsuits.

Yang had earlier told prosecutors that Liang owed Chen a debt and Liang had made the payment to clear the debt. But late Thursday, the prosecution found that Liang did not owe Chen a debt. Yang was thus charged with perjury.

Further investigation revealed that Chen was suspected of defrauding Liang, who will soon begin serving his term. As investigators were concerned that Chen might engage in collusion and destroy evidence, they requested the court to keep him under custody.

Chen has also been investigated for suspected involvement in other corruption cases including the Kaohsiung rapid transit scandal and a stock-playing scandal while he was working in the Presidential Office.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI TO APPEAL GOVERNMENT'S DECISION NOT TO LET PANDAS ENTER TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The Taipei City Government will appeal the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) government's decision not to allow a pair of gift pandas to enter Taiwan from China when the panda closure at the Taipei Municipal Zoo is completed in June, Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou said Friday.

Fielding questions from councilors at a city council meeting, Ma said the Council of Agriculture gave an "insufficient" reason for denying the Taipei Zoo import permits on grounds the zoo's facilities did not meet requirements for housing pandas, because few zoos would wait until after they had the facilities and then apply for import permits.
Ma said that before the Taipei Zoo's panda closure is completed in June, the Taipei City Government will send zookeepers to the United States, Japan and China to train in the care of giant pandas.
"When we've done all these things and then appeal the case, the government will be unable to say we haven't made the necessary preparations," he added.

Ma said if the government continues to contend that pandas are protected by the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES) and should not be allowed to leave their natural habitat, the city government will point out that many pandas have left their natural habitat in China, and that those in captivity have successfully reproduced 168 pandas through artificial breeding.
Beijing offered to give the two pandas to Taiwan as a gift during an historic visit to China by former KMT Chairman Lien Chan last year.
Proponents of Taiwan's independence in the DPP government have expressed suspicion that Beijing's gesture might be a "united front tactic" intended to win favor among the Taiwanese public.

DOC.HEADLINE: MARSHALL ISLANDS PRESIDENT TO VISIT TAIWAN APRIL 10-15

TEXT.P: Marshall Islands President Kessai Note and his wife will arrive in Taiwan April 10 for a six-day state visit, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Friday.

During his stay, Note will meet with President Chen Shui-bian and the two heads of state will exchange views on bilateral cooperation and other issues of common concern, the MOFA said in a news release.
Note will also attend a signing ceremony of a Taiwan-Marshall Islands agreement on the exchange of information on money-laundering activity, the MOFA said.

Note and his entourage will pay a visit to Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan, where they are scheduled to tour several facilities to study Taiwan's industrial achievements in the fields of ocean fisheries, aquaculture and solar energy.
Note is scheduled to depart Taiwan April 15. This will be Note's fourth visit to Taiwan since May 2002.

Taiwan and the Marshall Islands forged diplomatic ties Nov. 20, 1998. Since Note took office six years ago, he has on many occasions publicly expressed support of Taiwan's role in the international community.
President Chen will preside over a welcoming ceremony complete with a 21-gun salute in Note's honor April 11 at the square in front of the office of the president, MOFA officials said.

It will be the first welcoming ceremony for foreign heads of state to be held at the Presidential Office square. In the past, such ceremonies were held at the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall complex near the Presidential Office.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Senate Deal on Immigration Falters
U.S. Senate leaders reached agreement Thursd ay on a broad, bipartisan compromise that would put the vast majority of the nation's estimated 11 million illegal immigrants on a path to citizenship, but its prospects for passage grew more uncertain as Republicans and Democrats clashed late into the night over parliamentary procedure. Both sides said that without a quick resolution of the differences they would not ha ve a vote on the final legislation before Congre ss leaves for its spring recess on Friday, raising the possibility that the painstakingly negotiated compromise might unravel as it is exposed to intense political scrutiny during the two-week Congressional break.
Wall Street Journal: Dangerous Decision In South Africa, Poor AIDS Patients Adopt Risky Ploy
AIDS patients in South Africa can receive advanced anti-AIDS drugs free from the government. The pills work just the way they're supposed to, boosting the immune system, relieving the symptoms and restoring the health as long as she takes them twice a day. However,some stopped taking them, because thegovernment in addition to the drugs, the government will also give the patient a US$130- a-month disability grant -- but only if the patient gets sicker than he or she is now. And if the patient takes the drugs, he or she probably won't get sick enough to qualify for the cash. Medical workers, activists and academics in South Africa have been startled to discover that a number of impoverished AIDS patients are stopping taking medicine, risking death in order to secure welfare assistance.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER PRESIDENTIAL AIDE DETAINED ON CHARGES OF FRAUD

TEXT.P: Former Presidential Office Deputy Secretary-General Chen Che-nan was detained by the court on charges of fraud Friday.

Chen was allegedly involved in a political donation and influence-peddling scandal in which Liang Po-hsun, an economic criminal, claimed that he gave Chen NT$7.11 million in bribes through a sauna business owner named Yang Chen-feng.

Though Chen has returned the money to Yang, prosecutors found that their dubious relations warrant further probes that may lead to a breakthrough in the investigation into another scandal, in which Chen was suspected of conducting stock transactions at the Presidential Office while he served as a senior aide to President Chen Shui-bian.

DOC.HEADLINE: CULTURE MINISTER VISITS GERMANY TO PROMOTE EXCHANGES

TEXT.P: Council for Cultural Affairs (CCA) Minister Chiu Kun-liang is currently visiting Germany to promote cultural exchanges between Taiwan and Germany, a CCA official said Friday.
During his two-day visit, the official said, Chiu has met with many German politicians, artists and literary figures to explore possible short-, middle- and long-term cultural exchange programs.

According to the official, the director of a German national concert hall has promised to invite Taiwanese musicians and musical groups to perform in an East Asian music festival the concert hall plans to sponsor in 2009.
German museum and cultural heritage officials have also promised to offer tips and expertise on the repair of cultural relics, restoration technologies and preservation methods, the official said.
Chiu will travel to Poland after his visit to Germany and is scheduled to return to Taipei April 11.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOMINICAN REPUBLIC PRESIDENT TO VISIT TAIWAN IN JUNE

TEXT.P: Dominican Republic President Leonel Antonio Fernandez Reyna is scheduled to visit Taiwan in June to sign an agreement on cooperation in high-industry development, the Republic of China ambassador to the Caribbean nation said Friday.
Amb. John C. Feng told CNA in a telephone interview that Taiwan will assist the Dominican Republic in developing high tech industries under the cooperative agreement to be signed in June.
Commenting on a foreign wire service report that the Caribbean nation is considering forging ties with China, Feng said the Dominican Republic treasures its long-term friendly ties with Taiwan.

Feng said Dominican Republic Foreign Minister Carlos Morales Troncoso told him in a telephone conversation earlier in the day that the Dominican Republic's Asian trade development plan focuses on exploring trade and investment opportunities in India rather than China.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR APRIL 8 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Saturday, April 8:
09:00, A cross-Taiwan Strait crisis management study program will open at the Chunghua Institution for Economic Research.
10:00, The World Vision Taiwan will sponsor a children's sports contest at National Taiwan Normal University stadium.
11:00, Vice President Annette Lu will attend a Buddhist religious rite at the Armed Forces Activity Center in Taipei.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT MEETS WITH U.S. ACADEMICS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian met with a delegation of U.S. academics specializing in cross-Taiwan Strait affairs Friday for exchanges of views on a broad range of issues of mutual concern.

The delegation was headed by Nat Bellocchi, a former chairman of the American Institute in Taiwan, a quasi-official U.S. organization authorized to handle relations with Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic ties.
During the meeting, Chen told the American scholars that Taiwan's core values lie in the deepening and consolidation of its democratic system.

For the sake of good governance and upgrading of national competitiveness, Chen said Taiwan needs a new round of constitutional reforms. Even though current constitutional provisions set an extremely high threshold for constitutional amendments, Chen said he is confident of realizing the goal with the maturity of social conditions and popular support.
Chen said he would endeavor to honor his promise to render a new constitution for Taiwan that is "timely, relevant and viable" before he steps down from the presidency in May 2008.

Touching on relations with China, Chen said his firm conviction is that only the 23 million Taiwan people have a final say on Taiwan's future and its relations with China or any change to the present status quo.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, April 8, or the 11th day of the third month of the Year of the Dog according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
217 AD: Caracalla, or Marcus Aurelius Antonius, the Roman emperor who was obsessed with and sought to imitate Alexander the Great, is assassinated after a bloody reign.
1513: Juan Ponce de Leon, the Spanish explorer who completed the conquest of Puerto Rico, discovers Florida and claims it for the Spanish throne.
1861: Elisha Graves Otis, the American inventor of the passenger elevator which was first installed in 1857, dies at the age of 50.
1902: China's Ching court and Russia reach agreement on the evacuation of Manchuria. After the Boxer Uprising in 1900, Russia took the opportunity to occupy Manchuria. When the troops of the other foreign powers withdrew from Chinese territory, Russia refused to leave Manchuria.
1907: France and Britain sign a convention confirming the independence of Siam (now Thailand).
1914: The Republic of China's first Congress is organized in Beijing.
1913: Brazil officially recognizes the Republic of China, which was founded on Jan. 1, 1912, becoming the first country in the world to do so.
1925: The Australian government and the British Colonial Office offer low-interest loans to encourage 500,000 Britons to emigrate to Australia.
1946: The League of Nations holds its final session in Geneva. It was later replaced by the United Nations.
1958: U.S. President Dwight D. Eisenhower proposes mutual inspection as a means of enforcing the nuclear test ban.
1965: The ROC severs diplomatic relations with the Republic of Dahomey.
1966: Leonid Brezhnev is elected general secretary of the Soviet Communist Party. He later became president of the USSR in 1977.
1973: Dr. Mohammed Abder Rahman Basbeer, minister of communications of Jordan, arrives in Taipei for a week-long visit.
1973: Pablo Picasso, the Spanish artist who was one of the most prolific and influential artists of the 20th century, dies in his chateau at Mougins at the age of 92. He excelled in painting, sculpture, etching, stage design, and ceramics.
1979: Lee Pao-chen, a noted Chinese musician, dies in Taipei at the age of 73.
1981: Omar Nelson Bradley, the American general who played a major part in the Allied victory in World War II, dies at the age of 88. He commanded the U.S. forces in the Normandy invasion and later led the 12th Army Group as France was liberated.
1986: Clint Eastwood, the screen tough guy famed for his portrayal of "Dirty Harry," is elected mayor of Carmel, a Californian resort town.
1989: More than 60 Soviet submariners die after a nuclear-powered Mike-class submarine refuses assistance from nearby Western merchant ships after catching fire off the coast of Norway.
1990: ROC Economics Minister Chen Li-an and Singaporean Minister of Trade and Industries Lee Hsien Loong preside over the first ministerial-level conference on economic cooperation between the two countries.
1991: The second extraordinary session of the First National Assembly is convened in Taipei to discuss constitutional reforms.
1992: Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat is found alive 12 hours after his plane crashes in the Sahara desert.
1994: Japanese Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa resigns over a loan scandal.
1995: At a meeting of the National Unification Council, ROC President Lee Teng-hui offers a six-point proposal for Taiwan-mainland China relations.
1999: NATO continues airstrikes against Yugoslavia while the eastern European country says its 14-month war against ethnic Albanian separatists is over.
2000: Hong Kong Chief Executive Tung Chee-hwa tells U.S. President Bill Clinton that granting mainland China permanent normal trade relations status would give Hong Kong's recovering economy a further boost.
2001: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian says while attending the inauguration of Taiwan's Anti-Cancer Federation that a heart full of pleasure is the best medicine against cancer.
Confucius lesson of the day: "A gentleman who only thinks of the comforts of life cannot be a true gentleman."

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER PRESIDENTIAL AIDE DETAINED ON CHARGES OF FRAUD(repeat)

TEXT.P: Former Presidential Office Deputy Secretary-General Chen Che-nan was detained by the court on charges of fraud Friday.

Chen was allegedly involved in a political donation and influence-peddling scandal in which Liang Po-hsun, an economic criminal, claimed that he gave Chen NT$7.11 million in bribes through a sauna business owner named Yang Chen-feng.

Though Chen has returned the money to Yang, prosecutors found that their dubious relations warrant further probes that may lead to a breakthrough in the investigation into another scandal, in which Chen was suspected of conducting stock transactions at the Presidential Office while he served as a senior aide to President Chen Shui-bian.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN REGISTERS TRADE SURPLUS OF US$1.51 BILLION FOR MARCH

TEXT.P: Taiwan posted a trade surplus of US$1.51 billion in March, according to the latest tallies released by the Ministry of Finance (MOF).
Exports amounted to US$17.68 billion for the month, up 7.1 percent over the year-earlier level, while imports amounted to US$16.17 billion, down 0.5 percent, MOF officials said.

The trade surplus totalled US$3.23 billion in the three months to March, with exports rising 11.4 percent year-on-year to US$49.98 billion and imports climbing 9.3 percent to US$46.75 billion, the officials said.

They said Taiwan's trade has shifted from a deficit in February to a surplus in March mainly because of the decrease in imports such as steel, machinery, transport vehicles and organic chemicals and the increase in exports such as electronic and electrical products as well as optical equipment.

In the first quarter of 2006, capital equipment imports declined 12.2 percent from the same period last year, marking the third consecutive quarter that the figure has seen negative growth, they said.
Meanwhile, consumer product imports increased just 1.4 percent year-on-year in the first quarter of 2006, they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: YAHOO! TAIWAN'S RESOLVED ANSWERS TOPS 5 MILLION

TEXT.P: An online information-sharing forum operated by Yahoo! Taiwan Inc. has gathered more than five million resolved answers since it was established 18 months ago, company officials said Saturday.

The "Knowledge+" search service -- the Yahoo! Taiwan equivalent for the English-language "Yahoo! Answers" -- has seen an average 12,000 questions being answered per day over the past 18 months, the officials said.
The single-month non-repeated visits amounted to more than 6.7 million, they said.

In February 2006, the top three question categories that received the most responses from users were "science and health," with 210,000 responses; "computer and Internet, " with 170,000 responses; and "video and audio entertainment," with 150,000 responses, according to the officials.
They said "Knowledge+" has become a popular search model in Taiwan which has served the purposes of grouping and sharing.

DOC.HEADLINE: CDC MONITORING SCARLET FEVER OUTBREAK

TEXT.P: The Center for Disease Control (CDC) said Saturday that it is monitoring an outbreak of scarlet fever, which tends to peak in Taiwan during the spring to summer transition.

Tallies released by the CDC show that a total of 338 scarlet fever cases have been reported in Taiwan since January this year, which is slightly higher than the 309 cases recorded during the same period last year.
The cases reported so far this year include 10 cases of mass family infection affecting 22 people and four cases of mass school infection affecting eight people.
According to the CDC, patients with scarlet fever usually display symptoms such as fever, sore throat, rash, skin infection and peeling.

The bacteria that causes scarlet fever is transmissible through nasal and throat fluids by sneezing and coughing, and the patients must take medication for 10 days to prevent serious complications such as acute glomerulonephritis, rheumatic fever, rheumatic heart disease, otitis media or lymphadenitis, CDC officials said.
The officials urged people to wash their hands frequently to prevent scarlet fever and avoid going to public places if they have been infected so as not to spread the disease to others.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. CONGRESSMEN URGE LIFTING OF BAN ON TAIWAN HIGH-LEVEL VISITS
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 7 (CNA) (By Jorge Liu and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Two U.S. congressmen introduced a resolution Thursday calling for the lifting of all restrictions on visits to the United States by high-level Taiwan officials.

Steve Chabot (R-Ohio) and Sherrod Brown (D-Ohio), co-chairmen of the Congressional Taiwan Caucus, a pro-Taiwan group in the House of Representatives, introduced the resolution ahead of Chinese President Hu Jintao's scheduled visit to Washington, D.C. April 20.

The resolution says that "all restrictions on visits by high-level elected and appointed officials of Taiwan to the United States, including the democratically elected president of Taiwan, should be lifted.'
It also says that the U.S. "should encourage direct high-level exchanges at the Cabinet, in order to strengthen a policy dialogue with Taiwan's government."

Chabot previously expressed his concern about the restrictions during a Congressional hearing two years ago, citing the example of his meeting with Legislator Mark Chen (Tan Sun Chen) at that time but then not being able to meet with him a few weeks later after Chen had become foreign affairs minister.

Based on U.S. State Department guidelines, Taiwan's president, vice president, premier, foreign affairs minister and defense minister cannot make formal visits to the United States, although they can make transit stops, except in Washington, D.C.
"Frankly, I think that the policy is kind of silly, " Chabot said.

He noted that during former President Lee Teng-hui's visit to Washington, D.C. in October 2005, over a dozen members of Congress urged the Bush administration to not only welcome Lee but also to allow President Chen Shui-bian to come to the nation's capital and meet with Bush.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SUPPLIERS PARTICIPATING IN BOLOGNA COSMETICS SHOW
DOC.DATELINE: Rome, April 7 (CNA) (By Huang Kwang-chun and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: A total of 92 Taiwan suppliers are taking part in Cosmoprof 2006 -- an annual international perfumery and cosmetics exhibition -- which opened Friday in Bologna, Italy.
The event, which will run through April 10, has brought together 2,125 exhibitors from 52 countries, with Taiwan being among the 21 countries that have been offered a national exhibition pavilion.

According to officials from the O.P.C. International Exhibition Co., which arranged for the participation of the Taiwan suppliers, while this is the 16th year that Taiwan is taking part in the event, the floor area occupied by Taiwan exhibitors has also expanded from just 50 square meters in the first year to 1,400 square meters this year.

Statistics from the Italian government show that Italy imported 1.98 billion euros (US$2.43 billion) worth of cosmetic products in 2005, up 4.65 percent over the previous year. However, imports from Taiwan accounted for only 2.1 million euros, down 15 percent over the year-earlier figure.
In 2005, Taiwan imported cosmetic products worth some 18 million euros from Italy, up 3.76 percent over the previous year's level.

This year's Cosmoprof is the 39th of its kind, with the exhibition booths occupying a total area of 83,685 square meters. In addition to cosmetics and perfumes, other items on display include hair care, beauty and slimming products as well as workout equipment.

DOC.HEADLINE: CIVIC GROUP PLANNING TO SET UP GUIDE DOG SCHOOL

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Guide Dog Association on Saturday called for the public to support its plan to set up a guide dog training school to benefit the visually impaired in Taiwan.
The association made the appeal at a guide dog carnival it sponsored at the Sun Yat-sen Memorial Hall in downtown Taipei.

Chen Chang-chin, secretary-general of the association, noted that Taiwan currently has around 50,000 visually impaired people, but there are only 14 qualified guide dogs, and all of them were trained in other countries.
"This is why the association has decided to set up a school to train the best friends for the visually impaired," Chen said.

The association started to solicit money last year and has so far collected NT$10 million (US$307,700), but it is still NT$50 million short of its goal, Chen said, adding that the association will continue to sponsor a series of activities and launch a campaign to solicit more donations for the cause.

Chang Chiu-hsiung, president of the association, said that although a law to protect the physically and mentally challenged ensures the right of freedom of movement of guide dogs and young dogs under training in public transportation systems and business places, quite a few places still refuse these dogs entry.
Chang said the campaign of the association this year will focus on the concept of "no shutting out."

He said that guide dogs have to undergo long-term training. They are mild and stable and don't bark or bite recklessly, he said, expressing the hope that the public will allow the dogs more freedom of movement.
Director Liang Hsiu-shen also took the opportunity to publicize a TV movie featuring a guide dog he directed for the Public Television Service, which will debut April 19.

DOC.HEADLINE: STATE-RUN ENTERPRISES POST DEFICIT OF NT$11.28 B IN FIRST 2 MONTHS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's seven leading state-controlled enterprises together registered a deficit of NT$11.28 billion (US$349 million) in the first two months of this year, according to the latest tallies released by the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA).
Analysts said the situation poses a great challenge to the government's goal of the seven enterprises achieving NT$888 million in profits for this year.

Contributing the most to the deficit were Taiwan Power Co. (Taipower) and Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC) , which together lost NT$11.95 billion, owing to soaring international oil prices, the MOEA statistics revealed.

Taipower, which lost NT$2.62 billion in January and February, originally projected an after-tax deficit of NT$18.02 billion for 2006, but the company now expects the figure to further expand to more than NT$20 billion following increases in fuel and electricity costs.

The CPC originally projected a pre-tax profit of NT$17.36 billion for 2006, but this target now seems rather pessimistic given the enterprise's NT$13.8 billion in losses in the first quarter of this year, analysts said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MISSING TAIWAN TOURIST'S BODY FOUND IN KASHMIR

TEXT.P: Police in Indian Kashmir found the body of a missing Taiwan tourist in a famous lake in northern Kashmir, a spokesman of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs said Saturday.

Michel Lu said that police found the body of Huang Su-chin, a 52-year-old woman, in Dal Lake, Kashimir's main tourist attraction in the city of Srinagar. The lake is dotted with hand-carved pinewood houseboats popular with tourists.
Indian police, who suspect that Huang was drowned several days ago, are performing an autopsy to determine the cause of her death, Lu said.

Huang, who arrived in Srinagar in the volatile Himalayan region March 22, checked into a houseboat upon her arrival and told the houseboat owner that she was going to an Internet cafe. She had been missing since then.
Indian police had offered a reward for information on Huang's whereabouts in advertisements published on the front pages of newspapers in Kashmir.

Huang's daughter has already arrived in Srinagar, heading there after hearing that her mother had gone missing. Lu said that the ministry will help other members of Huang's family to travel to Srinagar as soon as possible to deal with the aftermath of her death.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEMICONDUCTOR FIRMS HAVE MOST JOB OPENINGS FOR FRESH GRADUATES

TEXT.P: Among the companies at the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park, those related to semiconductor manufacturing are offering the largest number of job openings for fresh graduates this year, officials at a leading online employment service provider said Saturday.

Of the total of 14,387 job openings for fresh graduates posted on the 104 Job Bank Web site by companies located in the industrial park, 4,423 are for semiconductor-related companies, the officials said.
Coming in second are manufacturers of photonics and communications products, which have 1,669 job openings, followed by electronics manufacturers, with 1,247 job openings, they said.

The positions offered by these companies include production/manufacturing jobs, computer hardware and communications jobs, software and information management positions, engineering and research and development jobs as well as quality control positions, they said.
Other positions include those in customer service and technical back-up, administration and general affairs, as well as sales and trade.

DOC.HEADLINE: EUROPEAN PARLIAMENT DELEGATION VISITS IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: An eight-member European Parliament delegation arrived in Taipei Saturday for a five-day visit.

The delegation, headed by Jose Javier Pomes Ruiz, vice chairman of a pro-Taiwan group in the European Parliament, will meet with President Chen Shui-bian, Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng and Joseph Wu, minister of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council, during their visit, Ministry of Foreign Affairs officials said.

Members of the delegation have voiced their strong opposition to China's enactment of the Anti-Secession Law targeting Taiwan on many occasions during the past year. They have also expressed their opposition to a proposed lifting of the European Union's ban on arms sales to China.
The parliamentarians have also spared no efforts in supporting Taiwan's bid to join the World Health Organization, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENTIAL OFFICE DEMANDS KMT LAWMAKER APOLOGIZE FOR ACCUSATION

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Legislator Lee Chuan-chiao should apologize within three days for making false accusations against President Chen Shui-bian and first lady Wu Shu-jen, otherwise, he will face a slander suit, a Presidential Office spokesman said Saturday.

Lee Chuan-chiao claimed at a news conference earlier the same day that President Chen had received political contributions from Liang Po-hsun, a convicted economic criminal. The lawmaker from Tainan County also hinted that the first lady had received cash coupons from Pacific Sogo Department Store.

Lee Chuan-chiao's accusations against the first couple came a day after Chen Che-nan, a former Presidential Office deputy secretary-general, was detained for alleged involvement in a bribery scandal. Chen Che-nan confessed to having received NT$7.11 million in bribe money from Liang. Lee Chuan-chiao claimed at Saturday's news conference that part of the money was political donations to President Chen.
In response, Lee Nan-yang, director of the Presidential Office's Public Affairs Department, said Lee Chuan-chiao should come up with concrete evidence to back up his allegations.

"Otherwise, his accusations are sheer speculation and his irresponsible act has seriously smeared the head of state's reputation," Lee Nan-yang said, adding that the lawmaker's unfounded accusations should be sternly condemned.

Lee Nan-yang stressed that the president has never accepted any political contributions from Liang and that the Presidential Office has no knowledge about whether Chen Che-nan has ever accepted any bribes from Liang.

As to Lee Chuang-chiao's allegation that the first lady had purchased tens of thousands of dollars worth of luxury goods at Pacific Sogo Department Store using cash coupons, Lee Nan-yang said Wu has never spent such a big sum of money at that department store. Since every cash coupon has a serial number, he said, it's easy to check whether the lawmaker's accusation is true.

Moreover, Lee Nan-yang said the wheelchair-bound first lady has consistently been accompanied by a large crowd of security officers and nurses on each of her shopping outings. "There are no secrets about the first lady's shopping activities," he added.
Lee Nan-yang further said that if Lee Chuan-chiao fails to make a public apology for the false accusations within three days, the first couple will file a slander suit against the lawmaker.

Liang, who fled to China in 2004 after being found guilty of embezzling funds from Overseas Chinese Bank, returned to Taipei last Saturday. He was arrested upon his arrival at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport.

Liang, a former chairman of Hsinchiehchung Construction Co. and a board member of the Overseas Chinese Bank, had told reporters before his return that he would come back to Taiwan to accuse Chen Che-nan of taking money from him to bribe judges but eventually failing to help resolve his embezzlement case.
Liang has been sentenced to one year in prison for embezzling NT$5.3 billion from the bank, and was given an additional 14-month prison term for forging his construction company's contracts.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-SPONSORED ACEH E-LEARNING CENTER OPENS

TEXT.P: To provide Internet access and rebuild tsunami-stricken Aceh in Indonesia, an Aceh e-learning center, sponsored by Taiwanese donors, opened Saturday as participants from Taiwan and Indonesia celebrated the occasion together via a digital video conference.

The center will provide free Internet classes to high school students in Aceh and also offer Chinese classes. There will be four school terms each year, and it is estimated that there will be 500 students registered each term. A Web site (www.aceh.url.tw) has also been set up to showcase the center and promote tourism in Aceh.
Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou said that the center was funded using the relief funds the Taipei City government collected from the public.

"We raised over NT$37 million (US$1.14 million) , and we thought this amount was too little for relief actions. We decided the best way was to use the money was to provide information technology education for the local people, so we have set up the information center, " Ma said during the opening ceremony.
A dozen Aceh students who came to Taiwan for their education after the tsunami were present at the event. They also talked to their families in Aceh happily during the digital video conference.
Aceh province was devastated by the tsunami tragedy of Dec. 26, 2004, with over 150,000 people being listed as dead or missing in the disaster.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHILDREN SHARE LOVE WITH TAIWANESE SPONSORS IN SPORTS GAMES

TEXT.P: More than 350 children from 12 countries who have been sponsored by Taiwanese are taking part in an international children's sports games in Taipei to share their dreams with their Taiwanese sponsors.
The two-day World Children's Sports Games, organized by World Vision Taiwan (WVT) , kicked off Saturday. The games features 11 events, including soccer, basketball and the 100-meter dash.

"Taiwan received assistance from its international friends during the bad times in past years, and now Taiwan is reaching out a helping hand and extending its compassion to the global community, " Premier Su Tseng-chang said at the opening ceremony at National Taiwan Normal University.
The competition is part of the "Make Friends With Children in the World" campaign launched by WVT to support children in war-torn, less-developed and poor countries.

WVT Executive Director Hank Du welcomed children from the Dominican Republic, Sri Lanka, the Philippines, Bosnia-Herzegovina, Mozambique, Mongolia, South Africa, the Republic of Congo, Malawi, Honduras and Haiti in his remarks.

"The special event tells us that there are many children in need of help in this world, but they need friendship more than just sympathy. And love does make miracles and brings us closer together," Du said. (By Chris Wang) enfitem/Li

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Berlusconi-Prodi duel in finals.
Premier Silvio Berlusconi and opposition leader Romano Prodi head into final showdown with more than 50 million Italian voters called to vote in the parliamentary elections Sunday and Monday and to decide whether to give Berlusconi five more years in power or to hand over the reins of government to Prodi, a former premier and former European Commission chief.

DOC.HEADLINE: HIGH-TECH APPROACH TO BE EMPLOYED TO MONITOR ILLEGAL GRAVEL MINING

TEXT.P: The Bureau of Mines under the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said Saturday that it is planning to employ a high-tech approach to help monitor illegal gravel mining on land.

Bureau officials said that with gravel in rivers gradually being depleted and gravel mining on land involving environmental issues and other problems, illegal gravel mining has become a serious problem in view of the strong market demand.

The officials said that illegal gravel mining also leaves ugly pits on land, which have posed a threat to public safety. If hazardous waste has been dumped in the pits, they could also affect environmental safety, they added.
To stop such illegal practices and to help city and county governments crack down on the practice, the bureau will use satellite imaging provided by the Formosat-2 as well as aerial photographs.

The officials said that they will soon target areas where rampant illegal gravel mining has been reported. They will pinpoint the locations and provide related information for reference to local governments, which can then send officials to crack down on the activities, they said.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PREMIER URGES CONFIDENCE IN ECONOMY

TEXT.P: Vice Premier Tsai Ing-wen on Saturday urged the public to have confidence in the nation's economy, saying that she is confident of its continued stable growth over the next two to three years.

Tsai made the remarks when she was invited by Legislator Hsieh Ming-yuan of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and the Taichung Association of Industry and Commerce to give a speech in Taichung, central Taiwan. More than 300 industrial and business leaders attended the meeting at which she gave her speech.
Tsai, a former head of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council, didn't talk too much about cross-strait issues.
She noted that some in Taiwan are pessimistic about Taiwan's economic development, even to the extent of criticizing the government as being incompetent.
However, the fact is that Taiwan ranks near the top of the list in every aspect of economic competitiveness in major international assessments, she said.

"The public need not feel uneasy about the nation's economic development, " she said, adding that "as long as Taiwan doesn't make any missteps, it can maintain stable growth over the next two to three years."
She also said that as Taiwan moves toward a high-tech knowledge-based economy, it is inevitable that the widening gap between rich and poor will become more serious.
"The government will have to embark on long-term structural reforms to effectively close the gap between rich and poor, " she continued.
On cross-strait economic issues, Tsai said that with the trend of globalization, the positive and negative effects of an economically rising China will impact Taiwan's economic development.
Taiwan businesspeople investing in China will get high yields if they are successful, but they shouldn't ignore the high risks inherent in the economic environment in China, she said.
She said she believes that direct cross-strait transportation is only a short-term issue and that the more important issue will be how to face an economically rising China in the long term.

Some participants suggested to Tsai that the idle Shuinan Airport complex in downtown Taichung be turned into an exhibition center, and Tsai promised to take their suggestion to the Council for Economic Planning and Development for studies.
Shuinan Airport has been idle since Chingchuankang Airport in suburban Taichung took over its business in 2004.
Some also suggested that Chingchuankang Airport open direct flights to Hong Kong and Macau.

DOC.HEADLINE: TOP PROSECUTOR'S CONFIRMATION HANGS IN BALANCE

TEXT.P: The opposition-controlled Legislative Yuan is scheduled to vote on President Chen Shui-bian's nomination for the nation's top prosecutorial post Tuesday, but the voting result remains uncertain, particularly after a former senior presidential aide was detained over a bribery scandal Friday.

Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Legislator Lee Chuan-chiao said Saturday that Hsieh Wen-ting, the nominee for the post of state public prosecutor general, must show a firm resolve to fight government corruption in order to win the opposition camp's support for his accession to the top prosecutorial post.

Lee urged Hsieh, who is now the chief prosecutor general of the Public Prosecutors' Office of the Taiwan High Court, to declare before the confirmation vote that he would be willing to appoint courageous, upright and incorruptible prosecutors to form a special panel to investigate a spate of high-profile corruption scandals allegedly involving senior officials.

"If Hsieh can do so, I'll do my best to persuade all of my KMT colleagues to vote for his appointment. Otherwise, I'll demand that the KMT legislative caucus order all members to cast a 'no' vote, " Lee said.

Tuesday's vote will mark the first time that the legislature has a role in the appointment of the state public prosecutor general. In the past, the president had full authority to appoint the nation's top prosecutor. According to the newly revised Court Organic Law, the president can only nominate a candidate whose appointment requires the legislature's confirmation.

Lee praised judicial authorities' decision to have Chen Che-nan, a former Presidential Office deputy secretary-general, detained for further investigations into his role in several suspicious official corruption scandals.

Chen was detained Friday on the charge of fraud after he confessed to having accepted NT$7.11 million in bribe money from a construction tycoon but eventually failing to help the convicted tycoon resolve an embezzlement case.

Lee said the fraud charge was relatively minor compared to Chen's alleged role in other high-profile influence-peddling scandals, such as the Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp. profiteering and the Pacific Sogo Department Store embezzlement cases.

Moreover, Lee claimed it is likely that more powerful politicians are involved in those cases. With a view to wiping out official corruption and establishing clean politics, Lee said the new top prosecutor must have the guts to name honest and trustworthy prosecutors to solve all those cases.

Yeh said Hsieh, who is now the Taiwan High Court's chief prosecutor general, already assured lawmakers at the legislature's judicial committee earlier this week that if he gets the top prosecutorial post, he would look into several widely watched controversial cases, such as suspected Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp. racketeering and possible irregularities in Taiwan High-Speed Railway Corp. financing and electronic freeway toll collection system bidding.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2006 HAKKA TUNG BLOSSOM FESTIVAL KICKS OFF IN NANTOU

TEXT.P: The 2006 Hakka Tung Blossom Festival kicked off Saturday with a fun-filled ceremony at Niuerh Arts Park in Nantou County's Puli township in central Taiwan.
A large crowd of tourists traveled to Puli from around Taiwan to appreciate white tung blossom in full bloom. Niuerh Arts Park boasts a spectacular collection of tung trees.
The Puli township government, with the support of the Council for Hakka Affairs, organized a number of festive activities to promote Hakka culture, customs, cuisine, dances, songs and artifacts.
Starting next week, other townships in Nantou County will present similar activities to mark the annual Hakka Tung Blossom Festival.

From April 15 through May 14, major Hakka communities around Taiwan will celebrate the festival in their own way, focusing on promoting tourism and creative Hakka-flavor foodstuffs, fashion products and decorative items.
This is the fifth consecutive year that the Cabinet-level Hakka council has organized a tung blossom festival to boost tourism and cultural development in Taiwan's major Hakka communities.
In 2005, the tung blossom festival attracted more than 3 million visitors and generated NT$3.5 billion in business revenues.

Tung tree is common in northern Taiwan's Hakka communities, the Hakka affairs council has "adopted" the tung blossom as a symbol of Hakka culture. The tree used to be an important source of income f or local Hakka people. It is hoped that through the annual festival, the trees will once again bring prosperity to Hakka communities.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN INVENTORS WIN BIG AT GENEVA INVENTIONS SHOW
DOC.DATELINE: Geneva, April 8 (CNA) (By Neil Lu and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan inventors have again demonstrated their ingenuity by winning a record-setting number of prizes at the 34th Geneva Inventions Show that opened Wednesday for a five-day run.
Taiwan inventors have captured four special prizes, 15 gold medals, 13 silvers and six bronzes. It was the largest number of honors that Taiwan team has ever garnered in the annual competition.
The Taiwan delegation presented 37 inventions at this year's event. Their inventions covered a wide variety of fields, including transportation, biotechnology, electronics and daily life amenities.
Their ingenuity and diversity have won much acclaim at the show, said Chen Chung-tai, head of the Taiwan delegation who concurrently serves as president of the Taiwan Inventors Association.

Senior Taiwan officials stationed in Switzerland, including Lin Yi-fu, representative to the World Trade Organization, and Shen Lu-hsun, head of the representative office in Geneva, have attended the show in the past few days to cheer up participating Taiwan inventors.
