DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, April 9, or the 12th day of the third month of the Year of the Dog according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1241: Batu Khan, grandson of Genghis Khan, leads his Mongol horsemen to victory over the Teutonic Knights at Liegniz, Silesia.
1626: Sir Francis Bacon, English philosopher, essayist, courtier, jurist, and statesman, dies at the age of 65. His writings include "The Advancement of Learning," and the "Novum Organum," in which he proposed a theory of scientific knowledge based on observation and experiment that came to be known as the inductive method.
1667: The world's first art exhibition opens in Paris, and lasts for 15 days.
1682: La Salle, the title of Robert Cavelier, the French explorer of North America who claimed Louisiana for France in 1682, reaches the Gulf of Mexico after traveling down the Mississippi River.
1865: Confederation Gen. Robert E. Lee surrenders to Union Gen. Ulysses S. Grant at the Appomattox Courthouse in Virginia, ending the U.S. Civil War.
1926: Tuan Chi-jui resigns as provisional chief executive of the Republic of China.
1928: Islam is no longer recognized as the state religion of Turkey.
1940: German troops invade Norway and Denmark.
1942: American and Filipino forces on Bataan surrender to the Japanese after a four-month siege.
1957: Egypt announces the opening of the Suez Canal after the withdrawal of invading troops from Great Britain and France from Port Said.
1961: The Republic of Vietnam holds its first presidential elections with Ngo Dinh Diem elected as president.
1963: British Prime Minister Winston Churchill is proclaimed an honorary U.S. citizen at the White House.
1965: The ROC and the United States conclude in Taipei an accord to establish a Sino-American fund for economic and social development in Taiwan.
1969: The Concorde, the supersonic passenger jet, makes its maiden flight from Bristol to Fairford in England.
1973: Hedley Donavan, editor-in-chief of Time magazine, arrives in Taipei for a two-day visit.
1973: Lt. Gen. Thomas K. McGebee, commander of the U.S. Aerospace Defense Command, arrives in Taipei from Bangkok for a three-day visit.
1974: Nguyen Van Kieu, newly elevated Vietnamese ambassador-extraordinary and plenipotentiary, presents a copy of his credentials to ROC Foreign Minister Shen Chang-huan.
1976: The fifth congress of the Federation of Asian Photographic Arts opens with 200 representatives from South Korea, the Philippines, India, Indonesia, Sabah and the ROC attending.
1976: Bernard B. Matawali, permanent secretary of the Ministry of Agriculture of Malawi, arrives in Taipei for a five-day visit.
1988: Mainland China's National Peoples Congress names Li Peng as premier.
1990: The Democratic Forum of Hungary sweeps to power in elections, after 40 years of communism.
1991: Georgia declares independence from the Soviet Union.
1998: More than 100 Muslim pilgrims are crushed to death in a stampede at the Haj pilgrimage in Saudi Arabia.
2000: Paraguay's first flower exhibition center is inaugurated in the Central Province city of Caacupe, with Paraguayan President Luis Gonzalez Macchi and Republic of China Ambassador to Asuncion Liu Ting-tsu cutting the ribbon.
2001: Former Republic of China Vice President Shieh Tung-min passes away at the age of 95 at his home in a suburb of Taipei from cardial infarction.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "When there is justice and order in the government of the country a man may be bold and lofty in the expression of his opinions as well as in his actions. When, however, there is no justice and order in the government of the country, a man may be bold and lofty in his actions, but should be reserved in the expression of his opinion."

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN MINISTER TO ATTEND REGIONAL WORKING MEETING IN AFRICA

TEXT.P: Minister of Foreign Affairs Huang Chih-fang was scheduled to depart Sunday for the north African country of Chad to preside over a regional working meeting of Republic of China diplomats and foreign mission executives posted around Africa.

Huang and his entourage, comprised of officials from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) , the Bureau of Foreign Trade, the Government Information Office and the International Cooperation and Development Fund, are scheduled to attend the 22nd African regional working meeting to be held in the Chad capital of Ndjamena April 10-11, according to MOFA officials.
In addition to attending the meeting, Huang is also expected to meet with political leaders of Chad, one of the ROC's staunchest diplomatic allies in Africa.
He will inspect the progress and operations of development projects that have been implemented in Chad under a bilateral cooperative program between Taiwan and Chad, MOFA officials said.

While meeting with ROC ambassadors and foreign mission heads from around Africa at the meeting, Huang and the diplomats are expected to review Taiwan's diplomatic operations in that part of the world, sort out new subjects and challenges, and plan for strategies and directions of diplomatic work in Africa.

By engaging in face-to-face discussions, Huang and his group are expected to reach consensus with the Africa-stationed diplomats on Taiwan's diplomatic front in Africa and hammer out policies to further consolidate Taiwan's ties with its African allies, the officials added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRIVATE INVESTMENT REGISTERED NEGATIVE GROWTH IN 2005

TEXT.P: If the government does not attach importance to investment in the service industry, it will be difficult to expect a good record in domestic investment, according to an economist who pointed out that private investment dipped 1.3 percent in 2005 on a year-on-year basis.

Ku Ying-hua, a research fellow at the Institute of Economics of Academia Sinica, made the remarks in an article she contributed to the online newspaper of the Ministry of Economic Affairs' Industrial Development and Investment Center.

She said the service industry has become the mainstay of Taiwan's economy, accounting for 73.56 percent of the gross domestic product (GDP) last year. However, she went on, the sector has received little assistance from the government.

Instead, she noted, the government has focused its energy on the manufacturing industry, which in 2005 accounted for only 21.13 percent of the GDP -- a level which she claimed could not possibly be a locomotive driving economic growth.
Still, Ku said, the government has made every effort to find land for investors wishing to invest in the manufacturing industry.
With the completion of the sixth naphtha cracking plant and the high-speed railway system, Taiwan will face a challenge in terms of increasing private investment, she said.

According to Ku, if the government wants to encourage investment in the service industry, it must start with urban development, as manufacturing has been moving out of the country, while the service sector will not see such a huge exodus.
"The only way to improve private investment is to legislate a good set of laws and regulations for the service industry that will provide good services to consumers," she said.
According to government statistics, fixed capital took a 19.7 percent share of Taiwan's GDP in 2005, a record low level with a total amount that is up only 0.46 percent from 2004.

Of that total, private investment actually dipped 1.3 percent from the previous year, Ku pointed out, adding that the share of fixed capital in GDP would have dropped even more had government-owned enterprises not invested 17.21 percent more than a year earlier to make up for the shortfalls in fixed investment.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP FORUM NOT MEANT TO SUPERVISE PERFORMANCE OF CABINET: PARTY WHIP

TEXT.P: A policy forum to be held by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) at the Presidential Office next week is aimed at seeking consensus between the party and the Cabinet on important issues, DPP spokesman Tsai Huang-liang said Sunday.

Tsai, a whip of the DPP's legislative caucus who also serves as the party's culture and information director, denied media claims that in holding the forum, the DPP is trying to supervise the performance of the Cabinet.
Tsai said the policy forum, which has been held by the DPP's Policy Committee several times over the past few years, is part of the party's consensus-seeking mechanism.

According to Tsai, participants in the forum will include President Chen Shui-bian, Premier Su Cheng-tsang, DPP Chairman Yu Shyi-kun, some Cabinet members, DPP legislators and possibly National Security Council Secretary-General Chiou I-jen.

News reports Sunday said the DPP chairman, who is a former premier, wants the party to be the locomotive in the government's policy planning and reviewing process, but some Cabinet officials believe that Yu has transgressed the bounds of his duty.

DPP Secretary-General Lin Chia-lung and other high-ranking party officials reportedly decided at a meeting last week that the party will begin to hold a policy forum every week to play a role parallel to that of the Research, Development and Evaluation Commission of the Executive Yuan in an attempt to supervise the Cabinet's performance on important policy issues.

The reports claimed that the DPP's "drastic move" is intended to revive the party's plummeting popularity in the wake of a series of corruption scandals implicating high-ranking government officials. According to the results of an opinion poll released last week, the approval ratings for the president and the DPP have plunged to 18 percent.

Commenting on the reports, Cheng Wen-tsang, a government spokesman and head of the Government Information Office, pointed out that the DPP's policy forum is nothing new. He said he had never heard of the DPP's plan to supervise the Cabinet's performance.

DPP Legislator Shen Fa-hui -- one of eight DPP lawmakers who called for an extraordinary session of the party's national congress to discuss ways to reform the party -- said that if the DPP wants to supervise the performance of the Cabinet, it should do so through the DPP caucus at the Legislative Yuan.
"The party does not have a mechanism to oversee the Executive Yuan's performance; it only has the right to make suggestions to the DPP's legislative caucus," Shen said.

Tsai Chi-chang, another DPP legislator who joined the call for an extraordinary session of the DPP's national congress, said it would sound "strange" if the party wanted to supervise the Cabinet in the implementation of important policies.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEASED FARMLAND TO BE RECLAIMED TO HELP SAVE ENDEMIC SALMON SPECIES

TEXT.P: Wuling Farm, located near the natural habitat of Taiwan's "national treasure" fish, the Formosan landlocked salmon in central Taiwan, said Sunday it has reclaimed most of its land that has been leased for fruit and vegetable plantation in an effort to help save the endangered species.

Water pollution caused by the pesticides used by fruit and vegetable growers in the Wuling Farm area over the years has been blamed as one of the reasons behind the decline in the population of the rare fish.

Actually, the Veterans Affairs Commission -- the owner of Wuling Farm -- has been cutting the leasing of land to fruit and vegetable growers over the past several years as the country's awareness of environmental protection has risen.
So far, according to the Wuling Farm management, only 40 hectares of land is currently leased, and this land will be reclaimed as soon as possible for reforestation.

Wuling Farm officials said that there are four categories of fish endemic to the Chichiawan stream area, which is part of the Sheipa National Park in central Taiwan. Of the four kinds of fish, the Formosan landlocked salmon, an endangered species endemic to Taiwan, is the most prominent, as it has been recognized as a subspecies of the cherry salmon, a throwback from the last Ice Age.

The salmon became landlocked during the glacial epoch in frigid mountain streams, and its discovery in Taiwan, a subtropical island, is regarded by biologists as "a miracle." Similar species are also found, although in much colder areas, in Japan, South Korea and northeastern China.

Wuling Farm officials said that in compliance with the policies of the Sheipa National Park Administration, the farm decided to forsake its economic gains to help protect the environment and conserve endangered species.

Despite the government's comprehensive and intensive conservation efforts, the number of Formosan landlocked salmon in the Chichiawan stream in the upper stretches of the Tachia river and the lower reaches of the Wuling stream in mountainous regions of central Taiwan has continued to decline in recent years as a result of ecological changes in the fish's natural habitat.

Sheipa National Park officials attributed the decline primarily to climatic changes and environmental pollution in the fish's native habitat. The crises identified by the officials include frequent typhoons and summer storms that affect water levels in the rivers where the fish lives, and global warming that scientists believe leads to a lower breeding rate.

According to the park officials, the Formosan landlocked salmon inhabits cold, slow-flowing streams with gently sloping beds at elevations above 1,500 meters. It needs clean cold water under 18 degrees Celsius to thrive.

Another crisis faced by the fish is that its native habitat is prone to forest fires, which can easily change the ecological balance in the region, the officials said, adding that water pollution caused by pesticides used by fruit and vegetable growers in the nearby Wuling Farm has also contributed to the population decline.

In addition, the establishment of sandtraps in the Tachia river to prevent downstream silting is yet another threat to the survival of the rare species, as the sandtraps prevent the adult salmon from returning to their spawning beds, park officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWANESE DIALECT TO BE PROMOTED NATIONWIDE

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Education is planning to promote the usage of Taiwanese dialect nationwide so that the mother tongue of the Taiwan people can be revived.

Beginning from the 2006 academic year, or Sept. 1 this year, a "Taiwanese Mother Tongue Day" will be implemented each week in elementary and junior high schools around the nation to allow children to practice Taiwanese so as to make the dialect part of their daily lives, said Pan Wen-chung, director of the Education Ministry's Elementary Education Department.

This "Taiwanese Mother Tongue Day" activity has been carried out in 1,524 elementary and junior high schools on a trial basis since last year, but starting from September, the weekly program will be a mandated part of the curriculum, Pan said.
The design of the "Taiwanese Mother Tongue Day" is aimed at enabling school children to speak Taiwanese as their mother tongue and to use it more frequently in their daily lives, Pan added.

The "Taiwanese Mother Tongue Day" curriculum will be considered an index of how successful local governments have been in promoting the dialect teaching in their respective areas, Pan said, adding that local governments that give outstanding performances in this regard will be rewarded with cash prizes of NT$500,000.

Meanwhile, Pan said, beginning from the 2006 academic year, kindergartens around the nation can apply for subsidies to provide dialect teaching, which could include Taiwanese and indigenous mother tongues.
The subsidies will amount to NT$70,000 for each kindergarten per academic year and up to 50 kindergartens nationwide could be chosen to receive the grant.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S AGRO-BIOTECH ACHIEVEMENTS TO BE SHOWCASED IN CHICAGO
DOC.DATELINE: New York, April 8 (CNA) (By Lillian Lin and Taijing Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's achievements in agro-biotechnology will be showcased at the Biotechnology Industry Organization's (BIO's) 2006 Annual International Convention April 9-12 in Chicago, a spokesman for the Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) said Saturday.

The spokesman said TAITRA wants to emphasize Taiwan's achievements in agro-biotechnology and biotechnology, while non-government participants at the convention will promote traditional Chinese medicine, which is becoming more and more popular.

Taiwan is proud of the agricultural assistance it has provided to its diplomatic allies, including the latest agricultural innovations such as the technology for genetically modifying orchids, and eco-friendly bio-fertilizers, the spokesman added.

Other Taiwan products that will be presented include a soybean product that has been clinically tested to be efficient in fighting cancer, a camphor-based health food that it's makers claim can enhance the body's immune system and tuckahoe tea, which is a well-known health food in the United States.

In Taiwan, he said, a "bio-cluster" has formed under the close cooperation of the Taipei Biotechnology Corridor and the Southern Taiwan Science Park, attracting investment from prominent biotechnology companies.
The spokesman said there is great market potential for health products because people are increasingly aware of the benefits of health food and natural herbal medicine.

In connection with the convention, the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Chicago is also to organize a "Taiwan Night" April 10 to help participants interested in Taiwan's products and technology to get in touch with each other.
The spokesman said more than 100 researchers, investors and representatives of biotechnology and pharmaceutical companies have been invited to "Taiwan Night."

DOC.HEADLINE: SIX KMT MEMBERS REGISTER AS CANDIDATES FOR KAOHSIUNG MAYOR

TEXT.P: Six members of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) have registered with the party to put themselves up as candidates in the KMT's primary election for Kaohsiung mayor after KMT Legislator Lee Fu-hsing submitted his application Sunday.

The five others who completed the application procedure in the past four days are former independent Legislator Su Ying-guei, former Kaohsiung City Council Speaker Huang Chi-chuan and legislators Huang Chao-shun, Lwo Shih-hsiung and Lee Chuan-chiao.
The six candidates have each submitted a NT$1 million deposit, plus documents to prove that their candidacy is supported by at least 2,097 KMT members.

Six other KMT members have also declared their intention to run but have not turned in application forms. They include former Kaohsiung Deputy Mayor Huang Jun-ying, former Legislator Chen Hsueh-sheng, former Penghu County Magistrate Lai Feng-wei, and Legislator Chiu Yi. They will have to decide whether to join the May 27 party primary before the registration ends Monday.
It is hard to predict at this stage which candidate will emerge as the KMT's nominee in the year-end Kaohsiung mayoral race.

According to regulations governing the KMT's primaries, in determining who will be the party's candidate in an election, support by KMT members accounts for 30 percent, while support by voters as reflected by opinion polls accounts for 70 percent.
The KMT primary for the Kaohsiung mayoral election will take place the same day as the party's primary for the Taipei mayoral election.
The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) is also scheduled to hold its primary election May 28 to choose the party's nominee for Kaohsiung mayor.
The competition in the DPP's Kaohsiung mayoral primary has been described as a battle between two women -- former Council of Labor Affairs Chairwoman Chen Chu and Legislator Kuan Bi-ling.

Kuan has urged Chen to withdraw from the race because of her poor record as the nation's highest labor official that resulted in her having to resign, while Chen's supporters have said that Kuan should finish her term as a legislator instead of switching her political track in a bid to become Kaohsiung mayor.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT TO KICK OFF 'LANGUAGE DECENCY' CAMPAIGN

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu urged politicians Sunday not to make allegations against others without evidence, adding that she will kick off a "language decency" campaign reminding people not to "dance to the tune of allegations."

Lu made the remarks when asked to comment on opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Legislator Lee Chuan-chiao's allegation that President Chen Shui-bian accepted a political donation from Liang Po-hsun, a bankrupt builder now in detention for economic crimes and forgery.
Lee also insinuated that first lady Wu Shu-jen has accepted gift coupons from a well-known department store.
Lu said Taiwan is a country under the rule of law and that politicians should not make groundless allegations against other people.
Liang's case is being handled by the court, she said, urging the media and the general public to "be patient with the justice system, " the dignity of which, she said, is important to maintain.
Lu made the call while attending a social function at Kaohsiung Girls' High School.

DOC.HEADLINE: ENVIRONMENTAL GROUPS CALL FOR SETTING OF CO2-CUTTING GOALS

TEXT.P: Scores of environmental groups issued a joint statement Sunday to call for the government to decide on goals for reducing emissions of carbon dioxide (CO2) and a timetable for their implementation to help Taiwan secure sustainable development.

The groups, led by the Taiwan Environmental Protection Union, called for the government to seek concrete results at a national sustainable development conference slated for April 21 in environmental protection efforts.

Expressing hope that the conference will not turn out to be another "show of formality, " the environmental protection groups said the government must come up with concrete goals for reducing CO2 emissions, requirements for the private industrial sector and an implementation timetable once the conference is convened.

They said these measures are imperative if Taiwan wants to prevent itself from facing the international trade sanctions that will occur if the country continues to slack off on control of emissions of greenhouse gases after the Kyoto Protocol entered into force in February 2005.

The statement said that before the government puts forth concrete goals for CO2 emission reduction programs and their implementation timetable, the Executive Yuan should not approve any new high CO2-emission development projects, such as the eighth naphtha cracking plant and big steel mills.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEXUAL EXPLOITATION OF MINORS THROUGH INTERNET ON RISE

TEXT.P: More and more paedophiles and sexual predators have been using the Internet as a channel to lure minors for sexual exploitation in the past three years, according to statistics released by the National Police Agency Sunday.
The figures show that police nabbed 54 offenders who tried to use online messages to seduce minors into sex acts, with the number increasing to 215 in 2004, and 409 in 2005.

The figures also show that seven sexual predators were arrested in 2003 for using the Internet as a medium for the sex trade, and that the number jumped to 71 in 2004. However, the number last year dropped to 20, thanks to a police crackdown on online pornography.
Under the Children and Teenagers Sexual Transaction Prevention Act, it is a criminal offense to cause minors to engage in sex trade or lure them through implicit online messageS into sex acts.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA, U.S., VIETNAM TOP THREE SOURCES OF TAIWAN'S TRADE SURPLUS

TEXT.P: China (including Hong Kong) , the United States and Vietnam were the top three sources of Taiwan's trade surplus in the first three months of this year, the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) under the Executive Yuan said Sunday.
Among the three, China and Hong Kong recorded a US$13.9 billion trade deficit with Taiwan, compared with US$11.9 billion during the same period of last year, DGBAS officials said.
During the first quarter of 2005, Taiwan's trade surpluses with the U.S. and Vietnam were US$2.19 billion and US$830 million, respectively, the officials added.

They noted that Taiwan's main export products were precision instruments, electric machinery, and electronics, which rose 68.8 percent, 30.2 percent, and 27.8 percent, respectively, from the same period of last year. However, shipments of information technology and telecommunication products were down 9 percent.

As for Taiwan's trade deficits during the first season of the fiscal year, Japan, Saudi Arabia and South Korea were the top three countries causing Taiwan's deficits, with Japan taking the lead at US$7.26 billion, followed by Saudi Arabia at US$2.4 billion and South Korea at US$1.82 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT CHALLENGES KMT TO ESPOUSE 'TWO CHINAS' THEORY

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu challenged Sunday the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) , which insists on its "one China, with each side of the Taiwan Strait free to interpret its meaning, " to espouse a "two Chinas" theory.

Speaking to a gathering of the Taiwan Heart Association founded by Lu herself, the vice president said she cannot accept KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou's "five do's" proposal for re-starting cross-Taiwan Strait negotiations based on the so-called "1992 consensus, " describing Ma's "five do's" as sugar-coated poison.
If the KMT is not faint of heart, it should put forth a "two Chinas" formula for handling Taiwan-China relations, she said.
The KMT, which ruled Taiwan until 2000, said its "one China" refers to the Republic of China, while for the Communist Party of China (CPC), it refers to the People's Republic of China.

President Chen Shui-bian, during a rare meeting with Ma earlier this month, challenged the KMT to wrestle a "one China" consensus from Beijing that allows Taiwan to proclaim itself the Republic of China. If such a consensus could be reached, Chen said he "absolutely will respect it."

The chairman of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), Yu Shyi-kun, reiterated the challenge in Chiayi, central Taiwan, where he called on the KMT to talk with the DPP before a KMT delegation leaves for a joint forum with the CPC in Beijing later this month.

Suspecting that the KMT-CPC forum is aimed at stripping the DPP government of its administrative authority over cross-strait affairs, Yu said the KMT should talk with the DPP over how to work for the best interests of the Taiwan people.

The proposed DPP-KMT talks could cover such topics as repatriating illegal immigrants from China, protecting the interests of Taiwan investors in China and reiterating the so-called "1992 consensus" claimed by the KMT to have been reached by officials from Taipei and Beijing in Hong Kong, Yu said.
It would better serve Taiwan's interests if the DPP and KMT could reach a consensus on how to talk with China, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S MILITARY MIGHT AMONG GREATEST IN ASIA-PACIFIC: H.K. ANALYST
DOC.DATELINE: Kuala Lumpur, April 9 (CNA) (By Y.P. Chin and Taijing Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's military power is one of the greatest among Asia-Pacific countries and therefore should not be neglected, a Hong Kong-born military analyst said Sunday at a seminar in Malaysia.

However, Taiwan cannot turn itself into a battlefield, because a conflict with China would take place on the west coast, which has the highest concentration of population, as well as the majority of economic and industrial installations, Ma told the seminar on the U.S.-China and cross-Taiwan Strait military situation.
He claimed that there is little possibility of war across the strait because public opinion has changed from that of the previous generation.
Ma also noted that the differences in the political beliefs of Taiwan and China have not impeded the development of non-government cross-strait relations.
On China's military power, Ma claimed that it has yet to strengthen its offensive or troop-deployment capabilities.
Ma is a researcher at the Guangdong Academy of Social Sciences in China.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-MADE LITHOTRIPTERS PRAISED IN PARIS
DOC.DATELINE: Paris, April 9 (CNA) (By Lo Yuan-hsao and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan-made extracoporeal shock wave lithotripters, which break up kidney stones with high-energy waves without injuring the patient, were cast into the spotlight here Friday during a meeting of European urologists, thanks to a report by two Taiwan doctors.

Doctors Chen Shih-jung from Hualien Hospital and Chang Cheng-yeh from Hsinchu Hospital shared their experience of using the machines in a report read at a panel discussion at the annual congress of the European Association of Urology (EAU).

The two urologists said the Taiwan-made device combines an X-ray machine, which locates the stones in the urinary tract, with an ultra-sound device that breaks the stones into small pieces that can be passed by the patient, and are nearly 100 percent precise.

The two urologists said they have used the machines to treat 514 patients aged between 21 and 76 and that no change in blood pressure during the process has ever been detected. Less than 20 percent of them had traces of blood in their urine -- a sign that their urinary tracts were injured by the process.
The machines have integrated the technology of computers, imaging, automation and machinery, the two doctors said.
Their report earned high respect at the congress which was held between April 5-8 and brought together more than 16,000 EAU members.

DOC.HEADLINE: KOREAN SOPRANO TO PERFORM IN TAIPEI APRIL 10

TEXT.P: Sumi Jo, a Korean coloratura soprano, is to show off her singing skills to Taiwan's audience with opera extraits from Rossini's "Semiramide" and Verdi's "Rigoletto" at the National Concert Hall Monday.

Speaking at a news conference Sunday, she said that international classical music audience has gradually come to accept Asian singers, but they have to work more on their techniques and language ability to increase their opportunities to perform on stage.
Jo, late German conductor Herbert von Karajan's protegee, became noticed on the international opera circle in the late 1990s.
Coming along with Jo is conductor Graeme Jenkins of Dallas Opera. Jenkins is going to accompany Jo's performance by conducting the National Symphony Orchestra of Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENTIAL OFFICE THREATENS TO SUE KMT LEGISLATOR

TEXT.P: The Presidential Office said Sunday it will sue opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Legislator Lee Chuan-chiao for alleging that first lady Wu Shu-jen has accepted NT$8.8 million worth of a department store's gift coupons and has used hundreds of thousands of NT dollars of these "special coupons."

The office's Department of Public Affairs had threatened Saturday to sue Lee if he did not apologize within three days, but an undeterred Lee made that allegation again Sunday, prompting the Presidential Office to threaten that it will file a lawsuit against Lee in order to clear Wu's name.

At a press conference at the Sungshan Airport in Taipei, Lee claimed that he had evidence of the first lady and her family members having used some of the "special coupons" that are different from those issued by Pacific Sogo Department Store.
Lee called on the first lady to make public the serial numbers of the coupons, claiming that he has "data on hand" that match the serial numbers of the coupons used by the first family.
He challenged the Presidential Office to sue him as soon as possible so he will have a chance to prove everything at the court.
The legislative caucus of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said a lawmaker should not use his immunity privilege to make allegations.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA LONGS FOR 30 YEARS OF PEACEFUL DEVELOPMENT: SCHOLAR
DOC.DATELINE: Singapore, April 9 (CNA) (By Charles Kang and Taijing Wu)

TEXT.P: Thirty years of peaceful and stable development is what China wants most at the moment, therefore Taiwan's government has to be aware that cross-Taiwan Strait situation is quite different from what it used to be, visiting Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh said Sunday upon his arrival in Singapore.

China has experienced 20 years of reform and has had a taste of peace, stability and development; what they most want to have now is thirty more years of peace, stability and development, Lee said as he arrived from Xiamen, southern China.
Lee said Taiwan has to realize the situation across the strait is not the same as before, as can be seen from the leading slogan in Xiamen, across Kinmen that is under Taiwan's jurisdiction.

Lee said the propaganda panel in Xiamen facing Taiwan's Kinmen Islands read "Unifying China with One Country-Two Systems," replacing the old one calling for "Liberating Taiwan, " and the change from "Liberating Taiwan" to "Unifying China" is quite significant.

Lee joked that foreigners in China sometimes ask locals if "One Country-Two Systems" means combining Taiwan's socialism and China's capitalism because social welfare in Taiwan, such as the national health insurance program and senior citizens' pension system are even better than in China.

Lee was scheduled to deliver speeches in Singapore on scientists' duties regarding energy and environmental protection during his two-day visit. He will also visit academic institutions doing research on physics and chemistry.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT-CPC FORUM TO FOCUS ON ECONOMICS, NOT POLITICS

TEXT.P: The five themes of the economic and trade forum between the Chinese Nationalist Party or Kuomintang (KMT) and the Communist Party of China (CPC) will be economic and trade, direct transportation links, tourism, agriculture, and finance, and politics will not be discussed, a KMT official said Sunday.

The cross-strait KMT-CPC forum is scheduled to be held April 14-15 in Beijing. More than 90 leaders of Taiwanese Business Associations in China and nearly 50 Taiwanese entrepreneurs will attend the forum, but KMT Chinese Affairs Department Director Chang Rong-kung didn't release the name list of business leaders.

He noted that KMT Honorary Chairman Lien Chan and Chairman Jia Qinglin of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference (CPPCC) will deliver keynote speeches at the opening ceremony of the forum.

Discussion will focus on the issues of cross-strait economy and trade in the midst of globalization rather than politics. The forum will be quite different from the previous meeting between two parties, Chang said. He said he believed that the conclusion of the forum will benefit all people in Taiwan.
After the meeting, former KMT chairman Lien Chan is scheduled to meet with Chinese President Hu Jintao on April 16 in Beijing, the KMT said.
An estimated of over 170 members in the KMT delegation, including party officials, legislators, scholars, and business leaders, will come from Taiwan.

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Monday, April 10:
09:15, Vice President Annette Lu will attend the 2006 TMAT International Conference on Turnaround Management at the Taiwan Academy of Banking and Finance in Taipei.
09:30, The 2006 Intel Developer Forum will open at the Taipei International Conference Center.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: U.S. Study Paints Somber Portrait of Iraqi
An internal staff report by the United States Embassy and the military command in Baghdad provides a sobering province- by-province snapshot of Iraq's political, economic and security situation, rating the overall stability of 6 of the 18 provinces "serious" and one "critical." The report is a counterpoint to some recent upbeat public statements by top American politicians and military officials. The report, 10 pages of briefing points titled " Provincial Stability Assessment, " underscores the shift in the nature of the Iraq war three years after the toppling of Saddam Hussein. Warnings of sectarian and ethnic frictions are raised in many regions, even in those provinces generally described as nonviolent by American officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BUSINESSMEN 0N MAINLAND COMPELLED TO JOIN CPC-KMT FORUM

TEXT.P: Taiwan business people operating in China are coerced to join an economic forum between the Kuomintang (KMT) and the Communist Party of China (CPC) which is set to open in Beijing on April 14, officials of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said Sunday.

The anonymous officials said their council have learned that leaders of Taiwan Businessmen Associations around China have been asked by the Taiwan Affairs Office under Beijing's State Council to participate in the forum to make it look successful.

Those who can't take part in the forum were asked to take a leave of absence from the Taiwan Affairs Office and to have their deputies attend the forum in their places, according to the MAC officials.
The MAC officials who frowned at the forum said Beijing's request have become a burden to Taiwan business people on the mainland.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, April 10, or the 13th day of the third month of the Year of the Dog according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1512: James V of Scotland, who became king at the age of 17 months, is born. He allied Scotland with France against the English.
1810: Pirate chieftainess "Dragon Lady" Cheng Yi-sao surrenders herself and the 1,800 junks under her command to China's Ching court.
1814: British and Spanish forces defeat Napoleon's army at the Battle of Toulouse, leading to his abdication and exile to the island of Elba the next day.
1829: William Booth, the British religious leader who founded the Salvation Army with his wife Catherine Mumford Booth and who served as its first general, is born.
1847: Hungarian-born American journalist Joseph Pulitzer is born. The newspaper publisher owned newspapers in St. Louis and New York City and established and endowed the Pulitzer Prizes for achievements in journalism and literature.
1858: Chinese Governor-General Ye Ming-chen of Canton and a prisoner of Britain, dies in Calcutta during an Anglo-French expedition against Beijing in 1858.
1898: France obtains concessions from China's Ching court.
1921: Dr. Sun Yat-sen is elected president of the Republic of China.
1932: German general and politician Paul von Hindenburg is re-elected president of the Weimar Republic with 19 million votes to Adolf Hitler's 13 million. He appoints Hitler chancellor in 1933.
1938: More than 99 percent of Austrian voters in a referendum cast their ballots in favor of a merger with Germany.
1944: Brigadier General Charles de Gaulle, who is number one on the hit list of the collaborationist Vichy government of Marshal Petain, becomes commander-in-chief of all the Free French forces.
1946: Japan holds general elections with women voting for the first time.
1953: The ROC Executive Yuan approves the resignation of Taiwan Governor Wu Kuo-chen and names Yu Hung-chun as his replacement.
1958: Dr. Hu Shih assumes office as president of the ROC's Academia Sinica.
1960: The U.S. Senate passes the Civil Rights Bill.
1963: The USS Thresher, an American atomic submarine, sinks in the northern Atlantic, killing all 290 aboard.
1971: Ethnic Chinese hold a mass rally in Washington, D.C., to show their support for the protection of a disputed territory known to the Chinese as the Tiaoyutai Islands.
1972: The ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs announces the establishment of diplomatic relations with the Kingdom of Tonga.
1972: The United States and the Soviet Union sign a treaty banning biological warfare.
1976: Miguel Urrutia Montoya, director of the national planning department of the Republic of Colombia, arrives in Taipei for a week-long visit.
1979: U.S. President Jimmy Carter signs legislation permitting continued commercial and cultural relations between the American government and the ROC following the break in their diplomatic ties.
1980: Mainland China and the Soviet Union end a friendship pact they signed in 1950.
1983: U.S. President Ronald Reagan's Middle East peace plan collapses when King Hussein of Jordan fails to reach an accord with the Palestine Liberation Organization on the terms of the deal.
1986: The United States conducts a nuclear test in the Nevada desert.
1991: Georgia becomes the latest of the Soviet republics wishing to break away from central control.
1996: Mainland Chinese Premier Li Peng's visit to France is marred by a diplomatic wrangle with his French counterpart Alain Juppe over human rights in Beijing.
2000: Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui confers the Order of Brilliant Star with Grand Cordon on David Dean, former Taipei director of the American Institute in Taiwan.
2001: The 13th annual convention of the Overseas Chinese Council in Asia opens in Osaka, Japan, with more than 400 delegates from the Asia-Pacific region participating.
2002: Vice President Annette Lu wins a civil suit against the Taipei-based Journalist weekly, for damage to her image arising from a false report carried by the magazine.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A man who possesses moral worth will always have something to say worth listening to, but a man who has something to say is not necessarily a man of moral worth."

The anonymous officials said their council have learned that leaders of Taiwan Businessmen Associations around China have been asked by the Taiwan Affairs Office under Beijing's State Council to participate in the forum to make it look successful.

Those who can't take part in the forum were asked to take a leave of absence from the Taiwan Affairs Office and to have their deputies attend the forum in their places, according to the MAC officials.

DOC.TEXT: Los Angeles Times: In Politics, Leaking Stories Is a Fine Art. Washington insiders have long honed the skill, learning exactly when, or to whom, to disclose secrets in order to advance their agenda. Months after U.S. troops stormed into Iraq, the Pentagon drafted a top-secret document using classified intelligence to spell out Baghdad's involvement with Al Qaeda. It supported one of President Bush's strongest arguments for the war .

Manila Bulletin: Palm rites begin Holy Week
The annual observance of Holy Week started yesterday, Palm Sunday, with millions of Filipinos trooping to churches all over the country carrying palm fronds which were blessed by parish priests.
The Philippine Daily Inquirer: Arroyo allies to devote Holy Week to Cha-cha
PRESIDENT Gloria Macapagal-Arroyo's congressional allies yesterday warned Catholic Church leaders to stay away from politics and said lawmakers would spend their Lenten holidays campaigning for the shift to the parliamentary system.
The Philippine Star: House pads 'pork' by P4.7B
It's payback time for members of the House of Representatives. The chamber padded its pork barrel by P4.7 billion, or an additional P20 million for each member, before approving the proposed P1-trillion 2006 budget last Tuesday.
The Manila Times: Immigration-policy protest rages in US
WASHINGTON: Pro-immigrant groups vow giant marches across the country on Monday demanding immigration reform and the legalization of nearly 12 million undocumented migrants living in the United States.
