DOC.HEADLINE: TRADITIONAL CHARACTERS DEFINITELY HERE TO STAY: EDUCATION MINISTER

TEXT.P: Minister of Education Tu Cheng-sheng said Monday the government is firm in its position that traditional Chinese characters will continue to be used in Taiwan's school system given their historical and cultural significance.
Speaking at the Legislative Yuan, Tu also said that traditional Chinese characters, or complex Chinese characters, have been used in Taiwan for a long time in official documents and everyday life.

Tu was asked by lawmakers whether Taiwan will consider adopting simplified Chinese characters, which are used in the People's Republic of China, as the United Nations is reportedly preparing to designate simplified characters as the official Chinese script to be used in all of the world body's official documents.

Simplified characters were officially adopted by Beijing in 1949 in an effort to eradicate illiteracy in the country. They are also used in Singapore, while traditional characters are used in Taiwan, Hong Kong, Macau and Malaysia.

Responding to the legislators' question, Tu said that his ministry is working to find out whether the reports are true, adding that regardless of what the U.N. does, traditional characters will continue to be used in Taiwan's educational institutions.

DOC.HEADLINE: FAPA TO STAGE RALLY AT WHITE HOUSE DURING HU'S VISIT
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, April 9 (CNA) (By Chu Lu-sheng & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The Washington D.C.-headquartered Formosan Association for Public Affairs (FAPA) is planning to stage a protest rally near the White House April 20 when Chinese President Hu Jintao is scheduled to visit his U.S. counterpart George W. Bush there, a FAPA executive said Sunday.

FAPA President Chen Wen-yen said that some 600 Taiwanese expatriates residing on the U.S. east coast are expected to attend the protest rally against China's military threat against Taiwan and its suppression of human rights. Several groups of Falun Gong practitioners and exiled Tibetans are also expected to participate, he added.

Chen made the announcement at a gathering of the Intercollegiate Taiwanese American Students Association in Los Angeles. Talking about the planned Hu-Bush meeting, Chen said that he does not expect the two will touch on the Taiwan issue and that they will focus on China-U.S. trade issues, the currency exchange rate, human rights in China, and the North Korea problem.

The FAPA, founded in 1982 in Los Angeles, is a non-profit organization that aims to promote international support for the right of the people of Taiwan to establish an independent and democratic country and to join the international community.

DOC.HEADLINE: OCAC TO LAUNCH INITIATIVES TO SUPPORT TRADITIONAL CHINESE CHARACTERS

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission (OCAC) will soon launch a series of initiatives at home and abroad to support the usage of traditional Chinese characters, an OCAC official said Monday.

The OCAC will sponsor press conferences and various publicity drives to draw the attention of overseas Chinese and Taiwanese as well as foreigners to the significance of using traditional Chinese characters instead of simplified characters, OCAC Vice Minister Cheng Tung-hsing said.
The United Nations is reportedly preparing to designate simplified characters as the official Chinese script to be used in all of the world body's official documents after 2008.

The plan has raised concerns among many people around the world. As of Monday, nearly 100,000 people have visited the voting Web site www.gopetition.com and signed their names in support of action to oppose the U.N.'s plan.

Fielding questions at the Legislative Yuan, Cheng said promoting the Chinese language and the traditional Chinese script is one of the OCAC's key tasks. On the U.N.'s plan, he said this "may serve as a crucial juncture for Taiwan to further promote traditional Chinese characters."

Cheng expressed the hope that the Taiwan public will also actively respond to the OCAC's initiatives in supporting the usage of traditional Chinese characters and opposing the U.N. plan to adopt simplified characters.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Military Plays Up Role of Zarqawi; Jordanian Painted As Foreign Threat To Iraq's Stability.
The U.S. military is conducting a propaganda campaign to magnify the role of the leader of al-Qaeda in Iraq, according to internal military documents and officers familiar with the program. The effort has raised his profile in a way that some military intelligence officials believe may have overstated his importance and helped the Bush administration tie the war to the organization responsible for the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACADEMIA SINICA HEAD TALKS ABOUT CAREER PLANS AFTER RETIREMENT
DOC.DATELINE: Singapore, April 10 (CNA) (By Charles Kang & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Lee Yuan-tseh, president of Taiwan's top academic institute, Academia Sinica, has said he will dedicate himself to cultivating young talent in science at the institute after stepping down from his current post in October.
Lee, a co-winner of the 1986 Nobel Prize in chemistry, made the remarks in an interview with CNA Sunday after arriving in Singapore for a two-day visit.

Taking about his retirement plans, the Taiwan-born Nobel laureate said he will continue his current work of assisting research projects at two Academia Sinica institutes -- the Institute of Atomic and Molecular Sciences and the Genomics Research Center.
"Being a scientist, what I love most is still scientific research," Lee said, noting that after he steps down, he would like to spend more time in the laboratory.

Lee, who has been the president of Academia Sinica since Jan. 15, 1994, also said he hopes he can help Taiwan work out and implement a policy to develop healthy energy resources and help the island build up its biotechnology industry.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI SHARE PRICES END LOWER

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed lower Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 1.3 points to close at 6,780.64.
The bourse opened at 6,759.38 and fluctuated between 6,815.73 and 6,758.07 during trading. A total of 3.15 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$91.99 billion (US$2.84 billion).

Four of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with paper and pulp issues moving up the most at 1.2 percent, followed by foodstuff issues at 0.5 percent, and textile stocks and construction issues both at 0.1 percent.

Three of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with plastics and chemicals shares moving down the most at 0.7 percent, followed by cement stocks at 0.6 percent and machinery and electronics shares at 0.1 percent.
Banking and financial shares remained unchanged.
Losers outnumbered gainers 454 to 442, with 145 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: HOLDING PRESIDENTIAL ELECTION EARLIER 'INAPPROPRIATE': CEC HEAD

TEXT.P: Holding the next presidential election two months earlier than scheduled would be "inappropriate" based on constitutional considerations, Taiwan's top official in charge of election affairs said Monday.

Central Election Commission (CEC) Chairman Chang Cheng-hsiung was responding to a proposal by the main opposition Kuomintang to hold the presidential election, set for March 2008, and the next legislative elections, set for December 2007, simultaneously on Jan. 19, 2008.

Chang said that although their is no provision in the Constitution on when a presidential election should be held, the constitution does stipulate that the period of time that a premier may take over the president's duties cannot exceed three months, and based on this, it would be "inappropriate" for the period of time between the election of a new president and his inauguration to exceed three months.

He noted that if the March 2008 presidential election were to be moved forward to Jan. 19, 2008, there would be a four-month interval between the new president being elected and his being sworn into office. During this interval, he argued, the government's major tasks, including the appointment of government personnel, decisions on administrative policies and responses to major events or incidents, would be left up in the air.
Discounting Chang's explanation, KMT Legislator Tsao Er-chung asked what's wrong with a four-month interval if all matters regarding the changeover are written down and followed.

The KMT has pushed for the "two-in-one" election format on the grounds that it is "based upon a social consensus, " that it would help save costs, and that it is in line with the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's stance in favor of holding fewer elections to avoid wasting resources.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA ADOPTS 'CARROT-AND-STICK' APPROACH TOWARD TAIWAN: MAC HEAD

TEXT.P: China has adopted a new "double-handed strategy" toward Taiwan, the nation's top China policy charter said Monday.

Joseph Wu, chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council, made the remarks when he and his deputy, You Ying-lung, were invited by the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) legislative caucus to report on an upcoming economic forum between the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and the Communist Party of China (CPC) April 14-17.

The forum is part of a five-point agreement reached between KMT Honorary Chairman Lien Chan and Chinese President Hu Jintao during their meeting in Beijing April 29, 2005, when Lien was still KMT chairman. The upcoming forum will discuss cross-Taiwan Strait trade and economy, transportation links, agriculture, tourism and finance.
Wu said that Beijing has "become softer" in trying to court Taiwan people, although the softness is only words, "most of which are fake."
On the other hand, China has "become harder" in its high-handed manner toward Taiwan, referring to its relentless diplomatic stifling and continuing military buildup.
Wu said China's "united front strategy" to drive a wedge into Taiwan society is an attempt to "maneuver Taiwan political parties to marginalize the Taiwan government."
He noted that the KMT and the CPC, while discussing cross-strait charter flights, cannot "rule out the participation of the government" as the issue involves government authority.
If the two parties were to attempt to circumvent the government and reach an agreement on behalf of Taiwan, "it would be basically illegal," he noted.

You echoed Wu's words, pointing out that any agreement reached between the KMT and the CPC involving government authority, policial issues or cross-strait cooperation, should conform with the Statute Governing the Relations Between the People of the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area, or will be invalid and non-binding.

Wu also said that China has told the heads of Taiwan businessmen's associations in China to attend the KMT-CPC forum and has instructed that if they cannot attend, they must take a leave of absence or instruct deputies to attend on their behalf.
"I cannot agree with this way of forcing Taiwan businessmen to attend," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: turnout rate tops 66.5 percent for the first day of general elections.
Some 66.5 percent of voters cast ballots in the first day of the two-day in general elections when the polls were closed at 10:00 pm Sunday. The polls are to be open again from 7:00 am to 3:00 pm Monday.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWMAKERS DENY PERSUADING EX-PREMIER TO RUN FOR TAIPEI MAYOR

TEXT.P: Several legislators of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) described as "misinformation" Monday reports they are going to the United States to persuade former Premier Frank Hsieh to run for Taipei mayor.

They were responding to media speculation that DPP legislators close to Hsieh, including Hsu Kuo-yung, Hsieh Hsin-ni and Lee Chun-yi, are planning to visit the United States April 18 to boost momentum for Hsieh, who is on a short-term study program at the John F. Kennedy School of Government at Harvard University, in the year-end mayoral election.

According to the reports, the recent spate of scandals allegedly involving the ruling party mean the DPP faces an uphill battle in the Kaohsiung and Taipei mayoral elections. In a bid to reverse the situation, some within the DPP are calling for Hsieh to run in the Taipei mayoral election.

The embattled DPP will find it hard to compete with opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou, who is also incumbent Taipei mayor and the best bet to represent the KMT in the 2008 presidential election, the reports claimed.
In response, Lee said that the reports are probably related to the DPP's low approval rating, which is why "some within the party" are desperate to win the year-end elections.

"The trip to the U.S. is mainly to exchange views with Hsieh on the DPP's future prospects, "Lee said, adding that the Taipei mayoral election is not their major issue and that they will not persuade Hsieh, a former Kaohsiung mayor, to throw his hat into the ring.
Lee said that the party could not determine the candidates for Taipei and Kaohsiung mayoral elections earlier because of an overall consideration of the development of the party's future.
He also said that the party is "not ruling out the possibility that the DPP's Taipei and Kaohsiung mayoral candidates will be the top executives and de facto leaders of the DPP."
Legislator Hsieh said that the year-end elections are critical to the party and that the party's candidates should be both capable and have chances of winning.
Hsu said they will travel to the U.S. to hear a speech delivered by Hsieh at Harvard University April 19, and not to "persuade Hsieh to run."

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW CHINESE PETROLEUM CORP. CHAIRMAN NAMED

TEXT.P: Pan Wenent, chairman of the Kuo Kuang Power Co., will serve as chairman of the Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC), Minister of Economic Affairs Hwang Ing-san announced Monday.
Pan, 61, chairman of Kuo Kuang Power Co. since October 2004, will fill the post left vacant by Kuo Chin-tsai, who left in January to serve as chairman of Kuo Kuang Petrochemical Technology Corp.
Pan has previously served as president of CPC.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT REFUSES TO APPROVE PROSECUTOR-GENERAL NOMINEE

TEXT.P: The legislative caucus of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) decided Monday not to endorse the nominee for the country's top prosecutorial post.

The KMT legislative caucus decided at a meeting that the party will not vote to confirm at a Legislative Yuan session Tuesday the the appointment of Hsieh Wen-ting, the Taiwan High Court prosecutor-general who has been nominated by President Chen Shui-bian to be the next state public prosecutor-general.

KMT legislative caucus whip Pan Wei-kang said the KMT feels that Hsieh will not live up to Taiwan society's expectations, particularly in the wake of a spate of incidents, including the 319 shooting of President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu, the KRTC Thai workers riot and alleged corruption in the high-speed railway development project, if he were approved to be the next prosecutor-general.
Pan claimed the KMT caucus has no doubt about Hsieh's integrity, but is worried that his weak personality might mean he will flinch from probing corruption charges involving high-ranking officials.

Noting that the Legislative Yuan has allowed Hsieh enough time and opportunities over the past two months to show his guts and ingenuity, KMT Legislator Wu Yu-sheng claimed that Hsieh is a "lame duck."

KMT Legislator Ting Shou-chung claimed that the KMT's refusal to approve Hsieh's nomination should serve to remind other nominees in the future that in addition to the president's nomination, half of the prosecutor-general's power comes from the legislature.
Pan said the KMT legislators will be fully mobilized to attend the legislative session Tuesday, although none of them will cast a vote, to "shore up the threshold of approval."

According to newly revised Court Organic Law, except for nomination by the president, the nominee's approval requires the presence of one-third of the 221-seat legislature at the meeting and the consent by half of the lawmakers present on the day.
If the legislature endorses the president's nomination, Hsieh will be the country's first top prosecutor to be appointed under the revised Court Organic Law that took effect Feb. 3 this year.
In the past, the president had full power to appoint a state public prosecutor-general. Under the new law, however, the president's nomination requires the legislature's consent.

Under the new law, the state public prosecutor-general will serve only a single four-year term. The new measures are designed to enhance the democratic legitimacy and independence of the prosecutorial system.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HEALTH GROUP ATTENDS HUMANITARIAN MEETING IN DUBAI

TEXT.P: Taiwan International Health Action (Taiwan IHA), a humanitarian body comprising resources and manpower from the government and the private sector, is attending the annual DIHAD conference in Dubai from Monday through Wednesday, a spokesman for the Ministry of Foreign Affairs said Monday.

Taiwan IHA will participate in all the activities and meetings and exchange opinions with international humanitarian aid groups at the Dubai International Humanitarian Aid and Re-development Conference and Exhibition (DIHAD), the spokesman said.

High ranking officials of the United Arab Emirates and more than 200 aid organizations from over 30 countries will take part in the DIHAD, the spokesman added, explaining that Taiwan IHA is composed of members from the national disaster rescue and relief team, the Taiwan Roots Medical Peace Corps and doctors from hospitals across Taiwan.

Taiwan IHA was set up in February this year to take part in global public health affairs. It has recently sent a group of experts to Burkina Faso and Chad, two of Taiwan's diplomatic allies in Africa, to fight avian flu.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN RICE SEEKS BETTER RETAIL SALES IN JAPAN

TEXT.P: Sales of Taiwan rice have been on the rise in Japan and the government is trying to set up new distribution channels through retail shops to help promote Taiwan's high quality rice in the Japanese market, an official of the Agriculture and Food Agency under the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture said Monday.

The agency has been contacting major rice distributors in Japan to open fresh outlets for high-end Taiwan rice in small packs, the officials said, adding that the agency is targeting Japanese retail shops to promote Taiwan's fine-quality and high-priced rice there.
Rice sold in small packs is more popular with Japanese consumers, the official noted.

Taiwan produced rice has gained greater popularity in Japan in recent years, in particular the varieties grown in eastern Taiwan, the official said, expressing his belief that Taiwan rice will be able to seize a bigger slice of the highly stringent but lucrative Japanese market in two or three years.

Foreign rice exported to Japan must be scrutinized by tests for 579 chemical residues, and Taiwan is one of the 15 countries whose products have been approved by the Japanese authorities, according to the official.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT-CPC FORUM AIMED AT BAILING OUT TAIWAN ECONOMY: KMT LAWMAKERS

TEXT.P: An upcoming economic forum between the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and the Communist Party of China (CPC) is aimed at bailing out Taiwan's flagging economy, KMT lawmakers said Monday.

KMT legislative caucus whip Pan Wei-kang and lawmakers Kuo Su-chun and Fei Hung-tai made the comments at a news conference prior to the KMT-CPC economic forum slated for April 14-15 in Beijing, which will focus on cross-Taiwan Strait cooperation on trade and commerce, agriculture and tourism, as well as stepping up financial exchanges and setting up direct transport links.

Pan defended the KMT's decision to hold the forum with the CPC, arguing that the KMT is just keen on seeking a way out for Taiwan's sluggish economy. She urged the "pan green camp" of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and the Taiwan Solidarity Union to stop political fighting for the sake of overall national interests.
Kuo criticized the "pan green camp's" boycott of the forum as "sour grapes, " accusing the "pan green camp" of standing in the way and trying to block efforts of others.
The KMT is planning to send a group of around 170 lawmakers, experts and business community representatives to attend the Beijing economic forum.

The agreement on holding the forum can be traced back to a five-point press communique signed in late April last year in Beijing by then-KMT Chairman Lien Chan and Chinese President Hu Jintao when Lien paid a landmark visit to China.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained ground against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Monday, increasing NT$0.077 to close at NT$32.405.
A total of US$990 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at the day's high of NT$32.430 and hit a low of NT$32.335.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES MOSTLY HIGHER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were mostly higher Monday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for April moved up 28 points to close at 6,779, with 48,184 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for May increased 24 points to finish at 6,772, with 1,628 contracts traded, while June futures decreased 20 points to end at 6,710, with 91 contract transactions. September futures increased 16 points to close at 6,550, with 63 contracts traded, while December futures moved up 42 points to finish at 6,561, with 12 contract transactions.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Monday at 6,751 for April, 6,748 for May, 6,730 for June, 6,534 for September and 6,519 for December.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were higher.

April TE futures increased 0.6 points to close at 301.8, with 6,303 contracts traded, while May TE futures gained 0.95 points to finish at 301, with 197 contract transactions. June TE futures moved up 0.65 points to end at 299, with five contracts traded, while September TE futures moved up 3.3 points to end at 296, with five contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for December.

April TF futures increased 3.8 points to finish at 895, with 2,071 contracts changing hands, while May TF futures gained seven points to close at 899, with 144 contracts traded. June TF futures moved up 4.6 points to end at 884, with four contract transactions, while September TF futures moved up 7.4 points to close at 882, with three contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for December.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI TO INCREASE HOURS OF CHINESE LANGUAGE LESSONS IN SCHOOLS

TEXT.P: The hours devoted to Chinese language lessons for first and second graders in Taipei City elementary schools will be increased from five or six hours per week to eight, the city's director of education said Monday.
Wu Ching-ji said the new regulation will be implemented from the 2006 academic year that will begin Sept. 1.

He made the announcement after Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou instructed the city education department to adjust the hours given over to Chinese and English language lessons, as well as to mother-tongue dialect lessons in schools.

Earlier, Wu reported to the mayor on his department's recent survey on the capital's Chinese language education. Citing official statistics, the report indicated that total hours of Chinese language lessons for sixth graders in elementary schools amounted to 80-133 hours per academic year, less than the level of 172 hours in China and 80-200 hours in Singapore.

The report suggested that efforts, including establishing a literature award for teenage writers, organizing Chinese cultural and artistic activities, increasing the number of hours of Chinese language lessons, and setting up Chinese proficiency indicators, be made to upgrade the city's Chinese language education.

Ma said that when he was a university student many years ago, he was already aware that Taiwanese students' linguistic ability in mandarin was weak and that the situation has become even worse in recent years with the increasing popularity of the Internet.

DOC.HEADLINE: EX-DEPUTY TRANSPORT MINISTER TESTIFIES AT KRTC SCANDAL HEARING

TEXT.P: Former Deputy Transport Minister Chen Shih-yih told a court Tuesday that the government procurement law should apply to six controversial sections of Kaohsiung's mass rapid transit system.

Chen's testimony at the court hearing on the applicability of the government procurement law on the issue could be damning to five members in the city government's "final decision group" who have been accused of breach of trust.

Chen said he had all along proposed that the construction of the city's rapid transit system should follow the government procurement law, a proposal he made at many screening meetings, including several at the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC).
He added that he did not know why his proposal was later rejected.

Chou Li-liang, former director of the city's Department of Rapid Transit System and one of the five accused, claimed that the Public Construction Commission of the Executive Yuan "has clearly stated that the government procurement law does not apply to the Kaohsiung rapid transit project."

If the court agrees with Chou, he and the other four -- former Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp. (KRTC) Vice Chairman Chen Min-hsien and General Manager Lai Hsien-yu, former Kaohsiung Urban Development Planning Bureau Director Wu Meng-te and former MOTC Chief Secretary-General Chung Shan-teng -- will be charged with breach of trust.
If the court decides to side with Chen, the five will be indicted on charges of "attempting to profit certain parties, " a charge that could bring heavier sentences for them.

Chen told the court that during the planning stage, the private sector needed invest just over NT$20 billion to control the whole build, operate, transfer (BOT) project worth more than NT$200 billion.
"The media at the time said this would give the private sector a chance to bet small money on a huge return," he said.
In response to a prosecutor's request, Chen explained that this means the private sector would be investing a small portion, with most of the money coming from the government.

The 42-km rapid transit system has ended up costing NT$181.6 billion to build, with the city government investing a whopping NT$150.8 billion or 83.2 percent, and yet allowing the KRTC, which was dominated by Chen Min-hsien, to control the use of the building funds.

Chen stands accused of breach of trust in connection with a corruption investigation into why Thai workers working on the KRTC project rioted in August last year and all five members in the "final decision" committee stand accused of attempting to profit certain contractors when awarding the NT$44.7 billion project because they failed to follow government regulations in choosing winning bidders.
The prosecution also charged them with disclosing bottom lines to certain bidders while excluding competitors, incurring heavy losses to the city government and to KRTC.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU URGES KMT TO SEEK CHINA'S COOPERATION IN EXTRADITING CRIMINALS

TEXT.P: The opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) legislative caucus urged the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Monday to seek Chinese cooperation in extraditing Taiwanese criminals who have fled to China to escape justice.

TSU legislators requested that Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Joseph Wu make a written request to former KMT Chairman Lien Chan, who is scheduled to make a trip to China April 13, to help extradite wanted Taiwanese criminals on the run in China.

The TSU caucus made the request when MAC officials briefed caucus members at the Legislative Yuan on the MAC's plan of action regarding a KMT-Communist Party of China forum scheduled for April 14-15 in Beijing.
Wu did not respond to the TSU request, but he urged Lien and the Chinese government to join Taiwan in fighting crime by sending Taiwanese criminals back to Taiwan.

TSU Legislator Lo Chih-ming said the most-wanted list includes individuals such as economic criminals Chang Chao-chuan, Wu Tzer-yuan, Liu Kuan-chun, Chu An-hsiung and Chen You-hao, all of whom are closely connected to the KMT.

Huang Shih-cho, another TSU legislator, suggested that Lien make a report to President Chen Shui-bian when he comes back from his China trip, as KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou did recently after returning from a visit to the United States.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOJ TO STUDY WHETHER TO INCREASE PUNISHMENTS FOR DRUG CRIMES

TEXT.P: Vice Justice Minister Lee Chin-yung said Monday that the ministry will study whether to increase the punishments for drug-related crimes.
Lee made the remarks while making a report at the Judicial Committee of the Legislative Yuan.
Legislators Wu Ping-jui and Kuo Jung-tzung of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party claimed that rampant drug abuse has been the major cause of deteriorating social order.

They noted that some of what they described as the "milder" forms of drugs, such as ketamine and FM2, are easily accessible and said the government should revise the law to step up regulations on such drugs.

According to Lee, such drugs, which he described as less likely to be addictive and the use of which he claimed carries no criminal responsibility, constitute a loophole in the law that should be closed as soon as possible.
The DPP legislators also asked the Ministry of Justice (MOJ) to study whether to increase the punishments for drug trafficking.
Meanwhile, PMMA, a new kind of ecstasy that is popular in Europe and the United States, has made inroads into Taiwan, a doctor at the Taipei Veterans General Hospital, reported Monday.

Dr. Yang Cheng-chang noted that recently a group of junior high school dropouts took part in a house party in Keelung, northern Taiwan, where two of them developed the symptoms of intoxication after consuming two PMMA tablets. One died on the spot and the other was rushed to hospital.
The 16-year-old boy was in coma when he arrived at the hospital, and he could not be resuscitated.

Yang said the toxicity of PMMA is several times stronger than the average ecstasy available in Taiwan and could easily lead to death. He urged the government to list PMMA at the same level as ecstasy so that it can be more strictly regulated.

DOC.HEADLINE: ADJUSTMENT OF PETROLEUM PRICES REQUIRES CABINET CONSENSUS: MOEA

TEXT.P: Any adjustments to petroleum prices will have to wait for a consensus within the Cabinet, Minister of Economic Affairs Hwang Ing-san said Monday.
Hwang made the remarks after newly named Chinese Petroleum Corp. Chairman Pan Wenent said domestic oil prices will have to follow a reasonable market mechanism.
Hwang said the Executive Yuan pronounced several principles early this year upon which domestic petroleum and electricity fees will be adjusted.
The principles include increasing the efficiency of state-owned enterprises, seeking new revenue and savings, and taking into consideration living conditions and economic development.
But Hwang said that if world oil prices soar to a high "beyond the expectation of the government, " the government will have no choice but to intervene.

Asked whether it is time to adjust petroleum prices amid reports that West Texas crude had reached US$68 a barrel, Hwang said only that whenever world oil prices fluctuate, domestic oil prices will have to be reviewed, which is what is happening now.

Pan earlier said that the CPC lost NT$13.8 billion (US$425.9 million) in the first quarter and that if the trend continues, the losses for the year could reach over NT$50 billion, or 40 percent of the CPC's paid-in capital.
"The company will collapse with those kinds of losses, " Pan warned.

He noted that the CPC is a state-owned enterprise whose losses will be shouldered by the public. The current oil price mechanism means that "the underprivileged subsidize the stronger groups, " or those who use smaller vehicles subsidize owners of bigger cars, which he said is not in the best interests of the nation.

"Using subsidized oil prices to achieve international competitiveness is fake competitiveness, " Pan said, adding his hope that oil prices can be adjusted in line with a "reasonable market mechanism."

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Democracy in the Arab World, a U.S. Goal, Falters
Steps toward democracy in the Arab world, a crucial American goal that just months ago was cause for optimism -- with elections held in Ira q, Egypt and the Palestinian areas -- are slowin g, blocked by legal maneuvers and official chang es of heart throughout the Middle East.
Wall Street Journal: Blonde Ambitions, A Battle Erupts Over the Right To Market Marilyn More than 40 years after her death, Marilyn Monroe's photos are used to hawk everything from T-shirts and posters to coffee mugs and key chains. Now, the late actress is at the center of a bitter legal dispute over who controls the rights to her profitable image.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP LAWMAKERS SKETCH OUT REFORM PLAN FOR CLEAN GOVERNMENT

TEXT.P: A work group preparing to hold a special conference of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) worked out a reform plan Monday calling for a "clean government" amid a series of corruption scandals implicating high government officials.

The work group, consisting of eight DPP legislators, proposed 10 days ago that DPP members meet to discuss various issues facing the party after a DPP legislator expressed his disillusionment with the DPP government and quit the party.

After the work group held its third meeting Monday, Tsai Chi-chang, one of the eight DPP legislators, told reporters the meeting adopted a sketch plan for clean government, including asking the Presidential Office to conduct a review of its staff and affairs that have become a source of controversy.
The plan will also ask the Presidential Office to respond to public concerns about the corruption scandals in a concrete manner.
According to Tsai, the reform plan suggests the DPP's legislative caucus establish a disciplinary committee with the power to investigate irregularities in the executive branch of government.

In addition, the DPP's legislative caucus should have the right to participate in the formulation of important government policies, and be consulted in advance when the government appoints a top executive to head a state-owned enterprise.
Tsai said the reform plan will be presented to the DPP's legislative caucus for approval before being included in the planned conference's agenda.

Although President Chen Shui-bian and other DPP heavyweights have thrown their support behind the conference, DPP legislative caucus whips Chen Chin-jun and Yeh Yi-chin expressed doubt about the event's usefulness because resolutions reached at the meeting will not be binding to either the party or the government.
They proposed the DPP hold an extraordinary national convention instead, so that reform plans from such a meeting could be realized.
In addition to Tsai, the DPP lawmakers who initiated the move to hold the special conference are Shen Fa-hui, Chen Chi-yu, Huang Wei-cher, Pan Meng-an, Cheng Yun-peng, Hsieh Hsin-ni and Yu Cheng-tao.

The call of the DPP "young turks" for party and government reforms came at a time when the president and the DPP's approval ratings slipped to a record low of 18 percent after a series of corruption scandals involving high-ranking government officials were brought to light, including accusations of insider trading, profiteering from the Kaohsiung rapid transit project and bribery in the bidding process for the electronic toll collection system on Taiwan's freeways.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHILDREN'S FOUNDATION TO HONOR TAICHUNG TEACHER

TEXT.P: Wang Ching-hsien, a high school teacher in Taichung, central Taiwan, will be cited April 16 by the Taiwan Fund for Children and Families for long-term financial assistance he provided to several disadvantaged children in Taiwan.
Wang said, "It is not difficult to help poor children. One just needs to have the intention, save some money every month and keep on doing it."
And when he sees a child grow up that he has helped, the sense of achievement encourages him to continue helping other children, he added.
Wang has assisted five children during the past 20 years while he was a teacher at I-Ning High School, a spokesman for the Taiwan Fund for Children and Families said.
The citation ceremony will be held in the northern Taiwan city of Hsinchu.

DOC.HEADLINE: UNFEASIBLE TO STOP COLLECTING TOLLS ON NO. 1 FREEWAY: MOTC

TEXT.P: Minister of Transportation and Communication Kuo Yao-chi said Monday that it is unfeasible to stop collecting tolls on the Sun Yat-sen Freeway (No. 1 Freeway) because the highway construction fund and the Highway Act states that parallel routes should adopt the same toll system.

If tolls are not collected on the No. 1 Freeway, then toll collection on the No. 3 Freeway would also have to stop, otherwise drivers would forsake the No. 3 and swarm the No. 1, Kuo said in reply to lawmakers' questions at the Legislative Yuan.

The government's freeway construction fund is now running a NT$190 billion (US$5.94 billion) deficit, and by 2015, another NT$241.1 billion (US$7.53 billion) will be needed to build more freeways, said Kuo.
The fund will not break even until 2037, when freeway tolls can finally be abolished, she said.

According to Tsao Erh-chung, a legislator of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT), the government originally planned to collect tolls for only 20 years on the No. 1 Freeway starting in 1974, but 32 years on, drivers still have to pay to use it, giving the government NT$75 billion (US$2.34 billion) in excess of its toll collection target. He urged the government to either stop collecting tolls or cut the tolls by half.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAICHUNG CITY TO ENFORCE 'CLEAN UP AFTER YOUR DOG' LAW
DOC.DATELINE: Taichung, central Taiwan, April 10 (CNA) (By Han Nai-kuo)

TEXT.P: The Taichung City Government announced Monday that beginning May 1, dog owners who allow their dogs to foul public places will be punished by a fine between NT$2,000 and NT$8,000.

Li Li-teh, head of the city government's Bureau of Environmental Protection, said patrol teams formed by officers from local police stations, the Construction Bureau and the Bureau of Environmental Protection will strictly enforce the environmental sanitation regulations enacted by the city council in 2004.

Li said that in the past two years, law enforcement officers have issued about 700 warnings to dog owners who failed to dispose of feces left by their dogs, and that only three serious offenses have been punished by a fine.

From May 1, these officers will mean business and enforce the relevant regulations strictly, he said, suggesting that when walking the dog, pet owners should carry a poop scoop and a small plastic bag to clean up after their dogs and safely dispose of the waste.

DOC.HEADLINE: FIRST LADY DID NOT ACCEPT GIFT COUPONS: PRESIDENTIAL OFFICE

TEXT.P: First lady Wu Shu-jen did not accept any gift coupons from a department store, so how could there be so-called serial numbers on the coupons, asked Tan Sun Chen, secretary-general to President Chen Shui-bian, Tuesday, in response to a lawmaker's allegation.

The president's senior aide was incensed by opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Legislator Lee Chuan-chiao's allegation that the first lady had accepted NT$8.8 million in gift certificates and used hundreds of thousands of NT dollars of these "special coupons" which were different from those issued by Pacific Sogo Department Store.
He challenged the lawmaker to produce evidence that would prove his allegation was not a lie. Otherwise, he said, "the lying lawmaker should step down."

In response to Lee's call on the first lady to make public the serial numbers on her coupons, the secretary-general said this was simply impossible since Wu did not take any gift coupons in the first place. Lee was just trying to make a fool of the public, he said.
Tan Sun Chen expressed hope the media would be bold enough to challenge lawmakers who make allegations to provide evidence, asking them "based on what are you making these allegations?"
The government is willing to take criticism, but the media should not shift responsibility for "proving things" to the government whenever it is alleged to have made a mistake, he added.
He claimed President Chen was "absolutely not afraid" of having his policies challenged by the people. However, he added, most criticism of the government is seldom based on fact.

He said he was concerned that Taiwan's society will become ever more chaotic if lawmakers continue taking advantage of immunity privileges to make unfounded allegations -- without ever having to bear the consequences.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO E2-K EARLY WARNING AIRCRAFT TO BE COMMISSIONED

TEXT.P: Two U.S.-built E2-K early warning and control aircraft will be commissioned into service Saturday to further beef up Taiwan's air combat capabilities, Air Force sources said Monday.
President Chen Shui-bian is likely to review the E2-K early warning aircraft commissioning ceremony at an Air Force base in Pingtung, southern Taiwan, the sources said.
Taiwan struck the E2-K procurement deal with the United States last year. The Air Force has completed personnel training and relevant preparations for the two warplanes' delivery, the sources said.
The Air Force's Thunder Tiger Aerobatics Team will perform a stunning flight show at the E2-K commissioning ceremony to celebrate the expansion of the country's warplane fleet, the sources said.

Saturday's show will be the first of its kind after a six-year hiatus. The team suspended all aerial shows six years ago after then Defense Minister Tang Yiau-ming enjoined military personnel to focus on combat preparedness.
Meanwhile, the sources said, the Pingtung air base will open its barracks Sunday for the public to view the new E2-K aircraft.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO ROOM FOR 'RESPECTIVE EXPLANATIONS' OF 'ONE CHINA': MAC

TEXT.P: The main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Honorary Chairman Lien Chan's refusal to relay the government's hope for Beijing's acknowledgement of "respective explanations" of the "one China" definition reflects the fact there is no room for such a statement, a government official said Monday.

Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Joseph Wu made the remarks during a meeting with the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union's (TSU) legislative caucus to discuss the government's response to an economic forum between the KMT and the Communist Party of China (CPC) in Beijing over the coming weekend.
"A lot of Taiwanese would applaud Lien if he were willing to speak out loudly for the Republic of China on the soil of the People's Republic of China," Wu said.
But Lien's rejection to do so is tantamount to a tacit consent that there is no room for "respective explanations" of "one China" in terms of Taiwan's relations with Beijing, he pointed out.

Since Beijing's enactment of the "Anti-Secession" Law in March last year, the Chinese communist regime has been seeking to contend with Taiwan over the law and the two press communiques that it signed later that year with leaders of the KMT and the People First Party, Wu said, stressing that "the MAC just cannot turn a blind eye to Beijing's vigorous practice of its 'one China' principle."
TSU Secretary-General Lo Chih-ming urged the KMT in a TSU advisory meeting not to "sell its soul" by aligning and conspiring with Taiwan's enemy.
"The KMT must not ignore the interests of Taiwan's 23 million people for the sake of private gain for the few," Lo urged.

Lo asked KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou to discipline KMT lawmakers not to go overboard by taking part in the Beijing forum, and also lashed out at the ruling Democratic Progressive Party for having failed to condemn the event.

Lien will lead a group of more than 170 KMT lawmakers, experts and business community representatives to attend the forum in Beijing -- the first between the KMT and the CPC in nearly 60 years, after Taiwan and China split in 1949 amid a civil war.
The KMT and the CPC are slated to discuss cross-Taiwan Strait cooperation on direct transport links, tourism, agriculture and financial exchanges.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET: NO COMMENT ON FUZHOU'S NEW ECONOMIC POLICIES TOWARD TAIWAN

TEXT.P: A Cabinet spokesman declined to comment Monday on new economic measures by Fuzhou, Fujian province, toward Taiwan after they were announced by the Chinese city's deputy mayor.

Cheng Wen-tsang, head of the Government Information Office, noted that one measure adopted by Fuzhou to enhance its economic and trade cooperation with Taiwan is to allow more of Taiwan's agricultural products to enjoy tariff-free treatment starting May this year.
Cheng said it was unlikely that China would let the deputy mayor of a second-tier city determine tariff matters on behalf of the central government.
He added that the Executive Yuan would not comment on Fuzhou's new economic policies toward Taiwan at this stage, but will keep an eye on developments.

Fuzhou's Deputy Mayor Liang Jianyong announced in Hong Kong that Fuzhou will increase the number of categories of Taiwan farm produce that enjoy tariff-free treatment, allow Taiwanese people to set up businesses in Fuzhou, encourage Chinese outside Fujian province to tour Taiwan's two outlying islands of Kinmen and Matsu, and expand the area of an agricultural experimentation program with Taiwan to cover the whole of Fujian province.
(By Han Nai-kuo) ENDIREM/diG

DOC.HEADLINE: DDP LAWMAKERS SAY KMT LAWMAKERS MAKING UNFOUNDED ALLEGATIONS

TEXT.P: Several legislators of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and high-ranking officials of the Presidential Office accused Kuomintang (KMT) legislators Chiu Yi and Lee Chuan-chiao Monday of making unfounded allegations.
Chiu alleged that Presidential Office Deputy Secretary-General Ma Yung-cheng was involved in the March 19, 2004 shooting incident of the president and a financial scandal.

DPP legislator Chen Chin-jun told media that Ma said he would resign from the post if he was found to be acquainted with "Doctor Yang" or had any relationship with the Fu-Ton group. On the other hand, if Chiu cannot prove his allegations, he should step down within three days, Chen quoted Ma as challenging Chiu.
"Ma has been considering what to do next, including filing a lawsuit against KMT legislator Chiu," Lee Nan-yang, the Presidential Office spokesman said.
Presidential Office Secretary-General Tan Sun Chen also noted that Ma had denied all allegations made against him. Chen said the unfounded allegations had already made a negative impact on society.

DPP Legislator Chen said the Presidential Office was under fire these days from opposition KMT Legislators Chiu and Lee Chuan-chiao, and that it was something that should be taken seriously. Lee also alleged that first lady Wu Shu-jen had accepted gift coupons from a department store.
On media speculation that the first lady was involved in a SOGO gift coupon scandal, DDP Legislator Yeh Yi-jin said that the KMT lawmaker's rumor-mongering was to blame for this situation.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT-CPC FORUM AIMED AT DEBASING DPP GOVERNMENT: MAC

TEXT.P: An economic forum soon to be held between Taiwan's main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and the Communist Party of China (CPC) is one of Beijing's strategies to sow seeds of discord in Taiwan and to debase the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) government, a China policy planner said Monday.

Mainland Affairs Council Chairman Joseph Wu made the remarks while meeting with a visiting delegation of American academics specializing in cross-Taiwan Strait affairs. The delegation was headed by Nat Bellocchi, a former chairman of the American Institute in Taiwan, which handles Taiwan-U.S. relations in the absence of formal diplomatic ties.

Wu told his guests that he deeply regretted the KMT's refusal to heed his call for KMT honorary Chairman Lien Chan to refrain from holding any closed-door meetings with Chinese President Hu Jintao -- who concurrently serves as the CPC general secretary -- during Lien's upcoming Beijing visit.
Lien, a former vice president, will head a large crowd of KMT lawmakers, scholars and business executives to attend the first-ever KMT-CPC economic forum slated for April 14-15 in Beijing.

During Lien's previous visit to Beijing, he held a closed-door meeting with Hu. Similar Lien-Hu talks are expected to take place again during Lien's forthcoming visit. Despite the MAC's call for having such a meeting proceed in public or broadcast live, KMT authorities ruled out such a possibility.
Wu said a closed-door meeting between an opposition bigwig like Lien and the top leader of Taiwan's rival would set a bad example that could be detrimental to Taiwan's young democracy.
Visiting American academics shared Wu's view, saying that most democratic countries would not tolerate such an action, which they said may incite internal division and chaos.

Wu said China has spared no effort to suppress Taiwan's international presence, even when it involves non-governmental international organizations. Regrettably, Wu said, the United States has often failed to warn China that such actions have hindered the development of cross-strait relations. As a result, he said, Taiwan's anxiety over diplomatic isolation is growing ever stronger.
Stressing that Taiwan is now a democracy, Wu said the United States should generously support Taiwan's efforts to preserve its liberal democratic lifestyle and political system.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC CHIEF DENIES EXISTENCE OF '1992 CONSENSUS'

TEXT.P: Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Joseph Wu told visiting European Parliament members Monday that the so-called "1992 Consensus" advocated by Taiwan's main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) has never existed.

Wu was referring to the KMT's claim that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait reached a "one China, respective interpretations" consensus during a meeting in Hong Kong in 1992 when the KMT was in power.

While meeting with a delegation of a pro-Taiwan caucus in the European Parliament, headed by Jose Pomes Ruiz, Wu said China has never accepted the so-called "1992 Consensus" or "one China with each side of the Strait having its own interpretations."
Wu added that China only recognizes the "one China" principle, but completely denies "one China" could mean the Republic of China as the KMT perceives it.

Wu also urged honorary KMT Chairman Lien Chan to publicly mention the term the "Republic of China" (ROC) during his upcoming China visit because Lien failed to do so while he visited China last spring.

DOC.HEADLINE: MARSHALL ISLANDS PRESIDENT ARRIVES FOR STATE VISIT

TEXT.P: Marshall Islands President Kessai Note arrived in Taipei Monday for a six-day state visit.

President Chen Shui-bian greeted Note at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport, Taiwan's main gateway. It marked the first time that Chen has traveled to the airport to greet an arriving foreign dignitary.

Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs Michael Ying-mao Kau said President Chen will preside over a formal welcoming ceremony complete with full military honors, including a 21-gun salute, in honor of Note Tuesday at the plaza in front of the Presidential Office.
During his stay, Note will hold talks with Chen on a range of issues of mutual concern, including measures to further boost bilateral cooperation and the Asia-Pacific regional situation.

Note will also witness the signing of a bilateral agreement on the exchange of information on money-laundering activities. Note and his entourage will pay a visit to Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan, where they are scheduled to tour several facilities to study Taiwan's industrial achievements in the fields of ocean fisheries, aquaculture and solar energy.
Note is scheduled to depart Taiwan April 15. This will be Note's fourth visit to Taiwan since May 2002.

Taiwan and the Marshall Islands forged diplomatic ties Nov. 20, 1998. Since Note took office six years ago, he has on many occasions publicly expressed support of Taiwan's role in the international community.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPANESE PEOPLE MAKE 1.12 VISITS TO TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Japanese people made 1.12 million visits to Taiwan in 2005, marking a 26.7 percent year-on-year increase, according to statistics released Monday by a quasi-official Japanese tourism promoting organization.
It marked the first time that Japanese visitors to Taiwan has breaken the one-million mark. Taiwan was the fourth most popular overseas travel destination for Japanese citizens.
According to Japanese tallies, Taiwan citizens made 1.27 million visits to Japan in the same year for an 18 percent year-on-year growth, making Taiwan the second largest tourist source for Japan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, April 11, or the 14th day of the March of the Year of the Dog according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1713: France cedes Newfoundland and Gibraltar to Britain.
1775: James Parkinson, the British physician who defined Parkinson's disease, a progressive disease of the nervous system also called paralysis agitans or shaking palsy, is born.
1814: Louis XVIII accedes to the throne as Napoleon Bonaparte abdicates and is banished to the island of Elba under the Treaty of Fontainebleau.
1893: Dean Acheson, the U.S. politician and secretary of state who helped to formulate the Truman Doctrine and the Marshall Plan and who promoted the setting up of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), is born.
1899: Spain transfers control of the Philippines to the United States.
1919: The International Labor Organization is founded in Geneva in affiliation with the League of Nations to improve living standards and working conditions.
1926: American horticulturist Luther Burbank dies at the age of 77. He developed countless new varieties of fruits, vegetables and flowers, including the Burbank potato and the Shasta daisy.
1935: Dust storms wreak havoc in the so-called "Dust Bowl" states of Kansas, Colorado, Wyoming, Oklahoma, Texas and New Mexico in the United States.
1945: U.S. forces capture the German towns of Essen and Weimar and liberate the Buchenwald concentration camp near the end of World War II.
1950: The Bank of Taiwan issues its first lottery.
1950: China lodges a complaint with the United Nations against Soviet aid to the Chinese communists, the Soviet invasion of China and Soviet violation of the U.N. Charter.
1951: U.S. President Harry Truman relieves Gen. Douglas MacArthur, the World War II hero who accepted the Japanese surrender in Tokyo Bay in 1945, of all his command, including that of U.N. forces in Korea.
1957: Singapore is granted self-government by the United Kingdom.
1969: Taiwan's Executive Yuan approves the "Guidelines for the Population Policy of the Republic of China."
1970: The government of Prime Minister Lon Nol announces abolishment of the monarchy and proclaims Cambodia a republic.
1974: U.S. Secretary of Agriculture Earl L. Butz, leading a party of 19, arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1974: The ROC Executive Yuan approves the Sino-Honduran Fishery Technical Cooperation Agreement.
1976: An ROC education mission headed by Education Minister Y.S. Tsiang leaves for the Middle East on a visit.
1976: Col. Carlos Humberto Romero, secretary of defense and pacific security of El Salvador, arrives in Taipei for a six-day visit.
1978: The Taiwan Province Black Foot Disease Control Center is inaugurated in Peimen Village, Tainan County.
1979: A combined force of Ugandan exiles and Tanzanian troops captures the Ugandan capital of Kampala, ending the eight-year rule of Idi Amin.
1981: Chen Ta, a noted singer of Taiwanese folk songs, dies at the age of 76.
1994: U.S. President Bill Clinton orders trade sanctions against Taiwan in accordance with the Pelly Act.
1995: Chen Yun, one of Communist China's leading veteran hardliners and one of its leading economic planners, dies in Beijing at the age of 90.
1997: Turin Cathedral is engulfed by flames, but firefighters manage to save the famous Turin Shroud.
2000: Foreign ministers of the 113-member Non-Aligned Movement endorse the Philippine-led regional code of conduct in the South China Sea to promote peace and stability in the region.
2001: The Executive Yuan signs an agreement with the Netherlands Trade and Investment Office (NTIO) in Taipei to enact regulations to prevent double taxation on Dutch people working in Taiwan as well as those from Taiwan in the Netherlands.
2002: The European Parliament passes a pro-Taiwan resolution urging mainland China to dismantle missile deployment against Taiwan.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A moral character always has courage; but a man of courage is not necessarily a moral character."

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATURE NIXES NOMINEE FOR TOP PROSECUTORIAL POST

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan rejected President Chen Shui-bian's nominee for the country's top prosecutorial post in a vote Tuesday.

A total of 101 lawmakers voted in support of the appointment of Hsieh Wen-ting, the Taiwan High Court prosecutor-general, to be the next state public prosecutor-general, while 19 voted against the nomination. There were a total of 88 invalid votes.
As Hsieh failed to receive the endorsement of half of the legislators present, Legislative Speaker Wang Jin-pyng announced that the nomination was rejected.

Despite the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) strong urging to approve the appointment of Hsieh, the legislative caucus of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) decided Monday that the KMT would not endorse the nomination. The legislative caucus of the People First Party, an ally of the KMT, decided in a meeting prior to the voting that it also would not support Hsieh's nomination.

KMT legislative caucus whip Pan Wei-kang said Monday that the KMT feels that Hsieh would not live up to Taiwan society's expectations, particularly in the wake of a spate of incidents, including the 319 shooting of President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu, the KRTC Thai workers riot and alleged corruption in the high-speed railway development project.

Pan claimed that the KMT caucus has no doubts about Hsieh's integrity but that the party is worried that his weak personality might mean he would flinch from probing corruption charges involving high-ranking officials.

In the past, the president had full power to appoint a state public prosecutor-general. However, under the newly revised Court Organic Law, the president's nomination requires the legislature's consent. According to the law, an appointment must be approved by half of the legislators present at a session, with at least one-third of the lawmakers in the 221-seat legislature being in attendance for the vote.

Under the new law, the state public prosecutor-general will serve only a single four-year term. The new measures are designed to enhance the democratic legitimacy and independence of the prosecutorial system.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.N. ADOPTED USE OF SIMPLIFIED CHINESE CHARACTERS IN 1971: MOFA

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Ministry of Foreign Affairs clarified Tuesday that the United Nations actually adopted the use of simplified Chinese characters in all respects in 1971.
The MOFA made the clarification in response to media reports that the U.N. was planning to do so in 2008.

Some media agencies reported recently that Chen Zhangtai, chief of China's academy of practical linguistics, said the U.N. would use only simplified characters in all the world body's documents from 2008. Simplified Chinese characters are used in China and Singapore, while traditional characters are used in Taiwan, Hong Kong, Macau and Malaysia.

"The U.N. adopted the use of simplified characters in 1971 when the People's Republic of China became a member. There has been no period of time when traditional characters and simplified characters have been used together in the U.N.," MOFA spokesman Michel Lu said.
He made the comments after receiving verification from Taiwan's representative office in New York.

Lu explained that when China became a U.N. member in 1971, Beijing demanded that the U.N. adopt the use of simplified characters, but all the world body's documents produced before 1971 were not affected.

DOC.HEADLINE: THUNDER TIGER AEROBATICS TEAM TO STAGE AIR SHOW

TEXT.P: The Air Force's Thunder Tiger Aerobatics Team will perform stunning air shows this weekend in celebration of the commissioning of two E2-K early warning and control aircraft, an opposition lawmaker said Tuesday.

Kuomintang Legislator Lin Yu-fang said the Thunder Tiger Aerobatics Team had originally planned to stage an air show at the E2-K aircraft commissioning ceremony to be held at the Pingtung air base in southern Taiwan Saturday.
While the air base will open its barracks Sunday for the public to view a static display of the two new U.S.-built aircraft, there will not be any air show on that day.

The decision drew complaints from local aircraft and air show fans because the commissioning ceremony would not be open to regular citizens, Lin said, adding that he then relayed the public complaints to Air Force authorities.

In response, Lin said, the Air Force command center has decided to have the Thunder Tiger Aerobatics Team stage an additional air show at 10 a.m. Sunday to coincide with the opening of the Pingtung air base barracks to the public.

Lin praised the Air Force command center for its quick response to public opinion. He also expressed the hope that the Thunder Tiger team can stage air shows once or twice every year to demonstrate its superb flight skills and win local people's recognition and support for the military. Lin suggested that the team present at least one dazzling air show around Aug. 14 Air Force Day every year.

Saturday's show will be the first of its kind after a six-year hiatus. The Thunder Tiger team suspended all air shows six years ago after then Defense Minister Tang Yiau-ming ordered military personnel to focus on combat preparedness.

Taiwan struck the E2-K procurement deal with the United States last year. The Air Force has completed personnel training and relevant preparations for the two warplanes' delivery, military officials said Monday.

The commissioning of the two E2-Ks is expected to further beef up Taiwan's air combat capabilities, the officials said, adding that President Chen Shui-bian is likely to travel to the Pingtung air base to review the commissioning ceremony.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI STUDIES CONFERENCE TO BE HELD IN EARLY MAY

TEXT.P: The 2nd International Conference on Taipei Studies is scheduled to be held May 6-7 at the National Central Library, featuring a series of seminars and a special "night sailing" boat tour on the Tamshui River to Taipei's historical spots.

"Taipei and globalization" will be the theme of the conference to be co-hosted by the governmental Taipei City Archives and the Society of Overseas Chinese Studies. Scholars in history, arts and culture have been invited to host seminars on topics featuring Taipei City's early-stage development, including trade and navigation; industrial development and daily life; emigrants and religious worship; emigrants and multi-ethnic society; as well as the ocean and cultural character.

In addition to the conference, a "history-exploration" boat trip is scheduled for the evening of May 7, beginning at Tataocheng, a historical site that played an important role in the urbanization of Taipei.

According to the organizers, the exporting of tea from Tataocheng is regarded as the first "globalized activity" in the modern history of Taipei City, with the activity helping establish a key foundation for the then agricultural town to transform into the island's economic and political center.

The planned two-hour boat trip will take participants on a tour to several of Taipei's historical spots, featuring the cultural characters of indigenous people, early settlers from southern China, early Han immigrants and foreign traders, according to the organizers.
The boat tour is open to the general public, with tickets priced at NT$400 (US$12) . The conference is also open to the pubic and is free of charge.
