DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA REFUTES REPORT ON DOMINICAN REPUBLIC SWITCHING TIES TO CHINA

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) refuted Tuesday a media report that the Dominican Republic, which has official diplomatic relations with Taiwan, is considering switching ties to China.

The Associated Press reported last week that Dominican Republic Foreign Minister Carlos Morales Troncoso said in a TV interview April 6 that his country would see whether China or Taiwan is better for it.

"Morales only said that whether the Dominican Republic will pursue relations with China depends on whether it suits the country's national interests.... What the media has reported is not true, " said Ko Jai-son, director of the MOFA's Department of Central and South American Affairs.
Ko pointed out that Morales said in the TV interview that the Dominican Republic will fortify ties with countries in Asia, mainly India, and that it wants to attract Indian business investment.
Ko reiterated that Dominican Republic President Leonel Fernandez said in public Jan. 13 this year that his country and Taiwan will maintain a friendly relationship and the stance will not change.

In related news, Ko revealed that President Chen Shui-bian will visit Costa Rica for President-elect Oscar Arias Sanchez's inauguration ceremony May 8, but he will not visit Haiti during the oversea trip to Central and South America. Ko said Chen will instead send an envoy to attend new Haitian President Rene Preval's inauguration ceremony May 14.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN UNIVERSITY STUDENTS TO TAKE PART IN MODEL U.N. CONFERENCE
DOC.DATELINE: New York, April 10 (CNA) (By Eric Tseng and Taijing Wu)

TEXT.P: Twelve Taiwanese university students arrived in New York Sunday to attend the annual National Model United Nations Conference slated for April 11-15 at the Mariott Marquis Times Square Hotel.

A spokeswoman for the Taipei-based King Car Education Foundation which is sponsoring the program said Monday that most of the 12 students are visiting New York for the first time and that they will have the chance to understand how the United Nations functions.

The 12 students, all female, were selected from among 120 applicants from various universities. Upon their selection, these students were requested to give English lessons at schools in remote areas of Taiwan in order to learn the meaning of serving other people, the spokeswoman said.
Kao Hui-hsuan, a student in civil engineering, said this event is giving her the opportunity to learn something about diplomacy and the difficult diplomatic situation Taiwan is in.
Liao Pei-chi, a student who majors in international relations, said that she will take the opportunity to learn how the international community perceives Taiwan's situation.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI SHARE PRICES END LOWER

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened low and closed lower Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 23.47 points to close at 6,757.17.
The bourse opened at 6,772.96 and fluctuated between 6,775.65 and 6,723.23 during trading. A total of 3.11 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$86.09 billion (US$2.65 billion).

Four of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with construction issues moving up the most at 0.8 percent, followed by paper and pulp issues and textile stocks both at 0.7 percent, and cement stocks at 0.2 percent.

Three of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with banking and financial shares moving down the most at 0.6 percent, followed by machinery and electronics shares at 0.5 percent, and foodstuff issues at 0.2 percent.
Plastics and chemicals shares remained unchanged.
Losers outnumbered gainers 483 to 421, with 124 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Parliament may be split.
Preliminary results of the April 9-10 general elections show that the parliament may be split with the ruling center-right coalition led by Premier Silvio Berlusconi controls the Senate and the opposition center-left Union led by former European Commission chief Romano Prodi has the majority in the House of Deputies. for the first day of general elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower Tuesday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index futures for April lost 24 points to close at 6,755, with 33,134 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for May dropped 24 points to finish at 6,748, with 1,448 contract transactions, while June futures moved down 37 points to close at 6,707, with 26 contracts traded.
September futures lost 10 points to finish at 6,540, with 17 contracts traded, while December futures moved down 51 points to close at 6,510, with six contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Tuesday at 6,779 for April, 6,772 for May, 6,744 for June, 6,550 for September, and 6,561 for December.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also lower.
April TE futures moved down 1.3 points to close at 300.50, with 3,727 contract transactions, while May TE futures lost one point to finish at 300, with 163 contracts traded.
September TE futures dropped 3.60 points to finish at 290, with one contract traded, while December TE futures moved down 4.30 points to close at 291.1, with one contract traded.
No transactions were recorded for June.
April TF futures moved down 6.8 points to close at 888.2, with 1,185 contract transactions, while May TF lost 10.8 points to finish at 888.2, with 58 contracts traded.
June TF futures gained one point to close at 885, with five contracts traded, while September TF futures lost one point to finish at 872.6, with two contracts traded.
December TF futures moved down 10.8 points to close at 867.4, with only one contract traded.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHIAYI RESIDENTS VOW TO FIND STOLEN TOURISM COW

TEXT.P: The Community Planners of Chiayi County, a community organization, said Tuesday that it is kicking off a campaign to find a stolen cow that was used for tourism and education purposes.
The Community Planners are also encouraging people to chip in money to buy another cow if the stolen cow is not recovered, a spokesman said.
Yu Hsin-you's cow was stolen on a rainy evening last month. Besides stealing Yu's cow, the thief is also suspected of poisoning Yu's neighbor's dog.

Yu, a retired farmer in his 70s, owned the cow for six years. The animal was used to pull an oxcart used in local primary schools' outdoor teaching activities to show children and tourists the life of a farmer.
In order to satisfy the needs of local tourism, Yu has been pulling the oxcart himself in the absence of his cow.
The spokesman said a cow costs approximately NT$60,000 (US$1,875) , and donors' names will be put on the oxcart and tourism brochures as well as on the county's Web sites.
"We are not only trying to find a cow, but also hope for our community," the spokesman said.

DOC.HEADLINE: SIX ACCUSED IN KRTC THAI WORKERS CASE TO BE SENTENCED IN MAY

TEXT.P: The Kaohsiung District Court has set May 3 for a trial of six defendants suspected of involvement in a scandal revolving around the Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp.'s (KRTC) importation of Thai workers.
Prominent defendants include Chen Che-nan, former deputy secretary general to President Chen Shui-bian, and Chen Min-hsien, former vice chairman of KRTC.
Chen Che-nan, now under detention in Taipei on charges of fraud in another scandal, was charged in this case with taking NT$94,700 (US$2,900) in illicit profits from a private contractor.

The prosecution said Chen Che-nan and his bodyguard were treated to two pleasure trips to Thailand and South Korea, as a result of which Huapan Administration Consultant Co. obtained an exclusive contract to manage Thai laborers working on the KRTC project.
However, Chen Che-nan had claimed that Huapan's owner Yen Shih-hua and his wife Wang Tsai-pi merely pre-paid plane tickets for him, payments which he said he later returned to them.

Chen Min-hsien stands accused of breach of trust in connection with a corruption investigation into why the Thai workers rioted last August, an incident leading to a spate of corruption and law-breaking charges.
In addition to the two Chens and the Yen couple, other defendants in the case were former KRTC General Manager Lai Hsien-yu and his special assistant Liu Ke-chiang.
All of the accused except Chen Che-nan were present at Tuesday's court session during which the procedures for the May 3 trial were arranged.

DOC.HEADLINE: ANY CROSS-STRAIT TIES POSSIBLE IF CHINA GIVES UP ONE-PARTY RULE: CHEN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Tuesday that if China renounces its one-party rule and totalitarianism, there is no ruling out of the possibility of developing any forms of cross-strait relations.
President Chen made the remarks when receiving a pro-Taiwan delegation from the European Parliament at the Presidential Office.

Chen said he is adamantly opposed to the totalitarianism in China, adding that the Chinese people have no democracy and no freedom of speech, press or religion under Beijing's premise that power comes from the barrel of a gun and stability overrides all other considerations.
"Beijing's trampling of human rights is well known, and its squeezing of the media and access to the Internet is also unacceptable," the president said.
He reiterated that if China renounces its one-party rule and totalitarianism, there is no ruling out the developing of any forms of cross-strait relations with the consent of the Taiwan people.

The president also took the chance to express his appreciation to the European Parliament, noting that it has passed several major resolutions in recent years to oppose a lifting of the E.U.'s ban on arms sales to China, which was imposed shortly after the Tiananmen Square massacre in 1989.
Chen said he hopes that the European Union will not lift its arms embargo before the human rights situation improves in China.

He also thanked the European Parliament, noting that it has expressed the hope that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait can peacefully resolve their differences and disputes through dialogue and that the free will of the 23 million people on Taiwan will be respected.
The European Parliament also urged China several times to remove the missiles and military equipment targeting Taiwan, Chen continued.

The president asked the delegation members to exert their influence in the European Parliament to sway the European Union nations so that Taiwan can be successful in its bid to become an observer at the World Health Assembly, the decision-making body of the World Health Organization, when it convenes its annual conference May 25.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH CALLS FOR SUSPENSION OF RENU LENS-CARE PRODUCT IMPORTS

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) has asked for a suspension of imports of ReNu multi-purpose contact lens solution produced by U.S.-headquartered Bausch & Lomb, a DOH official said Tuesday.

Sales of the ReNu MoisturLoc solution have been suspended in Hong Kong, Singapore and the United States following reports over the past several months suggesting that the product might be linked with an unusually high incidence of fungal infection-caused keratitis among contact lens wearers.
Deputy DOH Director-General of Pharmaceutical Affairs Liu Li-ling said that although approval has been granted for sale of the product in Taiwan, it has not yet been imported.

Out of health concerns, the DOH will not consider opening the doors for the import of ReNu MoisturLoc solution until the U.S. Food and Drug Administration releases the results of its investigation into the safety of using the contact lens care product, Liu said.

The culprit fungus, called fusarium, is commonly found in plant material and soil in tropical and subtropical areas. Without eye drop treatment, the infection can scar the cornea and blind its victims.

DOC.HEADLINE: PROSECUTORIAL NOMINEE RESPECTS LEGISLATURE'S DECISION

TEXT.P: Hsieh Wen-ting, the nominee for the post of state public prosecutor-general, said Tuesday that he respects the Legislative Yuan's decision after his nomination was rejected.

Hsieh, who currently serves as prosecutor-general of the Taiwan High Court, reiterated that the judiciary must be kept beyond the reach of political influence and must never yield to political pressure.
If the leaders of the judicial system cannot stay neutral while enforcing the law, it will be impossible for prosecutors to maintain their credibility, Hsieh said.

Hsieh said he has always stuck to this belief and will not compromise it for the sake of any position, adding that he will request that prosecutors get to the bottom of the various corruption scandals that have been uncovered recently with disregard for any political pressure.
Asked whether he would accept a second nomination by President Chen Shui-bian, Hsieh said he would not accept it for whatever reason since his nomination has been turned down by the legislature.

The nomination was rejected owing to objections from opposition legislators led by those from the Kuomintang (KMT) who expressed doubts about Hsieh's resolve to fight government corruption in the wake of a series of scandals allegedly involving senior officials.
KMT legislative caucus whip Pan Wei-kang said Tuesday that the solidarity of the KMT and its ally, the opposition People First Party, has been displayed in the voting down of Hsieh's nomination.
While Pan expressed her approval for Hsieh's integrity and professional ability, she said she doubts Hsieh's fortitude and ability to resist political pressure.

KMT Legislator Wu Yu-sheng said he hopes President Chen will reconsider his choice for the post and that he expects the next state public prosecutor-general will be one who is able to discriminate between right and wrong.

KMT lawmakers said they will continue to investigate into alleged scandals such as those involving the electronic toll collection (ETC) project and the procurement of Lafayette-class frigates from France as well as the alleged insider stock trading involving Presidential Office officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Tuesday, gaining NT$0.041 to close at NT$32.446.
A total of US$853 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$32.455 and fluctuated between NT$32.423 and NT$32.468.

DOC.HEADLINE: HEALTH CARE SPENDING WASTE COULD TOP NT$2.8 B. PER YEAR: BNHI

TEXT.P: An official from the Bureau of National Health Insurance (BNHI) said Tuesday that the amount of waste in health care spending could top NT$2.8 billion (US$86.4 million) annually.
Kao Tzu-shan, head of a medical screening section of the BNHI, made the remarks based on BNHI statistics about redundant use of prescription medicines and unnecessary medical exams.

The BNHI focused on waste in 12 areas of health care, including treatment of upper respiratory tract infections (including common colds) , diabetes, hypertension, mental illnesses, as well as CT scans, magnetic resonance imaging, dialysis, ultrasound examinations, and gastroscope examinations.

Kao cited several sensational examples of misuse of medical resources, including some patients seeing doctors for common colds up to six times a month and being prescribed more medicine than one patient could possible use. Some people received six gastroscope examinations in a single year, while others received four cataract operations in the same period of time, he continued.

In view of the huge amount of waste occurring in health care, the BNHI has been urging hospitals and clinics over the last few years to stop prescribing medicines or giving examinations that are not strictly necessary.
The efforts have borne some fruit, with hospitals and clinics saving at least NT$1.2 billion during the 2004-2005 period, the official added.

Currently, patients with respiratory infections, including those from common colds, are prescribed less medicine, while the number of self-payment treatments for some illnesses have increased, according to the official.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENTIAL OFFICE REGRETS REJECTION OF PROSECUTORIAL NOMINATION

TEXT.P: The Presidential Office expressed regret Tuesday over the Legislative Yuan's rejection of President Chen Shui-bian's nomination for the post of state public prosecutor-general.

Presidential Office officials stressed that the president has taken into consideration the personality, integrity and professional abilities of Hsieh Wen-ting, currently prosecutor-general of the Taiwan High Court, before nominating him for the post.
They said it is regrettable that the opposition-controlled legislature has reviewed the nomination in an irrational and highly politicized manner.
They urged both the ruling and opposition parties to put aside their prejudices against one another and not to hamper government operation and social development because of political considerations.

The nomination was rejected owing to objections from opposition legislators led by those from the Kuomintang (KMT) , who expressed doubts about Hsieh's resolve to fight government corruption in the wake of a series of scandals allegedly involving senior officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: PATIENTS WITH MENTAL DISORDERS LACK ADEQUATE CARE: KMT LAWMAKER

TEXT.P: A lawmaker with the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) called Tuesday for government aid to provide over 70,000 mentally diseased patients with adequate care and treatment at rehabilitation centers.

Lai Shyh-bao issued the call at a public hearing he held at the Legislative Yuan. Hau Lung-bin, a former minister of the Department of Health, and Yeh Ching-chuan, a former deputy mayor of Taipei, also attended the activity to support Lai's call.

More than 70,000 mentally challenged patients have not received enough care and treatment across Taiwan due to a lack of rehabilitation institutes in local residential communities, Lai said, asking the government to offer incentives to assist in setting up mental rehabilitation facilities in local neighborhoods.
According to Lai, the number of mentally diseased patients in Taiwan is increasing at a pace faster than that of rehabilitation centers in residential communities around the country.

Lai pointed out that the government needs to review its mental rehabilitation program that begun in 1997 on grounds that currently, the government has 73,572 patients with mental disorders (not hospitalized) registered around Taiwan, far more than the 1997 figure.

Although being attended by family members at home is the best arrangement for people who suffer a mental disease, Hau opined that setting up a neighborhood care and assistance system nationwide is needed urgently in view of the present-day social situation in which both husband and wife must often work to support the family.
According to a study, each patient would affect the lives of seven family members, Hau said.

Yeh, who is also a public health expert, called on the government to subsidize the establishment of mental rehabilitation institutes in local neighborhoods due to the expensive cost of opening such facilities.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S BIOTECH INDUSTRY SEEKS INTERNATIONAL COOPERATION
DOC.DATELINE: Chicago, April 11 (CNA) (By Lillian Lin and Taijing Wu)

TEXT.P: Leaders of Taiwan's biotechnology are seeking international cooperation by taking part in the Biotechnology Industry Organization's (BIO) 2006 Annual International Convention in Chicago Monday evening.

Academia Sinica academician Ho Tuan-hua and Development Center for Biotechnology CEO Huang Jui-lian, along with other specialists, presented the achievements of Taiwan's agro-biotechnology sector, including genetically modified orchids and environmental friendly fertilizers.
According to a spokesman of the Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA), which organized this trip to the U.S.

for agro-biotechnology scholars and investors, a "bio-cluster" has formed under the close cooperation of the Taipei Biotechnology Corridor and the Southern Taiwan Science Park, attracting investment from prominent biotechnology companies.
Ting Shan-long, project director of the Pingtung Agriculture Biotechnology Science-based Park, presented the advantages of investing in his park at the convention.

Other Taiwan's health products were presented as well, such as a soybean product that has been clinically tested to be efficient in fighting cancer, a camphor-based health food that its makers claim can enhance the body's immune system and tuckahoe tea, a well-known health food in the United States.

In connection with the convention, a "Taiwan Night" was held by the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Chicago Monday evening, attended by researchers, investors and representatives of biotechnology and pharmaceutical companies interested in Taiwan's products and technology.

Prominent politicians of Ohio State, such as governor Bob Taft and Chicago city government official, American-born Chinese, Gene Lee attended the "Taiwan Night." Taft said in his speech that he hopes to boost both sides' cooperation as he recently visited Taiwan and witnessed its advanced technology.

DOC.HEADLINE: VETERAN MEMBER OPTIMISTIC ABOUT DPP CAMPAIGN FOR KAOHSIUNG MAYOR

TEXT.P: Acting Kaohsiung Mayor Yeh Chu-lan said Tuesday that she is "not pessimistic" about the chance of the scandal-sullied ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) winning in the southern harbor city's year-end mayoral election.

Yeh made the remarks in response to reporters' questions about whether an influence-pedaling scandal involving Chen Che-nan, former deputy secretary general to President Chen Shui-bian, would hamper the DPP's chances of retaining the Kaohsiung mayor seat in the election.

There are many factors -- including the popularity of the political party, charisma of the candidate and the administration's performance -- that may affect election results, Yeh said, noting she has confidence in the DPP due to its excellent performance in the city's development.

Kaohsiung has been developed into a modern city in the past eight years under the administration of a DPP-led city government, a record far better than that of the opposition Kuomintang, which had run the city for 50 years before the DPP come to power, Yeh said.

Aasked whether she would run in the upcoming election as the DPP candidate, Yeh, who is highly respected by DPP members, did not give a clear answer but said "I am grateful" while thanking members of the "pan-green" camp for their support.

Stressing that taking on the post of acting mayor six months ago was not to "enjoy the power" but to "shoulder" the responsibility in the promotion of the city's development, Yeh expressed her gratitude for Kaohsiung citizens' support.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEE AO OFFERS TO VISIT SINGAPORE TO CLARIFY OFFENSIVE REMARKS

TEXT.P: Independent Legislator Lee Ao Tuesday offered to visit Singapore to clarify his recent offensive remarks about Singaporeans.
Lee said he would welcome it if Singapore's government or universities extend him an invitation to show their generosity.

The outspoken Lee in the past called Singaporeans "stupid" and met waves of protest from citizens in the city state. Trying to elaborate on his point recently in a television talk show that he hosts, Lee said there have not been any outstanding figures in Singapore because Singaporeans are "not a good race."

These recent remarks by Lee again triggered much displeasure among Singaporeans, with some criticizing Lee as "bullshitting" on TV and others calling him a "cultural chauvinist" in articles published in local newspapers.
Lee said he has called the Hong Kongers "bad, " Taiwanese "slack" and the Chinese "unpredictable" but has received no responses from any of them.
Lee added that it is "very cute" of Singaporeans to have responded to what he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'KAOHSIUNG EYE' EXPECTED TO BECOME MAJOR LANDMARK OF PORT CITY

TEXT.P: An NT$200 million (US$6.15 million) ferris wheel in Kaohsiung is expected to become a major new landmark of the southern Taiwan port city when assembly work is completed at the end of June.

The big wheel will be named "Kaohsiung Eye" in the same fashion of the famous London Eye, and will be located in a Uni-President Group investment project -- an NT$18.5 billion shopping mall which is still under construction.

Yeh Chih-chung, president of the Tung Li Development Company which is in charge of the shopping mall's development, said the assembly of "The Kaohsiung Eye" started in January, with final touches expected in June.
When the ferris wheel opens to the public, passengers will be able to get a bird's-eye view of nearby Kaohsiung International Airport, Kaohsiung's port and surrounding streets.
The wheel will be installed with various kinds of neon lights, which Yeh said will be able to project more than 80 types of light displays.
He said there will be 36 passenger capsules on the big wheel. It will rotate at a steady speed with one revolution taking place about every 15 minutes.
He estimated the "Kaohsiung Eye" will attract 1.4 million visitors in the first year and around 1 million per year afterwards.

DOC.HEADLINE: ESCAPED FOREIGN WORKERS AWAIT REPATRIATION

TEXT.P: Forty foreign laborers who escaped from their job were discovered by Keelung police department Tuesday, hiding in an abandoned factory in Pali, Taipei County.
The group is now being held in a detention center in the northern city of Sanhsia and awaiting repatriation.

Keelung police found the 38 men from Indonesia and Thailand and two Indonesian women in the early morning. A police spokesman said the foreign workers had all sustained themselves by doing short-term, illegal work.

While trying to locate the workers' employers, the police urged the public not to hire illegal foreign workers, an act that may be punishable by a fine of NT$150,000 (US$4,687.5) to NT$750,000 (US$23,437.5).

DOC.HEADLINE: FIRST COUPLE INSTITUTES CRIMINAL PROCEEDINGS AGAINST KMT LAWMAKER

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian and first lady Wu Shu-jen filed a private criminal complaint Tuesday against a legislator of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT), claiming that he defamed them with "false" allegations of receiving illegal political contributions and department store gift vouchers.

The first couple's lawyer, Ku Li-wei, filed the complaint at the Taipei District Court on their behalf against Legislator Lee Chuan-chiao, who claimed at a news conference last weekend that the president had received political contributions from a convicted economic criminal through a ranking official at the Presidential Office, while the first lady had received NT$8.8 million in gift vouchers from Pacific Sogo Department Store.

Before filing the complaint, the president and first lady had denied the allegations twice through Presidential Office spokesmen and demanded that Lee apologize within three days or face a slander suit.

Lee's allegations against the first couple came a day after Chen Che-nan, a former Presidential Office deputy secretary-general, was detained after admitting he took NT$7.1 million from Liang Po-hsun, who had asked Chen to use his influence to get him off the legal hook.

Liang, 50, a former vice chairman of the Bank of Overseas Chinese, was convicted in November 2002 for borrowing NT$5.3 billion illegally from several of the bank's branches through dummy accounts in 1996-97. The Taiwan High Court sentenced him to one year in prison, but while applying for a deferred prison sentence in March 2003, he absconded abroad and remained at large in China, Hong Kong, Japan and South Africa.
He was also sentenced to one year and two months in a separate case for committing forgery in real estate deals while he was chairman of the Hsinchiehchung Construction Co.

Liang was indignant that Chen took his money but failed to deliver what he had promised. He returned to Taiwan April 2 with evidence against Chen, although he knew he would be arrested and sent to jail to serve his sentence.
The KMT legislator has indicated that he would welcome the first couple's lawsuit, because it would give him the chance to present evidence in court to prove his allegations.

DOC.HEADLINE: EX-PRESIDENT ACCUSES KMT OF SELLING OUT TAIWAN

TEXT.P: A few days prior to a forum in Beijing between the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and the Communist Party of China (CPC) , former President Lee Teng-hui blasted the KMT for working with the communists through economic means to bring Taiwan to a "painless death."

From former KMT Chairman Lien Chan's meeting with Chinese President Hu Jintao in 2005 to the upcoming KMT-CPC forum, scheduled for April 14-15, Lee said, the KMT has been "selling out Taiwan and selling out the Republic of China." The KMT is acting as an accomplice in China's attempts to annex Taiwan, he charged.

Lee ridiculed Lien for "not daring to make a statement in front of Hu" about the KMT's "one China" position that Taiwan sees as "the Republic of China." Instead, Hu made it clear that the "one China" principle refers only to the People's Republic of China, Lee added.
He accused the KMT of fabricating its so-called "1992 consensus" to fool the people of Taiwan, an act he described as "unacceptable."
Lee said the KMT has been criticizing the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) for widening the income gap and causing tragedies in families whose members are hounded by heavy credit-card debts.

But at the same time, he continued, the KMT -- the party he once led -- has been advocating allowing Chinese investment in Taiwan and launching direct transport links across the Taiwan Strait, policy proposals that he claimed will "push Taiwan to the verge of destruction."

By holding a joint forum with the CPC, the KMT is joining hands with the communists to use economic means that would lead to the euthanasia of Taiwan's sovereignty, Lee said, urging the people to stop the KMT from creating such a danger for Taiwan.
Lee made the remarks in a statement read by Huang Chao-tang at a press conference denouncing the KMT-CPC forum.

DOC.HEADLINE: CEOS ON FOREFRONT OF INNOVATION WAR

TEXT.P: Chief Executive Officers (CEOs) of modern companies will find themselves at the forefront of the innovation war, which will be a big challenge, two Taiwanese CEOs said Tuesday.

"This is an age of competition, no matter what sector you're in. The product life cycle is as short as months. Innovation is not only inevitable but also the only way to move forward. And the CEOs are standing on the front line, " said Vincent Lin, President of Fuhwa Venture Capital and the Senior Vice President of Fuhwa Financial Holding Company.
"The CEO can't hide in his little hole. He has to embrace as many new technologies, keep making as many friends and visit as many places as possible in order to be innovative, " said Lin.
But "an innovation is more than just a crazy idea, it has to be feasible," said Charles Kao, General Manager of Innotera Memories.
To be innovative, a company has to sort out its core competence in the very beginning. "The key is know yourself. Go with what you have and what you're good at," Kao said.

"And don't be afraid of changes. Any innovation, personnel-wise or operation-wise, means you have to move in a different direction, which is against human nature of wanting to be stable, " according to Lin.
Both Lin and Kao agreed that business innovation is a "top-down" process in most companies.
"A good leader has to be someone who is optimistic, encouraging, curious, honest, always progressing, and profit-motivated," Kao said.

DOC.HEADLINE: HUALIEN COUNTY WANTS COMPENSATION FOR RICE EXPORTS TO JAPAN

TEXT.P: The central government should compensate the deficit that a farmers' association in Hualien county absorbs in its exports to Japan of locally grown "Fu Lee" rice, according to a county official.

According to Tu Lee-hua, director of Hualien county's agriculture bureau, the farmers' association in Fuli, Hualien county has exported high end "Fu Lee" rice to Japan since 2004 in line with the central government's policy to help Taiwan produced rice make inroads into the quality-conscious Japanese market.

As "Fu Lee" rice is exported to Japan at a much lower price than its production cost, the local farmers' association has to absorb a noticeable price shortfall, resulting in losses to the farmers' association, Tu said, adding that Hualien County Magistrate Hsieh Shen-san also viewed it as something extremely unfair to local farmers and residents.

"Fu Lee" rice is exported to Japan at a price of NT$22 per kilogram, Tu pointed out, noting that the local farmers' association purchases the rice from local growers at around NT$25 per kilogram to ensure their earnings and that the difference between them was absorbed by the farmers' association.

Although the local farmers' association is willing to cooperate with the central government's policy, Tu said, a lack of profits has led to a heavy financial burden on the local unit and it keenly hopes that the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA) will help reduce the financial strain by providing it with reasonable subsidies.

Tu also criticized COA officials for falling short of asking for a reasonable price for "Fu Lee" rice in negotiations with the Japanese side, lamenting that the failure is the root cause of the association's mounting losses.

Amid a central government drive to sell Taiwan's high quality rice to Japan since 2004, "Fu Lee" rice -- produced in eastern Hualien county -- was the only variety that passed a total of 127 tests for exports to Japan, Tu said.

Taiwan produced rice has gained greater popularity in Japan in recent years, in particular the varieties cultivated in eastern Taiwan, an official of the COA's Agriculture and Food Agency said Monday, adding that he believes Taiwan's fine quality rice will be able to seize a bigger slice of the highly stringent Japanese market in two or three years.
Taiwan is one of the 15 countries whose rice has been approved by the Japanese authorities to enter the Japanese market, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: COMMUNIST TOTALITARIANISM INTOLERABLE IN WORLD: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: The totalitarian system of the Communist Party of China (CPC) is intolerable in the international community and has done the greatest damage to the freedom, democracy, human rights and peace pursued by the world, President Chen Shui-bian claimed Tuesday.
Chen made the remarks during talks with Marshall Islands President Kessai Note, who is in Taiwan on a state visit.

Chen said that the greatest differences between Taiwan and China are their lifestyles and political systems, with Taiwan a country that practices democracy and freedom and China ruled by a dictatorship under the domination of the CPC.
The fact that Taiwan and the Marshall Islands are both followers of freedom, democracy, human rights and peace has brought the two countries closely together, Chen said.

Chen expressed his appreciation for the Marshall Islands' long-term, firm support for Taiwan's bid to participate in international organizations such as the United Nations and the World Health Organization and said he believes the Marshall Islands, under Note's leadership, will continue to offer its support for Taiwan.
Note thanked Chen for inviting him to visit Taiwan and for the assistance and support that Taiwan has offered the people of the Marshall Islands.
He said his country will fully support Taiwan's bids to take part in international organizations and that he believes Taiwan will be able to participate in the international community freely.
Note urged the international community to officially recognize Taiwan.
Earlier that day, Chen presided over a formal welcoming ceremony with full military honors, including a 21-gun salute, in honor of Note, at the plaza in front of the Presidential Office.

Addressing the ceremony, Chen said that unlike the rainy weather on Note's arrival the day before, the sun on Tuesday symbolized that the friendship between both countries will last long and grow stronger.

During his visit, Note will witness the signing of a bilateral agreement on the exchange of information on money-laundering activities. Note and his entourage will also pay a visit to Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan, where they are scheduled to tour several facilities to study Taiwan's industrial achievements in the fields of ocean fisheries, aquaculture and solar energy.
This is Note's fourth visit to Taiwan since May 2002. He is scheduled to depart April 15.
Taiwan and the Marshall Islands forged diplomatic ties Nov. 20, 1998.

DOC.HEADLINE: IMPORT SAFEGUARD MEASURES ON TOWELS SHOULD BE REASONABLE: ITC

TEXT.P: The International Trade Commission (ITC) under the Ministry of Economic Affairs decided Tuesday to elevate tariffs on Chinese towels dumped on Taiwan's market, but stressed that the import safeguard measures must be "reasonable."
ITC officials made the remarks after a commission meeting was held on whether to adopt import safeguard measures against Chinese towels, which are being sold in Taiwan at abnormally low prices.
Hung Teh-sheng, president of the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research and also an ITC member, presided at the meeting.
Although the meeting was prolonged from one hour to two, the ITC members did not reach a final decision on the duty rate, and expect that conclusion to be made at another meeting April 14.
Domestic towel manufacturers -- led by Taiwan Solidarity Union legislators -- went to the Ministry of Economic Affairs to present their petitions.

According to ITC officials, domestic towel producers are demanding the government elevate current tariffs of 10.5 percent on Chinese towels to 189 percent -- or a 189 percent tariff on Chinese towel products exceeding the annual quota of three million tons.

ITC member Huang Chih-tien, who is also a professor at National Taiwan University, noted that the commission has decided to elevate tariff rates on Chinese towels instead of adopting the tariff rate quota (TRQ) , in which imports above the quota threshold will face a much higher tariff as the TRQ will involve a more complicated calculation.
Huang said the import relief measure against Chinese towels will last three years, and that the tariff rate will return to the current 10.5 percent after three years.

In response to queries about the exact tariff rate on Chinese towel products, Huang stressed the import safeguard measures were aimed at preventing or compensating for the losses resulted from a market disorder caused by imported goods; therefore the import duty should be maintained at a reasonable level, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH SOLICITING VOLUNTEERS TO PROMOTE ANTI-BIRD FLU EDUCATION

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Department of Health said Tuesday that it is soliciting 100,000 volunteers to educate the public on how to prevent avian flu.
Shih Wen-yi, deputy director of the DOH's Center for Disease Control (CDC) , said the new project will start with 25 community universities around the country to deepen anti-bird flu education.

According to World Health Organization (WHO) statistics, there were 191 cases of H5N1 infection in humans around the world as of April 4, 108 of which were fatal, with the illness spreading from Asia to Europe and Africa.

To prevent an avian flu outbreak in Taiwan, the CDC is working out strategies to strengthen quarantine measures on people and goods entering the island, medical care systems and community anti-bird flu education, Shih said, expressing hope that more people will join the campaign to promote anti-bird flu knowledge.

DOC.HEADLINE: BANKS HIRING FEWER GANGSTERS TO COLLECT DEBTS: MOI

TEXT.P: Minister of the Interior Lee Yi-yang said Tuesday that incidents of banks hiring gangsters to collect on credit card debt defaulters have decreased over the past six weeks.

Lee made the remarks in a review of the results of telephone hotlines that were established in late February for the public to report on improper methods used by banks to intimidate credit card defaulters.
He said that out of 2,776 calls received, only 23 calls involved violent methods related to organized crime, intimidation, obstruction of freedom, vandalism, fraud and assault.
"The practice of using improper methods to collect debts has been checked, which is why the number of calls received daily has decreased to the level of less than one call per day," he said.
Lee said, however, that the hotlines will stay open, although the 20 existing lines will be cut to eight.

In addition, Lee said the National Police Agency has taken the initiative to crack down on underground loansharks, as well as illegal debt collection companies. A total of 301 people involved in the illegal practice have been turned over to the authorities for prosecution.

The hotlines and the crackdown were instigated by the government as part of its effort to help "credit card slaves" in the wake of increasing reports of suicide and robberies motivated by the heavy pressure of repaying outstanding credit card debts. Other measures include assistance to the debtors in their negotiations with banks to repay debts.
Vice Premier Tsai Ing-wen announced Monday that 53,000 "credit card slaves" have so far completed negotiations with banks on terms for settling their outstanding debts.

DOC.HEADLINE: BUSINESS MODEL INNOVATION A TOP PRIORITY FOR COMPANY SUCCESS: SURVEY

TEXT.P: Business model innovation is the most important factor in determining the success and revenue of modern enterprises, according to responses from 765 Chief Executive Officers (CEO) in a worldwide survey released Tuesday.

Conducted by International Business Machines Corporation (IBM ) , the biennial survey "The Global CEO Study" found that 28 percent of CEOs will focus on business model innovation, relatively lower than 42 percent who said they would focus on products/services/markets innovation and another 30 percent that would stress operational innovation.
However, after a more in-depth study of the responses from 200 companies, IBM concluded that business model innovation was the key factor in helping usher in more revenue for enterprises.
"The result tells us that emerging companies are those that can master business model innovations," said Paul Liu, Associate Partner of IBM Taiwan Corporation.
Among CEOs who regard business model innovation as the priority, 66 percent said they would implement organizational reform while 53 percent said they will seek to establish a strategic partnership.
Collaborative innovation is also indispensable for businesses, the survey found; meanwhile, it takes the full devotion and planning of upper-level management for innovation to be successful.

Eighty percent of CEOs believed it was important to integrate technology and business. Sixty-five percent of respondents said they would pay attention to and spend more energy on innovation in the next three years to embrace the trend of globalization.
The survey was based on responses of 765 CEOs from 200 companies representing 20 different sectors across three continents -- Europe, Asia and the Americas.
Eighty-six respondents were from the Greater China region, including 11 from Taiwan. The survey was first conducted in 2004.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO NEED FOR DPP TO FLINCH FROM 'ONE CHINA': KMT HEAD

TEXT.P: There is no need for the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) to flinch from "one China, with each side of the Taiwan Strait free to interpret its meaning" and President Chen Shui-bian needs just to recognize it, without Chinese President Hu Jintao's consent, opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou said Tuesday.
Ma also said KMT Honorary Chairman Lien Chan will not forward any message to Hu from Chen when they meet in Beijing later this month.

Chen said earlier this month he would "absolutely respect" if Hu accepts the so-called "1992 consensus, " which the KMT claims means "one China, with each side of the strait having its own interpretations."

But the Presidential Office's official records about Chen's promise to "respect" the 1992 consensus seem to have been erased, and the Presidential Office is suspected of having falsified history, according to Ma.

Several high-ranking officials, including Chen and DPP lawmakers, have urged Lien to publicly mention the term the "Republic of China" and "one China, respective interpretations" during his upcoming visit to China, but Lien has rejected the requests.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWMAKER TO SHOW EVIDENCE AGAINST FIRST FAMILY IN COURT

TEXT.P: An opposition lawmaker sued by the first family for defaming them said Tuesday that he would present his evidence in court and he urged the first family to face justice in person.

Lee Chuan-chiao of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) alleged that first lady Wu Shu-jen received NT$8.8 million in gift vouchers, some of which have been used by members of her family at Pacific Sogo Department Store in Taipei.

President Chen Shui-bian and his wife filed a private criminal complaint against Lee for defaming them with what they claimed are false allegations. Through their lawyer, Ku Li-hsiung, the couple said they would respect the judge's request for them to appear in court if need be.
Lee said he had anticipated the first family's reaction to his accusation and that he would produce further evidence to support his allegations.
During a press conference in Taipei, Lee called a person identified only as Miss Huang, who tipped him off about the allegations of the first family using the vouchers at the department store.
Huang said over the phone that she saw the president's daughter Chen Hsing-yu and her husband buying bedding at the department store nearly four years ago and paying with vouchers.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S.-TAIWAN TIES ENDURING AND UNSHAKEABLE: AIT DIRECTOR

TEXT.P: AIT Director Stephen M. Young described U.S.-Taiwan ties Tuesday as "enduring" and "unshakeable " and he also praised Taiwanese people for their ability to handle challenges.

Young voiced his wish that the ties between America and Taiwan will not falter. He described Taiwan as a beautiful island and said it is important for Taiwanese and their friends to "never forget how far Taiwan has come" since the early sixties when he first came to Taiwan, and to "admire anew that remarkable achievement."

"Most of all, it is the people of Taiwan that make it special ... I have always been optimistic about Taiwan's ability to deal with whatever challenges the world presents, because you have the grace and determination, the energy and the talent, to handle any challenge and turn it to your advantage," Young said.

Young made the remarks, during a reception he organized for local leaders in different circles together with foreign representatives and ambassadors in Taiwan. Premier Su Tseng-chang also attended the event. At the end of Young's remarks, he proposed a toast for the "unshakeable" ties between Americans and Taiwanese.
Young said that U.S.-Taiwan ties must be built on mutual trust and respect and he expressed his wish to work together with the Taiwanese to further the bonds between the two peoples.

DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Immigrants Rally in Scores of Cities for Legal Status
Waving American flags and blue banners that read "We Are America, " throngs of cheering, chanting immigrants and their supporters converged in Washington, D.C. and scores of other cities on Monday calling on Congress to offer legal status and citizenship to millions of illegal immigrants. The rallies, whose mood was largely festive rather than angry, were the latest in recent weeks in response to a bill passed in the House that would speed up deportations, tighten border security and criminalize illegal immigrants. A proposal that would have given most illegal immigrants achance to become citizens collapsed in the Senate last week.

Though political gridlock and waves of sectarian violence continue to afflict Iraq, clear signs are emerging that the U.S. is gearing up plans to reduce the number of its troops in the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAW AMENDED FOR 319 SHOOTING TRUTH INVESTIGATION COMMISSION

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan passed an amendment to the Organic Statute for the 319 Shooting Truth Investigation Commission Tuesday, providing the legal basis for the establishment of a 17-member commission to probe the shooting of President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu on the eve of the 2004 presidential election.

The legislative caucuses of the two main opposition parties -- the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) -- which enjoy a slight majority in the legislature, moved to put the amendment to a vote after failing to reach consensus in negotiations during the morning with the caucuses of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and its "pan-green camp" ally, the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU).
The opposition legislators passed their version of the amendment after DPP and TSU legislators walked out in protest.
The DPP and TSU legislative caucuses vowed that they will ask the Council of Grand Justices to rule on whether the amended organic statute is still unconstitutional.

On Dec. 15, 2004, the grand justices ruled that the original statute and a commission formed to investigate the March 19 shooting were unconstitutional because Article Eight of the statute tried to give the commission the same powers as those of prosecutors in carrying out investigations into the shooting, while Article 13 gave the commission the power to prosecute those responsible for the shooting.
In accordance with the grand justices' interpretation, the KMT and PFP caucuses proposed an amendment to revise the flawed clauses.
The amended statute would provide for the establishment of a commission, with its 17 members recommended by the political parties in proportion to the number of seats they hold in the legislature.

According to the amended law, legislators and members of the Control Yuan -- the highest watchdog body -- cannot serve on the commission, whose members should be impartial people equipped with the right expertise.

These members will be appointed by the Legislative Yuan speaker. If any party fails to recommend its own nominees, it will be seen as giving up its rights and the vacancies will be filled by nominations made by the commission's convener, with the approval of the legislature.

The commission will answer to the people only and will not be controlled by any government or law enforcement agencies. Its members will have the right to ask any organization to provide documents and evidence for its examination. Failure to cooperate could lead to a fine of up to NT$100,000.

After beginning its investigation, the commission will submit a written report to the Legislative Yuan and the Control Yuan every three months. If anyone is found to have committed a criminal offense, the commission will refer him or her to either public prosecutors or military prosecutors. The investigation is expected to be completed in six months.

The March 19 shooting occurred the day before the 2004 presidential election when the president and the vice president were campaigning in a jeep in Tainan, southern Taiwan. The opposition believes the incident generated sympathy votes for Chen and Lu, helping them to win the election by a mere 29,500 votes.
The opposition parties suspect that the incident was staged and their demand to form a commission to investigate the shooting has met strong opposition from the DPP and the TSU.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN DELEGATION HOLDS SEMINAR AT BIO2006 IN CHICAGO

TEXT.P: A Taiwan delegation to the BIO2006 Annual International Convention in Chicago gave a seminar Monday to introduce Taiwan's biotechnology innovation and the development of biotech industrial parks in Taiwan.
More than 200 people from the biotechnology industry attended the seminar to hear briefings by policy makers, executives of research institutes and leading biopharmaceutical companies.
Minister without Portfolio Lin Ferng-ching made opening remarks in which he talked about Taiwan's achievements in biotechnology research and interest in seeking international partners.
Taiwan's biotech industry has maintained double-digit growth since 2000, with the production value of the biotechnology, pharmaceutical and medical equipment sectors reaching US$4.53 billion in 2004.
Lin said the industry has benefited greatly from joint ventures, partnerships and foreign investment, and that the government is seeking international investment in Taiwan's biotech industrial parks.

Dr. Julien Huang, president of the Development Center for Biotechnology, reported on the evolving opportunities in Taiwan's biopharmaceutical industry. She introduced the current collaboration of the center with Taiwanese biopharmaceutical firms and various international partners.

This is the fifth time a Taiwan delegation has attended the world's largest biotechnology exhibition. More than 16,000 policy makers, business executives, researchers, venture capitalists and journalists are attending the four-day event. The exhibitions feature innovations from 30 countries and the convention is highlighted by 180 educational sessions and workshops on finance, partnering, research and development, and policy.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, April 12, or the 15th day of the third month of the Year of the Dog according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1606: The Union Jack becomes the United Kingdom's official flag.
1860: Vajirananavarorasa, prince and patriarch of Buddhism in Siam, is born. He institutionalized Thai Buddhism.
1861: The U.S. Civil War breaks out as Confederate forces under Gen. Pierre Beauregarde take Fort Sumter in Charlestown harbor, South Carolina.
1927: The Kuomintang starts a "purification" movement by expelling communist members.
1945: U.S. President Franklin D. Roosevelt dies in office at the age of 63. Vice President Harry S. Truman is sworn in as his successor.
1949: The 37.5 Per Cent Farm Rental Reduction Program goes into effect in Taiwan.
1953: The Legislative Yuan passes a bill submitted by President Chiang Kai-shek, extending the term of office for legislators by an additional year, to May 7, 1954.
1958: The first national meeting for commending "Good Men and Good Deeds" is held at Chung Shan Hall in Taipei.
1961: The Russians put the first man into space when cosmonaut Yauri Gargarin is launched in the Vostok I space vehicle for a single orbit of the earth.
1963: Indonesian forces launch an armed attack against Malaysia as part of a new policy of confrontation.
1966: Cheng Wan-fu, former chairman of the "Taiwan Democratic Party" and a leader of the "Taiwan Independence Movement" in Tokyo, returns to Taipei after 20 years of self-imposed exile in Japan.
1973: Deng Xiaoping, who was purged during the Cultural Revolution, resumes his position as the vice premier of Communist China.
1973: Vietnamese President Nguyen Van Thieu and his wife arrive in Taipei for a visit.
1974: Economic Affairs Vice Minister K.S. Chang, leading a group of government officials and businessmen, depart for San Francisco to attend a Sino-U.S. conference on economic relations.
1974: Tsinghwa University completes the installation of its second nuclear reactor for research purposes. This is the fourth research reactor installed in Taiwan.
1975: President Yen Chia-kan calls on the people to carry out the Last Testament of the late President Chiang Kai-shek.
1975: Taipei building contractors pledge NT$1 million to start a fund-raising campaign for the proposed Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall.
1979: Taiwan's first geothermal power plant formally begins operations.
1981: Joe Louis, American prize fighter, dies at the age of 67. He held the heavyweight title for nearly 12 years (1937-1949), successfully defending it a record 25 times.
1981: Columbia, the world's first reusable space shuttle, is launched at Cape Canaveral.
1983: China Airlines inaugurates its regular flight service to Amsterdam as the first step toward establishing worldwide commercial air services.
1989: Honduran President Jose Azcona Hoyo and his wife arrive in Taipei for a visit.
1994: The Mainland Affairs Council decides to suspend all cultural and educational exchanges with the mainland until Beijing provides reasonable and satisfactory explanations for the Qiandao Lake tragedy of March 31 in which 24 Taiwan tourists were killed.
1996: The Petronas Towers in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, are declared the world's tallest buildings.
2000: Republic of China Premier Vincent Siew meets with Guenter Rexrodt, a former German economics minister, to exchange views on bilateral relations between the two countries.
2001: an IBM-Linux Development Center is inaugurated in Taiwan. The center will provide local individual and group users with system testing, technical exchanges, experience sharing and training on using the Linux operating system.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "There are wise men who are not moral characters; but a fool is never a moral character."

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP CALLS FOR 'NO DOUBLE STANDARDS' IN DISCIPLINING PROSECUTORS

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Justice should not have double standards in meting out discipline to prosecutors, the legislative caucus of the opposition People First Party (PFP) said Wednesday.

The PFP legislative caucus made the appeal to lend support to Hualien district prosecutor Lee Tzu-chun one day after Lee joined around 1,000 demonstrators outside the Legislative Yuan when lawmakers were reviewing Hseih Wen-ting's nomination as the nation's top prosecutor and Vice Justice Minister Lee Chin-yung demanded that the Hualien Prosecutors' Office convene a meeting to discuss whether to discipline Lee. Lawmakers vetoed Hsieh as the state public prosecutor-general in a vote.

PFP legislative caucus whip Lu Hsueh-chang pointed out that Liu Cheng-wu, chief prosecutor of the Taoyuan Prosecutors' Office, stumped for President Chen Shu-bian when the latter sought re-election as Taipei mayor in 1998. Liu was then a Taipei district prosecutor.
"Liu's violation was even more serious as he openly interfered in election activities in his capacity as a civil servant," Lu said.

Lu pointed out that Council of Agriculture Chairman Su Jia-chyuan also protested against the deteriorating law and order situation in Taichung City when he was the interior minister on the eve of mayoral election in the central Taiwan city in December 2005 in a bid to help the candidate of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).
"Ministers taking to the streets is the worst example, " Lu said, urging the Ministry of Justice not to have double standards in disciplining Lee.

Lee became an instant celebrity when he summoned President Chen Shui-bian to testify before him in a probe into an alleged vote-buying case involving a DPP candidate for Hualien county magistrate last year. The outspoken prosecutor has recently appeared on TV political commentary programs to criticize the government.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN RANKS 17TH IN WORLD IN TRADE FOR 2005: WTO
DOC.DATELINE: Geneva, April 11 (CNA) (By Neil Lu and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Taiwan was the world's 17th largest trading nation in 2005, down two notches from the previous year, according to the annual world trade report released Tuesday by the World Trade Organization (WTO).

Taiwan's exports amounted to US$196.6 billion in 2005, up 8 percent over the year-earlier level, making Taiwan the 16th largest exporter in the world and the sixth largest exporter in Asia, behind China, Japan, Hong Kong, South Korea and Singapore.
Taiwan's export value registered 8 percent year-on-year growth, ahead of Japan's 5 percent, but behind China's 28 percent, Singapore's 16 percent, Hong Kong's 12 percent and South Korea's 10 percent.
Owing to a 10-percent increase in the total value of imports into Taiwan, the country's trade surplus slid from US$14.5 billion in 2004 to US$10.3 billion in 2005.

The WTO report said Taiwan's performance, which relies heavily on the export of electronic products, could have been affected by the slowdown in the global demand for computer and electronic products.
Also, soaring oil and raw material prices caused an increase in the costs of imports, which brought down Taiwan's trade surplus, the report said.

In 2005, world trade registered a growth rate of 6 percent, which was much lower than the 9 percent recorded for the previous year. The trade value, however, rose 13 percent in 2005 and topped US$10 trillion for the first time.
China maintained its status as the world's third largest trading nation in 2005, with its gross domestic product posting a growth rate of 10 percent and its trade surplus amounting to US$102 billion.
The WTO predicted that world trade will expand 7 percent this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN WON'T OPT FOR INDEPENDENCE: ACADEMIA SINICA HEAD
DOC.DATELINE: Singapore, April 12 (CNA) (By Charles Kang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh said in Singapore Tuesday that he firmly believes that President Chen Shui-bian is a rational man who will not opt for independence in terms of Taiwan's future.

Speaking during an interview with two Singaporean media outlets, the visiting Lee said that Chen putting forth the "five noes" doctrine in his 2000 inaugural address and repeating it in his 2004 inauguration speech clearly reflected his intention of improving bilateral relations with China.

Chen pledged in May 2000 that as long as Beijing has no intention of using military force against Taiwan, he will not declare independence, not change Taiwan's name, not add the state-to-state theory into the Constitution, not promote a referendum on the issue of independence versus unification, and not scrap the National Unification Guidelines during his time in office.
The president has been unwavering in upholding his pledge and has even tried to break the impasse across the Taiwan Strait via the United States, Lee said.
Nevertheless, Lee said, Chen's many gestures of holding out olive branches to the Beijing leadership have not been recognized nor appreciated.
Lee said it would be understandable if President Chen's stance were to change as his goodwill toward China has been consistently ignored for so many years.
Lee called for the Beijing leadership to show some respect to the people of Taiwan and the administration in Taiwan if it wants to defuse cross-strait tensions.

To improve relations with Taiwan, Lee said, Beijing needs to talk to the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , adding that if Beijing is unwilling to talk to the DPP, it should at least talk to some private groups in Taiwan, rather than engaging in talks only with the opposition "pan-blue alliance."

Lee, co-winner of the 1986 Nobel Prize in chemistry, also said it is perplexing that after having visited China almost every year since 1978 to help raise China's scientific research standards, Chinese authorities abruptly ceased contact with him after the year 2000, labeling him a supporter of Taiwan independence.

DOC.HEADLINE: FIVE TAIWAN COMPANIES PRESENTING NEW PRODUCTS AT BIO2006

TEXT.P: Five Taiwan companies are presenting their new products and technology at the BIO2006 being held at the Hyatt Regency McCormick Place in Chicago April 9-12, featuring traditional Chinese medicine and gene modification for plants.

Organized by the Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TETRA) , the five companies have joined Taiwan's leading biotechnology research institutes in presenting the Taiwan Pavilion at the world's largest biotechnology exhibition.
Four of the five companies are presenting agro-bio products and technology, namely the Sinphar Group, Well Shine Biotechnology Development Co., Microbio Co., and Exon Science Inc.

The Sinphar Group is presenting products which feature the purity of the efficacious extracts from green tea. A Sinphar report indicates that the products are expected to reach the market in 2007 as the U.S. Food and Drug Administration has approved the medicine-grade ingredient.
The Well Shine Biotechnology Development Co. is introducing cultivation techniques for Antrodia, a well-known source of traditional Chinese medicine for improving the body's immunocompetence.

While health food has been growing in popularity around the world, Microbio Co. is expecting that its new product, made from fermented soybeans, which can enhance the activity of natural killer cells in the human body, can make its way smoothly onto the world market.

Exon Science Co. has developed advanced gene modification techniques for orchids with a grant from the Council of Agriculture under the Executive Yuan. The new techniques allow the implanting of modified genes into orchids to help the plants resist cold or blight.

The Council of Agriculture delegate to the exhibition gave a briefing on Taiwan's agriculture biotechnology at a seminar Monday, saying that the council is undertaking six major projects, including orchid breeding and gene modification for animals and plants. The projects involve government agencies and research institutes as well as the private sector.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
: The Straits Times: Coming GE a watershed event, says DPM Wong.
Deputy Prime Minister Wong Kan Seng yesterday called the coming General Election (GE) a watershed event, with the People's Action Party aiming for a strong endorsement from voters.
The Lianhe Zaobao: Iran will own the nuclear technology very quickly.
Iran refined the uranium enrichment successful in the first time. Iran's President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad claimed Iran will be a country owned nuclear technology very quickly.
President Mahmound Ahmadinejad said Iran wants to achieve industrial-scale uranium enrichment, setting his country on a collision course with the United States which fears Tehran wants to make an atomic bomb.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Manila Bulletin: GMA names Davide to UN
President Arroyo has appointed former Chief Justice Hilario G. Davide Jr. as Permanent Representative of the Republic of the Philippines to the United Nations (UN) in New York in place of Ambassador Lauro L. Baja Jr.
The Philippine Daily Inquirer: Palace giveth, taketh
Just hours after it released an official list of the names of six distinguished Filipino artists -- led by the late actor-director and presidential candidate Fernando Poe Jr. -- who will be conferred the rank and title of Order of National Artist, Malacanang strangely withdrew the announcement.
The Philippine Star: GMA okays release of AFP report on election cheating
BAGUIO CITY - President Arroyo has approved the release of a report of an Armed Forces of the Philippines (AFP) fact-finding body on the possible involvement of military generals in the alleged cheating in the May 2004 elections, Malacanang said yesterday.
The Manila Times: Oil edges toward critical $70 mark
OIL prices inched closer to 70 dollars a barrel in Asian trading Tuesday as reports of a possible US military strike against Iran's nuclear facilities rattled the market, dealers said.

DOC.TEXT:
The Japan Times; Prodi claims victory in contested Italian poll
Opposition leader Romano Prodi claimed victory Tuesday as vote-counting continued in Italy's parliamentary election.
