Los Angeles Times: Across the U.S., 'We Are America'
Legal and illegal,carrying signs in English and Spanish, hundreds of thousands of immigrants and their supporters took to the streets Monday in the nation's capital and in dozens of cities around the country, spreading a sea of white T-shirts and American flags across city parks and TV screens in an effort to persuade lawmakers to grant foreign-born workers more rights.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT: The Moscow Times: In a First, Russia's Soccer Will Be in Dutch Hands Dutch coach Guus Hiddink will be the first foreigner to take charge of the Russian national football team. ( By Chang Hung-kuang)

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI SHARE PRICES END HIGHER

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened low and closed higher Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 51.33 points to close at 6,808.5.
The bourse opened at 6,710.62 and fluctuated between 6,813.66 and 6,709.83 during trading. A total of 3.85 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$109.02 billion (US$3.36 billion).

All eight major stock categories gained ground, with paper and pulp issues rising the most at 4.9 percent, followed by construction shares at 3.3 percent, textile stocks at 2.1 percent, cement shares at 1.3 percent, foodstuff issues at 1.1 percent, machinery and electronics shares at 1.0 percent, plastics and chemical issues at 0.3 percent, and banking and financial shares at 0.1 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 636 to 269, with 129 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: NSC, INTEL SIGN MOU ON RESEARCH AT TAIWAN UNIVERSITIES

TEXT.P: Taiwan's National Science Council (NSC) and U.S.-based chipmaker Intel signed a memorandum of understanding Monday to co-sponsor research projects at Taiwan universities.
This is the first time that Intel, the world's largest chipmaker, has signed an MOU with a government agency for such a purpose.
Chen Chien-Jen, minister of the NSC, and John Antone, general manager of Intel Asia Pacific, announced the strategic agreement in a joint press conference.

According to the agreement, Intel will first single out potential Joint Research Projects at Taiwan's universities and then provide technology consultation to accelerate commercialization of those projects. Meanwhile, the NSC, assisted by Intel, will identify and provide funding for the most promising projects.
The agreement will be renewed on a yearly basis, but no financial details were disclosed.
Chen Chien-Jen emphasized that the project, which combines funding by the NSC and Intel's technology and marketing capacity, will enhance Taiwan's ability in research and development.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN FLEXIBLE TOWARDS CROSS-STRAIT CHARTER FLIGHTS: PREMIER

TEXT.P: The government is holding an open attitude towards the expansion of cross-Taiwan Strait charter services and will not rule out any possibilities as long as they are arranged by both sides through negotiations, Premier Su Tseng-chang said Wednesday.

Such possibilities could include the launch of cross-strait cargo charter flights, the institutionalization of cross-strait passenger charter flights for special holidays and the launch of cross-strait weekend charter services, Su said.

Su made the remarks during a weekly Cabinet meeting, after listening to a briefing by Mainland Affairs Council Minister Joseph Wu on the status and outlook of cross-strait economic and trade interactions.
Su said in handling cross-strait affairs, the government must protect Taiwan's identity and the country's initiative in policy-making and should let the people understand the government's policy.
The government must request negotiations with China on any matters involving the exercise of government authority, Su said.

Su instructed authorities concerned to arrange for talks with Chinese authorities on issues related to cross-strait economic exchanges, cross-strait charter flights, and visits to Taiwan by Chinese tourists.

Also, the authorities concerned should set a reasonable timetable for the completion of these talks to display the government's positive and pragmatic attitude in handling cross-strait affairs, he said.

According to Su, Beijing has been delaying talks with Taipei on the issue of allowing more Chinese tourists to visit Taiwan, although Taiwan has since 2001 permitted the entry of Chinese tourists meeting certain criteria.

Su said proper planning is required before the measure can be implemented because this issue involves not only the availability of enough hotels, but also the exchange of Chinese yuan, the problem of Chinese tourists overstaying their visas, and the responsibilities of travel agencies.

For example, Su said, the U.S. government has recently confirmed that there are more than 39,000 Chinese citizens who have overstayed their visas in the United States, with more than 8,000 in detention centers, a problem which has caused a heavy financial burden on the U.S. government.

Unless a system for tourist identity authentication is established between Taiwan and China, there will be no way for the government to resolve the problem of illegal immigrants, which will threaten national security and increase social costs, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC REP TO U.S. VOWS TO SAFEGUARD TAIWAN INTERESTS
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 11 (CNA) (By Jorge Liu and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Representative to the United States David Ta-wei Lee said Tuesday he will do his best to safeguard Taiwan's interests when Chinese President Hu Jintao visits the United States April 18-22.

Lee noted that the representative office has kept in close communications with the U.S. government, expressing Taiwan's concerns over Hu's visit. He added that Washington, based on goodwill, has also communicated with his office for its understanding of the expected meeting between Hu and U.S. President George W. Bush April 20.
The representative office has done everything to prevent any possible harm to Taiwan's interests, Lee said, although it cannot guarantee that there will be no surprises.
"The representative office will work toward not letting the Bush-Hu meeting affect the interests of Taiwan and its 23 million people," he added.

On whether President Chen Shui-bian's recent announcement to cease the functions of the National Unification Council (NUC) , a symbolic body whose goal is eventual unification with China, will become an issue at the Bush-Hu meeting, Lee said that the U.S. and Taiwan have agreed that the NUC issue should be temporarily "put aside."
"What the representative office will do is work to prevent the things that the public does not want to see or take place, " he further said.

Lee noted that the U.S. has a consistent and long-standing policy toward the Taiwan issue, and as far as he knows, the U.S. side will "give its standard answer" if China raises any questions on the issue. The U.S. has said repeatedly that its policy toward Taiwan is based on the three communiques and the Taiwan Relations Act.
Meanwhile, on the largest-ever Chinese trade delegation currently visiting the United States to pave the way for the Bush-Hu meeting, Lee said that he has experienced a sense of "deja vu."
The visit by the Chinese delegation, led by Vice Premier Wu Yi, is expected to include 13 states and result in multimillion-dollar orders for Boeing and Motorola.
With China recording a US$200 billion trade surplus with the United States in 2005 and its desire to cool the protectionist sentiment in the U.S. Congress, Lee said he has felt a sense of "deja vu."

He noted that in order to cut the huge trade surplus with the United States in the late 1970s, Taiwan also sent large procurement delegations to the U.S. Although with the structural changes, it is not as easy for Taiwan to send such a large trade delegation to the U.S. for "policy" procurement nowadays as in the past, he continued.
Lee noted that Wu's delegation has targeted certain constituencies of individual congressmen to purchase items that China doesn't really need so as to court these congressmen.
"Taiwan should absolutely take heed, although there is no need to panic, " Lee said, adding that Taiwan's edge lies in its freedom and democracy and a political system that is relatively more mature.
"As long as Taiwan sticks to these values, the U.S. Congress will continue to support Taiwan," Lee said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Berlusconi proposes grand coalition.
Facing a uncertain result of the April 9-10 general election and a loomed defeat, Premier Silvio Berlusconi proposed Tuesday that the ruling and opposition camps form a grand coalition. Opposition Union leader Romano Prodi apparently rejected the proposal by saying that the center-left coalition can rule the nation alone.

DOC.HEADLINE: ICG TO CHANGE TAIWAN'S TITLE TO HELP CHINA'S MEMBERSHIP: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian expressed worry Wednesday that the International Crisis Group (ICG) might opt to change Taiwan's designation in the worldwide conflict prevention organization in order to facilitate China's admission.

Chen said it would be unfair for Taiwan if the ICG changes Taiwan's designation and the title used at the ICG Council simply because China is taking part in the group, after Taiwan has been one of the major contributors to the organization.

The president made the remarks during a meeting with two parliamentarians from Belgium at the Presidential Office. One of them was Alain Destexhe, a Belgian parliamentarian and former ICG president, who has been a staunch supporter of Taiwan and a major force in Belgium behind Taiwan's bid to join the World Health Assembly (WHA) as an observer.
Chen expressed his hope that Destexhe will bring his sense of righteousness into full play to help prevent Taiwan from being excluded from the ICG as a result of China's admission.

Meanwhile, the president also noted that Beijing has persistently blocked Taiwan from joining the WHA, the decision-making body of the World Health Organization (WHO) , and that China's ambassador to Belgium, Zhang Qiyue, has exerted pressure on the Belgian parliament to make it drop discussions on Taiwan's WHA bid.

Chen called for Destexhe to help revive the proposal to support Taiwan's WHA bid. "It would be the international community's loss if Taiwan continues to be excluded from global disease-prevent networks," he said.

The president also said the European Union should not consider lifting its arms embargo against China on the grounds that human rights protection has not improved in China. Besides, he added, China has deployed nearly 800 missiles targeting Taiwan and has passed its "Anti-Secession Law" that codifies China's longstanding threat to attack Taiwan if it thinks Taiwan is seeking formal independence.

He reiterated that it is natural that there are differences across the Taiwan Strait and said the differences should be solved only via peaceful dialogue, and that military or non-peaceful means should never be an option.
Nevertheless, he added, because of China's totalitarian regime, many issues are complicated ideologically, leaving the world's democratic communities "astounded."

Chen said the Beijing leadership believes that only the barrel of guns can protect power. In a society where politics and party are entwined, with the Chinese communist party forces in total control of politics, Chen said, the Beijing leadership believes that only "stability" will prevail.

Against this backdrop, he said, the Chinese authorities exert heavy control on society, with no human rights, no freedom of speech, no freedom of journalism, no freedom of religion, and where even Internet communications or media operations are censored, tampered with and kept under tight surveillance.
The president argued that the people and government of Taiwan do not oppose the people of China, but are definitely opposed to the Chinese communists' totalitarianism.

He said the biggest gap between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait lies in the difference in lifestyles and social systems. That is also the reason why the Taiwan people are firm in choosing their current path, though a harder one, toward peace, freedom and democracy, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. OFFICIALS 'AGREE, DISAGREE' WITH KMT HEAD: ROC REPRESENTATIVE

TEXT.P: U.S. officials do not see eye-to-eye with opposition Kuomintang Chairman Ma Ying-jeou on every issue between the two countries, despite what Taiwan's representative to Washington David Ta-wei Lee described Tuesday as their high opinion of him.

In a regular briefing with Taiwan journalists, Lee said U.S. officials were interested in some of Ma's ideas but did not agree with him on some issues, including Taiwan's national security and its proposed arms purchase from America.
The purchase has been mired in Taiwan's legislature because of KMT opposition.

Lee, who was blamed by critics in Taipei for not being present at Ma's meetings with U.S. officials in Washington during the KMT leader's March 19-29 visit, said Washington had informed Taipei of its officials' talks with Ma through Stephen Young, director of American Institute in Taiwan, who briefed the Taipei authorities on Ma's visit and through U.S. officials from the White House, the departments of defense and state and the National Security Council, who briefed Lee on Ma's activities in America.
"There is nothing unexpected." Lee said, adding that President George Bush's administration has fully honored its pledge to be transparent in terms of its dealing with Ma's visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT OFFICIAL URGED TO CLARIFY 'ONE CHINA' IN BEIJING

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Honorary Chairman Lien Chan should make clear to Beijing that the party's definition of "one China" refers to the "Republic of China" during his upcoming China visit, a Cabinet official said Wednesday.

Cabinet spokesman Cheng Wen-tsang was referring to the KMT's claim that Taiwan and China reached a consensus in 1992 that both sides can interpret the meaning of "one China" separately. He made the remarks during a news conference held after a weekly Cabinet meeting when asked how the government will react to an upcoming economic forum between the KMT and the Communist Party of China (CPC).

According to Cheng, if Lien recognizes the existence of the ROC and does not negate the legitimacy of the ROC government, he should tell China to stop its diplomatic suppression and military threats against Taiwan.

Cheng reiterated that any matters involving the exercise of government authority must be dominated by the governments on both sides of the Taiwan Strait or organizations authorized by the governments.
Lien, a former vice president, will head a delegation of KMT lawmakers, academics and business executives to attend the first-ever KMT-CPC economic forum slated for April 14-15 in Beijing.
During Lien's previous visit to Beijing, he held a closed-door meeting with Chinese President Hu Jintao. Similar Lien-Hu talks are expected to take place again during Lien's forthcoming visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE MEDICINES MUST COMPLY WITH GMP SYSTEM: DOH

TEXT.P: Producers of Chinese medicines must abide by set procedures and apply for GMP (good manufacturing practice) certification of compliance before they can sell their wares legally in Taiwan, an official of the Department of Health (DOH) said Wednesday.

Lin I-hsin, head of the Committee on Chinese Medicine and Pharmacy under the DOH, made the remarks in response to an appeal by Legislator Tseng Tsang-teng of the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union earlier that day for stricter regulation of illegal Chinese medicines, claiming that such medicine is easily available on the streets or over the Internet.
Lin said that China started to require GMP certification for its medicines three years ago, but still has difficulty in controlling quality.
However, Lin said the DOH "will not rule out the possibility of accepting Chinese applications to export medicines to Taiwan."

He noted that Taiwan has measures governing the application or certification of foreign medicines, adding that if individual pharmaceutical manufacturers in China apply, they should provide full information as well as allowing the Taiwan government to send representatives to inspect their plants.
He stressed that even if China determines that its medicine manufacturers have complied with the GMP system, they will still have to be examined by Taiwan inspectors.

Liao Chi-chou, head of the Bureau of Pharmaceutical Affairs under the DOH, said that no Chinese medicine manufactures have received GMP certification so far and urged people to support Taiwan-produced medicines, which he said are "cheap, safe and effective."

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. TO CONTINUE TO SUPPORT TAIWAN'S WHO BID: ROC REP
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 12 (CNA) (By Jorge Liu and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The U.S. government will continue to offer its support for Taiwan's bid to participate in the World Health Organization (WHO) during this year's annual meeting of the World Health Assembly (WHA) -- the highest decision-making body of the WHO, Republic of China representative to the United States David Ta-wei Lee said Wednesday.

Pointing out that Washington has offered its support for Taiwan over the past three years, Lee said Taiwan's tactics for promoting its WHO bid this year are being discussed by ROC Deputy Minister of Foreign Affairs Michael Ying-mao Kau and David J. Keegan, deputy director of the American Institute in Taiwan's Taipei office.
Lee said the communication is still going on because the two sides have not reached agreement on certain details.

The next WHA annual meeting is scheduled for May 22 in Geneva. Taiwan has been seeking to take part in the meeting as an observer for years, but its bids have been unsuccessful owing to China's opposition.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMOSAT-3 TO BE LAUNCHED APRIL 15: NSPO
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, April 11 (CNA) (By Chu Lu-sheng and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: FORMOSAT-3, Taiwan's third satellite project, is scheduled to be launched from the Vandenberg Air Force Base in California April 15, a project manager from Taiwan's National Space Program Office (NSPO) said Tuesday.

Dr. Chen Cheng-yi, manager of the FORMOSAT-3 project, said that after the satellite is launched into orbit and becomes fully operational, it will provide a powerful databank for climatology and atmospheric research.

The international meteorological community is eagerly awaiting the launch because it will be the world's first climate monitoring and forecasting system using a constellation of six microsatellites to collect atmospheric remote sensing data for operational weather prediction, said Chen.
FORMOSAT-3 is expected to significantly enhance Taiwan's cooperation with the international community, thereby improving Taiwan's international image, he added.

FORMOSAT-3, also known as Constellation Observing System for Meteorology, Ionosphere and Climate (COSMIC) , is an international collaborative project between the NSPO and the United States' University Corporation for Atmospheric Research that began in December 1997.

The satellite's mission will involve the placement of six microsatellites into six different orbits ranging between 700 km and 800 km above the earth's surface, Chen said, adding that the project is an academic research program with the goal of developing an advanced system for real-time monitoring of the globe's climate.
After it becomes fully operational, FORMOSAT-3 will be capable of providing some 2,500 pieces of meteorological data in every 24-hour period, covering all areas of the globe, Chen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Wednesday, gaining NT$0.086 to close at NT$32.532.
A total of US$1.06 billion changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$32.446 and fluctuated between NT$32.385 and NT$32.532.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAISUGAR CAN URGENTLY IMPORT SUGAR IF NEED ARISES: MOEA

TEXT.P: Taiwan is not suffering from a sugar shortage and the state-run Taiwan Sugar Company (Taisugar) can import sugar urgently if the need arises, Vice Economic Affairs Minister Chen Ruey-long said Wednesday.

Chen said that Taiwan consumes an average of 570,000 tons of sugar annually. Taisugar currently supplies around 1,500 tons of white refined sugar per day, more than 1,400 tons of which is to satisfy actual demand.
Taisugar also has no limitations on its supply of liquid or B-grade sugars, which are estimated to have a daily demand of 700 tons.
Even if there is no shortage of sugar on the market, sugar importers could still be reluctant to sell and are sitting on their stocks waiting for a better time to sell amid high world sugar prices.
Chen said Taisugar should keep an eye on the market situation and make necessary adjustments allowing it to import sugar urgently if needed.

The ministry has not prohibited Taisugar from hiking its prices, Chen said, adding that it has only asked Taisugar to act in line with other state-owned enterprises, which is to seek new revenues and to save expenditure.
If there is still a need to reflect world sugar prices, then the ministry will agree to Taisugar's request to raise prices, Chen added.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHIEF UNHAPPY ABOUT RECORDS OF MEETING WITH PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou expressed amazement Wednesday that his dialogue with President Chen Shui-bian early this month has been turned into a monologue of the president kept in the official records of the Presidential Office.

After learning that all of his statements had been erased from the official record of his meeting with Chen on the Presidential Office Web site, Ma joked that it looked he had "evaporated" from the televised meeting.
Ma, who is also mayor of Taipei, made the remarks in reply to Councillor Lan Shih-tsung's interpellation at the city council.

A Presidential Office spokesman said that as a rule, official records of meetings between the president and a visitor always focus on the president's remarks and that those of the Ma-Chen meeting were no exception.
The spokesman noted that the conversation between Ma and Chen was televised and said the presidential staff did not ignore Ma's remarks on purpose.

DOC.HEADLINE: LOCALLY DESIGNED ENERGY-EFFICIENT CAR TO BE UNVEILED

TEXT.P: An energy-efficient car designed by the Industrial Technology Research Institute will be unveiled in Taipei April 15 at a news conference held by the Bureau of Energy under the Ministry of Economic Affairs.

In a press release issued Wednesday, the bureau said the hybrid car powered by gasoline and electricity consumes 10 percent to 15 percent less energy than is required by the national standard and thereby emits less CO2, which is blamed for raising the earth's temperature by trapping heat.

If 10 percent of the country's cars are replaced by this energy-efficient type, the press release predicts, the country could reduce the consumption of gas by 14,000 kiloliters per year and reduce the emissions of CO2 by 35,000 tons per year.
Another advantage of the car is its longer life-cycle, which expands its environment-protection effect.

DOC.HEADLINE: FINANCIAL REFORM TO CONTINUE: EXECUTIVE YUAN

TEXT.P: The government's second phase of financial reform is a policy that is not going to be to halted and the government will be even more scrupulous when implementing it, Vice Premier Tsai Ing-wen said Wednesday.

Tsai made the remarks in response to media reports that the Executive Yuan has won approval from the Presidential Office to put a halt to the second phase of financial reform because of widespread worry that big conglomerates are trying to snatch control of the nation's financial industry.

As to concerns about the process of carrying out the reform, Tsai said that "we are reviewing the issue" but that no conclusion had been reached. "A complete explanation will be made to the public when we have completed our review, " she said during an interview at the Legislative Yuan.

According to the media reports, the government has given up its goal of halving the number of financial holding institutions by the end of the year, but Tsai said the government will not halt the reform program, adding that "we will be more careful when implementing the program."
She said the Executive Yuan will try to bring about a more efficient financial market whose financial institutions will be more competitive.
Her remarks were later quoted by Government Information Minister Cheng Wen-tsan in reply to questions from the media.

The first phase of financial reform consisted of reducing the non-performing loan ratio of domestic banks, while the second phase involves the privatization of state-owned banks and mergers between them, with the goal of halving the number of state-owned banks to six and ensuring that at least three domestic banks increase their market shares to more than 10 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP WANTS CLEAN POLITICS BUREAU IN CENTRAL GOVERNMENT

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) called Wednesday for the establishment of a clean politics bureau in the central government and urged opposition lawmakers to back the proposal and begin screening a draft bill on the issue as soon as possible.
DPP legislative caucus whip Chen Chin-jun made the call at a party meeting with officials from the Ministry of Justice (MOJ), who were reporting on the subject.
Citing the MOJ report, Chen claimed that it is a "world trend" to set up a task force at the central government level to crack down on corruption.

But he pointed out that an organic draft bill on opening a clean politics bureau under the MOJ has been stalled for some time by lawmakers of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP), although the proposal has gained widespread backing from the public. "So far, the progress regarding the issue at the Legislative Yuan has been limited," he noted.

Chen acknowledged that another reason behind the slow progress in the passage of the bill is partly related to a backlash from some Investigation Bureau staff members who are reportedly worrying that the bureau's stewardship of probes into major economic crimes and corruption allegations might be transferred to the new unit.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEARLY HALF WHITE-COLLAR FOREIGNERS IN TAIWAN SKILLED WORKERS: CLA

TEXT.P: More than 70,000 work permits have been issued to foreign white-collar workers since early 2004, nearly half of whom are skilled professionals, the Employment and Vocational Training Administration under the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) reported Wednesday.

Since Jan. 15, 2004 until Feb. 28 this year, the administration issued a total of 70,121 work permits for foreign white-collar workers -- more than 19,200 for Japanese workers, over 9,300 for Americans and more than 7,400 for Canadians, according to administration statistics.

In terms of occupation, more than 33,000 foreign "skilled technicians" got their permits to work in Taiwan during the same period, followed by about 15,900 in the field of "arts, religion and entertainment, " and over 15,800 at foreign language cram schools.
As of the end of February, 27,899 foreign workers still held valid work permits in Taiwan, 7,780 of whom were Japanese, 4,300 of whom were Americans and over 3,200 of whom were Canadians.
Most of the Japanese working in Taiwan are skilled professionals, while the majority of Americans and Canadians are English teachers at private language centers, according to the statistics.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMIC UNION WITH CHINA BEST SERVES TAIWAN'S INTEREST: EX-DPP HEAD
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, April 12 (CNA) (By Chang Ming-kun and S.C. Chang)

TEXT.P: A former chairman of Taiwan's ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) suggested Wednesday that Taiwan and China form an economic union.
"When the two become a country economically, it will best serve Taiwan's economic interests, " said Hsu Hsin-liang, who served as DPP chairman twice, in 1991-1993 and again in 1996-1998.
He made the suggestion during a speech to the faculty and students of Beijing University's School of International Relations.

He said Taiwan enjoys a surplus of US$50 billion annually in trade with China, meaning China has become so important to Taiwan that if it tightens cross-Taiwan Strait trade and economic exchanges, it would not be in the DPP government's interests.
"More than 10 years ago, I was already calling for a 'boldly go-west' policy for Taiwan, because combining Taiwan and China into an economic entity would best serve Taiwan's interests," Hsu said.

He also proposed that direct transportation links across the strait be conducted on a domestic basis because domestic flights are much less costly than international flights and more routes can be flown from Taiwan to China -- Taiwanese would be able to fly directly into 50 Chinese cities.

If Taiwan had adopted his "boldly go-west" proposal, because China's aviation industry is a latecomer on the world stage, Taiwan's China Airlines and EVA Airways might have by now become the world's largest airlines, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Wednesday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index futures for April gained 53 points to close at 6,808, with 53,379 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for May grew 47 points to finish at 6,795, with 3,887 contract transactions, while June futures moved up 43 points to close at 6,765, with 32 contracts traded.
September futures moved up 69 points to finish at 6,600, with 40 contracts traded, while December futures rose 54 points to close at 6,590, with 11 contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Wednesday at 6,755 for April, 6,748 for May, 6,722 for June, 6,540 for September, and 6,536 for December.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also higher.
April TE futures moved up 2.8 points to close at 303.30, with 7,015 contract transactions, while May TE futures grew 2.35 points to finish at 302.35, with 521 contracts traded.
June TE futures surged 2.85 points to finish at 301, with five contracts traded, while September TE futures moved up 1.30 points to close at 293.8, with one contract traded.
No transactions were recorded for December.
April TF futures moved up 4.6 points to close at 892.8, with 2,105 contract transactions, while May TF gained 2.8 points to finish at 891, with 191 contracts traded.
June TF futures lost 8.4 points to close at 885, with one contract traded, while September TF futures grew 4.4 points to finish at 872.4, with 18 contracts traded.
December TF futures moved up 0.4 points to close at 867.8, with three contract transactions.

DOC.HEADLINE: MARSHALL ISLANDS HOPES TO STEP UP FISHERY COOPERATION WITH TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Visiting Marshall Islands President Kessai Note expressed hopes Wednesday of strengthening fishery cooperation with Taiwan.
Note made the remarks when he called on Wang Shun-lung, president of the Taiwan Tuna Association, in Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan.

Note, who arrived in Taiwan Monday for a six-day state visit, noted that he visited the association in 1981 and developed friendships with several fishery officials there. He also visited several aquaculture farms and fishing companies at that time to coordinate the introduction of technology and capital to his country.
He added that the Marshall Islands have had a long-term relationship with the association and expressed hope that the cooperation can be expanded even further.

The waters around the South Pacific island nation are major fishing grounds for Taiwan fishing boats and more than 30 association-affiliated ships are currently operating there, fishing mostly for tuna and bonito. The ships also use the Marshall Islands as a shipping and logistics station.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT BACKS SECOND TRUTH COMMITTEE IF IT IS LAWFUL

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian would fully support the formation of a second truth investigation committee to probe the March 2004 election-eve shooting, as long as the task force is legal and constitutional, a Presidential Office spokesman said Wednesday.

Stressing that Chen is more eager than anyone else to know the facts behind the March 19 shooting of himself and Vice President Annette Lu while they were campaigning in southern Tainan city, the spokesman said that the president is also willing to cooperate with an investigation into the incident by the committee in line with the country's constitutional system.

The Presidential Office's remarks came after the opposition-controlled Legislative Yuan approved an amendment to the Organic Statute for the 319 Shooting Truth Investigation Commission Tuesday, allowing the legislature to set up a 17-member panel -- the second of its kind -- to probe the shooting.

Each political party is allowed to recommend members, who cannot be either legislators or Control Yuan members, to form the task force in proportion to the number of legislative seats the party controls.

Lawmakers of the "pan green camp" of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and the Taiwan Solidarity Union walked out of the Tuesday meeting in protest before "pan blue alliance" lawmakers voted on the passage of the law amendment.
Claiming that the second truth committee is still unconstitutional, the "pan green" lawmakers said that they will ask the Council of Grand Justices to give a ruling on its constitutionality.
The first truth investigation committee set up by the Legislative Yuan was dissolved after the Council of Grand Justices ruled in December 2004 that its establishment was unconstitutional.

The election-eve shooting prior to the March 20, 2004 presidential election is believed by many "pan blue alliance" supporters to have been staged by Chen to garner sympathy votes to help him win re-election.

After grueling investigations, prosecutors in charge closed the investigation of the case last August amid strong criticism after indirectly accusing Chen Yi-hsiung of being the mastermind behind the shooting without producing hard evidence.
Chen was found drowned in Amping Harbor in Tainan city around 10 days after the incident.

DOC.HEADLINE: DISCIPLINED PROSECUTOR URGED TO CONTINUE DUTIES

TEXT.P: Vice Justice Minister Lee Chin-yung said Wednesday that the ministry hopes Lee Tzu-chun, a prosecutor in Hualien, will continue to execute his duties faithfully despite having been disciplined.
Lee Chin-yung made the remarks after the Hualien Prosecutor's Office convened a disciplinary meeting at the request of the ministry and decided to mete out two minor demerits to Lee Tzu-chun.

The decision came one day after Lee joined around 1,000 demonstrators outside the Legislative Yuan when lawmakers were reviewing whether to endorse Hseih Wen-ting's nomination as the nation's top prosecutor. Opposition legislators vetoed Hsieh as the state public prosecutor-general in a vote.

Participants in the disciplinary meeting discussed Lee Tzu-chun's participation and a speech he made to the demonstrators and meted out the punishment on the grounds that Lee violated the public functionary service law and guidelines for prosecutors.
Lee Tzu-chun said that he will not appeal the decision.
"The ministry is gratified that the Hualien Prosecutor's Office responded quickly to the concerns of society over Lee Tzu-chun's behavior and made the decision," Lee Chin-yung said.
He said that though Lee Tzu-chun was disciplined, the ministry is not disappointed in him and hopes he will continue to be faithful to his duty and take into consideration the image of his office.

Lee Tzu-chun became an instant celebrity when he summoned President Chen Shui-bian last year to testify before him in a probe into an alleged vote-buying case involving a candidate of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party for Hualien county magistrate. The outspoken prosecutor has recently appeared on TV political commentary program to criticize the government.

DOC.HEADLINE: NPA, CLA VOW TO CRACK DOWN ON ILLEGAL FOREIGN WORKERS

TEXT.P: The National Police Agency (NPA) and the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) have launched a crackdown on illegal foreign workers, a spokesman for the NPA said Wednesday.
The spokesman said the action is aimed at protecting the rights of legal employers whose interests are being harmed by illegal brokers, employers and workers.

The remarks were made in the wake of the arrest Tuesday of a group of 40 absconded foreign workers by the Keelung police authorities. The workers were sent to a detention center for foreigners in Sanhsia to await deportation.

NPA statistics show that 23,574 foreign workers had absconded from their legal employers as of the end of March. The spokesman said foreign workers who have left their legal jobs are often exploited by their new employers.

The NPA urged legal foreign workers not to be tempted by illegal jobs and urged employers not to hire illegal foreign workers, warning that doing so could lead to fines of up to NT$750,000 (US$23,437).

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Iran Reports Big Advance in Enrichment of Uranium
Iran announced Tuesday that its nuclear engineers had advanced to a new phase in the enrichment of uranium, and President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad and a series of the country's ruling clerics declared that the nation would now speed ahead, in defiance of a United Nations Security Council warning, to produce nuclear fuel on an industrial scale. The declaration comes at a time of intense speculation in Washington that preliminary plans are advancing to take military action against Iran's nuclear sites if diplomacy fails, an idea Secretary of Defense Donald H. Rumsfeld dismissed Tuesday as "fantasy land."
Wall Street Journal: As the Price of Gasoline Takes Off, Oil and Auto Firms Trade Barbs
With consumers again facing rising gasoline prices, the two industries most often blamed for the energy crunch -- oil and auto companies -- are trading potshots over who is at fault.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLOUD GATE 2 TO PERFORM LO MAN-FEI'S LAST CHOREOGRAPHIC WORK

TEXT.P: Cloud Gate 2 Dance Theatre will perform late choreographer Lo Man-fei's last work in its annual presentation with Lo's proud student Sheu Fang-yi playing a leading role, the troupe announced Wednesday in Taipei.

"Pursuing the Dream," the last work directed by well-known choreographer and dancer Lo Man-fei, who died of lung cancer March 24, will be one of three programs in Cloud Gate 2's Spring Gathering 2006.

Lo, one of the most important figures in Asian dance and a New York University graduate, began her professional career in 1974 and continued her training at different schools, including the Martha Graham School. In 1979, she joined Cloud Gate Dance Theatre of Taiwan and was appointed artistic director of Cloud Gate 2 in 1999.
Cloud Gate 2 was founded in 1999 to foster young choreographers, and to tour campuses and grass-root communities in Taiwan. The dancers range in age from 18 to 25.

"It means a lot to me to play the lead role in [Lo's] last work," said Sheu, who is the first Taiwanese principle dancer in the prestigious Martha Graham Dance Troupe and one of Lo's favorite students. She will play the role of Tu Li-niang, the love-struck female who is willing to live or die for love.
It also means a lot to Sheu to dance in her hometown. The dance presentation premieres April 29 in Yilan, where Sheu grew up and dreamt of being a professional dancer as a young girl.
Lo's last piece was also her first collaboration with her New York-based elder sister Sophie Lo. The elder Lo, a singer, will perform Chinese traditional Kunqu opera during the program.

Sheu's long-time boyfriend Bularayang Pagarlava, a Paiwan Aborigine and up-and-coming choreographer in Taiwan, also made his presence felt in the show by his work "Gloaming." The third program is "A Dignified Joke," choreographed by Cheng Tung-lung.
The Spring Gathering 2006 will be performed April 29-30 in Yilan, May 4-7 in Taipei, May 20 in Kaohsiung and May 27 in Taichung. Ticket information is available at www.artstickets.com.tw.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER KRTC CHAIRMAN, INCUMBENT MANAGER INDICTED

TEXT.P: Former chairman Chen Chen-jung, vice chairman Chen Min-hsien and current General Manager Fan Chen-po of Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp. (KRTC) and three others were indicted Wednesday on charges of breach of trust for involvement in illegally contracting out public art projects to an American company.

Kaohsiung District Court's prosecutors were also indicting project manager Chou Yu-chu, former KRTC general manager Lai Hsien-yu and KRTC Deputy General Manager Hsu Ying-hsiung for their suspected roles in doling out a NT$185 million contract for installing public art at 37 rapid transit stations in the southern Taiwan port city.

The prosecution said Chou Yu-chu, an in-law of Chen Min-hsien who stands accused in other KRTC scandals, had not followed legal procedures in awarding the contract to Derix Art Glass Consults of the U.S. and ignored the city government's demand to submit documents for screening.

Because of her special relationship with Chen Min-hsien, a key KRTC player at the time, Chou had changed the contents of the public art contract and then sought approval from Chen and Hsu, the incumbent top executives of KRTC, according to the indictment.
As of Jan. 10 this year, according to the prosecutors, KRTC had awarded contracts worth NT$143 million for installing public works of art, of which NT$73 million has been paid.
Chen Min-hsien has been indicted on charges of breach of trust in connection with a Thai workers' riot last August which led to a spate of corruption and law-breaking charges.

DOC.HEADLINE: DANCER SHEU FANG-YI REMINISCES ABOUT HER LATE MENTOR LO MAN-FEI

TEXT.P: Dancing without hearing the instruction and compliments of a great teacher and friend takes a while to get used to, Martha Graham Dance Troupe principle dancer Sheu Fang-yi said Wednesday in reminiscing about Lo Man-fei, who passed away in late March.

Well-known choreographer and dancer Lo Man-fei, who died of lung cancer March 24, was Sheu's teacher and instructor since Sheu's freshman year in college. Sheu said the 15-year relationship "felt more like being friends" rather than a teacher/student relationship.

"I miss her voice, instruction, compliments and that simple gaze. She is always like a proud mother who would tell everyone that her daughter is the best dancer. I get confidence from her confidence in me," Sheu said while trying to fight back tears.

Lo's confidence in Sheu was not blind faith. Sheu, who left Taiwan in 1995 to pursue her dancing career in the U.S., has been rated by U.S. "Dance Magazine" as among the 25 most talented dancers of 2005.
Sheu also received the Order of the Brilliant Star from President Chen Shui-bian in May 2005 and was one of the "Top Ten Rising Stars" selected by CNA in 2006.

"She is always a person who looks at the bright side of life. It seems to me there's nothing she can't handle. As late as last December, when her condition was worsening, she still worked with me and the troupe every day -- and looked energetic," Sheu said.

Playing the lead role in Lo's last choreographic work brings mixed feelings for Sheu. She feels proud to perform Lo's work but has to control her emotions carefully because the dance makes her think of Lo.
For now, Sheu plans to keep dancing. In the future she wants to be involved in choreography and production, just like Lo.
"To carry on her legacy," Sheu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA IS HURDLE TO CROSS-STRAIT EXCHANGES: OFFICIALS

TEXT.P: China's vacillation has been the greatest hurdle toward the realization of regular charter flights across the Taiwan Strait, Government Information Office Minister Cheng Wen-tsang said Wednesday.

Cheng quoted Premier Su Tseng-chang as having made the comments during a weekly Executive Yuan meeting, during which the premier was briefed by Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) officials on the current situation in cross-strait exchanges.

According to Cheng, Su also asked relevant agencies in charge of cross-strait exchange issues to avoid creating the misunderstanding that it is Taiwan's government that does not wish to open the services.

Since 2001, the government has been ready to address issues such as Chinese tourism in Taiwan, agricultural exports to China and opening direct passenger and cargo charter flights between the two sides, Cheng said.

For instance, Cheng said, the government has never banned Taiwan's agricultural and fruit exports to China despite the small amount of trade. Last year, Taiwan's agricultural and fruit exports to China accounted for only 0.17 percent of total volume, he added.

In opening direct cross-strait charter flights on weekends or holidays, China insists that carriers must fly over the Hong Kong Information Zone, totally ignoring the MAC's proposals involving other options in neighboring countries, such as the Inchon Information Zone in South Korea or the Okinawa Information Zone in Japan.

On the other hand, China has been trying hard to stall bilateral negotiations and delay cross-strait exchanges by imposing many strict thresholds, he said, pointing out that China's flip-flops are the major reason behind broader two-way exchanges.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHILD ABUSE, CHILD MURDER CASES A 'NATIONAL DISGRACE': PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang said Wednesday that any case involving child abuse or parents murdering their children before taking their own lives is a national disgrace.
Su made the remarks at a weekly Cabinet meeting after being briefed on the nation's child protection mechanism.

Noting that child protection is an integral part of social security and care for the disadvantaged, Su said the Ministry of the Interior must cooperate closely with local governments in identifying children prone to fall victim to abuse or domestic violence and offer them timely assistance.

Medical personnel and police authorities should also never hesitate or delay in reporting any suspected child abuse case to relevant social welfare agencies, Su said, adding that judicial authorities should mete out harsh punishment to abusers or perpetrators in accordance with the law.

"If we can craft a sound and comprehensive system for child abuse risk assessment, prevention, reporting and supervision, we'll be able to better protect our youngsters and offer them better opportunities to grow up and enrich their life," Su said.

Social activism is also important in child protection, Su said, adding that neighbors, classmates and schools can play an active role in helping children in need. He cited a recent case in which a junior high school principal mobilized all faculty members and students to search for a dropout and have eventually persuaded him to continue his studies.
"They are all the benefactor of this student. I hope all of us can follow suit in helping troubled children, " the premier added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR MA HOSTS PARTY FOR ANMC21 REPRESENTATIVES

TEXT.P: The 5th Plenary Meeting of the Asian Network of Major Cities 21 (ANMC21) will be held from April 13th to 16th in Taipei.
Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou hosted Wednesday night a welcome party for guests and delegations from Asian cities, including Tokyo Mayor Shintaro Ishihara, in Far Eastern International Hotel.
"Every delegation should squeeze into their tight and busy schedules the chance to enjoy the Taipei experience," Ma said.
When Ma shook hands and had a friendly chat with Ishihara, they became the focus of a media spotlight.
The main theme of ANMC21 is "Asia in Transformation." The fourth plenary of ANMC21 was held in Jakarta last year.

The opening ceremony for cultural events will be held Thursday morning in Far Eastern International Hotel, followed by "Feeling the Pulse of the World" by Taipei Sun Son Theatre and "Folk and Traditional Dance" from Bangkok in the afternoon at Taipei's World Trade Center (TWTC) Hall 2.

A number of traditional performance groups, including the Taipei Clown Group, Wild Fire Music Troupe, Japan's Shishmai and Wadaiko, Indonesia's Jakarta City Performance Troupe among others will also perform at TWTC Hall 2.
The ANMC21 features five themes during four-day event-- Joint projects of ANMC21, Information Asia, Tourism Asia, Healthy Lifestyle Asia, and Handicraft and Cuisine Asia. (Timothy Hwang)

DOC.HEADLINE: NCC ALLOWS EASTERN MEDIA 'S CHANNEL' TO OPERATE ON CONDITIONS

TEXT.P: The National Communications Commission (NCC) decided Wednesday to allow Eastern Multimedia Group's S channel to resume operation on certain conditions.

The channel was shut down last year after the Government Information Office found the news channel was not broadcasting enough news programs and had received too many fines for breaking broadcasting rules.
The NCC, which took over part of the GIO's business, reviewed the company's appeal and decided the news channel's rule-breaking record was not that serious, although it did require improvement.
The NCC demanded the channel put forth a feasible plan of action on improving its operations or apply for a different license within a month.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP CALLS FOR AN END TO OBSTRUCTIONISM

TEXT.P: Ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Yu Shyi-kun urged the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) Wednesday to drop its obstructionist tactics, arguing that political infighting will lead nowhere.
Yu made the call a day after the opposition-controlled Legislative Yuan vetoed the president's nominee for the nation's top prosecutor by a margin of four votes.

"Yesterday was a dark day in our country's democratic development as our popularly elected legislature lost respect and its self-control by failing to confirm the appointment of a well-qualified judicial figure to the top prosecutorial post while passing an unconstitutional bill," Yu said.

Yu lamented that while some opposition lawmakers are now preoccupied with making unfounded accusations against senior government officials, their colleagues have continued to freeze the government budget and boycott critical bills, including a long-stalled U.S. arms procurement package.

"After virtually 'eradicating' the Control Yuan more than a year ago, the opposition again boycotted the appointment of the top prosecutor while refusing to unfreeze the budgets for the Executive Yuan and the Examination Yuan. I'm afraid our five-branch government is on the brink of paralysis," Yu regretted.

Noting that the golden credo of democracy lies in rational debate on major policy issues, Yu said the opposition "pan-blue alliance" should not scuttle any sensible discussion of crucial public issues.

As the ruling party, Yu said the DPP is obligated to carry out self-examination and self-improvement according to the highest moral standards. At the same time, Yu said he hopes the opposition will cooperate with the DPP in forging a political setting favorable for rational and sensible debate on major policy issues.

Despite the opposition's refusal to endorse the appointment of Hsieh Wen-ting as the state public prosecutor-general, the DPP legislative caucus urged President Chen Shui-bian to nominate Hsieh to the post again lest Hsieh become a pawn of domestic political infighting.

Chen Chin-jun, a DPP legislative whip, said Hsieh is well-qualified for the top prosecutorial post in trms of both professional capabilities and character. Against this backdrop, Chen said he is hopeful that the president can nominated Hsieh again.
In a statement issued after the legislature's veto, Hsieh said he would not accept a second nomination for whatever reason since his nomination has been turned down by the legislature.
Meanwhile, representatives from civil groups promoting judicial reforms criticized the opposition camp for rejecting Hiseh simply on their own political affiliations.
Chen Chih-ming, president of the Prosecutors Reform Foundation, said that political manipulation of the vote would damage judicial independence.

Legislator Yeh Yi-jin, also a DPP legislative whip, said KMT and PFP lawmakers wanted a state public prosecutor-general who is partisan because in Tuesday's vote, they received ballots yet intentionally surrendered their voting rights and even assembled a crowd to riot outside the legislature.

Yeh further said she felt sorry that opposition PFP Chairman James Soong had capitulated to demonstrators led by a TV talk-show host, who threatened to "obliterate Soong from the world" if the PFP caucus endorsed Hsieh's appointment.

In Tuesday's vote, Hsieh received four "yes" votes from the "pan-blue" or independent lawmakers. As the vote was conducted by secret ballot, the identity of the supposed "renegade" lawmakers was the source of medial speculation.
KMT Legislator Chen Chieh didn't cast his ballot, saying that he felt the decision by the KMT caucus to cast blank votes was "unthinkable."

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR APRIL 13 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Thursday, April 13:
10:00, President Chen Shui-bian will attend the opening ceremony for an Asian city network conference to be held at Far Eastern Plaza Hotel.
10:00, AIT Taipei Office Director Stephen Young will pay a visit to DPP Chairman Yu Shyi-kun at the party's headquarters.
10:30, The Ministry of Foreign affairs will hold a news briefing.
11:00, President Chen will receive a delegation from the Tokyo city council.
14:00, Vice Premier Tsai Ing-wen will attend an award presentation ceremony for volunteer lawyers for the Straits Exchange Foundation.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA CHECKS REPORT ABOUT SENSITIVE MACHINE TOOL EXPORT TO CHINA

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said Wednesday it will look into a media report that China has used Taiwan-made cutting-edge machine tools to manufacture missile components and parts.

The Japanese economic daily Nihon Keizai Shimbun reported in its Wednesday edition that China used scores of ultra-sophisticated numerical controlled (NC) machine tools purchased from Taiwan to manufacturer stainless steel missile components and parts in the second half of last year.

Responding to the report, Chen Chao-yi, director of the MOEA's Industrial Development Bureau, said the bureau has not yet received any relevant information about the reported NC machine tool export to China.
"We'll cooperate with our overseas representative offices in inquiring into the truth or details of the report," Chen said.
Huang Chih-peng, director of the MOEA's Board of Foreign Trade, said the international community has formulated strict regulations on trade in strategic high-tech products.

"We have also had a set of rules governing export and import of sensitive high-tech goods. Outbound shipment of controlled items has been subjected to stringent regulations," Huang said, adding that the United States and Japan have often provided relevant information to help Taiwan rein in exports of strategic high-tech products.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT PRESIDES OVER EMERGENCY RESPONSE DRILL

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian presided over a contingency response drill Wednesday night.

National Security Council Secretary-General Chiou I-jen said the drill was designed to test the response of various administrative and military units in case the nation encountered emergencies or dreaded situations.
The drill was also aimed at assessing inter-departmental coordination in the event of contingencies, Chiou said.
The two-and-half-hour drill proceeded smoothly, practicing operations in dealing with simulated contingencies, Chiou said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, April 13, or the 16th day of the third month of the Year of the Dog according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1732: Frederick North, the English prime minister who introduced the Tea Act that led to the "Boston Tea Party," is born. His policies finally led to Britain's loss of America.
1743: Thomas Jefferson, the third president of the United States, is born. He drafted the Declaration of Independence in 1776. His presidency was marked by the purchase of the Louisiana Territory from France in 1803 and the Tripolitan War from 1801 to 1805.
1862: France and Annam (now Vietnam) sign the Treaty of Shanghai, annexing the province of Cochin China to France.
1898: Prompted by the success of the Meiji Reformation in Japan, Kang Yu-wei initiates a reform movement and submits a report to Emperor Kuang Hsu of China's Ching dynasty, requesting government reformation.
1904: In the Russo-Japanese War, a mine sinks the flagship of the Russian fleet at Port Arthur (Lushun) in northeastern China, killing 600.
1906: Samuel Beckett, Irish dramatist and winner of the Nobel Prize for Literature in 1969, is born.
1919: British troops under the command of Brig. Gen. Dyer open fire on some 380 followers of Mohandas K. Gandhi in an incident known as the Amritsar massacre.
1939: Italian dictator Benito Mussolini's forces invade Albania.
1941: Japan and the Soviet Union sign the Soviet-Japanese Neutrality Pact in Moscow.
1945: Allied bombers launch massive bombing raids over Japan, destroying a large part of Tokyo.
1960: The construction of an atomic reactor at Taiwan's National Tsinghwa University in Hsinchu, the first of its kind in Southeast Asia, is completed.
1964: Sidney Poitier wins an Oscar for his performance in Ralph Nelson's "The Lilies of the Field," becoming the first black actor to receive the award.
1966: Iraq's President Abdul Salam Arif is killed in a helicopter crash.
1978: Communist China and Portugal formally sign a "joint statement" that clears the way for the return of Macao to Beijing on Dec. 20, 1999.
1980: Twenty-three-year-old Spanish golfer Severiano Ballesteros becomes the first European and also the youngest person ever to win the U.S. Masters in Augusta, Georgia.
1982: U.S. Secretary of State Alexander Haig returns to Washington following failed attempts in London and Buenos Aires to settle the Falkland Islands dispute.
1988: Hainan Island becomes the 23rd province and the fourth "special economic region" of mainland China under communist rule.
1990: The Soviet Union admits that its secret police was responsible for the 1940 systematic murder of 1,500 Polish army officers at Katyn, Poland.
1995: The Ukraine agrees to close the Chernobyl nuclear reactor by 2000.
1995: Lang Chin-shan, known as "China's father of photography," dies at the age of 104.
1999: Willi Stoph, chairman of the Council of Ministers of the former German Democratic Republic, dies at the age of 84.
2000: The World Trade Organization ranks Taiwan as the world's 14th-largest exporting country and the 15th largest importing country in terms of merchandise in 1999.
2000: The International Monetary Fund ranks the people of Taiwan as the 18th richest people in the world, with the nation's annual per capita income based on purchasing power parity expected to reach US$16,854 in 2000.
2001: U.S. Congressman David Wu (D-OR) arrives in the Republic of China at the head of a four-member delegation making a five-day visit.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Where there is affection, exertion is made easy; where there is disinterest, instruction will be neglected."

DOC.HEADLINE: EDITOR'S NOTE:Subscribers who used CEP 0007, sent April 12 with theheadline 'TAIWAN RANKS 17TH IN WORLD IN TRADE FOR 2005: WTO'and the dateline 'Geneva, April 11' are asked to use the followingstory.
DOC.TEXT:
In a April 12 story about Taiwan's foreign trade ranking in the world, the CNA reported erroneously that Taiwan ranked 17th for 2005.
Taiwan ranked 16th in the world for 2005, up one notch from its 2004 ranking of 17th.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORUM AIMED AT FINDING NEW WAYS TO RE-ENERGIZE TAIWAN'S ECONOMY: LIEN

TEXT.P: Main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Honorary Chairman Lien Chan said before leaving for China Thursday that the forum his delegation is attending there is aimed at finding a new way to revitalize Taiwan's trade and economy.
Lien is leading a group of legislators, business leaders and academics to attend the first "KMT-Communist Party of China Trade and Economic Forum" scheduled for April 14-15 in Beijing.
When there are difficulties in cross-Taiwan Strait dialogue at the official level, "we must boldly face the reality and try to seek a breakthrough," Lien said.
He pointed out that Taiwan's trade and economic performances have slipped in recent years to the bottom among Asia's "four dragons" which include South Korea, Hong Kong and Singapore.
As the industries in Taiwan and in China are "highly complementary, " he warned that great harm could be done to Taiwan's economy if no efforts are made to boost cross-strait economic cooperation.
On the other hand, he added, a "win-win situation" can be created if cooperation can be strengthened between the two sides of the strait under the trend of globalization.

He said the KMT, its legislative caucus and many private-sector business leaders as well as trade and financial experts have made great efforts to help expand Taiwan's trade and economic ties with China, but regrettably, the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) government has not done its share of the job, causing "a lot of harm" to Taiwan's economy.

He stressed that because of the impasse in official dialogue across the strait, his delegation will try to act as a bridge in cross-strait communications and find ways to create another economic miracle for Taiwan.
Besides attending the Beijing forum, Lien will pay tribute to his ancestors enshrined in his ancestral home in Zhangzhou, Fujian Province. Lien is a ninth-generation immigrant in Taiwan.

DOC.TEXT:
