DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Moscow Times: Shtokman Linked to WTO Fight
Russia appears to be signaling to U.S. officials that if it is not admitted to the WTO , American firms will be barred from taking part in the Shtokman natural gas project. Two sources who spoke to senior Russian officials said the implicit quid pro quo has emerged in the last month. ( By Chang Hung-kuang)

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Manila Bulletin: Solemn Holy Thursday set today
Christendom today will observe Holy or Maundy Thursday, a significant day for the believers in Jesus Christ because it marks the beginning of events that laid the basis for many rites and core belief of the Christian faith.
The Philippine Daily Inquirer: AFP clears four generals
THE MUCH-AWAITED military fact-finding report on the "Hello Garci" scandal has cleared three generals accused of conspiring to rig the 2004 elections in President Gloria Macapagal-Arroyo's favor.
The Philippine Star: Opposition: Cha-cha to make impeaching GMA impossible
The opposition in the House of Representatives warned the nation yesterday that Cha-cha (Charter change) would make ousting President Arroyo through the impeachment process impossible.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
: The Straits Times: KL axes plan to replace Causeway.
Malaysia yesterday said it was abandoning its plans to build a bridge to replace the Causeway, a move that caught officials and observers in both Malaysia and Singapore by surprise.
The Lianhe Zaobao: Malaysia drops plans for new bridge to Singapore.
Malaysia's Prime Minister Datuk Seri Abdullah Ahmad Badawi said yesterday in a statement that Malaysia Government was abandoning its plans to build a new bridge across the Johor Straits to replace the Causeway to Singapore.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Japan Times Cops blew probe into abduction,court says
A district court ruled Wednesday that the Tochigi Prefectural Police mishandled an investigation into a 1999 abduction in which the victim was eventually murdered.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Los Angeles Times: Iran Flaunts Its Nuclear Achievement.
President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad on Tuesday announced success in Iran's efforts to enrich uranium and he demanded respect for the nation's right to peaceful atomic energy, upping the ante in Tehran's dispute with the West about its nuclear program.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACTING MAYOR SEEKS TO BUILD KAOHISUNG INTO 'TAIWAN'S SHANGRI-LA'

TEXT.P: Acting Kaohsiung Mayor Yeh Chu-lan called on citizens of the southern port city to join her in making their town into "Taiwan's Shangri-la" where politicians do not engage in dogfights and people have "beautiful minds" and enjoy a peaceful and prosperous life.

Delivering her administrative report to the city council, Yeh said the government team she is leading has been working to build their city as "the ocean capital" of Taiwan where fragrant flowers bloom under bright sunshine and cultural activities demonstrating what she called "Taiwan spirit" are frequently staged.
Her government is kicking off a "love Kaohsiung" campaign calling on the residents to "love work, love sports and love cleanliness, " she said.

Yeh outlined her 12 administrative priorities, including promoting industrial development, building an all-serving traffic network, creating a harmonious urban ecology, building a social safety net, and encouraging life-time learning.

Efforts will also be made to prepare for hosting the 2009 World Games, to promote international cooperation and exchanges, to implement the policies of multiculturalism as well as of encouraging cultural creativity, Yeh said.
An election will be held late this year to choose her replacement and members of the city council.

DOC.HEADLINE: CIP HEAD SUPPORTS REFERENDUM ON ABORIGINAL CONSTITUENCY ISSUE

TEXT.P: Council of Indigenous Peoples (CIP) Minister Walis Pelin said Thursday that he supports the holding of a referendum on aboriginal constituency demarcation.

Walis Pelin noted that while the Constitution stipulates that the indigenous peoples should be taken as a whole in constituency demarcation, election laws in effect separate the indigenous population into two electorates, "plains aboriginals" and "mountains aboriginals." Since the law contradicts the constitution, he said he supports the referendum proposed by the Saisiyat tribal council to amend the error.
Walis Pelin claimed that ending the practice of separating the indigenous population into plains aboriginals and mountains aboriginals is the general will of all the aboriginal peoples in Taiwan.

The dispute over the issue of indigenous constituency demarcation has been going on for years. However, it was only recently that the Saisiyat tribal council proposed the holding of a referendum to resolve the issue.

A CIP official admitted that "separating the indigenous constituency into plains aboriginals and mountains aboriginals is unsuitable, " adding that the government made the decision in 1956 "for its convenience."

DOC.HEADLINE: AIT DIRECTOR PRAISES TAIWAN'S DEMOCRACY

TEXT.P: American Institute in Taiwan Director Stephen M. Young praised Taiwan's democracy when he met with Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Yu Shyi-kun Thursday.

"We talked about the progress Taiwan has made in democracy in the past few years, and it is a very precious achievement. I want to congratulate the DPP and the people in Taiwan on their contributions. This is Taiwan's most precious issue on the international stage, " Young said.
Young said that he and Yu talked about bilateral relations and the development of the DPP and other parties, adding that the United States welcomes the continuing exchanges with Taiwan.

Young visited Yu at the DPP party headquarters for about one-and-a-half hours Wednesday morning. Besides bilateral ties, the two also touched on cross-strait issues, but both declined to go into detail about their meeting when the press made inquiries afterwards.
Yu said that Young is an old friend and that they met when the DPP was still the opposition party, when Yu was the Yilan County magistrate. Yu said he was happy to see Young again.

Since assuming his duties as the AIT director March 18, Young has been meeting intensively with local political leaders, including President Chen Shui-bian, Premier Su Tseng-chang, Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng, and KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP ACCUSES KMT OF BECOMING TOOL OF CHINA'S UNITED FRONT TACTICS

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) accused the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Thursday of reducing itself to the position of "China's tool" to carry out Beijing's united front tactics against Taiwan for holding an economic forum with the Communist Party of China (CPC).

Arguing that Beijing should discuss cross-Taiwan Strait economic issues with the government of Taiwan, DPP legislative caucus whip Chen Chin-jun said Beijing is attempting to isolate Taiwan's government by holding talks with an opposition party.

Chen pointed out that Taiwan has allowed the export of agricultural products to China and in 2001 announced a policy of allowing visits to Taiwan by Chinese tourists but that Beijing has repeatedly ignored Taiwan's request for cross-strait negotiations to map out related measures.

Chen said it is "perplexing" that the KMT is cooperating unconditionally with China while the party has constantly obstructed the personnel nominations and budget proposals put forth by the DPP government.

KMT Honorary Chairman Lien Chan, who is a former vice president, left for China earlier in the day to attend the first-ever KMT-CPC economic forum slated for April 14-15 in Beijing. He is heading a delegation of KMT lawmakers, academics and business executives.
During the visit, Lien is expected to hold talks with Chinese President Hu Jintao.

Also Thursday, DPP Legislator Wu Ming-min urged Lien not to make any concessions to Beijing that would lead to a loss of capital, technology or talent in Taiwan's agricultural sector, that would allow China to dump its agricultural products in Taiwan, or that would ruin the livelihood of Taiwan's farmers.
Wu claimed that China has picked up Taiwan's agricultural technology after Taiwan exported its agricultural products to China.

According to Wu, a lot of China-produced fruits are now being sold under the name of Taiwan, and Taiwan's agricultural trade with China posted a deficit of NT$6.7 billion (US$206.15 million) last year because their competitiveness was brought down by expensive exportation costs.

After acquiring Taiwan's agricultural technology, China has begun dumping its agricultural products in Taiwan through channels such as the "mini three-links" and smuggling activities, Wu claimed, adding that China's agricultural products are also competing with Taiwan's products in the U.S. and Japanese markets.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN BLASTS CHINA'S INTERFERENCE IN TAIPEI HOSTING ANMC21 MEETING

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian lambasted China Thursday for its "forceful political intervention" that thwarted the 4th Plenary Meeting of the Asian Network of Major Cities 21 (ANMC21) in Jakarta in 2004, causing a suspension of the 2005 annual meeting.
Chen fired his accusation while speaking at the opening ceremony of the 5th Plenary of the ANMC21, which was hosted by Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou. The meeting will last until April 16.
In a keynote speech, Chen said the ANMC21, initiated by Tokyo Mayor Shintaro Ishihara in August 2000, has 12 country members from Asia, giving a special meaning to all Asian countries.
Chen said that in 2004, Beijing joined a race with Taipei to win the right to host the 5th ANMC21 meeting, using all sorts of political maneuvering to block Taipei from hosting the meeting in 2006.

Chen noted that in spite of an agreement reached by the ANMC21, China opposed including Taipei's right to host the 2006 annual meeting in the agreement. Nevertheless, because of Ishihara's decisive intervention to mediate, the 5th Plenary of the ANMC21 is being held, he said.

The president recalled a similar unhappy incident when he served as mayor of Taipei. Chen noted that China did all it could to erect obstacles to Taipei's hosting of a meeting of the International Union of Local Authorities as well as the World Capitals Forum in May 1998.
In spite of China's hard work to stop its allies from sending delegates to Taipei, 70 cities from 67 countries, including 61 capitals, were represented in the 1998 conference in Taipei.

Chen's presence at the ANMC21 function marked the first time he has met with Ma, who is also chairman of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) , since their meeting earlier this month at the Presidential Office which attracted the media's spotlight.

Ma hosted Wednesday night a welcome party for guests and delegations from Asian cities, including the Tokyo mayor and representatives from Bangkok, New Delhi, Singapore, Seoul, Kuala Lumpur, Jakarta, Hanoi, Manila and Yangon at the Far Eastern International Hotel.

Under the main theme of "Asia in Transformation, " five themes will be featured during four-day event -- namely Joint projects of the ANMC21, Information Asia, Tourism Asia, Healthy Lifestyle Asia, and Handicraft and Cuisine Asia.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened high and closed higher Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 47.24 points to close at 6,855.74.
The bourse opened at 6,850.19 and fluctuated between 6,868.74 and 6,828.95 during trading. A total of 4.51 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$130.77 billion (US$4.02 billion).

Seven of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with construction issues moving up the most at 4.9 percent, followed by banking and financial shares at 2 percent, paper and pulp issues at 1.4 percent, foodstuff issues at 1.2 percent, cement stocks at 0.8 percent, machinery and electronics shares at 0.3 percent, and plastics and chemicals shares at 0.2 percent.
Textile stocks remained unchanged.
Gainers outnumbered losers 625 to 297, with 121 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Berlusconi: there are election frauds.
Premier Silvio Berlusconi said Wednesday that there were frauds in the just-concluded parliamentary elections. There were irregularities in polling booths around the nation, he said. He is mulling over an appeal for an over-all recount of votes.

DOC.HEADLINE: NSC CONDUCTS EXERCISE TO HONE TAIWAN'S RESPONSE CAPABILITIES

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian presided over a regular political and military exercise Wednesday aimed at honing the country's ability to respond in several crisis scenarios, a Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) spokesman said Thursday.

The political and military exercise, dubbed the "Yushan No. 2, " was conducted to examine the Taiwan military, political and security authorities' response capabilities in the event of the Chinese president being assassinated during a visit abroad and Taiwan being fingered as the culprit, and in the event of China launching a surprise missile attack on Taiwan's political and economic "nerve centers," MOFA spokesman Michel Lu said.

Lu said that in the exercise, the MOFA chose to strengthen communications with the international community and seek help from the United Nations as well as Taiwan's neighboring countries in response to the scenarios.

The exercise began at 7: 50 p.m. Wednesday after an emergency order was directed to all top level officials from the Presidential Office, the Cabinet and the National Security Council, with President Chen as chief commander, according to Lu.
The exercise, mainly conducted at the Yuanshan Command Center near Taipei's Tachih district, lasted about two hours.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW CD RECYCLING TECHNOLOGY COULD SAVE MILLIONS

TEXT.P: A research laboratory at Far East College announced Thursday their latest achievement in developing compact disc (CD) recycling technology.
Dr. Chen Chia-hsun, the head of the laboratory, said that once applied, the improved technology can retrieve raw materials from junkyards worth up to NT$700 million per year.

Chen Chia-hsun said there are more than one billion CDs used per year in Taiwan, with most winding up in refuse dumps. But if the polymer composite in CDs is recycled, it could be used again in items such as car bumpers, mobile phones and laptop computers.

Chen explained that by combining microwaves, supersonic waves and a low density alkaline fluid, the new technology can peel down metal layers on CDs more efficiently and cost-effectively. After removing the metal layer, the remaining polymer composite may be crushed into small particles and used for other commodities.
Chen said that if all one billion CDs are recycled, the extracted polymer composite would have a market value of NT$500 million to NT$700 million.
"[It could be] quite profitable for the recycling company," added Chen.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Thursday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index futures for April gained 58 points to close at 6,866, with 37,579 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for May rose 55 points to finish at 6,850, with 4,457 contract transactions, while June futures moved up 55 points to close at 6,820, with 48 contracts traded.
September futures gained 60 points to finish at 6,660, with 28 contracts traded, while December futures moved up 36 points to close at 6,626 with nine contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Thursday at 6,808 for April, 6,795 for May, 6,765 for June, 6,600 for September, and 6,590 for December.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also higher.
April TE futures gained 1.60 points to close at 304.90, with 4,524 contract transactions, while May TE futures moved up 1.80 points to finish at 304.15, with 632 contracts traded.
June TE futures gained 1.50 points to close at 302.50, with two contracts traded, while September TE futures rose 3.55 points to finish at 298, with one contract traded.
No transactions were recorded for December.
April TF futures moved up 19.2 points to close at 912, with 2,693 contract transactions, while May TF gained 19 points to finish at 910, with 346 contracts traded.
June TF futures rose 14 points to close at 899, with three contracts traded, while September TF futures gained 15.2 points to finish at 891.8, with five contracts traded.
No transactions were reported for December.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar dropped against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Thursday, losing NT$0.034 to close at NT$32.498.
A total of US$983 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$32.560 and fluctuated between NT$32.485 and NT$32.578.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI KEEPS ANMC21 FUNCTIONING AFTER BEIJING'S 2005 BOYCOTT

TEXT.P: By taking over the 5th annual convention of the Asian Network of Major Cities (ANMC21) from Beijing, which failed to host it in 2005, Taipei has enabled the network to continue functioning, Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou said Thursday.

Ma made the remarks as the fifth plenary meeting of ANMC21 opened with President Chen Shui-bian blasting China for attempting to obstruct Taipei from hosting the event. Chen praised Ma for having worked hard to bring the event to Taipei.

Ma said Taipei had tried to win hosting privileges to the network's 2006 annual meeting, but China had intervened and provoked a controversy at its 2004 meeting in Jakarta. Beijing did not sign the Jakarta agreement and withdrew from the organization, he noted.

The 2004 Jakarta Declaration stated that Beijing would host the 2005 annual meeting and that Taipei had the "priority" right of hosting the 2006 meeting, according to Ma, who noted that Beijing did not sign the declaration and quit the organization, so the 2005 meeting was skipped, leading to Taipei hosting the fifth ANMC21 meeting half a year ahead of schedule.

He stressed that Taiwan is playing the role of peacemaker in cross-Taiwan Strait relations, not a troublemaker in regional affairs. He added that through close cooperation, Asian countries will be able to form a joint living and economic sphere in which prosperity can be created for all, as each country increases their industrial output and per capita income.

Among participants in the 2006 annual convention of ANMC21 were Tokyo Mayor Shintaro Ishihara, Mayor Matthias Yao of Singapore and deputy mayors or senior delegates from eight other Asian cities -- Seoul, New Delhi, Bangkok, Jakarta, Hanoi, Manila, Kuala Lumpur and host Taipei.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO OPEN MARKET TO PRC TOURISTS AFTER NEGOTIATIONS: MAC

TEXT.P: The government will allow Chinese citizens to visit Taiwan for sightseeing purposes as soon as both sides of the Taiwan Strait complete negotiations in this regard, a government official said Thursday.
Joseph Wu, chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), made the remarks at a meeting with members of the opposition People First Party's (PFP) legislative caucus.

At the meeting, which was aimed at inviting PFP representatives to participate in a planned conference on Taiwan's sustainable economic development to be organized by the Cabinet, Wu noted that the opening of cross-strait direct passenger and cargo charter flights is a set policy of the government.

Noting that the opening of Taiwan's market to Chinese tourists is also a set government policy, Wu said Taiwan will welcome those holding People's Republic of China passports to visit Taiwan for sightseeing purposes once cross-strait negotiations are completed.
Since 2002, Taiwan has allowed Chinese with permanent residency status in a third country to visit Taiwan in group tours for a short stay.
As for cross-strait direct passenger and cargo charter flights, Wu said former Premier Frank Hsieh had already ordered related agencies to actively promote such flights last June.
"If talks between the two sides can be completed within six months, such charter flight services will be opened immediately," Wu added.
Wu revealed that cross-strait negotiations on weekend charter flights are also under way, but declined to offer more details.
Stressing that the government's China policy has always been clear, Wu said obstacles the government faced in the past in implementing the policy mostly came from factors beyond Taiwan's control.

Wu stressed that since promoting cross-strait charter flights and opening Taiwan's market to Chinese tourists are both set policies of the government, the MAC will try its best to defuse pressure from all sides.
"The government will promote various mainland policies according to the schedule, despite obstructions," Wu added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT DENIES HAVING ACCEPTED SOGO GIFT VOUCHERS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian will resign to take responsibility if any members of the first family have accepted gift vouchers from Pacific Sogo Department Store, the Presidential Office said in a statement Thursday.

The Presidential Office reaffirmed that the first family has never accepted any gift vouchers presented by former SOGO major shareholder Chang Min-chiang, shareholder Lee Heng-lung, current major shareholder Douglas Hsu or former Presidential Office Deputy Secretary-General Chen Che-nan.

"The recent string of unfactual reports have done serious harm to the first family, which is extremely unfair. The president expresses regret over these insinuating and defaming reports, " the statement said.

Opposition Kuomintang Legislator Lee Chuan-chiao alleged last week that first lady Wu Shu-jen received NT$8.8 million in gift vouchers from Pacific Sogo Department Store and that some of the vouchers have been used by members of her family.
President Chen and his wife filed a slander suit against Lee Tuesday for defaming them with what they claimed were false allegations.

The gift vouchers mentioned by the legislator were reportedly issued as some kind of "public relations fees" to Lee Heng-lung, who allegedly sought the assistance of government officials on behalf of Chang Min-chiang to resolve a financial crisis four years ago.

The officials approached by Lee reportedly included Chen Che-nan, who was detained last week after admitting he took NT$7.1 million from former Bank of Overses Chinese Vice Chairman Liang Po-hsun, who had asked Chen to use his influence to get him off the legal hook.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT URGED TO VERIFY '1992 CONSENSUS' WITH BEIJING

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Honorary Chairman Lien Chan should verify with Beijing if there was a consensus between Taiwan and China in 1992 whereby both sides could interpret the meaning of "one China" separately, ruling Democratic Progressive Party Chairman Yu Shyi-kun said Thursday.
Yu urged Lien to raise the question during his meeting with Chinese President Hu Jintao.

Yu pointed out that the KMT -- the ruling party in Taiwan until 2000 -- has claimed for more than 10 years that such a consensus exists between the two sides, but Beijing has repeatedly denied the claim.
Yu said it would hamper the development of cross-Taiwan Strait relations if the dispute remained unresolved.

Noting that KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou has proposed that Taiwan and China establish a "modus vivendi" based on the so-called "1992 consensus," Yu said it would be impossible for the KMT to promote the proposal unless the dispute is clarified.

Lien is visiting China to attend the first-ever economic forum between the KMT and the Communist Party of China, slated for April 14-15 in Beijing. Lien is also expected to meet with Hu during the visit.

During a meeting held earlier this month between President Chen Shui-bian and Ma, Chen suggested that Lien try to clear up the dispute over the "1992 consensus" during the meeting with Hu. But Lien responded saying that he would not pass on any messages to Hu on Chen's behalf.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP CONDEMNS CHINA FOR FORCING TAIWANESE TO ATTEND BEIJING FORUM

TEXT.P: The Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP) legislative caucus condemned Chinese authorities for forcing China-based Taiwanese merchants to take part in a trade and economic forum in Beijing, which former Kuomintang (KMT) chairman Lien Chan will also attend, DPP legislative caucus whip Yeh Yi-jin said Thursday.

China is creating the erroneous impression that Taiwanese businesspeople support Lien, who is now in China to take part in the KMT-Communist Party of China (CPC) forum, Yeh told a news conference at the Legislative Yuan.

Yeh showed the press an official document that a Chinese provincial government sent to a Taiwanese business association, which states that the association's chairman must not be absent when Lien shows up at the conference; and if the chairman cannot attend, a vice chairman should show up.
Yeh said this is no different from forcing them to show up with Lien, creating the impression they lend their support.
Yeh urged Lien not to be "used" by the Chinese authorities, reminding Lien that the KMT was once defeated by the CPC.
Lien, who departed for China Thursday, is at the head of a 60-member KMT delegation attending the forum April 14-15 in Beijing. Lien is scheduled to meet with Chinese President Hu Jintao April 16.

The delegation Lien leads includes 29 KMT legislators, as well as other lawmakers of the "pan-blue alliance." Prominent business leaders, such as Jeffrey Koo, chairman of the Chinatrust Financial Holding, Deputy Chairman of Cosmos Bank Hsu Hsien-jung, Uni-President Group Chairman Kao Chin-yen among others are represented in the delegation.

DOC.HEADLINE: CULTURAL PROPERTIES CENTER TO OPEN CLASS FOR MUSEUM WORKERS

TEXT.P: The National Center for Research and Preservation of Cultural Properties is slated to begin an on-the-job training course April 24 for museum workers.

The center, located in Tainan City, is scheduled to start the five-day class for 30 museum workers in the Graduate Institute of Conservation of Cultural Relics at Tainan National University of the Arts.
The class is devoted to demonstrating how to identify artifacts in need of repair and preservation.
Those interested in the class can visit the Web site http://www.ncrpcp.gov.tw for more information.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT WELCOMES GOVT'S PLAN ON OPENING CROSS-STRAIT EXCHANGES

TEXT.P: The legislative caucus of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) welcomed Thursday the government's plan to open Taiwan to Chinese tourists and cross-Taiwan Strait charter flight services, urging it to take concrete action instead of just paying "lip service" to these issues.

KMT Policy Coordination Committee Director Tseng Yung-chuan issued the call at a news conference at the Legislative Yuan after Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Joseph Wu urged Beijing Wednesday to wrap up bilateral negotiations with Taiwan on these issues in six months -- just one day before a large KMT delegation, led by Honorary Chairman Lien Chan, heads to China.

According to Wu, the MAC would not rule out the possibility of unilaterally announcing the opening of Taiwan to Chinese tourists and specific-purpose charter flights as long as complementary measures have been put in place, even if two-way negotiations have not been wrapped up by that time.
He added that "it is China, not Taiwan, that has tried to block cross-strait exchanges."

Tseng hailed the Cabinet's planned opening and called on the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) to "back its words with action" based on the path laid down by the KMT -- referring to a five-point agreement reached in last April in Beijing between Lien and Chinese President Hu Jintao.

KMT legislative caucus whip Pan Wei-kang said that Taiwan "cannot afford to lose the Chinese market" in its globalization efforts and she urged the DPP government to be visionary when seeking outlets for Taiwan.
KMT Legislator Su Chi, who once served as MAC chairman, called on Premier Su Tseng-chang to "have more teeth" and not to back away from the opening plan.
Premier Su said in a weekly Executive Yuan meeting Wednesday that he hopes Taiwan and China can complete bilateral negotiations on cross-strait trade and commercial exchanges as soon as possible.
Regarding opening Taiwan to Chinese tourists, the government has already made public its measures in 2001 and is awaiting China's response, Premier Su pointed out.

As for setting up direct charter flight services between Taiwan and China, the government remains open to the issue and will not rule out any possibility as long as it is properly arranged through bilateral negotiations, Su said.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CALLS FOR CROSS-STRAIT ECONOMIC COOPERATION

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Honorary Chairman Lien Chan proposed Thursday that Taiwan and China work together to promote cross-Taiwan Strait economic and trade cooperation under a "peace and win-win" framework.

Lien made the remarks upon his arrival in Beijing to attend the first economic forum between the KMT and the Communist Party of China (CPC), slated for April 14-15. Lien was greeted by Chinese officials led by Taiwan Affairs Office Director Chen Yunlin at Beijing's airport.
Lien, who previously visited Beijing in April 2005 and met with Chinese President Hu Jintao, said he felt a sense of familiarity and joy of reunion during this second visit to Beijing.

In light of the close economic and trade relations across the Strait, both sides should seek ways to complement their competitive edge and division of labor through the KMT-CPC economic forum, Lien said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ADJUSTMENT OF OIL PRICES STILL UNDER REVIEW: ECONOMICS MINISTER

TEXT.P: Minister of Economic Affairs Hwang Ing-san said Thursday that it is time to review domestic gasoline prices, and that the final decision will be made by the state-owned Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC) at some point.
Hwang made the remarks during the changeover ceremony for the new CPC Chairman Pan Wenent.
Faced with surging crude oil prices in the international market, Hwang noted that they will affect the nation's economic policies and everyone's livelihood.
However, oil prices should be decided upon by the market and reflect CPC's oil costs. CPC holds a more than 70 percent share of the country's oil market.

DOC.HEADLINE: MORE VOLUNTEER ATTORNEYS JOIN SEF TO HELP SMOOTH CROSS-STRAIT TIES

TEXT.P: A second group of 27 volunteer attorneys were contracted by the quasi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Thursday to boost the intermediary organization's legal services across the Taiwan Strait, particularly for Taiwanese businesses operating in China.

Addressing a ceremony marking the establishment of the second SEF group of volunteer attorneys, Vice Premier Tsai Ing-wen exhorted the legal professionals to live up to their commitment so as to help raise the quality of exchanges across the Taiwan Strait.

Tsai said that when she was head of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) -- Taiwan's top China policy planner -- many Taiwanese businesspeople operating in China were being questioned by Chinese authorities for a litany of reasons. She said the authorities exerted an imperceptible form of intimidation that had "a deterrent effect" on them.

Tsai said the MAC perceived the implications of the interrogation and authorized the SEF to organize a group of attorneys to travel to China and provide consultation to those Taiwan businesspeople who had been questioned.

Tsai said that when Taiwanese became physically or mentally incapacitated or disturbed after being questioned by Chinese authorities or ran into legal problems in China, legal assistance from Taiwan was more than welcome.
She said that as the modes of cross-strait exchange have become even more diverse and complicated, the need for legal assistance is naturally more urgent.
She said lawyers and attorneys are not only the defenders of society's core values, they can also serve as catalysts who lead efforts to help stabilize cross-strait relations.
The first SEF group of 23 volunteer attorneys was established in December 2005.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN BLASTS BEIJING FOR BOYCOTTING ANMC21 PLENARY MEETING

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian criticized Beijing for boycotting the plenary meeting of the Asian Network of Major Cities 21 (ANMC21) and disregarding the network's resolution in his opening remarks of the 5th annual Plenary Meeting of the AMNC21 Thursday in Taipei.

"China continuously used its political power to hinder the meeting's progress by boycotting meeting sessions. Even worse, it disregarded the meeting's resolution, and was unwilling to allow the section giving Taipei priority as the 2006 host city to appear in the joint declaration," Chen said.

Chen praised incumbent Tokyo City Mayor Shintaro Ishihara for dealing with the matter resolutely and bringing the meeting forward to April this year. He also welcomed dignitaries who arrived from nine major Asian cities to take part in the meeting.
Cities that sent delegations to Taipei for the two-day meeting include Bangkok, Delhi, Hanoi, Jakarta, Kuala Lumpur, Manila, Seoul, Singapore and Tokyo.
A former Taipei City Mayor, President Chen cited past experience in which he took the proactive approach of promoting "city diplomacy" to help Taipei reach out to the world.
Taiwan is "not an isolated island, but rather, an island that embraces the world," President Chen stressed, adding that "a city charged with energy brings an influence far beyond our imagination."

ANMC21 was originally proposed by Ishihara in August 2000 in Kuala Lumpur during a joint conference involving the four cities of Tokyo, Kuala Lumpur, Delhi, and Seoul. It has 12 member cities before Beijing unilaterally withdrew from the ANMC21, resulting in the 2005 plenary meeting not being held.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New YOrk Times: Lenient Rule Set for Rebuilding in New Orleans
U.S. federal officials issued unexpectedly lenient guidelines on Wednesday for rebuilding the flood-damaged homes of New Orleans, potentially allowing tens of thousands of homeowners to return to their neighborhoods at costs far less than they had feared. The announcement dovetails with a political climate in New Orleans in which the idea of not rebuilding damaged neighborhoods has been taboo. In a heated mayor's race that is now reaching its conclusion, no candidate has been willing to say some areas should not be rebuilt because of flood danger.
Wall Street Journal: Wal-Mart Sticks With Fast Pace Of Expansion Despite Toll on Sales
After decades of relentless expansion in the U.S., Wal-Mart Stores Inc. is cannibalizing its own business in many markets. But the huge retailer says the strategy of opening new stores that compete with older ones is paying off and will continue, despite Wall Street's rising dissatisfaction. Some Wal-Mart watchers want the company to slow its expansion and channel more resources into improving the appearance of existing stores and upgrading its merchandise to entice shoppers to spend more. "What hurts the company and ultimately the value of its stock price is if you're paying more for the real estate but getting less and less out of it," says Morgan Stanley analyst Gregory Melich.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT SUES MEDIA COMMENTATOR FOR SLANDER

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian filed a lawsuit Thursday against media commentator Chang Yu-hua for slandering him with the allegation that the president met twice with a deposed Presidential Office official involved in a corruption scandal related to the Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp. (KRTC).

The president asked lawyer Ku Li-hsiung to institute the criminal proceedings after Chang ignored the president's demand that he apologize within three days over his allegation made during a TV program that the president met with his former aide Chen Che-nan in secret on Jan. 11 and shortly after Lunar New Year's Day on Jan 29.

Chen Che-nan, a notorious figure in Taiwan's political and business circles, is currently in detention and being investigated over a charge that he took money illegally from an economic criminal in 2002 and promised to get him off the legal hook.

Chen, who served as deputy secretary-general of the Presidential Office from 2000 to 2004, was forced to quit his post as the president's national policy adviser in early October last year because of his involvement in the KRTC corruption scandal, brought to light by the Aug. 21, 2005 riot of Thai laborers working on the Kaohsiung rapid transit railway project.

The public affairs department of the Presidential Office claimed that the president had never met with Chen Che-nan since Chen's resignation, and that Chang's allegation about his two meetings with Chen were "sheer fabrication" that cannot be substantiated with evidence.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI PUSHES FOR ALLIED ASIAN TOURISM NETWORK

TEXT.P: Taipei delegates to the 5th annual convention of the Asian Network of Major Cities 21 (ANMC21) called Thursday for the establishment of an allied Asian tourism network to help promote tourism development throughout Asia.

Kang Ping-cheng, a Taipei city government official in charge of tourism affairs, called for the governments of all ANMC21 members to form an allied Asian tourism network as a useful regional tourism promotion mechanism.
Kang's proposal was enthusiastically received by delegates from Jakarta, Bangkok, Hanoi and Tokyo.
Meanwhile, a Singaporean delegate advocated that young citizens from ANMC21 member countries be allowed to exchange residence experiences in different Asian cities under the ANMC21 framework.

Responding to the Singaporean delegate's advocacy, a Taipei delegate said that Taipei City receives about 100 young artists and performance artists from around the world each year to stay in Taipei for one to three months as "artists in residence."
Echoing the Taipei delegate's remarks, Tokyo Mayor Shintaro Ishihara said he has personally visited Taipei to pick up clues about Taipei's "artists in residence" program.

In turn, Ishihara -- who initiated the formation of the ANMC21 in August 2000 in Kuala Lumpur during a joint conference involving the cities of Tokyo, Kuala Lumpur, Delhi and Seoul -- said that enlightened by the Taipei International Art Village program, he has approached the authorities of Aoyama Gakuin University to suggest that a similar program be established in that institute.

Ishihara said Asia is a fast-changing area with the greatest development potential among all regions around the world and that regional and inter-regional exchanges and cooperation have thus become increasingly important. After having visited so many cities around Asia, Ishihara said, he found that the need for regional aircraft of about 100 seats has become increasingly urgent and he called for regional cooperation on this issue.

Among the participants in the 2006 ANMC21 are Ishihara, Mayor Matthias Yao of Singapore and deputy mayors or senior delegates from eight other Asian cities -- Seoul, New Delhi, Bangkok, Jakarta, Hanoi, Manila, Kuala Lumpur and host Taipei.
ANMC21 currently is down to 12 member cities as a result of Beijing's withdrawal from the ANMC21.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN MAKING BEHIND-THE-SCENES EFFORTS TO JOIN WHA: MOFA

TEXT.P: To gain support from the international community for Taiwan's bid to join the World Health Organization (WHO) , the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Thursday that it will continue making efforts behind the scenes.
However, a MOFA official said, it won't be easy for Taiwan to participate in the World Health Assembly (WHA) -- the WHO's governing body -- as an observer due to China's obstruction.

Chen Chaun, director of the Department of International Organizations of MOFA, said that despite support from European countries expressing their sympathy for Taiwan's "meaningful participation" in the WHO, it is difficult for them to vote or speak for Taiwan in public under pressure from China.

MOFA's Taiwan International Health Action (TaiwanIHA) has been functioning well, and has already recruited 2,400 volunteer medical professionals. Chen also said TaiwanIHA will be institutionalized and establish networking sites to integrate resources in case of contingency.

The WHA will hold an annual meeting in Geneva at the end of May. MOFA officials said they have tried hard to "row the boat silently, " adding they cannot release any details of their action plan at present.

As in the past, Chen said Taiwan's diplomatic allies will propose that Taiwan be admitted to WHA this year on grounds of humanitarianism and Taiwan's professional achievements in health care. (Timothy J. Hwang)

DOC.HEADLINE: MAJOR ASIAN CITIES TALK ON 'ASIA IN TRANSFORMATION' IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: Delegates from 10 major Asian cities assembled in Taipei Thursday for a two-day meeting, with the main theme of "Asia in Transformation," seeking to establish a network and deepen social and economic bonds and cooperation.

The fifth Plenary Meeting of the Asian Network of Major Cities 21 (ANMC21) is taking place in Taipei, with Beijing and Yangon the only absentees among the 12 member cities of the 6-year-old international platform.
Beijing withdrew from the organization in 2004 after Taipei was selected as the host city for the 2006 plenary meeting. The 2005 plenary meeting, which was to be hosted by Beijing, never took place.
Major Asian cities should "work together and share the same vision to fight poverty and achieve peace and prosperity, " said Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou at the opening ceremony.
Asia has been undergoing mass changes since the 1950s and this is especially true in the 21st Century, Ma said, which is why the theme of this meeting is "Asia in Transformation."
Delegates from Bangkok, Delhi, Hanoi, Jakarta, Kuala Lumpur, Manila, Seoul, Singapore, Taipei and Tokyo are attending the meeting that was proposed by Tokyo Mayor Shintaro Ishihara in 2000.

In addition to discussions on joint projects that range from the environment, urban planning, education, women's development, health and disaster control between member cities, they will also work on an amendment of the ANMC21 Charter and determine the host city of the next meeting before signing the Taipei Declaration.
Meanwhile, an exhibition and cultural events of all participating cities will take place at Hall 2 of the Taipei World Trade Center from April 13-16.
Since its establishment in 2000, the ANMC21 has held its plenary meetings in different member cities -- Tokyo in 2001, Delhi in 2002, Hanoi in 2003 and Jakarta in 2004.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-GERMANY PROJECT TO PAVE WAY FOR NEW VOCATIONAL TRAINING

TEXT.P: An ambitious educational project embarked upon by the government and enterprises is looking to model itself on German craftsmanship and pave the way for new vocational training in Taiwan, a government agency said Thursday.

The Tai-Ger Vocational Training Project (TGVTP) , which is entering its third year, enjoys the cooperation of the Taishan Training Center -- a subsidiary of the Council of Labor Affairs -- the German Trade Office in Taipei and the Association of German Chambers of Industry and Commerce (DIHK).

The project, which covers senior vocational schools, two-year junior colleges and two-year technical colleges, requires participating students to work for three days and go to school for two days every week.

"Our objective is to change the traditional thinking on Taiwan's vocational education, which is sometimes referred as 'secondary education, ' and help produce more competent workers, " said Liao Wei-ren, research and development section chief of the TGVTP.

Students admitted to the project will receive a 50 percent subsidy on tuition from the government and their salaries are required to be not less than 50 percent of a full-time employee who works in the same position.
Graduates of the project will receive DIHK certification.

"This is a project with mutual benefit to the students and companies. Students get the on-the-job training while the companies provide a training ground for their potential employees of the future, " said Jim Chang, a senior manager of the Ruentex Group, whose company employs 22 project participants.

"These students are usually more mature, motivated and goal-oriented than those in four-year universities because they receive academic, vocational and human skill training at the same time. And they know what they want, " said Mark Chen, a professor at Nanya Institute of Technology. The school has 249 students under the project this year.
TGVTP, which was launched in 2003, will have its first graduation class of 206 students this summer. More than 1,000 students have been admitted to the project in the past three years.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR URGES MUTUAL VISA-FREE TREATMENT IN ASIA

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou suggested to member cities of the Asian Network of Major Cities 21 (ANMC21) Thursday that they should persuade their respective governments to offer visa-free treatment to citizens of each other's countries.
Ma made the remarks at the 5th Plenary Meeting of ANMC21, which is being held at Far Eastern International Hotel in Taipei April 13-16.

In view of the fact that Japan's offering visa-free treatment to Taiwan tourists last year has helped boost Taiwan citizens' visits to Japan, Ma expressed hope that other ANMC21 member cities will suggest that their governments follow suit.

ANMC21, initiated by Tokyo Mayor Shintaro Ishihara in 2001, is a platform aimed at seeking progress and giving member cities an opportunity to strengthen cooperation in various aspects, such as economic, transport, cultural, urban planning, education, women's development, medical care, environmental protection and sustainable development.
Mayors and representatives from Bangkok, Delhi, Jakarta, Kuala Lumpur, Manila, Seoul, Singapore, Tokyo, Hanoi and Taipei participated in this year's plenary meeting.

Ma noted that Taipei's Cultural Affair Bureau invites some 100 artists from around the world annually to stay for periods of one to three months in Taipei to present their artistic talent and enhance exchanges with local artists. He said he hoped ANMC21 member cities can also share this project.

2006 ANMC21, which will feature theme exhibitions and present several performances by member cities, is expected to draw more than 50,000 local and international visitors, according to Taipei city officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: TRADITIONAL CHINESE CHARACTERS SHOULD BE MADE U.N. WORLD HERITAGE

TEXT.P: A group of academics in Taipei suggested Thursday that Taiwan file an application with the United Nations to make traditional Chinese characters a world cultural heritage entitled to special protection.

Professor Wang Kai-fu of National Taiwan Normal University said that although Taiwan is not a U.N. member and that an application put forth by Taiwan might encounter huge difficulties at the U.N. headquarters, efforts to push for traditional Chinese characters' being listed as a U.N.-protected world cultural heritage are imperative.

Kang said he is confident that traditional, complex, or long-form Chinese characters will survive and even thrive because of the medium's strong "vitality, " but he admitted that under Beijing's strong political pressure, it has become increasingly difficult for Taiwan to promote traditional Chinese characters and script around the world.
The best way to prevent traditional Chinese characters from being marginalized is to list them as a U.N.-protected world cultural heritage, Kang added.
Only Taiwan, Hong Kong and Macau still use long-form characters, with the rest of the world mostly using the simplified, or short-form characters developed in China, supposedly to "boost literacy."

Meanwhile, Professor Hsu Ching-yun of Soochow University said that simplified characters were officially adopted by Beijing in 1949. However, he claimed, the Chinese people have come to increasingly "crave" traditional characters as standards of living have continued to rise in China, a development that has led the Chinese people to need more cultural things.
Hsu also suggested that Taiwan convene an international sinology conference to raise world awareness about the importance and significance of traditional Chinese characters.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVERSUPPLY OF COLLEGE GRADUATES UPSETS CHINA'S LABOR MARKET: CEPD

TEXT.P: An oversupply of university graduates in China this year could upset the Chinese labor market and cause the nation's unemployment rate to rise further, the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) predicted in a report released Thursday.

The report quoted statistics compiled by the Institute of Population and Labor Economics of the Chinese Academy of Social Sciences in Beijing as showing that China is expected to have 4.13 million university graduates this year, representing an increase of 750,000 over 2005, while the average employment rate for them in the past five years was only 70 percent.

The report indicated that the number of university graduates in China has increased by leaps and bounds in recent years, causing the backlog of unemployed graduates to rise from 340,000 in 2001 to 790,000 last year.

The oversupply of university graduates has not only upset the labor market but has also caused the growth of salaries to stagnate. Chinese official statistics show that university graduates in China now receive an average monthly income of 1,588 yuan, up only 37 yuan from 2003, with 20.3 percent of them making less than 1,000 yuan a month.
The CEPD's report pointed out that the oversupply of university graduates and a shortfall in skilled workers have resulted in an imbalance in China's manpower structure.
It also said that China's actual unemployment rate might be higher than the officially acknowledged figure of 4.2 percent.

The report concluded that China's high economic growth will be dogged by the problem of high unemployment, a problem the Chinese leadership will have to overcome if it hopes to maintain China's long-term prosperity.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP EXPELS TWO LAWMAKERS INDICTED FOR INSURANCE FRAUD

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) decided Thursday to expel two lawmakers who have been indicted on charges of health insurance fraud.

The DPP's Central Review Committee (CRC) came to the decision to oust Chiu Yeong-jen and Peter Lin after a heated debate. Chiu lost his legislative seat simultaneously with his ouster from the DPP because he was a legislator-at-large with party membership as a prerequisite for the post. As Lin is a regional legislator, he will be able to retain his seat.
Chiu said he was disappointed and saddened by the party's decision and couldn't accept it. And Lin declined to make any comments.

Chiu, who runs the Yeong-jen Hospital in the southern port city of Kaohsiung, and Lin, owner of the Peter Lin Hospital, also in Kaohsiung, could each face five-year prison terms if found guilty. Prosecutors charge that they swindled NT$110 million and NT$190 million, respectively, out of the Bureau of National Health Insurance by making false insurance claims. Both of them have been allowed to remain at large after each paid bail of NT$3 million in February.

According to the DPP's disciplinary rules, party members indicted on charges of graft, malfeasance or vote buying, among other illegal acts that tarnish the party's image, will be immediately banned from taking part in party activities, but prosecuted members will be deprived of membership only if they are convicted at a first trial.

Both Chiu and Lin appeared at the CRC meeting to defend their memberships, arguing that they would eventually be acquitted, claiming that prosecutors made only cursory charges against them without assiduous investigations.
While some CRC members also voiced support for the two physicians-turned-politicians, the committee still decided to expel them after four hours of grueling debate.

CRC Chairman Kao Chih-peng said after the meeting that the DPP must adopt the highest level of moral standards in response to public expectations for clean politics and good governance and that if Chiu and Lin manage to clear them names, the DPP will seek remedial measures.
In accordance with the DPP's internal regulations, Lin wen-lang will fill the legislative seat left vacant by Chiu's ouster. Lin has served as a regional legislator for three terms.
Chen Chin-jun, a DPP legislative whip, said the party caucus supports the decision to oust Chiu and Lin as part of the party's effort to restore its clean image and regain public trust.

"The public's perception of our party's political integrity is the most important. Since the DPP no longer controls the largest number of seats in the legislature, it's not important that we have one less seat following Lin's ouster. Responding to public expectations for political accountability is more critical, " Chen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PREMIER WANTS QUICK RESPONSE FROM BEIJING ON NEGOTIATIONS

TEXT.P: Vice Premier Tsai Ing-wen urged Beijing Thursday to respond quickly to the government's call for re-opening bilateral negotiations on trade and commercial issues, as a delegation of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) left for China for an economic forum with Beijing officials earlier the same day.

Tsai made the remarks while answering questions from reporters after attending a ceremony held by the semi-official Straits Exchange Foundation in which more than a dozen lawyers were cited for their volunteer counselling services for people from the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

Pointing out that the Democratic Progressive Party government wanted to conduct talks with the KMT before the delegation left for China, Tsai expressed the hope that the KMT will take the initiative to discuss the issues that the mission talks about with the Chinese officials during the Beijing forum with relevant official agencies "out of respect for the government" after the group returns from the trip.

She also called on Beijing to respond swiftly to Taiwan's call for resuming two-way negotiations on cross-strait exchanges, as some of the issues that it is to discuss with the KMT delegation might infringe upon the power of Taiwan's authorities.

KMT Honorary Chairman Lien Chan led the group of over 170 lawmakers, experts and business community representatives to Beijing, where he will attend an economic forum with Communist Party of China (CPC) officials from April 14-17 to discuss ways to further advance cross-strait exchanges, mainly in the fields of tourism, direct transport links and financial exchanges.
The KMT-CPC economic forum is the first of its kind in nearly 60 years after Taiwan and China split in 1949 amid a civil war.

DOC.HEADLINE: BOFT CONCERNED ABOUT TAIWAN'S MACHINE TOOL EXPORTS TO CHINA

TEXT.P: Taiwan trade officials began to examine Taiwan's export of machine tools to China Thursday after foreign wire service reports said that China is using Taiwan-made high-precision machine tools to make parts for missiles.

A spokesman for the Board of Foreign Trade under the Ministry of Economic Affairs said the board had begun a case-by-case investigation to find out whether machine tools exported to China could be used for military purposes.

He acknowledged that the investigation was ordered after government officials became concerned about the news reports that China last year used dozens of Taiwan-made machine tools to manufacture parts and components for its missiles.

The spokesman said that a review shows that from January 2005 to January this year, Taiwan exported a variety of machine tools worth NT$230 million to China, including six cases that obtained the board's export permission granted under the regulations governing the export of strategic and high-tech products.
He said the initial understanding of trade officials is that the machine tools did not meet such high-precision standards as could be used for manufacturing missile parts.
The spokesman added that the news reports could also be a misrepresentation of the facts.

DOC.HEADLINE: TRAVELERS TO TAIWAN WARNED AGAINST BRINGING IN DRUGS

TEXT.P: A spokesman for the Kaohsiung Customs Office Thursday reminded travelers to Taiwan not to bring in any luggage on behalf of strangers in order to avoid unwittingly bringing illegal drugs into the country.

Stepped-up crackdowns on drug trafficking have uncovered led to an increase in the number of foiled drug-smuggling attempts, and the spokesman warned that people traveling to and from foreign countries might be asked to help carry suspect luggage into the country.
Travelers may be tempted by the profits to be made from bringing in illegal drugs, but would face severe punishment, the spokesman warned.

The spokesman said that 21,800 grams of heroin, marijuana, amphetamines and other drugs -- worth about NT$22 million (US$687,500) -- were seized in the past three months from travelers arriving from Hong Kong, Macau, Vietnam, Thailand and the Philippines.
Most have attempted to smuggle drugs through customs inspection by affixing the illegal shipments to their bodies, the spokesman said.
The spokesman said that Kaohsiung customs have established connections with various foreign agencies to facilitate the job of intercepting illegal drugs.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN MINISTER, EMBASSY STAFF UNAFFECTED BY FIGHTING IN CHAD: MOFA

TEXT.P: Minister of Foreign Affairs Huang Chih-fang has safely left Chad and is scheduled to return to Taipei Sunday, an official said Thursday.
MOFA spokesman Michel Lu made the remarks after foreign wire service reports said heavy fighting broke out in Chad's capital early Thursday.
Lu said Chadian government troops have held off a rebel attack and that Huang had already left N'Djamena for home.
"Huang is well aware of the security situation in Chad and there is no problem with his personal safety," Lu said.
Huang left Taipei for N'Djamena Sunday to preside over a regional working meeting of the nation's diplomatic mission chiefs posted around Africa.

Meanwhile, Lu said, the Republic of China Embassy in Chad remains intact despite fighting around the capital city. All embassy and agricultural mission staff stationed in Chad and their families are safe and unaffected by the rebel attacks, Lu added.

DOC.HEADLINE: MINISTER CALLS FOR CROSS-STRAIT COOPERATION IN FIGHTING CRIME

TEXT.P: Minister of Justice Shih Mao-lin urged China Thursday to strengthen cooperation with Taiwan in fighting crime.

"The two sides of the Taiwan Strait can cooperate in fighting internationally acknowledged severe crimes, including kidnapping, drug trafficking, robbery and murder, through information and judicial personnel exchanges," Shih said.

To maintain law and order, Shih said, Taiwan hopes to reinforce cooperation with China in criminal investigations. As China is a major source of illegal drug trafficking, Shih said, Taiwan needs China's cooperation in wiping out drug smuggling.
Shih also expressed his hope that China can repatriate wanted Taiwanese economic criminals who have fled across the Taiwan Strait to escape justice.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPAN'S POSITIVE STANCE ON TAIWAN'S WHA BID REMAINS UNCHANGED
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, April 13 (CNA) (By Mike Chang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Japan's stance on Taiwan's bid to join the World Health Assembly -- the governing body of the World Health Organization (WHO) -- as an observer remains unchanged, a Japanese diplomatic official said Thursday.
Since 2004, the United States and Japan have offered explicit support for Taiwan's quest for WHA observership at the world health regulatory body's annual conference in Geneva.

In response to an inquiry from CNA at a regular news conference, a Japanese Foreign Ministry spokesman said Japan hopes that a formula that satisfies every party concerned can be worked out to allow for Taiwan's meaningful participation in the WHA as an observer. "This stance remains unchanged," he added.
The WHA is scheduled to hold its 2006 annual meeting in May. A Taiwan delegation traveled to Tokyo earlier this month to seek for continued Japanese support for Taiwan's WHO bid.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR APRIL 14 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Friday, April 14:
11:00, President Chen Shui-bian will receive a delegation from the National Committee on American Foreign Policy headed by Winston Lord.
14:00, The Taiwan Foundation for Democracy will hold a seminar on political prisoners in China.
16:00, Marshall Island President Kessai Note will bid farewell to President Chen at the Presidential Office.
16:00, The Mainland Affairs Council will hold a news conference.
17:00, President Chen will receive a Japanese delegation headed by Tokyo Governor Shintaro Ishihara.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SEEKING TO IMPROVE CROSS-STRAIT TIES BY OPENING TOURISM: MAC

TEXT.P: Taiwan hopes to improve relations across the Taiwan Strait by offering to open its market to Chinese tourists and direct cross-strait charter flight services, a senior mainland affairs official said Thursday.
Mainland Affairs Council Chairman Joseph Wu made the remarks while meeting with visiting U.S. Congressman John Linder.

Despite China's unfair treatment of Taiwan's democratically elected leader, Wu said Taiwan is willing to open its market to Chinese tourists and direct charter flights in order to improve ties and maintain regional peace.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, April 14, or the 17th day of the third month of the Year of the Dog according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1629: Christiaan Huygens, the Dutch physicist and astronomer, is born. He discovered Saturn's rings in 1655, pioneered the use of pendulum in clocks in 1657, and formulated Huygens' principle.
1865: US President Abraham Lincoln is failing fast after being shot in the back of the head at point-blank range by actor John Wilkes Booth, a Confederate fanatic, at the Ford Theater in Washington, D.C. He died the next day and was succeeded by Andrew Johnson.
1889: Arnold Toynbee, British historian and author of a 12-volume work entitled "A Study of History," is born.
1903: The typhus vaccine is discovered by Dr. Harry Plotz in New York.
1912: The Titanic strikes an iceberg and sinks in the North Atlantic, killing 1,500 people.
1941: Condemning the Soviet-Japanese Neutrality Pact, Foreign Minister Wang Chung-hui of the Republic of China declares that Outer Mongolia and the northeastern provinces are Chinese territory and that the Soviet-Japanese statement is not binding on China.
1945: US bombers pound Japan's Imperial Palace during World War II.
1949: The Taiwan provincial administration announces a decision to carry out the "37.5 Percent Farm Rental Reduction" and the "Land-to-the-Tiller" policies.
1956: USS Saratoga, a US Navy aircraft carrier which joined the fleet in 1927 as the largest warship in the world, is formally decommissioned.
1956: The first videotape is demonstrated in Chicago.
1962: French Prime Minister Michel Debre resigns and is succeeded by Georges Pompidou.
1971: The new Tourism Bureau of the Ministry of Communications is inaugurated in Taipei.
1972: The first satellite observation station in the Republic of China is inaugurated at National Cheng Kung University.
1973: President Nguyen Van Thieu of the Republic of Vietnam leaves Taipei for home after a three-day visit.
1973: Dr. Jesus Soto Amesty, chairman of the Venezuela Senate Foreign Policy Committee, arrives in Taipei for a ten-day visit.
1975: Sikkim abolishes its monarchy and seeks full Indian statehood.
1976: A total of 3,460 students from 642 middle schools compete in the Taiwan Area Games.
1977: The ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs announces severance of diplomatic relations with the Hashemite Kingdom of Jordan.
1982: Armed bandit Lee Shih-khe robs the Land Bank of Taiwan's Kuting Branch in Taipei City of more than NT$5 million, a major criminal case at that time.
1988: The Soviet Union ends its intervention in Afghanistan and allows its troops to withdraw.
1993: On International Women's Day, a Chinese newspaper asks 100 women what they would most like to be. Sixty say that they want to be men.
1994: Two US F-15 fighters shoot down two American helicopters over northern Iraq killing 26 people.
1999: Pakistan test-fires a 2,000-km range ballistic missile.
2000: Ovidio Manuel Barbosa Pequeno, the new Sao Tome and Principe ambassador to the Republic of China, presents his credentials to President Lee Teng-hui.
2001: A four-member U.S. Senate delegation led by Sen. Phil Gramm (R-TX) arrives in Taipei to begin a three-day visit.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "To be poor without complaining is not easy; but it is easy to be rich without being proud."

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. EXPECTS CHINA TO HONOR COMMITMENTS: BUSH
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 13 (CNA) (By Jorge Liu and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: U.S. President George W. Bush urged China Thursday to honor its commitments with regard to trade to show the world that it means to be a trading partner that plays by rules.
Bush said he looks forward to his scheduled meeting with Chinese President Hu Jintao at the White House next week.

"America values China as a trading partner, but we expect China to live up to its commitments. China needs to make itself more transparent. China needs to enforce intellectual property rights," he said.
"China needs to take additional steps to address the trade imbalance between our countries. And China needs to move to a flexible, market-based currency," he further said.
Bush made the remarks while addressing the Small Business Administration's National Small Business Week Conference held in Washington, D.C.
Also Thursday, U.S. State Department spokesman Sean McCormack said human rights will be an important item on the agenda of the upcoming meeting between Bush and Hu.
"In terms of human rights, it is an issue that we raise with the Chinese government on every occasion that we have, " McCormack said during a daily press briefing.
McCormack said Washington encourages China to expand freedom of expression and freedom of worship and address serious human rights issues that the United States has raised.
"As for any actions that the Chinese may take, prior to or after the visit, we'll see," he said.

DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Friday are as follows:
The China Times: Purses shrink with price increases in edible oil, sugar and other daily necessites.
The United Daily News: President promises to step down if first lady found to have received gift coupons.
The Liberty Times: President promises to step down if found to have accepted gift coupons.
The Taiwan Daily: President denies accepting businessman's gift coupons, promises to step down if found otherwise.
The Central Daily News: Cross-strait forum opens. Lien Chan calls for cooperation in economy and trade to serve the interest of both sides.

The Taipei Times: Chen denies Sogo voucher charges.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOMINICAN PRESIDENT'S ECONOMIC ADVISER TO VISIT TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, April 13 (CNA) (By Raymond Huang and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Jose Luis Corripio Estrada, economic adviser to the Presidential Office of the Dominican Republic, and his wife are scheduled to arrive in Taiwan Friday for a weeklong visit, the Republic of China Embassy in the Caribbean country said Thursday.

The embassy said that the Dominican Republic is one of the ROC's most important diplomatic allies in the Caribbean and that Corripio, head of the Corripio Group, the largest media group in the country, holds sway in the nation's political, economic and media circles.
Corripio's visit to Taiwan is significant, embassy officials said, noting that Dominican President Leonel Fernandez Reyna will also visit Taiwan in June.
During Corripio's visit, he will be presented by President Chen Shui-bian with the Order of Brilliant Star with Grand Cordon.

He will also call on the Ministry of Economic Affairs and the Government Information Office (GIO) and attend luncheons hosted by Foreign Affairs Minister Huang Chih-fang and GIO Minister Cheng Wen-tsang in his honor.

DOC.HEADLINE: MA'S U.S. VISIT GOOD FOR CROSS-STRAIT RELATIONS: PRO-BLUE SCHOLARS

TEXT.P: Pro-blue scholars on Friday praised Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou's promotion of the "1992 consensus" and his 'modus vivendi' proposal during his recent visit to the United States, saying it was beneficial to cross-Taiwan Strait relations.

"Ma successfully combined the U.S.'s national interests and the ROC's national interests during his visit. His open ways will help the United States treat him as a real friend, and the Chinese leaders will not become his enemies, " said Chen I-hsin, a professor at Tamkang University's Graduate Institute of American Studies.
Chen said that Ma has defined himself as a peacemaker and that his proposal of a 'modus vivendi' between China and Taiwan is likely to succeed via mutual benevolence, trust and positive interactions.
Furthermore, Ma's promise to devote himself completely to improving Taiwan's economy if he is elected president was also music to U.S. ears, Chen said.
Chen made the statements during a seminar held Friday in Taipei on the impact of Ma's U.S. visit on Taiwan-U.S.-China relations.

Chinese Culture University Graduate Institute of American Studies director Chen Yu-chun said at the seminar that Ma's promotion of the "1992 consensus, " the "five noes" principle and a 'modus vivendi, ' together with his proposal for resuming cross-strait talks to avoid war comforted and soothed China.

DOC.HEADLINE: IIPA STRONGLY SUPPORTS U.S.-TAIWAN FTA
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 13 (CNA) (By Wennie Chi and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The International Intellectual Property Alliance (IIPA), an influential business entity, expressed strong support Thursday for the signing of a free trade agreement (FTA) between the United States and Taiwan.

IIPA President Eric H. Smith asserted at a symposium on the topic of a U.S.-Taiwan FTA that IIPA members strongly support the signing of such an agreement, rebutting a State Department official, who said that "until now, no member of the U.S. business sector has expressed support for a U.S.-Taiwan FTA."

Smith made the rebuttal immediately after Priscilla Hoffman-Stowe, a State Department economic analyst, said at the symposium that he has not heard any voices of support from the U.S. business sector so far about the signing of a U.S.-Taiwan FTA.

It marked the first time that the IIPA -- a private sector coalition comprised of seven trade associations representing 1,900 companies producing and distributing materials protected by copyright laws throughout the world -- has expressed support for the U.S.-Taiwan FTA initiative since Oct. 2002.

During the symposium, sponsored by George Washington University's Sigur Center for Asian Studies, most of the scholars present agreed that given Taiwan's dynamic economy and the close ties between the United States and Taiwan, it is imperative that a free trade agreement be forged between the two sides.

However, they admitted, the U.S.'s foreign policy, or Washington's stance on the cross-Taiwan Strait relations and the U.S. Congress' reaction to that stance, could be major obstacles to the FTA initiative.

The U.S. International Trade Commission (ITC) began to conduct a survey on the economic impact of a U.S.-Taiwan FTA in February 2002. When the survey was released in October the same year, more than 120 U.S. companies were found to be supportive of the U.S. signing a free trade agreement with Taiwan, but the IIPA block expressed opposition to the initiative, saying that it would be inappropriate to have the agreement signed before Taiwan improved its intellectual property rights (IPR) protection.

In January 2005, the Office of the U.S. Trade Representative (USTR) removed Taiwan from its "Special 301 priority watch list" in recognition of the island's efforts and progress in IPR protection. Taiwan had been on the "priority watch list" for four consecutive years dating back to 2001.

Political observers in Washington attributed the IIPA's turnabout on the U.S.-Taiwan FTA issue mainly to the fact that Taiwan has made significant progress in cracking down on commercial piracy and that the Taiwan legislature passed IPR protection legislation in 2004.

The IIPA -- which is comprised of most of the U.S. companies producing or distributing materials protected by copyright laws, including all types of computer software and entertainment software, movies, television programs, home videos, records, CDs, textbooks, professional publications and journals -- is now more focused on rampant commercial piracy and counterfeiting in China.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT URGED TO RESPECT GOVERNMENT'S EXISTENCE

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Honorary Chairman Lien Chan must not forget the existence of the ROC government and his identity as an ROC citizen during his current visit in Beijing, Premier Su Tseng-chang said Friday.
Su made the remarks during an interpellation session in the Legislative Yuan.

Su said Lien, as an ROC citizen, enjoys the freedom and democracy of this country and can travel in and out of the country freely, which is different from the situation in the People's Republic of China.

Pointing out that Lien has insisted that Taipei and Beijing should be allowed to maintain their separate interpretation of the meaning of "one China, " Su urged Lien not to forget to mention his version of "one China" -- the Republic of China -- while in Beijing.
While the PRC constantly suppresses the ROC and does not recognize the ROC, this is Lien's best opportunity to promote the existence of the ROC, Su said.
He further reminded Lien to respect the existence of the government if he is to discuss with Beijing authorities any issues involving the exercise of government authority.
Also, he called on Beijing to negotiate with the elected government in Taiwan or government-authorized organizations on issues in this regard.
On visits to Taiwan by Chinese tourists, Su said the main problem with this issue lies with China because Beijing has so far refused to allow its people to visit Taiwan for sightseeing purposes.

Lien is in Beijing to attend the first economic forum between the KMT and the Communist Party of China, which opened Friday. He is also expected to hold talks with Chinese President Hu Jintao during the visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUTOTRONICS TAIPEI 2006 TO OPEN MONDAY

TEXT.P: The Metal Industries Research and Development Center said Friday that it will present the initial results of its research and development in safer, smarter and more energy-saving automobiles at the upcoming Taipei International Automobile Electronics Show (AutoTronics Taipei 2006).
The show will be the first exhibition in the world featuring automobile electronics, center officials said.
They noted that auto makers and research and development groups will take part in the four-day exhibition to be held April 17-20 at the Taipei World Trade Center.

The center, as well as the Automotive Research and Testing Center and the Chung-Shan Institute of Science and Technology will present their R&D progress in several areas, including night-vision systems and lane deviation warning systems, at the Taiwan Automotive Research Consortium (TARC) Pavilion, one of the exhibition's three theme pavilions. The other two theme pavilions will be the Human Technology -- Intelligent Transportation Systems (ITS) Pavilion and the Yulon Motor and Satellites Pavilion.

The global market for automobiles is about 60 million new vehicles per year, center officials said, adding that if post-sale repair and maintenance are included, the demand for automobile electronics will see dramatic growth annually.
With Taiwan's edge in electronics and information technology, the country should be able to make inroads into automobile electronics markets around the world, they added.

DOC.TEXT:
Manila Bulletin: Death of Jesus mourned today

The Straits Times: PAP is 'all systems go' for elections.
The People's Action Party (PAP) is going full steam ahead for the next general election, and will soon enter the next phase of preparations for the polls.
The party rolled out its last batch of new faces yesterday. Tomorrow, Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong will release its election slogan and manifesto during a Young PAP event, talking the country one step nearer to Polling Day.
