DOC.HEADLINE: QUANZHOU-KINMEN 'MINI LINKS' ALREADY ON PLANNING CHART: MAC

TEXT.P: Direct shipping links between Taiwan's outlying island of Kinmen and Quanzhou in the Chinese province of Fujian have already been on the government's planning chart, the head of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said Friday.

The Quanzhou-Kinmen shipping links were included in the government plans when Taiwan initiated direct shipping links between Kinmen and Matsu islands and Fujian Province on Jan. 1, 2001 -- commonly known as the "mini three links -- MAC Chairman Joseph Wu said.

"It's nothing new in terms of government policy on the development of cross-strait relations, " Wu said when commenting on news reports that the Chinese authorities may declare the opening of the Quanzhou-Kinmen mini links as a goodwill gesture during the on-going economic forum between Taiwan's opposition Kuomintang and the Communist Party of China being held in Beijing.
Wu said that as a matter of fact, a plan to begin ferry services between Kinmen and Quanzhou is currently under screening at the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC).

Wu made the remarks at a meeting of the legislative caucus of the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) to which Vice Premier Tsai Ing-wen led an Executive Yuan group to keep the TSU fully abreast of an economic sustainable development conference that the government is planning to convene.

Meanwhile, according to Lin Chih-ming, director of the MOTC Department of Navigation and Aviation, the transportation and communication ministry is helping the private shipping sector solve the navigation problems regarding the ferry route between Kinmen and Quanzhou.

Lin said that a shipping company briefed the MOTC two weeks ago about a Kinmen-Quanzhou ferry service route. A problem that the company is facing is that when heading to Quanzhou, the ferry must first sail southward before turning to head to Quanzhou due to defense regulations imposed by the Ministry of National Defense (MND), Lin said.

Lin said he was told by the shipping company that by doing so, the one-way trip between Kinmen and Quanzhou would take about 100-120 minutes, much longer than the 70 minutes if the ferry were to sail directly in a northward direction from Kinmen to Quanzhou.
Lin said his office would like to talk with the MND authorities about the matter.

According to MOTC tallies, as regulations on the "mini three links" have been continually relaxed year-on-year, the number of people traveling via this channel has increased over the past four years -- to some 1 million in the second half year of 2005.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO CONTINUOUS HIKES IN CONSUMER PRICES EXPECTED: CEPD

TEXT.P: Consumer prices in Taiwan are not expected to rise continuously despite the recent hikes in the prices of certain products, Council of Economic Planning and Development Minister Hu Sheng-cheng said Friday.

Hu made the remarks in response to public concerns over the possible increase in inflation rate following the hikes in sugar prices by the state-run Taiwan Sugar Co. Also, the Chinese Petroleum Corp. is likely to hike oil prices in the near future.
Citing data from the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics, Hu said Taiwan's inflation rate has been declining since the start of this year.

While the consumer price index (CPI) increased only 0.41 percent in March over the same time last year, the CPI rose 1.35 percent year-on-year for the first quarter of this year, with the hikes in food product prices contributing 0.86 percentage points to the increase and the hikes in oil prices contributing 0.23 percentage points, Hu pointed out.

Hu said that the inflation rate is expected to gain 0.2 percentage points if oil prices are hiked 10 percent for one year and that the consumer prices will remain reasonable as long as food prices are maintained at a normal level.
He said the government will keep close watch over the situation but will avoid taking any intervention actions.

DOC.HEADLINE: FIRMS ATTENDING BEIJING FORUM MAY HELP BOOST CROSS-STRAIT TIES: MAC

TEXT.P: Taiwan entrepreneurs might be able to contribute to normalizing cross-Taiwan Strait relations if they make necessary suggestions to the Chinese authorities, the head of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said Friday.

Responding to the ongoing economic forum between Taiwan's opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and the Communist Party of China (CPC) being held in Beijing, in which executives of some 50 leading Taiwan businesses reportedly are also taking part, MAC Chairman Joseph Wu said that through their wisdom accumulated from their contributions to Taiwan's economic prosperity, executives of leading Taiwan businesses could serve as a catalyst for improving cross-strait political and business relations in the event that they offer the necessary suggestions during the KMT-CPC forum.

Speaking at the Legislative Yuan, Wu said that as Taiwan is a democratic country that follows market economic laws, the government will not and cannot impose any bans on their moves, such as attending the KMT-CPC forum.

Wu said the Taiwan entrepreneurs' participation in the forum is nothing for the government to fret over, although he admitted that the government is "concerned" about their activities in China, on the grounds that Taiwan's economic future hinges on their contributions in addition to the right policies and leadership direction of the government.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened high and closed higher Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 96.8 points to close at 6,952.54.
The bourse opened at 6,888.18 and fluctuated between 6,952.54 and 6,876.47 during trading. A total of 4.4 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$118.8 billion (US$3.66 billion).

All eight major stock categories gained ground, with paper and pulp issues moving up the most at 6.5 percent, followed by construction issues at 1.9 percent, cement stocks at 1.6 percent, machinery and electronics shares and banking and financial shares both at 1.5 percent, plastics and chemicals shares at 1.4 percent, textile stocks at 1.3 percent, and foodstuff issues at 1.1 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 677 to 232, with 114 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOE URGED TO RELEASE LIST OF PERMITTED SIMPLIFIED CHINESE CHARACTERS

TEXT.P: An opposition Kuomintang lawmaker urged the Ministry of Education (MOE) Friday to ditch a policy proposal under which students using simplified Chinese characters in examinations will have their marks deducted.
Legislator Wang Yu-ting said the policy should not be implemented until the MOE updates its list of commonly accepted simplified characters to serve as the criteria for mark deductions.
Wang pointed out that according to a list of standard characters published by the MOE, there are 57 commonly seen simplified characters that are now considered standard characters.

While the policy is expected to apply to basic ability tests for junior high school students starting this May, the MOE has so far not made public the criteria for mark deductions, which has caused anxiety among the students, Wang said.

Holding a similar view, Wang Kai-fu, a Chinese language professor at National Taiwan Normal University, said the policy will create a lot of trouble unless the MOE first clarifies exactly which simplified characters are forbidden.

Addressing the issue a few days ago, Education Minister Tu Cheng-sheng said students taking the tests are prohibited from using the simplified characters created by the Chinese authorities but are allowed to use those that have "become commonly accepted owing to evolution of languages."

DOC.HEADLINE: WEATHER TO DECIDE FORMOSAT-3 SATELLITE'S LAUNCH TIME
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, April 13 (CNA) (By Chu Lu-sheng & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Weather conditions will dictate whether Taiwan's third satellite project -- FORMOSAT-3 -- can be launched Friday as scheduled, project leader Dr. Chen Cheng-yi said Thursday.

The only factor that could delay the lift-off at the Vandenberg air force base in California is an expected thunderstorm, Chen said, noting that forecasters indicated that a thunderstorm front was expected to hit California Friday that would not leave until Saturday.

Since FORMOSAT-3 will be carried by a U.S. Air Force-owned spaceship on its journey into orbit, only a command from the Vandenberg base for the launch project can decide whether the launch will go ahead, Chen said.
FORMOSAT-3 is scheduled to be launched at 17:10, Western time, or 08:10 Saturday, Taipei time.

FORMOSAT-3, also known as Constellation Observing System for Meteorology, Ionosphere and Climate (COSMIC) , is an international collaborative project between Taiwan's National Space Organization and the University Corporation for Atmospheric Research of the U.S. It will be the world's first climate monitoring and forecasting system using a constellation of six microsatellites to collect atmospheric remote sensing data for operational weather prediction, according to Chen.

The satellite's mission will involve the placement of six microsatellites into six different orbits ranging between 700 km and 800 km above the earth's surface. The project is an academic research program with the goal of developing an advanced system for real-time monitoring of the globe's climate.
After it becomes fully operational, FORMOSAT-3 will be capable of providing some 2,500 pieces of meteorological data in every 24-hour period, covering all areas of the globe.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMOSAT-3 TO BE LAUNCHED

TEXT.P: The National Space Organization (NSPO) said Friday that the FORMOSAT-3, Taiwan's third sounding satellite, will be launched by the U.S. Air Force April 15 at 8: 10 a.m. Taipei time from Vandenberg air base, California to provide vital data for weather prediction, as well as research on the ionosphere, gravity, and global climate change.

The NSPO said the FORMOSAT-3, which has six micro-satellites, will be sent to the initial parking orbit of about 500 kilometers in altitude on Saturday. In 13 months, all six micro-satellites will gradually settle in their designed orbital planes to form a full function constellation.

An NSPO expert explained that equipped with three primary science payloads, Global Positioning System (GPS) radio receivers, tiny ionospheric photometer (TIP), and tri-band beacon transmitter ( TBB), FORMOSAT-3 can obtain near real-time figures on air pressure, temperature, water vapor in the atmosphere, and the electron density of the ionosphere.

The expert also said that although Germany already has one satellite with similar functions in operation, the FORMOSAT-3 is so far the only one that has six micro-satellites to cover the entire global atmosphere and ionosphere, as well as to provide sounding data on as much as 2,500 locations per day.

The NSPO's first satellite project, FORMOSAT-1, was designed to observe the effects of ionospheric plasma and electrodynamics, while the second project, FORMOSAT-2, was designed to conduct remote sensing and imaging over Taiwan.
The FORMOSAT-3 is a Taiwan-U.S. collaborative project, carried out by the NSPO in Taiwan and the University Corporation for Atmospheric Research (UCAR) in the United States.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMIC FORUM IS CHINA'S WAY OF HIDING EVIL INTENTIONS: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Friday that an economic and trade forum between Taiwan's opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and China's Communist Party of China (CPC) is China's way of hiding its evil intentions toward Taiwan.

Chen was referring to the two-day forum that opened in Beijing Friday, while he received a delegation from the National Committee on American Foreign Policy headed by Winston Lord, a former U.S. ambassador to China, at the Presidential Office.

According to the president, both the forum and a second meeting between Lien Chan, the KMT's honorary chairman, and Chinese President and CPC General Secretary Hu Jintao scheduled for Sunday are a "cloth used by China to cover up its hidden evil intentions toward Taiwan."

He said he believes it is a deliberate attempt by Hu to create "a facade of cross-Taiwan Strait peace" to mislead the international community prior to a scheduled meeting with U.S. President George W. Bush in Washington, D.C. April 20.
Beijing is aiming at "mitigating Washington's pressure in urging the Chinese leadership to have dialogue with Taiwan's duly elected government and leader," Chen said.

"All can remember that the first Lien-Hu meeting took place April 29, 2005, shortly after Beijing's enactment of the Anti-Secession Law targeting Taiwan in March, " Chen said, describing that meeting as also a deliberate bid by Hu to cushion the mounting pressure from the international community against its newly enacted law codifying the use of force against Taiwan should it move toward formal independence.

Beijing is using the same strategy to circumvent the duly elected government in Taiwan, Chen went on, adding, however, that as long as China refuses to renounce its one-party authoritarian rule and its use of force against Taiwan, then all its forums are just "facades."

He noted that the cover story of the latest edition of The Journalist, a news magazine that he described as "friendly toward the KMT, " reported that the five-point consensus -- including the resumption of stalled cross-strait talks and the termination of bilateral hostility -- reached after the first Lien-Hu meeting has achieved absolutely nothing a year after it was reached.
Chen predicted that the second Lien-Hu meeting will produce yet another "bounced check."
The president said that this is why the U.S. has encouraged cross-strait dialogue, especially Beijing's opening of dialogue with Taiwan's leader, to resolve cross-strait differences.
"Because regardless of whether the participants in the forum are enterprises or representatives of political parties, they cannot replace the government's authority," Chen pointed out.

On cross-strait trade and economy, he said the government's stance is unequivocal -- that the Chinese market is but one of the global markets and that Taiwan should not pin its economic lifeline and all its resources on China.
"Sovereignty, democracy, peace and equal footing" will be the guiding principles in dealing with cross-strait issues, Chen said.
China must respect and recognize the fact of the existence of Taiwan, respect the free will of the Taiwan people and not resort to force, he went on.
China should also use the results achieved in cross-strait talks in Hong Kong in 1992 to resume government-to-government negotiations, Chen added.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Friday, decreasing NT$0.017 to close at NT$32.481.
A total of US$680 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$32.520 and fluctuated between NT$32.425 and NT$32.540.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES HIGHER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Friday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for April moved up 118 points to close at 6,984, with 42,551 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for May increased 136 points to finish at 6,986, with 8,364 contracts traded, while June futures gained 112 points to end at 6,932, with 147 contract transactions. September futures increased 130 points to close at 6,790, with 23 contracts traded, while December futures moved up 126 points to finish at 6,760, with 10 contract transactions.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Friday at 6,866 for April, 6,850 for May, 6,820 for June, 6,660 for September and 6,634 for December.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were higher.

April TE futures increased 5.6 points to close at 310.5, with 5,917 contracts traded, while May TE futures gained 5.85 points to finish at 310, with 1,202 contract transactions. June TE futures moved up 0.5 points to end at 303, with one contract traded, while December TE futures increased 4.4 points to end at 300.05, with five contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for September.

April TF futures increased 9.4 points to finish at 921.4, with 2,562 contracts changing hands, while May TF futures gained 10.6 points to close at 920.6, with 593 contracts traded. September TF futures moved up nine points to end at 902, with 12 contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for June and December.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING DAMAGES ITSELF BY WITHDRAWING FROM ANMC21: TOKYO MAYOR

TEXT.P: Beijing is damaging its own interests by withdrawing from the organization of the Asian Network of Major Cities (ANMC21), Tokyo Mayor Shintaro Ishihara said in Taipei Friday.

At a press conference to mark the close of the 5th annual convention of the ANMC21 in Taipei, Ishihara -- who initiated the formation of the ANMC21 in August 2000 in Kuala Lumpur during a joint conference involving the cities of Tokyo, Kuala Lumpur, Delhi and Seoul -- said Beijing's withdrawal is having a negative impact on the Chinese capital.

According to Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, one of the hosts of the convention, Taipei tried to win hosting privileges to the network's 2006 annual meeting, but China intervened, provoking a controversy at the 2004 ANMC21 meeting in Jakarta. Beijing did not sign the Jakarta agreement and withdrew from the organization, he noted.

The 2004 Jakarta Declaration stated that Beijing would host the 2005 annual meeting and that Taipei had the "priority" right of hosting the 2006 meeting, according to Ma, who noted that Beijing did not sign the declaration and quit the organization, so the 2005 meeting was skipped, leading to Taipei hosting the fifth ANMC21 meeting half a year ahead of schedule.
By taking over the ANMC21 from Beijing, Taipei has enabled the network to continue functioning and has smashed China's attempt to obstruct Taipei from hosting the event, he added.

Ishihara said during the press conference that when in Jakarta, ANMC21 member cities put forth several versions concerning the hosting privileges to the network's 2005 annual meeting, but none of the versions was accepted by China.

Noting that China is a notorious major polluter in Asia and a major source of illegal immigrants, Ishihara claimed that the entry of illegal Chinese immigrants into Japan is one of the factors behind Tokyo's high crime rate.
He said Beijing is an important Chinese city and that important cities symbolize their countries, adding that Beijing's withdrawal from the ANMC21 was regrettable.

The 2006 annual convention of ANMC21 issued a "Taipei Declaration" Friday, one day before its close, after mayors and top city officials from Tokyo, Singapore, Seoul, Delhi Bangkok, Jakarta, Hanoi, Manila, Kuala Lumpur and Taipei took part in the four-day event April 13-16.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Prodi: Victory is confirmed.
Opposition Union leader Romano Prodi said Thursday that his victory in the April 9-10 general elections was confirmed in light of the fact that only several hundreds of officially disputed ballots were sent to the appeal court for examination. Prodi's center-left alliance won a razor-margin majority of 25,000 votes in the elections of House of Deputies out of 38.1 million cast.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT SHOULD URGE CHINA TO TALK WITH TAIWAN GOVERNMENT: MAC

TEXT.P: The Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) urged the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Friday to demand that the Chinese authorities open talks with the Taiwan government.
A KMT delegation led by the party's honorary chairman, Lien Chan, is visiting China to take part in a cross-Taiwan Strait economic and trade forum with the Communist Party of China (CPC).
The MAC pointed out that the forum is an exchange activity between individual political parties and said it cannot violate the framework for political party exchanges.

"To fulfill its duty, the KMT should demand that the Chinese authorities clarify whether they agree with the Republic of China's sovereign status as laid out in the so-called `1992 Consensus' as the KMT claims. At least the KMT should ask the Chinese authorities to declare that their stance is the same as that of the KMT, as this would be beneficial to the resumption of official cross-strait talks," MAC Vice Chairman David W.F. Huang said.

Huang said the KMT should also demand that the Chinese authorities reflect on their Taiwan policies, which are against Taiwan's popular opinions and democratic values, and urge them to engage in talks with the Taiwan government to initiate normal interactions.

He refuted the Chinese authorities' recent claim that everything is ready for cross-strait exchanges except for the Taiwan government's consent. He pointed out that the Taiwan government has already completed necessary plans for the exchanges proposed by Beijing, but claimed that the Chinese authorities are stalling for political considerations.

"The Taiwan government is open-minded and willing to negotiate with the Chinese authorities on various issues, including opening Taiwan to Chinese tourists, direct charter flights and the export of Taiwan agricultural produces to China," Huang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT: NO NEED FOR A 2ND KMT-DPP HEAD MEETING AT PRESENT STAGE

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou has no plans to hold a second meeting with President Chen Shui-bian at the present stage, a KMT spokesman said Friday.

Huang Yu-cheng, deputy director of the KMT's cultural and communications department, made clear the KMT position when asked by reporters to respond to a call by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) that Chen and Ma should meet again to discuss how to revive Taiwan's economy.

At a meeting in the Presidential Office a day earlier, DPP party leaders and DPP members serving as senior government officials decided that Ma should be invited to a second meeting with the president, with the focus of their discussion placed on issues that most affect people's livelihoods.

Huang said that the KMT "sees no need for a second Chen-Ma meeting at present. As to whether such a meeting will take place in the future, it will depend on the overall climate and the topics for discussion."
The KMT spokesman indicated that there are many urgent economic issues that could be tackled right away if the Cabinet could reach consensus with the Executive Yuan.
"If the DPP government really wants to devote itself to improving the nation's economy, it could do so right away without waiting for a second Chen-Ma meeting," he said.

Chen and Ma met April 3 at the Presidential Office and talked about a variety of topics, including the definition of the controversial "one China" policy, the cessation of the National Unification Council and its guidelines, arms procurement and constitutional reform. The two-hour meeting ended with neither side bending to the other on any of the issues at stake.

Ma acknowledged afterwards that he met with the president despite opposition within the KMT because he wanted to relay some important messages to him and allow him to explain his positions on the various issues.

According to results of an opinion poll conducted by the United Daily News shortly after the meeting, Ma's approval rating dropped from 67 percent to 58 percent, while that of Chen dropped from 21 percent to 20 percent.
It is believed Ma's reluctance to meet with the president again might be related to the lesson he has learned that he would have nothing to gain from another meeting with Chen.

DOC.HEADLINE: ITC RULES SAFEGUARD MEASURES ON CHINESE TOWELS

TEXT.P: The International Trade Commission under the Ministry of Economic Affairs decided Friday on relief measures it will implement to protect local towel manufacturers from Chinese dumping.
Officials said custom duties on imported Chinese towels will be changed from the current level of 10.5 percent based on price to a levy according to volume.
In the first year, tariffs will be NT$42 (US$1.3) per kilo, with NT$32 in the second year and NT20 in the third year, all of which will not be lower than the duties levied under the existing policy.

After a lengthy probe into Taiwan towel makers' complaints about Chinese dumping, the commission reached a conclusion March 17 that local towel makers have been harmed by a deluge of cheap Chinese products entering the Taiwan market.

Local towel makers have complained that since both Beijing and Taipei entered the World Trade Organization, China-made towel imports have taken 70 percent of the Taiwan market and have driven major local towel manufacturers out of business.

DOC.HEADLINE: FIRST DAUGHTER FILES DEFAMATION SUIT AGAINST POLITICAL COMMENTATOR

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian's daughter Chen Hsin-yu has filed a defamation suit at the Taipei District Court against Hu Chung-hsin, a noted political commentator, over the latter's allegation that she opened an account in the United States to launder money, officials from the Department of Public Affairs under the Presidential Office said Friday.

Hu made accusations against Chen while attending a TV talk show Oct. 11 and Oct. 18 last year, alleging that she had traveled to the U.S. to open a bank account to help her father conceal his assets, under the pretext of attending a meeting, the officials said.

The allegation then was quoted by Web sites in China, which described the first family as a criminal ring, seriously undermining the reputation of the first daughter and the first family, even affecting the public assessment of the first family, they said.

The officials added that the first daughter had not opened any account in the U.S. to conceal the president's assets and was forced to file suit to protect her name and deter erroneous misinformation.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR URGES BEIJING TO DEMONSTRATE GOODWILL TOWARD TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou urged Beijing Friday to treat the Asian Network of Major Cities 21 (ANMC21) with a sense of cooperation and goodwill.

Ma suggested that all major Asian cities dedicate themselves to boosting cooperative relationships and said no conflicts should be raised due to "technical problems. " He was referring to Beijing's withdrawal from the regional organization in fit of pique in 2004.

Ma made the call at a news conference co-hosted by the cities attending the AMNC21's fifth annual plenary meeting, which kicked off a day earlier in Taipei and closed Friday after delegates of all the participant cities released a "Taipei declaration."
In addition to Taipei, the cities taking part in the 2006 plenary meeting include Bangkok, Delhi, Hanoi, Jakarta, Kuala Lumpur, Manila, Seoul, Singapore and Tokyo.
Manila will be the host city for the 2007 meeting.

ANMC21 was originally proposed by Tokyo Mayor Shintaro Ishihara in August 2000 in Kuala Lumpur during a joint conference involving Tokyo, Kuala Lumpur, Delhi and Seoul. It had 12 member cities before Beijing withdrew in 2004 after failing to hinder the regional organization giving Taipei priority as the host city of the 2006 meeting.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO PROVIDE MEDICAL HELP TO MARSHALL ISLANDS

TEXT.P: Visiting Marshall Islands President Kessai Note said Friday that Taiwan has the advantages of good healthcare and sanitation, power generation, and fisheries, and can help upgrade the living standards of his country.

Note made the remarks during a second round of meetings with President Chen Shui-bian Friday on a range of issues of mutual concern, including measures to further boost bilateral cooperation and the Asia-Pacific regional situation.
Chen thanked Note for his visit and expressed concern about the health of the Marshall Islands first lady, who fell ill during their visit.
Note thanked Chen for the medical treatment his wife received in southern Taiwan.
Chen said he would like to provide the Marshall Islands with Taiwan's experience in economic development and expressed hope for further enhanced bilateral relations.
Note, who arrived in Taiwan April 10 for a six-day state visit, is scheduled to depart Taiwan Saturday. This is Note's fourth visit to Taiwan since May 2002.

Taiwan and the Marshall Islands established diplomatic ties Nov. 20, 1998. Since Note took office six years ago, he has on many occasions publicly expressed support for Taiwan's bid to join major international organizations, including the United Nations and the World Health Organization.

DOC.HEADLINE: ANMC21 ISSUES 'TAIPEI DECLARATION' ON CLOSER COOPERATION

TEXT.P: The Asian Network of Major Cities (ANMC21) concluded its fifth annual meeting in Taipei Friday after issuing a joint declaration on forging closer cooperative relations among member cities and playing a more important role in the international community.

Delegates from 10 ANMC21 member cities -- Bangkok, Delhi, Hanoi, Jakarta, Kuala Lumpur, Manila, Seoul, Singapore, Taipei and Tokyo -- signed the "Taipei Declaration" after two days of discussions on measures to galvanize the positive aspects of all member cities and expand their international presence.

Addressing the closing session, Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou expressed his gratitude for the foreign delegates who traveled to Taipei to attend the meeting and contribute their wisdom to the promotion of common prosperity and development of all ANMC21 member cities and the upgrading of the quality of life of their residents.

The declaration reviewed the organization's work since its establishment four years ago, saying that all member cities have achieved "steady results in implementing 18 joint projects, including `Promotion of Development of a small- to medium-sized Jet Passenger Plane' and `Countermeasures to Combat Infectious Diseases in Asia, '" and will continue working together to further advance and improve these projects.
During the past two days, the declaration went on, the conference attendees also discussed how to use information technology (IT) to further enhance urban functions and the civil service.

Noting that Asia has high IT potential, the declaration said all ANMC21 member cities will provide more IT-based civic services as a way of bridging the digital divide. The declaration also pledged that all member cities will make efforts to utilize IT to enhance their international presence and profile.

During this round of meetings, the declaration continued, all the participants reaffirmed their commitment to friendship and cooperation, and pledged to keep working together to tackle the common challenges they share, such as environmental issues, promotion of culture and tourism, advancing women's rights and joint development of new technology.
The 2006 plenary session also reached a conclusion that the sixth ANMC21 meeting will be held in Manila in November 2007.

Among the participants in the fifth ANMC21 meeting were Tokyo Mayor Shintaro Ishihara, Mayor Matthias Yao of Singapore and deputy mayors or senior delegates from eight other Asian cities -- Seoul, Delhi, Bangkok, Jakarta, Hanoi, Manila, Kuala Lumpur and Taipei.

Ishihara took the initiative to form the ANMC21 in Malaysia in August 2000 during a joint conference involving Tokyo, Kuala Lumpur, Delhi and Seoul. It had 12 member cities before Beijing withdrew in 2004 after failing to hinder the regional organization giving Taipei priority as the host city of the 2006 meeting. Yangon was also absent from the just-concluded meeting.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT VOWS TO WATCH OUT FOR UNUSUAL PRICE HIKES

TEXT.P: As prices of many commodities such as sugar and flour have surged after international crude oil prices skyrocketed to break the US$70 per barrel barrier, the Fair Trade Commission (FTC) said Friday that it respect the market mechanism regarding price fluctuations but will pay extra attention to "unusual" price hikes.

FTC member Chen Jung-chie said the commission will particularly watch out for international and seasonal price fluctuations, such as prices of consumer goods ahead of and during the traditional Spring Festival, as well as those of fresh milk in April, garlic in October and November, and fuel.

Unless there are people trying to profiteer by raising prices through improper means including hoarding, employing monopolization, and collaborative pricing, the FTC will respect the market and rulings of relevant authorities in terms of price changes, Chen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: More Retired Generals Call for Rumsfeld's Resignation
The widening circle of retired U.S. generals who have stepped forward to call for Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld's resignation is shaping up as an unusual outcry that could pose a significant challenge to Rumsfeld's leadership, current and former generals said on Thursday. Maj. Gen. Charles H. Swannack Jr., who led troops on the ground in Iraq as recently as 2004 as the commander of the Army's 82nd Airborne Division, on Thursday became the fifth retired senior general in recent days to call publicly for Rumsfeld's ouster. Also Thursday, another retired Army general, Maj. Gen. John Riggs, joined in the fray. There were indications on Thursday that the concern about Mr. Rumsfeld, rooted in years of pent-up anger about his handling of the war, was sweeping aside the reticence of retired generals who took part in the Iraq war to criticize an enterprise in which they participated.
Wall Street Journal: As Markets Bet on Rate Increases, Fed Officials Seem Less Committed
Financial markets increasingly expect the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates in May and keep lifting them into the summer. But not all Fed officials are convinced that much action will be needed. Two factors are influencing the markets. One is upbeat economic news, such as Ma rch's hefty job gains, which confirmed other ind ications that the first quarter was very strong. Fed officials agree that makes a rate increase in May very likely. The second factor is that the markets read the Fed's March statement as a commitment to raise rates in May and probably in June. But some Fed officials say they were trying to convey an inclination, not a commitment, to move rates in May, and weren't sending any signal about June.

DOC.HEADLINE: DELHI TRANSFORMING LIKE ALL ASIAN MAJOR CITIES

TEXT.P: Like all other major Asian cities, Delhi is working hard to transform itself into a better metropolis, Delhi city executives said Friday on the sidelines of a cultural and tourism exhibition of major Asian cities.

Delhi is among nine cities that participated in the "Asia TransPerforming" exhibition, a subordinate event of the Fifth Plenary Meeting of the Asian Network of Major Cities 21 (ANMC21), which ended that day in Taipei.

"Delhi's infrastructure construction is moving fast. We are reconstructing the airport and establishing a rapid transit system, and our tourism is taking off, " said Vimal Malhotra, divisional manager of the Delhi State Industrial Development Corporation (DSIDC), a government undertaking.

"Most people are not familiar with Delhi -- India's capital city, " DCIDC official Sharat Kumar said. "The population of Delhi is 15 million, which is two-thirds of Taiwan's population and more than that of Australia."
"Most people don't realize that you can almost do anything in Delhi on the Internet. Everything is connected on-line, " Kumar said.

The city will host the Commonwealth Games in 2010, which will be an opportunity for Delhi to show the world what it has to offer. Malhotra said: "With the direction Delhi is going at the moment, I believe people won't be disappointed."

DOC.HEADLINE: WIDE-RANGING TAIWAN-INDIA COMMERCIAL FORUM TO BE HELD IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: A large scale Taiwan-India forum aimed at increasing commercial exchanges and helping Taiwanese businessmen to "seize the India trend" will be held from April 27-28 in Taipei, organizers said Friday.

"This is the first time that experts from Taiwanese and Indian enterprises, academia, government and research institutes will have assembled on a single platform to discuss a wide range of commercial topics on India, " said Ho Mei-yueh, secretary-general of the Taiwan-India Cooperation Council (TICC).

The forum, titled "Seize the India Trend" is being organized by the TICC, the Taiwan Thinktank and the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) and is a response to the "Go South" policy the government advocates to shift the over-dependence of Taiwan's economy on China to South Asia, especially India.

The list of foreign guest speakers features executives from well-known Indian enterprises such as TVS Electronics, Synovate Business Consulting, and the Manufacturers' Association for Information Technology (MAIT).
Acer founder Stan Shih will lead a group of local speakers from the fields of government agencies, enterprises and the media.

Taiwanese businessmen have been successful in China, the Philippines, the Czech Republic and Hungary in the past few years, and it is time for them to take a look at India -- one of the fastest-emerging markets, said Vijay Gokhale, director-general of the India-Taipei Association.

India is going full-speed for political reform and refining the infrastructure, which includes airports, ports and highways, said Gokhale, adding that "in five years you will see big changes in India."

With more than 100 million middle-class people, India will also be a market with strong buying power that will benefit Taiwanese businesses, Gokhale added. He encouraged Taiwan people to learn more about India through the exchange forum.

The speakers will address general topics such as Taiwan's trade and economic policies in response to India's emerging market and branding Taiwan enterprises on the first day. More detailed sessions on different sectors -- textiles, medical, software and automobiles, to name a few -- will take place on the second day.

A semi-government organization established in February with the help of the Taiwan Thinktank, the TICC aims at strengthening economic, trade, parliamentary, artistic and cultural ties between Taiwan and India.
The forum will be held at the International Convention Center of the National Taiwan University Hospital.

DOC.HEADLINE: VISIT OF TOKYO CITY COUNCILORS HELPS TAIWAN-JAPAN EXCHANGES

TEXT.P: A recent visit to Taipei by 18 Tokyo city councilors has played a significant role in exchanges between the capital cities of Taiwan and Japan, Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) officials said Friday.
Exchanges between local governments have been given priority in efforts to promote Taiwan-Japan relations, the officials noted.

A MOFA news release said Friday that a 39-member delegation of a pro-Taiwan group of Tokyo city councilors of the ruling Liberal Democratic Party (LDP), headed by Kabayama Takashi, visited Taiwan April 12-14.

The delegation called on President Chen Shui-bian Thursday, took part in the two-day fifth annual plenary meeting of the Asian Network of Major Cities 21 that began in Taipei Thursday and also visited their Taipei counterparts.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT HONORARY CHAIRMAN CALLS FOR CROSS-STRAIT COMMON MARKET
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, April 14 (CNA) (By Chang Ming-kun and Han Nai-kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan and China should establish a common market, beginning with cooperation in the areas of agriculture, finance, energy and charter flights, Lien Chan, honorary chairman of Taiwan's opposition Kuomintang (KMT), said in Beijing Friday.

Speaking at the opening ceremony of a two-day economic and trade forum between the KMT and the Communist Party of China (CPC), Lien said that if the two sides miss the "rare window of opportunity" for mutual cooperation, they will both end up losers.

Lien, who is leading a 170-member KMT delegation to attend the forum, said he suggested the four relatively uncontroversial areas for cooperation because they are what the people on both sides need most at present and could yield the greatest benefits.

Noting that the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) government in Taipei has agreed to allow charter flights across the Taiwan Strait, he said the move shows that the DPP government is reluctant to move forward without a push from the opposition.

He criticized the lack of direct air links between Taiwan and China as the reason why he and his delegation were forced to spend eight hours making a detour in their flight path from Taipei to Beijing.
"I think everybody would have the same feeling: the detour was such a waste," he said.
Lien acknowledged that there are two irreversible trends in the world: regional economic cooperation and the rise of China.

He underlined the importance of Taiwan's trade relations with China and indicated that although Taiwan has faced a recessive domestic market over the past six years, it still managed to record an average economic growth rate of 3.57 percent, thanks mainly to its trade surplus with China.
The current visit is Lien's third to China within a year. He is scheduled to meet with Chinese President Hu Jintao Sunday.

During his first visit to China from April 26 to May 3 last year, Lien held talks with Hu in his then-capacity as KMT chairman -- the first talks between the heads of the KMT and the CPC since the 1940s. He made a second trip in October last year to see a panda conservation program in Sichuan Province.
Lien's delegation to the forum includes many influential Taiwanese industry leaders whose enterprises represent more than 40 percent of Taiwan's total industrial output.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP SLAMS KMT-CPC BEIJING FORUM

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) accused the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Friday of aligning with the Communist Party of China (CPC) to bully Taiwan, claiming that a KMT-CPC economic forum that kicked off earlier the same day in Beijing is hard evidence of this bullying.

DPP officials, including the party's public relations department head Tsai Huang-liang and China affairs department head Lai I-chung, condemned the KMT and the CPC at a news conference at the DPP headquarters following the opening of the forum.

According to Tsai, an address given by KMT Honorary Chairman Lien Chan at the forum's opening was nothing but flattery of China and also a demonstration of his disparagement of Taiwan. Lien's all-out effort to tout Taiwan investment in China reflects his lack of a global deployment and risk management concept, Tsai said.

In view of the anti-Taiwan independence remarks made recently by Jia Qinglin, a standing member of the CPC Central Committee Political Bureau, it is easy to see that the KMT and the CPC are conspiring against Taiwan, Tsai said.

He also lashed out at Lien for failing to underline Taiwan's national sovereignty and for failing to protest to Beijing officials against China's opposition that led to Taiwan's exclusion from world bodies.

Echoing Tsai's remarks, Lai claimed that Lien made various "mistakes" in his speech. For instance, he pointed out, Lien fell short of identifying China as the hurdle to Taiwan's participation in the region's free trade agreements. Lien should also make it clear to Beijing that it is to blame for Taiwan becoming an outcast in regional and international activities, he added.

Lai claimed that Lien was totally wrong when he called China a world economic powerhouse and a major world market and advocated a common market across the Taiwan Strait. Lien's efforts to tie Taiwan's economic development to the Chinese market is the leading obstruction to the nation, he argued.

The DPP does not deny the importance of the Chinese market, but risk control is the key to the issue, he said, blaming Lien for his failure to use the occasion to ask Beijing to improve the investment climate for Taiwan businessmen in China.

To date, Taiwan agricultural exports to China have made little progress, but Taiwanese farmers have been seriously hurt by fake products from China, he said, adding that "flattering China is useless to the call for a better investment environment there."

Lai also questioned the KMT's motivation in taking part in the forum, claiming that the participation by Hu Kang, an economist who is also a member of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference, is solid evidence of the KMT's attempts to contain the DPP government by aligning with the CPC.

According to Lai, Ho has been reported various times by both Chinese and foreign media as supporting the idea of an "economic blockade" of Taiwan. He claimed that should Lien fail to speak against any rhetoric of this kind from Hu at the forum, it will be clear evidence of the KMT's desire to get into bed with the communists.

Lai also asked whether KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou will sum up Lien's stance if Lien does not voice opposition to Hu's desire for an "economic blockade" of Taiwan. He demanded that the KMT give a clear explanation in this regard to the public.

Traveling at the head of a KMT delegation of more than 170 people, Lien arrived in Beijing Thursday to attend the forum that will discuss cross-strait cooperation in tourism, energy, transport links and financial exchanges through April 17.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT TO REVIEW COMMISSIONING OF E2-K EARLY WARNING AIRCRAFT

TEXT.P: Two U.S.-built E2-K early warning and control aircraft will be commissioned into service Saturday to further shore up Taiwan's air defenses, the Ministry of National Defense (MND) said Friday.
President Chen Shui-bian will preside over the commissioning ceremony, to be held at an air force base in Pingtung, southern Taiwan, MND officials said.

Taiwan struck the E2-K procurement deal with the United States last year, the officials said, adding that the air force has completed personnel training and relevant preparations for the delivery of the two planes.
The air force's Thunder Tiger Aerobatics Team will perform a stunning flight show at the E2-K commissioning ceremony to celebrate the expansion of the country's air arm, the officials said.

The show will be the first of its kind after a six-year hiatus. The Thunder Tiger team suspended all aerial shows six years ago after then-Defense Minister Tang Yiau-ming enjoined military personnel to focus on combat preparedness.
In connection with the E2-K commissioning, the officials said, the Pingtung air base will also open its barracks for public visits for two days from Saturday.

Besides watching the air show, visitors can also take a rare glimpse into the nation's air combat arsenals on static display, including AT-3 assault trainers, F-5E jet fighters, locally developed IDF jet fighters, U.S.-built F-16 jet fighters, French-built Mirage jet fighters, E-2T early warning aircraft, C-130H transport planes and many other weaponry systems.

Marching band performances, a local farm produce trade fair and an exhibition of aboriginal artifacts and handicrafts will also be held at the air base during the two-day period to help boost local tourism, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT URGED TO ATTEND NATIONAL ECONOMIC GROWTH CONFERENCE

TEXT.P: A lawmaker of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party urged the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Friday to take part in a national economic conference on sustainable growth to be convened by the Executive Yuan between May and June.

Yeh Yi-jin, a DPP legislative caucus whip, made the call at a Legislative Yuan news conference shortly after a high-profile economic forum between the KMT and the Communist Party of China (CPC) opened in Beijing that same day.

Since the KMT is willing to discuss economic issues with the CPC, it should also hold such talks with the DPP for the sake of national interests, she said, pointing out that Beijing's hostility toward Taiwan is the major reason behind the failure to re-open bilateral negotiations.

Meanwhile, KMT Honorary Chairman Lien Chan is attending an economic forum with CPC officials in Beijing that will run through April 17 -- the first of its kind in more than five decades after Taiwan and China split in 1949 amid a civil war.

Lien arrived in Beijing Thursday at the head of a delegation of more than 170 KMT lawmakers, business leaders and experts to take part in the forum aimed at discussing ways to boost cross-Taiwan Strait cooperation in energy, tourism, transport links and financial exchanges.

Business executives from Taiwan accompanying Lien on the tour said unanimously that economy is Taiwan's lifeline and claimed that political affiliation makes no difference among them in their pursuit of greater business development.
They said that Taiwan should further internationalize and that wider opening is necessary if it wants to play a bigger role on the world stage.

An improvement in cross-strait relations would be very helpful to this end and it is a major concern for many Taiwan businessmen in search of new horizons amid increased globalization that has made China a world economic powerhouse and possibly a world market of the future, they said.

Taiwan must not miss the chance and should not stand on the sidelines of the global market, the businessmen stressed, pointing out that they are very willing to help the government boost Taiwan's economy, through activities such as attending the forum in Beijing, regardless of their political leanings.

As cross-strait economic exchanges are already very close, it is natural that Taiwan businessmen will set their sights on the promising Chinese market, they said, adding that the Taiwan government has not expressed any special concern over their participation in the Beijing forum.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOST PEOPLE WANT SAY IN DETERMINING TAIWAN'S FUTURE: POLL

TEXT.P: An overwhelming majority of local people responding to a recent opinion poll have expressed their desire to have a say in determining Taiwan's future, the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said Friday.

The MAC commissioned National Chengchi University's election research center to conduct the telephone survey from March 31-April 2 to explore local adult people's views on the current state of relations across the Taiwan Strait. A total of 1,088 valid samples were collected, with a margin of error of 2.97 percent.

According to the poll results, 84.3 percent of the respondents agreed with the statement that Taiwan's future should be determined by the people of Taiwan themselves, and only 7.5 percent said Taiwan's future should be jointly determined by the people in Taiwan and China.
On Taiwan's status, 76.6 percent of those surveyed gave a thumbs-up to the statement that Taiwan is a sovereign independent state, and only a marginal 10.5 percent said Taiwan is part of China.

A noteworthy finding was that 34.5 percent of the respondents said the current speed of development in cross-strait exchanges is "too slow" -- the highest ratio since the MAC began to regularly survey local people's views on the issue in 1998.

While the ratio of respondents who said the government's restrictions on investment in China should be more stringent still surpassed the 50 percent mark to reach 54.6 percent in the latest poll, the ratio of those who said the government should further ease the restrictions reached 27.4 percent, also the highest level of all similar MAC-sponsored surveys.

Meanwhile, 54 percent of the respondents said they think local businesses' China investment fever has inflicted a negative impact on Taiwan's economic development and only 29.3 percent said they believe the phenomenon has had a positive effect.
The poll also found that a majority of 88.6 percent support the maintenance of the cross-strait status quo, roughly same as the findings in all previous MAC surveys.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT ASKS RESIDENT NOT TO BE 'FOUL-MOUTHED'
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, April 14 (CNA) (By Chang Ming-kun and Han Nai-kuo)

TEXT.P: A spokesman for Taiwan's main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) said in Beijing Friday that if President Chen Shui-bian wants to work for peace between Taiwan and China, he should not be "foul-mouthed" to the KMT and its economic and trade forum with the Communist Party of China (CPC).

Chang Jung-kung, deputy executive director of the KMT's Central Policy Committee, made the remarks in response to Chen's criticism made in Taipei earlier in the day that the KMT-CPC forum is China's way of "hiding its evil intentions" toward Taiwan.

Chen said he believes the forum is a deliberate attempt by Chinese President Hu Jintao to create "a facade of cross-Taiwan Strait peace" to mislead the international community prior to an April 20 meeting with U.S. President George W. Bush in Washington, D.C.

Chen also quoted a magazine comment as saying that KMT Honorary Chairman Lien Chan, who is heading a 170-member KMT delegation to the two-day forum April 14-15, was "hiding behind a pair of pandas" and that Lien's second meeting with Hu might be just "another bad check."

Rebutting Chen's criticism, Chang said the Democratic Progressive Party government under Chen's leadership in the past six years has achieved nothing in cross-Taiwan Strait relations, except to cause the political deadlock between the two sides to become more serious.
Chang said that as the main opposition party, the KMT is worried about the development and hopes to promote cross-strait peace, beginning with reconciliation between the KMT and the CPC.

The KMT spokesman added, however, that the KMT will not be affected by Chen's criticism and will continue to work for peaceful interactions and mutual benefit in trade and economic areas between Taiwan and mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA'S RISE AT CRITICAL CROSSROADS: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Friday that China's rise has reached a critical crossroads that could either be an opportunity or a threat.
Chen made the remarks while meeting with Tokyo Governor Shintaro Ishihara, who is in Taipei to attend the fifth annual meeting of the Asian Network of Major Cities 21 (ANMC21).

Ishihara touched on the topic regarding China's rise, saying that the United States has gradually come to understand that in China's rise lurks volatile political risks. Among others, Ishihara said, an average of 38,000 violent protests occur in China every year and the Chinese authorities have consistently crushed them with brute force.

Moreover, Ishihara went on, 3 percent of China's crude oil imports come from Sudan and he claimed that China has footed its oil bills by providing weapons for Sudan. In addition, he said, China has purchased a large amount of crude oil from Latin American countries, which he claimed has led to the rise of Anti-American leftist forces there.

In response, Chen said some countries have enormous illusions about China's rise, which they think could offer tremendous opportunities. But for other countries, China's rise could spell a threat to its security, Chen said, adding that for Taiwan, China's rise marks the rise of military threat.
Chen also blamed China for procrastinating government-to-government dialogue with Taiwan.

"U.S. President George W. Bush has said on many occasions that cross-strait issues should be resolved by the two sides of the Taiwan Strait through official dialogue and consultations. Bush has also urged Beijing to hold talks with Taiwan's democratically elected leader," Chen said.

Referring to an economic forum co-sponsored by Taiwan's main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and the Communist Party of China (CPC) being held in Beijing, Chen said cross-strait issues are too prickly, complicated and solemn to be addressed by any non-government organizations or individual politicians.
Without the participation of Taiwan's democratically elected government, Chen said any conclusions reached at the KMT-CPC forum would be empty talks and lead nowhere.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR APRIL 15 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Saturday, April 15:
09:40, President Chen Shui-bian will preside over the commissioning of E2-K early warning and control aircraft to be held at Pingtung air base.
11:00, Premier Su Tseng-chang will meet with Tokyo Governor Shintaro Ishihara at the Executive Yuan guest hall.
13:30, Vice President Annette Lu will attend the opening of a regional meeting of the 3480 District Rotary Club to be held at Grand Hotel in Taipei.
15:00, The World Vision Taiwan will hold a DIY training program at Taipei Youth Activity Center in preparation for the 17th 30-hour fast fund-raising campaign.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HELPS AFRICAN ALLIES FIGHT DISEASES

TEXT.P: An advisory mission organized by the government-funded Taiwan International Health Action (Taiwan IHA) has arrived in Burkina Faso to help the African nation control a bird flu outbreak, Ministry of Foreign Affairs officials said Friday.

Meanwhile, two Taiwan private organizations have recently donated blood collection equipment, including vehicles, tubes an needles, to Malawi to facilitate a blood donation campaign there as the African country faces blood shortages in its fight against AIDS, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, April 15, or the 18th day of the third month of the Year of the Dog according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1865: Andrew Johnson is sworn in as the 17th president of the United States following the assassination of Abraham Lincoln.
1912: The British luxury liner the Titanic sinks after hitting an iceberg during its maiden voyage to New York. More than 1,500 people are feared drowned in the icy waters of the North Atlantic.
1923: Insulin is made available for general use by diabetics when Canadian physiologist Sir Frederick Grant Banting shares a 1923 Nobel Prize for the discovery of insulin.
1927: Chiang Kai-shek, commander-in-chief of the National Revolutionary Forces, organizes the Republic of China government in Nanjing.
1942: Japanese artillery blasts U.S. positions on Corregidor in the Philippines.
1945: Art treasures looted by the Nazis, including paintings by Rubens, Goya, Raphael, and Leonardo da Vinci, are found in an Austrian mine shaft.
1949: The Chinese communists demand ROC government acceptance of their eight-point proposal by April 20, following talks which began in Beijing on April 5.
1952: U.S. President Harry S. Truman signs a peace treaty between the United States and Japan.
1958: The first meeting of independent African nations is held in Accra, Ghana.
1959: U.S. Secretary of State John Dulles resigns due to illness. The American diplomat and politician pursued a policy of opposition to the USSR largely through military and economic aid to American allies.
1966: A team of American virologists develops a vaccine for German measles, known medically as rubella.
1971: President Joseph Desire Mobutu of Congo and his wife arrive in Taipei for a visit.
1971: London and Beijing agree to the reopening of a telephone link between London and Shanghai which had been closed for 22 years.
1975: Praising the late ROC President Chiang Kai-shek as "an old friend and a great leader," Vice President Nelson A. Rockefeller of the United States arrives in Taipei to attend the National Memorial Services for the generalissimo.
1975: ROC Premier Chiang Ching-kuo reveals President Chiang's last written instruction to him. The late leader told his eldest son to assume full responsibility for the fate of the nation without regard to his personal fate.
1976: India and Communist China resume diplomatic relations.
1976: Dr. Alfredo Lamaison, a member of the State Council of Uruguay, and Arg Gustave Nicolich, president of National University, arrive in Taipei for a nine-day visit.
1980: Jean-Paul Sartre, the French writer and philosopher who declined the 1957 Nobel Prize for literature, dies in Paris at the age of 74. A leading existentialist, he wrote literary works such as the autobiographical novel "Nausea" and the play "No Exit," as well as philosophical volumes that include "Being and Nothingness."
1988: President Kim Il Sung receives 43,000 gifts as he celebrates his 76th birthday in style. The North Korean dictator died in 1994.
1989: Hu Yaobang, former general secretary of China's Communist Party, dies of a heart attack in Beijing at the age of 73. A democracy movement is launched by Beijing University students following his death.
1989: Ninety-five soccer fans are crushed to death and 200 injured at Sheffield's Hillsborough Stadium in Britain's worst-ever sports disaster.
1994: The Uruguay Round of talks on the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) concludes with ministers from more than 100 of the world's trading nations signing the GATT pact, the biggest market-opening treaty in history, and also with the announcement of the setting up of the World Trade Organization (WTO).
1996: The United States and Japan announce the closure of six more U.S. military facilities on Okinawa.
1997: The first locally-developed Ching Kuo tactical combat aircraft wing, a second generation ROC Air Force warplane, is founded at the Chingchuankang air force base in Taichung.
1998: Pol Pot, former Khmer Rouge leader, dies of a heart attack.
2000: Republic of China Defense Minister Tang Fei, who has been designated as the next premier by President-elect Chen Shui-bian, checks into Veterans General Hospital to undergo a thymoma operation.
2001: At least four persons are killed and more than 40 injure in an accident involving two buses near Encore Garden in Taichung, central Taiwan.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A wise and good man looks upwards in his aspirations; a fool looks downwards."

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA'S RISE AT CRITICAL CROSSROADS: PRESIDENT(repeat)

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Friday that China's rise has reached a critical crossroads that could either be an opportunity or a threat.
Chen made the remarks while meeting with Tokyo Governor Shintaro Ishihara, who is in Taipei to attend the fifth annual meeting of the Asian Network of Major Cities 21 (ANMC21).

Ishihara touched on the topic regarding China's rise, saying that the United States has gradually come to understand that in China's rise lurks volatile political risks. Among others, Ishihara said, an average of 38,000 violent protests occur in China every year and the Chinese authorities have consistently crushed them with brute force.

Moreover, Ishihara went on, 3 percent of China's crude oil imports come from Sudan and he claimed that China has footed its oil bills by providing weapons for Sudan. In addition, he said, China has purchased a large amount of crude oil from Latin American countries, which he claimed has led to the rise of Anti-American leftist forces there.

In response, Chen said some countries have enormous illusions about China's rise, which they think could offer tremendous opportunities. But for other countries, China's rise could spell a threat to its security, Chen said, adding that for Taiwan, China's rise marks the rise of military threat.
Chen also blamed China for procrastinating government-to-government dialogue with Taiwan.

"U.S. President George W. Bush has said on many occasions that cross-strait issues should be resolved by the two sides of the Taiwan Strait through official dialogue and consultations. Bush has also urged Beijing to hold talks with Taiwan's democratically elected leader," Chen said.

Referring to an economic forum co-sponsored by Taiwan's main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and the Communist Party of China (CPC) being held in Beijing, Chen said cross-strait issues are too prickly, complicated and solemn to be addressed by any non-government organizations or individual politicians.
Without the participation of Taiwan's democratically elected government, Chen said any conclusions reached at the KMT-CPC forum would be empty talks and lead nowhere.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOST PEOPLE WANT SAY IN DETERMINING TAIWAN'S FUTURE: POLL(repeat)

TEXT.P: An overwhelming majority of local people responding to a recent opinion poll have expressed their desire to have a say in determining Taiwan's future, the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said Friday.

The MAC commissioned National Chengchi University's election research center to conduct the telephone survey from March 31-April 2 to explore local adult people's views on the current state of relations across the Taiwan Strait. A total of 1,088 valid samples were collected, with a margin of error of 2.97 percent.

According to the poll results, 84.3 percent of the respondents agreed with the statement that Taiwan's future should be determined by the people of Taiwan themselves, and only 7.5 percent said Taiwan's future should be jointly determined by the people in Taiwan and China.
On Taiwan's status, 76.6 percent of those surveyed gave a thumbs-up to the statement that Taiwan is a sovereign independent state, and only a marginal 10.5 percent said Taiwan is part of China.

A noteworthy finding was that 34.5 percent of the respondents said the current speed of development in cross-strait exchanges is "too slow" -- the highest ratio since the MAC began to regularly survey local people's views on the issue in 1998.

While the ratio of respondents who said the government's restrictions on investment in China should be more stringent still surpassed the 50 percent mark to reach 54.6 percent in the latest poll, the ratio of those who said the government should further ease the restrictions reached 27.4 percent, also the highest level of all similar MAC-sponsored surveys.

Meanwhile, 54 percent of the respondents said they think local businesses' China investment fever has inflicted a negative impact on Taiwan's economic development and only 29.3 percent said they believe the phenomenon has had a positive effect.
The poll also found that a majority of 88.6 percent support the maintenance of the cross-strait status quo, roughly same as the findings in all previous MAC surveys.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HELPS AFRICAN ALLIES FIGHT DISEASES(repeat)

TEXT.P: An advisory mission organized by the government-funded Taiwan International Health Action (Taiwan IHA) has arrived in Burkina Faso to help the African nation control a bird flu outbreak, Ministry of Foreign Affairs officials said Friday.

Meanwhile, two Taiwan private organizations have recently donated blood collection equipment, including vehicles, tubes an needles, to Malawi to facilitate a blood donation campaign there as the African country faces blood shortages in its fight against AIDS, the officials said.

The Japan Times FSA orders suspension at Aiful
The Financial Services Agency said Friday it has ordered consumer finance firm Aiful Corp. to suspend most operations at its 1,700 outlets for three to 25 days over the use of strong- arm collection tactics.
