DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Berlusconi: No winner yet.
Premier Silvio Berlusconi refused to concede defeat Friday despite new data of the Interior Ministry showing that the number of disputed ballots would be insufficient to overturn the victory of the center-left coalition led by Romano Prodi in the just concluded general election. He said that there are neither winners or losers on the basis of popular vote. It is necessary to study a new solution to the stalemate, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMOSAT-3 SUCCESSFULLY LIFTS OFF

TEXT.P: Taiwan's third satellite project -- FORMOSAT-3 -- was successfully launched at 9:40 a.m. Saturday, Taipei time at the Vandenberg air force base in California.
All six microsatellites smoothly broke away from the rocket to go into the orbit 19.19 minutes after the lift-off, according to the Hsinchu-based National Space Organization (NSPO).
President Chen Shui-bian delivered a message of congratulations to the Vandenberg base right after the successful launch.

FORMOSAT-3, also known as Constellation Observing System for Meteorology, Ionosphere and Climate (COSMIC) , is an international collaborative project between Taiwan's National Space Organization and the University Corporation for Atmospheric Research in the U.S.

The project is regarded as the world's first climate monitoring and forecasting system using a constellation of six microsatellites. As soon as the constellation is completed, the microsatellites placed in six different orbits ranging between 700km and 800km above the earth's surface will begin to collect atmospheric remote sensing data for operational weather prediction.
After it becomes fully operational, FORMOSAT-3 will be capable of providing around 2,500 pieces of meteorological data in every 24-hour period, covering all areas of the globe.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN OFFICIAL CALLS FOR SUPPORT OF TAIWAN'S WHO BID
DOC.DATELINE: New York, April 14 (CNA) (By Lillian Lin and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Taiwan should not be excluded from the World Health Organization (WHO) for the sake of the safety of people in Taiwan and in the rest of the world, a Taiwan official said Friday.
Jack Kuo-jung Lee, deputy director of the information division at the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in New York, addressed the issue in an article published in the New York Sun newspaper.

Lee pointed out that while specialists from 192 WHO member states convened on World Health Day in Zambia April 7 to discuss ways to combat disease as a global community, Taiwan is unable to benefit from the meeting or the existing global health network because it is not a WHO member.
Not only is it not a WHO member, Lee noted, but it is also shut out of the Global Outbreak Alert and Response Network and the International Health Regulations 2005 mechanism.
"Taiwan is still struggling to gain access to the global disease prevention and control network. But because of China's intervention, the likelihood of this happening still seems small," he said.

Lee said the exclusion of Taiwan based on political reasons is obviously in violation of the principle of membership universality and the humanitarian spirit of the WHO, and that it is important for the WHO to follow this principle since "infectious diseases know no national boundaries."
For example, Lee said, if a flu virus originating in Thailand spreads to Taiwan -- a busy transportation and trade center -- it is likely the virus will propagate rapidly around the world.

When a large-scale SARS outbreak occurred in China in 2003, Taiwan -- located on the other side of the Taiwan Strait that separates both countries -- soon also fell victim to the SARS crisis, Lee recalled.

Taiwan's failure to obtain any immediate medical information or assistance from the WHO led to the death of 83 Taiwanese from the disease, with financial losses suffered by local industries amounting to US$1.8 billion, Lee said.

Although Taiwan is willing to contribute, the international community has no access to Taiwan's experience in medical development and disease control and prevention because it is not a WHO member, he said.

On Beijing's claim that Taiwan's people have enjoyed the health resources provided by the WHO under the so-called "one China" policy, Lee clarified that the Chinese government has no jurisdiction over Taiwan and therefore it is impossible for Taiwan to benefit from China's WHO membership.

While it is hard to predict when the next outbreak of SARS or flu will occur, a gap in the global health network will definitely bring about an unbearable impact on the international community, he said.

He said Taiwan will not politicize the issue of its WHO participation and is trying to resolve the problem through non-political means, such as putting forth a proposal to join the WHO as a "health entity."
Since the WHO has granted observer status to the Holy See and Palestine, there is no legitimate reason for the WHO to continue denying access to Taiwan, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Straits Times: SM hints: Polls likely in first half of May.
Singapore's General Election will likely take place in the first two weeks of May, Senior Minister Goh Chok Tong hinted yesterday.
The Lianhe Zaobao: SM Goh hits: Polls likely in first half of May.
Senior Minister Goh Chok Tong hinted yesterday that Singapore's General Election will be in the first half of May likely.
He added that three new PAP's candidates have the potential to become Ministers of State.

DOC.HEADLINE: ST. VINCENT DEPUTY PRIME MINISTER TO VISIT TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Louis Straker, deputy prime minister and minister of foreign affairs, commerce and trade of St. Vincent and the Grenadines, is scheduled to arrive in Taiwan April 17 for a six-day visit, Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) officials said Saturday.
During his stay in Taiwan, Straker will meet with President Chen Shui-bian, Vice Premier Tsai Ing-wen and Minister of Foreign Affairs Huang Chih-fang, the officials said.

Straker will also call on the Mainland Affairs Council and visit establishments including Wuling Senior High School in Taoyuan, Taipei's mass rapid transit system, the Taipei 101 building, the National Concert Hall, the Formosan Aboriginal Culture Village, Sun Moon Lake and the Shihlin Night Market in Taipei, they said.
Straker is set to depart April 22, they said.
According to the MOFA, since Straker assumed the post of foreign affairs minister in March 2001, he has made every effort to improve relations between Taiwan and St. Vincent and the Grenadines.

In addition to speaking up for Taiwan twice in the United Nations, Straker wrote to U.N. Secretary-General Kofi Annan in December 2002 calling for the removal of China's deployment of missiles targeting Taiwan.
In May 2003, Straker joined other foreign affairs ministers of Taiwan's diplomatic allies in signing a proposal in support of Taiwan's participation in the World Health Organization as an observer.
Last month, Straker and the ministers addressed a joint letter to the United Nations to express their support for Taiwan's decision to cease the function of the National Unification Council.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONTEST ON RUSSIAN PROFICIENCY TO BE HELD IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: A contest on Russian proficiency is slated to be held April 25 in Taipei in an effort to encourage people in Taiwan to learn about the culture and language of Russia and to promote exchanges between the two countries, said a Russian official stationed in Taiwan Saturday.

George Zinoviev, deputy director of the Moscow-Taipei Economic and Cultural Coordination Commission, said the winner will be awarded with a free trip to Russia, with the top three winners receiving free dinner at Russian restaurants in Taiwan and other valuable prizes.

The contest, the third of its kind, is co-sponsored by the commission and three departments of Russian language and culture at National Chengchi University, Tamkang University and Chinese Culture University.

DOC.HEADLINE: 19 TAIWAN SUPPLIERS TO ATTEND GERMAN EXHIBITION

TEXT.P: Nineteen suppliers from Taiwan will take part in Hannover Messe 2006 April 24-28 in Hannover, Germany, officials at the Taiwan External Trade Development Council said Saturday.

The Taiwan suppliers include those representing the fields of automation equipment, molding, powder metallurgy, casting, rubber or plastic components, power press and air tool parts, machine parts and bonding seals, the officials said.
The world's leading industrial exhibition will bring together approximately 5,000 suppliers from 60 countries this year, featuring 15 exhibition halls, they said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TOKYO AND SEOUL PAY ATTENTION TO URBAN REDEVELOPMENT

TEXT.P: An ongoing exhibition at the Taipei World Trade Center highlights new images of Tokyo and Seoul, both of which have devoted strenuous efforts to urban redevelopment in recent years.
The exhibition is being held in connection with the just-concluded fifth plenary meeting of the Asian Network of Major Cities 21 (ANMC21) hosted by the Taipei City Government.

Cheonggyecheon Restoration Project, which was completed in September 2005, brought back the vitality of downtown Seoul, transforming an area of concrete-covered stream and elevated highway into a leading tourist attraction.

In Tokyo's Akihabara district, the birth of "Akihabara Crossfield" complex aimed at expanding the famous district of eletronic goods to an "IT (Information Technology) hub." The complex was opened in March.

The ancient Cheonggyecheon stream was concreted over in the 1960s to resolve road problems and an elevated highway was constructed on top of the road later. However it started to pose safety and environment concerns for the city.

Led by Seoul Mayor Lee Myung Bak, who launched a "Vision Seoul 2006" initiative, the city of Seoul spent 386.7 billion South Korea won (12 billion $NT) and 27 months to complete the successful project, which has been reported by numerous international media.

Akihabara Crossfield project also tried to bring a "makeover" for an old district. As a part of "Tokyo Plan 2000, " the Tokyo Metropolitan Government released "Urban Development Guidelines for the Akihabara Area" in 2001, highlighting its intent "to create a global center for the IT industry."

The complex consists of two super-highrise buildings: Akihabara Daibiru Building and Akihabara UDX. It is expected to be a new focal point for the Akihabara district, holding areas for Industry-Academia Collaboration, information networking, and attractions for visitors.

Taipei City, which is hosting the Fifth Plenary Meeting of the ANMC21, also has been devoted to various urban redevelopment projects. It has submitted the concept of "Reverse the axis of development. Redevelop the western district, " which seeks to revamp the west side -- the earliest developed area of Taipei.
The estimated budget of urban redevelopment projects in Taipei City this year amounts to NT$40 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'TRANSFORMATIONAL DIPLOMACY' TO IMPACT U.S.-CHINA TIES: MAC

TEXT.P: The "transformational diplomacy" promoted by the U.S. government is expected to extend points of conflict between the United States and China from trade to political and military aspects, according to a recent report released by the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC).

The report pointed out that the idea of "transformational diplomacy" proposed by U.S. Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice Jan. 18 has since become the core diplomatic policy of the George W. Bush administration and that the main thrust of "transformational diplomacy" is to promote democracy around the world in order to achieve the ultimate goal of ending dictatorship.
As shown in the National Security Strategy 2006 report issued last month by the U.S. government, Washington thinks that China's economy is transforming but its politics have not, the MAC report said.

The report noted that the United States has repeatedly referred to China as a country requiring transformation and has taken measures such as pressing China to promote democratization, while strengthening the Chinese language ability of American diplomats and increasing the number of diplomats posted in China.

Under the principle of "transformational diplomacy," Washington's diplomatic policy towards China will be to urge Beijing to enhance its military transparency, stop using "energy diplomacy" to support non-democratic regimes and to carry out political and economic reforms simultaneously, the report said.

The MAC said the transformational diplomacy of the U.S. government was food for thought for Taiwan, where some are pushing the government to open cross-Taiwan Strait economic and trade exchanges with disregard to the fact that democratic development is going backwards in China.

DOC.HEADLINE: MONEY SPENT ON RESEARCH IN TAIWAN INCREASING: DGBAS

TEXT.P: Taiwan spent NT$260.9 billion (US$8.03 billion) on research projects in 2004, accounting for 2.4 percent of the country's gross domestic product (GDP) , similar to the 2.6 percent level in the United States, Germany, and South Korea, according to the Directorate-General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS).

DGBAS statistics released Saturday showed the amount of research funds recorded a growth of 30 percent over 2000, which represented an average annual growth rate of 7.2 percent during the four-year period.

The growth indicated both the government and private enterprises in Taiwan have never spared efforts in promoting research and innovation projects while facing strong global competition by emerging economies with low-priced products.

In an analysis of the 2004 research funds, the DGBAS pointed out that the private industrial sectors spent a total of NT$167.9 billion on high-tech research programs that year, a 33.6 percent growth from the 2000 level.
Most private funds were used in the research and development of innovative information and electronic products, the DGBAS said.

The analysis also showed that private sectors invested twice as much money in research and development as the government during the 2000-2004 period, a situation similar to that of Germany and the U.S.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN PRESIDES OVER COMMISSIONING OF E-2K EARLY WARNING PLANES

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Saturday that the commissioning of two U.S.-built E-2K early warning and control aircraft will enable Taiwan to respond quickly to any contingency in the event of a conflict in the Taiwan Strait.
Chen made the remarks while addressing the aircraft commissioning ceremony at Pingtung air base in southern Taiwan.
The president said the E-2K is one of the latest versions of early warning aircraft in the United States, which he said will greatly enhance the nation's overall air defense capabilities.

Noting that a strong air force will be a pillar in ensuring safety and stability in the Taiwan Strait, he urged legislators across the party spectrum to quickly pass a major arms procurement package from the United States.
"Taiwan is at a critical moment in its transformation and upgrading of combat capabilities," the president said.

But the opposition-controlled Legislative Yuan has continued to block three major items in a major arms procurement package -- eight diesel-electric submarines, a squadron of 12 P-3C anti-submarine aircraft and Patriot PAC-3 anti-missile batteries -- requested by the Executive Yuan, he lamented.

He said that during his April 3 meeting with Ma Ying-jeou, chairman of the main opposition Kuomintang, Ma said the KMT would support a reasonable arms purchase budget, but the arms procurement package was recently rejected by the legislature for the 51st time.
He urged legislators across the board not to put at risk the nation's security or use the defense budget as leverage in political squabbles, and to pass the arms purchase package as soon as possible.
The president later observed various aircraft flying past the review stand, including combat planes flying in formation and the Thunder Tiger Aerobatic Team doing a stunt flying performance.

During the review of ground forces, a minor mishap took place when the 20th battalion's flag snapped while paying tribute to the President. The flag bearer used too much force in saluting the president, a spokesman of the Ministry of National Defense later explained.

DOC.HEADLINE: SWAZI MINISTER OF AGRICULTURE TO VISIT TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Swaziland's Minister of Agriculture and Cooperatives will arrive in Taiwan Monday for a five-day visit, Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) officials said Saturday.

During his stay in Taiwan, Swazi Minister Mtiti Fakudze will exchange views with government officials on the proposed signing of a memorandum of understanding on promoting Taiwan-Swaziland cooperation on agricultural technology, the officials said.
He is slated to meet with Su Jia-chyuan, minister of the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA) , and MOFA Vice Minister Francisco Hwang.

He will also visit the Government Information Office, the COA's Livestock Research Institute, the Farmers' Association in Tainan County, Taiwan Sugar Corp., the National Palace Museum, the historic Chikan Tower and Taipei 101, the world's tallest skyscraper.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER CALLS FOR STEPPING UP INVESTMENT IN INDIA

TEXT.P: Taiwan and Japan can step up investment in India as one measure to cut risks associated with their increased economic interaction with China, Premier Su Tseng-chang said Saturday.
Su made the remarks while meeting with visiting Tokyo Governor Shintaro Ishihara, who is in Taipei to attend the Asian Network of Major Cities (ANMC21), which concluded Friday.

Su noted that although China has recorded rapid economic development in recent years, its economy has still fallen prey to its politics. In addition, China has lax regulations regarding the protection of intellectual property rights, often resorting to theft in the interest of its own technological development.

Also, China has often cracked down on domestic dissent in a violent fashion, and has no regard for environmental protection or human rights, the premier said, adding that China is a country "full of uncertainties."
But India -- with its booming high-tech developments in recent years, large workforce and substantial English-speaking population -- has become a rising star, Su said.

Su also said Taiwan and Japan -- and in fact all surrounding countries -- should be on guard against the avian flu in China, noting that China lacks transparency in reporting the outbreak of the disease.

DOC.HEADLINE: MA URGED TO 'SUMMON KMT LAWMAKERS FROM CHINA' TO SCREEN BILLS

TEXT.P: A legislative caucus whip of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party urged main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou Saturday to "summon KMT lawmakers visiting China" to return soon for review of pending legislation.
Chen Chin-jun was referring to some 30 KMT legislators in Beijing for an economic forum being held jointly by the KMT and the Communist Party of China (CPC).

Chen noted that consideration of the government's arms procurement bill was blocked by the opposition "pan-blue alliance" for nearly two years, which Chen said seriously threatened Taiwan's national defense.

The "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and the People First Party also boycotted the appointment of Hsieh Wen-ting as the nation's state public prosecutor-general, as well as the confirmation of Control Yuan member nominations, which Chen criticized as having damaged the country's constitutional system.

Since Ma has instructed the KMT think tank to study how to resolve problems involving the arms purchase bill and Control Yuan member nominations, he should summon back the KMT lawmakers as soon as possible to screen these major bills pending in the legislature, Chen said.
Chen also questioned why KMT legislators cannot communicate rationally with the ruling DPP administration while were willing to negotiate with China.
Besides, with the Legislative Yuan now in session, the KMT legislators should not forget their duties, Chen added.

Noting that China is employing the "two-faced" strategy of inviting the KMT to convene an economic forum to discuss favorable treatment toward Taiwan while targeting Taiwan with hundreds of missiles and promulgating the "Anti-Secession" Law, Chen reminded opposition parties to beware of China's "united front" tactics which intend to downgrade Taiwan as one of its local governments.
KMT's honorary Chairman Lien Chan is heading a 60-member delegation composed of lawmakers and business leaders to participate in a two-day economic KMT-CPC forum in Beijing that begun Friday.
Chen stressed that Taiwan's government is willing to negotiate with its Chinese counterpart in the interest of economic cooperation, but that such talks should be conducted on an equal footing.
China skipped talks with the DPP administration, but made frequent contacts with the opposition parties, Chen noted, urging the opposition not to make visits to China to "kowtow" to Beijing rulers.

Meanwhile, the KMT's legislative caucus said the same day that the Cabinet should withdraw its arms procurement proposal for a package including eight diesel-electric submarines, a squadron of 12 P-3C anti-submarine aircraft and six Patriot PAC III anti-missile batteries from the United States, since President Chen Shui-bian and the Ministry of National Defense had agreed to acquire the three major items through regular annual budgets instead of being put in a special budget.

Tsai Chin-lung, a KMT legislative caucus leader, noted that the procurement of Patriot PAC III anti-missile batteries had been vetoed by a national referendum, but the DPP still presented it in the package bill, which Tsai said was "very unreasonable.

DOC.HEADLINE: LIEN URGED TO RECOGNIZE TAIWAN'S ACHIEVEMENTS DURING CHINA VISIT

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu urged opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Honorary Chairman Lien Chan to publicly recognize Taiwan's progress and achievements during his current China visit.
Lu made the appeal during a local Rotary Club meeting held at Grand Hotel in Taipei.

Lu criticized Lien, who is heading a 170-member delegation to participate in a Beijing economic forum jointly organized by the KMT and the Communist Party of China (CPC), for saying "not even one good word" about Taiwan's progress during his China visits -- this year or in 2005.

As for domestic business leaders who have accompanied Lien to Beijing for the economic forum, Lu said she respected their efforts in Taiwan over the past several decades, stressing that their achievements, especially in high-tech industries, are the pride of Taiwan.

However, Lu reminded these entrepreneurs that it was Taiwan's government, not China's, that gave them the most preferential treatment by sometimes sacrificing the interests of traditional industries, therefore allowing them to achieve maximum progress.

Due to the constant blocking of the Cabinet's arms procurement proposal by the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and the People First Party, Taiwan's annual defense budget has remained at US$7.65 billion for the past four years, while China's has surged from US$20.4 billion to US$35.1 billion during the same period, Lu stressed.

Under such circumstances, Lu questioned whether Lien had ever asked China to dedicate itself to democratization or reduce its military threat against Taiwan. China has currently more than 700 misiles targeting Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: PROGRESSIVE STEPS TAKEN IN TB CONTROL: CDC CHIEF

TEXT.P: There is currently a set of plans being carried out step-by-step in the promotion of the "Directly Observed Treatment, Short course (DOTS) " program -- one of the government's key measures in the control of aggressive pulmonary tuberculosis (TB) outbreaks, said Center for Disease Control (CDC) Director-General Kuo Hsuh-sung Saturday.

In order to more efficiently and effectively carry out the DOTS program, the CDC budgeted NT$180 million (US$5.5 million) in 2006 for it, and the money will be used in employing and training DOTS care workers who will attend TB patients with sputum smear positive, and monitor their medicine intake, Kuo said.

Experts in the DOTS program in the United States, which has been implementing the same program for more than 20 years, will be invited to give professional training courses to local DOTS care workers, Kuo noted while explaining the CDC's budget regarding TB control.
Earlier, Legislator Yang Li-huan of the opposition Kuomintang and independent Legislator Chang Li-shan criticized the budget at a news conference as "inflated."
Chang criticized the CDC's proposed employment of 3,456 DOTS caretakers as being too numerous as only 292 people currently employed to take care of more than 4,000 TB patients around the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: THREE CANDIDATES FOR ACADEMIA SINICA PRESIDENCY SELECTED

TEXT.P: The candidates for the president of Academia Sinica has been shortlisted to three, the Academic Advisory Committee of the nation's top research institute said Saturday.

The committee started a vote on four recommended persons -- Academia Sinica Vice President Michael M. C. Lai; Chen Ding-shinn, dean of National Taiwan University's College of Medicine; Wu Mau-kuen, director of Academia Sinica's Institute of Physics; and Wong Chi-huey, director of Academia Sinica's Genomics Research Center -- in the afternoon.
Wong, Chen and Wu were selected and the shortened list will be submitted to President Chen Shui-bian for a final decision.
The tenure of Lee Yuan-tseh, current Academia Sinica president and a Nobel laureate, ended Oct. 17. He has declared that he will not seek an additional term.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA FINDS NO CASE INVOLVING SUSPICIOUS HIGH-TECH EXPORTS TO CHINA

TEXT.P: Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) officials said Saturday they have not found any suspicious case involving exports of high-precision machine tools to China as reported by the Japanese media.

Officials of MOEA's Bureau of Foreign Trade (BOFT) made the remarks after the Japanese newspaper Sankei Shimbun reported recently that some numerical control lathes exported by Taiwan manufacturers had been used by the Chinese military to produce stainless steel components in missile devices.
Sankei Shimbun cited Taiwan's Ministry of National Defense (MND) as the source of its information, which the MND denied.

BOFT officials said they had also asked relevant Japanese authorities for information about the report. None of the Japanese authorities had any information about the reported event, the BOFT officials said.
At present, the officials said, only Japan, Switzerland, Germany and the United States have the ability to produce the high-precision lathes described by the Japanese daily.

After examining export licensing documents from Jan. 1, 2005 through March this year, the officials said no suspicious cases were found in which domestic lathes makers imported high-precision numerical control lathes from Japan or Germany for later export to China after assembling.
The officials said they will keep checking other related export documents and remind domestic manufacturers to abide by the nation's export control regulations.
In Taiwan, high-precision machines that could be shifted to military use are prohibited, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLICY OF NOT ACCREDITING CHINA'S DIPLOMAS TO STAND: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Taiwan's policy of not accrediting college or university diplomas issued in China will be maintained, Vice Education Minister Lu Mu-lin said Saturday.

Lu made the remarks amid reports earlier in the day that China had announced 15 new goodwill measures toward Taiwan -- including the accreditation of diplomas from Taiwan's colleges and universities -- at the end of a two-day economic and trade forum between Taiwan's main opposition Kuomintang and the Communist Party of China in Beijing.
Lu said that China "has recognized Taiwan's diplomas from the start."
Taiwanese students have always been able to pursue studies in China, he said, wondering why China has raised the question at this juncture.
"At the present stage, Taiwan still won't accredit China's diplomas," he said.
Meanwhile, several college students were positive about China's accreditation of Taiwan's diplomas, believing the measure would benefit Taiwan's students.

National Taiwan University President Lee Si-chen said the measure would help Taiwan's students land jobs or pursue studies in China. Lee was not concerned about a "brain drain," saying since Taiwan excels in the high-tech industry, high-tech talent will remain in Taiwan.
National Chiao Tung University President Chang Chun-yen said that China is a vast market, and it would benefit Taiwan's students whether they work, study or obtain certificates in China.
National Cheng Kung University President Wu Jin said the time has come for Taiwan and China to start "head-hunting" for talent, and China's new measure is aimed at recruiting Taiwanese talent.
If Taiwan wants to compete with China, to recruit and retain talent, it must reciprocate and recognize China's diplomas, Wu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT HAILS FORMOSAT-3 LIFT-OFF

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian hailed the successful lift-off of FORMOSAT-3 -- Taiwan's third satellite project -- from a U.S. air base Saturday, saying the new satellite will help upgrade Taiwan's status in world atmospheric research.

In a taped speech transmitted after the lift-off to Vandenberg Air Force Base in California via videoconference, Chen expressed his felicitations and thanked those involved in the project for their hard work and contributions.

Noting that FORMOSAT-3 is aimed at establishing a global real-time atmospheric observation network, Chen said the project will enable Taiwan to exchange climatic information with countries around the world and thus enhance its status in global atmospheric research.

FORMOSAT-3, also known as Constellation Observing System for Meteorology, Ionosphere and Climate (COSMIC), is an important cooperative project between Taiwan and the United States that began in December 1997, Chen said.

The project has helped cultivate Taiwan's basic capacity in satellite development and manufacturing, Chen said, adding that the project has nurtured a new crop of outstanding satellite software talent and satellite components manufacturers.

Formosa-3 is regarded as the world's first climate monitoring and forecasting system using a constellation of six microsatellites. As soon as the constellation is completed, the microsatellites placed in six different orbits ranging between 700km and 800km above the earth's surface will begin to collect atmospheric remote sensing data for operational weather prediction.
After it becomes fully operational, FORMOSAT-3 will be able to provide around 2,500 pieces of meteorological data in every 24-hour period, covering all areas of the globe.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Rumsfeld Gets Robust Defense From President
President Bush strongly endorsed Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld on Friday, in an effort to quell widening criticism from retired generals who have urged Rumsfeld to resign. "Secretary Rumsfeld's energetic and steady leadership is exactly what is needed at this critical period, " the president's statement read. "He has my full support and deepest appreciation."
Wall Street Journal: As Users Go Online, Tax-Software Firms Retool Strategies
This year, more than 130 million Americans are suffering through the annual ordeal of tax filing. Behind the scenes, the companies whose software many people use to compile their returns are facing a challenge of their own. A growing number of Americans have turned to the Internet to file their taxes, using sites that crunch their numbers and zap returns to the Internal Revenue Service at lower cost. That shift has sent Intuit Inc. and H&R Block Inc., the companies that have long dominated the U.S. market for tax-preparation software, scrambling to retool their business models. Intuit estimates that more than 10 million people now file returns online.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WELCOMES CHINA'S NEW TOURISM OPENING MEASURES: MAC

TEXT.P: China is welcome to allow its citizens to make sightseeing trips to Taiwan, the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said Saturday.

The Cabinet-level council made the remarks after Chen Yunlin, director of a China's Taiwan Affairs Office, said earlier in the day that China will unveil Sunday a package of rules governing Chinese people's pleasure trips to Taiwan.
Despite a four-and-half-year delay for China to announce such a set of rules, the council said it still welcomes China's new step to pave the way for its citizens to sightsee in Taiwan.

Following the promulgation of its Taiwan sightseeing rules, the MAC said China has to take two additional steps for its people to realize their wish to make pleasure trips to Taiwan -- to place Taiwan on its list of destinations that Chinese tourists can visit and to hold talks with Taiwan on relevant technical details, including identity authentication and repatriation of overstaying Chinese tourists.

As to China's 15 new measures toward Taiwan announced Saturday at the end of an economic forum co-sponsored by Taiwan's main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and the Communist Party of China (CPC) in Beijing, the MAC said in a news release that it will not make any comment until after it make a comprehensive review of all details.

China's 15 new measures included recognizing Taiwan's tertiary education diplomas, allowing Taiwan citizens to take part in China's customs broker licensing examinations, sending farm produce procurement missions to Taiwan and allowing more Taiwan-grown farm produce to enter the Chinese market.

Noting that the KMT-CPC forum was basically a civilian exchange activity, the MAC said any of the forum's conclusions involving the exercise of public authority would lead nowhere without the authorization or arrangement of Taiwan's government.

Stressing that Taiwan has been open toward exchanges across the Taiwan Strait, the MAC said China should not skip talks with Taiwan's democratically elected government. Otherwise, it said, China is not sincere enough to improve cross-strait relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN LOOKS FORWARD TO SPACE-TECH COOPERATION WITH JAPAN: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang said Saturday Taiwan looks forward to cooperation with Japan in the development of space technology and atmospheric research.
Su's remarks came after the successful lift-off of FORMOSAT-3 -- Taiwan's third satellite project -- from a U.S. air base earlier the same day.

FORMOSAT-3, also known as Constellation Observing System for Meteorology, Ionosphere and Climate (COSMIC) , is a collaborative project between Taiwan and the United States that began in December 1997, Su said.

During a meeting with visiting Tokyo Governor Shintaro Ishihara, Su said he is hopeful that Taiwan and Japan can forge cooperative ties in space technological development and atmospheric research as Japan boasts a highly advanced aerospace industry.

Su said the successful launch of FORMOSAT-3 marks a new milestone in Taiwan's space technology development since 1991. Over the past 15 years, Taiwan has launched three satellites for various scientific and meteorological research purposes.

"All the three satellite projects have helped accumulated and upgraded Taiwan's basic capacity in space research and satellite manufacturing, " Su said, adding that Taiwan should further enhance its development capabilities in the field through international cooperation.

Noting that FORMOSAT-3 is aimed at establishing a global real-time atmospheric observation network, Su said the project will enable Taiwan to exchange climatic information with countries around the world and thus enhance its status in global atmospheric research.
In addition to helping cultivating a new crop of satellite software talent, Su said the FORNOSAT-3 project has also galvanized Taiwan companies to take part in space technological development.

"The project has inspired at least five Taiwan companies to tap into the space industry and produce 10 major satellite components, " Su said, adding that the project has opened up infinite opportunities for local industries to explore in spacecraft parts and components manufacturing.

Formosa-3 is regarded as the world's first climate monitoring and forecasting system using a constellation of six microsatellites. As soon as the constellation is completed, the microsatellites placed in six different orbits ranging between 700km and 800km above the earth's surface will begin to collect atmospheric remote sensing data for operational weather prediction.
After it becomes fully operational, FORMOSAT-3 will be able to provide around 2,500 pieces of meteorological data in every 24-hour period, covering all areas of the globe.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2ND ROUND OF CRISIS RESPONSE DRILL KICKS OFF

TEXT.P: A 24-hour fully integrated emergency response drill was launched Saturday noon to hone the nation's capabilities to respond in several crisis scenarios, national security officials said.
The simulated crisis response exercise was a regular event with the participation of senior administration officials and military and security personnel, the officials said.
President Chen Shui-bian presided over the drill, which was organized by the National Security Council under the codename "Operation Yushan," the officials said.
A preliminary two-hour drill was held Wednesday evening as part of the preparations for Saturday's full-fledged crisis response exercise, which will come to an end at Sunday noon.

The drill was designed to test military, administration and security divisions' response capabilities in the event of the Chinese president being assassinated during an overseas visit and Taiwan being fingered as the culprit, and in the event of China launching a surprise missile attack on Taiwan's political and economic "nerve centers" in which gas attacks at a railway station and blasts at mass rapid transit (MRT) stations were reported.

In the drill, relevant personnel, including premier, vice premier, the Executive Yuan secretary-general as well as Cabinet ministers, were required to reach the Yuanshan command center in 40 minutes after receiving the notice.

President Chen first went to the maximum-guarded Hengshan command center where he was briefed by Ministry of National Defense officials on the "war situation." Afterwards, Chen traveled to the Yuanshan command center to hold a national security meeting on the nation's general political situation.

In the simulated exercise, the president was required to decide in 150 minutes whether to declare war against China -- the first 90 minutes were used for a national security meeting and the remaining 60 minutes for pre-war preparations.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA URGED TO RESOLVE FARM PRODUCE COUNTERFEITING ISSUE

TEXT.P: The Council of Agriculture (COA) urged China Saturday to resolve issues regarding the counterfeiting of Taiwan's farm produce in China as well as theft and infringement of Taiwan's agricultural know-how.
The Cabinet-level council made the call after China announced 15 new measures toward Taiwan earlier the same day, seven of which were related with Taiwan's agricultural and fishery industries.

Noting that Chinese people's intellectural property rights infringements and rampant trademark and farm produce counterfeiting have been the most serious detriments to Taiwan farmers' interests and rights, the council said if China fails to resolve these issues, none of its so-called "goodwill" measures would be really meaningful or beneficial.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR APRIL 16 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Sunday, April 16:

09:30, Former National Security Council Secretary-General Ting Yu-chou will hold a news conference at National Taiwan University Hospital's conference room to introduce his new book on Taiwan's strategic security assessment.
10:00, The Taiwan Professors Association will hold a news conference on the just-concluded KMT-CPC economic forum.
15:00, DPP Chairman Yu Shyi-kun will attend a grassroots party affairs meeting in Tainan County.

From our great trials flow patience and experience that, in turn, elevate the hope of salvation.
The Philippine Daily Inquirer: Arroyo commutes all death sentences
WITH the resurrection of Christ as a backdrop, President Macapagal-Arroyo yesterday announced that all death row convicts would be spared and the maximum penalty commuted to life imprisonment.
The Philippine Star: Opposition: Life after death sentence
In the spirit of Easter, President Arroyo commuted yesterday the sentences of all death row convicts to life imprisonment.
The Manila Times: President orders halt to executions
President Arroyo announced on Saturday that the government would stop executing prisoners. "Regarding those who face the death penalty, I announce that we are changing that punishment and will make [the maximum penalty] life imprisonment," Mrs. Arroyo said in a statement as part of her Easter message.

Los Angeles Times: 4 TV Networks Challenge FCC on Indecency.
In a move that seems certain to force a showdown over what constitutes indecency on the airwaves, four TV broadcast networks and their affiliates announced Friday that they had united to challenge a Federal Communications Commission ruling that deemed language used in several of their shows indecent.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, April 16, or the 19th day of the third month of the Year of the Dog according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1828: Francisco Jose de Goya, Spanish artist whose paintings and etchings reflected the political and social turmoil of his time, dies at the age of 82.
1850: Madame Marie Tussaud, Swiss founder of the famous waxworks museum in London, dies at the age of 89.
1889: Sir Charles Spencer Chaplin, known as "Charlie," film actor and comedian much loved for his portrayal of a tramp in baggy pants and bowler hat, is born in Britain. His productions include "The Kid," "The Gold Rush," and "The Great Dictator."
1912: American pilot Harriet Quimby becomes the first woman to fly the English Channel.
1917: Vladimir Ilyich Lenin returns to Russia after three years of exile in Zurich.
1923: Japanese Crown Prince Hirohito arrives in Keelung for an inspection tour of Taiwan, which is under Japanese rule.
1925: In honor of Dr. Sun Yat-sen, who died in Peking on March 12, 1925 at the age of 59, the Kwangtung Provincial Government changes the name of Hsiangshan County, the place of birth of Dr. Sun, to Chungshan County.
1941: German troops enter Sarajevo, Yugoslavia, and the main synagogue is destroyed.
1948: The Organization for European Economic Co-operation (OEEC) is established in Paris by Western European nations in accordance with the Marshall Plan.
1960: The Taiwan Provincial Government begins the implementation of labor insurance regulations by establishing the Labor Insurance Bureau.
1972: Yasunari Kawabata, Japanese writer who won the 1968 Nobel Prize for literature, commits suicide at the age of 73. His novels, including "Thousand Cranes," often concern alienated, lonely individuals in search of beauty and purity.
1972: The Apollo 16 mission is launched from Cape Kennedy, Florida, to make the fifth manned moon landing.
1975: The communist Khmer Rouge seize Phnom Penh, capital of Cambodia.
1978: A tornado strikes the eastern state of Orissa in India, killing some 180 people.
1981: The Kaohsiung C.K.S. Cultural Center is inaugurated.
1982: Queen Elizabeth proclaims Canada's new constitution, severing the colonial links with Britain.
1985: The first test tube baby in the Republic of China is born at the Veterans General Hospital in Taipei.
1990: In London, Freed African National Congress leader Nelson Mandela publicly thanks the world for its support during his 26-year imprisonment by the South African government.
1998: Khmer Rouge leader Pol Pot is reported dead of a heart attack in his Cambodian jungle stronghold at the age of 73. During his four-year reign of terror some two million Cambodians died.
1999: Former opposition Democratic Progressive Party Chairman Hsu Hsin-liang is blasted by other DPP members for his recent remarks on plebiscites and Taiwan independence.
1999: A field hospital donated by Taiwan opens at the Stenkovee refugee camp outside Skopje, Macedonia.
2000: Republic of China President-elect Chen Shui-bian says that "maintaining peace and stability and safeguarding the interests of Taiwan are the highest goals and moral obligations" for him as president.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Men in old times educated themselves for their own sakes. Men now educate themselves to impress others."
