DOC.HEADLINE: MAGNITUDE 6.2 QUAKE FELT AROUND EASTERN, CENTRAL, SOUTHERN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: A magnitude 6.2 earthquake struck early Sunday morning in Taitung County, eastern Taiwan, waking people up as far away as central and southern Taiwan, the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) reported.

According to the CWB Seismology Center, the quake rattled eastern Taiwan for about 30 seconds at 6: 40 a.m., with the epicenter of the jolt located 19.9 km northeast of Taitung at a depth of 11.7 km beneath the surface of the sea, CWB seismologists said.

Because the quake occurred in a relatively shallow area, it was felt in almost every area in eastern, central and southern parts of the island. The shock waves penetrated beneath the Central Mountain Range to reach even Penghu Island offshore the southern county of Kaohsiung.
As of 9 a.m. Sunday, no damage or injuries had been reported, although officials are still checking to see if the tremor caused any landslides or falling rocks.
The quake is the second with a magnitude greater than 6.0 to rattle the island in less than half a month.

According to Kuo Kai-wen, director of the CWB Seismology Center, as the geological structure underneath and offshore Taiwan's eastern coast is uniquely complex, earthquakes in those areas could be the results of both squeezing and rupturing actions when the Pacific Plate and the Eurasian Plate collide, and when another deep-sea fault is broken.

The quake had an intensity of 5.0 in Taitung County's Chengkung area and Hualien County's Fuli area, 4.0 in Taitung City, 3.0 in Taichung, Nantou and Yunlin counties in central Taiwan as well as in Chiayi, Tainan, Kaohsiung and Pingtung counties in southern Taiwan, 2.0 in Yilan County in eastern Taiwan, Miaoli County in north-central Taiwan and Tainan City in southern Taiwan, and 1.0 on Penghu Island located in the Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHAIRMAN URGES DPP GOV'T TO 'TAKE IT EASY' ON KMT-CPC ENGAGEMENT

TEXT.P: Main opposition Kuomintang Chairman Ma Ying-jeou called for the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) government Sunday to "take it easy" upon the conclusion of the economic forum between the KMT and the Communist Party of China (CPC).
At the conclusion of the KMT-CPC forum held in Beijing Saturday, Beijing offered 15 incentive measures benefiting Taiwan's trade and business sectors and private exchanges across the strait.

Noting that these 15 incentive measures are poised to benefit Taiwan and its people, Ma called for the DPP administration to face them realistically with composure. Ma said The last thing that the DPP administration should do is to lash out at the KMT, a move, he said, which would only invite resentment from the people of Taiwan.

Ma made the remarks in the southern city of Chiayi, where he attended a tea party marking the opening of a voters service office of Chiang Yi-hsiung who won the legislative by-election in Chiayi in March.

DOC.HEADLINE: MORE OPENESS AND ENGAGEMENT ACROSS STRAIT THE RIGHT DIRECTION: LIEN
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, April 16 (CNA) (By CNA reporters and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Despite the unprecedentedly amicable cross-Taiwan Strait situation, there still exists a "push and pull" struggle between the forces of peace and the forces of conflict, Taiwan's main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) honorary Chairman Lien Chan said Sunday in Beijing.

During his meeting with Chinese President Hu Jintao at the Great Hall of the People in Beijing, Lien said that there have been ups and downs in the struggle between the forces for more openness and engagement and the forces for constriction of engagement. Lien asserted that expanding open and peaceful engagements should be the direction of concerted efforts of both sides of the strait.

Lien expressed welcome to the 15 incentive measures benefiting private exchanges across the strait that Beijing spelled out Saturday upon the conclusion of an economic forum between the KMT and the Communist Party of China (CPC), saying that these measures will have "far-reaching influence" on the development of cross-strait relations and that they reflect the expectations of "mainstream opinion" on both sides of the strait.

The former KMT chairman said he hopes that with the conclusion of the historic KMT-CPC economic forum, both sides will make unrelenting efforts to enable the two sides to face the even harder challenges that lie ahead.
For his part, Hu claimed that peaceful development should be made the common goal of the people across the strait and the main subject of all cross-strait exchanges.

Hu even stressed that the "92 consensus" reached during official cross-strait talks in Hong Kong in 1992 should be an important bedrock on which the two sides strive for peaceful development. Hu did not elaborate on the details of the "92 consensus." In Taiwan, President Chen Shui-bian has said recently that the "92 consensus" is only a fabricated term and does not exist.

Lien and the KMT delegation of 100-odd party officials, KMT legislators and heavyweights from Taiwan's business and industrial sectors are scheduled to proceed to Fujian Province Monday for a visit before returning to Taiwan.
This is Lien's second visit to Beijing since the spring of 2005.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEADER'S INTEGRITY AFFECTS TAIWAN'S SECURITY STRATEGY: NEW BOOK

TEXT.P: A new book released Sunday by the Cross-Strait Interflow Prospect Foundation -- a subsidiary of the National Security Bureau under the National Security Council -- says that the integrity of the head of state is the foremost factor affecting Taiwan's national security strategy.

The book, "2005-2006: An Assessment of Taiwan's Security Strategy, " compiled by former National Security Council Secretary-General Ting Yu-chou, includes reports by scholars in the areas of politics, economy, psychology and military affairs. It warns that the threats Taiwan is facing internally and externally are graver than in the past.

The book lists six factors as affecting Taiwan's national security strategy most and places the integrity of the head of state at the top of the list. The other five factors are the people's identification with and support for the nation, Taiwan's overall economic strength and development, Taiwan's defense capability, the situation in the Taiwan Strait in terms of whether there is peace and stability, and the United States' policy and attitudes toward the Taiwan issue.

In an interview upon the release of the book, Ting implied that the integrity problem refers to President Chen Shui-bian's recent scrapping of the National Unification Council and its guidelines, which he pledged not to abolish during his two inaugural speeches in 2000 and 2004.

According to the book, Taiwan's greatest national security threat comes from the rise of China. While the economic threat faced by Taiwan is greater than the military threat, the internal threat confronting Taiwan is more serious than the threat from outside.

Reports in the book say that the source of Taiwan's internal disputes lies in the divergence of views on such issues as national identity, Taiwan independence versus unification with China, and ethnic discord.

The reports suggest that the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and the opposition parties should address their differences by going back to their "greatest common factor" -- acknowledging the Republic of China as Taiwan's official title as a nation.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA'S '92 CONSENSUS' HAS NO ROOM FOR DIFFERENT INTERPRETATIONS: MAC

TEXT.P: China continues to make use of the so-called "1992 consensus" to insist on its "one China" principle, under which there is no room for "different interpretations" of the meaning of "one China, " Taiwan's Mainland Affairs Council said Sunday.

In response to Chinese President Hu Jintao's "four suggestions" for improving cross-Taiwan Strait relations, the MAC issued a press release accusing China of trying to dupe the people in Taiwan as well as the international community with its "one China" principle clothed in the "1992 consensus."

In his meeting with Taiwan's main opposition Kuomintang Honorary Chairman Lien Chan at the Great Hall of People in Beijing Sunday, Hu stressed that only by insisting on the 1992 consensus can cross-strait peace and development be realized. He also blamed "some people denying the existence of the 1992 consensus" for causing ripples in cross-strait relations.

Besides criticizing Hu for sticking to an outdated and obstinate "one China" principle that allows for no room at all for different interpretations, the MAC also blamed Lien for failing to ask Hu to clearly state whether their two parties (the KMT and the Communist Party of China) look at the 1992 consensus as the same thing.

What the MAC cares about is whether in Beijing's terminology, the 1992 consensus means Beijing's recognition of the Republic of China or at least Beijing's not denying the existence of the Republic of China. The MAC said it is regrettable that Lien failed to ask Hu to make a clear statement about this.
The MAC went on to blast China for unilaterally breaking up the institutional mechanism of cross-strait negotiations in 1995 before using its "one China" principle to blackmail Taiwan politically.

For Beijing, "one China" means the People's Republic of China. For the KMT, "one China" means the Republic of China. As a result, the KMT says, the "one China" principle in their 1992 consensus means "one China, different interpretations." But for the DPP, the 1992 consensus simply does not exist.
President Chen Shui-bian recently challenged Lien to ask Hu to state that China agrees with the KMT version of the 1992 consensus -- "one China, different interpretations."

The MAC said that since 2000, when the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) ousted the KMT at the polls to become the Republic of China's ruling party, mainland China has hidden its "sinister plots" in the KMT-created term "1992 consensus."

It charged that the Chinese authorities have intentionally ignored the fact that the ROC exists and have restricted the options for the people of Taiwan to decide on their future. "This is the fundamental reason for the impasse in cross-strait interactions, " it said.

While China has claimed that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait should work for peace and development, it has refused to enter into dialogue or negotiations with Taiwan, the MAC said. Instead, it added, China has beefed up its military deployment for invading Taiwan, threatening the safety of the people of Taiwan and their property, as well as peace and stability in the Taiwan Strait.

"This indicates that China has not the slightest sincerity to improve cross-strait ties; it has merely been adopting a two-pronged tactic of saying one thing and doing another toward Taiwan, " the MAC said.
It said the government of Taiwan has over the past years made a lot of efforts for improving cross-strait ties, without receiving any good-will response from China.
It urged China to give up its political prerequisites for talking with Taiwan and immediately resume talks with Taiwan on an equal footing in order to solve issues affecting both sides.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA'S ECONOMIC FAVORS TO TAIWAN SEEN AS UNITED FRONT GIMMICKS

TEXT.P: The 15 new measures toward Taiwan that China announced Saturday are just small favors aimed at creating conflicts within Taiwan, former Vice Premier Wu Rong-i Sunday.

Wu said he suspects that the new measures announced at the conclusion of the Kuomintang-Communist Party of China forum in Beijing are part of China's united front strategy toward Taiwan and "nothing but political maneuvering."

If China really wants to make a goodwill gesture to Taiwan, he said, it should first remove its missiles aimed at Taiwan, scrap its Anti-Secession Law, let Taiwan take part in the World Health Organization (WHO) and let Taiwan freely sign free trade agreements with other member countries of the WHO.

Commenting on the KMT-CPC trade and economy forum, Wu said Taiwan, a country with a free economy, is obliged to restrict trade activities with China because Beijing hasn't given up its intention to seize Taiwan by force as stated in its Anti-Secession Law, and because it is trying to suffocate Taiwan in the international community.

He said that Taiwan has to be careful with the 15 new measures. He cited the gravel industry as an example, noting that China's gravel exports to Taiwan were halted May 1 this year under a simple order from Chinese authorities.

Out of self-interest, some gravel business operators in Taiwan have gone as far as acknowledging that Taiwan is part of China, Wu said, adding that "this is where the gravest danger lies." He stressed that Taiwan must not surrender to China for the sake of some minor interests.

A 170-member delegation led by KMT honorary Chairman Lien Chan attended the KMT-CPC forum in Beijing, including many influential Taiwanese industry leaders whose enterprises represent more than 40 percent of Taiwan's total industrial export.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWANESE DOCTORS WELCOME CHINA'S OPENING OF HEALTHCARE MARKET

TEXT.P: Medical doctors in Taiwan welcomed on Sunday new measures announced by Beijing that will allow Taiwan investors to set up joint venture hospitals in mainland China and permit Taiwanese medical doctors to get a license and practice on the mainland.

Kao Ming-chien, president of the Taiwan Medical Alliance Association, said that although Taiwan's medical sector is elated by the news, the measures are really nothing new because Chinese authorities planned to allow Taiwan doctors to set up a healthcare complex in Xiamen, Fujian Province, three years ago.

Kao, a noted brain surgeon and former legislator, added that the plan did not materialize due to the severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) outbreak in April and May 2003 and the opposition from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and its "pan-green" camp partner -- the Taiwan Solidarity Union.

He said that in terms of opportunities in China's healthcare market, Taiwan is no longer in a favored position, as compared to three years ago, because the medical sectors of the United States, Japan and Germany have already made inroads in such major Chinese cities as Beijing, Shanghai and Shenzen.
Kao acknowledged that Taiwan still has opportunities in second-tier Chinese cities that host a considerable number of Taiwan businesspeople and members of their families.

Beijing announced last Saturday that Taiwan investors will be allowed to hold up to a 70-percent stake in joint venture hospitals they set up with mainland partners, and that medical doctors from Taiwan will be allowed to get a license and practice in the mainland after they pass official examinations.

Currently there are no legally established Taiwanese hospitals in China to provide healthcare to hundreds of thousands of Taiwanese living there, many of whom choose to go back to Taiwan for treatment when they get sick because the healthcare standards in China cannot compare to those in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT LEADERS' CRISIS MANAGEMENT ABILITY PROVEN IN WARGAME

TEXT.P: Leaders of various government departments have shown that their crisis management abilities are up to the level required by the government, a National Security Council (NSC) spokesman said Sunday.

President Chen Shui-bian took part in a 20-hour crisis simulation drill, presiding over seven contingency conferences attended by department heads on different crisis scenarios. The drill ended Sunday.
The spokesman said the wargame exercise has helped to strengthen the staff's analyzing ability in times of crisis and to improve the decision-making ability of department heads.

Each scenario was a test of physical endurance as well as decision-making capability for the representatives of government agencies as they had to make decisions under duress and within a short period of time, according to the spokesman.

DOC.HEADLINE: '92 CONSENSUS' NOT CLARIFIED DURING LIEN-HU MEETING: DPP

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) urged the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Sunday to stop creating chaos with the so-called "1992 consensus, " as Chinese President Hu Jintao failed to acknowledge "one China, respective interpretations" as its essence in his meeting with KMT honorary Chairman Lien Chan earlier the same day in Beijing.

Lai I-chung, head of the DPP's China affairs department, called on the KMT to stop misleading the Taiwan people as Hu, who also serves as general secretary of the Communist Party of China (CPC) , failed to make it clear in public during the Lien-Hu meeting at the Great Hall of the People that the "1992 consensus" refers to an agreement on "respective interpretations of 'one China'" as the KMT has been claiming.

Despite the fact that the KMT and the CPC came up with 15 beneficial measures aimed at "luring" the Taiwan people following a historic two-day KMT-CPC economic forum that wrapped up Saturday, Lai said that Hu did not respond to Lien's call for a cross-strati common market.
Lai claimed that Lien was fooled again by the CPC and that the results of the KMT-CPC forum have in turn become a bargaining chip for Beijing in its dealings with the United States.

As Hu did not mention in public that he accepts the "1992 consensus, respective interpretations of 'one China'" statement, it is obvious that there is no consensus in this regard between the KMT and the CPC, Lai said, accusing Lien of not having asked Hu to do so and calling it a flop of Lien in dancing to Beijing's tune.

Pointing out that the root of cross-Taiwan Strait squabbles lies in China's suppression of Taiwan, Lai blasted Lien for singing a duet with Beijing instead of speaking up for Taiwan during their meeting.

Chen Chin-jun, a DPP legislative caucus whip, said that although the Lien-Hu meeting seems to have produced many incentives, they are actually cover-ups of Beijing's malicious intentions against Taiwan. He claimed that "Taiwan's 23 million people will never accept them."

According to Chen, neither Taiwan nor China can provide documents to prove the existence of the disputed "1992 consensus" -- a result which former KMT government officials said they obtained during a 1992 meeting with Chinese officials in Hong Kong that both sides agreed to give their own definitions of the "one China" principle in terms of Taiwan's relations with the Chinese mainland.

The DPP remains firm on safeguarding Taiwan's national sovereignty and Beijing should not set any preconditions on reopening negotiations with Taiwan, Chen said. As long as Taiwan's national dignity and sovereignty and its democratic system are fully protected, the DPP government is willing to hold talks with Beijing on any topic, he said.
However, he stressed that the Lien-Hu meeting, a disguise of China's united front tactics, is unacceptable to the DPP government.

Chen maintained that Beijing should approach the ruling DPP government, rather than an opposition party, for talks on cross-strait relations, pointing out that Beijing's talks with the KMT is apparently a plot to cripple Taiwan's government.

Hu said during Sunday's Lien-Hu meeting, the second of its kind since last year, that peaceful development is the common desire of the people on both sides of the strait and insisted that the "1992 consensus" is the cornerstone on which Taiwan and China can achieve the goal through reciprocal and equal negotiations.
Hu also said that Beijing will "do its best" to live up to its promises made to the Taiwan people despite "changing situations across the strait and the boycott of a few people."

Lien paid a landmark visit to China in late April last year when he was still KMT chairman, breaking a decades-old stalemate between the KMT and CPC after Taiwan and China split in 1949 amid a civil war.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP URGES KMT TO DISCUSS WAYS TO UPGRADE TAIWAN'S INDUSTRIES

TEXT.P: Leaders of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) should sit down and discuss how to upgrade Taiwan's industries, a DPP legislative caucus whip urged Sunday.

DPP Legislator Chen Chin-jun told a news conference that the KMT should not be complacent about the favors granted by Beijing after KMT honorary Chairman Lien Chan's meeting on Sunday with Chinese President Hu Jintao, who also serves as the general secretary of the Communist Party of China (CPC).

"The Kuomintang cannot save Taiwan by only relying on China," Chen said, adding that there are many issues concerning Taiwan's economic development strategies that need to be sorted out between the DPP and the opposition parties.
Yet instead of discussing these issues with the ruling party behind closed doors, KMT leaders "are happy to become tools of China's united front tactics," he said.

Chen stressed that if the KMT does not stand firm on the issue of Taiwan's sovereignty and allows China to downgrade Taiwan to the level of a local government, then whatever was achieved by the KMT delegation during its two-day trade and economic forum with the CPC in Beijing would be of little significance.
He added that Taiwan and China should discuss mutual problems with no preconditions, with both sides treating each other as equals.
"The people of Taiwan will not accept the 'one-China' principle as a premise for cross-Taiwan Strait dialogue," Chen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP URGES CHINA TO CO-EXIST WITH TAIWAN'S DEMOCRACY

TEXT.P: Taiwan's ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) urged Chinese President Hu Jintao Sunday to talk with Taiwan's government and ruling party on ways of "co-existing with Taiwan's democracy."

On Hu's proposal to take "peace and development" as the foundation of cross-strait exchanges and the common goal for people on both sides, Yu Shy-kun, DPP chairman, said peace and development will not be possible if they are not built on the basis of freedom and democracy.
Hu also suggested that the 1992 consensus is a "critical basis for realizing peace and development across the strait."
Yu said Hu should recognize the fact that Taiwan exists and try to co-exist with Taiwan's democracy by, for instance, acknowledging the right of the Taiwan people to decide on their own future.

Yu also urged Hu to make "concrete commitments" about promoting China's democracy and human rights, adding that the DPP will closely monitor such "key indicators" as whether Hu will rehabilitate victims in the June 4, 1989 Tiananmen Massacre and whether he will continue to suppress China's freedom of speech.

Yu said he is asking China to speed up democratic reforms because only democracy can serve as a basis for cross-strait exchanges, and only democracy will minimize the hidden risks involved in China's economic development.

As Hu did not specify Beijing's position with regard to the KMT's claim of "one China, different interpretations," Yu called on the KMT not to mention it again since it was not even a consensus between itself and the Communist Party of China (CPC).
However, he noted that the DPP government would, in a spirit of pragmatism, like to resume talks with Beijing based on the "results achieved in the 1992 talks in Hong Kong."

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT'S CHINA POLICY PLATFORM NON-NEGOTIABLE: LIEN CHAN

TEXT.P: The Kuomintang's (KMT's) "one China, different interpretations" platform is clear and definite, leaving no room for further bargaining, the party's honorary chairman said Sunday.

Lien Chan made the remarks in answer to reporters' questions after he met with Chinese President Hu Jintao, a meeting in which some people in Taiwan expected he would raise the issue of "one China, different interpretations" to his host.

The issue is at the center of a controversy in Taiwan about the "1992 consensus" reached between Taipei and Beijing in Hong Kong. The KMT, which was in power at the time, said the two sides agreed on the principle of "one China, " with each side free to interpret what it means. The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) government has said that it will not accept the consensus until Beijing publicly endorses it.

Lien recalled that before he made his historic visit to China last year as the leader of Taiwan's largest opposition party, he informed President Chen Shui-bian that he would be taking the KMT's cross-strait policy proposals to China, proposals that were "very clear" and that "would not change a bit -- with nothing being added and nothing being taken away."
"I specifically asked him (Chen), do you get me?" Lien added.

The problem lies with Chen and his DPP, he said, adding that "this is their problem, which they themselves should solve. They should face the question posed by the media, namely: Do you accept 'one China, different interpretations?'"
On April 3, during a meeting with KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou, Chen challenged Lien to urge China's Hu to publicly proclaim Beijing accepts the KMT's version of "one China" -- the Republic of China.

Hu did mention the 1992 consensus while meeting with Lien Sunday, but only expounding on the two sides of the Taiwan Strait belonging to "one China" without mentioning whether he agreed with the KMT's interpretation of "one China" as the ROC.

To a reporter who said Hu did not mention "one China, different interpretations, " Lien jokingly began his response by saying: "I believe you are not asking me this question on behalf of Chen Shui-bian."

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP TO PUSH PASSAGE OF AMENDMENTS TO FACILITATE AT CHINA LINKS

TEXT.P: The People First Party (PFP) will push for passage of various law amendments at the Legislative Yuan in order to have direct transport links between Taiwan and China in place by the end of this year, PFP lawmaker Daniel Y. C. Huang said Sunday.
Huang made the remarks during the launch of a new book sponsored by the Cross-Strait Interflow Prospect Foundation.

According to Huang, the PFP is poised to do so by putting the revisions to the Statute Governing the Relations Between the People of the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area to a vote at the Legislative Yuan after a four-month negotiation period comes to an end late this month, despite the fact that a just-concluded economic forum between the Kuomintang (KMT) the Communist Party of China (CPC) failed to produce a timetable for the matter.

Huang called on the Democratic Progressive Party government to face up to the issue "the sooner the better, " as setting up direct air and shipping links will help Taiwan businesses significantly reduce their production costs.

The PFP lawmaker, however, called it a surprise development that the two-day KMT-CPC forum which ended Saturday in Beijing did not work out a fixed time frame on opening direct transport links across the Taiwan Strait, apart from 15 economic cooperation measures covering a wide range of issues from tourism, agriculture and health care.
KMT Honorary Chairman Lien Chan met Chinese President and CPC General Secretary Hu Jintao Sunday morning, with the two agreeing to further advance cross-strait peace and prosperity.

Meanwhile, the KMT-CPC economic forum and the Lien-Hu meeting drew flak from the ruling DPP, which criticized the KMT, Taiwan's largest opposition party, for "going a long way" to engage Beijing officials instead of holding talks with the government.
Speaking at Legislative Yuan news conference, DPP legislative caucus whip Chen Chin-jun condemned the KMT for being willing to act as a united front tool for the CPC.

Nevertheless, various DPP lawmakers reportedly have suggested that the government accept some "acceptable agreements" reached at the KMT-CPC forum as long as they do not infringe upon Taiwan's national sovereignty.

DPP whip Chen said he was disgruntled upon hearing this, stressing that Taiwan's status as an independent and sovereign nation must not be eroded no matter what. "The Taiwan people will never take any results yielded in talks held under the 'one China' precondition," he said.

Lien, leading a high profile delegation of more than 170 KMT lawmakers, experts and business leaders, arrived in Beijing Friday to attend the historic forum with CPC officials -- the first of its kind after Taiwan and China split in 1949.
Lien, in his capacity as KMT chairman, met Hu in Beijing for the first time during a landmark visit to China in late April last year, paving the way for their second meeting and the economic forum.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER NSC HEAD URGES ESTABLISHMENT OF HOMELAND SECURITY DEPARTMENT

TEXT.P: A former national security chief urged the Executive Yuan Sunday to establish a neutral and professional "homeland security department."

Former National Security Council (NSC) Secretary-General Ting Yu-chou said the "homeland security department" should integrate various areas of responsibility, including shipping security, coastal defense, airport and harbor security, natural disaster response and high-technology security, to name a few.

Ting said that most people do not have a clear concept of national security and national interests and that they do not even have a shared view on these issues. Therefore, he said, the government should put forth a clear vision on national goals and core interests in order to form a consensus.
Ting said he doubts whether Taiwan's current national security mechanism, operating around the National Security Council, could efficiently respond to a major threat to the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA AIMS TO ANNEX TAIWAN ECONOMICALLY VIA 'HAIXI PLAN': ADVISER

TEXT.P: Beijing's plan to develop China's Fujian Province into a "peaceful cooperation experimental district on the west side of the Taiwan Strait" -- known by its shortened name as the "Haixi district development plan " -- is aimed at annexing Taiwan economically, a Presidential Office adviser said Sunday.

Ruan Ming, a national policy adviser to President Chen Shui-bian, warned at a press conference on the implications of the just-concluded economic forum between the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and the Communist Party of China (CPC) held in Beijing that the Beijing leadership put forth a "tremendously dangerous" slogan at the forum, namely "district to district, enterprise to enterprise and private sector to private sector" in terms of cross-strait efforts to boost trade and business exchanges across the strait.

This slogan fully underscores the strategic goal of Beijing's "Haixi district development plan, " which was put forward by Chinese Premier Wen Jiabao during the National People's Congress in early March aimed at persuading more Taiwan businesses and industries to relocate their operations to Fujian and further "dwarfing Taiwan into a local district of China," Ruan said.

Ruan said that Beijing's according high-profile hospitality to KMT honorary Chairman Lien Chan and the offering of 15 incentive measures to Taiwan during the forum were mainly aimed at helping alleviate pressure that the United States is likely to exert on Beijing when U.S. President George W. Bush meets with President Hu Jintao in Washington, D.C. this week regarding economic, human rights and religious freedom issues.
The adviser made the analysis during the press conference sponsored by the Taiwan Association of University Professors.

Ruan invited his audience to view the politics and economies of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait separately, saying that politically, Taiwan is a free country with its own full sovereignty, while China is a totalitarian regime ruled by the Chinese communists.

Economically, he said, Taiwan can talk with the Chinese government on economic issues if the principles of equality and reciprocity exist. If this is the case, he said, Taiwan doesn't need to take a hostile stance toward China, although Taiwan should by no means condone China's plot to strip Taiwan of its sovereignty.

On Beijing's offering Taiwan the 15 incentive measures, Ruan said that despite China's rapid economic and industrial growth, the country is facing major problems in its agricultural sector, health system and educational reforms. China's opening of its doors to Taiwan medical professionals and larger-scale agricultural imports are part of its strategic scheming, he claimed.

He reminded Taiwan that before engaging in cooperation in the establishment of an agricultural cooperation experimental district in China, which would unavoidably involve Taiwan's agricultural high-tech know-how, Taiwan should demand that China follow international norms and regulations in terms of patent rights and intellectual property rights protection.

Ruan said Taiwan should work to prevent its hard-earned agricultural technology advances from being used by China for nothing. If it doesn't stop this from happening, he said, the Taiwan agricultural sector's international competitiveness will be compromised in the long run.

DOC.HEADLINE: LIEN CHAN TOUTS ACHIEVEMENTS OF KMT-CPC FORUM

TEXT.P: Main oppostion Kuomintang (KMT) honorary Chairman Lien Chan touted the just-concluded forum between his party and the Communist Party of China (CPC), saying the achievements were "better than expected."

Speaking at a news conference after his meeting with Chinese President Hu Jintao, who doubles as the CPC general secretary, Lien said the 15 measures announced by Beijing at the conclusion of the forum with the purpose of opening its market further to Taiwan cover a range of fields much wider than was expected and will have far-reaching effects.

Lien brushed aside his critics' claims in Taipei that he failed to prod Beijing to acknowledge the KMT's interpretation of "one China, different interpretations" as the essence of the "1992 consensus," saying it wasn't worth the fuss to respond.

However, Lien, who served as the KMT chief from 2000 to 2005, said his party's stance on the relationship between Taiwan and China is very clear and that it is more than his or KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou's personal view.

On the "five visions" that he worked out with Hu during their first meeting in Beijing in April, 2005, Lien said that they have already been translated into the KMT's political platform and that they were reaffirmed by Ma during his recent U.S. visit.

After being reminded by a journalist of his earlier claims that the difference between Taiwan and China lies in their different political systems, Lien said that it is obvious that Taiwan and China have different systems and that this doesn't need to be emphasized. However, he added that China has changed a lot in this regard and that the changes would be accelerated further in the future.
Lien led a 170-member delegation to the KMT-CPC forum which was held April 14-15 in Beijing.

DOC.HEADLINE: VIETNAMESE MAN SLIPS BY POLICE AT CKS AIRPORT

TEXT.P: A 32-year old Vietnamese man who flew in from Hanoi, Vietnam Saturday night slipped by airport police at the entry inspection counter at Chiang Kai-shek (CKS) International Airport.

Police at the airport said the man who arrived in Taiwan with a Vietnamese woman aboard Vietnam Airlines flight VN924 was stopped for questioning by police who suspected him of entering Taiwan for purposes inconsistent with the purpose stated on his travel documents.
The man, who spoke fluent Chinese, then proceeded to run away from the inspection counter and disappeared into the crowd while officers were busy studying his travel documents.
The woman accompanying him was detained by police and will be repatriated.

Police on Sunday made public the video footage of the man and appealed for help in locating him. They also issued a warning that sneaking into Taiwan illegally is punishable by up to three years' imprisonment.

The Washington Post: U.S. Plan For Flu Pandemic Revealed; Multi-Agency Proposal Awaits Bush's Approval.
President Bush is expected to approve soon a national pandemic influenza response plan that identifies more than 300 specific tasks for federal agencies, including determining which frontline workers should be the first vaccinated and expanding Internet capacity to handle what would probably be a flood of people working from their home computers. (By Jorge Liu)

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Pentagon Memo Aims to Counter Rumsfeld Critics
The U.S. Defense Department has issued a memorandum to a group of former military commanders and civilian analysts that offers a direct challenge to the criticisms made by retired generals about Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld. The memorandum begins by stating, " U.S. senior military leaders are involved to an to an unprecedented degree in every decision- making process in the Department of Defense." It says Mr. Rumsfeld has had 139 meetings with the Joint Chiefs of Staff since the start of 2005 and 208 meetings with the senior field commanders. Seeking to put the criticism of the relatively small number of retired generals into context, the e-mail message also notes that there are more than 8,000 active-duty and retired general officers alive today.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN IS A FROG IN CHINA'S GRADUALLY WARMING POT: SCHOLAR

TEXT.P: Taiwan is like a frog enjoying a good bath in a warm-water tub prepared by China, a scholar commented Sunday after Beijing released another series of economic favors to Taiwan at the end of a joint trade and economic forum of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the Communist Party of China in Beijing.

Lin Chung-pin, former vice chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council and former deputy defense minister, said the gravest danger facing Taiwan is that it is like a hypnotized frog in a gradually warming tub set up by China.

He said all of the new measures that Beijing has announced since April, 2005, including giving a pair of pandas as gift to Taiwan, importing Taiwan fruit at zero tariffs, lowering the tuition and offering scholarship to Taiwan students, were "unilateral" decisions that do not need Taipei's "matching" efforts.

Other such measures were lengthening the time for Taiwan journalists based in China, offering financial loans to Taiwan business people investing in China, relaxing rules on Taiwan citizens working in China, and encouraging dialogue with Taiwan's "die-hard independentists," according to Lin.
Beijing has been launching the "charming offensive" in the aftermath of enacting Anti-Secession Law, mainly to remedy the harms done by that piece of legislation, Lin said.

Beijing's "smile" tactic actually has extended to the United States, using the U.S. to restrain Taiwan, he said, noting that such a tactic indicates that Chinese President Hu Jintao is not afraid of delaying the time for a showdown with Taiwan.
By working with the U.S. in restraining the Taiwan independence movement, Beijing is trying to eventually annex Taiwan without triggering a war, said the China expert.
In the meantime, he pointed out, China has never slowed down the pace of its military modernization program, an indication that its "two-pronged" strategy toward Taiwan has not changed.

In spite of China's smile offensive and growing military might, Lin said there are still many opportunities for Taiwan, but Taiwan authorities must first of all work to build a party-government consensus and proceed to forge a national consensus.
Taiwan's government must also realize that China is a huge neighbor sitting near by the "small island" country, and try to take part in all aspects of cross-Taiwan Strait interactions, Lin said.
In particular, he suggested that Taiwan take part in the "fermenting" process of China's political reforms.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TAKES PART IN EIGHT WHO SPECIALISTS' CONFERENCE SINCE 2005
DOC.DATELINE: Geneva, April 16 (CNA) (By Neil Lu and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Twelve medical professionals from Taiwan have taken part in eight specialists conference organized by World Health Organization (WHO) ever since the health body signed an memorandum of understanding with China in last May to offer Taiwan access to relevant WHO technical activities, WHO Director-General Dr. Lee Jong-wook said recently.

Among the eight conferences with the presence of Taiwan's specialists, Lee said two were related to avian flu and all meeting-goers of these conferences considered Taiwan's participation positive and in line with a WHO resolution about universal participation in this health body.

Lee said the WHO signed the memorandum with China in order to fulfill its goal of helping all peoples attain the highest possible level of health, adding that the world can't afford any gap in its surveillance and response network against epidemics.
Lee made the statement in response to questions from some WHO member states which are concerned about Taiwan's access to WHO activities.

Taiwan which is not a member of the United Nations and is thereby shut out of the WHO refuses to accept the memorandum between the WHO and China which referred to Taiwan as a province of China and required the WHO to consult with China before conducting technical exchanges with Taiwan.
Instead, Taiwan said it is seeking the right to participate the WHO directly, fully, immediately, meaningfully and separately from China.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, April 17, or the 20th day of the third month of the Year of the Dog according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1421: More than 100,000 people drown when the sea breaks through a dike in Dort, Holland.
1790: American public official, writer, scientist, and printer Benjamin Franklin dies at the age of 84. He played a major part in the American Revolution, negotiated French support for the colonies, signed the Treaty of Paris and helped draft the US Constitution.
1824: The United States and Russia define respective rights in the Pacific Ocean and on the northwest coast of America.
1894: Nikita S. Krushchev, Soviet politician, is born. As Soviet leader he denounced Stalin and thwarted the Hungarian Revolution of 1956. He was deposed in 1964 for his failure to improve the Soviet economy.
1895: The Treaty of Shimonoseki is signed, compelling the Ching court to pay a huge indemnity, open its seaports, recognize the independence of Korea, and cede the Liaoning Peninsula, Taiwan and the Pescadores to Japan.
1897: During a revolt in Ottoman-held Crete, war breaks out between Greece and the Ottoman Empire.
1906: A Pacific cable between China and the United States is completed.
1938: Chang Kuo-dao, governor of the Chinese communist government that controls the region comprising Shensi, Kansu and Ningsia issues a statement in Hankou distancing himself from the Chinese Communist Party.
1941: U.S. President Franklin D. Roosevelt approves initial military aid US$45 million for China.
1946: Communist troops enter Changchun, Kirin Province, in northeastern China.
1950: The Chinese Women's Anti-Aggression League is formally inaugurated.
1964: The ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs issues a statement severing diplomatic relations with The Congo.
1968: U.S. President Lyndon B. Johnson meets with South Korean President Park Chung Hee in Honolulu, pledging U.S. protection for noncommunist Asia.
1971: Egypt, Syria and Libya sign an agreement to form a confederation.
1971: East Pakistanis declare their homeland an independent nation which they rename Bangladesh. Sheik Mujibur Rahman serves as the nation's first prime minister.
1973: President Lon Nol of Cambodia announces the resignation of his Cabinet.
1980: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) accepts mainland China as a member, and the Republic of China is forced to pull out of the organization.
1989: The Mainland Affairs Council passes a proposal to allow teachers and staff of public schools to travel to the Chinese mainland for family visits.
1992: Legislative proceedings are completed for the National Employment Act, which is to serve as the basis for employment of foreign nationals in the Republic of China.
1994: Mainland China's public security unit announces it has solved a criminal case in which 24 Taiwan tourists were killed at Qiandao Lake on March 31, 1994.
1995: Fire breaks out at a KTV on Hankou Street in Taipei, killing 12 people and seriously injuring 14 others.
1996: U.S. President Bill Clinton signs a joint declaration on security cooperation with Japanese Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto pledging to maintain American military levels in Japan and elsewhere in Asia.
1999: An ROC humanitarian relief delegation returns to Taipei after a visit to Macedonia to express concern and offer assistance to ethnic Albanian refugees from neighboring war-torn Yugoslav province of Kosovo.
2000: The Year 2000 Trend Setting & Technology Conference is held in Taipei with more than 100 experts and industrialists from home and abroad participating.
2000: The Republic of China Finance Ministry allows two local insurance companies to set up offices in mainland China, marking the first mainland foray for the island's insurance industry.
2001: The Taipei Bank is chosen over four other hopefuls by the Ministry of Finance (MOF) to issue both traditional and computerized charity lotteries.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A wise man is ashamed to say much; he prefers to do more."

Manila Bulletin: 31.5 M return to work today
total of 31.5 million workers -- about 30.1 million of whom are in private establishments and around 1.4 million in the government -- return to work today after a four-day Holy Week vacation that started last April 13, Maundy Thursday, and ended yesterday, Easter Sunday.
The Philippine Daily Inquirer: Crime victims shocked
PROTEST AND praise greeted President Gloria Macapagal-Arroyo's announced commutation of death sentences to life terms, with an anticrime advocate saying a "Black Easter message" had just been handed to victims and their kin.
The Philippine Star: GMA order draws cheers, jeers
Crime victims were shocked while death row inmates rejoiced yesterday after President Arroyo said she would commute death sentences to life imprisonment -- a move that could save about 1,200 convicts, including al-Qaeda-linked militants.
The Manila Times: Iran to unleash suicide bombers
LONDON: Iran has formed battalions of suicide bombers to hit American and British targets if its nuclear installations are attacked, The Sunday Times newspaper said.

DOC.HEADLINE: International Headline News
DOC.TEXT:
The Japan Times: China bans vessels near gas field
Liberal Democratic Party Secretary General Tsutomu Takebe criticized Beijing on Sunday over a news report that Chinese maritime authorities have banned ship traffic in the East China Sea near the median line with Japan while it expands the Pinghu gas field.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT: Moscow, April 17 [CNA] The Moscow Times: Inmate Slashes Khodorkovsky's Nose Yukos founder Mikhail Khodorkovsky's nose was slashed early Friday by a fellow inmate while Khodorkovsky slept in a barracks in the Krasnokamensk prison colony he has been confined to for the last six months, his lawyers said. [By Chang Hung-kuang]

DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Monday are as follows:
The China Times:
Government sent delegates to China prior to KMT-CPC meeting: former MAC vice chairman.
The United Daily News:
Tycoon reveals that he called on first lady to inquire about ownership of a department store.

Executive Yuan will not accept Chinese Petroleum Corporation's proposal to hike petroleum price by NT$2.5 per liter.

MAC criticizes KMT-CPC meeting.

Lien and Hu stress peace and prosperity after meeting.

Lien touts gains after cross-strait cooperation forum.

Lien-Hu meeting avoids defining '92 consensus.'
