Hu calls for new talks with Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TAKES PART IN EIGHT WHO SPECIALISTS' CONFERENCE SINCE 2005(repeat)
DOC.DATELINE: Geneva, April 16 (CNA) (By Neil Lu and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Twelve medical professionals from Taiwan have taken part in eight specialists conference organized by World Health Organization (WHO) ever since the health body signed an memorandum of understanding with China in last May to offer Taiwan access to relevant WHO technical activities, WHO Director-General Dr. Lee Jong-wook said recently.

Among the eight conferences with the presence of Taiwan's specialists, Lee said two were related to avian flu and all meeting-goers of these conferences considered Taiwan's participation positive and in line with a WHO resolution about universal participation in this health body.

Lee said the WHO signed the memorandum with China in order to fulfill its goal of helping all peoples attain the highest possible level of health, adding that the world can't afford any gap in its surveillance and response network against epidemics.
Lee made the statement in response to questions from some WHO member states which are concerned about Taiwan's access to WHO activities.

Taiwan which is not a member of the United Nations and is thereby shut out of the WHO refuses to accept the memorandum between the WHO and China which referred to Taiwan as a province of China and required the WHO to consult with China before conducting technical exchanges with Taiwan.
Instead, Taiwan said it is seeking the right to participate the WHO directly, fully, immediately, meaningfully and separately from China.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NOT TO BE MAIN TOPIC IN BUSH-HU MEETING: THINK TANK OFFICIAL
DOC.DATELINE: New York, April 16 (CNA) (By Lillian Lin and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan is not expected to be the top subject in the forthcoming meeting between U.S. President George W. Bush and Chinese President Hu Jintao in Washington, D.C., a think tank senior fellow said Sunday.

Elizabeth Economy, director of Asia Studies of the prestigious think tank the Council on Foreign Relations, said that from the U.S. point of view, the Taiwan issue will only be third on the list in the Bush-Hu meeting slated for April 20.

The most pressing issues that Bush is expected to talk with Hu about are the U.S. trade deficit with China and the undervalued Chinese currency, as well as global security issues involving North Korea and Iran, Economy said.
The Bush administration is also expected to push China to engage in a partnership with the United States to share responsibilities in the international community, she added.

Economy admitted that from China's perspective, Taiwan will always be the most or second most important issue to be talked about in meetings like the Bush-Hu one, and China will certainly raise the issue of U.S. arms sales to Taiwan as well as President Chen Shui-bian's independence inclination.
Nevertheless, she said, there have been no incidents regarding Taiwan over the past several weeks that were prominent enough to make the Taiwan issue the centerpiece of the upcoming Bush-Hu meeting.

To the United States, particularly the U.S. Congress, the trade deficit, the value of the Chinese yuan, and intellectual property rights (IPR) protection are the most crucial issues to be tackled, Economy said, adding that the United States' trade deficit with China exceeded US$200 billion for 2005 and that Congress has become increasingly concerned about fairness in trade with China.

Just recently, Economy said, Washington and Beijing jointly announced at a meeting of the Joint Commission on Commerce and Trade several measures regarding IPR protection and China's opening of its telecommunications market. The purpose of the meeting was apparently to pave the way for Bush and Hu to arrive at concrete conclusions in their meeting, she said. However, she added that the key is whether Hu will implement the measures after he returns to China.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Straits Times: Foreign docs and patients a must for S' pore to excel.
Keeping costs down and quality up - this is the core mission of Singapore's health-care system, and the knife edge on which it must learn to balance so that Singaporeans can continue to enjoy high-quality health-care services at affordable prices.
The Lianhe Zaobao: GE date may be out in next few days.
Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong may announce the date of the General Election (GE) in the next few days, said People's Action Party (PAP) chairman Lim Boon Heng yesterday.

DOC.HEADLINE: GAS PRICE HIKE NOT YET DECIDED: ECONOMICS MINISTER

TEXT.P: Minister of Economic Affairs Huang Ing-san said Monday that it has not yet been decided whether gasoline prices will be hiked and that discussions are currently being held on the matter.

Huang made the statement at the opening ceremony of a car electronics exhibition, responding to local media reports which said that the Executive Yuan opposes the Ministry of Economic Affairs' plan to raise gasoline prices by NT$2.5 (US$0.078) per liter.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC DISMISSES REPORTS ABOUT SPECIAL ENVOYS SENT TO CHINA

TEXT.P: The government has not sent special envoys to China to discuss matters concerning cross-Taiwan Strait charter flights, an official of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said Monday.

MAC Vice Chairman Liu Teh-shun was responding to news reports that quoted Chen Ming-tong, a National Taiwan University professor who once served as MAC vice chairman, as saying that delegates commissioned by President Chen Shui-bian traveled to Beijing prior to main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Honorary Chairman Lien Chan's current visit to China to discuss matters concerning the facilitation of cross-strait cargo charter flights, as well as passenger charter flights on holidays and weekends.

The delegates, who reportedly arrived in Beijing April 8-10, "comparatively made some breakthroughs, " according to Chen. Lien headed to Beijing for an economic and trade forum with the Communist Party of China (CPC) April 14-15. He met with Chinese President Hu Jintao Sunday.

Asked about Chen's statement, Liu said that the government has commissioned the Taipei Airlines Association, which has helped negotiate cross-strait charter flights for the Chinese New Year holidays before, to help arrange for negotiations on the issues of cross-strait cargo and passenger charter flights.
The communications have "been in progress" and have never been disrupted, Liu said, adding that "there are absolutely no special envoys or any need to designate envoys to communicate with China."
Liu said Chen's statement should be read as "both sides of the Taiwan Strait have continued to communicate and engage in close talks."

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT'S DAUGHTER-IN-LAW GIVES PIANO RECITAL IN NEW YORK
DOC.DATELINE: New York, April 16 (CNA) (By Eric Tseng and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The daughter-in-law of President Chen Shui-bian gave a piano recital in New York Sunday, ahead of her graduation from the Manhattan School of Music.

Huang Jui-ching, who married President Chen's son Chen Chih-chung last June, has been studying under piano virtuoso Solomon Mikowsky for more than a year and is expected to obtain a master's degree in piano performance from the music institute in June.

Chen Chih-chung offered Huang a bouquet and his admiration upon the conclusion of her solo recital, which featured pieces by Bach, Beethoven, Chopin and Ned Rorem. Nodding with a smile, Mikowsky was apparently content with Huang's performance.
Afterward, the two of them greeted well-wishers and took pictures at the cozy Greenfield Hall of the music institute.
Among the well-wishers was Andrew Hsia, Taiwan's representative in New York, who said: "I'm not an expert on music, but listening to Jui-ching's music gave me a pleasant feeling."

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened high and closed higher Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 47.55 points to close at 7,000.09
The bourse opened at 6,982.47 and fluctuated between 7,015.91 and 6,950.58 during trading. A total of 4.89 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$126.37 billion (US$3.9 billion).

Seven of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with paper and pulp issues moving up the most at 6.7 percent, followed by foodstuff issues at 4.9 percent, textile stocks at 4.5 percent, construction issues at 2.8 percent, cement stocks at 1.6 percent, plastics and chemicals shares at 1.3 percent, and banking and financial shares at 1.2 percent.
Machinery and electronics shares remained unchanged.
Gainers outnumbered losers 614 to 300, with 105 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: CPC TAPPING UNDERSEA NATURAL GAS OFF KAOHSIUNG COAST

TEXT.P: The state-run Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC) has discovered undersea natural gas off the coast of the southern port city of Kaohsiung and is expected to begin mass production of gas from the field beginning 2009, CPC sources said Monday.

The CPC is drilling 10 wells in an area about 100 km from Kaohsiung to explore the gas field, which is assessed to contain enough for commercial exploration for 10 years, said Lee Tsung-lung, a deputy CEO of the CPC's Natural Gas Division.
The CPC will also build a 120-km undersea pipeline to convey the natural gas to a refinery in Yungan, Kaohsiung County, Lee said.
Currently, the CPC imports liquefied natural gas (LNG) from Indonesia and Malaysia to meet domestic demand.
Meanwhile, Lee said, the CPC has been building another LNG processing and storage plant near Taichung Harbor in central Taiwan, which is expected to become operational in January 2008.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA URGED TO ADDRESS TAIWAN TRAVEL ISSUE IN 'ONE SHOT'

TEXT.P: A mainland affairs official urged China on Monday to take a "once-and-for-all" step in its move to allow its citizens to travel to Taiwan for sightseeing.

Commenting on Beijing's announcement a day earlier of a package of rules governing Chinese people's sightseeing travel to Taiwan, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Vice Chairman Liu Teh-shun said that even if the regulations are put into effect, this does not mean that Chinese citizens will be able to come to Taiwan for tourist visits right away, because Beijing has not yet listed Taiwan as one of the destinations where Chinese tourists can visit.

Compared with Taiwan's unveiling of a complete program and measures in 2002 in accepting Chinese tourists' requests for sightseeing trips to Taiwan, China's announcement Sunday marked a delay of four-and-a-half years, Liu said, adding that "it's time for China to catch up with Taiwan."

Analyzing Taiwan's measures to allow Chinese tourists to sightsee in Taiwan and Beijing's regulations for management of mainland residents' pleasure trips to the island, Liu said that some differences still exist between the two sides on the issue and that there are relevant technical problems that need to be settled through negotiations.

China's Taiwan sightseeing management regulations are comprised of two main parts, including rules governing Chinese tourists' activities in Taiwan, as well as regulations on the selection and management of Chinese travel agencies in providing Taiwan tour packages and on Taiwanese organizations receiving Chinese tourists.
"Why do our host units need China's affirmation?" Liu asked

Meanwhile, the Hong Kong daily Wen Hui Bao cited Feng Chuozhe, president of the Beijing-run China Strait Travel Service, as saying Monday that the new Taiwan travel rules are aimed at providing legal protection to Chinese tourists.

The new rules help unfold "trust-based tourist activities" across the Taiwan Strait, ensuring that China will transport tourists to Taiwan "in an orderly way" and that Chinese tourists will receive hospitable services, Feng said.

The report predicted that Taiwan's unique natural resources and abundant cultural landscapes will attract many Chinese tourists, estimating as many as 50 million mainland citizens will want to visit Taiwan for sightseeing.

DOC.HEADLINE: MARKET TO DECIDE GAS PRICES: EXECUTIVE YUAN

TEXT.P: Government Information Office (GIO) Minister Cheng Wen-tsang said Monday that the Executive Yuan will not interfere with Chinese Petroleum Co.'s (CPC's) decision to raise gasoline prices.

Cheng said the Executive Yuan has approved a gasoline pricing mechanism that allows the state-run CPC to decide gasoline prices according to market principles under the supervision of the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA).

Cheng added that the Executive Yuan is concerned about the influence that the gasoline price hike might have on other consumer products, but will not interfere in the CPC's decision on the range of adjustments.

DOC.HEADLINE: CALLS FOR FORMER PREMIER TO JOIN MAYORAL RACE GAIN MOMENTUM

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) is willing to see more talent, including former Premier Frank Hsieh, join the party's primary for the year-end Taipei mayoral election, a DPP official said Monday.

Tsai Huang-liang, director of the DPP's Department of Culture and Information, made the remarks after reports that the DPP's decision-makers will not rule out the possibility of inviting Hsieh to run for Taipei mayor.

President Chen Shui-bian is also willing to join other heavyweights to persuade Hsieh -- who is currently on a short-term study program at the John F. Kennedy School of Government at Harvard University -- after his return from the United States at the end of this month, the reports said.

Tsai noted that many party members think Hsieh has a good chance of winning the election, but he also said the party will give its full support to whoever wins the primary -- whether Hsieh or former DPP Legislator Shen Fu-hsiung, who is the only one to have expressed any intention of running for Taipei mayorship.
Ker Chien-ming, a DPP caucus whip in the Legislative Yuan, said "Hsieh is definitely the trump card to turn the situation around for the DPP."

Noting that pro-Hsieh legislators will organize a delegation to the United States to hear Hsieh give a speech at Harvard University Wednesday, Ker said that he will join them to try to persuade Hsieh.
Various factions within the DPP said Monday that they will respect Hsieh's wishes as to whether he wants to run.

Legislator William Lai, also convener of the DPP's New Tide faction, said the faction thinks Hsieh will be a suitable candidate, claiming that no-one, whether in the ruling or opposition parties, can be on a par with him in terms of service record and qualifications.
"The faction will give full support to the party's nominee, " Lai said.

Legislator Kao Chih-peng, secretary-general of DPP's Justice Alliance faction, said the decision-making of the DPP has been mostly from the bottom up and that only prodding from the grassroots will persuade Hsieh to run.

Legislator Kao Chien-chi of the Welfare State faction said the Presidential Office, the DPP legislative caucus and the party should discuss who have the best chances of winning the Taipei and Kaohsiung mayoral elections.
In addition to Hsieh, former DPP chairmen and premiers should also be possible candidates, Kao said.
Legislator Hsieh Hsin-ni, a protege of Hsieh, said the DPP leaders have realized that the party is in disarray in the wake of a spate of scandals.
"To galvanize the party, the most crucial battles will be the year-end Taipei and Kaohsiung mayoral elections. The DPP will be out of the woods if it can win the elections," she said.
If Hsieh considers joining the election, his motives will be "for the party, and not for the individual," according to Hsieh Hsin-ni.
If other factions are only attempting to keep Hsieh away from the presidential election in 2008, then the strenuous efforts to persuade him to join the mayoral race will be unnecessary, she added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN FARMERS URGED NOT TO OVER-PRODUCE UPON CHINESE OFFERS

TEXT.P: Taiwan farmers were urged Monday not to over-produce fruit and vegetables simply because China has offered to increase imports of Taiwan agricultural products duty free.

Taiwan fruit growers and vegetable farmers were warned by Chen Chang-chen, a deputy researcher with the Chung-Hua Institution for Economic Research -- a private think tank -- about the risks of excessive production in light of Beijing's offer, which so far is only verbal.

Chen said Taiwan farmers should give it a second thought before increasing production, given the gap in the price structures between Taiwan and China is wide, the fierce competition from Southeast Asia, and the generally short shelf life of fruit and vegetables.

Chen suggested that for future exports of Taiwan-produced fruit to China, such trade should follow the formula adopted when Taiwan exports fruit to Japan -- keeping the shipments high quality with high price tags.
He also suggested that Taiwan fruit growers export their produce directly to supermarkets or franchise stores in big cities in China to shorten delivery periods and avoid exploitation by middlemen.

At the conclusion of the economic forum between Taiwan's main opposition Kuomintang and the Communist Party of China held in Beijing Saturday, Chen Yunlin, China's top official in charge of Taiwan affairs, announced that China will dispatch procurement missions to Taiwan to purchase the "extra" fruit and vegetables in times of over-production. Such imports will also be duty free too, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENTIAL OFFICE DENIES INTERFERING WITH CITY MAYOR'S NOMINATION

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian will not get involved in the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DDP's) nomination of candidates for mayoral elections in Taipei and Kaohsiung, the Presidential Office said Monday.
It noted that the DPP will name someone who best represents the party in the election battles according to party rules, which include the holding of primaries.

The statement was in response to media claims that Chen will call on former Premier Frank Hsieh, who is studying in the United States, to run for mayor of Taipei in order to invigorate the demoralized rank-and-file of the ruling party.

Tsai Huang-land, director of the DPP's Department of Communication and Culture, denied the speculation after a meeting of senior officials of the Presidential Office, the DPP and the Executive Yuan. Tsai said the reports were incorrect.
He said the Presidential Office will respect the DPP's nominations for the two municipalities, which will hold mayoral and city council elections in December.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT TO HOST THREE BREAKFAST MEETINGS ON KMT-CPC FORUM RESULTS

TEXT.P: The legislative caucus of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) said Monday that it will host breakfast meetings for three days in which officials and businessmen will be invited to talk about the results of a just-concluded economic forum in Beijing.

Topics of the three breakfast meetings, which will start Tuesday, will center on direct cross-Taiwan Strait air links and tourist exchanges, agricultural and fishery issues and issues concerning education and health care.

The caucus wants to discuss with the government and the private sector 15 new measures toward Taiwan announced by China Saturday at the conclusion of the forum co-sponsored by the KMT and the Communist Party of China (CPC) in Beijing in the hope of seeking affirmation from the government and the private sector of the results of the KMT-CPC forum.

Tseng Yung-chuan, executive director of the KMT's policy coordination department, and KMT caucus whip Pan Wei-kang, as well as KMT legislators Joanna Lei, Wu Yu-sheng and Chu Feng-chi, announced the planned breakfast meetings at a news conference at the KMT legislative caucus.

China's 15 new measures, which KMT Honorary Chairman Lien Chan claims is designed to further open China's market to Taiwan, include recognizing Taiwan's tertiary education diplomas, allowing Taiwan citizens to take part in China's customs broker licensing examinations, sending farm produce procurement missions to Taiwan and allowing more Taiwan-grown farm produce to enter the Chinese market.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER PREMIER'S OFFICE, FRIENDS GROUP TO BE LAUNCHED IN MAY

TEXT.P: An office and a group of friends of former Premier Frank Hsieh will be inaugurated in Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan next month, an executive director of the office said Monday.
Chang Ching-chuan said the office will set up May 7, while the "Hsieh's friends" group will be launched May 18. Both aim to bring Hsieh closer to the grassroots.
"Hsieh hopes to hear the voice and keep abreast of the expectations of the grassroots to work for the good of Taiwan's future," Chang said.

Two other Hsieh offices will be set up in central and northern Taiwan later, he said, adding that he is hoping for 300 "Hsieh's friends" groups by the end of the year, with one in every village and township in the country.

Asked whether the inauguration of so many offices and groups in such a short time is related to paving the way for Hsieh to run in the presidential election in 2008, pro-Hsieh officials said that "it is premature to say this."

When Hsieh, who was Kaohsiung mayor before serving as premier, stepped down from the premiership in late January after serving for less than a year, he said clearly that he wanted to listen to the voice of the grassroots, and the "Hsieh's friends" groups will provide the best forum for this, they said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PROSECUTION IN NO HURRY TO INDICT FORMER PRESIDENTIAL OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: The prosecution authorities said Monday they are in no hurry to indict former Presidential Office Deputy Secretary-General Chen Che-nan, even though they have strong evidence to charge him with fraud.
Prosecutors said they were thinking of delaying Chen's indictment because he is also suspected of involvement in several other major scandals that are being investigated.

These scandals include stock playing at the Presidential Office and an ownership fight over the Pacific Sogo Department Store, which has led to a controversy over whether the first family accepted gift vouchers for the store.

Chen also stands accused in the Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp. (KRTC) scandal for using his political influence to help Huapan Administration Consultant Co. win a contract to manage foreign workers working on the KRTC's construction project.

As all of these scandals are very complicated, Taipei District Court Chief Prosecutor Yen Ta-ho called a meeting of prosecutors and investigators last week, urging them to "aggressively pursue all likely evidence."

On a newspaper report that the judicial authorities will soon conclude probes into the fraud case, in which bankrupt construction businessman Liang Po-hsun accused Chen of taking bribes from him, Prosecutor Lin Pang-liang said the prosecution will not consider which case to conclude first.

Chen Che-nan was detained April 7 on suspicion of defrauding Liang and is supposed to be indicted within four months. Because Chen is also highly suspected for his involvement in the stock playing and Pacific Sogo scandals, the prosecution was concerned that if Chen were freed on bail by a court hearing the case, investigations into his suspected roles in the other cases could be made difficult.
As a result, the Taipei prosecutors said they were in no hurry to indict Chen at present, as they have until Aug. 8 to take that action.
Both Chen and Liang could be indicted on charges of breaking the anti-corruption law, while Yang Chen-feng, a sauna business owner, is expected to be indicted on charges of perjury in the fraud case.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACTING KAOHSIUNG MAYOR TO VISIT JAPAN

TEXT.P: Acting Kaohsiung Mayor Yeh Chu-lan is scheduled to lead a delegation of municipal officials to Japan Wednesday for a five-day visit, mainly to enhance bilateral ties and gain a better understanding of Japan's experience in harbor city development, a city government source said Monday.
Topping Yeh's itinerary will be a visit to Hachioji -- a satellite city in the Greater Tokyo area -- for talks at City Hall on a sisterhood ties plan between Kaohsiung and Hachioji.

Hachioji is known for its strong academic atmosphere because of its great number of colleges, universities and other education institutions. The city is also one of the richest communities in Japan, with many of its residents being professionals with high incomes, according to the source.
Besides Hachioji, Yeh and her delegation are also scheduled to visit Yokohama -- Japan's second-largest city and the largest international harbor city in the Far East.

While in Yokohama, Yeh, formerly a vice premier and minister of transportation and communications, and the Kaohsiung officials are expected to pick up clues about the harbor city's urban development, particularly development along the banks of the harbor.
They are also expected to gain a better understanding of tourism development and resources in Yokohama, which is also one of most important tourism cities in Japan.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES MOSTLY HIGHER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were mostly higher Monday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for April moved up two points to close at 6,986, with 40,534 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for May decreased one point to finish at 6,985, with 13,914 contracts traded, while June futures gained 56 points to end at 6,988, with 117 contract transactions. September futures remained unchanged at 6,790, with 53 contracts traded, while December futures moved up 19 points to finish at 6,790, with seven contract transactions.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Monday at 6,984 for April, 6,986 for May, 6,932 for June, 6,790 for September and 6,771 for December.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mostly higher.

April TE futures decreased 2.4 points to close at 308.1, with 5,087 contracts traded, while May TE futures lost two points to finish at 308, with 2,344 contract transactions. June TE futures moved up five points to end at 308, with two contracts traded, while September TE futures decreased 2.6 points to end at 301, with three contract transactions. December TE futures gained 1.7 points to close at 303.35, with one contract traded.

April TF futures increased 7.4 points to finish at 928.8, with 3,431 contracts changing hands, while May TF futures gained 8.4 points to close at 929, with 2,469 contracts traded. June TF futures moved up 23 points to end at 931.4, with 15 contract transactions, while September TF futures moved up 14 points to close at 917, with seven contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for December.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Monday, decreasing NT$0.021 to close at NT$32.460.
A total of US$860 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at the day's high of NT$32.481 and hit a low of NT$32.340.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP LASHES OUT AT KMT OFFICIAL'S PERFORMANCE IN CHINA

TEXT.P: Ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Yu Shyi-kun expressed disappointment Monday with main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Honorary Chairman Lien Chan, accusing him of lacking moral integrity when speaking in front of Chinese leaders.

Yu said that Lien's performance in China was really deplorable because he did not dare mention the Republic of China or his own experience in serving as premier and vice president of the nation when meeting Chinese President Hu Jintao Sunday in Beijing following a two-day forum between the KMT and the Communist Party of China (CPC) that ended Sunday in the Chinese capital.

In addition, Yu also strongly criticized Lien for not having the courage to ask Hu to clarify the dispute centering on the "separate interpretation of 'one China'" statement regarding Taiwan's relations with China.

A set of 15 overtures offered by Beijing to Taiwan following the KMT-CPC forum are nothing more than some agreements that have been reached between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait or some issues that will soon be settled under the framework of the World Trade Organization, the DPP chairman said, urging China to stop playing the "carrot and stick" strategy.

The DPP legislative caucus also held a news conference at the Legislative Yuan to condemn the KMT-CPC forum, saying that in addition to Lien, KMT lawmakers attending the forum also have the responsibility to report on their meetings and the itinerary of their China tour to the Taiwan people in public after they return home.

Echoing Yu's view, DPP legislative caucus whip Chen Chin-jun claimed that the Taiwan people are "really disappointed" with the KMT after scores of KMT lawmakers have headed to Beijing to meet Hu -- something he called a sharp contrast to their all-out boycott of the DPP government at the Legislative Yuan.

Several key bills, such as a U.S. arms procurement package bill and a government budget bill, as well as a presidential nomination list of Control Yuan members, have long been pending legislative approval due to boycotts from the opposition "pan blue alliance" lawmakers of the KMT and the People First Party, Chen said.
If the KMT has faith in Taiwan, it should take part in an economic conference on sustainable growth to be convened by the Executive Yuan in June, he argued.

The 15 measures offered by Beijing in bilateral trade and economic exchanges are part of China's united front strategy aimed at Taiwan under its "one China" precondition, he claimed, urging Taiwan businessmen not to go overboard when facing Beijing's enticements.

Lien and the more than 30 KMT lawmakers that traveled to China to attend the Beijing forum should report on their trip to the public, as the Taiwan people will never accept such a closed-door meeting that would sell Taiwan out, said DPP legislative caucus members.
Lien said Sunday in Beijing that the results obtained during the KMT-CPC forum, the first of its kind in nearly 60 years, have been "more handsome than expected."

Meanwhile, Lien and his 170-member delegation of KMT lawmakers, experts and business leaders are slated to return to Taipei April 25 from Shanghai. Meanwhile, Lien will travel to Fuzhou, Zhangzhou, and Hangzhou for family visits and tourist purposes.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACTIVITY HELD TO RAISE FUNDS FOR DOMESTIC VIOLENCE VICTIMS

TEXT.P: The non-profit Modern Women's Foundation (MWF) held a public activity Monday in downtown Taipei to raise funds for women who are victims of domestic violence.

While calling on the public to care for these women, the foundation said the Ministry of the Interior has reported that some 60,000 women were living with domestic violence, twice as many as the level of five years ago.
The MWF estimated that there should be some 150,000 victims of domestic violence around the country who have not yet been listed in the government's protection and aid program.

Such women suffer more than just the physical pain of the abuse, the MWF said, noting that the foundation's research has found that on average, each domestic violence victim has to pay NT$500,000 (US$15,405) per year for medical treatment, lawsuits, work losses, rent, living expenses and tuition fees for their children.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVERFISHING DECIMATES KENDING FISH STOCKS

TEXT.P: Around 100 underwater photographers taking part in a competition titled "looking for fish stars in Kending" failed to get shots of any fish longer than 50 cm because rampant overfishing has decimated stocks.
The event, held from April 8-16, was sponsored by Taiwanese Coral Reef Society in conjunction with the coral spawning season in the area around Hengchun in southern Taiwan.
Competitors were asked to record 10 kinds of fish that live at the bottom of coral reefs, with a prize of NT$10,000 (US$307.7) for the winner.
However, despite the fact that the photographers made four dives during the period, none of them managed to photograph any fish over 50 cm long.
Only Taiwanese Coral Reef Society President Tsai Yung-chun, who knows the area well, was able to use a videocamera to record a vague photo of a grouper of more than 80 cm at a depth of 34 meters.
Cheng Cheng-yi, president of an underwater photography society, said he caught a glimpse of a small group of nearly 1-meter barracuda for a fleeting moment.
Meanwhile, the coral reef spawning entered its second day Monday with two kinds of coral releasing their eggs, Tsai said Monday.

Tsai said that the spawning will enter its peak period in the next two days, during which visitors will be able to see spawning by more than 20 out of the 300 species of coral found in the Kending area.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH URGES SELF-DISCIPLINE OF NEWS MEDIA IN REPORTING SUICIDES

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) said Monday that it will publish the names every month of media outlets that fail to conform to ethics in reporting suicides, starting from May.

The DOH cited statistics from the suicide prevention center as indicating that as of April 17, the print media had published 114 attempted suicide stories, 74 of which were fatal. Three of the 114 stories were placed on the front pages, with the suicide notes and photos of the deceased also displayed, it said.

In a bid to prevent the media from fueling a "suicide copycat tide, " such as a spate of suicides using charcoal to create deadly carbon monoxide gas, the DOH called a news conference to call for the media to exercise ethical responsibility.
Hsueh Jui-yuan, director of DOH's Department of Medical Affairs, took two mass-circulation papers -- China Times and Apple Daily -- to task in their reporting of suicides Monday.

The two newspapers not only published photos of the deceased, they also oversimplified the reasons why the deceased took their own lives, which he said were "inappropriate reports" over which he "felt deep regret."
Hsueh noted that whether in studies at home or overseas, inappropriate reporting or over-reporting of suicides can trigger emulations or copycat suicide behavior.
He urged editors and media executives to exercise "self discipline."

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP TO PUSH FOR DIRECT LINKS WITH SIX CHINESE CITIES

TEXT.P: The opposition People First Party (PFP) will continue pushing for direct transportation links between Taiwan and China although the just-concluded Kuomintang (KMT) -Communist Party of China (CPC) trade and economy forum failed to work out a timetable regarding the issue, a PFP lawmaker said Monday.

PFP legislative caucus whip Lu Hsueh-chang said at a news conference that it was "a pity" that the 15 new measures -- ironed out in the two-day KMT-CPC forum -- did not include a timetable for direct shipping and air links, and that the PFP would strive for direct air and maritime connections with six major cities in China, namely Beijing, Guangzhou, Shanghai, Dalian, Qingdao and Tianjin.
Lu added that the PFP is also considering adding Chengdu City of Sichuan Province on their list.

Speaking on the same occasion, another PFP legislator, Tsay Sheng-jia, urged the Chinese authorities to propose effective measures to protect Taiwanese fruit farmers who are victims of fake products grown by Chinese farmers. Lu said that if China failed to do so, Taiwanese fruit farmers would hardly make a profit.
(Taijing Wu)

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENTIAL OFFICE DENIES ITS DEPUTY SECERETARY-GENERAL RESIGNED

TEXT.P: The Presidential Office denied a claim by a TV commentator Monday that Ma Yung-cheng, the office's deputy secretary-general, has tendered his resignation to President Chen Shui-bian because of his involvement in a series of scandals.
David Lee, director-general of the Department of Public Affairs at the Presidential Office, said the claim made by political analyst Hu Chung-hsin about Ma's resignation was untrue.
Hours after the Presidential Office issued the denial, Ma held a press conference and denied all claims by Hu and Chiu Yi, a legislator of the main opposition Kuomintang.
Hu told a news conference earlier Monday that he received tips from a reliable source in the Presidential Office that Ma had tendered his resignation.

Hu accused Ma of using his influence to help Lin Ming-cheng become chairman of Hua Nan Financial Holdings Co. after Lin gave Ma NT$2 million as a wedding gift in September 2002. Hu said it was incredible that Lin, who owns less than 1 percent of the company's shares, could become its chairman.

At the same press conference, Chiu accused Ma of being involved not only in the chairmanship battle of Hua Nan Financial Holdings, but also in the ownership fight over Pacific SOGO Department Store and a controversy over who should run China Development Financial Holdings Corp., Waterland Financial Holdings Co. and Fuhwa Financial Holdings Co.
Chiu demanded that Ma explain to the nation whether he interfered in Pacific SOGO's ownership fight on behalf of the president or the first lady.

Ma denied having offered to resign. He acknowledged that Lin had attended his wedding but added Lin had not sent him a gift. He also said he was not involved in the chairmanship battles of any financial holding companies, nor was anyone else at the Presidential Office.
On Pacific SOGO's ownership transfer, Ma said it was purely a deal between businessmen and that the Presidential Office had nothing to do with it.

Former Finance Minister Lin Chuan, who accompanied Ma at the press conference, backed Ma's claim and said the Presidential Office had not given any instructions to the Finance Ministry on who should be selected as the top executives of the partially state-owned financial holding companies.

Ma said he had already filed a lawsuit against Hu several days ago, and that since Chiu had made similar allegations to defame him at the press conference, he would file another slander suit against Chiu.
In the past few days, there has been mounting publicity over the alleged involvement of the Presidential Office and the first lady in Pacific SOGO's ownership battle.

According to confidential depositions of witnesses leaked to a TV program, contenders offering to buy the department store were told that "the high level has already decided on who will have that thing."

Meanwhile, news reports said the first lady has been busy checking her shopping records in an attempt to prove she did not receive any Pacific SOGO gift vouchers during the ownership battle over the department store in 2002, and that the gift vouchers she used for shopping there in early 2003 were purchased with funds pooled by her and her friends.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWMAKER CALLS FOR REVISIONS TO FOREIGN SPOUSES' RESIDENCY RULES

TEXT.P: A ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) lawmaker urged the government Monday to revise the current immigration law to allow for foreign spouses with young children to remain in Taiwan in the event of their being divorced or widowed.
Legislator Lin Shu-shan made the call at a news conference attended by a divorced Vietnamese woman and a widowed Cambodian woman, both of whom are facing deportation.

Under current immigration rules, Lin said foreign spouses who arrive in Taiwan to reside with their Taiwanese mates are forced to leave Taiwan once they divorce or upon the death of their partners, as their resident permits are automatically invalidated.

If they fail to leave within 15 days, Lin said, they may be deported, forcing their children to travel to their mothers' home countries and become "stateless, " or to live in Taiwan without the care of their mothers.

Quoting statistics released by the Immigration Bureau, Lin said there are currently 850 children of mixed marriages under the age of 12 in Vietnam and Indonesia having had their Taiwan household registration revoked because they have not returned home for two years. If young children of mixed marriages who have not yet been abroad for two years are added up, Lin said the number may be between 3,000 and 4,000.

Except for extraordinary circumstances, the U.N. Declaration of the Rights of the Child prohibits the separation of young children from their mothers, Lin said, adding that Taiwan's child welfare law also stipulates that all public and private institutions must give priority to the child's well-being while dealing with issues involving children and adolescents.
Lin said Taiwan's current immigration rules are apparently in violation of the basic humanistic concern for the well-being of young children of mixed marriages.

For her part, the divorced Vietnamese woman, surnamed Hoang, said she faces a dilemma: if she leaves Taiwan without her young children, nobody will be able to care for them; but if she takes them with her to Vietnam, they will have difficulty obtaining Vietnamese citizenship and receiving an education.
The father-in-law of the widowed Cambodian woman said his daughter-in-law will be deported because she has overstayed the 15-day limit following his son's death.
"After her deportation, who will care for my two little grandsons? Both my wife and I are old. The government should scrap its inhumane immigration rules," said the man, surnamed Lai.

Speaking on the same occasion, Lo Hou-hsiang, the National Police Agency's alien affairs department chief, said the problems are partly the result of foreign spouses' neglect in applying for an extension 15 days before the expiration of their residence permits. If they fail to apply in time, they will overstay their visas, have to leave Taiwan and apply for re-entry.
Lo said the Ministry of the Interior is planning to extend the grace period to 30 days from the current 15 days to benefit foreign spouses of Taiwanese.

A Ministry of Foreign Affairs consular official present at the news conference said there is really a need for the government to revise the immigration law to allow for foreign spouses to reside in Taiwan with their children in case they are divorced or widowed.

DOC.HEADLINE: YILAN COUNTY'S INTERNATIONAL REGATTA MAY NOT BE HELD THIS YEAR

TEXT.P: The annual Yilan International Collegiate Invitational Regatta involving men's and women's teams from renowned world universities may not take place this year because of a shortage of funds, the Yilan County government, the sponsor of the event, said Monday.

Yilan County Magistrate Lu Kuo-hua told reporters that it costs more than NT$20 million to hold the annual boat race, and that in the past, the country government only needed to put aside about NT$4 million each year, with the rest of the funds coming from the central government.

Lu said the county government had received only a symbolic pledge of NT$1 million from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs for this year's event and nothing from the Ministry of Education or the Cabinet-level National Council on Physical Fitness and Sports.

The county government, troubled by deteriorating financial conditions in recent years, is unable to squeeze NT$20 million from its budget to hold the boat race in September, he said, adding that the event may have to be canceled this year.
Yilan County's international regatta developed from a boat race in 1995 between two well-known universities in Taiwan -- National Taiwan University and National Taiwan Normal University.

With the support of local residents, the county government invited 10 teams from 10 universities in five countries to the race in 1996, including Oxford and Cambridge from the United Kingdom and Yale and Harvard from the United States.
In 1999, the event was expanded by adding a competition in the women's group. Last year, 25 teams from 12 countries participated in the race.

DOC.HEADLINE: CEC ENUMERATES LEGAL HURDLES TO PROPOSED 'TWO-IN-ONE' ELECTION

TEXT.P: The Central Election Commission (CEC) said Monday it does not support a proposal to hold the next presidential election and the legislative election simultaneously in early 2008 because there are legal hurdles to that goal.

A simultaneous holding of the two elections will either require a constitutional amendment to extend the current legislature's tenure or electing a new president four months before the expiration of the current presidential term, the commission said.

The commission was responding to a media criticism that the CEC has failed to actively promote the integration of the next legislative and presidential elections. Under the current regulations, the next legislative election must be held no later than Jan. 21, 2008, and the next presidential election should be held before April 19, 2008.

If advancing the presidential election, the new president would have to wait for four months before taking office May 20, 2008. No major countries around the world have ever had such a long transition period, the commission said. If the legislative election is postponed until March -- the traditional month for the presidential election, the commissioned said the present constitutional provisions must be revised to extend the current legislature's term.
Given all these legal hurdles, the commission said the "two-in-one" election proposal advocated by opposition parties is not feasible.
As to the proposal to hold the next Taipei mayoral, city council and borough chief elections simultaneously, the commission said it has never voiced opposition to that suggestion.

Nevertheless, the commission said it is only authorized to decide the date for the Taipei mayoral and city councilor election, while the date for Taipei borough chief elections must be determined by the Taipei City Election Commission.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING REMAINS UNWAVERING ON 'ONE CHINA': ANALYSTS

TEXT.P: By Flor Wang CNA Staff Writer

Taipei, April 17 (CNA) Although Chinese President Hu Jintao has broached peaceful developments in cross-Taiwan Strait ties during a recent meeting with Taiwan's opposition Kuomintang Honorary Chairman Lien Chan, Hu is unlikely to soften his stance on Taiwan when meeting with U.S. President George W. Bush Wednesday at the White House, observers said Monday.

Political analysts made the forecast on grounds that Hu's firmness in upholding the disputed "1992 consensus" as the cornerstone of building peaceful exchanges between Taiwan and China was nothing more than an indication of Beijing's insistence on the "one China" prerequisite in its dealings with Taiwan.

Despite Hu's acknowledgement that Taiwan and China are not united, political analysts said Hu's insistence on both sides of the Taiwan Strait fostering peaceful developmental links under the so-called "one China" framework is a reflection of the Chinese president's "iron will" toward Taiwan.

Although Beijing's stance has not wavered in this regard, political watchers said that in the international arena, "one China" automatically refers to the People's Republic of China, not Taiwan. At the upcoming Hu-Bush meeting, for example, Beijing is unlikely to accept the "one China, different interpretations" rhetoric -- the focal point of the "1992 consensus" dispute between Taiwan and China.

Moreover, they pointed out, a favorable climate arising from a two-day economic forum in Beijing between the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and the Communist Party of China (CPC) last weekend is expected to help boost Hu's profile in his meeting with Bush. They added that it was worth watching to what extent the impact of the KMT-CPC forum would have on the Hu-Bush meeting.

Meanwhile, many analysts opined that a rally of more than 47 points Monday on the Taipei Stock Exchange could be viewed as a lift fueled by bullish sentiment injected by the KMT-CPC forum, which put forward 15 measures to boost cross-strait ties, ranging from tourism, agriculture to health care following its closing Saturday.

Therefore, observers said, the positive atmosphere from the KMT-CPC forum should help Hu strengthen his standing in the upcoming Hu-Bush meeting, which will serve as a stage for Hu to show Bush that Beijing is a keen peacemaker in the Strait and that it has gained support from Taiwan's largest opposition party.

The alignment between the KMT and the CPC -- coupled with Hu's visit to the United States -- are set to whip up strong pressure on the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party government in Taiwan, analysts pointed out, adding that the question of whether Hu will bring the diplomatic battle of unification versus independence to the United States and how Bush will react will be the focus of attention.
Lien, who led a KMT delegation to attend the event, met Hu Sunday following the KMT-CPC forum. Lien expressed his satisfaction that results of the event were "much more attractive" than expected.
The Lien-Hu meeting was conducted in a cordial atmosphere and with subtle interaction, which watchers said could be gauged from the color of the two men's ties.

Lien worn a red tie, the symbolic color of the CPC, while Hu wore a blue one, the color representing the KMT, which lost power to the independence-leaning DPP in 2000 after having ruled Taiwan for more than 50 years.

DOC.HEADLINE: PHILIPPINE POLICE CHIEF VISITS TAIPEI TO BOOST COOPERATION

TEXT.P: Philippine National Police Director
General Arturo Lomibao arrived in Taipei Monday for a three-day visit.

The main purpose of his visit is to promote cooperation on crime-fighting between Taiwan and the Philippines, including cracking down on drug trafficking, maritime smuggling and other cross-border criminal activities.
During his stay, Lomibao will pay visits to relevant law enforcement authorities, including the National Police Agency, to discuss possible cooperative projects.
Lu is accompanied by a group of senior Philippine police officers on his Taipei visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT NEED NOT DANCE TO THE KMT'S TUNE: DPP LAWMAKER

TEXT.P: The Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) government need not dance to the tune of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) which is touting its achievements in co-sponsoring an economic forum with the Communist Party of China (CPC) in Beijing last weekend, DPP sources said Monday.
The sources made the remarks after a meeting attended by officials from the Presidential Office, the Executive Yuan and the DPP headquarters, as well as DPP legislative caucus whips.

A participant at the meeting who preferred to remain anonymous quoted Presidential Office officials as having said the ruling party "need not dance to the tune of the KMT" in dealing with cross-Taiwan Strait affairs.

Minister without Portfolio Lin Hsi-yao said that not every department under the Executive Yuan must respond to the 15 new measures announced by China at the conclusion of the KMT-CPC forum last Saturday.
Government agencies just need to fulfill their official duties well and let the DPP legislative caucus respond to KMT overtures, Lin said.

Legislator Yeh Yi-jin, who is also a DPP legislative caucus whip, suggested at the meeting that both the government and the DPP closely monitor the aftermath of the "Lien-Hu meeting" and the soon-to-be-held meeting between Hu and U.S. President George W. Bush in Washington, D.C. The DPP should be prepared for the challenges ahead, she added.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA NOT ALLOWED TO DESIGNATE TAIWAN TRAVEL AGENCIES: MAC

TEXT.P: The government will absolutely not accept China's "designation" of Taiwan-based travel agencies eligible to receive Chinese tour groups, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Joseph Wu said Monday.

Wu was commenting on China's newly unveiled management rules on Chinese people's sightseeing trips to Taiwan. One of the provisions prescribes that a list of Taiwan-based travel agencies to be allowed to receive Chinese tourists will be announced after the "confirmation" of China's National Tourism Administration.
Wu said the government is trying to ascertain through proper channels the exacting meaning of "confirmation" in Article 4 of Beijing's Taiwan travel management regulations unveiled Sunday.

"If Taiwan-based travel agencies have to obtain China's prior approval or designation to receive Chinese tourists, neither our government nor our travel operators would accept such an insulting demand which infringes upon our government's authority," Wu said.

Stressing that the government is entitled to decide on its own which local travel agencies are qualified to receive Chinese tour groups, Wu said the government will be willing to inform China of the officially sanctioned list after it comes to a decision. Nevertheless, he said, China is in no position to interfere with the selection or screening process.
"The two sides of the Taiwan Strait should respect each other, " Wu added.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATIVE SPEAKER TO MEET WITH OPPOSITION LEADERS ON MAJOR BILLS

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng said Monday he will pay visits to influential opposition leaders this week for talks on a broad range of issues as the legislature will begin to screen major bills April 25.
Wang said he will meet with main opposition Kuomintang Chairman Ma Ying-jeou, People First Party Chairman James Soong and bigwigs of the Non-Partisan Solidarity Union.

Even though Wang would not reveal the agenda of his talks with opposition leaders, it is widely expected that their topics will include a long-stalled U.S. arms procurement bill and the confirmation of the Control Yuan nomination list proposed by President Chen Shui-bian.

On Monday afternoon, Wang met with a six-member delegation from the National Committee on American Foreign Policy, a noted U.S. think tank. The delegation was headed by the institution's president, George D. Schwab.

According to Wang, the U.S. delegation raised many prickly questions, but didn't expressed their opinions. On the arms bill, Wang said the Cabinet has not yet referred a new version of the arms procurement bill to the legislature and the KMT has also not come up with a position paper on the issue as it previously promised.
Following the opposition-control legislature's veto of Hsing Wen-ting as the next state public prosecutor-general, Wang said he has no knowledge about who the new likely candidate will be.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, April 18, or the 21st day of the third month of the Year of the Dog according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1480: Lucrezia Borgia, the illegitimate daughter of Pope Alexander VI, is born in Italy. She was married three times by the age of 18 to further her father's political ambitions.
1906: An earthquake devastates San Francisco, killing more than 1,000 people and making 300,000 others homeless.
1925: The first world women's exposition is opened in Chicago.
1927: The national government is established in Nanking by the Kuomintang.
1933: Fighting spreads in northern China as several strategic passes along the Great Wall fall to the Japanese.
1942: Planes from a U.S. aircraft carrier bomb Tokyo for the first time. They were commanded by Lt. Gen. James Doolittle.
1943: Isoroku Yamamoto, a Japanese naval officer, is killed when his plane is shot down by U.S. warplanes over the Solomon Islands. He planned Japan's naval strategies during World War II, including the attack on Pearl Harbor in 1941.
1946: The League of Nations is formally dissolved.
1948: By a two-thirds majority, the first National Assembly approves temporary provisions granting emergency powers to the president during the ongoing anti-Communist campaign.
1949: The Republic of Ireland is formally proclaimed in Dublin.
1954: Gamal Abdel Nasser becomes prime minister of Egypt.
1955: Albert Einstein, the German-born American theoretical physicist who won a Nobel Prize in 1921 for his explanation of the photoelectric effect, dies at the age of 76. His specific and general theories of relativity revolutionized modern thought on the nature of space and time and formed a theoretical basis for the exploitation of atomic energy.
1968: Army officers in western Africa's Sierra Leone take over the government, dissolve the Legislature and suspend the constitution.
1977: A boat capsizes near Suao Port in eastern Taiwan, killing 32 college students and teachers on board and injuring 16 others.
1980: The former Rhodesia becomes independent Zimbabwe under President Canaan Banana.
1982: Monaco's Prince Rainier III and his wife, Princess Grace Kelly, arrive in Taipei for a visit.
1988: The Republic of China Red Cross Society begins forwarding mail from Taiwan residents to mainland China.
1989: The Mainland Affairs Council under the Executive Yuan decides to permit Taiwan citizens to gather news and make films in mainland China.
1998: Official talks between South and North Korea end with the two sides failing to resolve a dispute over aid to the starving North and the reunion of separated families.
1999: A GIO-produced documentary featuring the relationship between the year of one's birth and the 12 animals in the 12-year cycle of the Chinese calendar wins a gold medal at the Houston International Film Festival.
2000: Tainan-based National Cheng Kung University signs an academic cooperation contract with Japan's Kanazawa Industrial University.
2000: President Lee Teng-hui confers the Order of Brilliant Star with Grand Cordon on U.S. Senator Frank Murkowski (R-Alaska) for his contributions to promoting bilateral relations between the ROC and the United States.
2001: The Tainan District Court approves a prosecution request to hold Tainan City Mayor George Chang incommunicado over his alleged involvement in a governmental land-requisition scam.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A wise and good man may be known in three ways which I am not able to show in my own person. As a moral man he is free from anxiety; as a man of understanding he is free from doubt; and as a man of courage he is free from fear."
