DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Moscow, April 18 [CNA] The Moscow Times: City Housing Prices Grow 7.5% a Month Moscow's residential real estate market continued to soar in March, as price increases hit an all-time high. The Irn.ru analytical center reported that apartment prices in the capital rose on average by 7.5 percent las t month -- the greatest monthly price jump in the market's 15-year history. The previous record was 5 percent.
[By Chang Hung-kuang]

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. SENATORS EXPRESS SUPPORT FOR TAIWAN'S WHO BID
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 17 (CNA) (By Jorge Liu & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Fourteen U.S. senators jointly sent a letter to World Health Organization (WHO) Director-General Lee Jong-wook last week to express their support for Taiwan's bid to join the World Health Assembly (WHA) as an observer.

The letter dated April 12 was jointly signed by Richard Lugar (R-Ind.) , chairman of the Senate Committee on Foreign Relations; George Allen (R-Va.) and Tim Johnson (D-S.D.) , co-chairmen of the Senate Taiwan Caucus, a pro-Taiwan group in the Senate, as well as other senators.

The senators urged Lee to help Taiwan gain observer status at this year's WHA gathering, slated to be held May 22-27 in Geneva. The WHA is the highest decision-making body of the WHO -- the world's leading organization in public health.

In the letter, the senators said that Taiwan, with a population of 23 million people, needs to be part of the world's joint efforts in the control and prevention of avian flu outbreaks and part of the global security network for public health.
Taiwan has sought to join the WHA as an observer since 1997. However, due to China's obstruction, Taiwan has seen little progress in its bid.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New YOrk Times: Storm Evacuees Found to Suffer Health Setbacks
Families displaced by Hurricane Katrina are suffering from mental disorders and chronic conditions like asthma and from a lack of prescription medication and health insurance at rates that are much higher than average, a new study has found. The study, conducted by the Mailman School of Public Health at Columbia University and the Children's Health Fund, is the first to examine the health issues of those living in housing provided by the Federal Emergency Management Agency. Based on face-to-face interviews with more than 650 families living in trailers or hotels, it provides a grim portrait of the hurricane's effects on some of the poorest victims, showing gaps in the tattered safety net pieced together from government and private efforts.
Wall Street Journal: Oil Settles Above $70 a Barrel, Despite Inventories at 8-Year High
Crude oil closed above US$70 a barrel for the first time, highlighting a phenomenon reshaping the petroleum world: Investment flows into oil futures are supplanting nitty-gritty supply-and-demand data as prime drivers of prices. Oil at us $70 a barrel, if sustained, is likely to damp U.S. consumer spending, which is already coping with the impact of higher interest rates and a cooling housing market.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT FLIGHTS DURING DRAGON BOAT FESTIVAL POSSIBLE: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang said Tuesday that the launching of cross-Taiwan Strait chartered flights during the upcoming Dragon Boat Festival is possible so long as negotiations between the two sides on the issue are successful.

Noting that the Taipei Airlines Association (TAA) has been conducting talks with Chinese authorities under the commission of the government on the opening of cross-strait charter flight services on weekends and certain holidays, Su said that "if the talks bear fruit, there will be provisional chartered flights during the Dragon Boat Festival."

The Dragon Boat Festival on the Lunar May 5 which falls on May 31 this year is one of the three most important holidays in Taiwan. The other two are the Spring Festival, or Chinese New Year, and the Mid-Autumn Festival.
While answering lawmakers' questions during an interpellation session at the Legislative Yuan, Su reiterated that the government has been open-minded toward the issue.

At the same session, Transportation and Communications Minister Kuo Yao-chi echoed the premier's remarks, saying that in principle, it is possible for the two sides to operate chartered flights on weekends and holidays.
However, the government has been hoping the planned service could be linked with tourism to "generate the greatest benefits, " Kuo said.

Meanwhile, Mainland Affairs Council Chairman Joseph Wu denied at a breakfast meeting hosted by the opposition Kuomintang a news report claiming the government had sent a secret envoy to Beijing to discuss the cross-strait chartered flight issue.
No individual or group other than the TAA has been commissioned to serve as the official representative in the talks, Wu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMOSAT-3 OPENS DOOR FOR TAIWAN'S HIGH-TECH MAKERS: NSC DEPUTY CHIEF

TEXT.P: After the successful launch of FORMOSAT-3, National Science Council (NSC) Deputy Minister Shieh Ching-jyh said over the weekend at the Vandenberg Air Force base in California that the satellite is a milestone in Taiwan's space technology development and opens the door for Taiwan's high-tech manufacturers to market advanced satellite components.

Shieh noted that so far, Taiwan has completed three satellite projects, 1999's FORMOSAT-1, 2004's FORMOSAT-2, and the just-launched FORMOSAT-3.FORMOSAT-1 allows Taiwan to do ionospheric research, while FORMOSAT-2 enables Taiwan to do remote sensing and imaging, and FORMOSAT-3 makes Taiwan a leader in global climate research, he said.

Shieh emphasized that FORMOSAT-3 is capable of collecting enormous amounts of weather data and that through the sharing of this vital data with other international partners, Taiwan can cooperate more closely with other countries as well as promote Taiwan's international profile.

He further said that FORMOSAT-3, which incorporates 14 components from five Taiwan-based manufacturers, also means much to local makers, because they can now boost their market share with the experience they have acquired working on this project.

DOC.HEADLINE: CPC STILL ASSESSING WHEN AND BY HOW MUCH TO HIKE PRICES

TEXT.P: Officials of the state-owned Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC) said Tuesday that the company is still assessing when and by how much to raise gasoline prices.
International oil prices hit a new high of over US$70 a barrel Tuesday largely due to mounting tension over Iran's nuclear program.
The continuous rise in international oil prices this year has translated into losses for the CPC totalling NT$13.8 billion (US$425.9 million) in the first quarter, the officials said.

The officials said that in assessing when and by how much to hike prices, they will take the lowest oil prices in neighboring Asian countries as a reference and take into consideration the impact of the price hike on the domestic economy.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Straits Times: Medisave change helps 1m with chronic illnesses.
About a million people with diabetes, hypertension, high cholesterol levels and stroke will be able to use Medisave to pay part of their outpatient bills before the year is out.
The Lianhe Zaobao: Four kind of chronic patients will be able to use Medisave to pay their outpatient bills.
Ministry of Health announced four kind of the chronic patients with diabetes, hypertension, high cholesterol levels and stroke will be able to use Medisave to pay part of their outpatient bills in this year, and the limit is S$300.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI SHARE PRICES END LOWER

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened high but closed lower Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 10.63 points to close at 6,989.46.
The bourse opened at the day's high of 7,007.45 and hit a low of 6,918.46 during trading. A total of 3.94 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$110.12 billion (US$3.39 billion).
Only one of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with machinery and electronics shares moving up at 0.2 percent.

The seven other major stock categories lost ground, with textile stocks and paper and pulp issues both moving down the most at 1.6 percent, followed by cement stocks at 0.8 percent, foodstuff issues at 0.7 percent, plastics and chemicals shares and banking and financial shares both at 0.4 percent and construction issues at 0.2 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 522 to 377, with 104 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP LAWMAKERS URGE PROBE INTO ALLEGATIONS OF CHINA ORGAN-HARVESTING

TEXT.P: Lawmakers of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) urged international organizations Tuesday to investigate claims that emerged about Chinese authorities harvesting organs from detained Falun Gong members in China.

Legislators William Lai, Tien Chiu-chin and Huang Chao-hui proposed that the Legislative Yuan issue a resolution to urge Amnesty International and the World Health Organization to send a task force to an alleged Chinese concentration camp to investigate allegations that Chinese authorities are harvesting human organs from detained Falun Gong members.

Lai urged people not to receive organ transplants in China not only because its medical care level is not as good as in Taiwan, but also because patients should not accept organs harvested in violation of human rights.

Falun Gong members in Taiwan claim that China is running a Nazi-style concentration camp where around 6,000 Falun Gong members are detained, and the harvested organs are sold to patients around the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT: La Repubblica: Supreme Court expected to decide final results of elections in two days. The Supreme Court is expected to issue its verdict in two days on the disputed vote of the April 9-10 general elections, judicial sources said. The verdict will decide who wins the elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAITRA ENCOURAGES TAIWAN COMPANIES TO ATTEND RUSSIA ICT SHOW

TEXT.P: The information and communications exhibition of Russia 2006, the largest ICT industry show in Russia and the North European region, will be held in Moscow May 10-15, and Taiwanese companies and business leaders are invited to attend.
In 2005, the information and communications exhibition of Russia attracted 33 countries -- including Taiwan -- representing more than 800 companies from around the world.
The Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) said companies interested in exploring markets in Russia and North Europe could contact 02-8792-6666 ext.247 for more information.

According to TAITRA, the 2006 exhibition in Russia is the 18th, with more than 72,000 people attending the show last year, including representatives of 872 corporations from Taiwan, Germany, France, South Korea, Sweden, Norway and the United States.

Taiwan Electrical And Electronic Manufacturers Association (TEEMA) brought 15 Taiwanese companies to the show last year. TEEMA is encouraging more Taiwanese companies to play a part in the exhibition this year. (Timothy J. Hwang)

DOC.HEADLINE: FAR EASTERN OPENS ALL-CARGO AIR ROUTE TO PALAU

TEXT.P: Far Eastern Air Transport (FAT) will open an all-cargo air link between Palau and Japan via Taipei Wednesday to transport Palau's fresh marine catches to Japan.

FAT will use a Boeing 757-200 all-cargo aircraft with a maximum cargo capacity of 26 metric tons to ply the route, with the first flight taking off from Taipei to Palau Wednesday, FAT announced Tuesday.
After being loaded with cargo, the inaugural flight will return to Taipei that same day, where the cargo will be transferred to flights destined for Japan, according to FAT.

Palau's fresh marine catch is usually shipped to Japan via Guam, so the new route provides more flights to Japan and will serve Palauan fishery operators better with larger cargo loads and bigger transportation flexibility, FAT executives said.
The first Palau-Taipei-Japan all-cargo flight has been booked with a full load, according to FAT.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN CLOSELY WATCHING DEVELOPMENTS SURROUNDING BUSH-HU MEETING

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) will keep a close watch over developments regarding an upcoming meeting between U.S. President George W. Bush and Chinese President Hu Jintao, a MOFA official said Tuesday.

For this purpose, an inter-ministerial emergency response task force headed by Minister of Foreign Affairs Huang Chih-fang officially started operations Tuesday, according to MOFA spokesman Michel Lu during a regular press briefing.
Lu said Taiwan maintains regular communication with the United States on major bilateral issues but he would not disclose the details of the communication.
Lu noted that issues likely to be addressed by the two leaders during their April 20 meeting at the White House include U.S.-China trade and China's democratization.
He said the government will watch if the Taiwan issue is raised for discussion and what Washington's and Beijing's stands are toward the issue.

Also Tuesday, Mainland Affairs Council Minister Joseph Wu said the government is concerned about the Bush-Hu meeting although there has been "intelligence" indicating the two leaders will not issue any joint statements after the meeting and that Bush will not make any remarks critical of Taiwan.
Wu urged the U.S. government to heed the voice of Taiwan's people and to treat democratic Taiwan fairly.

While the United States has made freedom and democracy the central values of its diplomatic policy, it will make people around the world doubt the consistency of U.S. policy if Bush makes remarks that are harmful to a democratic country or critical of a popularly elected leader, Wu said.
Wu made the remarks during a news conference hosted by the Peacetime Foundation of Taiwan.

Wu pointed out that resuming cross-Taiwan Strait dialogue is expected by Taiwan's people and is also the government's goal, but that goal is difficult to achieve because China has set the "one China" principle as its precondition for restoring talks with Taiwan.
Therefore, he said, the government is seeking to restart cross-strait talks on economic issues to try to transform cross-strait conflict into cooperation.
Wu called on Beijing to pay close attention to the voice of Taiwan's people, whom he said are expecting China to remove its deployment of missiles targeting Taiwan and renounce the use of force.

Predicting that it will be increasingly difficult for Chinese leaders to suppress the strong call for freedom and democracy within Chinese society, Wu said the government is concerned Beijing might make Taiwan its "scapegoat" in an attempt to divert internal pressure.
Wu said Taiwan's peaceful transition from authoritarianism to democracy can be a reference point for China in transitioning to a democracy.
Also, Taiwan should fight for international support because a democratic Taiwan deserves more recognition and backing from the international community, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower Tuesday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index futures for April lost three points to close at 6,983, with 38,280 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for May dropped three points to finish at 6,982, with 25,890 contract transactions, while June futures moved down 20 points to close at 6,968, with 144 contracts traded.
September futures lost five points to finish at 6,785, with 34 contracts traded, while December futures moved down one point to close at 6,789, with 54 contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Tuesday at 6,986 for April, 6,985 for May, 6,988 for June, 6,790 for September, and 6,790 for December.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mixed.
April TE futures gained 0.95 points to close at 309.05, with 5,442 contract transactions, while May TE futures moved up 0.6 points to finish at 308.6, with 4,178 contracts traded.
June TE futures gained 1.25 points to close at 307.8, with 10 contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.
April TF futures moved down 2.4 points to close at 926.4, with 3,142 contract transactions, while May TF remained unchanged to finish at 929, with 3,180 contracts traded.
June TF futures dropped 5.2 points to close at 925, with two contracts traded, while September TF futures gained 0.8 points to finish at 915, with two contracts traded.
December TF futures gained 10 points to close at 913.8, with one contract traded.

DOC.HEADLINE: RECOGNITION OF CHINESE DEGREES MUST FACTOR IN TAIWAN'S SOVEREIGNTY: SU

TEXT.P: Taiwan's sovereignty must be factored in when the government makes a decision on whether to recognize educational degrees issued by China, Premier Su Tseng-chang said Tuesday.
Replying to opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Legislator Hsieh Kuo-liang's questions, Su said that recognizing Chinese degrees is not just an educational issue.

"It involves Taiwan's education industry as a whole and the job market. The interest of Taiwan's students must not be sacrificed. Therefore, the government must thoroughly consider the issue before making a decision," he said.

In answer to questions from Liu Sheng-liang, another KMT lawmaker, Su said "we will never accept" Chinese President Hu Jintao's "one China" principle if it does not allow for Taiwan's interpretation but only means "the People's Republic of China."

The KMT interprets "one China" as the Republic of China, an interpretation that Su's Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) will not accept until China says it does. Even if China says so, President Chen Shui-bian has only promised that he will "absolutely respect" "one China, respective interpretations."

Liu asked Su if the government was opposing the KMT-Communist Party of China forum just concluded in Beijing because it feared the credit for promoting cross-strait trade and economic exchanges would be taken by the opposition parties.

Su said, "it is not so, " adding that the forum was conducted between political parties whose conclusions involve public authority and will require "government-to-government talks" before they can be implemented.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Tuesday, gaining NT$0.026 to close at NT$32.486.
A total of US$890 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$32.460 and fluctuated between NT$32.380 and NT$32.494.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT EXCHANGES SHOULD LISTEN TO VOICE OF PEOPLE: CIVIC GROUP

TEXT.P: The head of a civic group urged Tuesday that the true voice of the people be taken fully into account in future cross-strait exchanges.

Chien Hsi-chieh, executive director of the Peacetime Foundation of Taiwan, made the remarks during a presentation of a documentary recording a discussion on cross-strait relations by 60 participants with different years of age, educational backgrounds and political viewpoints at a three-day workshop last month.

Chien, a former legislator, said the foundation was pleased with China's goodwill overture at the conclusion of an economic and trade forum between main opposition Kuomintang and the Communist Party of China in Beijing last weekend.
"Any efforts made to promote cross-strait relations should be respected," Chien said.
"Cross-strait exchanges should return to rational debates, replacing past ideological vilification, and listen to the true voice of the people," he continued.
This is why the foundation has created the workshop, an independent program funded by the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council, albeit without any interference, Chien said.

Foundation officials noted that the tone regarding mainstream discourse on cross-strait relations has been set by the government over the past years, with voices from the private sector rarely receiving any attention.
"Taiwan's people haven't felt so strongly about disputes on the issue of independence versus unification," the officials said.

They urged the government to seek domestic consensus on cross-strait issues based on the basic needs and values of Taiwan's people, and to try to seek common ground on which Chinese government and private sectors can also agree.
All of the workshop's 60 participants exchanged views on cross-strait peace and tried to find common ground despite wide differences, the officials said.

Other wishes expressed by participants include a deepening of democracy in Taiwan, resumption of a stalled cross-strait negotiations, the international community helping Taiwan join governmental and non-governmental organizations, and China's removal of its 800 missiles targeting Taiwan and its renouncement of the use of force against Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: ENVIRONMENTAL GROUPS TO LAUNCH EARTH DAY BATTERY RECYCLING CAMPAIGN

TEXT.P: Domestic environmental groups will launch an Earth Day campaign April 22 around the island to invite the public to recycle used batteries and ink cartridges for computer printers.

In response to the main theme of this year's Earth Day -- "Climate Change Solutions Campaign, " the Society of Wilderness will launch the recycling program April 22 in nine cities and counties around the country, including Taipei City, Taipei County, Taoyuan County, Hsinchu County, Taichung County, Chiayi County, Tainan County, Yilan County and Hualien County.

Chang Hung-lin, secretary-general of the Society of Wilderness, said they will promote 10 ways people can do something for the sake of environmental protection, such as carrying their own chopsticks while dining at restaurants, paying attention to pro-environment news, and paying heed to candidates' environmental policies during elections so the public can enjoy a healthy and more eco-friendly life.
Meanwhile, Chen Yung-jen, director of Taipei City Government's Environmental Protection Bureau, noted that less than 20 percent of Taiwan's used batteries are recycled.
Chen cautioned the public not to underestimate the impact on the environment when they throw out a little battery.

A series of activities held that day at Sungshan Tobacco Factory in Taipei will allow the public to learn about a more eco-friendly life, including a demonstration on how to recycle paper and a test ride on electric bicycles.

DOC.HEADLINE: WASHINGTON URGED TO ASK BEIJING TO REDUCE CROSS-STRAIT TENSIONS
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 17 (CNA) (By Jorge Liu and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: A senior U.S. senator urged President George W. Bush Monday to seize the opportunity of his forthcoming meeting with Chinese President Hu Jintao to press Beijing to take action to reduce tensions with Taiwan.

"It is imperative that you impress upon President Hu the importance of diffusing tensions and enhancing stability in the Taiwan Strait by avoiding further provocations with Taiwan, and committing to a peaceful resolution on the question of Taiwan's status, " Senate Minority Leader Harry Reid (D-Nev) said in a letter addressed to President Bush.

Also, Reid said, it is essential that Hu's visit produce "real and lasting" progress on ending the nuclear weapons ambitions of Iran and North Korea, in light of the fact that China is opposed to the U.N. Security Council action against Iran and that the Bush administration's decision to rely on China to exert influence over North Korea's nuclear weapons ambitions through six-party talks has failed to yield satisfactory results.

Reid further criticized the Bush administration as having "badly mishandled" its protection of U.S. economic and trade interests, saying the administration has not taken any real action to address issues such as China's unfair manipulation of its currency, its rampant intellectual property piracy and its lack of compliance with its WTO obligations.

"You must use this visit to make clear to President Hu that your administration will no longer accept 'get tough' rhetoric and occasional press release progress instead of strict compliance by China with global rules," Reid said.

Also Monday, a group of 12 members of the House of Representatives sent a joint letter to President Bush urging him to use the April 20 meeting with Hu to request that China remove its missiles targeting Taiwan and open dialogue with the duly elected government of Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAISUGAR CHAIRMAN SAYS SEVEN DIVISIONS TO BE PRIVATIZED IN 2007

TEXT.P: The chairman of state-owned enterprise Taiwan Sugar Corp (TSC) , Yu Cheng-hsien, said Tuesday that seven divisions of the corporation will be privatized in 2007, except the Sugar Business Division and company assets.
Yu made the remarks during an inspection tour of the construction of the Sugar Industry Museum in Kaohsiung County.

He noted that sugar is a daily necessity and a strategic commodity that cannot be privatized, adding that TSC will establish an asset management holding coporation after these seven divisions have been privatized.

TSC has eight divisions, including the Leisure Business Division, Sugar Business Division, Agriculture Business Division, Hypermarket Business, Animal Business Division, Petroleum Business, Biotechnology Business Division, and Marketing Business Division.

TSC currently owns four sugar factories (located in Nanjing, Shanhua, Beigang, and Huwei) with a total milling capacity of 13,000 tons per day, and a sugar refinery in Hsiaogang with a melting capacity of 1,200 tons per day.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT OPEN TO CHINESE TOURISTS COMING TO TAIWAN: PREMIER

TEXT.P: The government has been consistent in welcoming Chinese people to Taiwan for sight-seeing purposes, and "it is China, not Taiwan," that has stood in the way, Premier Su Tseng- chang said Tuesday.

Su made the remarks while answering questions from ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) lawmaker Lee Chen-nan, who asked the government to work out complementary measures before opening Taiwan to Chinese tourists, and released the results of an Internet survey indicating that 33 percent of Taiwan's people hope that the government will do so out of concern over national security, public health and the spread of contagious diseases.

The government welcomes tourists from around the world to Taiwan, including those from China, but Beijing has yet to include Taiwan on its list of approved outbound travel destinations, Su said, adding that the government is poised to hold negotiations with China to settle some relevant issues.

Meanwhile, the Japan-based Senkei Shimbun cited Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Minister Joseph Wu in its Tuesday edition as saying that the Taiwan government is set to commission a private sector group to hold bilateral talks on cross-Taiwan Strait charter flight services with Chinese authorities, modeled after the Lunar new year holiday charter flight services earlier this year.

Speaking to Japanese media Monday in Taipei, Wu said that Taiwan welcomed the beneficial overtures offered by Beijing following a two-day economic forum held by the Kuomintang (KMT) and the Communist Party of China (CPC) in Beijing last weekend, including allowing Chinese tourists to visit Taiwan.
Wu did not specify when such two-way talks would begin but expressed optimism about the issue.
But Wu criticized Beijing's "one China" framework in its dealings with Taiwan and said that he was pessimistic that progress would be made to solve the political differences between the two sides.

Wu reiterated the Democratic Progressive Party government's basic stance on cross-strait relations, saying that Taiwan will not rule out the possibility of holding negotiations with China on any topic as long as they are based on reciprocity and equality.

Wu lashed out at the KMT-CPC forum, claiming the KMT's approach to the CPC has created chaos at home and confusion abroad, and he argued that Beijing should talk to the DPP government instead of an opposition party.

The MAC chief also expressed displeasure when blaming KMT Honorary Chairman Lien Chan for failing to stand up on behalf of the Republic of China during his Sunday meeting with Chinese President Hu Jintao, pointing out that Lien did not even dare mention the nation's official title when Hu talked about the disputed "1992 consensus" without displaying agreement on the attached "respective interpretations of 'one China'" statement.

DOC.HEADLINE: IACT RECRUITING VOLUNTEERS FOR HUMANITARIAN WORK IN TIBET

TEXT.P: A non-governmental organization (NGO) in Taiwan is recruiting 10 to 15 volunteers for humanitarian and medical assistance in Tibet, a spokesman for the NGO said Tuesday.

The International Action and Cooperation Team (iACT) is recruiting college graduates or anyone interested in humanitarian and medical assistance. Applications will be accepted until April 25, the spokesman said.

The first phase of training, with around 30 people selected among the applicants, includes courses on Tibetan history and community development. Trainees will also be taught international trends in humanitarian assistance and community development.
The second phase, in which only 10 to 15 volunteers selected from the first phase will attend, will focus on development issues in the Tibetan community.
The spokesman said that during the stay abroad, volunteers will be paid NT$200 (US$6.25) per day, and are required to file a report at the end of their mission in Tibet.

Applicants with good English communication skills will be given favorable consideration in the selection of candidates. Application forms can be downloaded at the iACT website (www.iaction.org) and sent by e-mail to the address: iact@iaction.org or by fax to (02)27042394.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENTIAL OFFICE CLARIFIES 'FALSE' ALLEGATIONS AGAINST FIRST LADY

TEXT.P: The Presidential Office Tuesday dismissed as "unfactual" recent allegations by a former legislator that first lady Wu Shu-jen is a woman who attaches great importance to money.
In a statement, the Presidential Office said the accusations have defamed the public image of the wheelchair-bound Wu and are extremely unfair to the physically challenged.
During a TV talk show Monday, former Legislator Ju Gau-jeng said Wu pays great attention to money because, he said, money is the best protection for a handicapped person.

Ju also claimed that President Chen Shui-bian's political career is determined by Wu's attitude and he insinuated that Wu is from a snobbish family, claiming that Chen's father would not visit his in-laws again after visiting them once.
The Presidential Office stressed that none of these accusations are grounded in fact.

Especially regarding Wu's attitude toward money, the Presidential Office pointed out that before entering politics, Chen was formerly a lawyer who earned a high salary, and that it was Wu who encouraged Chen to contribute toward Taiwan's democracy and supported Chen's decision to provide pro bono work for victims of the 1979 Kaohsiung Incident.
"This shows the first lady is a person of principle, rather than one who pays attention to money," the Presidential Office said.

Ju's accusations have come in the wake of allegations by opposition Kuomintang Legislator Lee Chuan-chiao more than one week ago that Wu received NT$8.8 million in gift vouchers from Pacific Sogo Department Store.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER PRESIDENTIAL AIDE QUESTIONED IN COURT OVER TWO SCANDALS

TEXT.P: Prosecutors at Taipei District Court questioned a former senior aide to President Chen Shui-bian Tuesday over his roles in two scandals that continue to rock the Chen administration.

Chen Che-nan, a former Presidential Office deputy secretary-general who is in detention on suspicion of defrauding Liang Po-hsun, a bankrupt construction businessman, was questioned on his role in buying and selling stocks while he was serving at the Presidential Office.

He was also questioned for suspected involvement in taking political "contributions" from former Tuntex Group's Chen You-hao, a wanted economic criminal who accused Chen Che-nan of taking NT$10 million (US$308,000) in cash from him Sept. 5, 2000 at a hospitality center run by Liu Tai-ying, a confidant of former President Lee Teng-hui.

Tuntex political donations became a top story that was widely reported during the 2004 presidential election, but the prosecution closed the case because the chief suspect, Chen You-hao, fled the country.

Prosecutors are now re-investigating the Tuntex case -- because Chen Che-nan was found to have been involved in quite a number of other corruption scandals, including an ownership fight over Pacific Sogo Department Store -- in the hope of getting new evidence on the political donations controversy.
Another focus of the prosecution investigation Tuesday was bank accounts and the flow of funds suspected to have been used when Chen Che-nan directed stock transactions at the Presidential Office.

While probing the allegations, the prosecution discovered that a large part of the political donations that Chen Che-nan had received flowed into the accounts of Liu Hsing-yi, Yang Chen-feng's girl friend, which were used by Yang to invest in the stock market.
Yang stands accused of perjury in the Liang case. Investigators suspect that Yang had been laundering money for Chen Che-nan.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA URGED TO ENGAGE IN DIALOGUE WITH TAIWAN'S ELECTED GOVERNMENT
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 18 (CNA) (By Jorge Liu and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: A U.S. senior official Monday again urged China to engage in dialogue with the elected government of Taiwan.

The official was responding to a query on whether the meeting in Beijing Sunday between Lien Chan, honorary chairman of the main opposition Kuomintang, and Chinese President Hu Jintao, would be a new factor in U.S.-China relations and whether the U.S. welcomed this type of dialogue.
"It's very clear that the U.S. welcomes dialogue between the authorities in Beijing and authorities -- all authorities in Taipei," the official said.

The U.S. has frequently said to the Beijing authorities -- and will say it again -- that it is important for the central government in Beijing to "engage directly with the elected government in Taiwan," the official said.
The U.S. stance with the Chinese government has been that "dialogue is good, but dialogue with the elected government in Taipei is essential," the official added.
The official made the remarks during a background briefing given to the media on Chinese President Hu's visit to the United States April 18-22.

DOC.HEADLINE: EDUCATION MINISTER STRESSES IMPORTANCE OF VOCATIONAL EDUCATION

TEXT.P: Minister of Education Tu Cheng-sheng stressed Tuesday the importance of vocational and technical education in a TV commercial released to the press that day.

In the commercial, which is one of three to be officially broadcast April 20, Tu learns how to decorate a cake from students at the Kaohsiung Hospitality College who once won an international cake decorating contest.

"The happiest thing in life is to do something in which one is really interested, " Tu said, encouraging students to study at vocational and technical schools in order to turn their interests into professions in the future.

Meanwhile, Chang Kuo-pao, director of the Department of Technological and Vocational Education under the Minister of Education, who features in another commercial, said that among the 30 children in his extended family, 16 studied at technical and vocational training schools.

Chang said he encouraged his son to study at technical and vocational school after he graduated from junior high school, and that his son was later able to spend a year honing his skills at the industrial design department of the renowned ASUSTeK Computer Inc.
Describing technical and vocational training as being of great benefit to peoples' careers, Chang urged more students to attend vocational schools.

DOC.HEADLINE: HIGH-SPEED RAILWAY TO OPEN IN OCTOBER: TRANSPORTATION MINISTER

TEXT.P: Minister of Transportation and Communications Kuo Yao-chi gave her assurance Tuesday that the high-speed railway undergoing test runs will open -- at least between the southern port city of Kaohsiung and Panchiao City in Taipei County -- by the end of October, or she will resign to take responsibility.
Kuo gave the assurance while answering questions from a legislator of the main opposition Kuomintang during an interpellation session at the Legislative Yuan.

She said the Taiwan High-Speech Rail Corp. (THSRC) has been conducting test runs recently, with results up to April 17 showing that the train can run smoothly between Kaohsiung and Taoyuan in northern Taiwan.

Kuo acknowledged that while the target is for THSRC to open the entire railway line by the end of October, there is no guarantee that a "bottleneck" problem relating to the section between Taipei and Panchiao can be sorted out in time.
Kuo reiterated her promise made previously at the legislature that if the high-speed railway again fails to open as scheduled -- it is already running years behind schedule -- she will step down.

Observers noted that while it might seem unusual for a Cabinet minister to risk her political future to guarantee the smooth operation of a transportation project undertaken by a private company, the Democratic Progressive Party government has been under fire for providing NT$308.3 billion (US$9.5 billion) in government loans to THSRC without oversight, against the NT$130 billion capital invested by the company's five shareholders.
THSRC Chairwoman Nita Ing has twice disappointed the nation by delaying the scheduled launch of the high-speech train service -- from June 2003 to October 2005 and again to October this year.
The construction of the 345-km railway linking Taipei and Kaohsiung -- Taiwan's two largest cities -- is about 96 percent complete.

THSRC has ordered 30 sets of the 700T trains from Japan, with each set consisting of 12 carriages that can seat 986 passenger. Running at 200 kph, the train could potentially reduce the time for the journey between Taipei and Kaohsiung to 90 minutes.

DOC.HEADLINE: HORSETRADING ALLEGATIONS SHOULD BE BACKED BY EVIDENCE: KMT CHIEF

TEXT.P: Evidence should accompany lawmakers' allegations of "behind the scenes" deals, main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou said Tuesday.

Ma, who also serves as Taipei mayor, said lawmakers from the ruling and opposition parties sometimes disclose "behind the scenes" deals and activities of politicians and celebrities, and he added that they should have strong evidence to support their claims.
Ma added that he will notify to KMT legislators to follow such guidelines whenever they have "a scoop."

Ma made the statement at a news conference at the Taipei city government in response to recent "behind the scenes" issues disclosed by Chiu Yi, a KMT legislator. Chiu recently claimed that Ma Yung-cheng, an aide to the president, had received NT$2 million (US$62,560) to pay for his marriage.

In related news, Yeh Yi-jin, a Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislative caucus whip, told a news conference at the Legislative Yuan that legislators and the media must not propagate unsubstantiated information about others and must not judge them based on scanty evidence.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP NAMES NEW DEPARTMENT OF INTERNATIONAL AFFAIRS HEAD

TEXT.P: Overseas Legislator Winston Dang will serve as the new director of the Department of International Affairs of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), party officials announced Tuesday.
Dang will take over the post left by Legislator Hsiao Bi-khim, who quit in response to DPP Chairman Yu Shyi-kun's call for neutrality in party affairs.

Dang, who holds a Master's degree from the Harvard School of Public Health and a Ph.D. in biochemistry from the City University of New York, has served in the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency and the U.S. Food and Drug Administration, as well as secretary-general of the World Federation of Taiwanese Associations.

DOC.HEADLINE: SYMPOSIUM ON ECONOMIC ASSESSMENT OF PUBLIC PROJECTS KICKS OFF

TEXT.P: A symposium on financial planning and assessing the economic benefits of public construction projects kicked off Tuesday, an event sponsored by the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) that was attended by more than 300 representatives of central and local governments, and governmental contract companies.

In the opening remarks of the three-day symposium, CEPD Minister Hu Sheng-cheng said that Taiwan needs more talent and experts in a wide range of fields in order to boost its industrial and economic development, adding that one of the best ways to train and keep people on the island is to build an environment with a high-grade infrastructure and quality services.

To have a high-quality living environment, the government needs to engage in a proper methodology for financing public construction projects, Hu said, noting that a budget arrangement taking economic impact assessment into account is crucial when upgrading the public living space.

With the symposium, the CEPD hopes those in charge of public construction projects will know how to better assess economic benefits and carry out financial planning for public construction projects, Hu added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER BACKS 'STANDARDIZED' MODEL FOR TAIWAN-CHINA CHARTER FLIGHTS

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang expressed his support Tuesday for a "standardized" model for direct charter flights across the Taiwan Strait, saying that the government has been talking with China on the issue.

Su made the remarks while answering questions from opposition People First Party lawmaker Feng Ting-kuo, who urged the government to work out a set of standardized mechanisms to operate direct charter flight services between Taiwan and China in the future, including on weekends and holidays.

Giving his assurances that the government has been working with the Chinese side toward that end, Su said a decision will be made pending bilateral negotiations and that the government will do its best to handle relevant issues.

The premier also promised that the government will not impose unnecessary limits on arriving Chinese tourists, adding that the government stands firm and clear on fully opening up to Chinese tourists.

Tainan Mayor Hsu Tain-tsair, who is a DPP member, said later the same day that setting up direct air and shipping links between Taiwan and China is an inevitable trend fueled by strong market demand, and he added that it should benefit the Taiwan economy over the long term as it will help reduce production costs for Taiwan companies.

But Hsu voiced concern over the impact of such flights on Taiwan's national security in the near term and called on the government to hammer out complementary measures before opening direct transport links across the strait. "The economy should not be compromised by politics or vice versa," he said.

Although Beijing has made many overtures to Taiwan following an economic forum in Beijing between the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and the Communist Party of China (CPC) April 14-15, Hsu warned that they are politically motivated cover-ups designed to hoodwink the Taiwan people.

History will prove that the April 16 meeting between KMT honorary Chairman Lien Chan and Chinese President Hu Jintao in Beijing was only a show in Hu's interest, he claimed, reiterating that Taiwan must prepare itself before establishing direct transport links with China.

DOC.HEADLINE: AD HOC GROUP FORMED TO PREVENT MANIPULATION OF COMMODITY PRICES

TEXT.P: An ad hoc group was formed Tuesday by the Cabinet-level Fair Trade Commission (FTC) to prevent manipulation of commodity prices, according to an FTC official.

According to the official, prices of several commodities in the domestic market moved up recently, in anticipation of rises in fuel prices expected to be announced soon by the state-owned Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC).

The official said the ad hoc group will keep a close eye on the prices of several commodities in the initial stage, such as oil, sugar, wheat, soybeans, electricity, gas, transport fees, agricultural and livestock products, to see if there is anyone involved in the monopolization or manipulation of the prices.
The FTC will offer information related to commodities and the market situation to the media in order to clear up any doubts among the public concerning commodity prices, the official added.

Noting that the FTC respects the price fluctuations in a free market mechanism, the official stressed, however, that anyone involved in manipulation of commodity prices will face fines of between NT$50,000 (US$1,543) and NT$25 million, as stipulated by the Fair Trade Law.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWMAKERS CLOSE TO FORMER PREMIER LEAVE FOR UNITED STATES

TEXT.P: Several ruling Democratic Progressive Party legislators close to former Premier Frank Hsieh left for the United States Tuesday.
The legislators, including Hsu Kuo-yung, Hsieh Hsin-ni and Lee Chun-yi, said they will attend a speech Hsieh is to deliver at Harvard University Wednesday.
They said that Hsieh, currently on a short-term study program at a school affiliated to the prestigious university, is concerned about the nation's future and will give his views in his speech.
Hsu said they will also convey to Hsieh the latest political situation and developments in Taiwan.
He denied that they will try to persuade Hsieh to run in the year-end Taipei mayoral election, describing that as nothing more than media speculation.

Amid strong calls within the party to draft Hsieh for the Taipei mayoral post, Hsu said he will convey the party's view to Hsieh but that Hsieh had no intention to run for the post before he went to the U.S. about two months ago.
Legislator Hsieh Hsin-ni said Hsieh advocated reconciliation and symbiosis when he served as premier, but she said that various factions within the DPP have been unable to reconcile.

Faced with the crucial battles in the year-end Taipei and Kaohsiung mayoral elections, the legislative elections in 2007 and the presidential election in 2008, she said that reconciliation within the party is crucial.
She said that whether Hsieh will run in the year-end mayoral election will depend on the party mechanism. The delegation is expected to return to Taiwan April 22, while Hsieh will return April 29.

Meanwhile, Premier Su Tseng-chang said Hsieh has a "brilliant" political record and qualifications, but whether he will run for the top post of the capital city will depend on his wishes and the nomination mechanism of the party.
It is just media speculation that drafting Hsieh to run would remove a hurdle for Su should he decide to run in the presidential election in 2008, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: BANKS SHOULD NOT LEND TO THSRC WITHOUT COLLATERAL: LAWMAKER

TEXT.P: A ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) lawmaker urged the government Tuesday to see to it that Taiwan's banks make no more loans to the Taiwan High Speed Rail Corp. (THSRC) if its five private investors do not put their own assets up as security for the loans.

Chang Hua-kuan told Premier Su Tseng-chang at the legislature that her voters in Chiayi County are not optimistic about the high speed rail service being launched at the end of October, as Transport Minister Kuo Yao-chi has guaranteed, vowing to step down if the launch does not go ahead on schedule.
THSRC has lied to the people by failing to fulfill its promise to launch the service last October, it has been arrogant to the government, but very luxurious to itself, Chang claimed.

The THSRC is asking the government to help secure yet another loan, this time of NT$65.5 billion, to make up for its financial shortfall, and banks should not loan the money if its own five initial investing conglomerates do not offer their own assets as collateral, Chang said.

In March, Su promised lawmakers that the government will not act as a guarantor in THSRC's bid to secure that loan. In the event that THSRC cannot launch services on schedule because it failed to get the loan, the government has prepared "a set of measures" to handle it, Su added.
Chang accused the THSRC of violating the principle of build, operate, transfer (BOT) and of trying to "sap Taiwan's financial strength" without giving it anything in return.

She expressed concern that if the high speed rail service cannot be launched at the end of October, the DPP will be devastated and there will simply be no chance for it to compete with other parties in the year-end mayoral elections of Taipei and Kaohsiung.

THSRC's five "original investors" are Continental Engineering Corp., Pacific Electric Wire and Cable Co., Evergreen Group, TECO Group and Fubon Financial, who together own 28 percent of THSRC's shares.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOMINICAN REPUBLIC OFFICIAL: RELATIONS WITH TAIWAN STABLE

TEXT.P: Diplomatic relations between Dominican Republic and Taiwan remain stable, although the Caribbean country does intend to boost its economic ties with China, a Dominican Republic official said Tuesday in Taipei.

"President Leonel Fernandez said that the relationship between Taiwan and Dominican Republic is beyond the diplomatic level. It's up to an ethical level, " said Jose Luis Corripio Estrada, an economic adviser to Fernandez and the president of Grupo Corripio, one of the biggest corporations in Dominican Republic.

The Associated Press reported two weeks ago that Dominican Republic Foreign Minister Carlos Morales Troncoso said in a TV interview April 6 that his country would consider establishing official diplomatic relations with China if it serves the country's interests.

A Spanish proverb says that when one faces a crossroads, taking both routes the best way, Corripio said, adding however that "the proverb is not suitable for describing the relations between Dominican Republic, Taiwan and China."
Dominican Republic is determined to maintain official relations with Taiwan and this can easily be seen, he said.

"First of all, President Fernandez is visiting Taiwan in June and will meet high-ranking officials here. He would not come such a long way to cut the ties between two countries. Also, Dominican Republic and Taiwan are about to launch a massive cooperation plan that has been worked on for many years. Why would we give it up for the sake of establishing relations with China? " he asked.

Speaking on China, Corripio said his country has been trading with China for decades, including the years during which the U.S. imposed an embargo on China. With China's rapid economic development, it's only natural for Dominican Republic to increase trade with China.

Dominican Republic is looking to maintain relations with Taiwan, Corripio said. But "a good relationship takes more than government administration. It takes more cooperation from the private sector to form a more solid bond between us, " he added as an encouragement for more Taiwanese businessmen to invest in Dominican Republic through joint ventures.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW FOREIGN COUPLE HAPPY ABOUT LONGSTAY IN PULI, CENTRAL TAIWAN

TEXT.P: A foreign couple who have visited for three days to get a feel about the longstay program offered by Puli township in Nantou County, said Tuesday they are very satisfied with life in the central Taiwan town.

The Japanese-American couple, who happen to have the same family name -- Nagamura -- as another Japanese couple who left Puli in disgust, said their first impression of Puli is "very good." They went as far as praising the town for having "the best living environment and quality of life in the world."

Mrs. Nagamura's is Taiwanese. The couple moved back to Taiwan to experience the longstay program after learning about the earlier Japanese couple's bad experience of dog feces on the streets and chaotic traffic, among a host of other complaints.
Mrs. Nagamura said her husband likes Puli very much and that they both feel prices for daily necessities and services are quite low.
"We intend to stay just 10 days this time. When more Japanese come and stay, we will consider joining them," she said.
She said it was "rude" for the former Nagamuras to spread a message on the Internet warning people not to come to Taiwan.
"Like Puli or not, it's a personal decision. They should not have warned other Japanese not to come," she said.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPPOSITION'S PRIORITY: APPROVE RIGHT PERSON AS TOP PROSECUTOR

TEXT.P: The opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) regards the selection of a qualified person to fill the nation's top prosecutorial post as an issue that should take precedence over all other issues, Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng said Tuesday.

Wang told reporters that when he meets with KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou and PFP Chairman James Soong later this week -- probably on April 20 -- their discussions will center on potential hopefuls President Chen Shui-bian might nominate for the post of state public prosecutor-general.

The top prosecutorial post has been left vacant after former State Public Prosecutor-General Wu Ying-chao resigned Dec. 27 last year to take responsibility for failing to stamp out bribery during the Dec. 3 local government elections.

Wang acknowledged that the KMT and the PFP believe that filling the post with the right person is more important than other issues, such as completing legislation for the military procurement plan and approving the president's list of nominees as members of the Control Yuan -- the nation's highest watchdog body.
A week ago, the opposition-controlled legislature rejected the president's nomination of Hsieh Wen-ting, prosecutor-general of the Taiwan High Court, to be the next state public prosecutor-general.
According to a newly enacted law, the president must submit the name of another nominee to the legislature for approval within a month, or before May 11.

If approved, the new state public prosecutor-general will serve a single four-year term only -- a measure designed to rid the prosecutorial system of political interference from the executive branch of the government.

DOC.HEADLINE: CUSTOMS DUTIES FOR GASOLINE LOWERED TO 5 PERCENT

TEXT.P: The Cabinet announced Tuesday that effective immediately, customs duties for imported gasoline will be lowered from 10 percent to 5 percent.

The Ministry of Finance indicated that the new measure will not affect the government's tax revenue to any large measure. Official statistics show that tax revenues from gasoline tariffs totaled only NT$370,000 last year, with the total imports worth NT$3.71 million.

Finance officials estimate that a 5 percent reduction in gasoline tariffs will only cut the revenue by less than NT$200,000. They said it is likely that the revenue might even rise as a result of increased gasoline imports under the new tariff.

The Council for Economic Planning and Development said the gasoline tariff has been lowered in an attempt to stabilize prices and encourage the private sector to import more gasoline so that the market will see more competitive prices.
At present, Taiwan's gasoline comes mainly from the refineries of the state-owned Chinese Petroleum Corp.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT'S FORUM WITH CHINA CREATES `ILLUSION' OF PEACE: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: A just-concluded forum between the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and the Communist Party of China has created an illusion of peace that has misled some into thinking the country's proposed purchase of arms from the United States is unnecessary, President Chen Shui-bian claimed Tuesday.

In an interview published by Paris-based daily Le Figaro, the president warned that the forum, which was held in Beijing April 14-15, as well as meetings between Chinese President Hu Jintao meetings with KMT Honorary Chairman Lien Chan and People First Party Chairman James Soong last year left a false impression that peace is already prevailing across the Taiwan Strait that makes any effort to strengthen Taiwan's defense capability unnecessary.

Citing reports of Japan and the United States, the president said that the military balance across the strait is tilting in China's favor, and as Taiwan's supreme commander of the armed forces, it is the president's responsibility to deter war by arming the country to match China's military buildup.

He defended his decision to end the function of a council set up to promote unification of Taiwan and China and the guidelines for the council, dismissing concerns that U.S. President George Bush might have him on the carpet for this during Bush's upcoming meeting with Chinese President Hu Jintao in Washington.
According to Chen, the U.S. fully understands that his decision did not constitute a breach of his commitment to preserve the status quo across the strait.

The president also stressed that the country's Constitution has been remodeled to reflect its political reality through the many amendments passed since 1991, when former President Lee Teng-hui began to adapt it to the nation. The "one China" principle is no longer enshrined in the Constitution, Chen added.

However, he reiterated his promise to craft a brand new constitution in his remaining two years in office, adding that the new constitution will also not change the status quo in terms of Taiwan's relationship with China.

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Wednesday, April 19:

13:30, The Central Standing Committee of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party will hold its weekly meeting at the party's Taipei headquarters.
14:00, The Central Standing Committee of the opposition Kuomintang will hold its weekly meeting at the party's Taipei headquarters.
14:00, Academia Sinica will present research achievements at a news conference at its Nankang complex.

DOC.HEADLINE: HIKE IN OIL PRICES ANNOUNCED

TEXT.P: An hike in oil prices was announced Tuesday night by Chinese Petroleum Corporation (CPC) , the country's largest fuel supplier.

Beginning from Wednesday, the company said, the prices for its gasoline and diesel oil will be raised by 9.2 percent, or NT$2 (US$0.061) per liter, the price for its heating oil will be raised by NT$740 per kiloliter, while the price for liquefied natural gas will be increased by NT$1.41 per kilogram.

After the hike, the prices for the premium gasoline will vary from NT$24.317 to NT$26.317 per liter according to their octane ratings, while the price for diesel oil will stand at NT$22.1227 per liter.
The CPC said the prices were hiked to reflect the rising prices of imported crude oil.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, April 19, or the 22nd day of the third month of the Year of Dog according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1832: Jose Echegaray y Eizaguirre, Spanish dramatist, mathematician, statesman and Nobel laureate, is born.
1853: Russia claims to be the protectorate of Turkey in a prelude to the Crimean War.
1882: British naturalist Charles Darwin dies at the age of 73. He revolutionized the study of biology with his theory of evolution based on natural selection. His most famous works include "Origin of Species" and "The Descent of Man."
1906: French chemist and physicist Pierre Curie is run over and killed in Paris at the age of 47. He and his wife Marie shared the 1903 Nobel Prize for fundamental research into radioactivity.
1928: Japanese troops occupy Shantung Province in northern China.
1942: Chinese Expeditionary Forces led by Gen. Sun Li-jen capture Yenangyuang in northern Burma, rescuing more than 7,000 British and Burmese troops from Japanese encirclement.
1948: The first National Assembly elects Chiang Kai-shek as the Republic of China's first president under the new ROC Constitution, garnering 2,430 out of 2,704 votes.
1956: Prince Rainier of Monaco marries American screen actress Grace Kelly in Monte Carlo. Over 1,200 guests attend the televised Catholic wedding ceremony.
1959: The Dalai Lama, the Tibetan leader fleeing a Communist Chinese invasion of his country, finds sanctuary in India.
1960: South Korean President Syngman Rhee is toppled in a nationwide pro-democracy student uprising that was protesting election fraud.
1966: Australian troops leave Sydney to join American forces in Vietnam.
1974: The Blood Donation Association of the Republic of China is inaugurated.
1975: India's first satellite is launched by a Soviet rocket.
1977: ROC Education Minister Tsiang Yien-si resigns to take responsibility for an incident in which 32 college students and teachers were killed when their boat capsized near Suao Port in eastern Taiwan. Tsiang was succeeded by Li Yuan-zu.
1992: Dutch Minister of Foreign Trade Yvonne van Rooy visits Taipei to seek stronger bilateral relations.
1993: A total of 87 Branch Davidian cult members, including their leader David Koresh, are killed when federal agents storm their compound in Waco, Texas, after a 51-day standoff. Nine other members are freed.
1995: A huge truck bomb destroys the Alfred P. Murrah government building in Oklahoma City, killing 168 people and injuring more than 400 others.
1995: Malawi President Bakili Muluzi pays a state visit to Taipei.
1997: The S.S. Sheng Da, a mainland China container freighter, steams into Kaohsiung Port on its maiden voyage, becoming the first ship to sail directly to Taiwan from the mainland in 48 years, and completing a historic crossing of one of the world's great political divides.
1999: Tsai Shun-fa, 52, known as "Bean Curd Papa," is honored by Premier Vincent Siew for donating blood 495 times over 20 years.
1999: The Republic of China-Swaziland Conference on Economical and Technological Cooperation opens in Taipei.
2000: Jeffrey Koo, chairman of the Taipei-based Chinese National Association of Industry & Commerce, says that if Beijing bullies Taiwanese doing business in mainland China, it will hurt both sides of the Taiwan Strait.
2000: President-elect Chen Shui-bian promises that his administration will help the Ministry of Justice Investigation Bureau transform itself into a "National Bureau of Investigation."
2001: Former ROC Premier Vincent Siew says that he will file an application with the government for a visit to mainland China to pitch for the formation of a "common market" across the Taiwan Strait.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Be not concerned that men do not know you; be concerned that you have no ability."

DOC.HEADLINE: BUSH WON'T SHY AWAY FROM RAISING QUESTION OF CHINESE MILITARY BUILDUP
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 18 (CNA) (By Jorge Liu and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: U.S. President George W. Bush will not shy away from raising the question of China's military buildup across the Taiwan Strait when he meets with Chinese President Hu Jintao April 20, a senior U.S. official said Monday.
The official made the remarks during a press briefing on Hu's visit to the U.S. April 18-22.

The Chinese military buildup is of concern to the United States, the official said, noting that Beijing claims that its desire is for peaceful settlement of the cross-strait dispute, but "there is no doubt that since 1995 there has been a large increase in military capabilities opposite Taiwan," the official said.
He noted that while Taiwan's military spending has been rather "flat" in recent years, Beijing has continued to increase its defense spending at double-digit rates.
"So this is an issue that we have to raise with the Chinese president, that he needs to know it is of concern to us, " the official said.
Beijing has often urged Washington to end its military assistance to Taiwan, but "there is no possible way we can end our military assistance to Taiwan under these circumstances," the official said.
"We have the Taiwan Relations Act. We will help Taiwan defend itself. This is part of our policy, and we enunciate that to the Chinese," he said.
The official stressed that the U.S. is not sure whether it will obtain any breakthroughs during Hu's visit, "but we don't shy away from the issue."

The U.S. is not going to shy away from "either talking about it or writing about it, as you have seen in the Department of Defense military power report. And there will be a new military power report coming out this year," he said.
