DOC.HEADLINE: 50% OF FRESH GRADUATES THINKING ABOUT SWITCHING PROFESSIONS: POLL

TEXT.P: Around 50 percent of fresh graduates in Taiwan think jobs are harder to find than expected this year, and a similar percentage of the graduates are considering joining professions that are different from their fields of training, according to the results of a recent survey.
The survey was conducted by the Career magazine April 7-12 on 2,371 students who are set to graduate this summer.
While 60 percent of senior high school graduates think that jobs are harder to find than expected, 40 percent of master's graduates share this view.

Fifty percent of the respondents expect their starting salaries to range between NT$24,000 and NT$30,000, with those having a master's degree expecting NT$36,000 on average, those having a bachelor's degree expecting no more than NT$30,000, and those having a technical college diploma expecting no more than NT$28,000.
The magazine said that the starting salaries expected by the fresh graduates are NT$2,000 to NT$4,000 higher than market levels.

Forty-seven percent of the fresh graduates said they are thinking about entering professions that are different from their field of training, with master's graduates registering the lowest ratio at 34 percent.

The survey shows that graduates from the fields of agriculture, tourism and leisure as well as education have the strongest desire to switch professions, while graduates from the fields of art and design, mass communications, and science and technology have the least desire to do so.

Meanwhile, if their job search is unsuccessful, 40 percent of the respondents said they will further their studies in Taiwan, and approximately 20 percent of the respondents said they will further their studies abroad.
The survey indicates that graduates of private schools and technical colleges have the strongest motivation to advance their education or acquire a second expertise.
By discipline, graduates from the field of education have the highest motivation to further their studies, and those from the field of tourism and leisure have the least motivation to do so.
While graduates from arts and communications schools prefer furthering their studies abroad, those from science and technology schools prefer doing so in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN FLEXIBLE ON OPENING DOOR WIDER TO CHINESE TOURISTS: MAC HEAD

TEXT.P: The government's policy of allowing no more than 1,000 mainland Chinese citizens a day to make sightseeing trips to Taiwan remains unchanged, although this policy is flexible and the government does not exclude the possibility of allowing a greater number of Chinese tourists in the future, the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) chairman said Wednesday.

Speaking in a meeting at the legislative caucus of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) , Joseph Wu said that as long as Beijing engages in talks with the Taiwan authorities to reach consensus on the issue, Taiwan will not oppose a full opening to Chinese tourists.
Wu claimed that the MAC published a policy of allowing mainland Chinese citizens to make tourism trips to Taiwan conditionally in 2001.

Actually, Taiwan has allowed mainland citizens studying abroad and those who have obtained permanent resident status overseas to come to Taiwan since 2002, and it further eased restrictions later that year to allow mainland Chinese living overseas -- including in Hong Kong and Macau -- for more than four years and who have work permits, to visit Taiwan, along with their spouses and immediate relatives under a principle of "groups in, groups out."
The regulations were later further relaxed to allow mainland citizens to make group tours to the island after visiting third countries.

To prevent mainland Chinese tourists from absconding en masse after entering Taiwan -- as happened on several occasions in 2005 -- the government has imposed a number of restrictions on this special group of visitors, including the requirement that they report to the local police each night of their stay.
Wu said this "daily report" requirement has already been relaxed to prevent Taiwan from being considered "a country where martial law is still imposed."

Beijing issued "15 incentives" to Taiwan at the conclusion of an economic forum in Beijing between the KMT and the Communist Party of China April 14-15. One of the "incentives" was a promise to allow Chinese citizens to make sightseeing trips to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Straits Times: NKF saga: Durai, four others charged.
The voices that filled Court 26 died down as charges were read out to the former chief of the National Kidney Foundation (NKF).
Standing in the dock, T.T. Durai, 57, was told he was being accused of intending to deceive the NKF when he approved payments to two companies for services that were apparently not rendered.
The Lianhe Zaobao: NKF scandal: 5 persons be accused.
The former chief executive of the National Kidney Foundation (NKF) , T.T. Durai, has been charged with intent to mislead and deceive the organisation.
Three former board members of the old NKF were also charged, along with a former assistant manager of the NKF's purchasing department.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Moscow Times: Rosneft's Terms Stun Small Investors
Rosneft stunned the market by announcing a plan Tuesday to consolidate shares in its subsidiaries on terms that some minority shareholders called below market value -- even as the company seeks to drum up investor support for an IPO this year. ( By Chang Hung-kuang)

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Manila Bulletin: GMA sets review of death cases
President Arroyo will implement a "case-to-case" review of the sentences of 1,205 convicts on Death Row pending commutation to life imprisonment, Malacanang said yesterday as it assured that there will be no execution until her term expires in 2010.
The Philippine Daily Inquirer: RP braces for shock as oil hits $71 per barrel
THE GOVERNMENT is looking at measures like improving the public's access to ethanol and coco-diesel and expanding the number of gas stations offering a P1-discount on diesel fuel to public utility vehicles to cushion the impact of escalating world oil prices on Filipino consumers.
The Philippine Star: GMA to certify measure abolishing death penalty
President Arroyo is willing to put her position on the line by certifying as urgent a consolidated version of several bills seeking to abolish the death penalty, Malacanang said yesterday.
The Manila Times: Charges reduced for 3 GIs in rape
The rape charges against three US Marines will be downgraded from being perpetrators to accessories, Justice Secretary Raul M. Gonzalez said Tuesday. But he affirmed that rape charges would be filed against the main suspect, Daniel Smith.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Japan Times: Death to cost MMC just 5.5 million yen
The Yokohama District Court on Tuesday rejected demands that Mitsubishi Motors Corp. and the government pay 100 million yen in punitive damages for MMC's failure to fix a known truck defect that caused a woman's death, and only ordered the firm to pay 5.5 million yen for the loss of life.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Los Angeles Times: Oil Rolls Past $70 a Barrel.
Oil prices jumped to a new high above $70 a barrel Monday and ignited fresh fears at the gas pump, where drivers seem to be paying more every day.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO INSTRUCTION GIVEN FOR TAIWAN MEDIA TO COVER BUSH-HU MEETING: MOFA

TEXT.P: Vice Foreign Affairs Minister Michael Ying-mau Kao has not instructed media outlets stationed in Washington, D.C. to cover the meeting between U.S. President George W. Bush and Chinese President Hu Jintao Thursday, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) spokesman clarified Wednesday.

Michel Lu was responding to a local news report that said Kao instructed the nation's representative office in the U.S. to ask Taiwan media outlets in the U.S. capital to do everything possible to enter the venue of the Bush-Hu meeting, the Oval Office of the White House, to pose questions and "defend Taiwan's rights."
"Kao has not issued any such instructions," Lu said.
The ministry respects freedom of the press and has smooth communications with the media, Lu added.

According to the news report, it will be almost impossible for Taiwan news media to enter the venue of the Bush-Hu meeting, as both sides will each only designate five to six members of the media to enter for a question and answer session after the meeting due to the limited space.

The report said that the ministry came up with the idea because of concerns about a repetition of the public rebuke of President Chen Shui-bian by President Bush when he received Chinese Premier Wen Jiabao in late 2003 to convey his sense of displeasure over Chen's insistence on holding a national referendum.
President Chen's announcement of ceasing the function of the National Unification Council in late February raised U.S. concerns once again.

DOC.HEADLINE: ST. VINCENT CONSTITUTIONAL REFORM CAN BE USED AS REFERENCE: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: The bottom-up approach of constitutional reform adopted by St. Vincent and the Grenadines can be used by Taiwan as a reference, President Chen Shui-bian said Wednesday.

Chen pointed out that the Caribbean nation's constitutional reforms were initiated by a constitutional advisory committee in Parliament, which then presented a conclusion report to Parliament as the basis of constitutional amendments.
He made the remarks while receiving Louis Straker, deputy prime minister and minister of foreign affairs, commerce and trade of St. Vincent and the Grenadines, who is on a visit in Taiwan.

Chen recalled that during his visit to St. Vincent and the Grenadines in September last year, he said that he could emigrate to St. Vincent and the Grenadines to run for president after he steps down in Taiwan in 2008.
He said that everybody knew that it was a joke, since there is no president in St. Vincent and the Grenadines, which follows a parliamentary system.

Chen said it was his greatest pleasure to be able to give a speech in the Parliament of St. Vincent and the Grenadines, which gave him the opportunity to better understand the Caribbean nation's achievements on constitutional reform.
Furthermore, Chen said he was impressed by the fact that opposition leaders were also allowed to give their welcoming remarks in Parliament.

DOC.HEADLINE: TUNGHAI UNIVERSITY PRESENTS 'SMART FARM'

TEXT.P: Imagine the fun of keeping a flock of chickens without actually getting your hands dirty feeding them. A research team at Tunghai University in Taichung presented Monday at the Taipei International Digital Electronics Show their new creation, the "Smart Farm," which allows people to raise their own flocks via the Internet, cell phone or PDA.

Dr. Chu Yen-ping, a professor in the Department of Computer Science and Information Engineering at Tunghai, said the project combines the idea of "virtual farm" and "actual farm." In the virtual farm, the customer can choose the chicken they want to raise and then monitor the growth of their "pet chicken" through computer or mobile phone, while staff at the actual farm take care of the chickens.

"The best thing about this project is that the customers don't need to really have a farm in order to enjoy the fun of raising a chicken," a department staff member said. "If they want to feed their pets, they can do so remotely, with staff responding to the order to feed the chicken."

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT TOURISM A 'NATION TO NATION' MATTER: PRIVATE GROUPS

TEXT.P: Tourism exchanges across the Taiwan Strait are a "nation to nation" matter, and visiting Chinese tourists should present their PRC passports for ROC visa stamps upon their entrance into Taiwan, a group of civic organizations said Wednesday.

The seven pro-independence groups, including the Taiwan Society South, issued a joint statement to call for the government to be on the watch for the expected flood of Chinese tourists into Taiwan after Beijing unveiled a set of management rules last week in preparation for mainland citizens to make sightseeing trips to Taiwan.

The mainland Chinese tourists should present their PRC passports, rather than simply travel documents, when entering Taiwan, for immigration authorities to stamp with official ROC visas, the statement said.

To date, according to the statement, special groups of Chinese citizens -- including Chinese officials visiting Taiwan via third countries, mainland citizens studying abroad, and those who have obtained permanent resident status overseas -- have been allowed to visit Taiwan for tourism but have all used travel documents issued by Taiwan without the printing of ROC stamps on their documents upon entrance.

Noting that illegal Chinese immigrants -- many of whom absconded en masse while traveling in tour groups -- have been a headache internationally, the statement said Taiwan's situation can only be worse. Since Chinese spies, or "Fifth Column" members, could sneak into Taiwan under the guise of being tourists, all Chinese citizens should be required to have their fingerprints taken upon entering the country for the sake of safeguarding Taiwan's national security.

In addition, the statement called for tighter complementary policies in terms of welcoming Chinese tourists to Taiwan, saying that Taiwan cannot be too careful, particularly with the bird flu threat in China.

Beijing issued "15 incentives" to Taiwan at the conclusion of an economic forum in Beijing between the main opposition Kuomintang and the Communist Party of China April 14-15. One of the "incentives" was apromise to allow Chinese citizens to make sightseeing trips to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHILE'S LEGISLATURE SUPPORTS TAIWAN'S WHA BID

TEXT.P: Chile's legislature passed a resolution Tuesday in support of Taiwan's bid to join as an observer the World Health Assembly (WHA), the decision-making arm of the World Health Organization (WHO).
Enrique Accorsi of the Party for Democracy and Pablo Galilea of the National Renewal Party spoke out in support of Taiwan's WHA bid during a session of the lower house of the Chilean legislature.
Antonio Leal, president of the Chilean Chamber of Deputies, put the resolution to a vote, without any member speaking against it.

The resolution, initiated by 10 lawmakers from the Independent Democratic Union and passed by a vote of 61-9, demands that the Chilean president support and push for Taiwan's participation in the WHA as an observer.

Sun Ta-chen, representative of the Republic of China Economic and Cultural Office in Santiago, extended his gratitude on behalf of the ROC government and its people to the Chamber of Deputies for supporting and passing several resolutions during the past few years in favor of Taiwan's participation in the WHA.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Wednesday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index futures for April gained 59 points to close at 7,042, with 22,187 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for May rose 71 points to finish at 7,053, with 38,740 contract transactions, while June futures moved up 68 points to close at 7,036, with 72 contracts traded.
September futures gained 66 points to finish at 6,844, with 87 contracts traded, while December futures moved up 63 points to close at 6,840, with 59 contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Wednesday at 6,983 for April, 6,982 for May, 6,968 for June, 6,778 for September, and 6,777 for December.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mixed.
April TE futures gained 4.40 points to close at 313.45, with 5,435 contract transactions, while May TE futures moved up 3.25 points to finish at 311.85, with 7,588 contracts traded.
June TE futures gained 6.05 points to close at 313, with one contract traded, while September TE futures rose 5.60 points to finish at 307.55, with three contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for December.
April TF futures moved down 0.4 points to close at 926, with 1,852 contract transactions, while May TF gained three points to finish at 932, with 2,936 contracts traded.
June TF futures rose seven points to close at 928, with only four contracts traded, while September TF futures dropped four points to finish at 914.8, with 19 contracts traded.
December TF futures moved up 4.2 points to finish at 910, with one contract traded.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Real estate tycoon arrested for market rigging.
Italy's real estate tycoon Stefano Ricucci was arrested Tuesday for alleged market rigging and other irregular financial operations in his stake-building in RCS Mediagroup which owns Corriere della Sera, one of the country's most influential newspaper.

DOC.HEADLINE: MORE CHINESE TOURISTS USING 'MINI THREE LINKS'

TEXT.P: Chinese tourist arrivals via the "mini three links" totalled 5,263 in the first two months of this year, a 1.2-fold increase over the same period of last year, according to tallies released Wednesday by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS).

The tallies show that in January and February, a total of 547 ferry trips operated between the Taiwan-held outlying islands of Kinmen and Matsu and the Chinese cities of Xiamen and Fuzhou, a decrease of 70 trips compared with the year-earlier level.

However, passenger arrivals via the "mini three links" jumped 14.9 percent year-on-year to 52,000 during the period, with Taiwan passenger arrivals rising 8.9 percent to 6,670 and Chinese passenger arrivals increasing 121.8 percent to 5,263.
While Taiwan citizens made a total of 266,000 trips to China in January, Chinese citizens made a total of 14,000 trips to Taiwan in the same months.
Meanwhile, the DGBAS said the communication volume between Taiwan and China has been increasing since the government lifted its ban on cross-Taiwan Strait telecommunications links in June 1989.
A total of 620 million phone calls were made across the strait in 2005, up 19.1 percent from the year-earlier level.
Looking at the calls in terms of time spent talking, 2.16 billion minutes were used, up 11.8 percent year-on-year.

DOC.HEADLINE: COA TO ASSIST FARMERS' ASSOCIATION TO REGISTER FARM PRODUCE IN CHINA

TEXT.P: The Council of Agriculture (COA) will assist the Taiwan Farmers' Association to register Taiwan farm produce in China to protect the rights of Taiwan farmers, a COA official said Wednesday.

COA Vice Minister Lee Jen-chyuan made the remarks in a seminar on cross-strait agricultural exchanges and cooperation convened by the main opposition Kuomintang's (KMT's) legislative caucus. Officials from the Mainland Affairs Council and the Intellectual Property Office under the Ministry of Economic Affairs also attended the seminar.

KMT Legislators Chu Feng-chi and Wang Yi-ting noted that although China announced the opening of its market to Taiwan agricultural imports a year ago, the actual amount of Taiwan farm produce sold in China has been limited.
However, Chinese farm produce falsely marketed as Taiwan produce has been selling like hot cakes in China, they said, asking the government to help Taiwan farmers solve the problem.

Lee said that the government has created several designs for a "Taiwan fruit" logo and that it is now in the final stage of selecting a design, a process he said he expects to be completed within a month.
The COA will then assist the Taiwan Farmers' Association to register the logo in China in a bid to combat rampant counterfeiting of Taiwan farm produce labels, Lee said.
In addition, Lee said, 13 Taiwan trademarks with Taiwanese geographical names, such as "Alishan Mountain tea" and "Chihshan Rice," have been registered in China.
The COA has commissioned representatives to file suits in China in the hopes that a court victories will stop Taiwan's famous brands from being encroached upon again.

Tsai Lien-sheng, director general of the Intellectual Property Office, said that the best way to approach the issue is via consultations on IPO protection between the two governments so as to protect their respective famous brands and root out counterfeiting.

DOC.HEADLINE: ARTIFICIAL REPRODUCTION APPLIES ONLY TO MARRIED COUPLES: BILL

TEXT.P: Legislators reached a consensus Wednesday that artificial reproduction technology can be used only by married infertile couples.
This means that couples in homosexual and cohabitation relationships, single parents, single individuals and widows will all be prohibited from using the technology.
The consensus was established during a review of the Artificial Reproduction Bill in the Legislative Yuan's Health, Environment and Social Welfare Committee.

According to opposition Kuomintang Legislator Wu Yu-sheng, the government should not encourage what he claimed is "irresponsible behavior" such as single parenthood and having children without getting married. He further claimed that the restriction is aimed at "protecting the younger generation."

Also, in a move aimed at preventing incest and the commercial trading of reproductive cells, the legislators agreed that people can only donate their reproductive cells once during their lifetimes, Wu said.

Meanwhile, the age of the donors is restricted to 20-50 for men and 20-40 for women, because medical research has found that the egg fertility rate of women over 40 is six times lower than when they are 20, Wu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC CHIEF WILLING TO HELP WITH TAIWAN FARM EXPORTS TO CHINA

TEXT.P: Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Joseph Wu said Wednesday that he is willing to work with the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) and the Council of Agriculture (COA) to help push for more exports of Taiwan farm produce to China.

Wu made the remarks while attending a seminar held by the legislative caucus of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) on ways to boost cross-Taiwan Strait agricultural exchanges, in which officials from the MOEA, the COA and the Taiwan Provincial Farmers' Association also took part.

Representatives of the farmers' association voiced dissatisfaction with what they called the government's "technical boycotts" to stall the sale of Taiwan farm products to China, arguing that the semi-official Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) , appointed by the government to take charge of local farm exports to China, has failed to help protect local farmers' interests in China.

Pointing out that TAITRA is not an organization specializing in agriculture, association representatives complained that TAITRA, whose main task is to promote Taiwan's foreign trade, is not suitable for the farm sales mission and that TAITRA has turned down their offers of help several times.

They questioned the government's motivation in allowing TAITRA to play the role, saying that they suspect the government is using a technical boycott to disguise its unwillingness to help Taiwan farmers sell to China to resolve their overproduction problems.

Wu denied their charges and claimed that the government has never stood in the way to block Taiwan's farm exports o China, ascribing the limited progress on the issue to political gridlock at home between the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and the opposition "pan blue alliance."

The MAC head said that he is willing to help and coordinate with the MOEA and the COA regarding the issue and he hailed the expertise of the provincial farmers' association, promising to help push for more local farm exports to China in cooperation with the association.
Agricultural cooperation between Taiwan and China has always been a major issue high on the cross-strait economic agenda.

Beijing announced 15 measures that it claims are beneficial to Taiwan following an economic forum last week in Beijing between the main Kuomintang (KMT) and the Communist Party of China, with Beijing agreeing to open the Chinese market wider to Taiwan's agriculture and fruit and to dispatch procurement groups to buy farm produce in Taiwan. P.K. Chiang, a vice chairman o f the KMT, said Tuesday while taking part in an economic symposium on Taiwan's industrial upgrading in Dongguan that Beijing's announcement that it will allow Chinese tourists to sight-see in Taiwan and will push for two-way direct air and shipping links will be a great stimulus to Taiwan's flagging economy.

Setting up direct transport links across the strait is especially important to Taiwan, Chiang said, claiming that it would help Taiwan businessmen keep their operations at home while luring greater foreign investment to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENTIAL OFFICE HOPES FOR SECOND MEETING OF PRESIDENT, KMT HEAD

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian and the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) hope that opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou will meet President Chen again before long to facilitate the formation of consensus on issues concerning Taiwan's economy and the people's livelihoods, the top presidential aide said Wednesday.
Presidential Office Secretary-General Tan Sun Chen said he wrote to KMT Secretary-General Chan Chun-po last week about the new invitation, but had not heard from him.
The holding of a second Chen-Ma meeting has been the hope of Chen, the DPP hierarchy and the DPP legislative caucus since April 3, when Chen met Ma at the Presidential Office, said Tan Sun Chen.

Tan Sun Chen said, however, that the KMT has been cool in its reaction toward the notion of a second meeting, which he claimed would be conducive to boosting harmony between the ruling and opposition parties. Harmonious engagement is not only the mainstream opinion in Taiwan, but the first Chen-Ma meeting was also received favorably by the Bush administration in the United States, he said.

During the first, unprecedented Chen-Ma meeting, the two men talked about a wide range of topics, including the definition of the controversial "one China" policy and the cessation of the National Unification Council and its guidelines.
After the meeting, Chen's approval ratings soared by 11 percentage points, while Ma's dropped by nine percentage points, according to a local television poll.

DOC.HEADLINE: ALL TAIWAN FOREIGN AID MEASURES TO CARRY ROC (TAIWAN) MARK: PREMIER

TEXT.P: All Taiwan foreign aid measures, including goods and infrastructure projects, should carry a mark indicating that it comes from "the Republic of China (Taiwan) , " Premier Su Tseng-chang said Wednesday.

Su said it might seem "ideological, " but the "ROC (Taiwan) " mark carried on foreign aid measures taken or contributed by Taiwan to other countries is essential to avoid Taiwan's assistance efforts from being misunderstood or simply "erased."

Taking some cases in Africa as an example, Su said that when the African people offered their gratitude toward Taiwan for the country's aid or assistance, they used the term "China" instead of "the Republic of China," apparently unwittingly, according to Su.
In those cases, he claimed, Taiwan's efforts seemed to have "gone to waste" or Taiwan had been on a "fool's errand, " contributing "only to China's publicity."

Taiwan should build up its own image and reputation in the international community by clearly spelling out the country's name, which he said is "the Republic of China on Taiwan, " adding that Taiwan should let the world know that Taiwan is not China.

Su made the remarks at an Executive Yuan meeting during which Ministry of Foreign Affairs officials briefed the premier on Taiwan's cooperation with the Guatemalan government on the preservation of historical and cultural relics in the ancient city of Antigua.

DOC.HEADLINE: CAP ON CHINESE TOURIST NUMBERS TO BE RAISED GRADUALLY: PREMIER

TEXT.P: The government's policy of allowing Chinese citizens to visit Taiwan is not only a matter of tourist numbers or national security but also the overall benefit to Taiwan's economy, Premier Su Tseng-chang said Wednesday at a weekly Cabinet meeting.
Su also noted that some other factors should be considered, such as sufficient preparations, management measures and tourist numbers, adding that "we want to keep them coming over and over again."

Su made the remarks in response to media speculation that there will be no limits on the number of Chinese tourist arrivals in Taiwan. It would be impossible for Taiwan to accommodate even half a million Chinese tourists in the initial stages, the premier said.

"In order to maintain standards of hotel accommodation, we must know how well our hotels can manage the numbers and related ministries should make plans in advance, especially how many Chinese citizens can enter Taiwan per day," Su said.

Su said that the policy of allowing Chinese citizens to come to Taiwan for sightseeing should be carried out gradually with an open-minded attitude, adding that "we should regard tourists from China as part of our worldwide tourism policy."

Earlier in the day, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Joseph Wu said the government's policy of allowing no more than 1,000 Chinese citizens a day to make sightseeing trips to Taiwan remains unchanged, although he added that the policy is flexible and that the government does not exclude the possibility of allowing a greater number of Chinese tourists in the future.

Speaking in a meeting at the legislative caucus of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) , Wu said that as long as Beijing engages in talks with the Taiwan authorities to reach consensus on the issue, Taiwan will not oppose full opening to Chinese tourists.

Regarding Beijing's new "15 incentives" offered to Taiwan at the conclusion of an economic forum in Beijing between the KMT and the Communist Party of China (CPC) April 14-15 -- one of which is to allow more Chinese tourists to visit Taiwan -- Wu responded that implementation of those incentives should be negotiated under the existing rules. The incentives are merely KMT-CPC bipartisan conclusions that have no government authority, he pointed out.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Wednesday, losing NT$0.078 to close at NT$32.408.
A total of US$1.073 billion changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at the day's high of NT$32.486 and hit a low of NT$32.350.

DOC.HEADLINE: PROMOTION OF TAIWAN PARK IN EL SALVADOR KICKS OFF

TEXT.P: A presentation to promote investment in an industrial park in El Salvador was held at the Taipei International Convention Center Wednesday.

The presentation, sponsored by the Industrial Development and Investment Center under the Ministry of Economic Affairs, was the first of three presentations held in Taiwan to promote investment in the Taiwan Park in the Central American country. Two other presentations will be held in central and southern Taiwan.

Vice Economic Affairs Minister Chen Ruey-long said that trade and economic relations between Taiwan and El Salvador are close. Taiwan will start free trade agreement (FTA) negotiations with El Salvador later this year and if the two countries sign an FTA, El Salvador will become a crucial link in Taiwan's globalization.

El Salvador Ambassador to the Republic of China Francisco Ricardo Santana Berrios noted that the U.S.-Central America Free Trade Agreement (CAFTA) was put into effect in March, making the Taiwan Park the best springboard for Taiwan businessmen making inroads into the American market.
The agreement promotes trade liberalization between the United States and the Central American countries of Costa Rica, El Salvador, Guatemala, Honduras and Nicaragua.

Chen noted that after the U.S.-CAFTA is put into effect, agricultural and industrial products exported to the United States will enjoy tariff incentives, with textile products enjoying the highest tariff incentive of 32 percent.

The government will also help manufacturers invest in and set up plants in Central America through a "co-prosperity" project that was first broached by President Chen Shui-bian during his visit to ROC allies in Central America last year.

The Taiwan Park, a brainchild of Vice President Annette Lu, is being planned by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and the National Science Council, based on the model of the Southern Taiwan Science Park.

The Ministry of Economic Affairs has estimated that Taiwan businessmen are best suited to invest in textiles, garments, farm and stock, food and wood processing, vehicles, small home appliances and plastic processing products in the Taiwan Park.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOJ WARNS THE PUBLIC NOT TO SELL VOTES IN FORTHCOMING ELECTIONS

TEXT.P: Minister of Justice Shih Mao-lin urged the public Wednesday not to sell their votes in the forthcoming elections for village and borough chiefs as well as township councilors scheduled for June and urged people to tip off the police should politicians attempt to buy their votes.
Shih made the appeal at a press conference in which an anti-vote buying commercial commissioned by the Ministry of Justice (MOJ) was released.

Several high-ranking law enforcement officials were also present on the occasion, including Central Election Commission Chairman Chang Chen-hsiung, State Public Prosecutor-General Wu Ing-chao, and Investigation Bureau Director Yeh Sheng-mao.

Shih noted that vote-buying is most rampant in grass roots elections, so the MOJ has strengthened strategies to crack down on vote-buying by releasing commercials, imposing stiffer penalties on violators and increasing the rewards for those who report vote-buying.

Shih noted that the Public Officials Election and Recall Act has increased penalties for vote-buying, with violators facing between three and 10 years in prison and fines of between NT$1 million (US$30,864) and NT$10 million.
In addition, people who tip off the police to vote-buying will be offered a reward of NT$500,000.
The MOJ also urged more people to join a volunteer group for the campaign against vote-buying.

DOC.HEADLINE: SANDSTORM FROM MONGOLIA TO HIT TAIWAN THURSDAY

TEXT.P: Air quality around Taiwan will be generally poor Thursday as a sandstorm spawned in Mongolia hits Taiwan -- the third to hit the country this year -- the Department of Environmental Administration (EPA) said Wednesday.
EPA officials said that from Thursday morning, the air quality around the nation will be affected by the sandstorm, which blew up in Mongolia and Inner Mongolia Wednesday.
They advised the elderly, children and people with respiratory illness to be on guard, to refrain from going outdoors or engaging in intense outdoor activities.
They said the effects of the sandstorm will peak Thursday night and that central and southern Taiwan will be affected Friday.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI TO BE 90 PERCENT WIRED BY JULY: MAYOR

TEXT.P: Speaking at the opening ceremony of the 5th Internet Carnival of Cisco Systems at The World Trade Center (TWTC) Wednesday, Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou said Taipei's broadband framework will be around 90 percent installed by July.
The exhibition, including 30 symposiums, that started that day, presented the accomplishments of intellectual Internet information applied to the service industry.

Honoring recent developments in technology, Ma noted that his predecessor, President Chen Shui-bian, upgraded the city government's bureaucratic efficiency by allowing citizens to apply for ID procedures within 10 minutes, adding that the city's Easycard can now be integrated with student IDs.

Ma said Taipei has advantages such as the penetration rates of cellphones, cable systems and wireless Internet, and that the city's broadband framework will be finished sooner than "other cities." (Timothy J. Hwang)

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: China's Rising Need for Oil Is High on U.S. Agenda
The competition for access to oil is emerging high on the agenda for President Hu Jintao's visit to the White House this week. President Bush has called China's growing demand for oil one reason for rising prices, and has warned Beijing against trying to "lock up" global supplies. With crude oil selling for more than US$70 a barrel and American motorists paying US$3 a gallon for gasoline, American officials say the subject cannot be avoided at Thursday's meeting in the Oval Office, as it was sidestepped when Bush visited Beijing last fall. In 2004 China used some 6.5 million barrels of oil a day and overtook Japan as the world's second largest user of petroleum products. The largest, the United States, consumes about 20 million barrels a day.
Wall Street Journal: House Calls, Portland Hospital Gives Acutely Ill A Homecare Option
Several hundred patients in Portland have had life-saving treatment at home under an unusual program run by the U.S. Veterans Administration medical center in Portland. Other home-based programs in the U.S. tend to serve early-discharge patients who can be safely monitored at home. By contrast, the Portland program was designed specifically as a substitute for hospital treatment.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI SHARE PRICES END HIGHER

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened high and closed higher Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, surging 49.32 points to close at 7,038.78.
The bourse opened at 7,073.32 and fluctuated between 7,093.43 and 7,038.78 during trading. A total of 4.79 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$143.59 billion (US$4.43 billion).

Four of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with foodstuff issues growing the most at 2.3 percent, followed by machinery and electronics shares at 1.2 percent, cement issues at 0.3 percent and construction stocks at 0.1 percent.
Textile stocks dropped 0.8 percent, while paper and pulp issues slid 0.5 percent and banking and financial shares moved down 0.1 percent. Plastics and chemicals shares remained unchanged.
Gainers outnumbered losers 463 to 424, with 113 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: USED DVDS, CELLPHONES MUST BE RECYCLED FROM JULY 1

TEXT.P: People who discard used DVDs and cellphones without recycling them will be subject to fines of up to NT$6,000 (US$185) from July 1, the Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) said Wednesday.
EPA officials said that discarded DVDs or cellphones are recyclable and should no longer be thrown away with everyday refuse.
From now until July 1, there will be a public awareness campaign, after which the fines will be imposed, they said.
The officials estimated that there will be around 240 tons of recycled DVDs per year, and around 32 tons of recycled cellphones.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHIEF RULES OUT SECOND MEETING WITH PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou ruled out the possibility Wednesday that he would consider meeting President Chen Shui-bian for a second time, saying that he has no plans for such a meeting.

Ma made the remarks while attending a weekly meeting of the KMT's Central Standing Committee after local media reported earlier the same day that Presidential Secretary-General Tan Sun Chen had phoned KMT Secretary-General Chan Chuan-po to relay the president's hope for a second tete-a-tete with Ma to discuss economic issues related to the people's livelihoods.
The Executive Yuan should discuss matters of major national concern, such as cross-Taiwan Strait policies, with the Legislative Yuan instead of holding meetings with him, Ma pointed out.

Ma also praised the Executive Yuan's mild reaction following an economic forum held in Beijing last weekend between the KMT and the Communist Party of China, saying that the government has been prudent and decent in refraining from making acrimonious attacks on the KMT over the event.

The KMT chairman first met with Chen in public earlier this month shortly after returning from a visit to the United States, where he was accorded a high-profile reception. The two exchanged viewpoints mainly on cross-strait ties.

DOC.HEADLINE: SMOKERS SHOULD BE WARNED ABOUT FLUORESCENT AGENTS: FOUNDATION

TEXT.P: Smokers should be clearly warned that fluorescent agents in cigarettes can be harmful to health if their combustion is incomplete, an official of the Consumers' Foundation said Wednesday.
The Consumers' Foundation published a report about a survey on 15 kinds of cigarette. The report claims that all 15 brands contain fluorescent agents.

The official claimed that second-hand smoke often causes more damage to people's health than regular smoking as the sidestream smoke, which comes from the burning tip of the cigarette, contains even more toxic matter, including fluorescent agents, because its combustion is incomplete. Therefore, such information should be printed on the cigarette packaging, the official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO WAY CHINA A RESPONSIBLE STAKEHOLDER: CHINESE ACTIVISTS

TEXT.P: There is no way that China can play the role of a "responsible stakeholder" in the international community because of its autocratic nature and resistance to political reform, a group of Chinese democracy activists said in a seminar Wednesday.

"People expect China to become a democratic country and responsible stakeholder after its economical development. It's a fantasy," said Ruan Ming, an advisor to President Chen Shui-bian and a former Communist Party of China (CPC) spin doctor in the 1970s before fleeing China.

The activists were responding to a 2005 statement by U.S. Deputy Secretary of State Robert Zoellick in which he said: "As it becomes a major global player, we are now encouraging China to become a 'responsible stakeholder' that will work with the United States and others to sustain, adapt, and advance the peaceful international system that has enabled its success."
Chinese President Hu Jintao insisted on a policy that "opens up the economy but retains political suppression," Ruan said, adding that he calls it an "open slavery system."
"Regardless of what attention it gets or doesn't get, the CPC will not be a responsible party, and this has always been the case," said Paul Lin, a New York-based political commentator.

The world is seeking a "new definition -- economically or politically" of the current China, said Hu Ping, the chief editor of Beijing Spring since 1996. But he said the world should also look at "the dark side behind China's peaceful rising."

"Economists offer praise and are amazed at China's economic boom. However, if China does not develop comprehensive political reforms, we'll be seeing an evil superpower ten years from now," Hu warned.

"The CPC will not be responsible to anything because it's a totalitarian regime, which is not being supervised by elections or the media as it is in democratic countries. You just can't trust them," said U.S.-based political commentator Cao Changqing.
The seminar "Will the CPC be a responsible stakeholder?" was organized by the Taiwan Foundation for Democracy.

DOC.HEADLINE: AWARD CEREMONY HELD TO HONOR BLOOD DONORS

TEXT.P: The Taipei Blood Donation Center held a citation ceremony Wednesday to honor those who actively donated blood in 2005.

At the ceremony held at the Taipei City Government, Huang Ku-ing, a section chief of the Taipei Blood Donation Center, presented a citation to the No. 1 blood donor, Chang Kuo-sen, who has donated blood more than 1,000 times as of Feb. 1.

Organizations that have contributed the most were the 43 branches of Lions Clubs in Taiwan and Chinese Culture University, which has been the No. 1 blood donor in terms of universities for 12 consecutive years, according to Huang.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP CHAIRMAN URGES KMT HEAD TO 'RESTRAIN' LAWMAKERS

TEXT.P: Ruling Democratic Progressive Party Chairman Yu Shyi-kun Wednesday urged Ma Ying-jeou -- his counterpart in the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) -- to "restrain" the party's lawmakers from making accusations against other politicians without evidence.
Yu was referring in particular to several KMT legislators who recently hinted that President Chen Shui-bian and First Lady Wu Shu-jen might have received political donations from entrepreneurs.
KMT lawmakers also alleged that Ma Yung-cheng, a Presidential Office deputy secretary-general, received bribes from local businessmen as payment for his "manipulation" in some business deals.
Stressing that such unfounded statements will cause anxiety in society, Yu urged Ma to restrain KMT lawmakers from such behavior.

Ma has in fact made comments on the phenomenon, saying Tuesday that lawmakers should provide evidence when making accusations against other politicians; otherwise, he said, it will not only damage the lawmaker's reputation, but also that of the party.
Ma said he would forward the suggestion to the KMT's legislative caucus for party lawmakers to review.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT BEGINS CRACKDOWN ON HIRING OF ILLEGAL MIGRANT WORKERS

TEXT.P: Employers who illegally hire absconded migrant workers will receive a maximum fine of NT$750,000 starting April 20, the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) , the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) , and the National Police Agency (NPA) announced Wednesday in a joint press conference.

"Undocumented migrant workers have become a critical concern affecting the public order in Taiwan. If employers obey the law and refuse to hire migrant workers who absconded from their legal jobs, we believe the number of unaccounted-for foreign workers and illegal recruitment agencies will gradually decrease, " said CLA Minister Lee Ying-yuan.

First-time offenders will face a maximum fine of NT$750,000, while repeat offenders within a period of five years will receive a sentence of three years or less or a maximum fine of NT$1.2 million, Lee said.

Under the current circumstances, undocumented migrant workers are easily exploited by their employers, for instance by working overtime or without labor insurance, Lee noted. And it is a problem the CLA is very concerned about.

Undocumented migrants workers are encouraged to turn themselves in to the authorities. Those who wish to do so can use toll-free telephone numbers of 0800-885885 (English) , 0800-885995 (Thai) , 0800-885958 (Indonesian) and 0800-017858 (Vietnamese).
The CLA has vowed to streamline the process of returning illegals home to their countries of origin and re-issuing missed passports for migrant workers.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING'S OVERTURES POLITICALLY MOTIVATED: MAC

TEXT.P: Economic overtures made by Beijing to Taiwan following a forum held jointly by the Communist Party of China (CPC) and Taiwan's opposition Kuomintang (KMT) last week in Beijing were politically motivated moves aimed at crippling the government, China Affairs Council (MAC) Vice Minister Huang Wei-feng said Wednesday.
Huang made the remarks at a seminar sponsored by the Taiwan Foundation for Democracy.
Huang pointed out that the 15 measures Beijing released after the KMT-CPC forum are all small favors too highly charged with political considerations to be dealt with by Taiwan's authorities.

For instance, he said, Beijing's zero tariff treatment for Taiwan's top-notch fishery products is purely superficial as the value of Taiwan's exports to China of this kind accounts for only 0.07 percent of the country's total.

Another of the 15 "incentives" from the forum proposes that private groups from the two sides handle issues that normally require government authorities, and is just a way to paralyze the government, he added.

Huang also said he does not think Beijing has made bold moves toward a "real opening," and that the time has not yet come to push China's political elite to do so until they have met with aggressive pressure to give up their privileges.

Dong Lee-wen, former head of the China affairs department of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, forecast that Chinese President Hu Jintao will not talk about his April 16 meeting in Beijing with KMT Honorary Chairman Lien Chan now that the U.S. government has recently asked Beijing again to enter dialogue with the DPP government.

Dong opined that conclusions reached by Lien and Hu were actually directed at KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou in hopes of having the KMT incumbent toe Lien's pro-unification line regarding Taiwan's future ties with China.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWANESE FRETTING ABOUT POSSIBILITY OF BUSH'S UNFAVORABLE REMARKS

TEXT.P: The people of Taiwan are worrying about the possibility of U.S. President George W. Bush making statements unfavorable to Taiwan during his upcoming meeting with Chinese President Hu Jintao, a senior official said Wednesday.
Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Joseph Wu made the remarks while meeting with a group of exiled Chinese pro-democracy dissidents, including Cao Changqing, Lin Baohua and Hu Ping.
Hu is currently on a high-profile U.S. visit and is scheduled to meet with Bush at the White House Thursday. The Taiwan Strait issue is expected to be high on the agenda of the Bush-Hu huddle.

Noting that Taiwan has emerged as a liberal democracy, Wu lamented that democratization has not visibly aided Taiwan's quest for representation in major international organizations or in the creation of a higher international profile. On many occasions, he said, the international community tends to misinterpret Taiwan's political reforms as signs of a change being made to the cross-strait status quo while ignoring China's human rights violations.

Take the government's recent decision to cease the function of the National Unification Council and its guidelines. Wu said many countries expressed concern about such a decision on grounds that it might alter the cross-strait status quo.
"In fact, the decision conformed to the basic democratic principle of respecting the Taiwan people's will in determining the nation's future," Wu said.

Over the past few decades, Wu continued, Taiwan has been actively promoting wide-ranging exchanges with exiled Chinese dissidents through various channels as part of its efforts to push for China's democratic reform so the Chinese people can enjoy freedom and democracy like their cousins in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN URGES POPE TO PAY HEED TO CHINA'S HUMAN RIGHTS CONDITIONS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian urged Pope Benedict XVI Wednesday to continue showing concern about religious freedom and human rights conditions in China and to push Beijing to dismantle hundreds of missiles aimed at Taiwan.
Chen made the appeal while attending a reception at the Vatican Embassy in Taipei marking the anniversary of Benedict XVI's accession to the papacy.

In his speech, Chen also called on the international community to pay heed to China's military threat against Taiwan, which has evolved into a liberal democracy and is dedicated to promoting world peace.

Prodding China to respond to the Pope's appeal to uphold peace in the pursuit of truth, Chen said China should stop oppressing its people, renounce the use of non-peaceful means against Taiwan and remove missiles targeting Taiwan to prove that its rise is truly peaceful and will threaten neither Taiwan Strait stability nor world peace.
"China should take concrete steps to prove its rise is peaceful and will be accompanied by an awakening to democracy," Chen added.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA MINISTER RULES OUT WATER RATE HIKE

TEXT.P: Minister of Economic Affairs Hwang Ing-san ruled out Wednesday the possibility of raising water rate this year.

Hwang's remarks came amid concerns about possible domestic consumer prices fluctuation following a steep 9.2 percent hike in gasoline prices announced by state-owned Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC) a day earlier.
As the international crude oil prices have surged to historical highs, Hwang said another state-owned utility, Taiwan Power Co. (Taipower), is also reviewing its electricity pricing formula.

"It remains uncertain whether Taipower will raise its electricity rates before the implementation of its summer power rates in June, " Hwang said, adding that the Ministry of Economic Affairs will decide whether to adjust domestic electricity rates after Taipower presents a comprehensive report or adjustment scale.

Despite the CPC's latest decision to raise its gasoline and diesel prices by NT$2 per liter from Wednesday, Hwang said he believes that the nation will still be able to realize the goal of keeping the domestic inflation rate at bay.
"I think there should be no problems with the goal of keeping the annual growth rate of the consumer price index below 2 percent this year," Hwang added. (Timothy J. Hwang)

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, PHILIPPINES TO STRENGTHEN POLICE COOPERATION

TEXT.P: Police authorities from Taiwan and the Philippines have agreed to strengthen cooperation in crime fighting, including crackdown on drug and human trafficking, a spokesman for the National Police Agency (NPA) said Wednesday.
The agreement was reached at a meeting between senior and Taiwan and Philippine police officers held n Taipei Tuesday.

The conference was to exchange information on crime-fighting following a successful joint operation last year that raided an amphetamine factory in the Philippines' Davao City, where 76 kg of the drug were confiscated and six people arrested.

Noting that international drug traffickers have increasingly used the Philippines as a trading center in Southeast Asia, the spokesman said Taiwan will step up cooperation with the Philippines in crackdown on cross-border drug trafficking.

The conference was attended by Philippine National Police Director Gen. Arturo Lomibao and his Taiwan counterpart, NPA Director-General Hou Yu-ih. Lomibao is visiting Taipei at the head of a high-level police delegation. He is scheduled to return to Manila April 20.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CALLS FOR HIGH-LEVEL EXCHANGES WITH MONGOLIA

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Wednesday he is hopeful that Taiwan and Mongolia can engage in high-level exchanges, with ministerial-level officials from the two countries exchanging visits regularly.
Chen made the call while meeting with a group of Mongolian prosecutors and other judicial personnel who are receiving training in Taipei.
Under a successful cooperative program launched last year, Chen said provincial-level officials from Mongolia attended training classes in Taiwan.

"We hope similar cooperative programs will continue and further expand," Chen said, adding that he hopes top leaders and ministerial-level officials from the two countries can exchange frequent visits to further boost bilateral cooperation in various fields.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, April 20, or the 23rd day of the third month of the Year of the Dog according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1526: Baber, or Zahir ud-Din Mohammed, leads 2,000 Moguls to victory over 10,000 Muslims and 100 elephants under Ibrahim at the battle of Panipat. The conqueror of India later captured Delhi and Agra and founded the Mogul dynasty.
1657: Jews in New Amsterdam (now New York City) are granted equal rights and privileges as citizens.
1836: The U.S. Congress officially separates the western part of the Michigan Territory, creating a new zone known as the Wisconsin Territory.
1859: Holland concludes a treaty granting Portugal the right to govern the eastern part of Timor as well as Atauro Island and Oecussi.
1889: Adolf Hitler, house painter and subsequently German dictator who founded the National Socialist (Nazi) Party and was the architect of World War II, is born in Austria.
1908: Taiwan's West Coast Railway Trunk Line from Keelung to Kaohsiung, with a total length of 405 kilometers, is opened to traffic.
1916: The Taipei Yuanshan Zoo is inaugurated.
1933: President Franklin D. Roosevelt removes the United States from the gold standard.
1944: Britain's Royal Air Force drops a record 4,500 tons of bombs on Germany in a single raid.
1945: Soviet troops penetrate Berlin defenses.
1950: The Taiwan Garrison Command Headquarters is established, with Gen. Sun Li-jen serving at its first commander.
1957: Japan protests against nuclear testing by the Soviet Union.
1968: Pierre Elliot Trudeau of the Liberal Party becomes the 15th prime minister of Canada.
1970: President Richard M. Nixon announces the withdrawal of 150,000 U.S. military personnel from South Vietnam.
1974: The Republic of China announces the termination of Taiwan-Japan flights by China Airlines and Japan Airlines after Japan and mainland China sign an air pact in Beijing.
1978: Soviet warplanes force an off-course South Korean airliner down in the Soviet Union near the Arctic Circle, killing two passengers aboard and injuring 13 others.
1984: Britain announces that its administration of Hong Kong will cease in 1997 when the colony is returned to mainland China.
1986: A reservoir bursts and floods a Sri Lankan town, killing 100 people and making some 20,000 families homeless.
1990: Soviet troops storm Lithuania's state printing works after Mikhail Gorbachev cuts off 85 percent of gas supplies to the rebellious republic.
1996: World leaders meeting in Moscow agree to cooperate on increasing nuclear safety.
1999: Taiwan's Council of Agriculture rejects a call from South Korea for a resumption of reciprocal trade in fruit between the two countries.
1999: Defense Minister Tang Fei denies a U.S. media report that the Republic of China plans to develop medium range missiles.
2000: Central News Agency President Bill Wang says that CNA will shortly add a commercial information databank to its Internet services.
2000: National Yang Ming University President Tseng Chih-lang announces that he has decided to accept President-elect Chen Shui-bian's offer of the post of education minister in the new administration.
2001: Japanese Foreign Minister Yohei Kono announces that Japan will issue a visa to former ROC President Lee Teng-hui to seek medical treatment for his heart condition.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A man who does not anticipate deceit nor imagine untrustworthiness, but who can readily detect their presence, must be a very superior man."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ASSURED 'THERE WILL BE NO SURPRISES' FROM BUSH-HU MEET: REPORT
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 19 (CNA) (By Jorge Liu and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Washington has assured Taipei that "no surprises" will come out of the forthcoming meeting between U.S. President George W. Bush and Chinese President Hu Jintao, Taiwan's representative to the United States said in a recent interview with an American newspaper.
David Ta-wei Lee said he has been told that Bush will resist any demands from the Chinese side for new pressure on Taiwan.
"I have met with a number of administration officials, and the word I keep getting is that there will be no surprises, " Lee was quoted by the Washington Times as saying.
"I am sure the Chinese side will very much want to bring up the issue of Taiwan's status, but we have been told by our U.S. friends that Taiwan's interests will not be hurt," he said.
The newspaper noted that White House officials had made clear that Bush hopes to spend as little time as possible discussing Taiwan with Hu.
Bush is scheduled to meet with Hu at the White House Thursday.

During Bush's meeting with Chinese Premier Wen Jiabao in December 2003, Bush openly rebuked President Chen Shui-bian for his government's plan to hold a referendum regarding cross-Taiwan Strait relations.
Chen's decision to cease the function of the National Unification Council in late February has also raised concerns in Washington.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATOR PUSHES FOR RECOGNITION OF CHINESE ACADEMIC DEGREES

TEXT.P: An opposition legislator unveiled Thursday his plan to put forth a proposed amendment to a law on cross-Taiwan Strait relations to allow for the recognition of mainland Chinese academic degrees by the government.

According to Lai Shyh-bao of the Kuomintang (KMT) , the measure will be consistent with the principle of reciprocity because Beijing has recently announced that it will recognize academic degrees conferred by accredited Taiwan universities.

Lai said that the proposed amendment to the Statute Governing the Relations Between the People of the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area has won the endorsement of more than 20 KMT legislators and that the bill will be submitted to the Legislative Yuan's procedure committee as soon as the required 30 endorsement signatures are collected.

DOC.HEADLINE: ELECTRICITY RATES COULD BE HIKED THIS YEAR: ECONOMICS MINISTER

TEXT.P: Minister of Economic Affairs Hwang Ing-san raised Thursday the possibility of hiking electricity rates this year, noting that "it would not be fair for Taiwan Power Co. (Taipower) to pay the bill alone."
Hwang said Taipower should take the initiative to review its electricity pricing system which has been not adjusted for 23 years.

Hwang made the remarks in response to media questions at the Legislative Yuan amidst concerns about possible inflation following a steep 9.2 percent hike in gasoline prices announced by state-owned Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC) on Tuesday.

As international crude oil prices have surged to historical highs, Hwang said Taipower, a state-owned utility, estimates that it will suffer losses totalling NT$25 billion this year and that the figure could rise to as high as NT$30 billion if oil prices continue to climb.

"Consumers use electricity in different ways, and it wouldn't be fair for Taipower to pay for the loss alone," Hwang said, adding that the Ministry of Economic Affairs will decide whether to adjust domestic electricity rates after Taipower submits a comprehensive report on adjustments.
Hwang said that Taipower has its own adjustment mechanism for evaluating electricity rates.
On Wednesday, Hwang said that "it remains uncertain whether Taipower will raise its electricity rates before it adopts the summer power rates in June." (Timothy J. Hwang)

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ORCHIDS TO BLEND INTO TULIP FESTIVAL IN CANADA'S CAPITAL

TEXT.P: Taiwan orchids will blend into this year's Canadian Tulip Festival in Canada's capital city of Ottawa May 4-22 when over three million tulips are expected to create an exotic mosaic of color and beauty in the world's largest tulip festival.

Chang Hsin-hsiung, director of the Science and Technology Division of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office (TECO) in Canada, said the orchids will not only speak for Taiwan's agricultural technology but also increase Canadian and international awareness of Formosa, "the beautiful island."

Under the auspices of local Taiwanese community groups such as the Taiwanese-Canadian Association and Tzu Chi Buddhist Foundation, Taiwan orchids as well as folk cultures will be featured in a Taiwan Hall, Taiwan Day activities, a flower and design show, and a flower boats parade.
The Taiwan Hall will be part of International Friendship Village activities in an Ottawa park May 12 through May 22, one of the highlights of the Canadian Tulip Festival.

Festival organizers have designated this year's Mother's Day, which falls on May 14, as "Taiwan Day" at the International Friendship Village, when the Taipei Folk Dance Theater will stage two performances in celebration of the day.
From May 16 through May 22, tourism information about Taiwan, tea-making arts, gourmet food and handicrafts, including lanterns, will be presented at the Taiwan Folk Culture Hall.

On May 21 and May 22, Tzu Chi Buddhist Foundation will celebrate its 40th anniversary, an occasion to look back on its previous charity work around the world and share its visions about the future with visitors.

Well-known florists from Taiwan are invited to participate in the flower design exhibition May 19-22 to show off their flower arrangement skills. Along with an international evening gown pageant, the flower design show is another highlight of this year's Canadian Tulip Festival.

On May 21, an orchids-decorated boat will represent Taiwan in a flower boats parade on the Rideau Canal in Ottawa, marking the first time Taiwan has participated in the Flotilla on Canal, the festival's ever-popular parade on water.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC ACCUSES CHINA OF BLOCKING CROSS-STRAIT TALENT EXCHANGES

TEXT.P: The government's efforts to promote exchanges of specialized talent across the Taiwan Strait have been ineffective because China has imposed strict controls over such exchanges, a Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) official said Thursday.

MAC Vice Minister Johnnason Liu pointed out that the government long ago announced measures allowing Chinese students to visit Taiwan for up to four months for short-term exchange activities, but only 10 people have applied to join the program so far.

While the government has also made available measures facilitating Chinese technological talent to work in Taiwan, with their duration of stay extending up to six years, this program has seen no progress, either, owing to China's restrictions preventing the drain of its technological talent, Liu said.

Liu made the remarks during a seminar hosted by a group of opposition Kuomintang legislators, who were pressing the government to recognize mainland Chinese academic degrees and promote cross-strait medical and health exchanges and cooperation.
The legislators claimed that the government should encourage mainland Chinese students to study in Taiwan to resolve the oversupply of higher education resources in the country.

Also, they said the government should allow medical institutions to set up operations in China and allow medical workers to work in China to resolve the problem of the surplus of medical workers owing to the declining fertility rate in Taiwan.
