Finally showing his hand after months of deliberation, Los Angeles Mayor Antonio Villaraigosa announced Tuesday that he would ask the Legislature to give him overwhelming authority to run the city's embattled public schools.

DOC.HEADLINE: SIDEWALKS CAUSE SERIOUS INJURIES TO DISABLED, GROUPS COMPLAIN

TEXT.P: Blocked and illegal occupation of pedestrian areas and poor sidewalk design and construction are common causes for pedestrians being forced into the road, often causing them serious injury, advocacy groups for the disabled complained Thursday.
At a press conference, these groups -- including the Federation of the Disabled of the Republic of China -- urged the government and the public to "return the sidewalks to pedestrians."
Wen Chi-hsiang, secretary-general of the Federation of the Spine-Wounded, told how he was injured four years ago at an intersection of two major roads in Banqiao, suburban Taipei.

Because the sidewalk was filled with motorcycles and vendor stands, he had to drive his electric wheelchair in the slow-traffic lane of the road and was hit from behind by a taxi, he said, adding that he suffered a dislocated left shoulder, broken pelvis and facial injuries when his wheelchair was overturned.
Left-handed Wen said he could no longer use his left hand to write or do other things. In order to protect himself, he has installed a flashlight on his wheelchair.

Eden Social Welfare Foundation's deputy CEO, Lin Chin-chuan, who also relies on an electric wheelchair, said, in March last year he had to "fight with cars" in order to cross ZhongXiao Bridge in Taipei because there was no access to the sidewalk.

It was when he was using a car lane that he was seriously injured in an accident. He had tens of stitches on his head and was hospitalized for three months; his brain injury continues to pose problems with his sense of smell, he said.
Another story of a disabled person suffering an injury on the streets was told by Lu Hung-wen, chairman of the Taipei Association for the Promotion of Welfare for the Blind.

Lu said one of the association members was also forced to walk in the slow traffic lane two years ago because the sidewalk was occupied. The road was being repaired, but the warning signs were beyond the reach of a blind person's white stick.
The sightless person fell into sewage that was five floors deep and had to stay in the hospital for two weeks as he had absorbed too much sewage water, Lu reported.

Hsieh Tung-ju, secretary-general of the Federation of the Disabled, suggested that government officials regularly update their knowledge about laws and regulations that can help ensure the safety of the disabled on the road.
If they find laws and regulations that are outdated, they should take the initiative to propose amendments in order to keep similar unfortunate stories from happening again, Hsieh added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened high and closed higher Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 63.96 points to close at 7,102.74.
The bourse opened at 7,061.38 and fluctuated between 7,107.68 and 7,030.89 during trading. A total of 4.32 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$136.61 billion (US$4.22 billion).

Five of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with paper and pulp issues moving up the most at 2.7 percent, followed by machinery and electronics shares at 1.3 percent, banking and financial shares at 0.7 percent, plastics and chemicals shares at 0.2 percent and foodstuff issues at 0.1 percent.
The three other major stock categories lost ground, with textile stocks moving down at 0.7 percent and cement stocks and construction issues both dropping at 0.1 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 482 to 387, with 132 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Supreme Court: Center-left Union wins.
The Supreme Court announced Wednesday that the center-left alliance "Union" won the April 9-10 general elections with a margin of 24,755 votes in the House of Deputies. The Union, led by former European Commission chief Romano Prodi obtained 19,002,598 votes and the center-right coalition "House of Liberty", led by outgoing premier Silvio Berlusconi, got 18,977,843 votes, the court said after completing the scrutiny of disputed ballots.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Unforeseen Spending on Materiel Pumps Up Iraq War Bill; Senate to Take Up Measure as Military Fights to Keep Guns, Tanks Working
With the expected passage this spring of the largest emergency spending bill in history, annual war expenditures in Iraq will have nearly doubled since the U.S. invasion, as the military confronts the rapidly escalating cost of repairing, rebuilding and replacing equipment chewed up by three years of combat.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. CONGRESSMAN URGES LIFTING TRAVEL BAN ON TAIWAN LEADERS
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 19 (CNA) (By Jorge Liu and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: It is ridiculous that Communist China's dictator Hu Jintao receives a 21-gun salute when he visits the White House while Taiwan's democratically elected president -- one of the strongest allies of the United States -- cannot even visit Washington, Congressman Steve Chabot (R-Cincinnati) said Wednesday.

"Taiwan is an independent, sovereign nation. No amount of diplomatic doubletalk can obscure this fact. It's time to recognize this reality fully and welcome our democratic allies to our nation's capital," Chabot said in a news release Wednesday.
"Pressure from Communist China to isolate Taiwan is a direct result of our failed 'One China' policy that curries favor with a dictatorship while belittling our democratic ally," Chabot said.
"The travel ban [on Taiwan's democratically elected leaders] is an excellent illustration of that discredited policy, " Chabot claimed.

Chabot, co-founder and chairman of the Congressional Taiwan Caucus, said he has recently introduced a resolution in the House of Representatives urging the Bush administration to permit official visits to the United States by high-level officeholders from Taiwan.
Current U.S. policy prohibits official travel to the United States by Taiwan's president, vice-president, foreign minister and defense minister.

Chabot introduced House Resolution 381 along with Ohio Congressman Sherrod Brown (D-Ohio) . Chabot and Brown, both senior members of the House International Relations Committee and its Asia-Pacific subcommittee, are co-founders and chairmen of the Congressional Taiwan Caucus.

"I think our resolution is long overdue and believe it sends the right message at the right time, " Chabot said, adding that travel to the United States by senior Taiwanese officials has occasionally been allowed, but only for "transit visits" permitting a short layover before traveling to another country.

Chabot recalled having to travel to New York with other pro-democracy Members of Congress to meet with Taiwan's President Chen Shui-bian during one such visit. Most recently, he and others spoke to Chen via video teleconference when the Taiwanese leader had a stopover in Miami.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN UNRELATED TO SOLOMON ISLAND RIOTS: MOFA SPOKESMAN

TEXT.P: Ministry of Foreign Affairs Spokesman Michel Lu said Thursday that Taiwan was not involved in unrest surrounding the Solomon Islands' elections, and "we will find out why Taiwan is rumored to have been involved."

According to media reports, a curfew in the Solomon Islands capital Honiara will be enforced for a second night Thursday. The rioting followed the election Tuesday of Snyder Rini as prime minister, a move which angered supporters of rival Job Dudley Tausinga. Rioters targeted Chinese businesses because they were believed to be backing Rini.
Australian Foreign Minister Alexander Downer said Tuesday that the riots in the streets of Solomon Islands' capital are related to China-Taiwan powerplay in the South Pacific region.

At a press briefing, Lu said there were only two Taiwanese businessmen in the Solomon Islands -- one is running a restaurant, and the other owns a garage. Both are safe, and the ROC Embassy and the agricultural missions of the International Cooperation and Development Fund (Taiwan ICDF) have not been affected.
"The burnt-out area is the Chinatown where most overseas Chinese came from China," said Lu, stressing that the riot had nothing to do with Taiwan, as the Solomon government has confirmed.
"Taiwan's diplomatic ties are based on mutual trust for the purpose of long-term development, and we love to see democratic elections held in those countries," Lu said.
Since Australian-led peacekeeping troops now remain in the Solomon Islands, Lu said the riots should be quelled soon.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEMOCRACY IS TAIWAN'S BEST PROTECTION: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian asserted Thursday that the country's wave of democracy and freedom can never be halted by nuclear weapons, missiles or dictatorship because democracy is "the best TMD [theater missile defense] for Taiwan."

The purpose of the government's move to introduce a referendum system in Taiwan and cease the function of the National Unification Council is precisely to cement and deepen the country's democracy and realize the principle of "sovereignty lying with the people, " Chen said.
He said the roots of the cross-Taiwan Strait dispute are not in ideological differences but in the divided choices of the two sides in terms of lifestyle and political system.
Chen noted that democracy means the people are the masters of the country, and that they should be entitled to freedom of choice and the right to a referendum.
In line with this principle, "ultimate unification" with China should not be predetermined as the sole option available to the people of Taiwan, Chen said.

The president made the remarks while receiving Chinese democratic activists -- including Ruan Ming, Lin Baohua, Cao Changqing, Hu Ping and Wang Ce -- in Taipei, ahead of a high-profile meeting between U.S. President George W. Bush and Chinese President Hu Jintao in Washington D. C.

Chen noted that Bush previously said that only when China becomes free and democratic will it stop being a threat to its neighboring countries, and that U. S. officials have repeatedly expressed the expectation that China will act as a responsible stakeholder.

Chen said he also hopes the rise of China will be accompanied by an awakening to peace and democratic development, and that when the "sleeping lion" of China wakes up it will become a truly responsible stakeholder in the world.
Although such expectations appear illusory and naive, he is willing to dream this dream and work with others to try to attain that goal, he said.
Chen stressed that he is not against the Chinese people, but against the one-party totalitarian rule of the Chinese Communists, because "China itself is not a problem, but Chinese communism is."
Describing China as a country with one of the worst human rights records in the world, Chen said Taiwan has traveled a similar path -- transforming itself from authoritarianism to democracy.
Chen said Taiwan is willing to share this precious experience with the 1.3 billion people in China so that Taiwan's success story will serve as a beacon inspiring China toward democratization.

DOC.HEADLINE: CPI HIKE MIGHT EXCEED 2% IF ELECTRICITY RATE GOES UP 10%: SCHOLAR

TEXT.P: The consumer price index (CPI) might rise 0.6 percent if electricity rates go up 10 percent as a result of gasoline price hikes, a scholar at the Taiwan Research Institute (TRI) said Wednesday.

Lin Tang-yu, a leading scholar at the TRI, said that if the cost of electricity goes up 3 percent, the CPI will roughly increase 0.2 percent this year, and if electricity prices rise 10 percent, the CPI rise will possibly reach 0.6 percent this year, causing the CPI adjustment to exceed the 2 percent target.
The Directorate-General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) previously predicted the annual CPI rise this year would be 1.7 percent.
Lin said that it will be quite difficult to keep the CPI increase under 2 percent this year when electricity costs are taken into account.

However, Lin said that expenditure on electricity only represent 10 percent of the total cost of the country's energy-intensive industry and is not expected to greatly affect industrial competitiveness or people's everyday life.
Lin suggested that the cost of electricity should reflect the cost of its fuel, but that each time its price adjustments should not exceed 6 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEASIDE CYCLING TO MARK HSINCHU'S WORLD EARTH DAY

TEXT.P: The Hsinchu City Government will organize a seaside cycling event Saturday to mark "World Earth Day, " with the objective of promoting non-polluting bicycle-related sports, a spokesman for the city government said Thursday.
The spokesman said the six-kilometer seaside bicycle trip starts at the Gangnan Canal Coastal Scenic Area and finishes at a sports park to the north of the scenic area.
Leading Taiwanese bicycle manufacturer Giant Manufacturing Co., which makes Giant bicycles, is sponsoring the event. It will also introduce a new model of women's bicycle at the event.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA IS OBSCURE TO THE TAIWANESE: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: In contrast to the clear notion the American people possess of China, China remains something obscure to the people of Taiwan, according to President Chen Shui-bian.

Compared to more than half of Americans who view China both as an economic and military threat to the world, Taiwan's people are sharply divided over the question of whether China is an "enemy" or a "friend, "a motherland" or a "foreign country" to Taiwan, Chen said in an electronic newsletter published Thursday by the Presidential Office.

As Chinese President Hu Jintao is soon to meet with U.S. President George W. Bush Thursday at the White House, a "China fever" is also emerging in the United States in response to the question of whether China brings opportunities or threatens the world, Chen said.

Citing results of a public opinion survey by thinktank Rand Corp., Chen pointed out that 64 percent of Americans view China as an economic threat to the United States while 50 percent think it poses a military threat to the country.

The survey also found that some 55 percent believe China obtains its economic growth through unfair competition, and many among the U. S. public feel resentment toward China, mainly due to its poor human rights record, military buildup, unfair trade practices, commercial piracy and currency manipulation.

Compared to Americans who have a clear picture of China in their minds, Taiwan's 23 million people lack a profound understanding of what China means to this country, the president said, adding that many Taiwanese don't even know whether China is a "foreign country" or "the motherland."

Taiwan must gain a clear concept of its national standing in the world and of what it wants and believes in amid rapidly changing cross-Taiwan Strait relations, the president said. China is an important market, but by no means the sole or the last outlet for Taiwan, he asserted.

Taiwan can never turn a blind eye to China's atrocities and its hegemonic mindset while engaging in trade and economic exchanges with the neighboring country, which is hostile and a threat to Taiwan, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Thursday, decreasing NT$0.097 to close at NT$32.311.
A total of US$1.23 billion changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$32.420 and fluctuated between NT$32.3 and NT$32.462.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES HIGHER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Thursday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for May moved up 68 points to close at 7,121, with 52,886 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for June increased 70 points to finish at 7,106, with 345 contracts traded, while September futures gained 61 points to end at 6,905, with 51 contract transactions. December futures increased 64 points to close at 6,904, with 60 contracts traded, while March futures moved up 30 points to finish at 6,912, with four contract transactions.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Thursday at 7,053 for May, 7,036 for June, 6,844 for September, 6,840 for December and 6,882 for March.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also higher.

May TE futures increased 4.95 points to close at 316.8, with 6,573 contracts traded, while June TE futures gained 2.5 points to finish at 315.5, with 42 contract transactions. September TE futures moved up 1.05 points to end at 306, with four contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for December and March.

May TF futures increased four points to finish at 936, with 2,971 contracts changing hands, while June TF futures gained 6.8 points to close at 934.8, with seven contracts traded. September TF futures moved up 5.2 points to end at 920, with eight contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for December and March.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT HOLDS DRAWING FOR ORDINAL NUMBERS IN TAIPEI MAYOR RACE

TEXT.P: A drawing to determine the ordinal balloting number assigned to Taipei mayoral candidates of the opposition Kuomintang party (KMT) was held Thursday, with Legislator Ting Shou-chung drawing number one, followed by former deputy Taipei mayor Yeh Chin-chuan, Legislator John Chiang and former minister of the Environmental Protection Administration Hau Lung-bin.
The four candidates also signed a joint pledge that there will be no bribery in the form of entertainment, gifts, or vote-buying in their campaigns to win the KMT nomination.

Legislator Chiang, who was first to draw, hailed his good number 3, and Hau said, "Number 4 is the sign of victory." Number one Legislator Ting shouted with glee, saying "renewing Taipei, braced for competition," while Yeh cheered "Taipei, Yeah!"
According to the joint pledge, all candidates will obey the rules, including no blackening of the KMT's image or damaging party unity, no cheap shots at each other and no bribery.

Meanwhile, the candidates must not interfere with the results of the primary by staging riots, protests, rallies or other irrational measures. They also promised to respect primary results and to help the winner run his campaign. (Timothy J. Hwang)

DOC.HEADLINE: HSINCHU'S INTERNATIONAL GLASS ART FESTIVAL DRAWS 350,000 VISITORS

TEXT.P: The 2006 Hsinchu International Glass Art Festival has attracted more than 350,000 visitors since it began Feb. 11 and is expected to reach a climax in its final 10 days with various folk dance and pop music programs, event organizers said Thursday.

Officials of the Hsinchu City Government's Bureau of Cultural Affairs, which has organized the biennial event since 1995, indicated that they will invite pop music and folk dance groups from Paraguay, Peru, Thailand and the United States to stage various performances during the two final weekends of the festival.
The officials said this will be an ideal opportunity for entire families to spend leisure time together and enjoy the interaction of international cultures.
The event this year is the sixth international glass art festival held in Hsinchu, which deems itself the "city of culture and science."

The theme of this year's exhibition, "Alice in a Glass Castle," encourages artists to create a fairy-tale dreamworld by combining high-tech know-how with artistic creativity. Their glass works of art are on display at the Glass Art Museum, located in Hsinchu Park.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Storm Evacuees Are Straining Texas Hosts
Seven months after two powerful hurricanes blew through the Gulf Coast, elected officials, law enforcement agencies and many residents say Texas is nearing the end of its ability to play good neighbor without compensation. Houston is straining along its municipal seams from the 150,000 new residents from New Orleans, officials say.
Crime was already on the rise there before the hurricane, but the Houston police say that evacuees were victims or suspects in two-thirds of the 30 percent increase in murders since September. The schools are also struggling to educate thousands of new children.
Wall Street Journal: Rapid Economic Growth at Home Adds to Heat on Hu to Adjust Yuan
Adding to U.S. pressure on President Hu Jintao to let the yuan appreciate, China's growth at home is surging so quickly it risks overheating. Driven by exports and rapid developmment, China' s economic growth raced ahead by 10.2 percent in the first three months of this year, even faster than the blistering 9.9 percent pace registered for all of 2005.

DOC.HEADLINE: SUSTAINABLE DEVELOPMENT CONFERENCE MAY OPEN UNDER SHADOW OF PROTEST

TEXT.P: A national conference on sustainable development is set to open Friday in Taipei and environmentalists are threatening to stage a protest against government projects which they claim will take a heavy toll on the environment.

In a news conference held by the conference's organizer, the National Council for Sustainable Development under the Executive Yuan, Minister without Portfolio Lin Si-yao -- who doubles as the chief executor of the council -- said the two-day conference will focus on four themes: major transportation projects, the development of water resources, a reduction in greenhouse gas emissions and restructuring industry.

He said the Executive Yuan will consult with environmental groups for their opinion on these four themes without prejudice, adding that he believes these groups will exchange views with government officials rationally and reasonably during the conference.

The conference results will be submitted to the National Council for Sustainable Development as guidelines for revising the country's sustainable development action program, the minister said. Issues that cannot be solved at the conference through consensus will be discussed further in public hearings or citizen conferences to be organized afterward, Lin went on.

However, several environmental groups -- including the Taiwan Ecosystem Association -- have threatened to organize a protest rally outside the conference venue Friday to protest the government's insistence on pushing for several economic projects, which they claim would serious damage the island's environment.

Chen Ping-heng, secretary-general of the Taiwan Ecosystem Association, said the conference would be meaningless as the administration still gives economic development precedence over environmental protection.

DOC.HEADLINE: RECORD-HOLDING BRITISH YACHTSWOMAN VISITS KEELUNG
DOC.DATELINE: Keelung, April 20 (CNA) (By Pien Chin-feng and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Ellen MacArthur, the fastest ever sailor to complete a solo non-stop circumnavigation of the globe, arrived in Keelung Harbor Thursday aboard her solo racing 23-meter trimaran the B&Q Castorama for a short visit.

MacArthur, who completed her single-handed round-the-world voyage in a record-breaking time of 71 days and under 15 hours in February 2005 and was made a Dame by Queen Elizabeth in honor of her achievement, said upon anchoring off Keelung at around 3:30 a.m. that she was overwhelmed by the kindness and warm welcome that the Taiwan people extended to her.
The 28-year-old Briton was scheduled to depart Keelung for Hong Kong at around 6 p.m. Thursday after renewing her supplies.

Taiwan is one of the stops on her current Asian voyage, which began in Yokohama, Japan in mid-March and is expected to conclude in Singapore in mid-May. The two-month Asian voyage will also take MacArthur and the B&Q Castorama to China's Hainan Island, Hong Kong, Vietnam and Malaysia.
MacArthur beat the previous record of 72 days and 22 hours set by Frenchman Francis Joyon to break the round-the-world sailing record.

Joyon's achievement in February 2004 raised the bar in solo non-stop circumnavigation of the globe. He smashed the previous record by a massive 20 days and it was widely believed in the sailing world that his mark would go unchallenged for several years.
MacArthur chased Joyon's record with a boat that is smaller, and therefore slower than his, although its lighter weight helps counterbalance that disadvantage.

However, the vessel she has guided across more than 27,000 miles was specially built with this task in mind. She had to contend with extreme weather conditions and technical problems in her bid to better Joyon.
Mountainous seas, icebergs and gale force winds had threatened to capsize her boat and she narrowly missed a collision with a whale during the voyage.

In breaking the latest record, MacArthur also broke five other records -- beating Joyon's times to the Equator, the Cape of Good Hope, Cape Leeuwin in Australia, Cape Horn and back again to the Equator.
She was conferred a Laurence Olivier Award for Extreme Sports and was chosen as one of the world's 100 heroes by Time magazine late last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA KEEPING WATCHFUL EYE ON MEETING BETWEEN U.S., CHINA LEADERS

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Thursday it is hoped that the forthcoming meeting between U.S. President George W. Bush and Chinese President Hu Jintao will not harm Taiwan's national interests in any way.
MOFA spokesman Michel Lu made the remarks on the same day that Hu was scheduled to arrive in Washington, D.C. for a meeting with Bush at the White House.
Noting that MOFA attaches great importance to the Bush-Hu tete-a-tete, Lu said the ministry has activated a contingency response task force to keep close tabs on the developments in Hu's visit.
Lu said there has been a smooth communication mechanism between Taiwan and the United States to deal with major issues of mutual concern.

As to the topics to be brought up in the Bush-Hu meeting, Lu said the U.S.-China trade issue, China's human rights conditions, its suppression on religious freedom and slow progress in democratic reform as well as the Taiwan Strait issue are expected to be high on the agenda.

Asked about the possibility of Bush expressing his hope during the meeting that President Chen Shui-bian will uphold his now famous "five noes" pledge, Lu said he would not respond to any hypothetical questions. Bush was quoted by U.S. Deputy Secretary of State Robert Zoellick as having expressed such a hope recently.

"We should have confidence in ourselves. We have maintained smooth communications with the United States and it's a matter of fact that both sides understand and respect each other's stances on all relevant issues," Lu said.

The "five noes" pledge refers to the promises Chen made in his 2000 inaugural speech that if China has no intention of using force against Taiwan, he will not change Taiwan's national title and flag nor declare independence during his term.

On Feb. 27, Chen announced the cessation of a government body responsible for eventual unification between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, provoking an angry reaction from Beijing and consternation in the United States, Taiwan's most important ally.

Chen said in an article published in the Asian Wall Street Journal that day that Taiwan is not moving toward formal independence but is trying to shore up the status quo in the Taiwan Strait as rival China tries to change the situation in its favor.

He pointed out that China's deployment of more than 800 missiles aimed at the island and its passage in 2005 of its Anti-Secession Law codifying the use of force against Taiwan required the country to act decisively.

"It is unfortunate that the process of shoring up such efforts has been interpreted by China as evidence of moving toward formal independence, " Chen wrote. "At times I also hear concern from the U.S. and the international community suggesting that developments in Taiwan... are aimed at changing the cross-strait status quo, or worse, provoking confrontation with China. That certainly is not the case," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: SUPER BASKETBALL LEAGUE POST-SEASON TO BEGIN

TEXT.P: Taiwanese basketball will be at its best during the coming month as four teams kick off the Super Basketball League (SBL) post-season play that begins Friday, the league announced Thursday.

Two-time defending champions Yulon Dinos will meet Bank of Taiwan and Dacin Tigers will meet Taiwan Beer in the best-of-five first round playoffs. The first-round winners advance to the best-of-seven finals.

Led by national team coach Lee Yun-kwang and star center Tsun Wen-ting, regular season champion Yulon will try to win its third consecutive title after finishing 24 wins and 6 losses in the regular season.

Its opponent will be Bank of Taiwan, the "cinderella team" which made the post-season for the first time in SBL's three-year history with a 15W-15L record. With Yulon regarded as a hands-on favorite, Bank of Taiwan head coach Wei Chen-ming predicted that his underrated team will at least get one win in the series.
The games will take place at the Taipei Physical Education College Gymnasium. Game days of the first-round series are April 21, 22, 23, 26 and 27.
SBL, which was established in 2003, is the most competitive senior-level basketball league in Taiwan. Currently there are seven teams in the league.

DOC.HEADLINE: VALUES, CHARACTER IMPORTANT IN BUSINESS AND HIGHER EDUCATION

TEXT.P: Developing character and the appropriate personal values of students and employees is important in both university education and business, representatives from universities and local corporations said Thursday.

"For National Taiwan University (NTU), developing personal values through a whole-person education is one of our priorities, " said Joyce Feng, Dean of NTU's Student Affairs Division, in a press conference held to announce the survey results of local businesses' school preference in hiring fresh graduates.

"Of the three key components we look for in an employee, we think character is even more important than soft skills, which means communication skills, and hard skills -- the domain of knowledge, " said Kuo Keng-tsung, special assistant to the president of Mediatek Inc.
"We don't expect employees to change their character to accommodate the company. On the contrary, we look to place employees in the most suitable positions for them, " Kuo added.

In the days of "knowledge explosion" and "chaotic" values, professional knowledge is no longer the most important segment in business hiring and college education, they agreed, which is why NTU has declared its core elements of "TAIDA" -- teamwork, accountability, integrity, diligence and ambition/vision, Feng said.
Mediatek Inc. also looks for six characteristics it calls "TICTIC, " in its employees -- trust, integrity, courage, teamwork, innovation and continuous learning.
"People can always learn because learning takes a lifetime. We believe, however, that once the character is shaped, it's hard to change," Kuo said.
"Even today, the key to success for a person or corporation still lies in the fundamentals," Kuo said.

DOC.HEADLINE: NCKU GRADUATES MOST SOUGHT BY LOCAL CORPORATIONS: POLL

TEXT.P: Graduates from National Cheng Kung University (NCKU) are those most sought by local corporations, according to the results of a poll released Thursday, the 10th consecutive year the public school has topped the poll.

The survey was conducted by Cheers magazine to explore the top 1,000 corporations' manpower recruitment plans and their school preferences. The corporations were selected in terms of ratings compiled by the CommonWealth business monthly.

The poll found that while NCKU, located in the southern city of Tainan, leads the overall ratings in seven categories, National Taiwan University (NTU) ranks top in terms of producing graduates with leadership and global vision.
Tamkang University has the most sought-after graduates among private universities for the second consecutive year.

In the overall ratings, NTU graduates came in second, followed by those from National Chiao Tung University, National Tsinghua University and National Chengchi University. National Taiwan University of Science and Technology, National Taipei University of Technology, Tamkang University, National Sun Yat-sen University and Chung-yuan Christian University rounded out the top 10.

Among other findings, the survey shows that compared to five years ago, fresh graduates are better in terms of innovation, global vision and foreign language proficiency but worse in stability, problem-solving ability, professional knowledge and teamwork.
According to the poll, 73.2 percent of the companies surveyed said they will recruit fresh university graduates this year, slightly down from last year's 79.8 percent.
The service industry has replaced the finance industry as the sector with the highest hiring intentions. 86.1 percent of the service industry businesses surveyed showed hiring intention this year.
The survey polled 1,600 local businesses from Feb. 17 to March 22 and received 370 responses.

DOC.HEADLINE: S. KOREA SURPASSES TAIWAN TO BECOME CHINA'S 2ND-LARGEST IMPORT SOURCE

TEXT.P: South Korea has outperformed Taiwan since the beginning of this year to become China's second-largest import source, the Chung-Hua Institution for Economic Research (CIER), a private think tank, reported Thursday.

CIER researchers quoted the latest report released by the Korean Trade Investment Promotion Agency as indicating that South Korea has enjoyed growth in its exports to China since January, while exports to China from Taiwan, Japan and the United States have continued to decline.

The researchers said South Korea's exports to China have continued to expand over the past three years, with China's eastern province of Jiangsu being the biggest recipient among China's 31 provinces and cities. The amount that Jiangsu Province imported from South Korea over the past three years was twice as much as South Korea's entire exports to Germany in the same period and four times as much as South Korea's exports to the United Kingdom, the researchers said.

The CIER researchers attributed South Korea's soaring exports to China mainly to rising economic performance in the Yangtze River Delta Economic Circle and increasing two-way trade between China and South Korea, as well as expanding Korean investment in China.
They forecast that South Korea will surpass Japan to become China's largest import source within three years.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA'S ECONOMY IN QUAGMIRE OF OVERCAPACITY: SCHOLAR

TEXT.P: Behind China's rapid economic growth is its industrial overcapacity, which is shrinking the industry's profitability, a Taiwan scholar said Thursday.

Kao Chang, dean of National Dong Hwa University's School of Humanities and Social Sciences, called for attention to China's industrial overcapacity in an article he contributed to the electronic newspaper of the Ministry of Economic Affairs.

The article quoted a State Council research center as saying that in 2006, China's domestic steel products supply will reach 450 million tons, up 48 percent from a year earlier, while its demand will be 337 million tons, creating a surplus of almost 120 million tons.

Another metal industry research center in China has estimated that the oversupply will be between 50 million tons and 60 million tons. Kao said that although the estimates are different, both point to an overcapacity of China's steel industry.

Similar statistics show that the capacity of China's aluminum industry has reached 10.3 million tons, with an idle capacity of 2.6 million tons, the metal alloy industry has a capacity of 22.1 million tons, coal mining has created a surplus of 100 million tons and the cement industry is also in surplus.
This has led to a slight decline in prices, blunting the industry's profit margin and increasing losses, according to the article.
Kao further pointed out that even in China's booming auto industry, the overcapacity problem is deteriorating. At present, only 55 percent of China's auto production facilities are in use.

Quoting official Chinese tallies, Kao said the Chinese auto industry can now churn out 8 million cars a year and its annual production capacity will reach 10.2 million units when production lines currently under construction are completed. But in 2005, only about 5.5 million vehicles were sold in China, indicating that 45 percent of its capacity was left idle.

DOC.HEADLINE: BENEFITS OF TAIWAN FISHERY EXPORTS TO CHINA REMAIN TO BE SEEN

TEXT.P: Whether and how China's plans to import Taiwan fishery products duty free will benefit Taiwan's fishing sector remains to be seen, a fishery industry source in Keelung said Thursday.

China issued "15 incentives" to Taiwan at the conclusion of an economic forum in Beijing between Taiwan's main opposition Kuomintang and the Communist Party of China April 14-15. One of the "incentives" was a promise to allow eight categories of Taiwan fishery products, including mackerel and shrimp, to be exported to China duty free with speedy quarantine procedures.

In response, You Jih-hsing, chairman of the Keelung Fishermen's Association, said that although it is better than nothing, it will be of more benefit to deep-sea fishing operators than to coastal fishing boats.
Most of the Keelung Fishermen's Association members operate coastal fishing boats, whose catches barely meet domestic demand, You said.

In addition, he went on, Taiwan's coastal fishing boats have met increasing difficulties in their daily operations, given that fishery sources in these regions have continued to decline, while Taiwan fishing boats have fishery disputes with their Japanese counterparts due to overlapping fishing grounds and increasing numbers of Chinese fishing boats are poaching in Taiwan territorial waters.

Meanwhile, You said, if the Beijing incentive is put into practice, it would mean that Taiwan fishing boats can sail directly from the open seas to China to sell their catches instead of returning to Taiwan.
This scenario could cause Taiwan's fishing sector to shrink from the roots -- a situation that could concern national policy and which the government should not ignore, he said.

Meanwhile, Wang Ling, an official with the Yilan Braided Twine Fishing Association, said China's offer to allow mackerel caught by Taiwan fishing boats to be exported to China duty free is not attractive to Yilan fishing boats at all, since Taiwan fishing boats can export this catch to Europe at a price higher than NT$20 per kilo, compared with only around NT$10 per kilo for export to China.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO ADDITIONAL BUDGET FOR 4TH NUCLEAR PLANT: ENVIRONMENTAL GROUPS

TEXT.P: More than 10 domestic environmental groups expressed strong opposition Thursday to any additional government budget for the fourth nuclear power plant project -- still under construction in Kungliao township, Taipei County.

Leaders of the the civic groups, including the Taiwan Environmental Protection Union, the Taiwan Academy of Ecology and the Homemakers Union and Foundation, said they met with President Chen Shui-bian, Premier Su Tseng-chang and the chairman of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, Yu Shyi-kun, to present their case.

They said they will call Friday on Ma Ying-jeou, chairman of the main opposition Kuomintang, to seek his support for an eight-point proposal for a greener way of living in Taiwan, including calling on the Legislative Yuan to veto the NT$73.3 billion additional budget requested for the fourth nuclear power plant project.

Chen Shu-hua, president of the Taiwan Environmental Protection Union, noted that the state-run Taiwan Power Co. (Taipower), which is in charge of constructing the plant, has requested the Executive Yuan to provide two supplementary budgets of NT$19 billion and NT$54. 3 billion, causing the original budget to balloon to NT$243 billion and making the plant "the most expensive nuclear power plant in the world."

She said Taipower has acknowledged that even if the 2,700-megawatt nuclear power plant is in operation for 40 years, it will not be able to recover the construction cost, let alone the cost of nuclear waste disposal and subsequent expenses to retire the plant when it becomes obsolete.

The DPP government indicated recently that it will not abandon the project or purposely delay its construction. The Ministry of Economic Affairs has said it regards the plant as essential to Taiwan's economic development.

In October 2000, the DPP government suspended construction of the plant under its policy of a nuclear-free Taiwan, resulting in billions of dollars-worth of losses. The work resumed 110 days later after political wrangling among the ruling and opposition parties.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA HEIGHTENS TRAVEL ADVISORY FOR CHAD

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) heightened its travel advisory for Chad Thursday as the political situation in the north-central African country remains precarious after a recent rebel attack on its capital.

The MOFA issued a "yellow" travel advisory for Chad earlier this year and raised the advisory to the more serious "orange" level Thursday, urging local people to refrain from traveling to the country for the time being.

MOFA officials said that although Chadian government troops have crushed rebel forces that attacked N'Djamena recently, the country's political situation remains tricky, with a presidential election scheduled to take place May 3.
For safety concerns, the officials said, local people should postpone any non-essential Chad-bound travel plans until after the political situation stabilizes.
Chad is one of Taiwan's diplomatic allies.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP CONCERNED OVER POSSIBLE U.S.-CHINA ALIGNMENT AGAINST TAIWAN

TEXT.P: As China and the United States are seeking cooperation in handling controversial global issues and both wish to maintain the current policy framework regarding the Taiwan Strait, it is worrisome the two countries' leaders might work together in an upcoming meeting to contain Taiwan, a lawmaker of the opposition People First Party (PFP) said Thursday.

Legislator Chang Hsien-yau, who concurrently chairs the PFP's policy research center, expressed worry that U.S. President George W. Bush may join forces with Chinese President Hu Jintao to deal with Taiwan in a meeting at the White House scheduled for that day, after President Chen Shui-bian announced in late February the cessation of the National Unification Council -- a move that drew criticism from both Washington and Beijing.
Chang forecast that Bush and Hu will reiterate their "one China" and anti-Taiwan independence positions at the meeting.

It would be greatly damaging to Taiwan if Bush -- when commenting on cross-strait policy -- were to focus only on the three communiques signed between Washington and Beijing and fail to mention the Taiwan Relations Act during his meeting with Hu, Chang said.

As China has responded to the U.S. call for reducing its huge trade surplus in bilateral trade and for stepping up law enforcement in order to protect U.S. intellectual property rights, Chang speculated that the two sides are likely to express hope for maintaining the current cooperation framework, further limiting Taiwan's role in the development of Washington-Beijing ties.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOI HOLDS MEETING ON 'FOREIGN SPOUSE' PHRASING

TEXT.P: The Ministry of the Interior (MOI) said Thursday the phrase "foreign spouses" will continue to be used in official and legal documents, as the term is now commonly used in local society.
The decision was reached after the ministry called a meeting of relevant government officials, academics, experts and representatives from foreign spouses associations and advocacy groups.

The ministry held the meeting in response to calls from some social quarters that a more circumspect term should be coined to replace the phrase "foreign spouses" because the word "foreign" seems to distance them from Taiwan society.

After open and candid discussions at the two-hour meeting, MOI officials said it was decided that the term "foreign spouses" will continue to be in use because they said it does not imply any discrimination.
The officials said the term "foreign spouses" refers to foreign citizens as well as people from China, Hong Kong and Macau who marry Taiwan citizens, regardless of their gender.

As some social groups like to use phrases such as "new immigrants, " "new residents, " "daughters-in-law of Taiwan " and "international immigrants" to refer to the foreign mates of local citizens, the officials said the ministry will respect their choices.
The officials also called on local people to always help foreign spouses adapt to local lifestyles and customs, while respecting the cultures and habits of their countries of origin.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT: CHINA'S GROWING INFLUENCE CHANGES STATUS QUO

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said in an article published in the Wall Street Journal Thursday that China's growing influence in terms of its economic and military strength is gradually changing the status quo in the Taiwan Strait in a way that his government "cannot afford to ignore."

"While we may not be able to curb this trend completely, we still strive to maintain a peaceful status quo in the Taiwan Strait, " he said, adding that as Taiwan's president, he is trying to find ways to prevent this trend from hurting the interests of his people.

Chen criticized Beijing for refusing to interact with Taiwan's democratically elected government during the past six years, while inviting Taiwan's opposition party leaders to visit China, in an attempt to undermine the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).
"These visits were very cynically timed to draw attention away from the passage of China's so-called 'Anti-Secession Law,'" he said.

He deplored the fact that despite criticism from the international community and strong public opposition in Taiwan, Beijing passed the law to codify non-peaceful means against Taiwan, unilaterally changing the status quo in the Taiwan Strait.
Chen reiterated that the DPP government is willing to have direct dialogue with Beijing without preconditions to work out peaceful solutions to bilateral problems.
"Meaningful reduction of the military threat and dealing directly with Taiwan's duly elected leaders would be a good foundation on which to start," he said.
The president pointed out that China has deployed more than 800 missiles targeting Taiwan and that the number is increasing by 100 to 125 per year.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACTING KAOHSIUNG MAYOR ON HECTIC VISIT TO JAPAN
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, April 20 (CNA) (By Wang Shu-feng and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Acting Kaohsiung Mayor Yeh Chu-lan continued her hectic visit to Japan Thursday, meeting with Japanese political heavyweights and touring major urban redevelopment projects in major Japanese cities.
Yeh first paid a visit to Chikage Ogi, president of the upper house of the Japanese Diet, for wide-ranging talks.

Yeh, who arrived in Tokyo a day earlier for a five-day visit aimed at learning from Japan's urban redevelopment experience and boosting bilateral commercial, tourist and cultural exchanges, and Ogi, an influential Japanese politician, exchanged views on the importance of gender equality in political participation and women's role in modern society.

Ogi told Yeh that she has fond memories of her last visit to Kaohsiung in 1997, particularly the integrated manufacturing, packaging and transport operations at Kaohsiung's export processing zone. Yeh invited Ogi to visit the southern Taiwan port city again in the near future.
Earlier in the day, Yeh visited Yokohama, where she met with Yokohama Mayor Hiroshi Nakada and toured the city's revamped harbor zone.

Under an 18-year development project, the 186-hectare Yokohama harbor zone has been turned into a "shining commercial zone" that now accommodates many noted Japanese corporate headquarters. Yeh said Kaohsiung can learn from Yokohama's tax-deduction measures to facilitate redevelopment of Kaohsiung's harbor zone.

Yeh also met with Takeo Hiranuma, head of a Taiwan-friendly Japanese parliamentary group, to seek his assistance in attracting more Japanese citizens to visit Kaohsiung. Most Japanese tourists have only visited Taipei and its nearby regions. "We hope more Japanese citizens can travel to Kaohsiung to get a taste of southern Taiwan people's hospitality and the city's beautiful oceanic scenes," Yeh said.
Yeh is accompanied by Legislator Hsiao Bi-khim of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and several Kaohsiung city officials on her Japan visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S.-BASED TAIWAN GROUPS RUN AD CALLING FOR CROSS-STRAIT PEACE
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 20 (CNA) (By Wennie Chi and Taijing Wu)

TEXT.P: Around 20 Taiwanese-American groups published an advertisement in the Thursday edition of the Washington Times urging China not to intimidate democratic Taiwan.
The three-quarter page advertisement also said democratic Taiwan wants to co-exist with China as an independent, friendly neighbor.

The groups put up the advertisement in coincidence with the arrival of Chinese President Hu Jintao in Washington, D.C. for a high-profile visit and talks with U.S. President George W. Bush at the White House.

The advertisement urged China to dismantle the 800 missiles aimed at Taiwan and stop blocking Taiwan's bid to join the World Health Organization. It also pushed China to stop oppressing its own people and offer them religious, assembly and speech freedoms.
Meanwhile, the advertisement asked the United States to allow Taiwan's democratically elected leaders to visit Washington, D.C.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR APRIL 20 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Friday, April 21:
09:00, President Chen Shui-bian will attend a meeting on Taiwan's sustainable economic development at the Civil Service Development Center.
10:00, A seminar on Bush-Hu meeting and Taiwan-U.S.-China relations will be held at National Chengchi University.
11:00, President Chen will meet with Andrew Schally, a Nobel Prize winner in medicine.
16:00, The Mainland Affairs Council will hold a news conference.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. REAFFIRMS ESTABLISHED STANCE ON CROSS-STRAIT ISSUE: MOFA

TEXT.P: Minister of Foreign Affairs Huang Chih-fang said Thursday that both U.S. President George W. Bush and Chinese President Hu Jintao have reaffirmed at a welcoming ceremony for Hu at the White House their governments' established stances on issues regarding Taiwan.
Hu arrived in Washington, D.C. earlier the same day for an official visit and talks with Bush on matters of mutual concern.

In his speech delivered at the welcoming ceremony for Hu, Bush said the U.S. government will continue to deal with cross-Taiwan Strait issues in terms of the three communiques between Washington, D.C. and Beijing as well as the Taiwan Relations Act -- the U.S. law that regulates relations with Taiwan in the absence of official ties.

Bush also galvanized the two sides of the Taiwan Strait to engage in wide-ranging exchanges and avoid conflicts. He further stressed that any cross-strait disputes should be resolved by peaceful means and neither side should take unilateral step to change the status quo.

For his part, Hu reiterated that Taiwan is an inalienable part of China and that China would not tolerate any step to promote formal independence. He also said China would try its utmost to seek peaceful cross-strait unification.
Huang said the MOFA has been closely monitoring developments in Hu's current U.S. visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA UNVEILS NEW LOAN PROJECT TO ENCOURAGE DOMESTIC INVESTMENT

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) unveiled a new loan project Thursday to attract overseas Taiwanese businesspeople to return home to rebuild their business.

According to the MOEA-drafted plan, the Executive Yuan will appropriate NT$200 billion for offering low-interest loans to Taiwan businesspeople who once invested abroad, including China, and now intend to launch new investment projects at home.
If all goes smooth, MOEA officials said, the new loan project will be put into practice by the end of May.

Under the project, prospective investors can apply for loans for land acquisition, factory construction, procurement of automated production facilities and pollution-control equipment, as well as manpower training, research and development, and short-term working capital.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, April 21, or the 24th day of the third month of the Year of Dog according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1634: Jan van Riebeeck, Dutch naval surgeon and founder of Cape Town, South Africa, is born.
1898: The United States declares war on Spain.
1910: Mark Twain, pen name of Samuel Langhorne Clemens, American author and humorist, dies at the age of 74. He drew on his childhood along the Mississippi River to create masterpieces of humor and sarcasm, including "Tom Sawyer" and "The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn."
1926: Elizabeth II, Queen of England since 1952, is born.
1930: Fire breaks out at the Ohio state penitentiary, killing 355 people.
1935: An earthquake hits central and northern Taiwan, killing some 3,000 people.
1937: Steamships formally begin plying a regular weekly route between Shanghai and San Francisco.
1946: British economist John Maynard Keynes dies at the age of 63. He proposed that high unemployment, being a result of insufficient consumer spending, can be relieved by government-sponsored programs.
1948: Republic of China troops evacuate Yenan.
1949: The Chinese communists resume an all-out offensive and cross the Yangtze River.
1954: The United States flies a French battalion to Indochina to defend Dien Bien Phu, which is overrun by Vietnamese forces three weeks later.
1957: Taiwan voters go to the polls for the third time to elect county magistrates, city mayors and provincial assemblymen.
1958: The Taiwan Provincial Assembly building in Wufeng, Taichung County, is inaugurated.
1960: Brazil moves its capital from Rio de Janeiro to Brazilia, the brain-child of President Juselino Kubitschek.
1966: The ROC and Dahomey resume diplomatic relations.
1971: Haitian dictator Francois Duvalier, known as "Papa Doc," dies at the age of 64. Elected president in 1957, he declared himself president for life in 1964 and ruled in an authoritarian manner until his death. He was succeeded by his son Jean-Claude, who fled the country in 1986 after widespread civil unrest.
1975: South Vietnamese President Nguyen Van Thieu resigns after denouncing the United States as untrustworthy.
1987: Terrorists detonate a bomb near the main bus station in Colombo, Sri Lanka, killing and injuring more than 400 people.
1989: More than 10,000 workers and students clamoring for democracy and human rights march from campuses to converge on Tiananmen Square in Beijing in defiance of official warnings against anti-government protests.
1997: An advance contingent of communist Chinese troops enter Hong Kong in preparation for the July 1 handover of the British crown colony to communist China.
1998: Seoul drops efforts to receive Japanese compensation for women held as sex slaves during World War II and says it will pay the surviving women.
1999: A survey conducted by the Switzerland-based Business Environment Risk Intelligence ranks Taiwan as the least risky area for investment in the world.
1999: Renowned local writer Su Hsueh-lin, winner of the Chungshan Literature Prize and the National Literature Prize, dies at the age of 104.
2000: Taiwanese "Go" player Wang Li-cheng wins the title of "Go Sage," the highest title and honor for any Go professional in Japan.
2000: Tsai Ying-wen, an advisor to the National Security Council and a professor at National Chengchi University, is confirmed chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council.
2001: A pro-unification organization urges Taiwan's three main opposition parties to monitor the Democratic Progressive Party-led government to prevent Taiwan from "marching toward independence."
Confucius lesson of the day: "A good horse is considered so not because of its mere brute strength but because of its moral qualities."

DOC.HEADLINE: BUSH REITERATES U.S. DOES NOT SUPPORT TAIWAN INDEPENDENCE
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 20 (CNA) (By Jorge Liu and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: U.S. President George W. Bush reiterated that the United States does not support independence for Taiwan during his meeting with Chinese President Hu Jintao Thursday at the White House.
Bush told a news conference after the meeting that although he and Hu do not agree on everything, they are able to discuss their disagreements "in a spirit of friendship and cooperation."
"We spent time talking about Taiwan, and I assured the president my position has not changed. I do not support independence for Taiwan," Bush said.
For his part, Hu noted that Bush said during the meeting that he hopes the Taiwan authorities do not make any moves to change the status quo which would upset the China-U.S. relationship.

"We have the utmost sincerity, and we will do our utmost with all sincerity to strive for the prospect of peaceful reunification. This being said, we will by no means allow Taiwan independence, " Hu said, reiterating China's long-standing position that "Taiwan is an inalienable part of Chinese territory."

"We maintain consistently that under the basis of the one-China principle, we are committed to the safeguarding of peace and stability in the Taiwan Strait and to the promotion of the improvement and development of cross-strait relations," Hu said.

Addressing an arrival ceremony for Hu held earlier that day at the South Lawn of the White House, Bush said the United States maintains its one-China policy based on the three U.S.-China communiques and the Taiwan Relations Act.

"We oppose unilateral changes in the status quo in the Taiwan Strait by either side, and we urge all parties to avoid confrontational or provocative acts. And we believe the future of Taiwan should be resolved peacefully," Bush said.
In Taipei, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs said in a brief statement that Bush's remarks indicate that the United States' long-standing position on cross-strait issues has remained unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TEAM INVENTS MASS SPECTROMETER FOR MEASURING CELLS, VIRUSES

TEXT.P: A research team at Academia Sinica announced Wednesday that they have created the first mass spectrometer in the world that can measure the mass of cells and viruses.
For decades, scientists have used mass spectrometry to weigh minute substances, such as molecules or particles, but it has never been successfully applied to "larger" ones like cell or viruses.

A mass spectrometer weighs a substance in the following way. First, a laser is used to turn the sample into ionized particles, which are then accelerated in a vacuum toward a detector. Then, researchers can determine the weight of the particles by recording the time elapsed between the particles departing and reaching the detector. By targeting characteristic particles of the viral coat protein, the virus can be identified by matching the results to entries in genetic databases.
However, when it comes to micron-sized substances without rigid walls, like cells or viruses, the ionizing process will usually destroy them, which makes it impossible to weigh them.

Nevertheless, the team at Academia Sinica refined their mass spectrometer by targeting the laser on a silicon wafer to cause acoustic waves, which can "push" the cell or virus out of the sample without destroying it. Then, a quadruple ion trap is applied to catch the subject of interest for mass determination.

The team's research paper, titled "Laser-Induced Acoustic Desorption Mass Spectrometry of Single Bioparticles," was accepted by the renown periodical "Angewandte Chemie" as "very important," a term it has used for only 5 percent of all the research papers it has published.

Dr. Chang Huan-Cheng, the head of the team, said they have already used the method to measure several kinds of cells and viruses, including erythrocyte, vaccinia virus, Escherichia coli, and some cancer cells. Once they finish the study of several other cells and viruses, he said, the complete database can be applied to medical practice, helping doctors to identify the real pathogen of epidemics.
Chang explained that in practice, if there is any epidemic, doctors can now isolate the suspected pathogen and weigh it, then compare the weight to the entries in the database to identify what it is.

"Since the database will also show the normal weight of a particular cell, the doctor can also identify if there is cancer metastasis by noticing that the weight of certain cells are changing," Chang added.
