DOC.HEADLINE: 'PAN GREEN' LAWMAKERS URGE BOTH TAIWAN, CHINA TO CHANGE NAME

TEXT.P: A ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislator said Friday that both Taiwan and China should change their national designations to avoid confusion or fiascos from occurring on international occassions again.

Speaking during a meeting at the Legislative Yuan on affairs of the state, DPP Legislator Chen Chung-hsin said that when U.S. President George W. Bush met with his Chinese counterpart Hu Jintao on the lawn outside the White House for an official meeting Thursday, the People's Republic of China was incorrectly referred to by the announcer as the Republic of China prior to the playing of the national anthems of the United States and China.
Chen attributed the fiasco to the fact that Taiwan's official title of "The Republic of China" is too similar to China's.
Chen suggested that China and Taiwan discard their confusing national designations altogether and simply call themselves China and Taiwan.

Meanwhile, Legislator Lo Chih-ming from the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU), which together with the DPP forms the "pan-green camp, " said that the mistake by the announcer at the White House reflects the fact that it is imperative and justifiable that Taiwan change its official name.
The "pan-green" legislators also unanimously condemned the "Bush-Hu" meeting for downgrading Taiwan's status.

TSU Legislator Mark Ho claimed that while talking about Taiwan during their meeting, the two heads of state actually voiced different positions on the Taiwan issue, with Bush stressing that cross-Taiwan Strait issues should be solved peacefully and the cross-strait status quo should not be changed, and Hu stressing that Taiwan is "an inalienable part of China"

DOC.HEADLINE: 2ND SHANGHAI-TAIWAN FINANCIAL FORUM TO BE HELD IN TAIPEI JUNE 28

TEXT.P: The second financial forum between Shanghai and Taiwan will be held in Taipei June 28, it was learned Monday.
Reports quoted Lu Hongjun, head of the Shanghai Institute of International Finance, as saying that cooperation and a win-win situation for cross-strait finance will be the theme of the forum.
More than 100 representatives from financial institutions across the Taiwan Strait as well as experts and scholars will take part in the forum.
The first Shanghai-Taiwan financial forum was held in Shanghai in October 2004.

DOC.HEADLINE: CIER REVISES FORECAST FOR TAIWAN'S ECONOMIC GROWTH TO 4.17% FOR 2006

TEXT.P: The Chung Hua Institution for Economic Research (CIER) on Friday revised its forecast for Taiwan's economic growth to 5.39 percent for the first quarter of this year and 4.17 percent for the whole of 2006 in light of the country's excellent foreign trade performance.
The think tank predicted that economic growth will reach 4.55 percent for the second quarter of this year, 3.74 percent for the third quarter and 3.09 percent for the fourth quarter.

While Taiwan's export orders are valued at more than US$20 billion per month and have posted a growth rate of over 20 percent for seven consecutive months, the country's foreign trade is expected to continue to see strong growth this year, according to the CIER.

It projected that private-sector spending will expand by a moderate 3.12 percent this year, owing to the negative growth in salaries and the problem of "credit card slaves, " which has prompted local banks to tighten their credit services.
The CIER predicted that domestic investment will rise 4.57 percent this year, up 4.1 percentage points over last year.
Exports are expected to reach US$215.51 billion this year and imports are expected to amount to US$200.29 billion, it said.
Meanwhile, the CIER forecast that the country's consumer price index will rise 1.82 percent for 2006.

DOC.HEADLINE: RESEARCHER DEVELOPS NEW DRUG FOR CHOREA

TEXT.P: Chern Yi-juang, a researcher at Academia Sinica, said Thursday that he has developed a new drug to help treat chorea, allowing clinical doctors to control the symptoms, such as irregular and involuntary movements.
Chorea, a primary feature of Huntington's disease, is caused by the over-activity of the neurotransmitter dopamine in the brain areas that control movement.
Chern said that the new drug is designed to control and revitalize the movement control area in the brain and thus help patients gain better control over their body movements.
Noting that the new drug, extracted from herbs, has proved effective on mice, Chern said testing on humans will begin as soon as authorities give the green light.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Bush, Hu Produce Summit of Symbols; Protester Screams At Chinese President.
President Bush pressed China's visiting President Hu Jintao yesterday to open up markets, expand freedom and do more to curb nuclear programs in Iran and North Korea but came away with no specific agreements in a summit emphasizing symbolism over breakthroughs.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Prodi urged to decide House speakership.
The Democratic Left Party, which is the largest party in the opposition Union led by Romano Prodi, urged the Union leader Thursday to decide the the House speakership. The Democratic Left is pitting against the Communist Refoundation Party in a battle for the leading parliamentary post. The Supreme Court announced a day earlier that Prodi's center-left alliance won the April 9-10 general elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Straits Times: Polling day: May 6.
On May 6, Mr Lee Hsien Loong leads the ruling People's Action Party (PAP) to the polls for the first time in what he describes as a 'very important election' to secure Singapore's future.
The Lianhe Zaobao: Nomination Day is April 27, Polling Day is May 6.
The Singapore government has announced that the 2006 General Election will be held on May 6, with Nomination Day falling on April 27. (By Charles Kang)

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Moscow Times: Gazprom Warning Has EU Worried
Amid growing tensions between the European Union and Gazprom, an EU spokesman said Thursday that the gas monopoly's warning to European countries not to block its expansion had intensified fears about growing reliance on Russian gas. ( By Chang Hung-kuang)

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Manila Bulletin: SC voids EO 464 provisions
Malacanang says it will respect decision The Supreme Court (SC) , voting unanimously, yesterday declared void two portions of Executive Order No. 464 while upholding the power of Congress to compel the appearance of executive officials in its inquiries in aid of legislation.
The Philippine Daily Inquirer: High court strikes down major parts of EO 464
THE SUPREME COURT yesterday upheld the right of lawmakers to compel the appearance of executive officials at congressional inquiries, and stressed that the issue involving Executive Order No. 464 pertained not only to Congress' right to know but also the people's right to take part in government affairs.
The Philippine Star: SC voids portions of EO 464
The Supreme Court struck down yesterday portions of the controversial Executive Order (EO) No. 464 issued by President Arroyo last year that had barred officials from testifying in Congress without her consent.
The Manila Times: SC deals Palace a blow on EO 464
THE Supreme Court on Thursday ruled that President Arroyo's order banning Cabinet and military officials from testifying at legislative inquiries is unconstitutional.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Los Angeles Times: Rove's Role Cut and McClellan Out in Shake-Up.
Moving to reinvigorate his presidency and recover from low public approval ratings, President Bush on Wednesday reduced the official role that Karl Rove, his chief political strategist, will play in setting policy, and accepted the resignation of spokesman Scott McCellan.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Japan Times: Tokyo, Seoul scurry to avert islet clash
Japanese and South Korea negotiators raced Thursday to avert a clash over disputed islets as Seoul accused Tokyo of neocolonial ambitions and warned of a possible high seas confrontation.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN HOPES FOR 2ND MEETING WITH KMT HEAD

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian expressed the hope Friday that he can meet with opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou again before long to facilitate Taiwan's pursuit of sustainable economic, environmental and social development.
Speaking duing a ceremony marking the opening of a national sustainable development conference, Chen said that he remains open regarding the time and venue for a second Chen-Ma meeting.

Chen said he was enormously impressed and grateful to Ma for his explanations made during their first meeting held at the Presidential Office April 3 about his U.S. trip in March and his suggestions to the government.
For his part, Ma said he has let the Presidential Office know that he will not attend a second Chen-Ma meeting.

He added that the country has come to understand clearly the president's stance on several key issues via the televised Chen-Ma meeting. For other matters in the future, he said, should they be matters concerning the Executive Yuan or the Legislative Yuan, they should be referred to the two yuans for resolution, tacitly implying that a second Chen-Ma meeting is unnecessary.
Presidential Office Secretary-General Tan Sun Chen said earlier this week that he wrote to KMT Secretary-General Chan Chun-po days earlier about the new invitation but had not received any response.
The holding of a second Chen-Ma meeting has been the hope of Chen, the DPP hierarchy and the DPP legislative caucus since April 3, when Chen met Ma at the Presidential Office, Tan Sun Chen said.

However, he continued, the KMT has been cool in its reaction to the notion of a second meeting, which he claimed would be conducive to boosting harmony between the ruling and opposition parties. Harmonious engagement between the parties is the mainstream opinion in Taiwan, he said, adding that the first Chen-Ma meeting was also received favorably by the U.S. administration.

During the first, unprecedented Chen-Ma meeting, the two men talked about a wide range of topics, including the definition of the controversial "1992 consensus" and the cessation of the National Unification Council and its guidelines.
After the meeting, President Chen's approval ratings soared by 11 percentage points, while Ma's dropped by nine percentage points, according to a poll conducted by a local television station.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEEDS TO UPGRADE ITS DEMOCRACY: FORMER LAWMAKER
DOC.DATELINE: Boston, April 20 (CNA) (By Eric Tseng & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: In Taiwan's political environment, elections decide everything, said a former Taiwan lawmaker and governmental official Thursday.

However, "elections aren't everything in a democratic nation, " Lou Wen-chia said in an interview with CNA on the campus of Harvard University. Lou was once praised as the best-performing lawmaker at the Legislative Yuan by journalists stationed there.

"People's self-discipline and knowledge of democracy, as well as a culture of democracy, are the crucial factors that decide the quality of democracy," Luo said, claiming that these are things that Taiwan lacks.
Luo said that Taiwan does not lack an election system, which he claimed is even more complete than that in the United States.

"Taiwan does not lack freedom of speech, either; what Taiwan's democracy does not have is quality, " Lou said, underscoring that what Taiwan needs now is to upgrade its democratic practices and political culture.
Luo arrived at Harvard University two weeks ago to pursue further education in his capacity as an international scholar of the Fairbank Center for East Asian Research.

During his planned eight-month stay at Harvard, Luo said that he intends to engage in research on cross-Taiwan Strait relations, explaining that he wants to know the political perspectives and the possible political structure of Taiwan in the next five or 10 years.
Luo, one of the most popular members of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, was defeated by Chou Hsi-wei of the opposition Kuomintang in the Taipei County magistrate election last December.
Speaking on the setback, the 40-year-old politician said that "it was no more than an election; life still goes on."

Luo said his life on campus is relaxing, although his schedule is filled, with reading, surfing the Internet, jogging and chatting with Taiwanese students. "Suddenly I've become a lot younger," he said.

Mentioning his experience of going to see a professional baseball game in Boston and witnessing the passion the American people have for sports, Luo said he wonders why Taiwan uses all of its energy on vicious political conflicts.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI SHARE PRICES END LOWER

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened high but closed lower Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 9.69 points to close at 7,093.05.
The bourse opened at 7,130.68 and fluctuated between 7,160.74 and 7,092.93 during trading. A total of 5.32 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$167.78 billion (US$5.2 billion).
Two of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with textile stocks and machinery and electronics shares both moving up at 0.4 percent.

The six other major stock categories lost ground, with paper and plup issues moving down the most at 2.9 percent, followed by foodstuff issues at 2 percent, cement stocks at 1.4 percent, plastics and chemicals shares at 1 percent, banking and financial shares at 0.7 percent, and construction issues at 0.2 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 520 to 353, with 119 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HOPES TO BECOME WHA OBSERVER: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian expressed his hope Friday that Taiwan will be admitted as an observer into the World Health Assembly (WHA) , the decision-making body of the World Health Organization (WHO), to enable it to contribute more to global public health efforts.

Saying that disease and healthcare should know no borders, Chen said he does not want to see Taiwan continue to be excluded from the world health group, becoming the only loophole in the global disease prevention system.
He said Taiwan is very willing to do its duty as a member of the global village, particularly in efforts to improve medical care, public health and disease prevention around the world.

Chen made the remarks during a brief meeting at the Presidential Office with visiting members of the International Congress of Oral Implantologists (ICOI) led by Dr. Kenneth Judy, chairman of the ICOI World Federation.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S.-PRC MEETING MARKS END OF DEALING WITH NUC ISSUE: LEGISLATOR

TEXT.P: The meeting between U.S. President George W. Bush and Chinese President Hu Jintao can be seen as marking an end to the two countries' dealings with the controversy surrounding President Chen Shui-bian's cessation of the National Unification Council (NUC), Legislator Su Chi of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) claimed Friday.

Su, a former chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council, made the remarks after the Bush-Hu meeting at the White House a day earlier during which Bush reiterated that the U.S. does not support independence for Taiwan, while Hu claimed that Taiwan is an inalienable part of Chinese territory and that China will promote peaceful unification with the utmost sincerity.

In contrast to the serious concerns expressed by both China and the United States following Chen's February "ceasing of the function" of the NUC, a body that envisioned eventual unification with China, Su said that remarks made by Bush and Hu Thursday were "quite standardized."
Su said that as he expected, they did not use harsh words.

He said the U.S. accorded KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou with high-level treatment during his visit to the United States last month. The U.S. also expressed the hope for stable cross-strait relations to let the Taiwan people know clearly where the U.S. stands.

On the other hand, Hu used a meeting with Lien, honorary chairman of the KMT, last Sunday, to say to the Taiwan people that Beijing attaches importance to cross-strait trade, economy and peace, and even offered 15 "goodwill measures" to Taiwan, according to Su.
The U.S. and China's way of dealing with Chen's announcement has been "indirect, " but has "embarrassed the DPP administration, " Su claimed.
Chen pledged "five noes, " including no scrapping of the NUC if China has no intention to use force against Taiwan, in his inaugural speeches in 2000 and again in 2004.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAX REFORMS CRUCIAL TO UPHOLDING SOCIAL JUSTICE: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian pledged Friday that the government will continue to enhance social justice and fairness by promoting tax reforms.

Chen noted that measures taken by the government under the reforms include introducing a minimum tax rate targeting high-income earners and shaping up the retirement benefit program for civil servants, military personnel and public school teachers.
"While pursuing economic development, we must not neglect the promotion and realization of social fairness and justice," Chen said.
"By the same token, when seeking national development, we must not focus on economic development only, but we must also pay attention to sustainable development," he added.
The president made the remarks while addressing a national sustainable development conference hosted by the National Council for Sustainable Development.
Chen said Taiwan has a stronger need than other countries to sustain its development because it is a small yet populous country with scant natural resources and a fragile geographic environment.
Therefore, Taiwan should develop its economy on the basis of protecting its environment and natural resources, Chen said.
He said Taiwan has created a world-acclaimed economic miracle with the collective efforts of the people over the past five decades, but that the country has also paid a great price.
While the over-emphasis on economic growth has led to severe pollution and damage to the environment, such excessive exploitation is now meeting backlashes from nature, he noted.

For example, the over-development of hillside land has resulted in the loss of topsoil and water resources, with the lifespans of reservoirs having declined significantly and the problem of water shortages becoming more and more severe year after year, he said.

The over-development of coastal land has caused the ratio of artificial coastline to exceed that of natural coastline in Taiwan, and the over-drainage of underground water has led to subsidence and in-flow of sea water, he went on.
Also, illegal gravel extraction and waste dumping on fallow farmland are seriously jeopardizing the use of land resources, he said.
Therefore, he said, the country needs to seek to improve its environmental protection to balance the economic development and enhance the quality of life.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP AFFIRMS BUSH'S INSISTENCE ON SECURITY COMMITMENT TO TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Ruling Democratic Progressive Party Chairman (DPP) Yu Shyi-kun extended his gratitude to U.S. President
George. W. Bush Friday for reaffirming security commitment to Taiwan during a meeting with Chinese President Hu Jintao a day earlier.

According to Yu, Bush said at Thursday's meeting with Hu that the U.S. government opposes unilateral changes in the status quo in the Taiwan Strait by either side and that the future of Taiwan should be resolved peacefully.
"Bush has not deviated from his consistent stance and has not harmed Taiwan's interests," Yu said.

He also expressed appreciation for Bush's insistence on the United States' security promise to Taiwan, not accepting China's "one China principle, " and opposing any "non-peaceful" method by China to handle cross-strait issues.

Yu noted that Taiwan is very willing to cooperate with the United States in safeguarding cross-strait peace, promoting regional democracy and establishing a fair and reasonable economic and trade environment, especially with regard to intellectual property rights, as both Taiwan and the U.S. are victims of China's pirated goods.
The DPP also strongly protested against Hu's public opposition to talks with Taiwan on an equal footing, Yu said.
In addition, Hu also reiterated China's position that "Taiwan is an inalienable part of Chinese territory, " ruling out the Taiwan people's option of independence, Yu added.
Hu's intention to make Taiwan one of China's local governments is very clear, which the DPP also protested.

Claiming that recognizing democracy and liberty is the basis for the two sides of Taiwan Strait to develop peacefully, Yu said Hu should recognize Taiwan's existence, accept the Taiwan people's right to choose their future, and present firm promises to promote China's democracy and human rights so that the two sides can co-exist peacefully.

"Democracy is democracy, and there is no debate on this," Yu said, adding that any movement to harm democratization, religious freedom and the freedom of speech will be renounced by history. Yu expressed hope that Hu will not stand on the wrong side of history.
Meanwhile, he also urged the Taiwan people to distinguish between the opportunities and threats from China, claiming that "even American people will not blindly embrace China" for economic benefits.
However, Yu added, some politicians in Taiwan, including opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Honorary Chairman Lien Chan, have been "kowtowing" to China under the excuse of promoting cross-strait exchanges.

Lien recently headed a 170-member delegation of lawmakers and business leaders to participate in a two-day economic forum held between the KMT and the Communist Party of China in Beijing, in which he received a high-profile welcome from Hu.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES LOWER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower Friday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for May moved down 16 points to close at 7,105, with 38,249 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for June dropped 22 points to finish at 7,084, with 254 contracts traded, while September futures lost one point to close at 6,904, with 39 contract transactions.
December futures moved down 14 points to close at 6,890, with 16 contracts traded, while March futures rose 67 points to finish at 6,977, with one contract transactions.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Friday at 7,121 for May, 7,106 for June, 6,905 for September, 6,904 for December and 6,910 for March.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mixed.

May TE futures moved up 1.7 points to close at 318.5, with 5,905 contracts traded, while June TE futures gained 1.7 points to finish at 317.2, with 48 contract transactions. September TE futures moved up 4.35 points to close at 312.95, with two contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

May TF futures dropped 7.8 points to finish at 928.2, with 2,355 contracts changing hands, while June TF futures gained 0.2 points to close at 935, with four contracts traded. September TF futures moved down four points to finish at 916, with one contract traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW TAIWAN ENVOY TO E.U., BELGIUM NAMED

TEXT.P: Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs Michael Ying-mao Kau has been designated by President Chen Shui-bian to serve as Taiwan's representative to the European Union and Belgium, said Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) officials Friday.
Kau will succeed Chen Chien-jen who is going to retire after a long diplomatic career.
Kau, 72, holds a bachelor's degree in politics from National Taiwan University and a master's degree and doctorate in comparative politics and international relations from Cornell University.

Before Kau joined the MOFA in 2002, he had been a professor of politics at Brown University in the United States, chairman of the Association of Chinese Social Scientists in North America, an advisor of the Institute of International Relations at National Chengchi University, and a member of the Advisory Committee of the National Security Council.

An expert in relations between Taiwan and countries in the South Pacific, as well as Japan and the United States, he has always been conscientious in his efforts to promote Taiwan's access to the World Health Assembly as an observer. Kau has visited Europe many times to lobby for the bid, the MOFA officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Friday, losing NT$0.002 to close at NT$32.309.
A total of US$1.082 billion changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at the day's high of NT$32.330 and hit a low of NT$32.235.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT TO SUPPORT MEASURES FAVORABLE TO PUBLIC: PREMIER

TEXT.P: The government will support the conclusions reached during a recent meeting between the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and the Communist Party of China (CPC) as long as they are beneficial to the people of Taiwan and do not compromise Taiwan's identity, Premier Su Tseng-chang said Friday.
Su said the government will not resist the conclusions just because they were announced by the KMT or Beijing, and that President Chen Shui-bian also shares this view.

Su was referring to a package of 15 measures announced by Chinese officials during the KMT-CPC economic forum held last week in Beijing. These include the recognition of academic degrees conferred by accredited Taiwan universities, allowing Chinese citizens to travel to Taiwan for sightseeing purposes and permitting qualified Taiwan physicians to practise in China.

Su noted during an interpellation session at the Legislative Yuan that the government long ago announced a policy of allowing visits to Taiwan by Chinese tourists but that Beijing has refused to lift travel restrictions on its people for the past four years.
Su pointed out that Beijing has also declined to negotiate with the government on affairs involving the exercise of government authority.

On KMT Honorary Chairman Lien Chan's performance in Beijing, Su said it is regrettable that Lien did not mention the "Republic of China" -- his version of "one China" -- despite his repeated insistence that both sides of the Taiwan Strait should be allowed to interpret the meaning of "one China" on their own terms.

DOC.HEADLINE: NUCLEAR PLANTS SHOULD BE KEPT: ACADEMIA SINICA HEAD

TEXT.P: Until recycled energy technology matures, Taiwan will have to rely on nuclear power as long as clean air and sustainable development issues are concerned, Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh said Friday.

In a keynote speech delivered at the National Sustainable Development Conference, Lee, a 1986 Nobel laureate in chemistry, said Taiwan should continue developing nuclear power in the next one to two decades and that construction of the Fourth Nuclear Power Plant should not be further stalled.

Lee said that so long as radioactive waste is "properly handled, " Taiwan basically faces no problems as regards nuclear safety protection, adding that the existing second and third nuclear power plants should continue to function, while the fourth should continue to be built.

He speculated that Taiwan's dream of becoming a nuclear-free country will probably not come true for another 50 years, when optoelectronic technology and technologies of solar energy and other recyclable energy become truly mature.

After the Kyoto Protocol entered into force in February 2005, he said, the reduction of carbon dioxide (CO2) emissions has become an imperative task globally and Taiwan should not slack off in this effort. Consequently, he said, Taiwan should strive to lessen its reliance on coal and fossil fuel for energy so as to reduce emissions of greenhouse gases.

Emissions of CO2 have continued to increase worldwide and in Taiwan as well, Lee said, adding that per capita CO2 emission in Taiwan averages 12.4 tons annually, second only to the United States' 19.95 tons and Australia's 19.1 tons, serving a "tremendously bad" example for the world.
However, Professor Shih Hsin-min from National Taiwan University discounted Lee during the conference, saying that all of Taiwan's nuclear power plants should be closed down immediately.

Shih pointed out that problems concerning Taiwan's nuclear waste management are rife, the safety of Taiwan's existing nuclear power plants remains to be examined and the world trend of reducing greenhouse gas emissions is by developing recyclable energy and optoelectronic technology, rather than pushing for nuclear power.

He called for the government to push for nationwide energy-saving regulations and come up with policies soon to encourage the development of optoelectronic and renewable energy, rather than continuing to build the fourth nuclear power plant.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI COUNTY SCRAPS BOT MODEL FOR BELT LINE MRT

TEXT.P: Taipei County's belt line rapid transit railway project will no longer follow the build-operate-transfer (BOT) model in view of the corruption scandal involving the Kaohsiung mass rapid transit (MRT) railway project, Taipei County Magistrate Chou Hsi-wei said Friday.

Chou told a press conference that the county government has decided to build, own and operate its own MRT system after seeing how the BOT model adopted by the Kaohsiung city government for its MRT railway project has been used for illegal profiteering by officials working in collusion with contractors.
Another reason for the policy reversal is that the county government wants to ensure the quality of the construction project and give Taipei County residents a safe MRT system.

He said the central government has approved the route of the belt line for the first stage of the project and that the county government's reversal of its policy will not affect the progress of the construction.
Chou acknowledged that the change will cause the budget to rise by NT$16 billion, of which the county government hopes that NT$3.1 billion can come from a central government subsidy.

As for the remaining NT$12.9 billion, the county government estimates that benefits accruing from land development projects surrounding the belt line will total NT$13.5 billion within 12 years -- more than enough to cover the added cost.

Chou urged the central government to support the Taipei county government with additional funds. He said that if the central government denies his request, he will appeal to the Legislative Yuan for help.
The county government will work out a new budget plan and a detailed feasibility analysis, Chou said, adding that the entire project is expected to be completed in 2013.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA ACCEPTS U.S. STATEMENT ON TAIWAN `GRUDGINGLY:' ACADEMIC

TEXT.P: U.S. President George W. Bush set the tone on the Taiwan issue during a welcome ceremony for Chinese President Hu Jintao, and although Hu was discontent, he could only grudgingly accept it, a professor at Tamkang University said Friday.
Professor Pan Hsi-tang of the university's Institute of China Research was giving his take on a meeting between Bush and Hu a day earlier.

During a welcome ceremony held on the South Lawn of the White House, Bush reiterated that the U.S. policy toward Taiwan is based on the three comuniques and the Taiwan Relations Act. The U.S. opposes unilateral changes in the status quo in the Taiwan Strait by either side and it believes that the Taiwan issue should be resolved peacefully, Bush said.
According to Pan, Bush "thinks that he has had the controversy surrounding President Chen Shui-bian's cessation of the National Unification Council well under control" and wants Beijing to stay calm.

He pointed out that Beijing exercised a great deal of "self-restraint" after President Chen Shui-bian's announcement of the cessation of the National Unification Council in late February, fearing that any "strong reactions" would only backfire.

In contrast, the United States has continued to use various ways to display its strong displeasure since Chen's announcement, but in the end Beijing's hopes of the U.S. "reining in" Taipei were dashed after seeing the U.S. "saying much but doing little."

Bush made known his stance on Taiwan during Hu's visit mainly because he hopes to dispel suspicion on the part of the Beijing authorities that Taiwan and the U.S. were complicit in the controversy, or that the U.S. was indulging the advocacy of Taiwan independence, Pan said.
But Bush also hoped that China would not overreact or made a fuss about it, and that the focus of the meeting would not be the Taiwan issue, according to Pan.

Pan analyzed that Bush believed the U.S. had done everything it could after Chen's announcement. This, coupled with the fact that the Taiwan government has not made any follow-up moves toward de jure independence, has made Bush think it is not meaningful to "continue to stall on the issue."

The U.S. approach is to keep an even keel in its cross-strait approach, avoiding a tilt toward Beijing and hoping that China will resume its dialogue with the elected government of Taiwan soon, according to Pan.

DOC.HEADLINE: RECOGNITION OF CHINA'S DIPLOMAS NEEDS CAREFUL REVIEW: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Recognizing China's academic accreditations would require comprehensive review because the move could impact Taiwan's education policy, job market and even national security, Premier Su Tseng-chang said Friday.

Su made the remarks during a legislative interpellation session in which main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Legislator Kao Su-po questioned the rationale behind the government's refusal to recognize China's university diplomas.
According to Su, the rampant use of fake school diplomas in China is only a minor factor in the consideration of the issue.

The main cause of the government's reluctance to recognize China's tertiary academic accreditation lies with other concerns, including whether the recognition would have a negative impact on Taiwan's education policy, industrial development, job market and national security.

Noting that academic accreditation is done at administrative discretion, Su said the KMT's inclusion of promoting mutual recognition of university diplomas in its 15-point consensus reached with the Communist Party of China at the end of an economic forum sponsored by the two parties in Beijing last week is not binding to Taiwan's government.

Acknowledging that Taiwan has a glut of tertiary education institutions, Su said the Ministry of Education is working on a supervisory mechanism that would require poorly managed colleges or universities to shut down. However, he added that the reluctance to recognize China's diplomas has nothing to do with the glut of local schools as has been claimed by some opposition political figures.

DOC.HEADLINE: STUDENT WITH MUSCULAR DYSTROPHY HONORED FOR FACING LIFE BRAVELY

TEXT.P: A student at Pingtung Senior High School who suffers from the incurable disease of muscular dystrophy, was presented with a medal Friday by a private charity for his courage in facing life's challenges.

In a ceremony held at the school, 18-year-old Lin Yu-wei was awarded with the Loving Life Medal by the Chou Ta-kuan Foundation, as well as an iPod from Lin's idol -- Vice Premier Tsai Ing-wen -- who attended the ceremony in southern Pingtung County.

Muscular dystrophy covers a group of more than 30 genetic diseases characterized by progressive weakness and degeneration of the skeletal muscles that control movement. Few sufferers attain the age of 20.
Lin, whose two sisters died from the disease at the ages of 14 and 15, respectively, cannot even eat or brush his teeth without assistance.

Speaking at the ceremony, Lin said he felt anger and pain during his childhood because he could not play with the other children, but he added that he learned to come to terms with his physical restrictions, knowing that some facts in life cannot be changed and that complaining would not make his life any better.
"Although I can't determine how long I will live, I have decided to face each day with courage and value it as a precious gift from God," he said.
He said he appreciates his parents for their care and his teachers and classmates for their support, which not only makes his life colorful but has also become a part of his life.
Wang Che-hua, one of his classmates, said Lin is the wiseacre of his class, who broadens the horizons of everyone around him and encourages them.
"He helps us more than we help him," Wang said.
Tsai, who had not met Lin until Friday, said she presented him with an iPod, which she has begrudged buying for herself because she knew it would be more useful to Lin than to herself.
The Chou Ta-kuan Foundation was originally set to present the medal to Lin in May but moved it ahead to Friday to coincide with his birthday.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXECUTIVE YUAN TO OPEN WEBSITE FOR KIDS

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan is scheduled to inaugurate a Web site Saturday as part of its efforts to help children obtain information about the country and government, officials said Friday.

The Web site, titled Children's E Amusement Park and located at http: //kids.ey.gov.tw, is an idea of Premier Su Tseng-chang, who attaches great importance to the care and education of children and hopes the Web site will help them understand the concepts of a country and an administration, and help young people develop into responsible citizens, the officials said.
The site has six major themes -- knowing the Executive Yuan, children and policies, activity information, games, information about Taiwan, and relevant links.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC URGES PEACE, DEMOCRACY TO RESOLVE CROSS-STRAIT DISPUTES

TEXT.P: Only peace and democracy will resolve cross-Taiwan Strait disputes, an official of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said Friday.

MAC Vice Chairman Liu Teh-shun made the remarks one day after U.S. President George W. Bush told Chinese President Hu Jintao that the U.S. opposes unilateral changes in the status quo in the Taiwan Strait and that differences between the two sides should be resolved peacefully.

Liu lauded Bush's statement, saying that it conforms with the United Nations' charter, which says peace is the only way to settle international disputes and which is also in line with the government's policy.
He noted that China has engaged in a rapid military buildup in recent years despite the lack of an outside threat, which he said has caused widespread misgivings in the international community.
The large number of missiles and submarines China has deployed threatens peace-loving Taiwan and its neighbors, he continued.

China also enacted the Anti-Session Law, which codifies the use of force against Taiwan should the nation move toward de jure independence. This law grossly violates the international convention regarding peaceful resolution of disputes, he added.

He said the status quo in the Taiwan Strait is that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait are independent of one another, the sovereignty of Taiwan lies with its people and only the Taiwan people have the right to decide their future.

"Taiwan will not rule out the possibility of developing any types of relations with China," he said, adding, however, that Taiwan is already a democratic country and that the resolution of cross-strait disputes will have to be agreed by the Taiwan people through the democratic process.

Hu's statement that "Taiwan is an inalienable part of China's territory" has been a serious threat to changing the status quo in the Taiwan Strait and the international community should express serious concern, Liu said.
This will help avoid any misjudgment on the part of China and will help it avoid sabotaging the current status quo in the Taiwan Strait, Liu added.

Liu said it is government policy to promote democracy in China and that the MAC will urge the international community to ask the Chinese government to lift its ban on certain newspapers, remove censorship and release all prisoners of conscience.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR ENCOURAGES CHILDREN TO READ

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou read the story, titled The Parcel of Kate's, for students from elementary schools in Taipei Friday and encouraged children to read from a young age to cultivate the habit of reading.
Ma offered his encouragement during the opening ceremony of a "non-stop reading in town" event organized by the Department of Education of the Taipei city government.

Ma expressed concern about the reading situation of new immigrant parents and their children and added his hope that such families can live joyfully and understand more about Taiwan through reading local books.

The Department of Education also collected 15,000 books from 150 schools to initiate other reading activities. The city government will give the books to students in remote districts of Taiwan. (Timothy J. Hwang)

DOC.HEADLINE: JOBLESS RATE BELOW 4 PERCENT FOR 5TH CONSECUTIVE MONTH: DGBAS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's unemployment rate was 3.87 percent in March, the fifth consecutive month in which the figure was less than 4 percent and a new March low for nearly six years, the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) said Friday.
DGBAS officials said the number of employed totaled 10.029 million in March, up by 23,000 from the previous month. The number of jobless totaled 404,000 in March, down by 4,000 from February.

With the advent of the economic turnaround, the officials said, the number of first-time job seekers was cut by 4,000, the numbers of those who became unemployed because of dissatisfaction with their jobs or the end of temporary jobs were also cut by 2,000 and 1,000, respectively.
But the number of jobless as a result of closures or scaling down of workplaces increased 5,000 in March, the officials said, mainly because of the end of the Chinese New Year holiday.
The average number of weeks without employment was 25.3 weeks in March, or 0.2 weeks less than the previous month, the officials added.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEMOCRACY KEY ISSUE IN U.S.-TAIWAN-CHINA TIES: MINISTER

TEXT.P: Minister of Foreign Affairs Huang Chih-fang said Friday he believes that China's democratization was the key issue during a meeting between U.S. President George W. Bush and Chinese President Hu Jintao a day earlier.

Huang, who kept a close watch Thursday on Hu's first official visit to the United States since assuming office, noted that the issue of China's democratization is the core problem in the triangular relations among the United States, China and Taiwan as well as relations across the Taiwan Strait.

"We are pleased to see that Bush reaffirmed the U.S. government's opposition to unilateral changes in the status quo in the Taiwan Strait by either side, " Huang said, adding that Bush's remarks were consistent with Taiwan's stance.
In addition, both U.S. and Taiwan concerns over China's democratization are also consistent, Huang added.

Huang pointed out that when Hu was asked by a journalist when China will implement democratization, he answered that he did not quite understand the meaning of "democracy" as defined by the reporter, and then he talked about what he described as "Chinese style" democratization.

On this question, Huang said it is quite simple for many people. Basically, democracy means that people can choose their leaders freely, that people can participate in the policy-making process of their country, and that both the people and the government can respect and protect the opinions and the rights of the minority, Huang added.

"While China has always said that the 'Taiwan problem' is the most sensitive issue in its relations with the United States, we believe that the democratization issue is the core problem in the trilateral relations," Huang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAINAN AUTOMATION INDUSTRY TRADE FAIR OPENS
DOC.DATELINE: Tainan County, southern Taiwan, April 21 (CNA) (By Han Nai-kuo)

TEXT.P: The Tainan Automation Industry Exhibition opened Friday, with 217 exhibitors from home and abroad taking part.
The exhibition, at the Taiwan Beru Exhibition Center in Jenteh township, Tainan County, will last until April 25.
The exhibition hall is divided into six areas for different categories of machines. Altogether there are 550 stalls run by the exhibitors.
The Kaohsiung-based Metal Industries Research and Development Center has a special area all by itself, putting its research results on show with a focus on micro mold and die technology.

Gildemeister Group, a German machine tool manufacturing company with 135 years of expertise, is also displaying its top-of-the-line products at the show, including lathes, milling machines, and a new compact vertical machining center.
According to organizers, entry to the exhibition is free and the exhibition center will open from 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. during the exhibition period.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER APPRECIATES U.S. EMPHASIS ON SECURITY COMMITMENT TO TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang said Friday that he appreciates U.S. President George W. Bush's emphasis on the U.S. security commitment to Taiwan and the preservation of peace in the Taiwan Strait in a meeting with Chinese President Hu Jintao at the White House a day earlier.

Fielding questions at a Legislative Yuan interpellation session, Su said he admires Bush's advocacy of freedom, democracy and peace during talks with Hu, who is currently on an official visit to the United States.
"As the leader of a world power, Bush didn't hesitate to preach universal values of peace, democracy and freedom in his meeting with his counterpart from Communist China," Su said.
Su further said that democratization is Taiwan's most invaluable asset.
"Taiwan stands firm in the world because it upholds the values of freedom and democracy, which distinguishes it from China," he added. (Timothy J. Hwang)

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S MEDICAL GROUP IN PANAMA TO OFFER FREE TREATMENT
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, April 21 (CNA) (By Ramon Huang and Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: A Republic of China medical delegation headed by presidential adviser Twu Shing-jer is in Panama to offer free treatment to Panamanians.

According to ROC Ambassador to Panama Hou Ping-fu, the medical group, organized by the International Cooperation and Development Fund under Taiwan's Ministry of Foreign Affairs, will conduct five medical trips to Panama's capital city and its hinterland.
In addition to free medical services, Taiwan will also donate toys, clothes, shoes, bicycles, and wheelchairs to Panama's poor families and the disabled.
After its trip to Panama, the medical delegation will proceed to Guatemala to offer free medical services there.

Twu, a former minister of the Department of Health, said the delegation forms part of Taiwan's medical services to its diplomatic allies and that the ROC government may consider strengthening its cooperation with biotechnology industries in these countries in the future.

Taiwan will send 12 medical delegations abroad this year and donate medical equipment to countries in need, as well as strengthen cooperation with hospitals and clinics of ROC's diplomatic allies, Twu said.
Twu stressed that Taiwan has not been permitted to join the World Health Organization (WHO) and as a result fell victim to the severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) outbreak in 2003.
Although more and more countries are supporting Taiwan's bid to enter the WHO, Taiwan continues to be excluded from the world organization due to China's objections, Twu added.
Blocking Taiwan from entering the WHO is unfair to the health of its 23 million citizens, and unfair to those underdeveloped countries that need Taiwan's assistance, he said.
Thanks to the help of many other countries Taiwan's medical achievements rank among the world's best, Twu said, adding that Taiwan is willing to share its medical expertise with other countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEEDS A NEW APPROACH IN LATIN AMERICA: MOFA OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Taiwan needs to explore a new approach in cooperating with its Latin American allies in order to prevent China from infiltrating a region where Taiwan has enjoyed international amity, a Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) official said Friday.

China has had its sights set on Latin America since its economic boom, hoping to use financial aid and trade agreements to squeeze Taiwan's dipomatic space in the region, said Jason Ko, Director of the MOFA's Department of Central and South America Affairs, at the 2006 Taiwan-Latin America Forum.
Taiwan must hold its ground in Latin America, where 12 of its 25 diplomatic allies are located, and devise a new approach to replace the traditional way of "dollar diplomacy," Ko stressed.

"Our allies in Latin America wanted a brand new cooperation format instead of simply receiving financial aid. They hope to see more investment from Taiwanese businesses," he said. The "Jung Pang Project," an initiative President Chen Shui-bian proposed during his 2005 trip to Latin America, may be a good start. The NT$7.5 billion (US$250 million) project is aimed at encouraging Taiwanese investment in the region and represents a new diplomatic strategy.

The project was welcomed by foreign representatives who attended the annual forum: Costa Rican Ambassador Oscar Alvarez, Ambassador of the Republic of Paraguay Ramon Diaz Pereira and Guatemalan Ambassador Jorge Ricardo Putseys Uriguen.

"I would describe the relationship between Taiwan and Latin America as 'both getting what they want.' Latin America needs economic assistance while Taiwan needs help in the political arena," said Elisa Wang, Dean of Tamkang University's Graduate Institute of Latin America Studies, which organized the forum.
"With a brand new thinking and approach, I believe Taiwan and Latin America can create a 'win-win' situation," Wang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOV'T WEIGHING FEASIBILITY OF PAY HIKE FOR CIVIL SERVANTS: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang said Friday he has asked relevant government agencies to study the feasibility of a pay raise for civil servants, military personnel and public school teachers amid an upward spiral of domestic consumer prices.

Su made the remarks during a legislative interpellation session in which opposition People First Party Legislator Lin Hui-kuan asked the premier to clarify whether the government is likely to raise salaries for government employees, military members and public school teachers July 1.
The government has usually adjusted its payroll Jan. 1 to coincide with the start of the new year and has seldom made adjustments from July 1, Su said.

As the domestic inflationary pressure is gaining momentum following a steep 9.2 percent rise in gasoline prices announced by state-owned Chinese Petroleum Corp. earlier this week, Su said he has directed the Central Personnel Administration and financial departments to keep a close watch on the local market situation and evaluate the feasibility of raising the government's payroll.
"Key elements to be gauged will include the government's financial status, the general economic situation and the payscale of major private industries," Su said.

While the premier didn't rule out the possibility of a pay raise for all public functionaries and school teachers, Su said the government should consider its finances before making a final decision on any pay raise proposals. The timing and the range of adjustments must also be considered, Su added, (By Sofia Wu) ednitem/diG

DOC.HEADLINE: WOMAN DIES AFTER JUMPING IN FRONT OF MRT TRAIN

TEXT.P: A 57-year-old woman passenger died Friday afternoon after jumping in front of a moving train at the Chiyen station on the Tamsui Line of the Taipei rapid transit system.
Close-circuit cameras show that the woman, surnamed Hsu, apparently jumped onto the track deliberately as the Tamsui-bound train pulled into the station at 4:03 p.m.

The train conductor and station workers managed to carry the woman from under the train onto the platform. After finding she was still alive, they called an ambulance to rush her to the Veterans General Hospital. She died in the hospital despite doctors' efforts to save her.
The Taipei Rapid Transit Corp. urged members of the public to treasure their lives and respect other people's right to a smooth-running mass rapid transportation system.

Figures compiled by the Taipei Rapid Transit Corp. show that since the MRT system became operational in 1996, at least 25 accidents have occurred after passengers jumped or fell onto the tracks, resulting in eight deaths -- mostly on the Tamsui Line.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXPERTS, AMBASSADORS SHARE THOUGHTS ON LATIN AMERICA INITIATIVE

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian's "Jung Pang Project" initiative will facilitate relations with Latin American allies but its implementation requires respect for each ally's unique situation, ambassadors and experts said at an international forum Friday.

The project, proposed by President Chen during a 2005 Latin American trip, budgeted NT$7.5 billion (US$250 million) and aimed at encouraging Taiwanese investment in Central and South America. It serves as a strategy to neutralize China's increasing impact in the region.

Paraguay welcomed the project and hopes to be Taiwan's "gateway" to enter the Latin American market, Ambassador of the Republic of Paraguay Ramon Diaz Pereira said at the 2006 Taiwan-Latin America Forum, which was organized by Tamkang University Graduate Institute of Latin America Studies. Paraguay is one of 12 Latin American countries that have established official relations with Taiwan, which currently has 25 diplomatic allies.

"Taiwan can use this project to developing better ties with Latin American countries. For example, high-caliber Costa Rican employees will be helpful to Taiwan in developing the Spanish-version of computer software," said former ambassador to Costa Rica Mao Kao-wen.
"Every country has different needs, environment and background. Different detailed plans are needed to make the most out of the project," Mao noted.

The US$250 million pales in comparison with the US$10 billion China invests in Latin America every year, said Juan Hung Hui, a professor at Tamkang University. This is why Taiwan needs to improve its relations with China -- to avoid such diplomatic competition, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA URGES LOCAL PEOPLE TO SUSPEND NEPAL TRAVEL PLANS

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) upgraded its travel advisory for Nepal to the most serious level Friday as the political situation continues to deteriorate there.

MOFA officials advised Taiwanese to refrain from traveling to Nepal for the time being as conflicts between security forces and anti-king demonstrators show no signs of subsiding in the South Asian country.

The ministry decided to raise its Nepal travel advisory from the second most dangerous "orange level" to the highest "red level" after Nepal's royal government imposed a new 11-hour curfew in the capital Friday, during which security forces are allowed to open fire on any individual defying the curfew decree.

Many countries, including the United States, Britain and Japan, have all advised their citizens to suspend Nepal travel plans until otherwise notified, MOFA officials said, adding that they will adjust the level of travel advisory according to security developments there.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Shiite Drops Bid to Keep Post as Premier
Under intense domestic and American pressure , Iraqi Prime Minister Ibrahim al-Jaafari dropped his bid to retain his job on Thursday, removing a major obstacle to forming a new government during a time of rising sectarian violence. Leaders from each of Iraq's main factions -- Sunni Arab, Shiite and Kurd -- called the decision a breakthrough.
Wall Street Journal: Hu Yields Little On Major Issues in Bush Summit
Chinese President Hu Jintao offered cooperation on issues from trade to nuclear proliferation during a long-awaited visit to the White House, but he pointedly declined to give President Bush concrete promises on key economic and foreign-policy disputes. While that left bidg divisions between the two countries over China's currency and Iran's nuclear program, the political disagreements are being contained for now by American companies' huge interest in maintaining good relations with China and steady access to its market.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SHOULD WORK WITH U.S. TO NUDGE CHINA TOWARD DEMOCRACY: SCHOLAR

TEXT.P: Taiwan should cooperate with the United States in galvanizing China to move toward democratic reform, otherwise its regional strategic status could be diminished, a local academic said Friday.

Huang Chieh-cheng, deputy executive director of the private think tank Foundation on International and Cross-Strait Studies, was speaking at a seminar on the just-concluded meeting between U.S. President George W. Bush and Chinese President Hu Jintao and its possible impact on Taiwan-U.S.-China relations.

According to Huang, bilateral relations between the United States and China will develop in a more "stable and mature" fashion following Thursday's Bush-Hu huddle at the White House, with both sides stressing "common interests" in their interaction.

As a democratic country, Huang said, Taiwan tends to emphasize its "common values" with the United States in their bilateral exchanges. But Huang said Taiwan's government should pay attention to whether its major policy line -- particularly issues related to cross-Taiwan Strait exchanges -- will undermine U.S. interests.

Moreover, Huang said, Taiwan's strategic status may be affected once the United States feels it no longer needs Taiwan's assistance in shaping a climate or environment favorable to China's democratic evolution.
Against this backdrop, Huang said, Taiwan should consider whether it's wise or beneficial to choose a completely confrontational strategy toward China.

In his view, he said, pursuing sustainable economic growth is most conducive to Taiwan's well-being and best conforms to the Taiwanese people's expectations. He urged the Democratic Progressive Party government to adopt a more pragmatic policy toward China.

DOC.HEADLINE: BUDGET FREEZE GRAVELY HINDERS GOVERNMENT OPERATIONS: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang said Friday the opposition-controlled Legislative Yuan's reluctance to freeze a total of NT$180.2 billion in the government budget has seriously crippled the administrative arm's operations.
Su made the remarks in a speech delivered at a Legislative Yuan interpellation session.

"Today marks the last day for me to field questions from lawmakers during the current legislative session. Starting next week, the legislature will begin screening bills. It is hoped that lawmakers from across the party spectrum will give priority to deliberating major bills related with economic development, people's livelyhoods and property safety," Su said.
He also expressed regrets that the legislature has so far de-freezed one-seventh of the "frozen" government budget for 2006.

Noting that the domestic economy is now in a good shape, with the unemployment rate declining steadily and stock prices soaring, Su said the legislature should cooperate with the executvie arm in further sustaining this growth momentum by de-freezing the government's budget as early as possible.

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG TO FORGE SISTERLY TIES WITH JAPANESE CITY
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, April 21 (CNA) (By Wang Shu-fen and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Acting Kaohsiung Mayor Yeh Chu-lan paid a visit to Hachioji -- a satellite city in the Greater Tokyo area -- Friday, receiving a warm welcome from senior Hachioji city officials.
Hachioji Mayor Ryuichi Kurosu briefed Yeh on the city's special features, major development projects and tourist attractions.
With a population of 530,000, Hachioji is known as an "academic city" because it boasts 21 colleges and universities ans is home to many high-tech companies.

After an hour-long talk, Yeh and Kurosu agreed that Kaohsiung and Hachioji will forge a sisterly relationship in October this year when Kurosu is expected to visit Kaohsiung to sign an agreement to that effect.
By then, Hachioji will become Kaohsiung's fourth sister city in Asia, after Busan of South Korea, Towrane of Vietnam and Cebu of the Philippines.
Earlier in the day, Yeh met with Tokyo Governor Shintaro Ishihara who lauded Yeh as an outstanding politician and encouraged her to vie for Taiwan's presidency in the future.

Yeh, heading a delegation of Kaohsiung municipal officials, arrived in Japan Wednesday for a five-day visit aimed at boosting city-to-city exchanges and learning from Japan's urban redevelopment projects.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, April 22, or the 25th day of the third month of the Year of the Dog according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1500: On his way to India with 13 ships, Portuguese navigator Pedro Alvarez Cabral discovers Brazil and claims it for Portugal.
1724: Immanuel Kant, German idealist philosopher and one of history's greatest thinkers, is born. He argued that reason is the means by which the phenomena of experience is translated into understanding. His classic works include "Critique of Pure Reason" and "Critique of Practical Reason."
1870: Vladimir Ilich Lenin, Russian leader of the Bolshevik Revolution and first leader of Communist Russia, is born.
1904: Robert Oppenheimer, American nuclear scientist who developed the atom bomb, is born.
1915: The Germans use poison gas for the first time on British troops on the Western Front during World War I.
1944: Allied forces land on Dutch New Guinea.
1947: Wei Tao-ming becomes governor of the newly established Taiwan Provincial Government.
1951: The first contingent of officers from the U.S. Military Assistance Advisory Group (MAAG) in Taiwan, arrives in Taipei. Maj. Gen. William C. Chase, the first MAAG chief, would arrive in Taipei later.
1956: Beijing appoints the Dalai Lama as chairman of a committee to prepare Tibet for regional autonomy within Communist China.
1961: The construction of the Taipei Chunghua Bazaar is completed with Gov. Chow Chih-jou of Taiwan Provincial Government presiding over the inauguration ceremony.
1969: American surgeons conduct the first human eye transplant.
1973: President Hammer de Roburt of the Republic of Nauru and his wife arrive in Taipei for a visit.
1974: A Pan American Airlines passenger plane crashes in Bali, Indonesia, killing 107 people.
1975: The first batch of Vietnamese refugees arrive on the western coast of the United States, as South Vietnam falls to the communists.
1980: S.S. Don Juan, a vehicle ferry, collides with a car float and sinks near Mindoro Island in the Philippines, killing some 1,000 people.
1984: Medical researchers working in the United States and France identify a type of human cancer virus that may be the causative agent in the killer disease Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome (AIDS).
1991: The second extraordinary session of the First National Assembly passes, at its sixth plenary meeting, the Additional Articles of the Constitution of the Republic of China and approves the abolishment of the Temporary Provisions Effective During the Period of Communist Rebellion.
1992: Gasoline that leaked from a nearby refinery explodes in the sewer system of Guadalajara, Mexico, killing more than 200 people and injuring over 600 others.
1993: The Legislative Yuan ratifies a 1989 ROC-U.S. copyright agreement and passes amendments to the ROC's copyright law that go into effect April 26.
1993: Tongan Prime Minister Baron Vaea and Madame Vaea visit the Republic of China.
1994: Former U.S. President Richard M. Nixon dies of a stroke at the age of 81. He visited mainland China in 1972 and established detente with the USSR. When Congress recommended three articles of impeachment for Nixon's involvement in the Watergate scandal, he resigned from office Aug. 9, 1974.
1999: Visiting President Kirsan Nikolayevich Ilyumzhinov of the Kalmykia Republic meets with Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou and expresses interest in creating sisterhood ties between the Russian state and Taipei.
2000: The newly founded People First Party calls for a halt in revamping the ROC Constitution by the National Assembly, branding the draft amendments unconstitutional.
2000: The ROC Foreign Ministry formally approves the appointment of Chen Kuo-huang, director of the Foreign Ministry's Western Asian Affairs Department, as ambassador to Palau.
2001: Nobel laureate Yang Chen-ning is honored as the outstanding alumnus of the century in Hsinchu, northern Taiwan, by his alma mater National Tsinghua University.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "When the rulers encourage education and good manner, the people are easily amenable to government."
