DOC.HEADLINE: DPP WILLING TO REFLECT UPON ITSELF: LEGISLATIVE WHIP

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) is willing to listen to public criticism and reflect upon itself with an open mind, a DPP caucus whip in the Legislative Yuan said Saturday.

Legislator Yeh Yi-jin was responding to a recent poll conducted by a local newspaper showing approval ratings for President Chen Shui-bian hovering around 26 percent, with about 50 percent casting doubt on the integrity of the Presidential Office in the wake of an ownership battle scandal for a Taipei department store allegedly involving an aide of the Presidential Office and the first lady.

Yeh said that given the present "expose culture," some news is blown out of proportion by the media, a reference to a series of sensational "revelations" made recently by political figures and the media without providing substantive evidence.
"This has led to the public forming a stereotyped impression of the government," Yeh said.
For this reason, the poll -- conducted by the media -- can only be used as a reference, she said, although the DPP will engage in serious soul-searching to address any possible wrongdoing.
Legislator Huang Wei-cher also said that all DPP members are in the same boat, and that the party can only accept people's views "in tears."
The party will reflect upon itself and do its best to solicit the support of the people, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER PREMIER NOT TO FORM NEW PARTY: LAWMAKERS

TEXT.P: Former Premier Frank Hsieh, a ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) heavyweight, has clearly expressed that he will never withdraw from the party to form a new one, his protege said Saturday.
Legislator Hsu Kuo-yung made the remarks upon his return from the United States, where he attended a lecture given by Hsieh at Harvard University April 19.
In response to media queries, Hsu also conveyed Hsieh's message that he currently has no intentions to run for Taipei mayor in the year-end election.

Hsu cited the former premier as saying that he will not discuss with party members whether he is willing to participate in the election before his political views are discussed and approved by the party.

Hsieh left for the U.S. March 7 to spend time as a visiting research fellow at Harvard University's John F. Kennedy School of Government after stepping down from his post as premier in January. He delivered the speech at the institute to mark the end of his term of study.
Besides Hsu, several other Hsieh's proteges, including Legislators Lee Chun-yee, Eva Hsieh and Huang Chien-hui, also traveled to the U.S. to listen to their mentor's speech.

Mentioning that Hsieh has been preparing to propose a reform plan to overhaul the DPP upon his return, Lee pointed out that Hsieh, a leading figure of the DPP's subgroup the Welfare State Alliance, has never ceased reflecting on how to settle interparty infighting and boost party unity.
Hsieh has hoped his idea of "mutualism" could be first carried out in the DPP, Lee noted.
Lee revealed that Hsieh is slated to return home April 29, but that the schedule may be delayed because Hsieh has received many invitations to visit overseas Taiwanese groups in the U.S.

DOC.HEADLINE: SATISFACTION WITH SOCIAL ORDER UP SLIGHTLY: SURVEY

TEXT.P: Public satisfaction with domestic social order in Taiwan has increased slightly -- by three percentage points -- to 19 percent this month, according to a survey released Saturday by th Institute for National Policy Research (INPR), a private tank.

The survey was conducted via telephone interview April 16-17 by the Master Survey and Research Co. at the request of the INPR. It received 1,069 valid samples from around the island, with a margin of error of 3 percent.

The press conference was presided over by Academia Sinica researcher Lin Cheng-yi with the attendance of experts and professors in crime prevention and law enforcement from National Taipei University and Central Police University who were invited to analyze the survey's results.
The survey, the second of its kind this month, was made in response to Premier Su Tseng-chang's pledge to improve social order within six month after assuming office in late January.

Although the social order satisfaction rate has moved up slightly, the dissatisfaction rate still registers as high as 77.3 percent, with only 22.53 percent of respondents having confidence in the government's initiatives, while 65.17 percent indicated pessimism.

Compared to the previous survey conducted on April 1, the public believed social problems such as illegal firearms possession, kidnapping and circulation of substandard food products have all improved slightly, while fraud, theft, robbery and drug abuse have not yet shown signs of improvement.

According to the survey, more than 83.5 percent of respondents said they have received fraudulent phone calls in the past month, 28.53 percent have had possessions stolen and 13.13 percent have been robbed.

When asked which social problems the government should address first, the respondents said they hoped the government would prioritize drug addiction and the drug trade, fraud, and robbery -- in that order.
Regarding the performance of law enforcement officers, 49.17 of respondents said they were "too weak" in the exercise of public authority, with 8.6 percent responding that police are "too bullying."

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER CALLS FOR GRANTING 'BASIC DUE RESPECT' TO FIRST FAMILY

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang urged the public Saturday to grant the first family "the basic due respect" inherent in the country's rule of law, and called on legislators and the media to refrain from making sensationalistic accusations.

The premier made the remarks on the sidelines of a ceremony marking the Executive Yuan's inauguration of a children's Web site when asked about a recent poll conducted by a local newspaper showing President Chen Shui-bian's approval ratings hovering at around 26 percent, with half of respondents casting doubt on the Presidential Office's integrity.

Su noted that recently some political figures had made a number of "sensational revelations" under the guise of whistleblowing, and that they used the pretext of "reasonable doubt" to point the finger at President Chen and members of the first family.

On allegations that the first lady inappropriately received and used Pacific Sogo Department Store gift vouchers, Su said the president had categorically denied the claim, saying that if he or any members of his family had been involved in the gift voucher scandal, he would be willing to step down.
For this reason, the premier urged a halt to unfounded smear campaigns and sensationalistic rumormongering simply because the president holds "the top [leadership] position and is very visible."

With the president willing to put his post on the line if he or any of his family members were involved in the gift voucher scandal, the public "should give the first family the basic due respect of their position," he said.

As a country ruled by law, political figures should adhere to the basic democratic principle, the premier said, adding that if there is any substantive evidence it should be presented to judicial authorities for further investigation.
Otherwise, people should refrain from making irresponsible sensationalistic allegations which only reveal their own political motivations, the premier added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT COLLECTS NEW VERSION OF NATIONAL ID CARD

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian picked up the new version of his identification (ID) card Saturday at the borough chief office of Taipei's Minsheng community where he legally resides.
Chen was accompanied by Minister of the Interior Lee Yi-yang when he arrived at the office on Mingsheng E. Road to receive his new ID card.
The president was all smiles while posing for an army of photo journalists with his new card, even jubilantly kissing it before the camera.

First lady Wu Shu-jen was not present. When asked how the wheelchair-bound first lady would receive her new ID, Hsieh Ai-ling, director of the Population Administration Department under the Ministry of the Interior (MOI), said Wu could apply for home delivery service by household registration staff.

Interior Minister Lee said, however, that all local citizens are required to pick up their new ID cards in person. Comatose, seriously ill and physically challenged people may be eligible for home delivery service, but registration officials must see applicants before handing over the new ID cards -- to them or to their family members, the minister added.

Lee said distribution of the new ID card is ahead of schedule. As of Friday, 6.5 million citizens had already received new ID cards -- 35.2 percent of the more than 18.46 million people eligible to receive them.
After many twists and turns, population administration offices around the country began issuing the new ID cards Dec. 21, 2005, with distribution scheduled to conclude by the end of this year.

According to MOI regulations, local citizens can have others apply on their behalf for ID card renewal, but the new cards must be picked up in person so that administrators can confirm the authenticity of ID photos. Nevertheless, population staff offer home delivery for the frail and elderly, seriously ill patients and those with major disabilities.

About the size of a credit card, the new ID has 21 forgery-proof features. For example, the shapes of Jade Mountain, Taiwan and the MOI emblem are imbedded images, while a butterfly hologram can be observed from viewing the card at a different angle.
The new ID's name column has room for either 15 Chinese characters or 20 romanized letters, making it more convenient for aboriginal people to use their indigenous names.
The government has renewed ID cards before -- in 1947, 1954, 1966, 1976 and 1986, respectively.

The MOI had initially planned to renew the ID cards starting July 1, 2005 and to require fingerprinting from all applicants, but the plan was postponed until December after some ruling Democratic Progressive Party legislators requested a constitutional interpretation by the Council of Grand Justices over the controversial policy.
The grand justices ruled on Sept. 28, 2005 that the fingerprinting policy was unconstitutional, prompting the MOI to drop the plan.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Top Shiites Nominate A Premier For Iraq; Al-Maliki Opposed Hussein And the U.S.-Led Invasion.
Jawad al-Maliki, an experienced political operator and advocate for Iraq's Shiite Muslims, won the approval of Shiite party leaders for the post of prime minister on Friday, a day after the parties' original nominee bowed out under political pressure.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER PRESIDENT RECOVERING FROM TB

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang said Saturday that former President Lee Teng-hui is covering from a mild case of tuberculosis and requires a period of recuperation, urging the public not to disturb Lee at present so he can enjoy a full recovery.

Hsiao Kuang-ming, a doctor at Taipei Veterans General Hospital specializing in respiratory diseases, confirmed the same day that Lee was discharged from the hospital Friday after receiving treatment for a mild case of tuberculosis.
The 83-year-old Lee went to the hospital in mid-March after suffering from fever and a cold, but a later medical checkup found that Lee had tuberculosis.
Hsiao noted that after two weeks of treatment, Lee's fever and cough had receded and the tuberculosis was no longer contagious, adding that Lee is now well on the road to recovery.
However, the hospital did not mention where Lee's tuberculosis had originated.
Meanwhile, Shih Wen-yi, deputy director of the Center for Disease Control (CDC) under the Department of Health (DOH) , refused to comment on Lee's case to protect patient confidentiality.
Noting that Lee is only one of 15,000 annual cases of tuberculosis in Taiwan, Shih said local health agencies will carry out follow-up epidemiological survey and quarantine work.
According to CDC statistics, tuberculosis is Taiwan's No. 1 contagious disease, with an annual case load of 15,000 -- more than the number of AIDS cases and other infectious diseases combined.
With some 1,000 people dying from tuberculosis each year, the DOH has been working on a plan to cut the tuberculosis death rate in half within 10 years.

DOC.HEADLINE: STATE-RUN ENTERPRISES LOSE NT$18.15 BILLION IN Q1

TEXT.P: The seven state-run enterprises under the jurisdiction of the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) incurred an accumulated loss of NT$18.15 billion (US$561.76 million) in the first quarter (Q1) of this year, according to official tallies released Saturday.
Because of soaring crude oil prices, Chinese Petroleum Corp. and Taiwan Power Co. registered a combined loss of NT$19.35 billion during the January-March period, MOEA statistics showed.
As the five other state-owned firms posted a small amount of pre-tax profit, the seven companies total Q1 financial loss was narrowed to NT$18.15 billion.

The five other state-owned corporation are Taiwan Sugar Corp. (TSC) , Taiwan Water Corp. (TWC) , China Shipbuilding Corp. (CSBC), Tang Eng Iron Works Co. (TEIWC) and Aerospace Industrial Development Corp (AIDC).

The Q1 pre-tax profits for the TSC, the TWC, the CSBC and the AIDC amounted to NT$403 million, NT$556 million, NT$236 million and NT$18 million, respectively, while the TEIWC registered a loss of NT$11 million during the same three-month period.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER PREMIER TALKS ABOUT CROSS-STRAIT RELATIONS IN U.S.
DOC.DATELINE: Boston, April 21 (CNA) (By Eric Tseng & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Former Premier Frank Hsieh said Friday in a speech to some 200 students in the New England area that he agrees with the idea of opening direct transport, postal and trade links across the Taiwan Strait because it would be beneficial to Taiwan's economy.

The reason the "three links" idea failed to be implemented during his barely one-year service as premier ending in January, 2006, was that only the president-chaired National Security Council has the right to decide on the matter, Hsieh noted.

However, touching on the standoff between Taiwan's ruling and opposition parties, Hsieh said he believes issues concerning national security should never be used as a weapon in the service of party-to-party competition.

In his speech at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT), Hsieh spent most of the time conveying his views on how to settle nasty disputes on cross-strait issues between Taiwan's two major political parties -- the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and the opposition Kuomintang (KMT).

Hsieh said that there are issues -- such as maintaining the cross-strait status quo, Taiwan's future being decided by the Taiwanese, dismantling China's missiles targeting Taiwan, and promoting dialogue with Beijing -- on which the two parties can easily produce a consensus, suggesting they would be a good starting point for the DPP and KMT to defuse hostilities.

However, the DPP heavyweight also suggested cross-strait talks be conducted on a government-to-government base, describing the 15 promises Communist Party of China (CPC) General-Secretary Hu Jintao made during his recent meeting with KMT honorary Chairman Lien Chan in Beijing as no more than consensus reached "between two good friends" which would not be legally binding.
Only results produced in government-to-government negotiations can truly protect the people's interests, Hsieh underscored.

Calling for cross-strait cooperation, Hsieh stated that even without an agreement on the two sides' "ultimate goals" -- China wants unification and Taiwan seeks independence -- efforts could still be made to promote friendly dialogue between the two.

Hsieh recently concluded his short-term research program at Harvard University's John F. Kennedy School of Government, where he gave his first lecture in the U.S. April 19. The MIT speech was his third during his U.S. visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER INAUGURATES EXECUTIVE YUAN WEB SITE FOR KIDS

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang hosted a ceremony Saturday to inaugurate the Executive Yuan's new Web site for kids.

More than 100 children were invited to attend the inauguration of the "Children's E-Amusement Park" Web site, which was developed according to proposal of Su, who said he hopes the new site can help young people obtain more information about their country and government.
The site, http://kids.ey.gov.tw, has six major themes -- getting to know the Executive Yuan, policies related to children, activities and events, games, information about Taiwan and relevant links.
During the ceremony, Su played with the young guests and taught them how to find data on the Web site.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO STEP UP SATELLITE MONITORING TO CURB GRAVEL POACHING

TEXT.P: Taiwan will strengthen satellite surveillance of its territory in order to prevent gravel poaching at a time when China will stop exporting gravel soon, a government official said Saturday.

Chang Jing-sen, vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) , made the remarks in a speech delivered at a forum on national land development organized by the Taipei-based Geographical Society of China.
Chang noted that gravel prices in Taiwan have risen recently amid reports that China may prohibit the exportation of sand and gravel starting from May.
To address the problem, the government has invited construction industry representatives to work on a series of joint measures to stabilize gravel prices, Chang added.

Noting that Taiwan's gravel industry has in part been monopolized by organized crime rings, Chang said the government will strengthen satellite monitoring to both curb illegal gravel poaching and to better take advantage of a natural supply of gravel stripped from mountains after typhoons.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S ECONOMIC GROWTH COULD BE CUT TO 3.79% THIS YEAR: THINK TANK

TEXT.P: Taiwan's economic growth will be adjusted downward to 3.79 percent this year if soaring oil prices affect exports and dampen willingness to invest, a local think tank said Saturday.
Analysts from the Chung-Hwa Institution for Economic Research unveiled the latest economic forecast amid reports that crude oil has topped US$75 per barrel in New York.
The researchers said that based on calculations with oil prices between US$50 and US$60 per barrel this year, Taiwan's economic growth should be around 4.1 percent.
But with a looming nuclear crisis in Iran and the decrease in stockpiled oil in the United States, crude oil has just hit US$75 per barrel in New York, they noted.

If soaring oil prices affect the global economy -- which in turn affects Taiwan's export performance -- it is estimated that exports for each of the two seasons in the latter part of the year will be cut by US$20 billion, and that the willingness to invest during each of the two quarters may be cut by NT$10 billion.
If such is the case, economic growth this year will be adjusted downwards to 3.79 percent, and the consumer price index will be upgraded to 2.1 percent.
Meanwhile, the analysts called attention to the fact that momentum for continued economic growth is gradually losing steam.

They said that investment in Taiwan decreased 11.85 percent in the fourth quarter of 2005, a sharp contrast to the economic growth of 6.4 percent of that season, showing that investment in Taiwan is slowing down, especially for small- and middle-sized enterprises.
The analysts noted that 2,810 plants closed their doors during the first two months of this year, showing that small- and medium-sized enterprises are still facing difficulties.

They noted that equipment imports amounted to only US$3.93 billion in the first quarter -- down 18.1 percent from the same period last year -- and that since investment in machinery equipment has been a staple for Taiwan, the decrease has reflected a doldrums trend.

They said that soaring oil prices may slow down the economic rebound. This, coupled with some major domestic construction projects -- such as high-speed rail construction entering the final stages of contruction -- will all be unfavorable factors that may slow investment.

DOC.HEADLINE: SCHOLARS CALL FOR MORE EFFORTS TO STRENGTHEN TIES WITH U.S.

TEXT.P: The just-concluded meeting between U.S. President George W. Bush and Chinese President Hu Jintao showed that there are many contradictions between the two powers and that the time is right for Taiwan to furthur boost relations with the U.S., scholars said at a forum Saturday.

U.S.-China relations are not expected to change dramatically in the near future, scholars agreed at the forum which was organized by Taiwan Thinktank to discuss Taiwan-U.S.-China relations after the Bush-Hu huddle.

"I really don't think the U.S. and China will be 'strategic partners' because the two sides don't share common values, although they do have common interests," said Raymond Wu, deputy chief executive officer of the Cross-Strait Interflow Prospect Foundation.

If Taiwan can combine its interests with those of the U.S., the two sides' relations would greatly improve, as Taiwan and the U.S. both share common values of democracy, human rights and freedom of speech.

By working with the U.S. to advance "transformational diplomacy" -- a strategy advocated by U.S. Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice aiming to "work with our many partners around the world to build and sustain democratic, well-governed states that will respond to the needs of their people" -- Taiwan will integrate its interest with that of the U.S., Soochow University professor Lo Chih-cheng said.
"Helping China move toward a democratic and human rights-respecting country serves U.S. and Taiwan's interests at the same time," Lo said.
Two major points of contention between China and the U.S. are coming up shortly, said Lin Wen-cheng, a professor at National Sun Yat-sen University.

The Iran issue will be discussed in the Security Council of the United Nations next week and the U.S. is seeking China's support. The annual report of the U.S. Treasury Department, which is expected to bring up China's currency control issue, will also be released soon.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER INSPECTS HSUEHSHAN TUNNEL TESTING

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang tested traffic control and emergency response systems in Hsuehshang Tunnel Saturday to see whether the tunnel will be ready for a formal opening in June as scheduled.

Noting that 14 years have passed since construction began on the 12.9km tunnel, the centerpiece of the 55-km Peiyi Expressway linking Taipei to the northeastern county of Yilan, Su said the government must be assured that all professional requirements and safety considerations are fully met before the tunnel formally opens.

Because of the special terrain of Mount Snow -- under which the tunnel is located -- construction on the tunnel has encountered many tough challenges. With the perseverance of a large number of domestic and foreign engineers and construction workers, the tunnel was completed late last year, but testing on its traffic control system and emergency response networks is an ongoing process.

While many have been urging the government to complete all preparations and open the tunnel by Dragon Boat Festival, which falls on May 31 this year, Su said the public's safety remains the primary concern.

In addition to ensuring that all safety details are up to professional requirements, Su said the Ministry of Transportation and Communications must step up a publicity campaign to help drivers get familiar with the tunnel's special traffic rules and emergency response measures in preparation for its formal opening.

The Toucheng-Suao section of the Peiyi Expressway opened to traffic Jan. 22 this year with little celebrations as it came a day before a major Cabinet reshuffle. Both Toucheng and Suao are coastal town in Yilan County.
With a price tag of more than NT$100 billion, the expressway is expected to cut the travel time between Taipei and Yilan when it fully opens to the traffic.

The Hsuehshan Tunnel, reputed as the "tunnel beneath troubled water" due to the engineering difficulties encountered during its construction, was originally scheduled to open to traffic in late January to coincide with the lunar New Year holiday.

The plan was scrapped because some construction work inside the tunnel had yet to be fully completed, including its mechanical, electrical, fire-fighting, ventilation and monitoring systems. Engineering experts said at the time that the inauguration of the tunnel would only be possible by June at the earliest.

DOC.HEADLINE: UGANDAN CHILDREN'S CHORUS SINGS TO RAISE FUNDS FOR ORPHANS

TEXT.P: A children's choir from Kampala, Uganda, will perform several charity performances around Taiwan to raise funds for the care of those orphaned by the AIDS epidemic, estimated to be nearly a million in the African country.

Saturday's warm-up performance of the Watoto Children's Choir in front of Shinkong Life Tower building in downtown Taipei -- featuring elements of native African rhythms, contemporary gospel music and ethnic dance -- attracted the attention of many passers-by.
A Mrs. Wu, who watched the performance with her two children, said it was a good opportunity for her kids to learn how to help and pray for children in need from other countries.

The chorus, composed of children of AIDS victims, has been invited by World Vision Taiwan to have five performances around Taiwan. Those interested in attending the concerts or making on-line donations can visit the Web site: www.worldvision.org.tw.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: C.I.A. Fires Senior Officer Over Leaks
The Central Intelligence Agency has dismissed a senior career officer for disclosing classified information to reporters, including material for Pulitzer Prize-winning articles in The Washington Post about the agency's secret overseas prisons for terror suspects, intelligence officials said Friday. The C.I.A. would not identify the officer, but several government officials said it was Mary O. McCarthy, a veteran intelligence analyst who until 2001 was senior director for intelligence programs at the National Security Council, where she served under President Bill Clinton and into the Bush administration. The dismissal of Ms. McCarthy provided fresh evidence of the Bush administration's determined efforts to stanch leaks of classified information.
Wall Street Journal: As Energy Costs Soar, Companies Retool Operations
Soaring energy prices have yet to take a big bite out of economic growth, but already, the high cost of energy is changing corporate behavior. In industries from airlines to glassmaking, companies are curbing usage, revamping machinery and shifting production schedules to offset energy costs. But most indications are that companies still aren't passing on the bulk of higher oil prices to consumers. "Some sectors, such as trucking, are passing higher energy costs on to customers, but most sectors just have to increase their efficiencies to cover those costs," says Stephen Brown, director of energy economics at the Dallas Federal Reserve.

DOC.HEADLINE: BUSH-HU MEETING FRUITLESS FOR CHINA: ANALYSTS

TEXT.P: Chinese President Hu Jintao not only failed to get what he anticipated but also "lost face" during his not-so-successful U.S. visit, some local international relations scholars said Saturday at a forum organized by Taiwan Thinktank.

"If we can't say Hu's visit was a failure, it wasn't a success, either. China didn't get anything it wanted. And the protest [on the South Lawn of the White House by a Falun Gong member] humiliated Hu," said Lin Wen-cheng, a National Sun Yat-sen University professor.
The U.S. refused to consider the trip a state visit and reiterated that it would deal with the Taiwan issue based on the three communiques and the Taiwan Relations Act, Lin explained.
China "made a huge investment in the trip but gained little in return, " said Paul Lin, a New York-based political commentator who relocated to Taiwan in March.

Lin said China had made every effort before the Bush-Hu meeting at the White House Thursday -- including signing a US$16 billion procurement deal, holding forums with Taiwan's Kuomintang (KMT) and setting up an international Buddhism forum -- to ensure the visit's success.

China's wishes did not materialize, Lin said, as U.S. President George W. Bush pressured China on the trade deficit, Iran and currency control, but would not make any concessions on the cross-Taiwan Strait issue.

"Obviously, the U.S. was in the offensive mode from the beginning and made Hu play defense, " said Cheng Tuan-yao, acting director of the Institute of International Relations at National Chengchi University.

"I didn't see any major breakthrough in China-U.S. relations. Moreover, China's promise to work with the U.S. on major international issues will come on a test next week when the U. N. Security Council will begin to address the Iran nuclear controversy," Cheng said.

"Compared to former Chinese President Jiang Zemin's U.S. visit in 1997, Hu did not do a good job this time," Lo Chih-cheng, a Soochow University professor, said, adding that future U.S.-China relations will become even more complex.
"As expected, the Bush-Hu meeting was more symbolism than substance," summed up Raymond Wu, deputy chief executive officer of the Cross Strait Interflow Prospect Foundation.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO BE 'EXCITING' MARKET IF CHINA TIES IMPROVE: FUND MANAGER

TEXT.P: Taiwan will be an "exciting" market if relations across the Taiwan Strait improve, a legendary U.S. investment expert said in Taipei Saturday.
Jim Rogers, a co-founder of the Quantum Fund, one of the world's most successful hedge funds, made the forecast after delivering a speech to local fund managers and stock investors.

Rogers is known to bear a strong confidence in the vast Chinese market. He once famously predicted that China would emerge as the world's largest economy in 20 years. He hires a babysitter of Chinese descent to care for his 3-year old daughter to allow for her to grow in an English-Chinese bilingual environment.
If Taiwan maintains a good relationship with China, Rogers said Taiwan will definitely be an "exciting" market for investors.
Rogers also predicted that the current raw materials market boom will continue gaining momentum in the coming decade. He attributed the phenomenon in part to China's rise.
For those intending to invest in China, Rogers said farm produce, industrial raw materials and tourism-related industries could be the best bets.
Noting that Chinese people have been banned free movements for nearly a century, Rogers said the travel service sector has an amazing growth potential when their government lifts overseas travel ban.
Rogers said he plans to relocate to the greater Chinese region. In addition to Shanghai, Singapore and Hong Kong, he said Taipei is also a possible destination.

Meanwhile, Rogers gave a pessimistic forecast on the U.S. dollar's prospect. The astronomical U.S. trade deficit has dimmed the greenback's value, he said, adding that at least 10 to 12 other foreign currencies, such as the Chinese yuan, the Singaporean dollar and the Canadian dollar, are more valuable than the greenback.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER VOWS TO DEVELOP GREEN ISLAND INTO ECOTOURISM HEAVEN

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang promised Saturday to develop the scenic outlying islet of Green Island off southeastern Taiwan into an ecotourism paradise.

Su made the promise in a speech delivered at the closing ceremony for a two-day national sustainable development conference to solicit opinions from non-government organizations (NGOs) in preparation for a sustainable economic development conference scheduled to be held between May and June.

The proposal to develop Green Island into an ecotourism heaven was broached by Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh, a co-winner of the 1986 Nobel Prize in chemistry, in his speech at the opening session of the conference.
Su said he has directed relevant government agencies to flesh out a detailed Green Island ecotourism development plan.

Consensus was reached on 248 topics discussed during the two-day conference, but participants failed to come to terms on 72 other topics. Su said he will see to it that consultations are held in the coming weeks to seek common grounds.

According to one of the agreements reached at the meeting, senior officials, including the president, the premier, legislative speaker, the heads of the Judicial Yuan and the Control Yuan and all political appointees, must attend at least 10 hours of classes annually on sustainable development and environmental protection subjects to be organized by NGOs.
Su said he fully supports the proposal and will take pleasure in attending those classes in the future. He also promised to brief President Chen Shui-bian on this proposal.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER PREMIER CALLS FOR CROSS-STRAIT MUTUALISM

TEXT.P: Former Premier Frank Hsieh said Friday the two sides of the Taiwan Strait should learn from the two prestigious U.S. schools -- Harvard University and Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) -- in forging a mutualism-based relationship.
In a speech on MIT campus to more than 200 students in the New England area, Hsieh said many Americans used to advocate a merger of Harvard and MIT.

"As Harvard is bigger, richer and older, it stands a good chance to 'annex' MIT. However, MIT has persevered in pursuing excellence in research and development in science and technology. Over the years, MIT has maintained its own 'unique identity' while developing a close cooperative tie with Harvard, " Hsieh said. Nowadays, MIT professors can teach at Harvard and its students can attend Harvard classes and vice versa. The two schools also maintain a close cooperative ties in library resources and information exchanges.
"The Harvard-MIT tie exemplifies the basic spirit of mutualism, " Hsieh said, adding that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait should learn from this Harvard-MIT cooperative formula.
Given its small size in comparison with China, Hsieh said, Taiwan should be more dexterous and flexible in engagement with China.

"At a time when China is growing economically and relations between China and the United States are improving continuously, Taiwan should be more open to China while maintaining its own national identity," Hsieh said.

Hsieh left for the United States March 7 to spend time as a visiting research fellow at Harvard University's John F. Kennedy School of Government after stepping down from his post as premier in January. The MIT speech was the third and last of a lecture series marking the end of his term of study.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR APRIL 23 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Sunday, April 23:
09:00, Premier Su Tseng-chang will attend a job promotion activity for the physically and mentally challenged to be held at Taipei 101 Tower.
10:00, Premier Su will attend a meeting of local government chiefs on crime-fighting to be held at the National Police Agency.
10:00, National Youth Commission Minister Cheng Li-chun will preside over a youth volunteer recruitment activity at National Taiwan University.
13:30, Minister of Economic Affairs Hwang Ing-san will inspect a dredging and cleanup project at the upper stretch of Shihmen Reservoir.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, April 23, or the 26th day of the third month of the Year of the Dog according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1616: William Shakespeare, English playwright and poet whose body of works is considered by most as the greatest in English literature, dies at New Place at the age of 52.
1616: Miguel de Cervantes, Spanish writer best known for his classic satirical novel "Don Quixote," dies at the age of 69.
1873: The Dutch war against the Sultan of Achin begins in northwest Sumatra, Indonesia.
1895: Russia, Germany and France protest the ceding of Chinese territory to Japan.
1897: Lester Pearson, Canadian prime minister from 1963-1968, is born. He won the 1957 Nobel Peace Prize for his part in settling the Suez crisis.
1919: Peking Teachers High School for Girls is formally established.
1928: Shirley Temple Black, American child star who went on to become the U.S. ambassador to Ghana, is born. As Shirley Temple, she was an immensely popular child actress of the 1930s, starring in films such as "Wee Willie Winkie" and "Bright Eyes."
1935: Joseph Stalin officially opens the Moscow underground rail system.
1945: U.S. and Soviet forces meet at Torgau in eastern Germany.
1946: Hsia Kai-chun, noted writer of modern Chinese literature, dies in Shanghai at the age of 63.
1949: Government forces of the Republic of China evacuate Nanking.
1962: In the biggest-ever "ban the bomb" demonstration, some 150,000 people rally in London's Hyde Park.
1965: The Soviet Union launches its first communications satellite.
1965: President Charles de Gaulle of France emphasizes his opposition to the United States' Asian policies by withdrawing French units from naval maneuvers of the Southeast Asia Treaty Organization.
1969: A Los Angeles jury decides that Sirhan B. Sirhan should be sent to the gas chamber for the murder of Sen. Robert Kennedy in June 1968.
1975: U.S. President Gerald Ford declares the Vietnam War is over as panic grips Saigon after the South Vietnamese regime's Cabinet resigns.
1985: The Industrial Technology Research Institute successfully develops an amorphous-silicon solar battery of high commercial value.
1986: National Taiwan University Hospital separates a pair of 14-day-old Siamese twins, saving the life of one of the girls. The twins set a record for being the youngest to be separated.
1990: Li Peng, premier of mainland China, arrives in Moscow for a visit, becoming the most senior Beijing leader to tour the Soviet Union in 26 years.
1991: Tens of thousands of striking Soviet workers fill the streets in Minsk on the eve of the Communist Party plenum.
1997: After 26 days of occupation by rebels, Peru's government launches a sudden attack on the Japanese ambassador's residence in Lima, freeing 71 hostages. Three soldiers, one hostage and all 14 guerrillas die in the attack.
1999: State-run Taiwan Sugar Corp. inaugurates a phalaenopsis plant in Costa Rica, with scores of ranking Costa Rican government officials attending the ceremony.
2000: Former U.S. Assistant Secretary for East Asia and Pacific Affairs Winston Lord visits People First Party Chairman James Soong to exchange opinions on the Taiwan Strait situation.
2000: President-elect Chen Shui-bian and Vice President-elect Annette Lu kick off an island-wide tour to express thanks to their supporters in the March 18 presidential election.
2001: Computer chip giant Intel signs a memorandum of cooperation with the Industrial Development Bureau and the Technology Department under the Ministry of Economic Affairs.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A wise and good man is one who sets himself seriously to order his conversation aright."

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Los Angeles Times: CIA Officer Sacked for Leaking Detention-Site Secrets to Media.
The CIA has fired a senior officer for leaking classified information to news organizations, including material for Pulitzer-winning stories in the Washington Post that said the agency maintained a secret network of prison facilities overseas for high-ranking terror suspects.

TEXT.P: Taiwan will be an "exciting" market if relations across the Taiwan Strait improve, a legendary U.S. investment expert said in Taipei Saturday.
Jim Rogers, a co-founder of the Quantum Fund, one of the world's most successful hedge funds, made the forecast after delivering a speech to local fund managers and stock investors.

Rogers is known to bear a strong confidence in the vast Chinese market. He once famously predicted that China would emerge as the world's largest economy in 20 years. He hires a babysitter of Chinese descent to care for his 3-year old daughter to allow for her to grow in an English-Chinese bilingual environment.
If Taiwan maintains a good relationship with China, Rogers said Taiwan will definitely be an "exciting" market for investors.
Rogers also predicted that the current raw materials market boom will continue gaining momentum in the coming decade. He attributed the phenomenon in part to China's rise.
For those intending to invest in China, Rogers said farm produce, industrial raw materials and tourism-related industries could be the best bets.
Noting that Chinese people have been banned free movements for nearly a century, Rogers said the travel service sector has an amazing growth potential when their government lifts overseas travel ban.
Rogers said he plans to relocate to the greater Chinese region. In addition to Shanghai, Singapore and Hong Kong, he said Taipei is also a possible destination.

Meanwhile, Rogers gave a pessimistic forecast on the U.S. dollar's prospect. The astronomical U.S. trade deficit has dimmed the greenback's value, he said, adding that at least 10 to 12 other foreign currencies, such as the Chinese yuan, the Singaporean dollar and the Canadian dollar, are more valuable than the greenback.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER PREMIER CALLS FOR CROSS-STRAIT MUTUALISMrepeat

TEXT.P: Former Premier Frank Hsieh said Friday the two sides of the Taiwan Strait should learn from the two prestigious U.S. schools -- Harvard University and Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) -- in forging a mutualism-based relationship.
In a speech on MIT campus to more than 200 students in the New England area, Hsieh said many Americans used to advocate a merger of Harvard and MIT.

"As Harvard is bigger, richer and older, it stands a good chance to 'annex' MIT. However, MIT has persevered in pursuing excellence in research and development in science and technology. Over the years, MIT has maintained its own 'unique identity' while developing a close cooperative tie with Harvard, " Hsieh said. Nowadays, MIT professors can teach at Harvard and its students can attend Harvard classes and vice versa. The two schools also maintain a close cooperative ties in library resources and information exchanges.
"The Harvard-MIT tie exemplifies the basic spirit of mutualism, " Hsieh said, adding that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait should learn from this Harvard-MIT cooperative formula.
Given its small size in comparison with China, Hsieh said, Taiwan should be more dexterous and flexible in engagement with China.

"At a time when China is growing economically and relations between China and the United States are improving continuously, Taiwan should be more open to China while maintaining its own national identity," Hsieh said.

Hsieh left for the United States March 7 to spend time as a visiting research fellow at Harvard University's John F. Kennedy School of Government after stepping down from his post as premier in January. The MIT speech was the third and last of a lecture series marking the end of his term of study.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Sunday are as follows:
The China Times:
Father's death brings reunification of boy and mother.
The United Daily News:

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Manila Bulletin: DENR receives 'Lagpak Award' from Greenpeace
Department of Environment and Natural Resources (DENR) Secretary Angelo Reyes yesterday took as a challenge the dubious "Lagpak Award" the department received from Greenpeace Southeast Asia and Sagip Pasig Movement.
The Philippine Daily Inquirer: Arroyo, military ready to protect turf from Senate inquiries
THE SUPREME Court may have spoken on the issue of Executive Order No. 464 but the battle over what can and cannot be disclosed to the public seems far from over.
The Philippine Star: Palace: JIs in Mindanao confirmed but contained
Malacanang confirmed yesterday fresh warnings of terror attacks by al-Qaeda-linked Jemaah Islamiyah (JI) extremists in the country but assured the people that they have been contained.
The Manila Times: Palace lashes out at 'rogue inquiries'
Malacanang said on Saturday that Cabinet members and other administration officials can still invoke executive privilege during "rogue inquiries" called by lawmakers with political mischief in mind.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: New Plans Foresee Fighting Terrorism Beyond War Zones; Pentagon to Rely on Special Operations.
Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld has approved the military's most ambitious plan yet to fight terrorism around the world and retaliate more rapidly and decisively in the case of another major terrorist attack on the United States, according to defense officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW TAIWAN ENVOY TO E.U. VOWS TO DEVELOP STRATEGIC DIALOGUE

TEXT.P: Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs Michael Ying-mao Kau, who was appointed by President Chen Shui-bian last week to serve as Taiwan's representative to the European Union and Belgium, said Sunday that he will strive to develop Taiwan's strategic dialogue partnership with Europe.

Kau said the government has decided to increase interaction between Taiwan and European countries, as the region has become as strategically significant as the United States and Japan have traditionally been to Taiwan.

He said that as the development of Taiwan's relations with the United States and Japan has become stable and mature, the country should pay closer attention to and invest more resources in relations with Europe.

He added that after he assumes his new post -- probably in June or July after this year's World Health Assembly (WHA) slated for May 22-27 -- he will strive to implement strategic dialogue between Europe and Taiwan in a bid to keep Europe's governments fully abreast of what is going on in East Asia.
Kau claimed that "most European countries lack strategic perspectives" toward East Asia, except for their colonial legacy and history in this part of the world.

Kau, who has been in charge of Taiwan's efforts to join the WHA -- the decision-making body of the World Health Organization (WHO) -- over the past five years, said that all European countries respect democracy and human rights, a situation that provides a "niche" for Taiwan in terms of cementing bilateral ties.
Taiwan must let the European Union understand that after the Cold War and the disintegration of the Soviet Union, China's rise is a tremendous challenge to the E.U. if the rise is not peaceful.
Kau will succeed Chen Chien-jen, who is set to retire after a long diplomatic career.
Kau, 72, holds a bachelor's degree in politics from National Taiwan University and a master's degree and doctorate in comparative politics and international relations from Cornell University.

Before joining the Foreign Ministry in 2002, he was a professor of politics at Brown University in the United States, chairman of the Association of Chinese Social Scientists in North America, an advisor of the Institute of International Relations at National Chengchi University, and a member of the Advisory Committee of the National Security Council.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP URGES TAIWAN TO QUIT 'CULTURAL REVOLUTION'

TEXT.P: The legislative caucus of the opposition People First party (PFP) called on Taiwan's ruling and opposition parties to renounce what it described as the "Taiwan-style cultural revolution" and devote themselves to developing the nation's economy.

Lee Hung-chun, caucus secretary-general, claimed that Taiwan is losing its economic advantages as a result of political instability. "While China was engaged in its Cultural Revolution, Taiwan was focused on developing its economy. Now China is focusing on developing its economy, while Taiwan is engaged in a cultural revolution," he claimed.

According to Lee, excessive political populism and election liberalization have restricted the power of public authorities and many good policies cannot be implemented because of election considerations in Taiwan.
"This is something to which politicians in and outside of the government, in the ruling party and in the opposition, should give serious thought," he added.
Lee said a key to Taiwan's continued economic development is cross-Taiwan Strait relations, whose smooth development relies on "dialogue between the top leaders on both sides of the strait."

Now that China has said it is willing to talk with Taiwan on an equal footing, Taiwan has no reason to turn down the offer, he claimed, adding that the government should "give up its ideology" and seek to talk with China as soon as possible.

"As long as the dialogue will not hurt Taiwan's interest and national dignity, it should be held as soon as possible, " he said. "What is important is to come to a conclusion that will create a win-win situation for both sides," he went on.
A media report quoted Lin Yifu, director of the Chinese Economic Research Center at Beijing University, as suggesting that Taiwan and China could beef up agricultural and fisheries exchanges.

According to Lin, if Taiwan's economy remains stagnant, the coastal provinces of China will catch up with Taiwan in about 10 years, and when Taiwan loses its economic advantages, "it will lose everything."
Lee said the top leaders of Taipei and Beijing must talk, because only when a mutually acceptable conclusion has been reached will Taiwan's economy gain a new push for further growth.
He suggested that Japan or the United States could be invited to mediate a resolution to settle the political differences between Taiwan and China.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT HEAD SCOFFS AT PRESIDENT'S 'INTELLIGENCE WAR' ACCUSATION

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou scoffed Sunday at President Chen Shui-bian for reportedly accusing the opposition of organizing an "intelligence war" against his administration, saying that an object must become corrupt first before worms can emerge from it.

The opposition leader quoted the Chinese proverb in response to media questions about his views of Chen allegedly charging the opposition parties with gathering intelligence against his family and senior aides in a "soft decapitation" strategy against him.

Chen's remarks about ulterior motives of opposition politicians who expose possible corruption on the part of senior Presidential Office officials or the president's family show that the president is not a "truly progressive democrat," said Ma.
He suggested that Chen reflect on himself before accusing the opposition of trying to expose possible irregularities in his government.

When he was an opposition lawmaker, Chen also exposed a lot of government irregularities, but the government of the time did not accuse the opposition legislators of "acting in an organized way" in a bid to bring down the government, Ma continued.
"It's natural for opposition parties to monitor the government, so the government should not look at such activities from such a perspective," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC HEAD TERMS U.S. ENVOY APPOINTMENT 'SHEER SPECULATION'

TEXT.P: Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Joseph Wu denied through his aides Sunday a newspaper report that he is expected to be appointed by President Chen Shui-bian as Taiwan's top representative in the United States, replacing David Ta-wei Lee.

Wu described as "sheer speculation" the report, which quoted what it claimed was a "reliable source" as saying that Chen was dissatisfied with Lee's ability to "precisely and effectively" communicate with the U.S. government over Taiwan's policies and thus has been hoping for Lee's replacement.

The report also speculated that Lee is expected to be replaced by Wu and that the vacancy left by Wu will be filled by Shi Hwei-yow, currently a deputy director-general of the National Security Bureau.
The personnel changes are expected to be finalized in late May or early June after the legislature recesses, the report claimed.
Meanwhile, Ministry of Foreign Affairs spokesman Michel Lu also dismissed the newspaper claim, saying that the Foreign Ministry has no plans concerning Lee's replacement.
Lu said Lee has been working hard and has given a commendable performance as Taiwan's top representative in Washington, D.C.

Commenting on the newspaper speculation, an opposition People First Party legislative caucus whip said the problem in Taiwan-U.S. relations is not a matter of "who is serving as Taiwan's representative in Washington."
Lee Hung-chun claimed that it is a matter regarding what the Taiwan leadership is thinking.

He said it is unfair to blame David Lee for Taiwan's setback in its relations with the United States. The crux of the problem is the Presidential Office's foreign policies and cross-Taiwan Strait policy, he added.
He claimed that the president is the sole decision-maker concerning what role Taiwan plays in the international community, as well as how Taiwan should deal with China.
With a "waverer" as president, Lee Hung-chun claimed, even a god cannot do his job for Taiwan in the United States, let alone Joseph Wu.
An opposition Kuomintang (KMT) official also commented on the newspaper speculation.

Tseng Yung-chuan, executive director of the KMT Central Policy Committee, said that what he claimed are "deteriorating" Taiwan-U.S. relations was the result of President Chen's announcement of the cessation of the National Unification Council and its guidelines, as well as the ineptitude and inefficiency of the Democratic Progressive Party administration.
Taiwan must strive to build mutual trust with the United States and the problem cannot be solved simply by changing the representative, Tseng said.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP HEAD WILL NOT TAKE PART IN TAIPEI MAYORAL RACE

TEXT.P: Yu Shyi-kun, chairman of the ruling Democratic Progressive Part (DPP), said Sunday that he will not take part in the December Taipei mayoral election but will do his best to invite qualified DPP members to run.
Yu made the remarks in Taichung city, central Taiwan, where he was taking part in a party affairs meeting.

Pointing out that he has no intention of running for the post of Taipei mayor on behalf of the DPP, Yu said that his major task now is to lead the party and carry out party reforms. But he added that in his capacity of DPP chairman, he will call on prospective candidates to gain an understanding of their willingness to run, including former Premier Frank Hsieh and former lawmaker Shen Fu-hsiung.

In response to a media report that Hsieh said Yu should run, DPP spokesman Tsai Huang-liang said that Yu does not plan to run but has instead promised to help the DPP's nominees to run in both Taipei and Kaohsiung.
According to Tsai, the DPP would welcome Hsieh to run in Taipei because he is prestigious and a qualified candidate.
No matter whether Hsieh or Shen will get the DPP's nomination, the party will make all-out efforts to help whoever is nominated to win, Tsai said.
Meanwhile, Hsieh, who is slated to return to Taiwan later this month after concluding a study tour at a school affiliated to Harvard University, will open a workshop in early May in Kaohsiung.

But it remained unclear if Hsieh is willing to run in Taipei, where the voter base of the pro-independence "pan green camp" of the ruling DPP and the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) is smaller than that of the opposition "pan blue alliance" of the Kuomintang and the People First Party.

The DPP's Central Standing Committee has recently decided to put off the party's registration deadline for primaries from late April to early May -- a move that has been widely viewed as a way of leaving room for Hsieh to participate.
Meanwhile, the opposition TSU announced that it will nominate Monday Chou Yoh-kow, a TV talk show host, and lawmaker Lo Chih-ming, to run in Taipei and Kaohsiung, respectively.
Lo, who also doubles as the TSU's secretary-general, said that the TSU will not negotiate with the DPP over who should represent the "pan green camp" in Taipei, as the TSU supports Chou.

The TSU will not give way to the DPP no matter whether Shen or Hsieh wins the DPP's nomination, Lo said, although he expressed the hope that the two parties will work a way out to field a common candidate to represent the "pan green camp" in Kaohsiung.

DOC.HEADLINE: HUMAN RESOURCES KEY TO KEEPING TAIWAN'S ECONOMIC ADVANTAGES: CEPD

TEXT.P: In the face of the rapid economic rise of China and India, the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) under the Executive Yuan said Sunday that human resources is a key for Taiwan to maintain its economic advantages.

CEPD officials cited the example of the United States, saying that America will double its expenditure on research and development (R&D) in the next 10 years. The United States, where R&D spending accounts for one-third of the world total, is one of the most dynamic destinations for investment.

U.S. R&D expenses in fiscal 2007 will rise to US$137 billion, up more than 50 percent from 2001 and the U.S. government has also launched an action plan to boost American competitiveness by enhancing R&D abilities, innovation and human resources.
In the R&D field, the U.S. has transformed from the PC industry, the Internet and communications technology to nanotechnology, high-speed operations and new energy sources.
Meanwhile, America will also train 70,000 high school mathematics and science teachers and hire 30,000 basic math and science professionals to teach in high schools.
In order to continually maintain its competitive edge, Taiwan should enhance its own R&D ability, create an innovative environment and train its human resources, the officials noted.

They pointed out that the government budgeted NT$50 billion to implement its "elite universities in the world" program to bring one Taiwan university into the top 100 in the world within 10 years. In addition, under a 2005-2008 program, the government will send a total of 3,284 students overseas to study advanced technologies.

Moreover, the government is planning to set up a "National Education Academy" that will be responsible for drafting forward-looking programs to promote innovative education for key technologies, the officials said. (Timothy J. Hwang)

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER ANNOUNCES WIDER CAREER ACCESS TO HANDICAPPED

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang announced three policies Sunday that will give wider access for the handicapped and disabled to job and vocational opportunities.

During a ceremony marking the 10th anniversary of the implementation of the Protection Law for the Handicapped and Disabled, Su announced that government appropriation for enhancing employment for the handicapped and disabled will be increased by 20 percent annually -- from NT$890 million (US$27.55 million) in 2006 to NT$1.7 billion in 2007.

Su announced that the number of jobs made available by the Employment and Vocational Training Administration under the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) will be increased by 20 percent annually -- from 7,000 posted in 2005 to 8,400 this year.

He also announced that the government's requirement that companies must have a quota of physically challenged is not being met and that the shortfall of 3,400 unemployed handicapped and disabled will be reduced by 20 percent -- from the 3,400 people last year to 2,720 this year.

Meanwhile, the CLA invited a group of physically and mentally challenged people to visit Taipei 101 -- the tallest building in the world -- Sunday as one of the activities celebrating the 10th anniversary of the implementation of the Protection Law for the Handicapped and Disabled.

DOC.HEADLINE: TESCO TO BUY FROM TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Tesco, the largest supermarket chain in the United Kingdom, intends to purchase cosmetics, automobile accessories, stationery, toys and products for use by children, a spokesman for the Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) said Sunday.
The spokesman said a presentation on Tesco's procurement policy in Taiwan will be held Tuesday. Tesco is organizing the event at TAITRA'S invitation, the spokesman said.
Firms wishing to sell to Tesco can attend the presentation or call TAITRA for further details, the spokesman said.

Tesco opened its first Taiwan outlet at the end of 2000 in Taipei's Nankang area. The shop was acquired from Makro, a Dutch group that shifted its business to wholesale from retail. Tesco is set to pull out of Taiwan's retail market later this year.
Tesco is the second-largest retailer in Europe and the third in the world. It has 2,365 stores around the world and its annual turnover is more than US$68 billion per year.

DOC.HEADLINE: YOUTH COMMITTEE CALLS FOR COMMUNITY VOLUNTEERS

TEXT.P: National Youth Committee (NYC) Minister Cheng Li-chiun said Sunday that the NYC hopes to enroll more than 50,000 young volunteers within a year to do community service work.

Cheng said the NYC has encouraged people to volunteer their service since 2001, when Taiwan took part in the Global Youth Service Day (GYSD) activities of the United Nations, adding that more than 60,000 people have done volunteer work over the past four years. In the past year alone, more than 26,000 people have enrolled as volunteers.
GYSD was launched by the U.N. in 2000 to encourage young people around the world to serve their communities.

GYSD this year is set for April 21-23. During the three-day event, young volunteers in 150 countries will be involved, while the NYC is enrolling volunteers between 12 and 30 years of age in community service jobs, international assistance and education.

The education volunteers will be assigned to more than 2,000 elementary and junior high schools around Taiwan and will organize educational camps for school children, while international assistance volunteers will be assigned jobs in humanitarian assistance, medical assistance, ecological protection and community development.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA TO AUDIT DEBT COLLECTING COMPANIES

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) will have a full scale check into the operations of debt-collecting companies starting July 15 and will punish those found to have broken the law.

As huge amounts of debt have piled up because of banks' unchecked issuing of credit cards, the government has since March been taking preventive measures to stop card debts from rising even further, including imposing fines upon 29 debt-collection agencies.

These companies were fined after the MOEA and the Financial Supervisory Commission under the Executive Yuan completed on-the-spot checks of 57 companies and audited the financial statements of 92 other companies.
The MOEA turned the illegal cases over to the Bureau of Investigation for further investigation, while also asking county governments to crack down on illegal debt-collecting practices.

Companies involved in illegal debt collection will have their power and water supplies cut if they are found to have violated the regulations on the use of the buildings in which they are located, the MOEA said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CRACKDOWN ON NIGHTCLUBS, INTERNET CAFES TO BE REINFORCED: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang said Sunday that the Executive Yuan will reinforce crackdowns on illegal activities at nightclubs and Internet cafes in order to preserve public security.
Su made the statement at a joint meeting of the central and local government on public security at the National Police Agency (NPA).
During the report, he pointed out 33 issues of public security that should be improved.
Su said that crackdowns on nightclubs, including pubs, Internet cafes and KTVs, are aimed at preventing illegal activities.
Whenever it is necessary, local governments and police departments are empowered to cut water and electricity supplies to places where illegal activities are carried out, Su said.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER PREMIER WILL NOT RUN FOR TAIPEI MAYOR
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, April 22 (CNA) (By Laurence Chu and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Former Premier Frank Hsieh said Saturday here that he has no intention of running in the December election for Taipei mayor and also denied a media report that some heavyweights of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) have asked him to run.

Hsieh denied the speculation that some lawmakers and influential figures from the DPP traveled to Los Angeles to persuade him to seek the party's nomination, saying that "it is not the case." He said that "he is unwilling to vie for the post, at least for the time being."
Hsieh said that he would not consider running unless "the whole country sees such a need" or "it is a strategy designed by the DPP."
Hsieh flew into Los Angeles Saturday after concluding a study tour at a school affiliated to Harvard University.

Hsieh was greeted at the airport by officials from the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Los Angeles and hundreds of Taiwanese supporters who chanted slogans encouraging him to take part in the 2008 presidential election.

Meanwhile, DPP lawmakers Hsu Kuo-yung and Hsieh Shing-ni said Sunday in Taipei that Hsieh, who is a former premier, will set up a workshop in Kaohsiung to help strengthen the public's confidence in Taiwan's future by holding seminars on school campuses across Taiwan after he returns from the United States.

Speaking to a group of reporters in Taipei, Hsu Kuo-yung said that idea of launching the "Safeguarding Taiwan" activity focuses on building a notion among the public that Taiwan's fundamentals remain healthy and sound and that the people should take care of the country when facing persistent annexation threats from China.

Although Hsieh called for Taiwan's wider opening toward China, Hsu Kuo-yung said, however, that "co-existence" is the precondition of this advocacy and that Taiwan's survival must be guaranteed along with China's.
Turning to the future of the DPP, Hsu Kuo-yung quoted Hsieh as saying that the DPP should move toward the center.

Although both the DPP and its "pan green camp" partner, the Taiwan Solidarity Union, call for Taiwan independence, Hsieh was quoted as saying that each party should walk its own path. "Otherwise, the two parties should merge into one."

DOC.HEADLINE: SCHOOLS HONORED FOR PROMOTING HUMAN RIGHTS ON CAMPUSES

TEXT.P: Ten schools of various levels were honored by the Ministry of Education Sunday for their efforts to enhance human rights awareness on their campuses.

Notable among the award-winners is Sanchan Elementary School in Hualien County, eastern Taiwan, which was ranked as the most excellent among all the schools in instilling in its students the concept of human rights.

In a citation of the school, the Education Ministry said the Sanchan school, most of whose students are aborigines, set up a student autonomy group with its chief elected by the students for one semester, which exposed the students to the ideas of human rights, gender equality and the value of life.
The ministry said the school has successfully taught its students the vital concepts of a civil society through the autonomy group.

Lotung Senior High School in Lotung, Yilan County, was honored for setting up a student meeting in each class and a student council for all students and a student court to handle students' misbehaviours.
The ministry said Lotung has succeeded in teaching students the ideas of human rights through these self-ruling mechanism.

National Tatung Agricultural and Industrial Vocational School was honored for doing away altogether the restrictions on students' hairstyles and the ban on mobilphones in classes and giving students a freehand in choosing their own hairstyles and using mobilephones on campuse without disrupting the classes.
Through this experiment, the ministry said, students at that school have learned to mind their outlooks and behaviour out of self-respect.

At the request of the Education Ministry, the Public Television has filmed the ten award-winning schools' human-right promoting campaign into a documentary which was showed on Sunday's award-presenting ceremony.

DOC.HEADLINE: THSRC GOAL UNCHANGED TO LAUNCH KAOHSIUNG-TAIPEI SERVICE IN OCTOBER

TEXT.P: Taiwan High Speed Rail Corp. (THSRC) said Sunday its goal remains unchanged to launch the high speed rail service from Taipei to Kaohsiung at the end of October, 2006.

THSRC made the statement in the wake of a Japanese newspaper report that in the initial period, service will be provided only from Kaohsiung to Banqiao, near Taipei, while the Kaohsiung-Taipei service will have to wait until the end of January, 2007 at the earliest.
The Banqiao-Taipei service will be delayed because of electric engineering problems, according to the report.
Without explaining why the problems can't be solved by October, THSRC said it will "strive to reach the goal of launching the whole 345-km service from Kaohsiung to Taipei at the end of October."
Informed sources said THSRC is negotiating with Taiwan Shingansen Co. (TSC) over a contract to install the electrical systems between Banqiao station and Taipei station.

TSC is requesting that the job be completed by next January, but THSRC will not agree to that, insisting that it be finished by October so trains will travel from Kaohsiung to Taipei, and now both sides are in a deadlock, according to the sources.

After THSRC announced last year putting off the launch of service for a year, its contract with TSC had to be extended. As TSC thought that it needed time to study the new contract, it did not start talking with THSRC until Feb., 2006, when penalty on construction delays should begin. However, the sources noted, THSRC has not raised the issue with TSC as of now.

Transportation Minister Kuo Yao-chi has betted her political future on starting Kaohsiung-Banqiao service by the end of October, pledging that she would step down that if that does not come to pass. She has not promised when to launch the full-line service from Kaohsiung to Taipei.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT TO DECIDE MAYORAL CANDIDATE AFTER SOONG'S ANNOUNCEMENT: MA

TEXT.P: Chairman Ma Ying-jeou of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) said Sunday the "pan-blue alliance" will handle the issue of nominating a candidate for Taipei's mayoral election after Chairman James Soong of the People First Party (PFP) decides whether he will run or not.

Ma made the remarks in response to media reports that Soong is most likely to announce in May his bid to join the race for Taipei mayor, a move that will make pan-blue election campaigns more complicated.
"It will be better for Soong himself to proclaim that he wants to run or not," Ma told reporters while attending an event at the former residence of Chiang Kai-shek in ShiLin, Taipei.
"KMT will decide what to do after Soong makes known his decision," Ma added. The election is scheduled for December.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIDE DENIES REPOPRT ABOUT PRESIDENT'S ACCUSATION OF OPPOSITION

TEXT.P: The Presidential Office denied a local daily's report Sunday that President Chen Shui-bian branded a series of wrongdoing allegations about his family members and his senior aides as parts of an political-motivated scheme against him.
In a terse response to the report carried on Sunday's China Times, an anonymous aide to the president said it is "groundless."

The paper quoted Chen as telling his supporters in Changhua Saturday that the allegations of wrongdoings about his wife Wu Shu-chen and his senior aides are part of a scheme crafted by the "pan-blue alliance" led by the main opposition Kuomintang.

Under this scheme, Chen was reportedly saying that his political foes have gone out of the way to search and concoct false allegations of wrongdoings involving his senior aides or family members to tarnish the president and his administration.
The paper said the president called the scheme an intelligence warfare with the code name of "soft decapitation."
In response to these allegations, the first family has brought three lawsuits against an opposition lawmaker and two political commentators respectively for slander since April 12.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Protests Mount as Nepal Parties Reject King's Bid
For the second day in a row, more than 100,000 protesters flooded the streets as police officers, backed by the Royal Nepalese Army, for the most part stood by and let them pass through what was, even a day before, the heavily fortified Ring Road encircling the city center. Only around the palace did the police say that they were under strict orders to keep protesters at bay. By midafternoon Saturday, the coalition of Nepal's seven largest political parties, which began the demonstrations more than two weeks ago, formally rejected the king's offer, made in a televised address on Friday night, to return control of the government to a prime minister of the parties' choosing. In a statement, the seven-party alliance vowed to carry on with the agitation.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOTC OVERAHULING SCANDAL-STRICKEN TAIWAN RAILWAY ADMINISTRATION

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Transporation and Communications (MOTC) is reshuffling Taiwan Railway Administration's management in the wake of a series of accidents and a spate of corruption scandals in which at least a senior TRA engineer has been detained for suspected involvement in bidding irregularities.

MOTC Deputty Minister Ho Nuan-hsuan, who has acted as TRA director general since March 31, said Sunday he has ordered a suspension of the procurements of 316 commuting trains, pending a review of the their bidding documents.
TRA meanwhile has put a halt to the bidding process for purchasing 20 diesel-powered trains and 30 electric trains worth around NT$6.1 billion.
Ho said he intends to change some mid-level managers in an effort to restore discipline at TRA. If necessary, some of the senior managers will also be rotated, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR APRIL 24 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Monday, April 24:
10:00, President Chen Shui-bian will preside over a monthly meeting in remembrance of the country's founder Dr. Sun Yat-sen at the presidential office.
11:00, President Chen Shui-bian will receive a group of overseas Taiwan businessmen at the presidential official.
11:30, The Mainland Affairs Council will hold a news briefing at its Taipei office.
16:00, The members of the Council for Economic Planning and Development will hold a meeting.
16:00, The Ministry of Economic Affairs will reveal the country's export orders and industrial production index for March.
16:30, The Ministry of Finance will hold a news briefings.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN TO VISIT COSTA RICA, PARAGUAY IN MAY

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian is expected to visit Costa Rica and Paraguay from May 3-11, according to sources at the Presidential Office.
The president will attend the inauguration of Costa Rica president-elect Oscar Arias in San Jose on May 8 and will fly on to Paraguay, Taiwan's only ally in South America, for a visit.
Details of his itinerary is still working out by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and is expected to be announced later this week, said the sources.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, April 24, or the 27th day of the third month of the Year of the Dog according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1731: Daniel Defoe, British journalist, novelist and economist, dies at the age of 71. His works include "Robinson Crusoe" and "Moll Flanders."
1800: The U.S. Congress votes to set up a congressional library.
1898: Spain declares war on the United States after receiving a U.S. ultimatum to pull out of Cuba.
1919: Chan Tien-yu, a railway pioneer in China, dies in Hankou at the age of 59.
1941: Hsieh Chin-yuan, a Chinese hero in the War of Resistance Against Japan, is assassinated at the age of 37. The ROC Army regimental commander led his "800 Brave Fighters" in a heroic battle against invading Japanese troops at a warehouse in Shanghai. Shanghai was captured by the Japanese on Nov. 11, 1937, after three months of fierce fighting.
1946: The ROC government postpones the convention of the National Assembly set for May 6, 1946.
1948: Lin Hsien-tang is appointed head of the Historical Research Commission of Taiwan Province.
1955: The Bandung Conference ends with five Asian states condemning colonialism by both the West and the Soviet Union.
1963: "Liang Shan-po and Chu Ying-tai," a movie directed by Lee Han-hsiang, premieres in Taipei and receives a warm welcome from a large audience.
1965: The Indonesian government formally takes control of all foreign companies in the country.
1967: Soviet cosmonaut Vladimir Komarov plunges to Earth and dies when parachute straps on his Soyuz craft get tangled.
1970: Vice Premier Chiang Ching-kuo arrives in New York for a visit and survives an assassination attempt in front of his hotel by a pro-Taiwan independence radical.
1970: Mainland China launches its first satellite, the Dong Fang Hong, into orbit.
1970: The Food and Fertilizer Technology Center of the Asian and Pacific Council is inaugurated in Taipei.
1974: A 16-member Orient Trade Mission of the U.S. Pacific Northwest International Trade Council, led by William Martin, president of the council, arrives in Taipei for a three-day business trip.
1975: Thousands of Vietnamese refugees are flown to Guam as communists move rapidly in their takeover of South Vietnam.
1976: The 1976 convention of 4-H Clubs opens in Taipei with more than 300 delegates taking part.
1981: A train encounters a landslide while on its way to Mt. Ali in Chiayi County, killing 10 passengers and injuring 19 others.
1986: Wallis Simpson, Duchess of Windsor, for whom a British king gave up his throne amid great controversy, dies in Paris at the age of 89.
1986: ROC Minister of Foreign Affairs Chu Fu-sung and Paraguayan Foreign Minister Carlos Augusto Saldivar sign an extradition treaty in Taipei on behalf of their respective governments.
1990: West and East Germany agree to set July 2 as the date for economic union, a prelude to full political unification.
1996: Russian President Boris Yeltsin meets with his mainland Chinese counterpart, Jiang Zemin, at the start of a visit to Beijing.
1997: The head of states of Russia, mainland China, Kazakhstan, Tajikistan and Kyrgyzstan sign a pact on troop reduction along the former Sino-Soviet border.
2000: The ROC National Assembly begins to fade into history after it downgrades itself to a virtual ceremonial organization without much power by passing a series of constitutional amendments during a third reading.
2001: Competition at the Second Asian Physics Olympiad kicks off in Taipei with 81 senior high school students from 12 countries participating.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A wise and good man sometimes also meets with distress; but a fool, when in distress, becomes reckless."
