DOC.HEADLINE: MAC DISMISSES REPORT CLAIMING ROC REP TO U.S. TO BE REPLACED

TEXT.P: A Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) vice chairman on Monday described as groundless a newspaper report claiming that MAC Chairman Joseph Wu is expected to replace David Ta-wei Lee as Taiwan's top representative in the United States.
Johnnason Liu made the remarks at the Legislative Yuan when asked by opposition Kuomintang lawmaker Lai Shyh-bao about the report.

The newspaper report quoted a "reliable source" as indicating that President Chen Shui-bian has been dissatisfied with Lee's ability to precisely and effectively communicate with the U.S. government over Taiwan's policies and therefore wants him replaced. The report also said that the post left vacant by Wu will be filled by Shi Hwei-yow, deputy director-general of the National Security Bureau.
The personnel changes are expected to be finalized in late May or early June after the legislature goes into recess, the report said.

Wu denied the validity of the report through his aides Sunday. Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) spokesman Michel Lu also dismissed the newspaper report the same day, saying that the MOFA has no plans to replace Lee.
Lu said that Lee has been working hard and has performed his duties commendably as Taiwan's top representative in Washington, D.C.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT'S TRANSIT STOPS IN U.S. STILL BEING WORKED OUT: ROC REP
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 23 (CNA) (By Jorge Liu & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's top envoy to the United States, David Ta-wei Lee, dismissed Sunday a news report from Taiwan that said President Chen Shui-bian would make a stopover in New York May 10 on his way back home after concluding a trip to Latin America.

Chen is expected to visit Costa Rica and Paraguay from May 3-11. Presidential Office sources have indicated the president will attend the inauguration of Costa Rican President-elect Oscar Arias in San Jose May 8 and then fly on to Paraguay, Taiwan's only diplomatic ally in South America, for a visit.
Details of the president's itinerary are still being worked out by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and won't be finalized until later this week, according to the sources.
Lee said he was very surprised by the newspaper report and wondered what it was based on, noting that he is still engaged in talks with relevant U.S. authorities on Chen's transit stops.
"So far, the U.S. side hasn't yet given any official answers on the matter," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: LABOR UNION LEADER PUSHES FOR CLA'S RELOCATION TO SOUTHERN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: A labor union leader urged the Cabinet-level Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) Monday to relocate to the southern port city of Kaohsiung "to reflect current realities and better meet laborers' needs."

Chang Hsu-chung, chairman of the Chunghwa Telecommunications Labor Union, one of the largest labor unions in Taiwan, called for the CLA to relocate its headquarters from Taipei, northern Taiwan to the south to better serve the country's blue-collar workers.

Speaking at a hearing held to push for the CLA's relocation, Chang said there are around 650,000 blue-collar workers in Kaohsiung City, which is more than in Taipei County or Taoyuan County -- two counties known for their large numbers of laborers.
Kaohsiung also has a serious problem with unemployment, making it pressing for the government to come up with coping measures to help the unemployed find jobs, Chang said.
He also argued that the CLA could save a lot of the NT$80 million (US$2.48 million) it currently spends each year on renting office space in Taipei if it relocates to southern Taiwan.

Chang called for parties across the political spectrum to jointly establish an "action alliance to promote the CLA's relocation to the south" to help materialize a slogan which has been said for years without any action being taken.
He suggested that the legislature first freeze the CLA's annual budget so as to exert pressure on the council to relocate.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened low but closed higher Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 2.99 points to close at 7,096.04.
The bourse opened at 7,066.19 and fluctuated between 7,141.29 and 7,057.19 during trading. A total of 3.93 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$117.88 billion (US$3.67 billion).

Six of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with foodstuff issues moving up the most at 4.5 percent, followed by construction issues at 3.5 percent, paper and pulp issues at 2.6 percent, textile stocks at 2.3 percent, cement stocks at 1.2 percent, and banking and financial shares at 0.7 percent.
The two other major stock categories lost ground, with machinery and electronics shares moving down at 0.4 percent and plastics and chemicals shares dropping 0.3 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 536 to 351, with 99 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: BAPHIQ ESTABLISHES NEW BIO-DATABASE ON VERMIN, VIRUSES

TEXT.P: The Bureau of Animal and Plant Health Inspection and Quarantine (BAPHIQ) under the Council of Agriculture (COA) announced Friday that it has completed a new bio-database on vermin and viruses.
The BAPHIQ said that the database --with nearly 5 million entries from Taiwan, China and several other countries -- can facilitate cross-examination on possible infections of animals and plants.

Once the pathogen is determined, the BAPHIQ said, the database can also help in making the best decision, whether to exterminate the infected fauna and flora or to use proper treatment against the specific vermin or virus.

The BAPHIQ said that the database already contains the following items -- biological information on known vermin and viruses, an interface allowing users to compare the known RNA and DNA to the unknown ones, and a bibliography of past analysis and research on vermin and viruses.
The BAPHIQ emphasized that they will keep on expanding the database to meet future needs.

DOC.HEADLINE: HOSPITAL CRITICIZED FOR NOT REPORTING LEE'S TB CASE TO TAIPEI GOV'T

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou said Monday that Taipei Veterans General Hospital (TVGH) had violated the law for reporting former President Lee Teng-hui's tuberculosis case directly to the central government and bypassing the Taipei City Government.
The TVGH confirmed last Saturday that Lee was discharged from hospital the previous day after receiving treatment for a mild case of tuberculosis.
The 83-year-old Lee went to the hospital in mid-March after suffering from fever and a cold, but a later medical checkup found that Lee had tuberculosis.
Ma stressed that as tuberculosis is a notifiable disease, hospitals are required by law to report TB cases to the local government.
The Taipei City Government will ask for an explanation from the hospital and will not exclude the possibility of interviewing related doctors to determine who should take responsibility.

Meanwhile, Shih Wen-yi, deputy director of the Center for Disease Control (CDC) under the Department of Health (DOH) , said the TVGH really mishandled the matter by not first reporting Lee's tuberculosis case to the Taipei City Government.
Although the TVGH's mishandling has not had a negative impact on epidemic control efforts, the CDC will respect the decision of Taipei City Government on whether to mete out punishment.
According to Shih, the CDC has checked some 20 people who had close contact with the former president, and the results show that none of them have been infected.

As to the source of Lee's TB, Shih stressed that the incubation period of TB may last several months, therefore it is quite difficult to determine the source since Lee, as a popular former head of state, has close contact with countless numbers of people on a regular basis.

Shih noted that Lee has been a good patient, following all the rules of TB treatment, including temporary quarantine, and the CDC may invite Lee to serve as the TB representative in the future to help promote the campaign against tuberculosis.
According to CDC statistics, tuberculosis is Taiwan's No. 1 contagious disease, with about 15,000 cases annually -- more than all the other infectious diseases combined.
With some 1,000 people dying from tuberculosis each year, the DOH has been working on a plan to cut the tuberculosis death rate in half within 10 years.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO CHINESE INVOLVEMENT IN ALLEGATIONS AGAINST PRESIDENT: BOI CHIEF

TEXT.P: There is absolutely no "Chinese involvement, " "pan-blue alliance" "intelligence organization" or "soft decapitation" attempts against the president and the first family, the nation's top investigative officer said Monday.
Yeh Sheng-mao, director of the Bureau of Investigation under the Ministry of Justice, made the remarks in reply to a question from opposition lawmaker Lee Ching-huan at the Legislative Yuan.

A major newspaper reported a day earlier that President Chen Shui-bian told his supporters in Changhua County Saturday that allegations of wrongdoings involving his wife Wu Shu-jen and his senior aides were part of a scheme crafted by the "pan-blue alliance" led by the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT).

Under this scheme, Chen reportedly claimed, his political foes have been concocting false allegations of wrongdoings involving his senior aides and family members to tarnish his image as well as that of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) government.
The daily quoted Chen as describing the scheme as "intelligence warfare" bearing the codename "soft decapitation."
The Presidential Office denied the report as "groundless."

Lee asked Yeh if government investigators have found any evidence of Chen's reported allegations about the "pan-blue alliance's" intelligence gathering organization or Chinese involvement in an attempt at "soft decapitation, " to which Yeh replied: "absolutely not." He said his bureau gathers valid information and investigates facts only, and he called for support for the bureau's operations.
In response to media questions about the president's reported allegations, KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou scoffed at the president for making the allegations.

Ma quoted the Chinese proverb: "An object must become corrupt before worms can emerge from it, " and urged Chen to reflect on himself before accusing the opposition of trying to expose possible irregularities in the government.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. TRANSIT STOPS FOR PRESIDENT, PREMIER BEING ARRANGED: MOFA

TEXT.P: Transit stops in the United States for President Chen Shui-bian and Premier Su Tseng-chang when they travel to and from Latin America next month are being arranged, officials from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Monday.
Chen is scheduled to visit Costa Rica and Paraguay for state visits May 3-11, while Su is scheduled to depart in mid-May for Haiti and several other Caribbean allies, according to MOFA officials.

The MOFA expects that both Chen and Su will be able to make stopovers in the United States on their way to and from Latin America and the ministry is making relevant arrangements toward that end, the officials said.
Meanwhile, Chen was asked by opposition Kuomintang (KMT) legislators Monday to declare his advocacy of the "one side, one country" concept when he makes his stopovers in the United States.

KMT Legislator Lee Ching-hua chided Chen for pushing for Taiwan independence by saying in a speech to a group of supporters two days ago that one of his achievements as president has been the establishment of the "one side, one country" concept as Taiwan's stance on cross-Taiwan Strait relations.
Lee claimed that Chen's "one side, one country" concept is tantamount to a declaration of Taiwan independence and added that Chen should also make the stance known to Washington.
He called on the president not to advocate Taiwan independence only within the country, saying that Chen should "declare it loudly" to U.S. President George W. Bush during his transit stops.
Pan Wei-kang, a party whip of the KMT legislative caucus, claimed that by establishing the "one side, one country" concept, Chen was actually "inviting war" across the Taiwan Strait.

Pan claimed that Chen has been scheming with a series of eyebrow-raising slogans and activities -- including talk about constitutional engineering and intelligence exercises on crises and war scenarios -- to draw the public's attention away from the string of recent corruption scandals involving high-ranking government officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES LOWER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower Monday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for May moved down 24 points to close at 7,081, with 41,657 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for June dropped 12 points to finish at 7,072, with 320 contracts traded, while September futures lost 22 points to close at 6,882, with 27 contract transactions.
December futures rose 10 points to close at 6,900, with eight contracts traded, while March futures moved down 37 points to finish at 6,940, with three contract transactions.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Monday at 7,105 for May, 7,084 for June, 6,904 for September, 6,890 for December and 6,977 for March.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mixed.
May TE futures moved up 2.5 points to close at 316, with 6,211 contracts traded, while June TE futures lost 2.95 points to finish at 314.3, with 39 contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

May TF futures gained 10.6 points to finish at 938.8, with 4,175 contracts changing hands, while June TF futures moved up 11.6 points to close at 940, with 43 contracts traded. September TF futures rose four points to close at 920, with 21 contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: BSMI TO LAUNCH CAMPAIGN IN BATTLE AGAINST SUBSTANDARD GOODS

TEXT.P: The Bureau of Standards, Metrology and Inspection (BSMI) is launching a campaign Tuesday to educate governmental personnel on how to detect substandard products, a BSMI spokesman said Monday.

The campaign, which will run until May 18, is part of the government's efforts to crack down on substandard and counterfeit products. Courses will be offered to government procurement personnel in Keelung, Taipei, Hsinchu, Taichung, Tainan, Kaohsiung and Hualien, the spokesman said.
Government personnel in charge of receiving consumers' complaints are also requested to attend the courses, according to the spokesman.

The BSMI spokesman said that commodities that should have labels proving that they have passed quality and security inspections include television sets, air conditioners, water boilers and dish dryers, to name a few. The fines for products without such labels range from between NT$200,000 (US$6,250) and NT$2,000,000, the spokesman said.

DOC.HEADLINE: OFFICIAL VOWS TO STEP UP CONTROL MEASURES AT AIRPORTS

TEXT.P: Vice Interior Minister Yen Wan-chin pledged Monday to step up security control measures at the nation's international airports following several embarrassing incidents of inbound passengers slipping past security check points at the Chiang Kai-shek International Airport.
Yen made the remarks at the Interior Committee of the Legislative Yuan during which National Police Agency (NPA) reported on security control measures at international airports.
Noting that the airports are the nation's gateways to the world, Yen said the NPA will review any possible loopholes and make the necessary improvements.
Legislator David Huang of the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union pointed out that in 2004, a spate of incidents involving Chinese tourists took place when they fled en masse upon arriving in Taiwan.

Since this year, four incidents involving inbound passengers slipping past security check points at the CKS Airport were reported, Huang continued, showing that security controls are alarmingly lacking at the airport.
At a time when the world is stepping up airport security controls following the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks in 2001, Taiwan's security controls are simply too lax, Huang claimed.
Legislator Lin Yun-sheng of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party said that although aviation policemen are equipped with guns, they mostly avoid using them for fear of hurting innocent bystanders.
For this reason, sticks and whistles may also not be helpful, Lin said, suggesting instead less lethal weapons such as stun guns, anesthetic guns or net guns to catch airport runners.

NPA officials said that since the latest incident involving a Vietnamese slipping through security checks at the CKS Airport April 18, the agency has increased aviation police deployment contingent on the situation, installed additional remote-control video cameras, set up alarm connection lines and automatic power shut-down facilities at the airport.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT URGED TO REVIEW EARLY CHILDHOOD EDUCATION POLICY

TEXT.P: Experts and academics in early childhood education called Monday for the government to review its pre-school education policy and integrate resources to address the problem that many disadvantaged families cannot afford pre-school education, despite being entitled to government subsidies.

The call was made at a news conference held by the non-profit Education Reconstruction Front and the Taiwan Provincial Education Association to report their monthly reviews of educational reforms the government began 10 years ago.

During the news conference, the experts and academics expressed doubt as to the effectiveness of the government subsidy of NT$5,000 (US$156) per school term per child. For wealthy families, the money is a drop in the bucket, while for poor families, the subsidy is not enough for them to send children to private kindergarten. Meanwhile, there is an insufficiency of public pre-school institutues for such children.
Ou Tzi-hsiu, a member of the board of the Association of Early Childhood Education Reform, suggested the government do more than just throw money at the problem.
Ou pointed out that the country lacks public kindergartens and is also faced with an insufficiency of qualified pre-school teachers.

Furthermore, the government has failed to guide the development of early childhood education, Ou claimed, citing statistics as saying one-third of pre-school institutes around Taiwan are unlicensed and are operating as cram schools.
Her association has found that most parents would rather send their children to public kindergartens than private ones, Ou added.

DOC.HEADLINE: RISING CURRENCY, OIL PRICES SEEN TO ADVERSELY IMPACT TAIWAN EXPORTS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's rising currency and surging oil prices are adversely impacting Taiwan's export trade, a trade association official warned Monday.

The drastically appreciating NT dollar -- which rose at one point to nearly NT$32 to the US$1 Monday morning -- coupled with surging oil prices, is driving Taiwan exporters' spirits low, said Lo Huai-chia, deputy secretary-general of the Taiwan Electrical and Electronic Manufacturers' Association.

Lo claimed that the NT dollar's recent appreciation does not reflect Taiwan's economic fundamentals but has been caused by speculation by international fund operators who believe cross-Taiwan Strait relations might improve in the near future.

Lo called for Taiwan exporters to take hedging measures against variables and uncertainties and said that the association -- which is comprised of companies that together form the backbone of Taiwan's economy -- will also make the exporters' worries known to the government.
He also urged the Central Bank of China to try to keep the currency stable.

Meanwhile, Tai Sheng-tung, chairman of the National Association of Small- and Medium-sized Enterprises, said that should the NT dollar continue to appreciate, it will seriously compromise the international competitiveness of the country's export trade, which will in turn drag down Taiwan's overall economic growth.
Noting that export trade has been the prime mover behind Taiwan's economic growth, Tai urged relevant government agencies to face this crisis squarely and come up with useful policies soon.

DOC.HEADLINE: EFFICIENCY SHOULD BE CONSIDERED IF CLA IS TO BE MOVED SOUTH

TEXT.P: Vice Minister Su Li-chiung of the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) said Monday that the administrative efficiency of the CLA should be taken into account in any decision to relocate the office to Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan.

Su made the statement in response to Chunghua Telecom Workers' Union Chairman Chang Hsu-chung's call for the CLA to move its headquarters from Taipei, the capital city in northern Taiwan and the home of the central government, to Kaohsiung in the south, a move that he claimed would better serve blue-collar laborers.

Chang even called for a cross-party "action alliance to promote the CLA's relocation to the south" and suggested that the Legislative Yuan freeze the CLA's annual budget as a means of pressuring the council to relocate.
Su said that she was open to such a suggestion, but noted that if there should be a relocation plan, it would have to be made in the context of the Executive Yuan's government restructuring program.
Su pointed out that most governmental departments are located in the north, and "easy communications among departments" should be taken into account if the CLA is to be relocated.
She added that the CLA is increasing staff members in its offices in southern Taiwan, an indication that the CLA values laborers in the south.

Statistics compiled by the Directorate-General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) show that there are 1.7 million laborers in Taipei City, 1.32 million in Taipei County, 870,000 in Taoyuan County -- all in the north -- compared to just 786,000 in Kaohsiung City and 423,000 in Kaohsiung County.

DOC.HEADLINE: PLANS TO ABOLISH 6-YEAR MAXIMUM STAY FOR FOREIGN WORKERS

TEXT.P: The Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) is planning to cancel the six-year ceiling of cumulative stay in Taiwan by foreign blue-collar workers, a move that is aimed at benefiting both Taiwan employers and the foreign workers, a CLA official said Monday.
Su Li-chiung, a vice chairwoman of the CLA, said the council is amending the employment law to abolish the six-year rule for foreign blue-collar workers.

Should the amendment be passed by the Legislative Yuan, the six-year ceiling will be removed for workers who have given outstanding performance and who have worked legally in Taiwan for more than six years without any record of irregularities, Su said.
Meanwhile, Su said, the employment law will also be amended to stiffen punishments for local employers who hire illegal alien workers.
To encourage absconded foreign workers to turn themselves in, the CLA is also pondering an amnesty for this group of people, Su added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CALLS KMT-CPC CONCLUSIONS 'SUGAR-COATED POISON'

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian accused the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Monday of "coercing everyone to swallow sugar-coated poison" by demanding that the government accept recent conclusions on cross-Taiwan Strait issues reached between the KMT and the Communist Party of China (CPC).

Chen further accused the KMT of attempting to curry favor with Beijing for the sake of partisan interests and carrying out a "political struggle" against the ruling Democratic Progressive Party "under the pretense of promoting economic and trade exchanges" with China.

He made the remarks while receiving representatives of the World Taiwanese Chambers of Commerce. He was referring to conclusions reached at last week's KMT-CPC economic forum held in Beijing, in which the two parties agreed to promote direct cross-strait transport links, enhance cross-strait agricultural exchanges and cooperation, strengthen cross-strait financial exchanges, encourage Taiwan's services sector to enter the Chinese market, boost cross-strait tourism and seek to establish a stable mechanism for cross-strait economic cooperation.

Chen said the government is not against China or the Chinese people or cross-strait economic and trade exchanges, but that Taiwan must not harbor any "wishful thinking" or turn a blind eye to the potential danger and crisis underlying cross-strait economic activities.

Chen said the government hopes to engage in dialogue and consultations with China but cannot accept any attempts by Beijing to downgrade and marginalize Taiwan and to deny the legitimacy of the government and sovereignty of Taiwan.
Chen said it is part of China's united front tactics against Taiwan to bypass the popularly elected government, which he said is unhelpful to the development of cross-strait economy and trade.

The president pointed out that improving law and order, preventing a bird flu outbreak and boosting the economy are the three major goals of the Cabinet led by Premier Su Tseng-chang and he praised Su as handling Taiwan-U.S. relations and cross-strait ties very properly.
On reports by local media that Su is at odds with Chen on the government's cross-strait policy, Chen dismissed these as "unfactual reports" aimed at driving a wedge between Su and himself.

According to Chen, Su's April 12 announcement regarding the government's policy towards cross-strait charter flight services, visits to Taiwan by Chinese tourists and the export of Taiwan's agricultural products to China was based on Chen's instruction that the government must take the initiative in cross-strait relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Monday, losing NT$0.317 to close at NT$31.992.
A total of US$1.388 billion changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at the day's high of NT$32.309 and hit a low of NT$31.982.

DOC.HEADLINE: CEC HEAD NIXES IDEA OF 'TWO-IN-ONE' ELECTIONS IN JANUARY 2008

TEXT.P: Central Election Commission (CEC) Chairman Chang Cheng-hsiung said Monday that three months is the ceiling for a president-elect to assume the presidency according to the spirit of the Constitution.

Chang made the remarks while delivering a report to the Committee on Organic Laws and Statutes at the Legislative Yuan on a study of the transitional period between election day and the inauguration of the president.

Noting that the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) has proposed to hold the next presidential and legislative elections simultaneously in January 2008, Chang said that the "two-in-one" election proposal does not conform with the spirit of the Constitution.

According to the Constitution, the next president cannot take office until May 20, 2008. If the next president were to be elected in January 2008, the president-elect would have to wait for four months to take office.
Chang noted that the period between election day and inauguration day is no longer than 80 days in the United States and between one and two months in most other countries.
The longest transition period is three months and 20 days in Peru, according to Chang.

Under current constitutional provisions, the premier should perform the duties of the president in the event of vacancies in both the presidency and the vice presidency, but the period is limited to three months, he added.

Meanwhile, KMT Legislator Wu Chih-yang said that nearly 2,000 boroughs will only see one candidate in the borough chief elections in June, and since the candidate will only need one vote to be elected, and the candidates will surely vote for themselves, he asked if the one-candidate boroughs can scrap the voting and counting process of a poll to save manpower and resources.

Chang said that the civil servant election and recall law indeed has not set the threshold for the borough chief to be elected, mainly because it is a grassroots election and if anyone is willing to serve, the government is appreciative.
But the campaign activities will still be held even if it is a one-man election, Chang added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT WARNS AGAINST OPENNESS TO CHINA WITHOUT RISK MANAGEMENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Monday that openness without risk management toward China could result in high unemployment, low income and low corporate benefits.

Chen made the remarks during a meeting with a delegation from the World Taiwanese Chambers of Commerce, in which he also urged the public to pay heed to the impact China's economic rise has caused on the global economic system.

Chen noted that China was the world's largest coal and steel consumer and the second-largest importer of petroleum in 2003, and that its endless demand for energy has pushed up commodity prices around the world.
In addition, China's cheap labor has grabbed employment opportunities from many people around the world.

Quoting tallies complied by the U.S. Commerce Department, Chen said 13 of Mexico's top 20 export industries saw their global market shares shrink substantially between 2002 and 2003 due to fierce competition from China's low-priced products.
According to U.S. statistics, Americans lose some 400,000 jobs to their Chinese counterparts each year, Chen said.
The soaring commodity prices and unemployment rates have squeezed the development space of both developed and underdeveloped countries, Chen said.
He further said although some economic problems are due to domestic factors, most of the difficult economic situations could be blamed on China's unbalanced development and unfair trade competition.
Taiwan has also faced terrible ordeals, Chen pointed out, adding that Taiwan's failure to properly manage its opening to China in the past has resulted in a huge capital flow to China.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPPOSITION LAWMAKERS URGED TO FREE BUDGETS FOR MAC, NSC

TEXT.P: The legislative caucus of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) urged opposition legislators Monday to free the budgets for the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) and the National Security Council (NSC), warning that otherwise, their operations will grind to a halt by late May.

At a press conference at the Legislative Yuan, DPP caucus whip Chen Chin-jun criticized the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) for having blocked a motion to free the budgets eight times at the procedure committee.
He expressed worry that if the budget freeze is not removed, the MAC and the NSC will not be able to pay their utility bills in the next couple of months, let alone salaries for their personnel.
Chen urged the opposition legislators not to block the motion for the ninth time when it is reintroduced in the procedure committee Tuesday.

In early January, the opposition-controlled legislature slashed the MAC's 2006 budget by 21 percent, totaling NT$96 million, and froze one half of the approved part of its budget, in an apparent move to show the "pan-blue alliance's" dissatisfaction with the MAC's performance last year.
KMT and PFP legislators passed a resolution requiring MAC officials to appear at the legislature's Home and Nations Committee and Budget and Final Accounts Committee to defend the MAC's China policy.

The MAC has been at odds with the KMT and the PFP on how to handle relations with China. In December last year, the MAC refused to allow Chen Yunlin, director of the Taiwan Affairs Office under China's State Council, to visit Taiwan to attend a cross-strait economic and cultural forum sponsored by the KMT. More recently, the MAC further angered the opposition by calling China's "goodwill" gesture of offering a pair of pandas to Taiwan "a united front tactic."

The NSC also suffered a budget cut of NT$8 million, with two-thirds of its NT$200 million budget frozen, mainly because opposition lawmakers wanted to retaliate against NSC Secretary-General Chiou I-jen for masterminding the DPP's campaign prior to the mayoral and county magistrate elections in December last year. To remove the freeze, Chiou will have to give an assurance that the NSC will remain neutral in domestic politics in the future.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWMAKER CALLS FOR MEETING BETWEEN KMT HONORARY HEAD, PREMIER

TEXT.P: Independent lawmaker Lin Wei-chou urged Premier Su Tseng-chang Monday to meet with Kuomintang (KMT) Honorary Chairman Lien Chan to forge a consensus on Taiwan's future ties with China after Lien returns from a visit there.
Lin issued the call at a Legislative Yuan news conference prior to Lien's slated return Tuesday.

According to Lin, Su should invite Lien to discuss ways to implement the 15 overtures made by Beijing following an economic forum between the KMT and the Communist Party of China (CPC) April 14-15 in Beijing. He said Beijing and Taipei should also ink a pact to assure the implementations of the 15 measures.
If either Su or Lien refuses to meet, it would be clear that their earlier remarks about building a better Taiwan are nothing more than "political fireworks" concealing ulterior motives, Lin claimed.

He suggested that the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) government sponsor a national affairs conference and invite KMT and CPC officials to explore means of resolving cross-Taiwan Strait disputes and problems.

Brushing aside the opinion prevailing among DPP members that more frequent and closer cross-strait exchanges might undermine Taiwan's national sovereignty, Lin said that the DPP should bravely face up to China's rise, as the results of various surveys show there is a five-fold increase in the number of local people who now think of themselves as Taiwanese rather than Chinese.

DPP legislative caucus whip Chen Chin-jun said that the Executive Yuan should consider taking the initiative in cross-strait affairs that require government authority by putting forth complementary measures to help implement Beijing's 15 overtures as long as Taiwan's national sovereignty is fully safeguarded.

The DPP legislative caucus would be happy to see a Su-Lien meeting, as well as a second meeting between KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou and President Chen Shui-bian, or even a meeting between the president and Lien, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT SAVINGS NEGATIVE FOR THIRD CONSECUTIVE YEAR: ACADEMIC

TEXT.P: The central government's savings have been in the red for three consecutive years and its outstanding debt has hit a critical level, an academic said Monday.

Professor Tseng Chu-wei of National Chengchi University made the remarks in a speech titled "Financial Disciplines and the Establishment of an Early Warning System on Debts" at a monthly meeting at the Presidential Office.
He described the two main indicators on the top limit of outstanding debt as the "macro economics" indicator and the "financial stability" indicator.

He said that based on the ratio of budget surplus, most cities in Taiwan, including Taipei and Kaohsiung, are showing yellow lights, which is "tolerable" for the financial stability indicator. Only Penghu, Chiayi, Taichung, Kinmen and Lienchiang counties are showing "white" or safe lights, he added.

The macro economics indicator is divided into two parts -- government savings and domestic net investment, while the financial stability indicator is assessed by budget shortfalls and the surplus ratios of the government's key budgets.

Tseng said the savings of the central government were negative for three years in a row starting from 2001, something that had never happened before 1999. He noted that the 2001-2003 debts were NT$185.6 billion, NT$131.6 billion, and NT$50.4 billion, respectively, indicating that the government is a net borrower of resources.

Domestic net investment decreased for the five consecutive years from 1999 to 2003, although government savings during the same time did not, so the net investment indicator remained at a "white" or safe level, he said.
Nevertheless, he warned that a warning light could flash for the net investment indicator if the government's financial situation does improve. (Timothy J. Hwang)

DOC.HEADLINE: HEROIN TRAFFICKER NABBED AT CKS AIRPORT

TEXT.P: A Taiwanese man attempting to smuggle heroin from China into Taiwan was arrested at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport Sunday, the Coast Guard Administration said.

A spokesman for the administration said Monday that Fang Chih-wei, who was returning from Guangdong province, China via Macau, was carrying 792 grams of heroin -- tied around his abdomen and thighs -- as he walked through an immigration checkpoint.

The spokesman said that acting on tips about Fang's drug-trafficking plan, the Coast Guard Administration's detachment on the outlying island of Kinmen worked with police and customs officials and waited at the airport for his arrival.
As soon as Fang showed up, he was escorted to a special room for a body search, yielding 792 grams of first-grade heroin with a street value of NT$6 million.
Fang admitted he agreed to carry the drugs for a drug-trafficking ring in return for NT$200,000.
Police are still investigating the case.

DOC.HEADLINE: PUNISHMENTS FOR ANIMAL SMUGGLING TO BE INCREASED

TEXT.P: Animal smugglers will face harsher penalties if a draft bill clears the legislature.

The Legislative Yuan's Committee on Economy and Energy Resources passed Monday the first reading of a draft revision to the existing law on prevention and control of infectious animal diseases that raises punishments for animal smugglers.

According to the draft amendment, anyone caught bringing animals into Taiwan without permission can be sentenced to a maximum of seven years in prison instead of the three years provided for at present, plus fines of up to NT$3 million (US$93,800).

Any vehicles used by the smugglers to commit the crime, such as ships or cars, will be confiscated, according to the committee, which explained that the amendment is part of the government's efforts to prevent animals carrying infectious diseases from entering Taiwan.
The draft amendment only has to pass reviews of the committee before it can be delivered to the plenary session of the Legislative Yuan.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH SAYS HEPATITIS-B VACCINE EFFECTIVE

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) has no doubt about the protective power of hepatitis-B vaccine and will not advise that people get additional shots, a DOH official said Monday.

Shih Wen-yi, deputy director-general of the DOH's Center for Disease Control (CDC) , made the remarks amid reports that a 15-year-old teenager was recently diagnosed with acute hepatitis-B despite having received four shots previously.
Shih said that cases of people being infected with hepatitis-B after receiving vaccinations are rare and that the center will investigate the case.

He noted that the CDC had previously commissioned National Taiwan University for a study showing that at the most conservative estimate, 20 percent of vaccinated newborns will lose the antibodies in between 15 and 18 years.
But whether this means that the protective power of the vaccines is undermined will still have to be studied, he went on.
He said Taiwan's public health environment has been upgraded substantially, greatly reducing the hazards of the virus.
Reported cases of acute hepatitis-B have not seen a dramatic increase in recent years, Shih said, and Taiwan's achievement in preventing the disease has been recognized internationally.
Therefore, a vaccination consultation committee has concluded that there is no need for people to get additional shots, he added.

But medical staff or families that have members who are hepatitis-B virus carries are still advised to consult with doctors to see if they still have antibodies, CDC officials said. Even if tests show negative, they can still get an additional shot at their own expenses with the consent of their doctors, the officials added.

They also said that in addition to getting shots, the public should refrain from hazardous behavior such as unsafe sex or sharing needles and razors. The officials also described getting tattoos or piercings as "hazardous behavior."

DOC.HEADLINE: EDITOR'S NOTE

TEXT.P: Re CEP 0033, the last paragraph should read "...if the government's financial situation does not improve." The original copy missed the word "not."

A corrected version follows:

He described the two main indicators on the top limit of outstanding debt as the "macro economics" indicator and the "financial stability" indicator.

He said that based on the ratio of budget surplus, most cities in Taiwan, including Taipei and Kaohsiung, are showing yellow lights, which is "tolerable" for the financial stability indicator. Only Penghu, Chiayi, Taichung, Kinmen and Lienchiang counties are showing "white" or safe lights, he added.

The macro economics indicator is divided into two parts -- government savings and domestic net investment, while the financial stability indicator is assessed by budget shortfalls and the surplus ratios of the government's key budgets.

Tseng said the savings of the central government were negative for three years in a row starting from 2001, something that had never happened before 1999. He noted that the 2001-2003 debts were NT$185.6 billion, NT$131.6 billion, and NT$50.4 billion, respectively, indicating that the government is a net borrower of resources.

Domestic net investment decreased for the five consecutive years from 1999 to 2003, although government savings during the same time did not, so the net investment indicator remained at a "white" or safe level, he said.
Nevertheless, he warned that a warning light could flash for the net investment indicator if the government's financial situation does not improve. (Timothy J. Hwang)

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN MIGHT EVACUATE EXPATRIATES FROM SOLOMON ISLANDS

TEXT.P: The government will evacuate families of the country's diplomatic and technical personnel from the Solomon Islands if turmoil in the Pacific nation does not improve by April 28, a Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) official said Monday.
According to MOFA spokesman Michel Lu, only about 10 people would be affected in the event of an evacuation.
Lu said he believes the situation in the Solomon Islands will soon be brought under control because Australia and New Zealand have increased their peace-keeping presence there.

In response to China's claim that it will protect the safety of all ethnic Chinese in the Solomon Islands -- including Taiwanese, Hong Kong and Macau expatriates, Lu said Taiwan has an embassy in the Solomon Islands and does not need any help from Beijing.
Riots broke out in the Solomon Islands last week following the election of Snyder Rini as prime minister, amid rumors the election was swayed by influence from Taiwan or China.
With rioters targeting ethnic Chinese businesses because they were believed to be backing Rini, China has evacuated the country's expatriates from the Solomon Islands.
Taiwan issued a travel alert Friday advising its people to postpone their plans to visit the Solomon Islands for sightseeing or business purposes.

MOFA statistics show there are approximately 1,000 ethnic Chinese in the Solomon Islands. While most of these ethnic Chinese are from Hong Kong and China's Guangdong province, there are also some immigrants from Southeast Asia and Chinese citizens who work there. Of these ethnic Chinese, around 500 have obtained Solomon citizenship. There are less than 20 Taiwanese expatriates in the Pacific nation, according to the MOFA.

DOC.HEADLINE: MARCH EXPORT ORDERS HIT NEW HIGH

TEXT.P: Taiwan's export orders hit a record single-month high at US$24.94 billion in March, rising 19.33 percent from the same time last year, according to tallies released Monday by the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA).
MOEA officials said export orders for basic metals, plastic and rubber products, machinery and precision instruments all posted new single-month highs in March.

Export orders in March for information and communications products increased 50.08 percent year-on-year to US$1.78 billion owing to strong demand in the global notebook computer and mobile phone markets, while orders for electronic products rose 32.91 percent to US$1.38 billion, the officials said.

They said orders from the United States amounted to US$6.73 billion, up 22.67 percent over the same month last year. Those from Hong Kong, including China, totalled US$5.91 billion, up 16.94 percent year-on-year. Those from Europe and Japan were valued at US$4.27 billion and US$2.72 billion, respectively.
For the first quarter of this year, Taiwan's export orders amounted to US$67.31 billion, up 21.25 percent from the same time last year, the officials said.
They predicted the country's export orders will continue to increase in April, with information and communications products expected to see the highest growth.
They said Taiwan's export orders are likely to continue to post a double-digit growth in the second quarter.

Meanwhile, 25.82 percent of exporters surveyed by the ministry expect export orders to further increase in April, 22.14 percent expect the orders to decrease, and 52.04 percent expect the orders to remain the same, according to the MOEA.

DOC.HEADLINE: PULI RESIDENTS LEARNING JAPANESE TO ATTRACT MORE LONG-STAY VISITORS

TEXT.P: Puli township in central Taiwan's Nantou County is working actively on a series of measures -- including Japanese language training among its residents -- to improve its environment and promote a long-stay program for Japanese citizens.

Puli has also fixed the 10th day of each month as the township's "clean-up day" and has decorated the lobby of Puli's library in a Japanese style to serve as a social gathering place for potential Japanese visitors in the future.

The township's efforts came after it suffered a setback when the first Japanese retired couple arrived in Puli, known for its picturesque scenery and high-quality water, in early March for the long-stay program.
The couple complained of too many motorcycles and dog feces in the streets, describing Puli's water and air quality as "substandard."
The couple cut short their originally planned three-month stay to only 10 days, and left the town in disgust.

The second Japanese couple arrived in Puli April 18, and although they felt satisfied with Puli's environment, the township still decided to continue its beautification plan and strengthen the Japanese-language capabilities of its residents in order to attract more Japanese long-stay visitors.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOJ WANTS FINGERPRINTING OF CHINESE VISITORS

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Justice (MOJ) said Monday the requirement for visitors from China to have their fingerprints taken upon arrival should be implemented as soon as possible.

Since the "fingerprinting" regulation is prescribed in the newly revised Statute Governing the Relations between the People of the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area, MOJ officials said they look forward to its speedy implementation.
The officials made the call during a meeting held by the Mainland Affairs Council, in which the MOJ presented a report on the prevention of criminal activities by people from China.

At present, certain categories of Chinese citizens, including professionals and technicians, can visit Taiwan. The newly revised statute on cross-strait exchanges requires fingerprinting for them, but the requirement has not been implemented because some complementary measures have yet to be fleshed out.

As the government is preparing to open the door for ordinary Chinese citizens to sightsee in Taiwan, the officials said they will push for a further law revision to require fingerprinting for Chinese tourists as well as Chinese fishery workers aboard Taiwanese fishing boats and seized illegal Chinese immigrants.

According to the officials, the lack of a databank on personal information of Chinese people makes it difficult to investigate crimes involving Chinese visitors, posing a major risk to local law and order.

As no personal data such as fingerprints, DNA files or criminal records of Chinese visitors are available, it is very difficult for investigation and police authorities to nab Chinese criminals here, no matter whether they entered Taiwan legally or illegally, the officials said.

The MOJ has, through the Taiwan High Court, notified local district courts and prosecutors, if backed by solid evidence, to detain or ask for jail terms for Chinese people who commit serious crime in Taiwan, they noted.
According to MOJ statistics, from 2001 to 2005, crimes perpetrated by Chinese people in Taiwan were mainly related to document forgery and violations of national security.

DOC.HEADLINE: BURKINA FASO PRIME MINISTER TO VISIT TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Paramanga Ernest Yonli, prime minister of Burkina Faso, is scheduled to arrive in Taiwan April 26 for a five-day visit, Ministry of Foreign Affairs officials said Monday.

During his stay here, Yonli will call on President Chen Shui-bian and Premier Su Tseng-chang, and meet members of Taiwan's industrial and business communities to discuss issues surrounding investment in Burkina Faso, they said.
Meanwhile, French Senator Monique Papon, who chaired a pro-Taiwan parliamentary group, arrived in Taiwan Monday for a five-day visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLA VOWS TO CUT OCCUPATIONAL INJURY RATE BY 20% WITHIN TWO YEARS

TEXT.P: Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) Minister Lee Ying-yuan said Monday he hopes to reduce the country's occupational injury rate by 20 percent within two years.
Lee made the statement at the opening ceremony for the Eastern Taiwan Clinic Center for Occupational Injuries and Diseases at the Buddhist Tzu Chi General Hospital in the eastern county of Hualien.
Lee said there are around 2,000 cases of occupational injuries in the eastern counties of Yilan, Hualien and Taitung each year.
He said he expects the newly-launched center will not only provide the best medical and rehabilitation services, but also keep track on each case of injury.
Lee added that the CLA has dedicated the week of May 1-7 to promoting safety at work and preventing occupational injuries and diseases.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWMAKERS PROPOSE NO AGE DISCRIMINATION IN HIRING

TEXT.P: Legislators from the "pan-green" camp proposed Monday an amendment to a law with the aim of barring businesses from discriminating against people based on age.

Legislator Lu Tien-lin of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and his colleague David Huang of the Taiwan Solidarity Union made the proposal to the Committee on Public Health, Environment and Social Welfare at the Legislature Yuan when it was discussing revisions to the Employment Service Act.
Lu said that government statistics showed the jobless rate among those aged 45-64 was 3.2 percent in 2004, compared to 2.92 percent three years earlier.

He said that during the same period, the jobless rate of those aged 24-44 declined to 3.97 percent from 4.17 percent, indicating that the unemployment situation has deteriorated for the middle-aged and elderly.
Noting that more and more countries have proposed bills against age discrimination in employment, he said that Taiwan should also revise its laws in line with the global trend.

Huang proposed that the employment service law be amended, saying that in addition to barring discrimination in hiring based on factors of race, class, language, disability or gender, age should also be included.

Council of Labor Affairs Vice Minister Su Li-Chiung said she fully supported the proposal, but that whether the amendment should be added to the Employment Service Act or the Equality Employment Law would require further discussion.
She said that enterprises should not discriminate based on age except in the case of a special regulation, such as the stipulation that a laborer must retire at the age of 65.

DOC.HEADLINE: NSC WELCOMES PROBE INTO SCIENCE PARK'S VIBRATION-REDUCTION PROJECT

TEXT.P: The National Science Council (NSC) said Monday it was cooperating with prosecutors in an investigation of suspected irregularities in awarding a contract for reducing train vibrations at the southern Taiwan science park.
Yang Hung-dun, a vice chairman of the NSC, said he believes the council's staff members had acted in accordance with the law and relevant rules throughout the bidding process three or four years ago.

Yang made the comments after Taiwan District Court prosecutors and investigators searched NSC offices and left with boxes of documents about the council's decision to select Hung Hua Engineering Co. to carry out the NT$8.05 billion project.

The project was necessary because the high-speed railway will pass through the park, which is designed to accommodate high-tech companies including top-notch chip makers who are sensitive to vibrations over 48 decibels.
Prosecutors said they have been investigating the case after some lawmakers suspected irregularities may have occurred when the NSC was awarding the contract.

The NSC set a two-phase schedule to choose the best contractor for the project. First, all contractors must submit a feasibility proposal, which needs to be supported by lab evidence. Second, eligible competitors must submit an engineering project to achieve the stated purpose.

Yang said the contract had been awarded and that construction is expected to reach completion in August. The controversy may have been raised by the company which failed to win the contract, he noted, much like the controversy over the highway toll collection project.
"The NSC will fully cooperate with the prosecution in its investigation, as we believe our colleagues have acted legally and that judicial authorities will clear up all the facts," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHORT-TERM CURRENCY SURGE HAS LITTLE IMPACT ON EXPORTS: SCHOLAR

TEXT.P: A short-term surge in the value of the New Taiwan dollar will not have a major impact on Taiwan's exports, Taiwan Thinktank Chairman Chen Po-chih said Monday.

Chen said he does not think a rising local currency would cause any great damage to Taiwan's industries as long as its appreciation remains a short-term phenomenon, because both local high-tech and traditional businesses have turned profitable after having weathered a recession over the past several years.
Chen forecast that Taiwan's central bank will not rush to adjust its monetary policy now that consumer product prices in the domestic market haven't picked up markedly.
Fueled by a strongly appreciating Japanese yen, the new Taiwan dollar rose by NT$0.317 against the U.S. dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange to close at a two-month high of 31.992.

Market watchers said it was no surprise that the local currency is gaining steam and picking up in value since the Chinese yuan has continued moving up recently following a White House meeting between Chinese President Hu Jintao and U.S. President George W. Bush last week.
The Chinese yuan once picked up to 8 against the U.S. unit prior to the Bush-Hu huddle -- a record high in recent months.

But they pointed out that a gradually rising new Taiwan dollar is not expected to deal a heavy blow to Taiwan exports as long as it does not rapidly rise to 32 against the U.S. unit on grounds that most Taiwan companies should have taken hedging measures to avoid currency exchange risks.

Meanwhile, foreign stock analysts said the local currency will jump to 30 or even 29 against the U.S. dollar by the end of this year -- to be sustained by Taiwan's sound economic growth and also fanned by keen anticipation of a even stronger Chinese yuan that is set to push other Asian currencies to gain value.

Golden Sachs predicted the new Taiwan dollar will appreciate to 30.5 against the U. S. currency in a year, while JP Morgan forecast that it will rise to 29.5 against the U. S. dollar by the end of this year, thanks to improved cross-Taiwan Strait ties.
Merrill Lynch, however, called for attention to possible currency exchange losses that could be made on Taiwan's high-tech exports as a result of an appreciating local currency.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT MANUFACTURING SEMINAR BENEFICIAL TO FUTURE COOPERATION

TEXT.P: A cross-strait manufacturing seminar held at a Kaohsiung university is beneficial towards future Taiwan-China cooperation, a Chinese professor who attended the seminar said Monday.

Lei Yuanzhong, a mechanical department chief at the National Natural Science Foundation of China (NSFC) made the statement at the seminar held at the National Kaohsiung First University of Science and Technology.
Lei said that the NSFC is supportive of cross-Taiwan Strait cooperation in research and development in science and technology.
"We hope there will be more of such exchanges to facilitate cross-strait development in manufacturing technology," Lei said.

Cheng Cheng-yuan, chief of the Taiwan-based TECO Group's research and development department, said the group has an electric motor R&D center in China's Wuxi City, and will establish a compressor manufacturing center in Qingdao. The new center will produce around 1 million compressors per year.
More than 50 academic papers will be presented and 10 speeches delivered at the two-day seminar which will close Tuesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Prodi: He will deal with financial problems quickly.
Opposition Union leader Romano Prodi said that he will form his government in 48 hours after being appointed premier and that his future government will deal with financial problems quickly. Prodi made the remarks following the International Monetary Fund's warning against Italy's increasing public debt. Prodi's alliance won the April 9-10 general election with a razor-margin mayority, but the ruling coalition led by Premier Silvio Berlusconi refused to concede defeat.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Moves Signal Tighter Secrecy Within C.I.A.
The crackdown on leaks at the Central Intelligence Agency that led to the dismissal of a veteran intelligence officer last week included a highly unusual polygraph examination for the agency's independent watchdog, Inspector General John L. Helgerson, intelligence officials with knowledge of the investigation said Sunday. The special polygraphs, which have been given to dozens of employees since January, are part of a broader effort by Porter J. Goss, the director of the C.I.A., to re-emphasize a culture of secrecy that has included a marked tightening of the review process for books and articles by former agency employees.
Wall Street Journal: Chavez Plans to Take More Control Of Oil Away From Foreign Firms
Venezuelan President Hugo Chavez is planning a new assault on Big Oil, potentially taking a major step toward nationalization of Venezuela's oil industry that could hurt oil-company profits, reduce production and put further pressure on global oil prices. Venezuela's Congress, made up entirely of Chavez's allies, is considering sharply raising taxes and royalties on foreign companies' operations in the Orinoco River basin, the country's richest oil deposit. Major oil companies like Exxon Mobil Corp. and Conoco Phillips of the U.S. and Total SA of France have invested billions of dollars there to turn the basin's characteristically tar-like oil into some 600,000 barrels a day of lighter, synthetic crude.

DOC.HEADLINE: ASIAN CURRENCIES IN UPWARD TREND AS U.S. ECONOMY SLOWS: ACADEMIC

TEXT.P: International investments, or "hot money," will flow into Asian countries to take advantage of favorable return prospects as the United States' economy is expected to slow down in the next six months, an academic said Monday.
Hwa Erh-chang predicted that Asian currencies will likely appreciate in coming months amid speculation on the appreciation of China's renminbi (RNB).
The U.S. dollar lost ground against the new Taiwan dollar (NTD) on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Monday, shedding NT$0.317 to close at NT$31.992.

Hwa, chairman of the Department of Economics at Shih Hsin University, said that the U.S.' economic situation will slow down a bit later this year after the bull market of several years runs its course.
He added that the market is expecting a more conservative policy from the U.S. after the federal funds rate reaches five percent, and international hot money will look for markets elsewhere.

Moreover, speculation on the Chinese currency will lead Asian currencies to appreciate, Hwa stressed. He said that Asian currencies, including the New Taiwan dollar, should continue to rise as hot money pours into Asian markets.

Hwa pointed out that NTD's appreciation would damage Taiwan exports but suppress consumer prices, adding that the annual increase of core prices for the first quarter is only 0.58 percent, which is not serious.
Hwa noted it is too early to tell whether the Central Bank is going to take preventive measures to suppress prices.

DOC.HEADLINE: HARMONY IN CROSS-STRAIT TIES HELPFUL TO ARMS PURCHASE: KMT LAWMAKER

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian should not provoke Beijing with negative statements if he really wants the Legislative Yuan to pass arms procurement legislation, a legislator of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) said Monday.

Su Chi, who has served in many key government posts including chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council from 1999 to 2000 when the KMT was in power, said if the president hadn't announced the scrapping of the National Unification Council and its guidelines in his New Year's address, the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and the People First Party would have proposed its own version of the arms procurement plan in the legislature.

Su told reporters that the opposition caucuses had to abort the legislation for the arms deal because purchasing weapons at a time when relations were tense between Taiwan and China would have further diminished the already flimsy basis of mutual trust.

He pointed out that Taiwan's major arms purchases -- 150 F-16 jet fighters and six Knox-class frigates from the United States and 60 Mirage fighter planes and six Lafayette frigates from France -- were all carried out during 1992-1995 when the two sides of the Taiwan Strait were engaged in peaceful dialogue.

Opposition legislators hope the less controversial items on the procurement list will pass the legislature at an earlier date, and the president could help with the legislation's passage if he avoids using negative comments to provoke Beijing, Su said.

In the past two years, the opposition-controlled legislature has blocked two government-proposed bills that ask for a special budget of NT$480 billion (US$14.9 billion) to buy eight diesel-electric submarines, 12 P-3C submarine-hunting aircraft and six Patriot PAC III anti-missile batteries from the United States.

The legislative caucuses of the KMT and the PFP have argued that a 2004 referendum vetoed the proposed purchase of six Patriot PAC III missile batteries, which would cost NT$140 billion, and that according to law the issue of buying Patriot missiles batteries should not be raised again until the end of 2007.

The opposition lawmakers also believed there was no justification for Taiwan to pay the exorbitant price of NT$299 billion (US$9.16 billion) for eight diesel-electric submarines. They indicated that anti-submarine helicopters were the only item likely to gain their approval.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOJ STEPS UP CRACKDOWN ON GRAVEL POACHING

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Justice (MOJ) has directed local prosecutorial offices to step up efforts to crack down on gravel poaching prior to China's suspension of gravel exports May 1, an official said Monday.

Domestic gravel prices have spiked in recent weeks due to an imminent China export ban. Against this backdrop, the official said, local criminal rings may speed up gravel and sand poaching in environmentally protected areas.

"Prosecutors' offices around the island should take the initiative to investigate the gravel supply situation, including looking into whether any underworld gangs have colluded with business groups and grassroots administrative agencies in illegally digging up gravel in off-limit areas," the official said.

Noting that gravel poaching in certain areas has drawn public resentment and led to many grievance cases, the official said the MOJ is determined to take effective steps to wipe out the illegal operations.

According to the official, the MOJ has demanded the top prosecutor at the Taoyuan Prosecutors' Office look into the environmental disaster caused by long-term gravel poaching in the Shihmen Reservoir catchment area.

For years, underworld gangs have illegally snatched gravel from the upper stretch of the Tahan River, leading to the river's deformation and the accumulation of silt in the downstream area of Shihmen Reservoir. The reservoir's high turbidity has resulted in a chronic water shortage in the Taoyuan area, which relies on the reservoir as its main source of drinking water.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET INSISTS ON GOVERNMENT'S ROLE IN CROSS-STRAIT AFFAIRS

TEXT.P: The government must play a leading role in the cross-Taiwan Strait engagements, Cabinet spokesman Cheng Wen-tsang said Monday.

Cheng, who concurrently serves as Government Information Office minister, was responding to independent Legislator Lin Wei-chou's call for a meeting between Premier Su Tseng-chang and opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Honorary Chairman Lien Chan to discuss the 15 conclusions reached at a recent trade forum co-sponsored by the KMT and the Communist Party of China (CPC) in Beijing.
Noting that any agreement reached between the KMT and the CPC is not legally binding, Cheng said the government's role in cross-strait policy formulation can never be ignored or eschewed.

"There is no point to argue whether the premier should meet with Lien. The KMT is welcome to send representatives to attend a national conference to be organized by the Cabinet in June on Taiwan's sustainable economic growth, " Cheng said, adding that the Cabinet will be more than willing to listen to the KMT's recommendations on the development of cross-strait exchanges in various fields.
Chen also denied speculation that President Chen Shui-bian and Premier Su do not see eye to eye on cross-strait issues.

"The Presidential Office and the Cabinet maintain close contact and are in perfect congruence from policy planning through implementation. There has not been any disagreement between the president and the premier on cross-strait policy," Cheng asserted.

As far as cross-strait issues are concerned, he added, the government must play a leading role and emphasize Taiwan's unique identity while taking the initiative to address any problems arising from bilateral engagements.

DOC.HEADLINE: EUROPEAN PARLIAMENT TO HOLD SEMINAR ON TAIWAN'S WHO BID
DOC.DATELINE: Brussels, April 24 (CNA) (By P.C. Tang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe (ALDE), the third largest political group in the European Parliament, will hold a seminar Tuesday to drum up support for Taiwan's bid to join the World Health Organization (WHO).

A number of noted politicians and public health experts have been invited to attend the seminar and deliver speeches on major global health concerns, including the fight against avian influenza, organizers said.
Taiwan's exclusion from the global disease prevention and control network due to the absence of WHO membership will also be high on the meeting agenda.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, April 25, or the 28th day of the third month of the Year of the Dog according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1744: Anders Celsius, Swedish astronomer who devised the Celsius thermometer in 1742, dies at the age of 43.
1859: Under the direction of Ferdinand de Lesseps, the construction of the Suez Canal begins. It was opened 10 years later on Nov. 16, 1869.
1874: Gulielmo Marconi, Italian engineer and inventor who shared the 1909 Nobel Prize in physics, is born. He became the first person to transmit long-wave radio signals across the Atlantic Ocean, doing so in 1901.
1895: Lai Ho, a noted Chinese writer of anti-Japanese literature, is born in Changhua.
1898: The U.S. Congress passes a joint resolution declaring war on Spain over events in Cuba.
1912: The Chung Kuo Ke Ming Tung Meng Hui is reorganized as the Kuomintang.
1925: Field Marshal Paul von Hindenburg becomes the second president of Germany's postwar Weimar Republic.
1927: After the national government in Nanking announces a purification movement that will entail the expulsion of Chinese communists, the communists meet in Wuhan and decide to set up a Soviet-style regime.
1930: Construction of the Chianan irrigation canal is completed.
1941: The United States and the United Kingdom sign in Washington separate but parallel agreements with China for stabilizing China's national currency. The United States provides US$50 million and the United Kingdom provides five million pounds.
1942: An accident at a coal mine in Benxi, located within Japanese-occupied China, kills 1,549 workers in the world's worst mining disaster.
1945: Delegates of 45 nations, including the Republic of China, meet in San Francisco, Calif., to organize the United Nations.
1946: The foreign ministers of the United States, Soviet Union, Britain and France meet in Paris to discuss the signing of a peace treaty with Germany.
1956: The Republic of China Ministry of Foreign Affairs announces the establishment of diplomatic relations with Haiti.
1962: The United States successfully launches its Saturn rocket, the largest in the world at the time.
1965: President Lyndon B. Johnson sends U.S. troops to the Dominican Republic to maintain order after rebel followers of Juan Bosch try to seize power.
1971: T.V. Soong, former president of the Executive Yuan, dies in San Francisco at the age of 77.
1971: Some 200,000 anti-Vietnam War protesters march on Washington, D.C.
1973: The Chinese National Baseball Team leaves Taipei for Manila to take part in the 10th Asian Cup Tournament.
1974: Portugal's dictator Marcelo Caetano is overthrown in a bloodless military coup. He surrenders to Gen. Antonio de Spinola, who becomes president the following month.
1982: The last Israeli soldier leaves Sinai, ending 15 years of Israeli occupation of the peninsula.
1989: Japanese Prime Minister Noburu Takeshita announces plans to resign over the "Recruit Affair," the country's biggest political scandal in decades.
1994: Tsutomu Hata becomes Japan's 51st prime minister.
1995 Ginger Rogers, American dancer and actress, dies at the age of 83. She is particularly noted for her partnership with Fred Astaire in several motion pictures, including "Swing Time," "Flying Down to Rio" and "Roberta."
2000: President Lee Teng-hui bestows a medal on Steve Forbes, president and CEO of U.S.-based Forbes Magazine, in recognition of his long-term contribution to the promotion of exchanges and coorperation between the Republic of China and the United States.
2001: President Chen Shui-bian says that the ROC government will take steps to develop the island into a "competitive country with a knowledge-based economy" within five years.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "The ancient Emperor Shun was perhaps the one man who successfully carried out the principle of no-government. For what need is there really for what is called government? A ruler needs only to be earnest in his personal conduct, and to behave in a manner worthy of his position."

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. HAS NO INFO ON PRESIDENT CHEN'S POSSIBLE TRANSIT STOPS
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 24 (CNA) (By Jorge Liu and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The U.S. State Department said Monday that it has no information concerning ROC President Chen Shui-bian's and Premier Su Tseng-chang's plans to make transit stops in the United States next month.
"I'm not aware that any decision has been made on any possible request, " State Department Deputy Spokesman Adam Ereli said during a daily press briefing.

Chen is set to visit Costa Rica and Paraguay for state visits May 3-11, while Su is scheduled to depart in mid-May for Haiti and several other Caribbean allies, according to Taiwan's Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA).

MOFA officials said earlier that they expect that both Chen and Su will be able to make stopovers in the United States on their way to and from Latin America and that the ministry is making relevant arrangements toward that end.

DOC.HEADLINE: NSC DEPUTY CHIEF ARRIVES IN CALIFORNIA FOR 1-WEEK VISIT
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, April 25 (CNA) (by Wu Jih-chun and Zep Hu)

TEXT.P: National Science Council (NSC) Deputy Minister Chi Gou-chung arrived in San Francisco Thursday for a one-week visit to California, seeking closer business and technology cooperation between Taiwan and the United States.

Chi said that the future of Taiwan-based manufacturers lies in biotechnology and Internet software, both of which require research and innovation. Noting that Silicon Valley is the leader in research and innovation, Chi said he hopes Taiwan can learn a lot through closer ties with businesses in the area.

During his week-long stay, Chi will first head to Silicon Valley, focusing on local software and biotechnology businesses. He will then visit Los Angeles to try to enhance cooperative ties between U.S. defense industry firms and Taiwan contractors.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN EXPRESSES WILLINGNESS TO EXPAND COOPERATIVE TIES WITH UAE
DOC.DATELINE: Geneva, April 24 (CNA) (By Neil Lu & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan will seek to boost its cooperative ties with the United Arab Emirates (UAE), especially in the field of petrochemical development, Taiwan's representative to the World Trade Organization (WTO) said Monday.

Lin Yi-fu made the remarks at the WTO's first workshop to review the UAE's trade policies. Lin also conveyed to UAE Minister for Economy and Planning Sheikha Lubna Al Qasimi the message that Taiwan and the UAE should seek to expand their cooperative ties.

Mentioning the longstanding and close Taiwan-UAE economic relations, Lin indicated that the UAE is Taiwan's fourth largest trade partner in the Middle East, with bilateral trade reaching about US$2.73 billion in 2005.

Taiwan believes there is enormous potential to boost Taiwan-UAE trade, especially in petroleum products, Lin said. However, compared with a strong growth in bilateral trade, mutual investment appeared weaker. It is hoped the UAE will ease its restrictions on foreign investment so that Taiwan investors will be able to make inroads into the region, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEMITECH TAIPEI TO OPEN MAY 3 AT WORLD TRADE CENTER

TEXT.P: This year's "Semitech Taipei, " sponsored by the Taiwan Semiconductor Industry Association (TSIA) and the Taipei Computer Association (TCA) , will open May 3 for a three-day run at the Taipei World Trade Center (TWTC).

According to a staff of the show, the highlight of the "Semitech Taipei 2006" will be the presentation of two special awards, one to Chairman Morris Chang of Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. (TSMC) and the other to Dr. Shih Chin-Tay of National Tsing Hua University (NTHU).

The staff member said that Chang is being honored with the Superior Leadership Award for his achievement in leading TSMC to become the largest semiconductor manufacturer in the world, while Shih is receiving the Distinguished Contribution Award for his lifelong devotion to semiconductor technology research and development.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'MINI THREE LINKS' TO BE EXPANDED STARTING MAY 1: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang announced Tuesday that the targets and routes of the "mini three links" will be expanded from next month.
Beginning May 1, the dependents and close relatives of Kinmen and Matsu residents will be allowed to travel across the Taiwan Strait via the "mini three links," Su said.
Also, a new route between Kinmen and Quanzhou in China's Fujian Province will be launched in June, Su said.

Su made the announcement in a news conference held at the Sungshan air base in Taipei, after his plan to fly to Kinmen for an inspection tour of the "mini three links" was canceled due to bad weather.
The "mini three links" refers to the ferry services currently available between the Taiwan-held outlying islands of Kinmen and Matsu and the Chinese ports of Xiamen and Fuzhou.

While the services are applicable to people who have registered their household in Kinmen or Matsu for at least six months, their dependents and close relatives are currently only allowed to use the service if they are traveling together.

Others who can use the services include Taiwan businesspeople with operations in China; veterans who were born in Fujian Province and those of Fujian ancestry; and Fujian residents married to Taiwan citizens.
Su stressed that the policy to expand the "mini three links" was based on a directive from President Chen Shui-bian.

Su said that while Taiwan has not restricted the destination ports of the "mini three links" since the links were launched in 2001, China has refused to open up more ports other than Fuzhou and Xiamen to operate the services.
Meanwhile, Su invited China to hold a joint cross-strait sea rescue exercise with Taiwan in September.
Su said that as more and more passengers are traveling across the Taiwan Strait via the "mini three links, " the government thinks it is important to improve the safety and care for the travelers.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI SHARE PRICES END LOWER

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened high but closed lower Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 36.1 points to close at 7,059.94.
The bourse opened at 7,125.9 and fluctuated between 7,166.47 and 7,052.9 during trading. A total of 4.72 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$134.91 billion (US$4.22 billion).

Seven of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with construction issues moved up the most at 4.4 percent, followed by paper and pulp issues at 3.1 percent, foodstuff issues at 2.2 percent, textile stocks at 2 percent, banking and financial shares at 1.3 percent, cement stocks at 0.4 percent, and plastics and chemicals shares at 0.3 percent.
The one other major stock category lost ground, with machinery and electronics shares dropping at 1.6 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 478 to 408, with 95 stocks remaining unchanged.
