DOC.HEADLINE: PUBLIC CONFIDENCE IN CONSUMER PRICES HITS NEW LOW IN APRIL

TEXT.P: Public confidence in Taiwan's consumer price levels fell to a record low in April as skyrocketing oil prices have resulted in public anxiety about possible inflation, according to the results of a survey released Tuesday by National Central University's Taiwan Economic Development Research Center.
While the consumer confidence index gained 1.75 points from the previous month to stand at 70.78 in April, four of the six indicators used in the survey declined.
The "domestic consumer price level in the next six months" saw the greatest rate of decrease, losing 4.7 points over the previous month to hit a record low of 40 in April.

The "family financial status in the next six months" fell 1.95 points from March to 56.25. The "domestic economic outlook in the next six months" hit 53.70, down 1.2 points from March. The "employment opportunities in the next six months" slid 0.5 point to 75.25.

Meanwhile, the "timing for investing in the stock market in the next six months" soared 18.60 points from the previous month to 84.50 in April, and the "timing for buying durable goods in the next six months" rose 0.2 point to 114.95.
The survey was conducted April 18-20 among 2,688 adults around Taiwan via telephone. It had a margin of error of plus or minus 1.9 percentage points.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN EXPECTS PREPARATORY MEETING WITH JAPAN BEFORE FISHERY TALKS

TEXT.P: Taiwan hopes to hold a preparatory meeting with Japan if formal talks between the two countries are impossible in the near future because of the huge differences in viewpoint between them, a Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) official said Tuesday.

Liao Ching-pang, vice chief executive officer of the MOFA's Committee on Japanese Affairs, said the planned 16th round of Taiwan-Japan fishery talks was originally scheduled to be held in March but was postponed due to the huge differences in the positions of the two sides.

Taiwan and Japan have held 15 rounds of fishery talks since 1996. The focus of the disputes lies in the sovereignty dispute over the the Tiaoyutai Islands -- known as the Senkaku Islands in Japan -- an uninhabited island group in the East China Sea.

The waters near the Tiaoyutais northeast of Taiwan have been considered by Taiwan fishermen as their traditional fishing grounds. However, Japan demarcated the area as part of its 200-nautical mile economic zone in 1996 and has since that time often chased Taiwan fishing boats that enter the area and fined the owners of the boats.

In 2003, Taiwan drew a provisional "demarcation line" or "jurisdiction line" along the center line in the two countries' overlapping economic zones in order to avoid further disputes. However, neither country has recognized the demarcation lines drawn by the other side, leaving the problem unresolved.

Regarding waters around Okinotorishima, Japan's southernmost island located 1,730 kilometers southeast of Tokyo, Liao noted that Taiwan claims that the area is a disputed marine area and urged Japanese authorities not to chase or detain Taiwanese fishing boats operating in this area before a negotiated settlement is reached between the two countries.

The U.S. currency opened at NT$31.992 and fluctuated between NT$31.86 and NT$31.997.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA ASKED TO COOPERATE WITH TAIWAN IN SEA RESCUE DRILL

TEXT.P: Mainland Affairs Council Vice Chairman Johnnason Liu expressed Tuesday the hope that China would respond with goodwill to Premier Su Tseng-chang's proposal of conducting a joint sea rescue drill.

Su made the proposal earlier while announcing the expansion of current "mini-three links" operations with China on two offshore islands, Kinmen and Matsu. He said he hoped such a drill would be carried out before September, after which the seas would be too rough.

Describing the proposed joint drill as "pragmatic practice" since both Taiwan and China have sea routes in the Taiwan Strait, Liu said rescue operations in the strait would be more effective if the two forged cooperative efforts and answered each other's call for assistance.

At present, the central government is building up an integrated sea disaster rescue system with the collaboration of all relevant government agencies, including the Coast Guard Agency, the Ministry of National Defense, the Ministry of Transportation and Communications, and the Ministry of the Interior, as well as related local government agencies.
Once it is established, the planned system could also serve the needs of its Chinese counterpart, Liu noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIT DIRECTOR CALLS AT TAICHUNG AMERICAN CORNER

TEXT.P: Stephen M. Young, director of the Taipei Office of American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) paid a visit to the Taichung American Corner which is located in National Taichung Library and had lunch with Taichung Mayor Jason Hu Tuesday.
Hu suggested that the AIT set up a Taichung Office which would offer consular services to the six million people in central Taiwan. The AIT has offices in Taipei and Kaohsiung.
To promote American culture, AIT had set up the Taichung American Corner to provide opportunities for citizens in central Taiwan to discover American culture.
This is the first time Young has visited the American Corner in Taichung since he assumed the post March 18.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT HONORARY CHAIRMAN RETURNS FROM CHINA VISIT

TEXT.P: Lien Chan, honorary chairman of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT), returned to Taiwan from Shanghai Tuesday after concluding a 13-day visit to China.

Traveling as the head of a KMT group made up of more than 170 members including KMT lawmakers, academics and business leaders, Lien departed for Beijing April 14, where a historical economic forum between the KMT and the Communist Party of China (CPC) was held through April 15.
Lien met Chinese President and CPC General Secretary Hu Jintao for talks on cross-Taiwan Strait relations April 16 in Beijing -- the second of its kind in a year.

While most members of the KMT delegation left Beijing for Taiwan April 17, Lien and his families headed to Fujian, Zhejiang and Jiangsu provinces and Shanghai for family visits and sight-seeing purposes.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE YUAN SWAP MULLED ON TAIWAN PROPER: MAC OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: To prepare for the opening of Taiwan to Chinese tourists, the government is planning to allow some domestic locations to convert renminbis, a government official said Tuesday.

Jan Jyh-horng, secretary-general of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) , made the revelation in response to questions from main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) lawmakers Lai Shyi-bao and Yang Chiung-ying at a seminar on cross-Taiwan Strait financial exchanges held by the KMT legislative caucus at the Legislative Yuan.

Lai and Yang asked Jan whether the government is considering renminbi swaps to be allowed on Taiwan proper and cited a newspaper report as pointing out that some shops at Alishan and Sun Moon Lake -- two popular scenic spots in central Taiwan -- already accept renminbis from Chinese visitors.

They questioned the rationale of the government's policy of permitting Chinese visitors to enter with renminbi but prohibiting them from changing the Chinese currency into the local one, asking Jan whether the government encouraged them to make deals on the black market.

At present, only Chinese living abroad and those flying into Taiwan from a third country or area are permitted to visit Taiwan for sight-seeing purposes. The Taiwan government is expected to announce a full opening to general tourists from China.

Although according to the Republic of China's law, only shops on offshore islands of Kinmen and Matsu are allowed to convert renminbi into the local unit, Jan admitted that the MAC and relevant government agencies are mulling the possibility of setting up other points in Taiwan, in line with the government's anticipated opening to Chinese tourists.

But Jan added that the government still needs to work out relevant details, such as deciding a maximum convertible amount and the question of whether new Taiwan dollars could be swapped back into renminbis by departing Chinese tourists.

The government hopes to conclude tourist talks with the Chinese side in six months and Taiwan is likely to announce the opening on its own even if bilateral negotiations are not wrapped up by that time, Jan said, adding that the renminbi-NT dollar swap measure will be announced concurrently.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'MINI THREE LINKS' SEES 20-FOLD USER GROWTH IN 5 YEARS: MOTC

TEXT.P: The number of passengers using the transportation links between Kinmen, Matsu and China-based ports, or the so-called "mini three links" has grown more than 20 times since the service was launched Jan. 1, 2001, a spokesman for the Ministry of Transportation and Communication (MOTC) said Tuesday.
MOTC statistics show that in 2001, 25,000 passengers traveled using the mini three links between Taiwan's Kinmen and Matsu and China's Xiamen and Mawei.
The number more than doubled the following year to 58,000. In 2003, the mini three links served more than 167,000 people; the number increased to 427,000 in 2004 and reached 555,000 in 2005.
The spokesman said the increases are due to the government's easing of restrictions, allowing more people to take advantage of the mini three links.
Starting May 1 this year, those originating from Kinmen and Matsu can also travel to China via the mini three links. Only Kinmen residents were allowed to use the links when they began.

Since the direct links were launched, ships using the route have made a total of 15,000 port calls at Matsu and Kinmen as of October last year. Among these, 44.3 percent were Taiwanese ships and 54.5 percent were Chinese ships, according to tallies compiled by the Directorate-General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS).

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER PREMIER HSIEH WON'T RUN FOR MAYOR UNLESS DPP REACHES CONSENSUS

TEXT.P: Through a ruling party legislator, Former Premier Frank Hsieh said Tuesday that if the party loses year-end elections for Taipei and Kaohsiung mayorships, the party's senior leadership should take responsibility for the failure by not running in the 2008 presidential election.

Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Legislator Li Chun-yi made the remarks as he and other lawmakers close to Hsieh met DPP Chairman Yu Shyi-kun to discuss the possibility of Hsieh running for Taipei mayor.
Yu said he has confidence in the party's primary system and believes the best candidates will be nominated through the party's democratic mechanism.

Li said that if the mayoral elections are regarded as most important to the DPP, all ruling party members should put the DPP's interests above individual political considerations, adding that President Chen Shui-bian should be in charge of meetings to select the best candidates.
Li also said the DPP should make a decision on whether candidates who are going to run for Taipei and Kaosiung mayor should be excluded from the presidential election in 2008.
He said, former premier Hsieh won't run in the mayoral election unless the DPP's high-ranking officials reach a consensus on the issue.

Those party leaders must take political responsibility if the party fails to win back people's confidence in the year-end municipal elections and they should pledge not to run for the presidency in 2008, Li said.

DOC.HEADLINE: FIRST LADY HAS STOCKS WORTH NEARLY NT$50 MILLION: REPORT

TEXT.P: First lady Wu Shu-chen owns stocks with a combined face value of NT$48.32 million, all of which have been put into trust, according to the latest Control Yuan report disclosing the assets of public officials.

Stocks held by Wu include Fubon REITs No.1, Taiwan Cement, Nan Ya Plastics, United Microelectronics, Accton Technology, Nanya Technology, MediaTek, International Bank of Taipei, Hua Nan Financial Holdings, Mega Holdings and Faraday Technology, according to the report.

Also in trust are deposits amounting to NT$494,295 under the name of President Chen Shui-bian, deposits amounting to NT$745,798 under Wu's name as well as eight land properties and eight housing properties.
Meanwhile, Wu has deposits amounting to NT$2.07 million that are not in trust, the report shows.
The tallies are based on an assets declaration made by President Chen in November 2005.

The previous assets declaration by Chen in June 2004 indicated that Wu had stocks with a combined face value of NT$8.19 million that was in trust. Also in trust were deposits amounting to NT$28.83 million under Chen's name and deposits amounting to NT$12.69 million under Wu's name.
Chen put his assets in trust in April 2004 after the first lady was attacked for improperly engaging in stock trading during the run-up to the 2004 presidential election.
In February this year, the Executive Yuan passed a package of regulations that require senior appointed government officials in the Cabinet to place their assets into trust.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREVALENCE OF AIDS INCREASING AMONG DRUG ADDICTS: LAWMAKER

TEXT.P: The number of drug addicts testing positive for the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) in Taiwan experienced a large boost, driving up the overall growth rate of the HIV-positive people last year to 70 percent from 10 percent in 2003, a lawmaker said Tuesday.

Legislator Lin Shu-san of the Democratic Progressive Party also noted at a news conference that the number of AIDS patients increased to 3,405 people in 2005 from 773 in 2003 -- a five-fold rate of growth.
Among the people found to have contracted HIV last year, 2,434 are drug abusers.
"It's astonishing," Lin said.

Faced with Lin's request to address the problem, Yang Shih-yang, a disease control official of the Department of Health (DOH) , said measures have been taken on a trial basis in four cities and counties -- Taipei City and County, Taoyuan County and Tainan County -- as part of the government's initiative to protect drug addicts from contracting AIDS.

The measures include providing clean hypodermic needles and methadone therapy for drug addicts which, according to World Health Organization statistics, has proven to be effective in lowering the AIDS prevalence by 18 percent, Yang said.
The DOH hopes the counter-AIDS program will be carried out in all cities and counties around Taiwan by July if there are enough funds, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: REPORTER FINED FOR REFUSING TO TESTIFY AT 'STOCK VULTURES' HEARING

TEXT.P: A newspaper reporter was fined NT$30,000 Tuesday for refusing to reveal his source in a story that has become part of a court hearing on the "stock vultures" case. His newspaper vowed to appeal the court ruling.

This is the second time Kao Nien-yi of the United Daily News was fined; the first was on the first day of his appearance in the Taiwan High Court Monday, for the same reason. The court is summoning him to testify again Wednesday.
The court handed down the fines because, it said, "the witness does not have a legitimate reason to refuse" to reveal his news sources, which have a strong bearing on the public interest.

The prosecution suspects that Lee Chin-cheng, former director of the Financial Supervisory Commission's Examination Bureau and a key suspect in the insider trading case, might have leaked critical information to Kao, whose report was used as a tool by Lee's stock-trading friends, who have also been charged for making illicit profits.
The court said the public's interest in knowing who leaked the information "is obviously larger than the interest involved in the reporter refusing to testify."

The UDN said that keeping its news sources confidential is key to the media's operation, which aims to monitor the exercise of public authority -- a right that should not be damaged by judicial institutions.
Whether a newspaper story has been used to commit a crime has nothing to do with the identity of the story's reporter since it was totally beyond the reporter's control, said the daily.

Moreover, it continued, as the case is still in progress, the court should not violate the principle of "not guilty until proven so" by handing down a fine on the witness before a conviction has been made.
The daily called on the public to pay attention to this incident, which it said involves the critical issue of press freedom and the operation of the country's democratic system.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPENING TAIWAN TO CHINESE TOURISTS HELPS CROSS-STRAIT TIES: MAC HEAD

TEXT.P: The best part of opening doors to Chinese tourists is the effect of "culture shock" on mainlanders, who emerge in an atmosphere of democracy and see the real face of Taiwan, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Joseph Wu said Tuesday.

Referring to Beijing's media block on the matter, Wu claimed that most in China know about Taiwan and the democracy it has worked hard to promote, despite insufficient information. Now, with the opening in tourism, he said, mutual understanding between people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait is expected to get a boost, and such a development helps to improve cross-strait relations.
Besides, such an outcome is far more beneficial to Taiwan than the estimated yearly economic benefit of about US$500-600 million generated from tourist-oriented visits by Chinese in Taiwan, Wu noted.

The official said the two sides need to sit down for talks immediately, to discuss how there are currently only limited openings for sightseeing visits available to a handful of Chinese tourists who hold residency in a foreign country or travel via a third country to Taiwan as part of a tour package. The official also said the two sides need to work out issues such as the confirmation of Chinese tourists' identity and ensuring Chinese tourists are well-treated during their stay.

DOC.HEADLINE: CDC TO UPGRADE ANTI-EPIDEMIC MECHANISM IN KINMEN AND MATSU

TEXT.P: In order to prevent bird flu from entering Taiwan, the government will consider upgrading the anti-epidemic mechanism on Kinmen and Matsu which have direct shipping links with China, Center for Disease Control (CDC) director Kuo Hsu-sung said Tuesday.
Kuo made the statement while inspecting anti-epidemic infrastructure and operations in Kinmen.

He said once new rules are implemented May 1 this year, allowing people originating from Kinmen and Matsu to go to China via the links, there will be more and more people traveling through Kinmen and Matsu. Thus he said, it is necessary to reinforce the anti-epidemic mechanism to prevent avian flu from entering Taiwan.
Kuo said that China is one of Taiwan's largest sources of infectious disease, so reinforcing the prevention of avian flu in Kinmen and Matsu is of primary importance.
Ku added that the CDC is looking to increase its anti-epidemic staff in Kinmen and Matsu once the number of users of these links reaches a certain level.
The shipping links between Taiwan's Kinmen and Matsu and China's Xiamen and Mawei. It was launched Jan. 1, 2001, with a 20-fold growth of users registered as of 2005.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT GUIDES NATION'S CROSS-STRAIT POLICY: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang said Tuesday that President Chen Shui-bian is guiding and setting the tone on the nation's major policies, including those concerning cross-Taiwan Strait relations.

Su made the remarks to clarify the decision-making process on cross-strait policy amid reports that the premier is not on the same page as the president in this regard after a recent trade and economic forum between the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and the Communist Party of China (CPC) in Beijing.

According to the reports, Su did not dismiss the conclusions reached at the April 14-15 KMT-CPC forum completely -- which include the recognition by China of academic degrees conferred by accredited Taiwan universities, allowing Chinese tourists to travel to Taiwan and permitting qualified Taiwan physicians to practice in China -- when he said last Friday that the government will support the conclusions as long as they are beneficial to the people of Taiwan and do not compromise Taiwan's identity.

In response to reports that there is a gap between the president and the premier on cross-strait policy, Chen also denied Monday that this is the case, saying that Su's pronouncement on cross-strait issues came at the suggestion of National Security Council (NSC) Secretary-General Chiou I-jen, based on the president's will.

Su pointed out that relations between Taiwan and China are complex and sensitive and that it is the president who sets the tone on cross-strait policy, after which related agencies in the Executive Yuan work closely with the NSC before the Executive Yuan announces the results.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU CALLS FOR BASIC LAW FOR AGRICULTURE

TEXT.P: Opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) Legislator Yin Ling-ying called for establishing a basic law for agriculture to protect the rights and interests of Taiwan farmers amid increased globalization.
Yin, quoting former President Lee Teng-hui -- the TSU's "spiritual leader" -- issued the call at a public hearing on Taiwan's agricultural development sponsored by the TSU at the Legislative Yuan.

According to Yin, Lee is very concerned about the future of Taiwan's agriculture and believes that it is necessary to set up a basic law to help maintain continued growth in the domestic agricultural sector in line with growing concerns over environmental and consumer protection.

She also criticized what she described as the inactivity of the Democratic Progressive Party government in the face of the deteriorating situation in the domestic agricultural industry due to Taiwan's entry into the World Trade Organization.

However, she claimed that the 15 overtures released by Beijing directed at Taiwan following an economic forum between the leading opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and the Communist Party of China (CPC) that ran from April 14-16 in Beijing will not benefit Taiwan.
"Taiwan farmers might be hurt by the measures, " she claimed.

As China has so far failed to work out measures to protect Taiwan's farm products in the Chinese market, China's wider opening to imports from Taiwan would just further fan commercial piracy there, which is likely to deal a fresh blow to Taiwan farmers who are already suffering under the onslaught of fake Chinese products, she said.
In addition, she expressed concern that an influx of Taiwan's agricultural goods to China would allow Chinese farmers to learn from Taiwan's know-how, eroding Taiwan farmers' competitive edge.

DOC.HEADLINE: CAA TO ADD DEPARTURE LOUNGE AT CHINCHUANKANG AIRPORT

TEXT.P: A departure lounge built by the Ministry of Transportation and Communications at a cost of NT$12.94 million (US$404,300) for the passengers on international chartered flights out of Chinchuankang Airport in Taichung is set to be completed by the end of this month.

Officials from the Civil Aeronautics Administration noted that Chinchuankang Airport launched the international chartered flight services in 2004 but is not yet an international airport. Passengers awaiting international charter flights have to share a departure lounge with passengers on domestic flights.

With the limited space of the domestic departure lounge, the airport has until now dealt with the issue by adjusting the time schedules, allowing international charter flights only after 7 p.m., the officials said.
But this has affected the development of the international charter flight business and the operators have demanded separate departure lounges for domestic and international passengers.
Construction work is now 90 percent complete, the officials said.
The international charter flights went to Japan and South Korea in the initial stage, then mainly to Hong Kong and Macau, CAA officials said.

As of the end of February, the number of international charter flights had reached 138, carrying 10,570 passengers. The operators are looking forward to apply to fly to Vietnam and Thailand in the future.

DOC.HEADLINE: UP TO 96 PERCENT PASS RATE FOR NATURALIZATION TEST: MOI

TEXT.P: Up to 96 percent of those who took the naturalization test have passed since the test was offered this January, Ministry of the Interior (MOI) officials said Tuesday.
The officials said that as of the end of March, 361 foreigners had taken the test, of which 347 passed, which they claimed shows that the content of the test databank is appropriate.

On criticism that some of the questions in the test are too difficult or unrelated to daily life, the officials explained that they invited experts, academics and related government agencies to work out the test questions.
The aim is to let those who have taken the test understand the rights and obligations of a national and quickly assimilate to life in Taiwan, the officials said.

Addressing criticism that the legal regulations or "common sense" parts of the test are not relevant, the officials claimed that this does not mean the test is not close to life, but serves as a reminder so that the test-takers will not inadvertently violate the law.
The officials said that to ensure that the questions are in tune with the times, they welcome the views from all quarters to serve as reference to future test revisions.

DOC.HEADLINE: BILL APPROVED IN LEGISLATURE TO GOVERN FUND-RAISING FOR CHARITY

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan approved Tuesday a bill that will govern fund-raising for charity and other issues regarding public welfare.

Ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Legislator Wang Jung-chang, who initiated the bill, noted that its passage will help make charity donations more transparent and allow for better management of the donated money.
Political and religious donations are not covered by the bill.
Under the bill, government agencies cannot raise funds for charity and the fund-raising activities should be permitted by the government.
Fund-raisers cannot force their subordinate organizations to make donations and should carry certification documents proving they are allowed to raise funds.

Once a fund-raising campaign is approved by the government, the fund-raisers must open an account in a financial institution and release publicly all the details regarding the donations, including the names of donors, the donated articles, the date of donation and the spending of the donation, within 30 days after receiving the donation.
Violators will face fines of between NT$10,000 (US$312) and NT$200,000, and serious violators will have their permission to accept donations revoked.

DOC.HEADLINE: WRA TO INCREASE RIVER DREDGING

TEXT.P: The Water Resources Agency (WRA) under the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) has made plans to increase river gravel dredging in order to cover a shortage, the director-general of the WRA said Tuesday.
Chen said that Taiwan uses 60 million cubic meters of gravel for construction each year, with an average of 5 million cubic meters used each month.

He added that there will be a 9 million cubic meter gravel shortage once China suspends gravel exports to Taiwan May 1, which has prompted the WRA to work out a plan to allow additional dredging from the Lanyang, Dajia, Jhuoshuei and Gaoping rivers, as well as several others, allowing an additional 4 million cubic meters of gravel to be collected from these rivers.

Chen said that according to tallies compiled by the Bureau of Mines under the MOEA, there are approximately 8 million cubic meters of gravel in storage and the government must prevent construction companies from hoarding gravel.
In related news, meanwhile, the Ministry of Justice (MOJ) ordered local prosecutor's offices a day earlier to step up efforts to crack down on illegal dredging of gravel.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Dismissed CIA Officer Denies Leak Role; Official Says Agency Is Not Asserting She Told of Secret Prisons.
A lawyer representing fired CIA officer Mary O. McCarthy said yesterday that his client did not leak any classified information and did not disclose to Washington Post reporter Dana Priest the existence of secret CIA-run prisons in Eastern Europe for suspected terrorists.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HIGH COURT BEGINS TO HEAR PACIFIC SOGO OWNERSHIP CASE

TEXT.P: The Taiwan High Court began to hear the case of an ownership fight over the Pacific Sogo Department Store Tuesday, with Pacific Group former Chairman Chang Min-chiang seeking to have 600,000 shares in the Pacific Distribution Investment Co., which owns Pacific Sogo, returned to him.

Chang said he had entrusted the 600,000 shares to Lee Heng-lung, landlord of Pacific Sogo and deputy chairman of the Pacific Group, in May 2002 after Lee and Walter Lin, chairman of Waterland Financial Holdings Co., promised to help him get bank loans to tide Pacific Sogo over financial difficulties caused by a flood in the typhoon season of 2001.
Pacific Sogo, a subsidiary of Pacific Group at the time, has been one of Taiwan's most successful department stores.

Lee became chairman of Pacific Distribution Investment after the shares were transferred to his name. However, instead of helping Chang to obtain the needed loans, Lee and Lin stripped Chang of his ownership of Pacific Sogo and replaced the entire management team.

Sensing that Lee and Lin might have ulterior motives, Chang began to let the word out that he wanted to sell Pacific Sogo. Tsai Chen-yang, head of My Humble House Group, was among the first to respond, offering to buy the department store for NT$10 billion, but Lin and Lee, who were in full control of Pacific Sogo, refused, saying that someone at "a high level" had a specific buyer in mind.
The ownership fight became a tug-of-war among several business leaders, each claiming to have support from either the Presidential Office or the first lady.
Chang claimed that Lee and Lin sold Pacific Sogo to Douglas Hsu, chairman of the Far Eastern Group, by signing a secret agreement in September 2002.
After repaying NT$2.5 billion in debts due at the time for Pacific Sogo, Far Eastern named Chung Chin, former head of the Government Information Office, as chairwoman of the department store.
Newspaper reports Monday quoted Lee as saying that Hsu hired Chung as Pacific Sogo chairwoman because it was the decision of the "high level."

The secret agreement came to light only recently after Lee claimed that Pacific Sogo was temporarily registered under Far Eastern's name because the deal had not been completed. He said Hsu had not fulfilled his part of the obligations and that according to the agreement, he is entitled to 33 percent of Pacific Sogo's shares -- estimated to be worth more than NT$15 billion.

Lee told the court that it was Pacific Sogo, rather than Chang, that entrusted the 600,000 shares of Pacific Distribution to him. He insisted there was no written trust agreement between him and Chang about the transfer of those shares and that Chang has no right to the shares.

As the court proceeding continued, media coverage was mounting about a scandal implicating first lady Wu Shu-chen, who has been accused of taking millions of dollars-worth of Pacific Sogo gift vouchers during the ownership fight over the department store. She has admitted shopping with such gift vouchers, but claimed they were bought by her and her friends with pooled funds.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN PICTURE BOOK EXHIBITION HELD IN TAIPEI BOOKSTORES

TEXT.P: A month-long exhibition of Australian picture books will showcase the creativity of illustrators like Shaun Tan, who is visiting Taiwan, and the diversity of Australian children's literature, the Australian Trade and Industry Office (ACIO) in Taipei announced at a press conference Tuesday.
More than 40 picture books authored by well-known illustrators like Alison Lester, Ron Brooks and Tan will be displayed in nine Eslite Bookstores from April 25 to May 21.

The exhibition provides a good opportunity to understand Australian children's picture book publishing, which is different from British and American picture books, said Evelyn Killick, executive deputy director of ACIO's Economic and Policy Section.
Australia is an incredibly diverse country and it shows in its picture books, with illustrators coming from all walks of life, race and age, said Tan, who is of Chinese descent.
Tan provided two of his books -- "The Red Tree" and "The Lost Thing" -- in the exhibition and has been giving speeches on various campuses in Taiwan during his tour.

"Australia has long been known for its picture book publishing, " said Sarah Ko, a professor at National Taipei University. "But Taiwan people often mistake Australian picture books for American or British publications."
"The stories and graphics of Australian picture books are not as dramatic and eye-catching as American and British books. They are more tender and subtle, and show a profound power," she claimed.

DOC.HEADLINE: JUDGES MUST BE COMPLETELY INDEPENDENT: JUDICIAL CHIEF

TEXT.P: Judicial Yuan President Weng Yueh-sheng said Tuesday that judges must act independently and cannot allow themselves to be influenced by their superiors, with "conscience and instinctive moral sense" their criteria in making court decisions.

Weng made the remarks when he presided over the Judicial Yuan's first judicial reform seminar in Pingtung, southern Taiwan, which will be followed similar functions in other counties and cities around the country.

The first order of work in judicial reform is winning the trust of the people, he said. This should be followed by efforts to make it easier for people to obtain services in the judicial system, Weng added.

Building a "pyramid" court trial system is another priority in the reform project, so that the current system of three trials (first trial for ascertaining facts, second trial for factual review and third trial for legal sentencing) will become more efficient, he said.
The court's mediation function should also be strengthened and civil suits handled in batches in order to increase the judges' efficiency in resolving civil disputes, he said.
Other work that needs attention is increasing prosecutors' ability to produce evidence, which will speed up conclusion of lawsuits, according to Weng.
He said the Judicial Yuan is promoting a new system for recruiting judges from among lawyers, prosecutors and academics instead of by written tests.
The new policy will be implemented in three or five years, as more than 50 lawyers have applied to become judges, of whom 20 have been selected, he noted.

Weng and his senior staff members exchanged views with local district court judges and leaders of advocacy groups, who made a list of suggestions including the establishment of mediation organizations for consumer complaints.

DOC.HEADLINE: REPORTER HAS RIGHT TO REFUSE TO TESTIFY: JOURNALIST GROUP

TEXT.P: The Justice Journalists Association of Taipei issued a statement Tuesday in protest over the Taiwan High Court's refusing a reporter the right to refuse to testify in regard to a news story that has become part of a court hearing on the "stock vultures" case.
The statement noted that freedom of speech is protected by the Constitution and that reporters have the right to refuse to testify at court hearings.
They claimed that forcing a reporter to reveal his news sources will not help find the truth in a lawsuit but will create strained relations between the media and the judiciary.
The association was responding to the case of a newspaper reporter who was fined NT$30,000 for refusing to reveal the sources of his news story.

It was the second time Kao Nien-yi of the United Daily News had been fined. The first was on the first day of his appearance at the Taiwan High Court Monday, for the same reason. The court is summoning him to testify again Wednesday.
The statement said the "stock vultures" case has nothing to do with national security and that the reporter's testimony is not the only way to find the facts.
The court is violating the principle of proportion by fining the reporter over and over again instead of mobilizing the administrative resources at its disposal, it said.

Catching criminals is a basic responsibility of the judiciary, and it will damage public's right to know and weaken the media's work to monitor the government if reporters' news stories are seen as helping criminals, the association said.
It also noted that keeping news sources confidential is key to the media's operation.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT LAWMAKER BACK FROM CHINA WITH INFO ON ANOTHER SCANDAL

TEXT.P: The first family should clarify whether they took NT$10 million in 2002 from the Tuntex Group through the Presidential Office's then-deputy secretary-general, Chen Che-nan, in return for helping the company obtain NT$60 billion in loans from several state-owned banks, a legislator of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) said Tuesday.

Legislator Chiu Yi said that during a trip he made to Beijing last week, Tuntex Group former Chairman Chen Yu-hau authorized one of his aides to provide him with information showing that Chen Che-nan received NT$10 million as a "political contribution" to help finance President Chen Shui-bian's campaign for re-election.
Chiu said it is unlikely that Chen Che-nan kept the money for himself and said the first family should tell the nation who took the money.

Noting that with Chen Che-nan's help, Tuntex was able to get NT$60 billion in loans at favorable rates with extended periods for repayment, Chiu said he suspects the loans were made possible because of the campaign contribution.

The opposition legislator said that if the president and first lady are found to have played a role in granting the loans to Tuntex, they will be liable for prosecution on charges of corruption because some of the loans have become bad debts.

In response to Chiu's remarks, the Presidential Office said claims about monetary political contributions were nothing new and that if Chiu has obtained new evidence, he should give it to the Prosecutor's Office.
Chen Yu-hau, a fugitive wanted by the Taipei District Court on charges of embezzlement since June 2003, is believed to be hiding in China.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA AIRLINES OPENS ABU DHABI SERVICE

TEXT.P: China Airlines (CAL), Taiwan's major air carrier, added a new stopover in Abu Dhabi, capital of the United Arab Emirates (UAE), to its Taipei-Vienna route Tuesday.
Foreign Minister Huang Chih-fang, Minister of Transportaton and Communications Kuo Yao-chi and several other high-ranking officials boarded the plane to mark the opening of the service.

A CAL official said the opening of the Abu Dhabi service will be a great convenience to those from Taiwan or Europe who often travel to the Middle East for business, and will help explore other potential tourists to the region.
CAL once operated services to Abu Dhabi in its Taipei-Rome route during the period from 1995 to 2004.
Last October, then Minister of Transportation and Communications Lin Ling-san signed a memorandum of understanding with the UAE for the resumption of its service to Abu Dhabi.

CAL will operate three flights on the Taipei-Abu Dhabi-Vienna route per week. With the new Abu Dhabi stopover, the arrival time from Taipei to Vienna will be one hour later than the original Taipei-Vienna flight, the official added.

DOC.HEADLINE: 50% OF COLLEGE STUDENTS HAVE GOOD FINANCIAL MANAGEMENT SKILLS: SURVEY

TEXT.P: Contrary to public belief that young consumers are frivolous spenders, nearly 50 percent of local college students possess good financial management skills, according to the results of a survey released Tuesday by MasterCard.

Instead of being "materialistic paycheck spenders, " the survey found, nearly 50 percent of the students polled have a high awareness of their financial situations and show sound financial management skills.

The survey shows females to be better at managing their finances than their male counterparts. Twice as many male students (14.7 percent) found themselves in financial crisis as measured by the "personal financial health index" used in the survey compared to female students (7.6 percent).
About a quarter (25.5 percent) of the male respondents surveyed spend a significant amount on trying to impress girls, compared to 5.5 percent of their female counterparts.
Women, however, spend more on skin care, with 24.5 percent spending on skin care and cosmetics compared with males (1.5 percent).

The survey also found that the level of debt for students increased with age and income. The personal financial health index -- which grades the respondents' financial status from one to 10 -- for freshmen averaged 0.95 points, compared to 1.28 for sophomores, 1.32 for juniors and 1.83 for seniors.
MasterCard conducted the survey between March 8 and March 31 among 550 students from five universities. The percentage of male and female interviewees was 38.8 percent and 61.2 percent, respectively.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA AIRLINES OPENS ABU DHABI SERVICE(repeat)

TEXT.P: China Airlines (CAL), Taiwan's major air carrier, added a new stopover in Abu Dhabi, capital of the United Arab Emirates (UAE), to its Taipei-Vienna route Tuesday.
Foreign Minister Huang Chih-fang, Minister of Transportaton and Communications Kuo Yao-chi and several other high-ranking officials boarded the plane to mark the opening of the service.

A CAL official said the opening of the Abu Dhabi service will be a great convenience to those from Taiwan or Europe who often travel to the Middle East for business, and will help explore other potential tourists to the region.
CAL once operated services to Abu Dhabi in its Taipei-Rome route during the period from 1995 to 2004.
Last October, then Minister of Transportation and Communications Lin Ling-san signed a memorandum of understanding with the UAE for the resumption of its service to Abu Dhabi.

CAL will operate three flights on the Taipei-Abu Dhabi-Vienna route per week. With the new Abu Dhabi stopover, the arrival time from Taipei to Vienna will be one hour later than the original Taipei-Vienna flight, the official added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, April 26, or the 29th day of the third month of the Year of the Dog according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1452: Leonardo da Vinci, Italian painter, engineer, scientist and one of the most versatile artists of the Renaissance, is born. As a painter, he is best known for "The Last Supper" and "Mona Lisa."
1885: Britain occupies Port Hamilton, Korea.
1925: Paul von Hinderburg, German general and politician, is elected president of the Weimar Republic. He appointed Adolf Hitler as chancellor in 1933.
1946: Chinese communist troops take over Harbin and Tsitsihar as Soviet forces evacuate.
1954: The United Nations meets at Geneva and insists on free elections in Korea.
1960: The construction of the East-West Cross-Island Highway in Taiwan is completed.
1966: Mt. Kelud erupts in Java, Indonesia, killing some 1,000 people.
1971: A White House commission recommends that Communist China be brought into the United Nations, with the Republic of China on Taiwan retaining its membership.
1972: The eleven-member Chinese track and field team returns from Manila after winning 11 gold, 2 silver and 4 bronze medals in the three-day Philippine National Open Track and Field Championships.
1975: The Embassy of the Republic of China in Saigon suspends operations.
1975: Shortly before the fall of Saigon, former South Vietnamese President Nguyen Van Thieu and his wife arrive in Taipei for a temporary stay before going into exile in the United States.
1976: The Fourth Asian Writers Conference of International P.E.N. opens with some 90 leading writers in Asia, Europe and America attending.
1976: The government of the Republic of China and the government of the Republic of South Africa announce the elevation of their consulates general to embassy status.
1976: Brig. Gen. Dan A. Brooksher of the U.S. Air Force arrives to replace Brig. Gen. David O. Williams Jr. as chief of staff of the U.S. Taiwan Defense Command.
1983: Explosions occur in buildings occupied by the Central Daily News and the United Daily News in Taipei.
1984: U.S. President Ronald Reagan and his wife Nancy leave for a trip to mainland China.
1986: A nuclear reactor at the Chernobyl plant in the Ukraine explodes, spreading a radioactive cloud across Europe and causing grave pollution. It was the world's worst nuclear accident.
1989: Mainland students march to central Beijing to protest government statements condemning their campaign for democracy.
1994: A China Airlines A300-600 Airbus crashes at Nagoya airport in Japan, killing 264 aboard. There were only seven survivors.
1996: Communist China, Russia and three former Soviet republics sign a treaty aimed at reducing tensions along their common borders.
1997: Peng Zhen, a senior leader of Communist China, dies in Beijing at the age of 95.
1999: NATO planes destroy the Zezeljev railway bridge in Novi Sad during the Kosovo war.
2000: Rodolfo T. Reyes, the new defacto Philippine representative to the Republic of China in the absence of formal diplomatic ties between the two countries, arrives in Taipei to assume office.
2000: ROC President-elect Chen Shui-bian pays a visit to former Premier Hau Pei-tsun for talks on a wide range of issues.
2001: The ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs congratulates Junichiro Koizumi on his election as Japanese prime minister.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Be conscientious and sincere in what you say; be earnest and serious in what you do: in that way, although you might be in barbarous countries, you will get along well with men."

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMICS MINISTER CONFIRMS ELECTRICITY RATES TO BE HIKED

TEXT.P: Economic Affairs Minister Hwang Ing-san confirmed Wednesday that electricity rates will be raised in the near future.
Hwang made the remarks while giving a report on consumer prices at a meeting of the Legislative Yuan's Committee on Economics and Energy.
Hwang said that Taiwan Power Co. is currently working out related details and is expected to announce the hikes in mid-May.

DOC.HEADLINE: THINK TANK ADJUSTS DOWNWARD FORECAST FOR ECONOMIC GROWTH FOR 2006

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Institute of Economic Research adjusted downward Wednesday its forecast for Taiwan's economic growth for 2006 from 4.02 percent to 3.91 percent.

Researchers from the private economic think tank attributed the lower than expected growth mainly to soaring international crude oil prices and excessive consumer credit card debt -- two factors which they said will drive down consumption.
Growth of 3.91 percent for 2006 would be slightly lower than the 4.09 percent posted for 2005.
The Taiwan Institute of Economic Research is the first Taiwan think tank to predict a growth rate below four percent for Taiwan in 2006 thus far.

DOC.HEADLINE: PASSENGER NABBED AT CKS AIRPORT FOR BRINGING IN LIVE BIRDS FROM CHINA

TEXT.P: A passenger was nabbed at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport for bringing in live birds from China into the country, officials of the Taipei Customs Office reported Wednesday.
The customs officials said the four Japanese White-eyes were found in a bird cage hidden in the carry-on luggage of the passenger, surnamed Chen, Tuesday night.
Chen claimed that he was returning from Shanghai via Hong Kong and that the four songbirds are his pets.
The customs officials have turned Chen and the birds over to the Hsinchu branch of the Bureau of Animal and Plant Health Inspection and Quarantine under the Council of Agriculture.

The officials noted that China is listed as a bird flu-affected area and that those who violate Taiwan's regulations aimed at preventing animal contagious diseases face up to three years in prison or/and a maximum fine of NT$150,000 (US$4,690).

Japanese White-eyes, or Mejiros, are relatively small songbirds with an average height of about 4.5 inches. The birds, which have a slightly curved black bill extending from their yellow forehead, are named for the silky white rings around their eyes.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEADING EUROPEAN PARLIAMENT MEMBER PROMOTES TAIWAN'S WHO BID
DOC.DATELINE: Brussels, April 25 (CNA) (By P.C. Tang and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: A leading member of the European Parliament called Tuesday for direct access for Taiwan to the World Health Organization (WHO).

Graham Watson, leader of the Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe in the European Parliament, said the inclusion of Taiwan in the world health network will not only protect the people of Taiwan but also create a fitter global health framework to protect people around the world.
Watson expressed his disapproval of the fact that Taiwan has only been allowed to take part in some technical meetings held by the WHO, and he urged the WHO to address this problem.
Watson made the remarks during an event in support of Taiwan's bid to participate in the WHO. The event was co-organized by Watson and the Geneva-based consultant firm Health Diplomats.

Also at the event, Delon Human, CEO and president of the Health Diplomats and former secretary-general and CEO of the World Medical Association, urged European Parliament members, European Union officials, European media representatives and European medical workers to exert their influence and press the European Union to help Taiwan gain access to the WHO.

Before Taiwan succeeds in its bid to obtain observer status at the World Health Assembly (WHA) , which will involve a very long process, the WHO should take several steps to try to mend the gap in the world health network, Human suggested.

These steps include the inclusion of Taiwan in the Global Outbreak Alert and Response Network and the International Health Regulations mechanism and allowing Taiwan to take part in WHO-affiliated regional organizations, Human said.

Printed materials prepared by the organizers stated that Taiwan is one of the areas that is shut out of the global public health network and that in the event of bird flu or other infectious diseases breaking out in Taiwan, the 23 million people of the island will have no way to gain assistance from the WHO to fight these diseases.
The consequences of this gap were demonstrated during the 2003 SARS outbreak, according to the printed materials.

Also attending the event, Winston Dang, a legislator of Taiwan's ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) who concurrently serves as director of the DPP's Department of International Affairs, told the Central News Agency that the European Union has become more supportive of Taiwan's WHO bid this year after the United States and Japan have openly expressed their support for Taiwan.
If Taiwan is still barred from participating in the WHA as an observer this year, the government should consider applying directly with the WHO for membership, Dang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: GRAVEL SHORTAGE ISSUE TO BE ADDRESSED ASAP: ECONOMICS MINISTER

TEXT.P: Economic Affairs Minister Hwang Ing-san said Wednesday that the current gravel shortage -- caused by traders' reluctance to sell as gravel prices have been rising ahead of China's suspension of gravel exports from May 1 -- will be addressed in the shortest possible period of time.
Fielding questions at the Legislative Yuan, Hwang said he will see to it that the gravel supply situation is tackled first, before other measures are taken to stabilize prices.
Domestic gravel prices have risen recently amid reports that China will ban gravel exports starting May 1.

An islandwide gravel trade association reportedly wrote to Beijing authorities recently, asking China not to ban gravel exports to Taiwan, which the association claimed is a "domestic district" of China.
Ruling Democratic Progressive Party Legislator Tang Bi-a lashed out at the trade association for being willing to sacrifice Taiwan's sovereignty for personal gain.
Tang also criticized the administration for doing nothing to deal with the gravel trade association's actions, asking whether the government in fact condones such behavior by private groups.

Hwang responded by saying that the gravel association was definitely "wrong" for writing the letter, adding that Bureau of Mines authorities will communicate with the association over the matter while the case is referred to the Ministry of the Interior.

The economics minister remarked that actually, there still are stocks of gravel in Taiwan, but traders have become reluctant to sell their product due to speculation that prices will increase further.
He said the Ministry of Economic Affairs is now planning to have gravel transported from eastern Taiwan to western Taiwan for sale while overall domestic production will be increased to meet demand.

Admitting that domestic gravel prices are too high, Huang said his ministry is also working to import gravel from the Philippines, where gravel prices are only about 7.6 percent higher than those in China. The ministry is also looking at Vietnam as a possible source of gravel to meet local demand, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN ILLUSTRATOR A LATE BLOOMER

TEXT.P: Australian illustrator Shaun Tan was neither fazed by the fact that he was the shortest student in his class nor by the fact that he was not recruited by the famous Disney-Pixar animation studio. He has been enjoying being a picture book illustrator.

As a latecomer who started working on children's picture books at the age of 20, Tan is regarded as one of the most promising Australian illustrators. Tan is visiting Taiwan on a promotional tour for Australian picture books.

Tan was born in 1974 and grew up in the northern suburbs of Perth, Western Australia. His father is a Malaysian civil engineer of Chinese descent who relocated to Australia. In school, Tan became known as the "good drawer" which partly compensated for always being the shortest kid in every class.

He graduated from the University of Western Australia in 1995 with degrees in fine arts and English literature. Currently, Tan works full-time as a freelance illustrator and writer, concentrating mostly on picture books.

Tan began drawing and painting images for science fiction and horror stories in magazines as a teenager. He has won numerous awards for his work. He recently worked for Blue Sky Studios and Pixar, providing concept artwork for films, and turned down Pixar's offer of a full-time job.

Tan introduced to Taiwan two of his books, "The Red Tree" and "The Lost Thing", both of which are currently being adapted for short films. His works reflect a lot of his childhood memories and observations of life, making them suitable for both children and adults.

Speaking at the opening ceremony of an exhibition of more than 40 Australian picture books at Eslite Bookstores in Taipei Tuesday, Tan said he is proud of Australian picture books publishing and the country he comes from.

"Australia is an incredibly diverse country. And its picture books publishing is very disorganized, which is good. Artists in the field come from everywhere. There are businesspeople, school teachers, parents, people who live in the city, and people from the countryside," he said.
"And Australian picture books are being recognized for being experimental and adventurous, " Tan said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS

New York Times: Bush Takes Steps to Ease Increase in Energy Prices U.S. President Bush announced a series of shoort-term steps on Tuesday intended to ease the rise in energy prices, including a suspension of government purchases to refill the Strategic Petroleum Reserve, a relaxation of environmental rules for the formulation of gasoline and investigations into possible price gouging and price fixing. The rise in energy prices has undermined the administration's effort to build a case that its policies have led to economic prosperity and has given Democrats an opening to portray the White House and Congressional Republicans as allies of the oil industry. With Bush's poll numbers sagging and his party on the defensive over the Iraq war, Republicans have been scrambling to show they are trying to help consumers.
Wall Street Journal: Last Resort In Russia, Grim Case Spotlights Distress Of Justice Denied
In Russia, the European Court has become a last resort for thousands of citizens who've lost hope of obtaining justice at home. More cases against Russia are pending in Strasbourg than against any other country -- 13,945 at the end of 2005. Last year alone, Russians filed 8,500 complaints there, a sixth of all it received, according to a Kremlin official. While Russia is a large country, this still reflects a big showing. The complaints include many that don't fit the human-rights mold -- things like unpaid pensions -- as frustrated Russians treat Strasbourg as a kind of general court of appeal. Russia's representative at the court calls the high number of cases misleading, because "around 96 percent are declared inadmissible."
