The Pentagon plans to release nearly a third of those held at the prison for terrorism suspects in Guantanamo prison because they pose no threat to U.S. security, an official of the war crimes tribunal said Monday.

DOC.HEADLINE: 77% OF TAIWAN PEOPLE SUPPORT TAIWAN-U.S.-CHINA TALKS: POLL

TEXT.P: As many as 77 percent of the people in Taiwan are in favor of three-party talks by Taiwan, the United States and China to discuss issues regarding peace and stability across the Taiwan Strait, according to the results of a survey released Wednesday.

While 67 percent of the people are aware of Chinese President Hu Jintao's recent U.S. visit and his meeting with U.S. President George W. Bush, 60 percent do not believe Hu's claim that "China has always been committed to maintaining world peace and stability."
Also, 50 percent of the respondents do not think China will grant its people the freedom of assembly, speech and religion, and 26 percent think the Bush-Hu meeting has damaged Taiwan-U.S. relations.
In the event of China using force against Taiwan, 52 percent of the respondents think the United States will send troops to defend Taiwan.
The survey was conducted by the Decision Marking Research company for the Taiwan Thinktank April 22-24 on 1,099 people. It has a margin of error of plus or minus three percentage points.

Chen Ming-tong, a professor at National Taiwan University's Graduate Institute of National Development, said the survey shows that the people of Taiwan are concerned about the developments coming out of the Bush-Hu meeting.

Chen said the survey also reflects public expectations in Taiwan for a U.S. role in cross-strait relations and that the public will rethink the role played by the United States if Washington fails to handle the issue properly.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOV'T TO OFFER SUBSIDIES TO COLLEGE STUDENTS TO TEACH CHINESE ABROAD

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Education (MOE) will provide subsidies to university students in Chinese-language teaching programs who are offered teaching internships overseas, an MOE official said Wednesday.

In order to promote Chinese-language teaching abroad, the MOE will also encourage local universities and colleges to establish Chinese-language teaching departments or expand their existing departments, the official added.

Currently, there are only three universities in Taiwan that have Chinese-language teaching departments -- National Taiwan Normal University, Chung Yuan Christian University and National Kaohsiung Normal University.

In the past, most Taiwan university students enrolled in Chinese-language teaching programs headed to the United States, France or Germany for overseas teaching internships. The MOE said it hopes that in the future, more and more students will choose to head to other countries to hone their Chinese-language teaching skills.
Initially, the MOE will provide a subsidy to these students to cover their round trip air fare, with some students also receiving subsidies to cover their living expenses.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI SHARE PRICES SURGE

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange rose Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 109.04 points to close at 7,168.98.
The bourse opened at 7,080.62 and fluctuated between 7,173.56 and 7,047.96 during trading. A total of 4.37 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$124.16 billion (US$3.88 billion).

All eight major stock categories gained ground, with textile issues moving up the most at 3.8 percent, followed by foodstuff issues at 2.88 percent, paper and pulp stocks at 2.76 percent, banking and financial shares at 2.38 percent, construction stocks at 2.25 percent, machinery and electronics shares at 1.53 percent, plastics and chemicals shares at 0.38 percent, and cement stocks at 0.34 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 669 to 214, with 99 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: FINGERPRINTING REQUIREMENT FOR CHINESE VISITORS STILL UNDECIDED: MAC

TEXT.P: The issue of whether visitors from China should be required to have their fingerprints taken upon arrival in Taiwan has not yet been decided, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Joseph Wu said Wednesday.

The Ministry of Justice-proposed fingerprinting requirement for Chinese tourists, fishing boat crew members and nabbed illegal Chinese immigrants is still being discussed by the relevant administrative agencies, Wu said.

Fielding questions at the Legislative Yuan, Wu said that although more and more countries around the world have adopted similar measures for the sake of national security, the government has still not decided whether to implement such a requirement for Chinese citizens.
Opposition Kuomintang Legislator Lee Ching-hua said that if Taiwan implements such a requirement, Beijing may respond with a similar measure for Taiwan citizens entering China.
Lee also asked Wu whether the requirement should be imposed on visitors to Taiwan from other countries besides China.

Ruling Democratic Progressive Party Legislator Kao Chien-chih said he supports the proposed fingerprinting requirement, noting that Taiwan citizens traveling to the United States are also required to have their fingerprints taken upon arrival in that country.

DOC.HEADLINE: LIEN FAILS TO FIGHT FOR TAIWAN PEOPLE'S POLITICAL APPEALS: SCHOLAR

TEXT.P: A political analyst from Hong Kong said Wednesday that Taiwan's opposition Kuomintang (KMT) honorary Chairman Lien Chan failed to fight for the political interest of the Taiwanese people during his recent visit to China.

Professor Cheng Yu-shek of the City University of Hong Kong made the statement during an interview with Voice of America. Cheng said that Lien's visit did bring achieve some results in economic fields, referring to the "15 incentives" offered by China, but he added that Lien did not do his best to fight for the Taiwan people's political appeals.
Cheng said it is obvious that Beijing is aware of the reward of applying the united front strategy to the KMT because it offered Lien all kinds of privileges and economic incentives during his visit.
Cheng added that President Chen Shui-bian was forced to accept these offers against his will because of huge pressure from Taiwan's businesspeople.

Lien returned to Taiwan from China Tuesday after concluding a 13-day trip. He departed for Beijing April 14, at the head of a 170-strong group that included KMT lawmakers, academics and prominent businesspeople.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT URGES PRESIDENT TO THINK ABOUT PEOPLE INSTEAD OF POWER

TEXT.P: The main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) called on President Chen Shui-bian Wednesday to devote his time and energy to developing Taiwan's economy and improving people's livelihood rather than to the pursuit of political power.

KMT spokeswoman Cheng Li-wen made the remarks in response to Chen's accusation that the KMT is working with the Communist Party of China (CPC) to seize power in 2008. Chen made his statement during an interview with the Wall Street Journal, Asia Tuesday.

Cheng claimed that the recent KMT-CPC forum in Beijing was aimed at improving Taiwan's economy as well as people's livelihood because what the people of Taiwan care about most is their daily lives, which have been affected by a host of economic and other problems.
"People care only about their own lives, which have nothing to do with who will be in power in 2008," she added.

Chen has won re-election and no longer needs to worry about running for another term, Cheng said, adding that it is time for him to lead a competent and efficient government that will better serve the people.
"If he just thinks about campaigns and political power, people will not have a high expectation of him," she said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: President Ciampi urges political blocs to hold talks.
President Carlo Ciampi urged squabbling political blocs Tuesday to leave behind them the bitter clashes of the electoral contest and create a dialogue for the sake of the national and people's interests. Ciampi made the call in his message marking the 61th anniversary of Italy's liberation from the fascism.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S TOURISM POLICY TOWARD CHINESE CITIZENS ADJUSTABLE: MAC

TEXT.P: The government will adjust its tourism policy toward Chinese citizens, including refusing entry to Taiwan by Chinese tourists, if the problem of runaway Chinese visitors becomes too serious, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Joseph Wu said Wednesday.

Wu told the Legislative Yuan's interior and ethnic affairs committee that the government maintains a quota of 1,000 Chinese tourist entries per day and that 112,091 Chinese tourists had visited Taiwan as of April 15 since the government started to allow Chinese citizens meeting certain criteria to make pleasure trips to Taiwan in 2002.
Of these 112,091 Chinese tourists, 108 absconded during their stay in Taiwan, 74 of whom have been found, Wu said.
Wu proposed that China negotiate with China on the qualifications for Chinese citizens allowed to visit Taiwan in order to better prevent the problem of runaways.

At present, Chinese citizens who are allowed to make pleasure trips to Taiwan include those studying abroad, those who have obtained permanent resident status overseas, and those who transfer to Taiwan after visiting third countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: HU FAILS TO 'SCORE' AGAINST TAIWAN ON U.S. TRIP: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said recently that Chinese President Hu Jintao failed to "score points" against Taiwan during his visit to the United States last week.

In an interview with the Wall Street Journal, Asia that appeared Wednesday, Chen said that Chinese officials had hoped U.S. President George W. Bush would censure his decision in late February to cease the functioning of the National Unification Council, a body dedicated to eventual unification with China.

But Taiwan had already negotiated the language of that announcement with Washington, so Bush merely restated U.S. opposition to any unilateral changes in Taiwan's status by either Taipei or Beijing. Bush "did not allow China to score points on the Taiwan issue," according to Chen.

He also said that a gaffe by an MC during a welcoming ceremony for Hu at the White House was understandable given Beijing's insistence that Taiwan is part of China. He was referring to the MC's announcement of the playing of the anthem of the Republic of China, which is actually Taiwan's official name.
Chen said that to make the distinction clearer between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait is a central task for his remaining two years in office.

"I would like to see the international community gain a better understanding of the differences between democratic Taiwan and totalitarian China, " he said. "They are, in fact, two separate countries."
But he also said that China's rise poses longer-term military and economic threats to Taiwan and its people.

With China's military buildup in recent years, he said, the U.S. and Japanese governments have assessed that the balance of military power in the Taiwan Strait is tilting sharply toward China. "We must strengthen our defense capabilities," he said.

Although the opposition-dominated legislature has blocked a multimillion dollar arms procurement package -- eight diesel-electric submarines, six Patriot PAC-3 anti-missile batteries and a squadron of 12 P-3C submarine-hunting airplanes -- from the U.S. for nearly two years, Chen claimed that an accord with opposition legislators could come "in the near future."

"Only by strengthening our national defense can we ensure and safeguard the hard-won fruits of democracy as well as economic prosperity, " Chen said in the wide-ranging interview at the Presidential Office Tuesday.

With close business relations between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, evidenced by statistics provided by Taiwan's Ministry of Economic Affairs showing that government-approved investment in China by Taiwanese companies was estimated at around US$6 billion in 2005, he sounded a cautious note.
"When Taiwan's economy becomes overly dependent on or tilts excessively toward China, I think the government has a responsibility to issue an early warning," he said.
But he also said that "investing in China is part of the global plan of Taiwanese companies. The government cannot stop it."

Chen said China's rise is causing a list of problems for Taiwan and other countries: rising prices of raw materials, inefficient energy consumption and a flood of cheap imports that is causing structural unemployment.
China's growth "isn't only an opportunity for the global economy. More importantly, it's a kind of threat," Chen said.

He said the government wants to ensure that Taiwan, which has a per capita income of more than US$14,000 compared with China's US$1,700, does not "place all its bets" on China as Taiwanese companies rush to tap China's huge market and cheap labor.
Taiwan retains the edge over China in the information technology industry, Chen said, adding that "Taiwan's economy cannot become merely an appendage of China's economy."

But he also dismissed concerns about a possible government crackdown on investment in China in the wake of his announcement earlier this year that the government will more "actively manage" investment across the Taiwan Strait.
He said that prosecutors' investigation into chip giant United Microelectronics Corp's possible illicit ties to a Chinese semi-conductor company is "an isolated case."

He also voiced optimism that a long-awaited influx of Chinese tourists to Taiwan could occur later this year after Beijing recently announced that it might be willing to lift its restrictions on letting its citizens travel to Taiwan as tourists.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT THANKS TAIPEI MAYOR FOR SUPPORTING `REASONABLE' ARMS DEAL

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian thanked opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou Wednesday for supporting "reasonable" arms procurements, adding that he hopes the arms procurement bill could be passed at the Legislative Yuan as soon as possible.

During an interview with the Wall Street Journal, Asia Tuesday, Chen said that the best strategy for Taiwan is to "deter effectively and defend resolutely." He noted that Taiwan will never launch a first strike against any other country.
"Taiwan's defense is based on protection and prevention, and the top three principles of defense are preventing a war, defending the territory, and taking anti-terrorism measures," Chen said.
Chen said that Taiwan would do its best to avoid a war, "therefore, we need to enhance our defense capabilities."
Chen pointed out that the main reason for Taiwan to enhance defense capabilities lies with China, which has never given up the option of using force against the country.
Moreover, he continued, China passed its Anti-Secession Law in March last year and has deployed 784 missiles targeting Taiwan.
Between the "pan-green camp" and the "pan-bule alliance" there should be neither disputes nor ideological differences over enhancing Taiwan's defense power, Chen said.

Chen criticized the visits to China by former opposition KMT Chairman Lien Chan and People First Party Chairman James Soong, claiming that the visits have given wrong signals that will be misinterpreted.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT'S CHIEF POLICY PLANNER TO QUIT

TEXT.P: The chairman of the Research, Development and Evaluation Commission (RDEC) under the Executive Yuan will leave the administration by the end of April, it was announced Wednesday.

Emerging from a Cabinet meeting, the government's chief policy planner, Yeh Jiunn-rong, said that Premier Su Tseng-chang accepted his resignation at the meeting after trying in vain for days to persuade him to stay in the Cabinet.

Yeh, who was a professor at the Law School of National Taiwan University before being appointed minister without a portfolio in 2002 by then-Premier Yu Shyi-kun and going on to head the RDEC in 2004, said his four-year furlough from the university expires at the end of April and he has to return to his teaching work.

As the minister responsible for the re-organization of the Executive Yuan, Yeh expressed regret that a bill crafted by his council to streamline the executive branch has been bogged down in the opposition-controlled legislature.

Yeh said he asked opposition Kuomintang Chairman Ma Ying-jeou, who attended Wednesday's Cabinet meeting in his capacity as Taipei mayor, to support the bill, which crystallizes his work in office, so that hopefully it could be enacted during the present legislative session.
Although he will leave the Cabinet by the end of April, Yeh said he has agreed to continue seeking lawmakers' support for the bill as a private voluntary worker for the administration.
In a token of appreciation of Yeh's service, the premier awarded him a medal at the Cabinet meeting and retained him as a policy adviser to the Executive Yuan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO SKIRT TIAOYUTAI ISSUE IN FISHERY TALKS WITH JAPAN: COA

TEXT.P: Taiwan will skirt the thorny Tiaoyutai issue to facilitate the holding of fishery talks with Japan in the future, a Council of Agriculture (COA) official said Wednesday.

To facilitate the holding of a preparatory fishery meeting with Japan, Taiwan will intentionally not address the fishing area below 27 degrees north, or the southern area of the Tiaoyutai islands -- known as the Senkakus in Japan -- an uninhabited island group in the East China Sea where fishery as well as crude oil resources are reportedly abundant, said COA Vice Chairman Lee Chien-chuan.

Ministry of Foreign Affairs officials said a day earlier that Taiwan hopes to hold a preparatory meeting with Japan if formal talks between the two countries are impossible in the near future because of the huge differences in their respective viewpoints.

A planned 16th round of Taiwan-Japan fishery talks, originally scheduled to be held in March, was postponed to April and reportedly to an unspecified date, due to huge differences in the positions of the two sides on issues including overlapping territorial waters and the Tiaoyutai issue.

Meanwhile, Lee said, the Ministry of the Interior has drawn a provisional demarcation line or jurisdiction line along the center line of the two countries' overlapping economic zones since 2003 in order to avoid further disputes.
Taiwan fishing boats are not impounded by Japanese patrol ships if they operate only to the west of the demarcation line, he noted.

Taiwan and Japan have been embroiled in a long-running dispute over their overlapping economic zones, with many Taiwanese fishing boats being chased away or detained while operating in waters outside the temporary demarcation line.

Lee added that the COA Fisheries Administration has also allocated a budget to subsidize 230 Taiwan fishing boats to install advanced virtual memory system on their vessels to let them know whether they have crossed to an area east of the demarcation line when operating in the overlapping fishing grounds.
Taiwan and Japan have held 15 rounds of fishery talks and two rounds of preparatory meetings since 1996.

The waters near the Tiaoyutais northeast of Taiwan are considered by Taiwan fishermen as their traditional fishing grounds. However, Japan demarcated the area as part of its 200-nautical mile economic zone in 1996 and has since then often chased Taiwan fishing boats that enter the area and fined the owners of the boats.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES HIGHER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Wednesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for May moved up 155 points to close at 7,208, with 43,395 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for June rose 151 points to finish at 7,193, with 379 contracts traded, while September futures gained 143 points to close at 7,005, with 50 contract transactions.
December futures moved up 137 points to close at 6,990, with 20 contracts traded, while March futures gained 137 points to finish at 6,999, with five contract transactions.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Wednesday at 7,053 for May, 7,042 for June, 6,862 for September, 6,853 for December and 6,862 for March.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also higher.

May TE futures moved up 5.85 points to close at 317.2, with 6,531 contracts traded, while June TE futures gained 5.85 points to finish at 316.3, with 36 contract transactions. September TE futures rose 2.75 points to close at 306.6, with two contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for December and March.
May TF futures gained 33 points to finish at 980, with 3,778 contracts changing hands, while June TF futures moved up 29.4 points to close at 976, with 42 contracts traded.

September TF futures moved up 19.6 points to finish at 952, with 21 contract transactions, while December TF futures gained 31.4 points to close at 943.3, with two contracts traded. March TF futures rose 29 points to close at 949.8, with only one contract traded.

DOC.HEADLINE: RATIO OF PESSIMISTIC MANUFACTURERS INCREASES: POLL

TEXT.P: More Taiwan manufacturers have a negative outlook for the manufacturing sector over the next six months owing to uncertainties such as skyrocketing oil prices, according to the results of a survey released Wednesday by the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research.

The survey, conducted in March on the business climate for the manufacturing sector, shows that 16.1 percent of the respondents think conditions will be worse over the next six months, compared with just 7.6 percent who thought so in February.

A total of 34.7 percent of the respondents predicted that conditions will improve over the next six months, down significantly from 58.5 percent in the February survey. Meanwhile, 49.2 percent said they think conditions will remain the same, up from 33.9 percent in February.
The composite business climate indicator for the manufacturing sector stood at 105.84 in March, up 0.51 points from 105.33 in the previous month.

A total of 48.8 percent of the respondents in the March survey said the industry's current climate is good, up from 34.1 percent of respondents in February, while 12.8 percent said it is bad, down from 20.1 percent. At the same time, 38.4 percent said the climate is average, down from 45.8 percent a month earlier.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Straits Times: Thai King tells judges to find way out of crisis.
In a rare move, Thai King Bhumibol Adulyadej yesterday summoned the nation's top judges to his summer palace and told them they had to find a way to bring an end to the country's political crisis.

DOC.HEADLINE: 8 CITIES/COUNTIES RATED 'A' FOR ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION

TEXT.P: The Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) under the Executive Yuan rated eight cities and counties in Taiwan with an "A" for environmental protection performance, an EPA spokesman said Wednesday.

The top performing administrative areas are Taipei, Kaohsiung and Taichung cities and Taipei, Taoyuan, Chiayi, Kaohsiung and Yilan counties. They were rated according to 16 environmental protection indicators, including air quality, water resource management, soil conservation and waste treatment.
The spokesman said people are attaching greater and greater importance to environmental issues, which are always top of the list of their concerns in opinion polls about government performance.
On the other hand, local environmental protection officials also care very much about ratings of their work, adding a driving force behind their improved performances, the spokesman added.

However, despite the progress, the spokesman said, there is still room for improvement for all the cities and counties in terms of recycling, garbage incineration, the cleanliness of public toilets and sidewalks, and the quality of tap water.

DOC.HEADLINE: SLACKENING INVESTMENT, CONSUMPTION TO HINDER GROWTH: TIER

TEXT.P: With the adverse impact of soaring oil prices and huge credit card debts owed by local consumers becoming ever more evident, private investment and consumption growth is expected to slow, which will in turn affect the nation's economic growth this year, an economic think tank predicted Wednesday.
The TIER adjusted downward its economic growth forecast for this year from 4.02 percent to 3.91 percent, with the trade surplus expected to reach US$26.4 billion.

At a press conference on Taiwan's macro economy, TIER President David Hong noted that surging international crude oil prices and gigantic credit card debt in the domestic market will result in a decrease in private consumption growth from the original target of 3.07 percent to 2.82 percent, and will cause domestic investment growth to drop from the originally estimated 4.09 percent to 2.35 percent.
However, Hong said that although TIER adjusted downward this year's economic growth forecast, it does not mean that the research institute is pessimistic toward the country's economy.

According to a TIER estimate, Taiwan's consumer price index (CPI) will register a 1.84 percent growth this year, as TIER predicted that international crude oil prices will be maintained at between US$60 and US$65 per barrel this year, which the TIER said is not expected to cause too much inflation pressure.
In addition, the new Taiwan dollar is expected to appreciate against the U.S. dollar to the level of NT$31.893 this year, which Hong said will help reduce cost of imports and curb inflation.

Meanwhile, a TIER survey shows that only 34.7 percent of local manufacturers believe that the domestic economic prospects will improve in the coming six months, compared with the 58.5 percent registered in a previous survey conducted in February, while those pessimistic toward the business prospects in the coming six months rose from 7.6 percent to 16.1 percent due largely to the soaring oil prices.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Wednesday, gaining NT$0.059 to close at NT$32.053.
A total of US$971 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$32.065 and fluctuated between NT$31.998 and NT$32.075.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT LEGISLATOR GIVES UP BID FOR TAIPEI MAYOR

TEXT.P: Legislator John Chiang of the main opposition Kuomintang announced Wednesday that he will give up his bid for the post of Taipei mayor for the sake of the party's solidarity.

Chiang, accompanied by his wife and two daughters, said in a statement that since his decision to run in the mayoral election, he has found that elected officials, KMT members and relatives were put in a difficult situation after being asked to take sides among the KMT hopefuls.
"In the long run, this would seriously undermine the solidarity within the party," Chiang said.

After his withdrawal from the race, the other three KMT hopefuls left in the field to vie for a chance to represent the KMT in the year-end election are former Taipei Vice Mayor Yeh Chin-chuan, Legislator Ting Shou-chung and former Environmental Protection Administrator Hau Lung-bin.
Chiang said that KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou and KMT Honorary Chairman Lien Chan, both of whom he visited, support his decision. Chiang also called on Legislative Speaker Wang Jin-pyng Wednesday.
Chiang said he had hoped for a chance to serve through a fair and just democratic mechanism, but had to reconsider his bid in the wake of the latest developments.

He said that from his past experience as KMT secretary-general, he knows that solidarity within the party will be the key in competition with other parties, and that he had to consider the best interests of the party.
Yeh, whose support is catching up with the front runner, Hau, in polls, lauded Chiang, a former foreign affairs minister, for his expertise in diplomatic and cross-Taiwan Strait affairs.
Yeh also said that he would call on Chiang to seek his advice on city administration.
Chiang declined to discuss who he will support after his withdrawal.
Ting, who has the support of Lien, said that his ideal of upgrading the competitiveness of Taipei City remains unchanged.
Although facing an uphill battle, Ting said that "giving up has never been one of my options."
Ma said the primary has a fair competition mechanism and that he will respect the wills of all aspirants.

As long as there is more than one hopeful wanting to take part in the election, the party will follow the set procedure of holding a primary and will then throw its weight behind the winning candidate in the election.

Asked about integration with its ally, the People First Party, Ma said that both the KMT and PFP have yet to field their candidates and that if both parties field candidates, he will coordinate with the PFP to study whether to field one candidate to represent both parties in the election.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW REGULATIONS STIPULATE MORE TOILETS IN LADIES ROOMS

TEXT.P: The number of lavatories in women's public toilets should be increased to three or five times more than those in men's toilets, according to revised construction regulations, Vice Interior Minister Yen Wan-chin said Wednesday.
Under the new regulations, schools, stations and cinemas, where the toilets are often busy at certain periods, the ratio of toilet stalls between men and women should be one to five.
In other public places such as offices, factories and dormitories where toilets are not necessarily required by people at the same time, the ratio should be one to three.

Newly built buildings designed for public use will have to meet this criteria before they will granted licenses for use. State-owned buildings already built before the regulations take effect should improve gradually to meet the criteria, Yen said.

Private public buildings already constructed will not be affected by the regulations retroactively but should meet this requirement if they are applying for licenses for use other than originally intended.
The revision of the regulations was made after consulting with feminist groups to accommodate women's toilet needs, Yen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MODEL TO SERVE AS SPOKESWOMAN OF WORLD VISION AIDS PROGRAM

TEXT.P: Taiwan's top model, Lin Chiling, will serve as the spokeswoman for a program of World Vision Taiwan that cares for orphans left by deceased AIDS parents, officials of the charity organization said Wednesday.
Lin will travel with a delegation organized by the organization to Swaziland, which has the highest AIDS infection rate in Africa, from May 7-13, they said.

Lin said that since a horse-riding accident in China last year, she had reflected upon her life during her months of convalescence and decided to serve as a World Vision volunteer. She expressed hope that her visit to Swaziland will be her first lesson of a richer life.
Lin said she also met a Watoto children's chorus from Uganda recently to "further her understanding" of Africa.
The officials said that World Vision launched the HIV/AIDS HOPE Initiative to take care of children orphaned by AIDS parents, as well as AIDS-affected families.
The initiative, which stands for H-help, O-orphan, P-prevent, and E-educate, will also work on preventing AIDS infections and on educating the public on AIDS awareness, they added.
The program will operate in countries with high AIDS infection rates such as South Africa, Swaziland, Lesotho, Malawi, Ethiopia, India, China and Laos.
They urged the public to contribute to the program through the Web site i-payment.worldvision.org.tw. Related information can also be obtained by calling 02-2585-6300 or from www.worldvision.org.tw.

DOC.HEADLINE: REPORTER FINED FOR THIRD TIME FOR REFUSING TO GIVE TESTIMONY

TEXT.P: The Taiwan High Court fined a United Daily News reporter NT$30,000 for the third time in a row Wednesday after he again refused to give testimony about his sources for a news story that is part of a court hearing on an insider stock trading case.

Kao Nien-yi remained silent on the question of who gave him the information he reported March 16, 2005 regarding an insider trading scandal in which senior government officials are allegedly involved.

The prosecutors said they believe Lee Chin-cheng, former director of the Examination Bureau of the Financial Supervisory Commission and a key suspect in the case, might have leaked critical information to Kao, whose story was used as a tool by Lee's stock-trading friends, who stand accused of making illicit profits.

In that story, Kao reported that Lee gave his friends advance information on a government probe of illegal trading of Power Quotient International Co.'s shares. Armed with the information, they made huge gains by selling short on the small computer company's stock, leading to an extremely volatile stock market at the time.
Liu Shou-sung, a spokesman for the court, said the court handed down the fine because it claimed Kao had "neither a proper reason nor the right" to refuse testimony.
Kao's newspaper has pledged to lodge a formal complaint against the court ruling on the consecutive fines, claiming that freedom of the press and the country's democratic system are at stake.

Other media organizations and journalist groups have also voiced support for the reporter, urging the court to respect the ethics of their profession and not to infringe on their constitutionally protected rights.

Government Information Minister Cheng Wen-tsang called for a rational debate on the issue, which he said involves "two important values in a democracy" -- freedom of the press and judicial independence.

Freedom of the press is a pivot of democracy, while judicial jurisdiction is the last defense of social justice, Cheng noted. "Both are important. When they are in conflict, we need a rational debate to clear things up," he added.
As to whether a criminal act has been committed in the process, that is something the judicial authorities are still investigating, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: ETHNIC CHINESE YOUTHS TO BE RECRUITED TO TEACH ENGLISH IN TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: New York, April 25 (CNA) (By Lillian Lin and Taijing Wu)

TEXT.P: The Taipei-based King Car Education Foundation is looking for young ethnic Chinese in North America to teach aboriginal children English in Taiwan this summer, foundation Director Morgan Sun said in New York Tuesday.
Sun said that the foundation would like to provide English education to aboriginal children in eastern Taiwan while helping young ethnic Chinese living in North America experience life in Taiwan.
The King Car Education Foundation introduced last year 30 young overseas Chinese to remote spots in Kaohsiung, Hualien and Nantou counties in Taiwan to teach English.
People interested in the program can visit the foundation's Web site at www.kingcar.org.tw. Applications for the program are accepted until April 30.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT URGES FRANCE TO HELP TAIWAN JOIN WHO

TEXT.P: The people of Taiwan must not be deprived of their right to health, and Taiwan hopes France will help it join the World Health Assembly (WHA) as an observer, something the country has vigorously attempted to do for the past ten years, President Chen Shui-bian said Wednesday.

Chen made the remarks during a meeting with the French parliament's pro-Taiwan group at the Presidential Office. He expressed hope the group's leader Senator Monique Papon and other members would exert their influence to help Taiwan participate in WHO (World Health Organization) activities.
France has sold a large amount of weapons to Taiwan, including Lafayette-class warships and Mirage 2000 aircraft which are still the mainstay of Taiwan's armed forces, Chen said.

He noted that bilateral trade between Taiwan and France reached almost US$4 billion in 2005, with France registering a US$1.1 billion trade deficit, adding that Taiwan is France's 6th largest import country and 5th largest export market.

As there should not be any question of national boundaries when it comes to public health promotion and the prevention of epidemics, Taiwan's 23 million people must not be deprived of their right to health, Chen stressed.

Chen criticized China's poor human rights record, which he claimed has shown no improvement since the 1989 Tiananmen incident, as China remains a country where there is no freedom of speech, freedom of assembly or freedom of the press.

Moreover, he continued, China passed the "Anti-Secession" Law in March last year, and has increasingly deployed missiles targeting Taiwan. Therefore, European countries should maintain the arms embargo on China, Chen added.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEMOCRATIC TAIWAN CORNERSTONE OF ASIA-PACIFIC SECURITY: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Democratic Taiwan is the cornerstone of Asia-Pacific security, a visiting Taiwan official said Wednesday.
Presidential Office Secretary-General Tan Sun Chen made the remarks during a speech delivered at a forum on Taiwan affairs organized by Waseda University in Tokyo.

Noting that Taiwan and Japan are on the "same boat" in the face of China's increasing military power, the former ROC minister of foreign affairs said the two countries should cooperate closely to maintain the peace and security in the Asian and Pacific region.

"The west Pacific where Taiwan and Japan are located is not politically stable, with democratic and communist forces competing with each other on both sides of the Taiwan Strait, " Chen said, adding that while Taiwan has been devoting itself to democratization, China is using its new-found economic power to expand its global hegemony.

Noting how Taiwan and Japan have played a key role in China's modernization and economic rise, Chen said Japan had offered development aid worth US$30 billion to China, while Taiwanese investors have been injecting US$280 billion into its economy.
Despite this, China has spared no efforts in squeezing Taiwan's presence within the international community, Chen stressed.
With China's military spending growing by double digits every year, Chen said Japan and other Asian countries should also question the motivation behind such a phenomenon.
"Although China is using every method to obstruct Taiwan's democracy, the island should not concede in this field, as democracy is the treasure and the bottom line of Taiwan," Chen said.

Chen also expressed gratitude to Japan for offering Taiwanese tourists 30-day visa-free treatment during his term as ROC foreign minister and for hailing Taiwan's democratization as U.S. President George W. Bush did in his speech delivered in Kyoto last November.

Stressing that democracy is a core value shared by Taiwan, Japan and the United States, Chen said the three countries should strengthen their cooperation to protect democracy in the Asian-Pacific region.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN MINISTER CONFIDENT ABOUT TIES WITH SOLOMON ISLANDS

TEXT.P: Minister of Foreign Affairs Huang Chih-fang said Wednesday he is confident that diplomatic relations between Taiwan and the Solomon Islands will remain intact, despite the recent turmoil in the South Pacific island nation.

Huang was responding to foreign wire service reports that quoted the Solomon Islands' sole opposition candidate for prime minister, Manasseh Sogavare, as saying earlier the same day that if elected he will consider severing diplomatic ties with Taiwan.

Noting that the political situation in the Solomon Islands has not yet stabilized following a recent riot in the country's capital city, Huang said various political forces are now vying for the power to form the next Cabinet.

As Taiwan has devoted long-term efforts to maintaining extensive ties with both ruling and opposition parties in the Solomon Islands, Huang said he is confident that bilateral relations won't be affected by the country's recent political developments.

At a time when the Solomon Islands is undergoing a power transition, Huang said the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) dares not let down its guard and will keep close tabs on all relevant developments.

The Solomon Islands' capital of Honiara was wracked by burning and looting -- mostly businesses owned by ethnic Chinese there -- after its parliament elected Snyder Rini as prime minister April 18. The situation abated after Australia and New Zealand sent troops and police officers to maintain law and order.

Australian officials claimed the riot was a reaction to Taiwan's involvement in the Solomon Islands' prime minister election. But Huang dismissed the claim, stressing the Republic of China's government had no involvement in its ally's election.
Following Rini's resignation Tuesday on the eve of the opening of the new parliamentary session, the Solomon Islands' political situation has again caused concern.
Rini will serve as caretaker prime minister until the parliament elects a replacement. On Wednesday, Sogavare was appointed as the sole opposition candidate in the upcoming prime minister election.

DOC.HEADLINE: IMPOSSIBLE TO LOWER NOISE LEVEL BELOW 48DB IN S. SCIENCE PARK: NSC

TEXT.P: It's simply impossible to lower the noise level to below 48 decibels in Southern Taiwan Science Park, where a vibration-reduction engineering project has become the subject of controversy, a senior National Science Council official said Wednesday.
Hsieh Ching-chih, an NSC vice chairman, said even without the noise from high-speed trains running through the park, its background noise was already at the 50-52 decibel level.

He claimed that from the very outset, it was a "mission impossible" when the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) and the NCS discussed the target of lowering the noise level to below 48 decibels.

Therefore, he added, it was not an issue that the NSC allowed a private contractor to try to complete that impossible mission, since the project was aimed merely at "reducing" the vibration or noise level -- or improving it.
Hsieh made the comment as some have suspected irregularities may have occurred during the process of selecting the project's winning contractor.

For example, in an area 200 meters from the high-speed railway, Hung Hua Technology Engineering Co. has managed to bring down the noise level from 60db to 50db, which is quite an improvement, he said.
When high-tech companies set up their own production lines, they will install their own facilities so that manufacturing sites would have a noise level as low as 30db or 20db, he added.

In response to Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) Legislator Liao Pen-yen's suspicion that the NSC might have been overcharged by the private contractor, Hsieh said even if it were just one cent, NSC would "demand it back."

Kuomintang (KMT) Legislator Lee Chi-chu quoted an April 6 administrative court ruling as saying the NSC went ahead to decide on a winning contractor in spite of the fact that none of the competing companies had presented a proposal that met the NCS's own requirements.
She said the NCS will have to explain why it decided to waste taxpayer money to build a "vibration reduction" wall that it knew full well would not work.
Hsieh and other officials, including those at the science park, will attend a legislative committee meeting to face lawmakers' questions Thursday.

DOC.HEADLINE: TOURIST ARRIVALS UP IN FIRST QUARTER: DGBAS

TEXT.P: The number of inbound passengers reached 860,000 in the first quarter of this year, marking a 7.5 percent year-on-year growth, the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) said Wednesday.
Among them, tourists accounted for 352,000, up 12.8 percent from the year-earlier level, and business travelers numbered 237,000.
Japan remained the largest source of visitors to Taiwan, accounting for 294,000 or 34.2 percent of the total and representing a 7.5 percent year-on-year increase.
Visitors from Hong Kong and Macau formed the second largest group of inbound passengers, accounting for 101,000, according to DGBAS tallies.
The United States was the third largest source of visitors to Taiwan during the January-March period, totaling 91,000.
During the first three months of this year, Taiwan citizens made 2.03 million overseas visits, up 7.9 percent from the year-earlier level.
Hong Kong remained Taiwan people's top overseas travel destination, making 693,000 visits during the three-month period.

The number of Taiwan visitors to Thailand registered a 58.7 percent year-on-year growth in the first quarter, DGBAS officials said, adding that the steep rise was attributable to a relatively small number of travelers to that country last spring following the tsunami disaster in South and Southeast Asia in December 2004.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Rumsfeld and Rice Make Unannounced Visit to Iraq.
BAGHDAD, April 26-Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld and Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice made an unannounced joint visit to Iraq Wednesday to bolster the new emerging government and to ensure that the sometimes disjointed U.S. political and military operations are working seamlessly with the transition to a permanent government.

DOC.HEADLINE: SCO AIMED AT COUNTER-BALANCING U.S. CONTAINMENT: SCHOLAR

TEXT.P: The Shanghai Cooperation Organization (SCO) allows China to offset the perceived attempt by the United States to surround and contain China, said a Hong Kong professor Wednesday.

Barry Sautman, an associate professor of the Department of Social Science at the Hong Kong University of Science and Technology, told CNA in a telephone interview that the abovementioned purposes of the organization are more important than its stated objectives of anti-terrorism and combating separatism.

With the organization moving beyond anti-terrorism to projects involving military cooperation, it is trying to impress on the West -- particularly the United States -- that it would be unsuccessful in any attempt to contain China, such as the case in the 1950s and 60s, he said.
This is one reason why Chinese and Russian leaders are anxious to expand the organization to include other countries in Western Asia, such as Iran, India and Pakistan, he added.
"In fact it means that most countries surrounding China would be more or less friendly -- or at least well disposed toward China -- through the Shanghai Cooperation Organization," he said.
However, Sautmen said that some member countries may have different reasons for participating in the quasi-alliance.
"Some Central Asian countries see China as a counter-balance to Russia," he said.
However, he said, most of the quasi-alliance's results would be in the realm of psychological warfare.

"What China's trying to do is basically show that wing of opinion in U.S. solid circles that any attempt on their part to create a bloc to surround China -- or contain China -- would be fruitless because China has created a counter-organization involving neighboring countries," he said.

U.S. leaders, he added, certainly don't want to have any kind of competing regional organizations, especially given the fact they have been rebuffed in their attempt to gain observer status in the SCO.
Sautman also noted that the SCO is stronger than it was several years ago.
The SCO was founded in 2001 based on an informal regional alliance set up in 1996. Its members include China, Russia, Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Tajikistan and Uzbekistan.
Mongolia, Pakistan, India and Iran are observers at SCO meetings.
The SCO held a one-day defense ministers' meeting in Beijing Wednesday, in which the six nations announced they will hold joint anti-terrorism exercises in Russia next year.
The Chinese side has said that SCO is not aimed at confronting other parts of the world and will not damage the interests of other countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SHOULD TRY TO SIGN FTA WITH CHINA: KMT CHIEF

TEXT.P: Main opposition Kuomintang Chairman Ma Ying-jeou proposed Wednesday that Taiwan explore new ways to improve ties with China, such as signing a Free Trade Agreement (FTA) and other measures conducive to Taiwan's economic development.
Ma made the remarks in a speech titled "Standing on Taiwan, Looking at the World," at National Cheng Kung University in Tainan in southern Taiwan.

Ma said to an audience of students: "We should try our best to find opportunities for Taiwan, such as signing an FTA with countries like the United States and Singapore, in the same way that Panama has been the first country to sign an FTA with Taiwan."

He noted that members of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) are promoting a "ten plus one" or "ten plus two or three" trade zone, which will eventually include Japan, China, and South Korea -- but possibly exclude Taiwan.

Globalization doesn't just mean speaking English or going abroad; rather, it means taking advantage of Taiwan's being at the center and the front door of East Asia, Ma said, adding that it also means to explore any opportunities or connections with China, including signing an FTA.

Ma also suggested that Taiwan open its doors as soon as possible to China's high school graduates so they would be able to study at Taiwan's universities, a move he claimed would decrease hostilities between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEEDS TO SHORE UP NATIONAL DEFENSE: JAPANESE PROFESSOR

TEXT.P: Taiwan needs to shore up its national defense instead of emphasizing its independent sovereign status, a Japanese law professor who spent part of his youth in Taiwan before World War II said at a Taipei seminar Wednesday.

"From the international law perspective, Taiwan is already an independent country with its own territory, government and people," said Shigeru Oda, a professor at Japan's Tohoku University and a former judge of the International Court of Justice for 27 years.
"There's no need for Taiwan to stress the fact of independence, " Oda said. "Instead, what Taiwan urgently needs to do is shore up its national defense."

The Oda family enjoyed a deep relationship with Taiwan when the island was under Japanese colonial rule (1895-1945). During that period, Oda's grandfather and father served as doctors in Taiwan, helping to establish medical schools on the island.
Oda, 79, grew up and received most of his secondary education in Taipei before returning to Tokyo in 1945 to pursue an international law career, which has taken him to the U.S. and the Netherlands.
During the last 60 years, Oda has occasionally visited Taiwan and described himself as "nostalgic" and holding special feelings for the island.

Oda addressed a full house about how the Taiwanese were reluctant to talk about politics after the tragic Feb. 28 Incident of 1947 in which many elite Taiwanese professionals were jailed or executed by the then-Kuomintang government.

In his view, Oda continued, Taiwan was wrong to adopt an "all or nothing" approach in its battle to defend its seat in the United Nations in the early 1970s. Because of then-President Chiang Kai-shek's reluctance to make any compromise on the Republic of China's national title, the U.N. General Assembly came to adopt Resolution No. 2758 in 1971, giving the "China" seat to Beijing at the expense of Taipei.

The seminar "My perspective on Taiwan" was part of a series of activities to commemorate the late ruling Democratic Progressive Party Chairman Huang Shin-chieh. It was co-organized by the Ketagalan Institute and the International Cultural Foundation.

DOC.HEADLINE: YOUTH UNEMPLOYMENT RATE DROPS: CEPD

TEXT.P: The jobless rate among young people aged between 15 and 24 declined slightly to 10.59 percent last year from 11.45 percent in 2004, the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) said Wednesday.

With a view to bridging the gap between tertiary education and the needs of the job market, CEPD officials said this year the government will invest NT$220 million in vocational training programs for new graduates and helping young people improve their professional skills or obtain new ones.

Moreover, the officials said the government will offer subsidies to galvanize local universities to open courses in semiconductivity, optoelectronics and telecommunications in order to expand the talent pool for manufacturing companies in those fields.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR TO VISIT SINGAPORE MAY 6-9

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou will leave for Singapore May 6 for a three-day visit at the invitation of the Singapore government, city officials said Wednesday.

Ma will exchange views with Singaporean officials on a range of topics, including wireless broadband Internet connectivity, fight against official corruption, economic development and urban renewal, the officials said.

During his visit, Ma will meet with Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong, Minister Mentor Lee Kuan Yew and other senior officials. Ma, who doubles as main opposition Kuomintang, is scheduled to return May 9.

DOC.HEADLINE: CDC RESPECTS FINES FOR HOSPITAL OVER FAILURE TO REPORT TB CASE

TEXT.P: The Center for Disease Control (CDC) respects the Taipei City Government's decision to fine Taipei Veterans General Hospital (TVGH) for its failure to report a case involving a notifiable disease, an official said Wednesday.

CDC Deputy Director Shih Wen-yi made the remarks after the Taipei City Government's Department of Health decided to fine Taipei Veterans General Hospital (TVGH) NT$300,000 (US$9,375) for failing to inform it of former President Lee Teng-hui's mild case of tuberculosis (TB) contraction.
The city government also fined the doctor in charge of Lee's case NT$90,0000 (US$2,812.5) in accordance with the law on epidemic prevention and control.

As tuberculosis is a notifiable disease, the hospital and the doctor are required by law to report Lee's case to the municipal health department within a week. However, the hospital violated the law by reporting the case directly to the central government and bypassing the municipal health authorities.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, April 27, or the 30th day of the third month of the Year of the Dog according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1521: Portuguese navigator Ferdinand Magellan is killed by the inhabitants on the island of Mactan in the Philippines.
1791: American painter and inventor Samuel F.B. Morse is born. A portraitist whose subjects included Lafayette, he refined and patented the telegraph and developed the telegraphic code that bears his name.
1822: Ulysses S. Grant, the 18th president of the United States, is born. After his victorious Vicksburg campaign, he was made commander in chief of the Union Army and accepted the surrender of Confederate Gen. Robert E. Lee at Appomattox in 1865, thus ending the Civil War.
1882: Ralph Waldo Emerson, the American essayist, philosopher, and a central figure of American transcendentalism, dies at the age of 78. His poems, orations and essays are regarded as landmarks in the development of American thought and literary expression.
1887: The world's first surgical removal of an appendix, an operation known as an appendectomy, is performed by American surgeon Dr. Thomas Morton in Philadelphia.
1911: An uprising in Canton, China, is foiled when revolutionaries led by Huang Shing are defeated by the local garrison. The battle in Canton is the 10th uprising directed by Dr. Sun Yat-sen after he launched a revolutionary movement against the Ching court in the late 19th century.
1937: The new Golden Gate suspension bridge linking the city of San Francisco with Marin County reaches completion after four years.
1945: The Allies reject peace offers by German S.S. chief Heinrich Himmler, insisting on unconditional German surrender.
1949: Republic of China President Chiang Kai-shek arrives in Shanghai and reiterates his determination to suppress the communist rebellion.
1950: The British government officially recognizes the state of Israel.
1956: Rocco Marciano, known as "Rocky," the American boxer who won the world heavyweight championship in 1952 and defended it six times, retires as undefeated world heavyweight boxing champion.
1959: Liu Shao-chi is elected "state chairman" of Communist China.
1960: The ROC establishes diplomatic relations with the Republic of Togo.
1960: Syngman Rhee resigns as president of South Korea, ending his 12-year rule.
1962: Hsieh Chin wins the "best director" award in the first film festival to be held in mainland China.
1972: After a journey to the moon, U.S. Apollo 16 spacecraft carrying three astronauts makes a safe landing in the Pacific Ocean.
1972: Kwame Nkrumah, the Ghanaian president who was deposed in 1966 by a military coup while he was in mainland China, dies in Bucharest, Hungary.
1973: Jordanian Ambassador to the ROC Mutasim Bileisi returns to Amman after a two-year tour of duty in Taipei.
1974: The Academia Sinica Advisory Council votes on a list of candidates for academicians.
1974: The Taiwan Railway Administration and General Electric of the United States sign a contract for the electrification of Taiwan's western trunk line railway. GE will provide 74 locomotives and heavy trucks for the project.
1978: President Mohammed Daoud is killed in a bloody coup and replaced by Afghanistan's first communist ruler, Nur Mohammed Taraki, who proclaims the Democratic Republic of Afghanistan.
1992: The International Monetary Fund and World Bank approve the membership of Russia and 12 other former Soviet republics.
1993: Koo Chen-fu, chairman of the ROC Straits Exchange Foundation, and Wang Daohan, chairman of Beijing's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait, meet in Singapore in what is the first official contact between Taipei and Beijing since 1949.
1997: The world's longest road-rail suspension bridge, linking Hong Kong to its new offshore airport, is formally opened.
1998: Nguyen Van Linh, former general secretary of the Vietnam Communist Party, dies.
1999: Verka Modanu, the Republic of Macedonia's first resident envoy to the Republic of China, arrives in Taipei to assume her post.
2000: President-elect Chen Shui-bian says that only mutual trust can bring real peace to the people of both sides of the Taiwan Strait.
2001: The first-ever civic group to promote private exchanges between Taiwan-controlled offshore island of Kinmen and mainland China' Xiamen is formally established following the implementation of the "mini three links" with mainland China at the beginning of the year.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "When you meet the proper person to speak to and do not speak out, you lose your opportunity; but when you meet one who is not a proper person to speak to and you speak to him, you waste your words. A man of intelligence never loses his opportunity, neither does he waste his words."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STILL WAITING FOR U.S. REPLY ON STOPOVER REQUEST
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 26 (CNA) (By Jorge Liu and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Taiwan was still waiting as of Wednesday afternoon for a reply from Washington to its request that President Chen Shui-bian be allowed to make transit stops in the United States next week, according to diplomatic sources.
Chen is set to depart Taipei May 3 for Paraguay. He will later visit Costa Rica for the inauguration of President-elect Oscar Arias before returning to Taipei May 11.

Taiwan hopes that Chen will be able to make a stopover on the west coast or southern part of the United States on his way to Latin America and make a stopover in New York or on the U.S. west coast on his way back to Taiwan, the sources said.
Taiwan's representative office in the United States filed an application with the U.S. State Department April 21.
Asked about the issue during a daily press briefing Monday, State Department Deputy Spokesman Adam Ereli said he has no information concerning such an application.
"I'm not aware that any decision has been made on any possible request, " Ereli said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN OFFICIAL CALLS EUROPE'S ATTENTION TO CHINA'S RISE

TEXT.P: Taiwan's representative to Britain, Edgar Lin, urged the European Union Wednesday to pay attention to China's rise and study its possible impact on global security.

Expressing his doubts about Beijing's claim to be pursuing a "peaceful rise, " Lin noted that China has taken advantage of its rapid economic growth to build up its military with the ambition of becoming a superpower.
While China's arms spending power is second only to the United States, Beijing has never relaxed its efforts to suppress Taiwan in the international arena, Lin said.
Lin said the European Union has focused its attention on China's economy and has ignored the human rights situation in the country.
Lin made the remarks while giving a speech at the School of Oriental and African Studies of University of London.

During a question and answer session, Lin said that as Beijing will host the 2008 Olympic Games, it will try to put China's best face forward to the world and will restrain itself to avoid causing any military conflict across the Taiwan Strait.

Although China may seem friendly to Taiwan in appearance, it is taking every possible step to block Taiwan's participation in international organizations, including the World Health Organization, Lin said.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP DENIES PRESIDENT LEADING MOVE TO BOOST NUMBER OF LEGISLATIVE SEATS

TEXT.P: The legislative caucus of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party Thursday denied as "groundless" reports that President Chen Shui-bian has been quietly leading a campaign to increase the number of legislative seats from 113 to 164 and to adopt the Cabinet system of government.

Chen Ching-chun and Yeh Yi-jin, leaders of the DPP caucus, said the president cares only about "giving Taiwan a suitable Constitution" but has never gone into such details as to how many seats should be adopted in the coming amendments to the Constitution.

To change the number of legislative seats, the Constitution must be amended. And to change a Constitutional provision, a proposal must be signed by a quarter of the legislators, who would then vote on whether or not to put the proposal to a national referendum.

The proposal would require the support of three-quarters of the lawmakers in a legislative session attended by at least three-quarters of all legislators. This is why it is considered to be a "high threshold" for any Constitutional amendment proposal to pass the legislature. After that, the legislature-approved proposal would be put to a national referendum.

In spite of the difficulties in having a constitutional provision revised, lawmakers from all the major parties at the Legislative Yuan have been quietly forming a "united front" to try to change the provision on the number of seats in the next and future legislature, a local newspaper reported Thursday.
The report said President Chen Shui-bian has been behind the campaign, a report that the DPP caucus called "groundless."

Chen Ching-chun said the Constitution had just been amended last year to cut the number of legislative seats by half. If the lawmakers themselves propose another amendment just to increase their own chances of getting re-elected, this will leave a bad taste in the people's mouths, he added.
DPP Chairman Yu Shyi-kun also said the party cannot seek to "turn the clock back" when it comes to amending the Constitution.

Regarding the election of the members of the legislature, the Constitution was amended last year to include a clause on the "single constituency, two votes" system to come into effect in 2007. Last year's amendments also enshrined the general public's right to referendum, an achievement that President Chen has said he is proud of.
"In the future, " Yu said, "the DPP will not support any constitutional amendment proposals that are not in accord with the spirit and purpose of national referendum."

Claiming that he remains "completely neutral" in this controversy, legislative speaker Wang Jin-pyng said increasing the number of legislative seats is something that should at least be discussed. "How realistic it is to amend the Constitution in that way is another story," he added.
One hundred and thirteen legislative seats indeed are "too few, " he said, adding that "what should be reformed should be reformed, for the sake the country."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN INFORMATION SECURITY COMPANIES LAUNCH ALLIANCE

TEXT.P: Three Taiwan-based information security companies announced Wednesday that they have initiated an " Information Security Research Alliance," aiming to provide locally made, all-round security solutions.

Yang Po-keng, an offical of the Industrial Development Bureau under the Ministry of Economic Affairs, said that he hopes the new alliance can improve Taiwan's research capacity in information security technology.

The alliance is made up of Softnext Technologies Co. -- specializing in e-mail security, Dragonsoft --focusing on network vulnerability assessment, and BroadWeb -- concentrating on preventing intrusion through the Internet.

An executive of Dragonsoft said that in the strategic alliance, his company serves as a safeguard and detects security loopholes for clients, while Softnext and BroadWeb offer protection for e-mail, computer system and application software.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN DENIES INVOLVEMENT IN SOLOMON ISLANDS' ELECTION

TEXT.P: Taiwan maintains stable and close relations with the Solomon Islands but has never interfered in any democratic elections of the South Pacific nation, a Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) official said Thursday.

According to Donald Lee, director-general of the MOFA's Department of East Asian and Pacific Affairs, Taiwan has provided a lot of assistance to the Solomon Islands to promote the country's national development projects since the two countries established diplomatic relations in 1983, and both sides have developed a close relationship over the past 20 years.

Lee said that Taiwan also maintains good relations with Manasseh Sogavare, the Solomon Islands' sole opposition candidate for prime minister, and that Sogavare's Social Credit Party is supportive of the diplomatic relations with Taiwan and Taiwan's bids to join the United Nations and other international organizations.
Lee made the remarks during a regular news briefing in the wake of reports that Sogavare will consider severing diplomatic ties with Taiwan if elected.
Snyder Rini, who was elected by the Solomon Islands' parliament as prime minister April 18, resigned Tuesday on the eve of the opening of the new parliamentary session.
Rini's election to the post triggered riots in the Solomon Islands amid rumors that Taiwan or China had been involved in influencing the election outcome.

MOFA spokesman Michel Lu said there is no reason for Taiwan to try to influence the election because the majority of the parliamentarians in the Solomon Islands are in favor of maintaining diplomatic relations with Taiwan.

DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Grand Jury Gets Rove Testimony Over C.I.A.
Leak Karl Rove, the senior counselor to President Bush, testified for several hours on Wednesday before the federal grand jury in the C.I.A. leak case, in an appearance that was a sign of renewed attention by the special prosecutor in a matter that has lingered unresolved for months. It was the fifth time Rove has appeared before a federal grand jury in the case. The appearance came at a politically sensitive time for Rove, who was relieved of his policy portfolio at the White House in a staff reshuffling earlier this month and now faces the challenge of helping Republicans maintain their primacy in the midterm elections this fall.
Wall Street Journal: Economy's Surge Stirs Questions About When Slowdown May Come
The latest readings suggest the United States' economy is carrying significant momentum into the second quarter, raising new questions about when a slowdown might come after a torrid start to the year. By most accounts, the economy surged in the first quarter after a brief lull late last year. Over the rest of the year, Federal Reserve officials expect growth to moderate to a long- term rate of 3 percent to 3.5 percent, slow enough to keep inflation at bay but fast enough to keep unemployment from rising. That would permit the Fed to stop the campaign of interest-rate increases it began in June 2004.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER MEETS WITH BUSINESS LEADERS

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang hosted a breakfast meeting with business leaders Thursday, during which one participant suggested that the government set up a free port like Hong Kong's.
Hsu Sheng-fa, leader of the Suzuki group in Taiwan, made the suggestion to Su, who was hosting his first such meeting with business leaders since becoming premier in March.

Other participants included Theodore M.H. Huang, chairman of the Chinese National Association of Industry and Commerce; Chen Wu-hsiung, chairman of the Chinese National Federation of Industries (CNFI) ; Wang Ling-in, chairman of the General Chamber of Commerce; Hsu Sheng-hsiung, chairman of the Taiwan Electrical and Electronic Manufacturers' Association; Day Sheng-tong, president of the National Association of Small and Medium-Size Enterprises; Morris Chang, chairman of Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Corp.; Douglas Hsu, chairman of the Far Eastern Group; and Cheng Shen-chih, chairman of the Taiwan Financial Services Roundtable (TFSR).

"Developing Taiwan's economy, cracking down on crime, taking good care of minorities and the disadvantaged, and leading a clean and competent government are my administrative priorities, " Su told the business leaders.

DOC.TEXT:
Los Angeles Times: Bush's Proposals Viewed as a Drop in the Oil Bucket.
Under intense political pressure, President Bush on Tuesday pledged new government action to root out any gasoline price gouging and announced a series of measures designed to encourage conservation and foster enery alternatives. But White House officials acknowledged that the steps were not likely to bring immediate relief.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWMAKERS CALL FOR CUT IN NUMBER OF MOBILE PHONE BASE STATIONS

TEXT.P: A group of legislators urged the National Communications Commission (NCC) Thursday to see to it that the number of mobile phone base stations (MPBS) around the country be substantially cut to return to the Taiwan public a safe and radiation-free environment.

According to NCC Vice Chairman Liu Tsung-teh, there are 26,000 base stations for 2G mobile phones, 6,500 base stations for 3G mobile phones and 16,000 base stations for personal handy-phone systems (PHS), for atotal of about 48,000 base stations around the country.

Ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Legislator Kuo Chun-ming said he wants the NCC to "strongly intervene" in efforts to cut the number of base stations by at least half since the coverage rate of existing MPBSs is more than five times the amount that Taiwan residents actually need.

DPP Legislator Tsai Chi-chang asked Liu whether the number of base stations can be cut by half in the future and said that the NCC should demonstrate its authority by controlling the number of base stations.

Opposition Kuomintang Legislator Tsai Cheng-yuan said that based on the ratio of mobile phone base station efficiency to the area of Taiwan, the island needs no more than 10,000 base stations. He urged the NCC to deal with this issue without delay so as to avoid public protests, particularly by people in residential and school areas.

Tsai said that residential neighborhoods and schools must not be exposed to the risk of radiation which might cause cancer, miscarriages, and diseases of the nervous system, and may even drive people to suicide, arguing that existing mobile phone base stations must be made to move out of such areas, as studies show that radiation levels at such facilities in Taipei and Tainan all surpass reasonable levels.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI SHARE PRICES END LOWER

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened high but closed lower Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 32.77 points to close at 7,136.21.
The bourse opened at 7,203.75 and fluctuated between 7,229.35 and 7,136.21 during trading. A total of 6.35 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$170.71 billion (US$5.34 billion).

Four of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with textile stocks moving up the most at 3.6 percent, followed by cement stocks at 2.9 percent, banking and financial shares at 2.8 percent and plastics and chemicals shares at 0.3 percent.

The other four major stock categories lost ground, with machinery and electronics shares moving down the most at 1.7 percent, followed by foodstuff issues and paper and pulp issues both at 1.6 percent and construction issues at 0.5 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 514 to 377, with 82 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHUNGHWA TELECOM WINS READER'S DIGEST PLATINUM SUPERBRAND AWARD

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Chunghwa Telecom has for the third consecutive year won a platinum superbrand award for the category of telecommunications company, according to the results of the Reader's Digest Asia SuperBrand 2006 Survey released Thursday.
Meanwhile, Taiwan Mobile has for the third consecutive year won a gold superbrand award for the category of mobile service provider.
Since 1999, Reader's Digest has conducted the annual survey on 42 product categories in six Asian markets, including Hong Kong, Malaysia, the Philippines, Singapore, Taiwan and Thailand.

In the surveys, consumers were asked to nominate their favorite brands and assess these brands for their quality, value, strength of brand image, trustworthiness and how well each brand understands consumers' needs.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAITRA IN CHARGE OF FARM PRODUCE EXPORTS TO CHINA: MAC

TEXT.P: The Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) is the liaison portal for Taiwanese farm produce exports to China, a policy the government will not change, a Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) spokesman said Thursday.

Fu Dong-cheng, director of the MAC's Department of Economic Affairs, made the statement in response to Li Shuilin, chairman of the China-based Association of Economy and Trade Across Taiwan Straits (AETATS), who recently said he would invite Taiwanese fruit, fishery and agricultural associations to Beijing in May to discuss technical issues surrounding Taiwanese farm produce exports.

Fu said the government's policy of delegating that line of business to TAITRA has not altered, adding that both governments can begin negotiating on the issue if China is really sincere about importing Taiwan fruit.
The government assigned TAITRA as the liaison office regarding Taiwan's farm produce exports to China in June last year.

Since China announced its duty-free policy on importing 15 kinds of Taiwanese fruit last August, the ROC government has been urging the Chinese authorities to discuss measures of implementing the policy, Fu said.

The Washington Post: Iranian Leader Warns U.S. Of Reprisal; Khamenei Is Defiant Ahead of U.N. Report.
PARIS, April 26 -- Escalating the threats between Washington and Tehran, Iran's supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, warned Wednesday that his country would strike U.S. targets around the world in the event it is attacked over its refusals to curb its nuclear program.

La Repubblica: Israel protests against burning Israeli flags in Italy's liberation day rally.
