DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT MULLS CHANGING LAW ON RIGHT TO REFUSE TESTIMONY

TEXT.P: The Judicial Yuan will investigate whether to amend a law to allow journalists the right to refuse to testify in court, a senior official said Thursday.
Fan Kuang-chun, secretary-general of the Judicial Yuan, made the remarks as the nation is embroiled in a controversy about a reporter's right to refuse to give court testimony.

Kao Nien-yi, a United Daily News reporter, has been fined three consecutive days by the Taiwan High Court for keeping mum on the question of his sources for a news story that was part of a court hearing on the "Stock Vultures" case.

Fan said the Yuan's Criminal Department will gather all relevant data before looking into the necessity of amending the law to exempt people in certain professions from the obligation to observe court requirements about disclosing information.
"But we'll be looking at the issue as a whole, not from the perspective of a specific case," he noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVER 20% OF FIFTH, SIX GRADERS HAVE THOUGHTS OF SUICIDE: POLL

TEXT.P: A member of the Taipei City Council called on the nation's parents and school authorities Thursday to pay heed to the emotional inner life of fifth and sixth graders after a survey showed 26.4 percent of children in that age group have had thoughts of taking their own life.

City Councilor Lee Yen-hsiu made the call after releasing the results of the survey, which was conducted Feb. 23-March 9 on fifth and sixth graders from 12 elementary schools -- representing 12 administrative districts of Taipei -- and their parents.
Some 1,137 effective samples were collected with a margin of error of plus or minus 3 percent.
According to the survey, 49.7 percent of students responded they had once felt "sick of their life" while 26.4 percent said they had thought of committing suicide.
Among that number, 70.8 percent said their greatest source of pressure was to get high scores in school, while 9.5 percent said their parents were the greatest burden in their mind.

Lee said the survey also found that most fifth and sixth graders try to let off steam by playing computer games or sports, airing their grievances with friends or seeking comfort through religion. However, 25.7 percent of the students said they usually take the pressure in silence, she noted, urging school authorities to pay closer attention to students' emotional difficulties.

Psychiatrist Lee Kuang-huei, who was also present at the news conference held by Lee and her colleague Chin Li-fang at the city council to publicize the survey, confirmed that most of today's elementary school students are under great pressure to perform academically and show signs of developing symptoms of melancholia.

However, children suffering from depression develop different symptoms than adults, Lee said, noting that kids more often carry out actions of self-harm. If their parents would be more careful to take the time to listen to their children for few minutes, a child's emotional disorder may be easily adjusted, Lee added.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONFERENCE ON TAICHUNG CITY'S PUBLIC SECURITY TO BE HELD FRIDAY

TEXT.P: The Taichung City Government will organize a conference Friday aimed at gathering experts' opinions on ways to improve public order and safety in the city, Taichung's Mayor Jason Hu said Thursday.
Hu said that Taichung's social order has long been criticized, and he hopes that experts in the field will provide advice on how to make the city a safer place.

Experts such as Professor Yang Shu-lung, director of National Chung Cheng University's Graduate Institute of Criminology and Professor Meng Wei-teh of Central Police University will attend the conference. Former Premier Hau Pei-tsun is also invited because one of his principal achievements in the early 1990s was to improve law and order.
Yeh Kun-fu, director-general of the Taichung City Police Department, said the purpose of the conference is to determine the real problems at issue so the city can improve its crime-fighting policies.
The police chief added that the Taichung City Government has significantly expanded its police force, but that he still receives negative feedback on the city's law and order.
He said the phenomenon may not be the sole responsibility of law enforcement, as it may also be influenced by other factors such as the local economy, family issues, education and foreign workers.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES LOWER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower Thursday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for May moved down 32 points to close at 7,176, with 45,862 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for June decreased 32 points to finish at 7,161, with 366 contracts traded, while September futures lost 11 points to end at 6,994, with 65 contract transactions. December futures decreased 40 points to close at 6,951, with 25 contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for March.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Thursday at 7,208 for May, 7,193 for June, 7,005 for September, 6,991 for December and 6,989 for March.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mostly higher.

May TE futures decreased 4.8 points to close at 312.4, with 7,173 contracts traded, while June TE futures lost five points to finish at 311.3, with 71 contract transactions. December TE futures moved down 5.35 points to end at 306.7, with five contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for September and March.

May TF futures increased 21 points to finish at 1,001, with 7,372 contracts changing hands, while June TF futures gained 25 points to close at 1,001, with 104 contracts traded. September TF futures moved up 17.2 points to end at 969.2, with 17 contract transactions, while March TF futures increased 46.8 points to end at 989.8, with two contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for December.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Thursday, decreasing NT$0.129 to close at NT$31.923.
A total of US$917 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at the day's high of NT$32.052 and hit a low of NT$31.910.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF ATTEMPT TO ASSIST INJURED TAIWANESE TOURISTS NIXED BY ARATS

TEXT.P: The Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) , Taiwan's quasi-official intermediary body tasked with cross-strait exchanges, has offered assistance to families of Taiwanese tourists who were recently injured in a car accident in Zhangzhou, China, but the SEF's request for a travel permit fell on deaf ears.

SEF Secretary-General You Ying-lung said Thursday that his office wrote the day before to the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) -- the SEF's counterpart in Beijing -- asking for permission for Huang Kuo-jui -- a SEF director in charge of travel affairs -- to accompany the Taiwanese tourists' families to Zhangzhou so he could facilitate medical treatment, rehabilitation and related affairs for the injured.
The SEF, however, did not hear from ARATS until Thursday at noon, when the Taiwanese families were departing Kinmen Island for Zhangzhou, You lamented.
Receiving no response from ARATS, Huang, who had traveled from Taipei to Kinmen to meet with the tourists' families, could only remain there Thursday.
Four members of the Taiwanese tourist group were reportedly critically injured while 20 others had sustained light injuries from the accident.

You said that despite ARATS' ignorance of the SEF's requirements, the SEF's determination to be of help remains unchanged, adding that Huang will remain in Kinmen to meet with the Taiwanese tourists' families until they return from China with the injured.

DOC.HEADLINE: REDISTRICTING PROPOSAL ON SCHEDULE: CEC SPOKESMAN

TEXT.P: The Central Election Commission (CEC) plans to forward its draft redistricting proposal for next year's legislative elections to the Legislative Yuan for passage before the end of May as scheduled, a CEC spokesman said Thursday.

Teng Tien-you made the remarks while commenting on news reports that said several lawmakers were preparing to submit a constitutional revision proposal to the Legislative Yuan in May to seek an increase in the number of legislative seats from 113 to 164, a change in the electoral system to multiple seats per constituency and the adoption of the parliamentary system.

A constitutional reform package passed in June 2005, which stipulated that starting from the seventh legislature -- to be elected in late 2007 -- the total number of seats will be halved from 225 to 113, and the electoral system for legislators will be changed into a "single-seat constituency, two votes" format -- that is, one vote for candidates, and the other for political parties.

Based on the reforms, the CEC worked out the redistricting proposal months ago, which states that among all the 25 counties and cities, 10 will have one seat each, while the constituencies of the others must be redistricted in proportion to population size.

A total of 73 seats will be elected from regional districts, while six seats are reserved for aboriginal representatives and 34 seats for at-large and overseas Taiwanese representatives. Legislators will serve four-year terms rather than the current three-year terms, according to the revised Constitution.
Teng said the CEC will not adjust the existing procedure in handling redistricting despite some lawmakers' new proposal.

DOC.HEADLINE: UNIVERSITIES WITH SPECIAL FUNDING SHOULDN'T HIKE TUITION FEES: MOE

TEXT.P: Universities that have received special funding from the Ministry of Education (MOE) should not hike their tuition fees, Education Minister Tu Cheng-sheng said Thursday.
Tu was referring to 23 universities which have received funding under a five-year, NT$50 billion-dollar higher education subsidy program and a teaching excellence subsidy program.
Tu noted that a panel under the MOE will review plans by local universities to hike tuition fees and will decide by the end of May whether to approve the proposals.
In considering the plans, the ministry should ensure the hikes are reasonable and that they take into account the financial ability of the underprivileged, Tu said.
Tu made the remarks during a meeting of the Legislative Yuan's Education and Culture Committee, where Tu was invited to brief lawmakers on the ministry's policy regarding university tuition.
According to the MOE's Department of Higher Education, the ministry approved only 10 out of 145 plans proposed by public universities to hike tuition fees last year.

Opposition People First Party Legislator Cheng Chin-ling argued that while private universities should enjoy some autonomy in adjusting tuition fees, public universities should not hike fees since they enjoy more government funding than private institutions.

DOC.HEADLINE: PUBLIC URGED TO PURCHASE DOH-CERTIFIED POWERED MILK FOR INFANTS

TEXT.P: The public were urged Thursday to only purchase infant formula and follow-on formula that carry certification labels issued by the Department of Health (DOH).

Wung Hsiu-chen, an official of the DOH's Bureau of Food Sanitation, made the call at a news conference held by legislators Lin Yun-sheng and Lin Shu-fen of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party at the Legislative Yuan.

The two lawmakers revealed that about 158 tons of dehydrated milk for babies were shipped into Taiwan from China during the 2004-2005 period. However, there was no information about where it was circulated, and the milk did not undergo any official quality testing.

Citing DOH data, they said there are currently 78 brands of infant formula, as well as 43 brands of follow-on formula, certified by the DOH, and that most of the products are imported from Europe, America and Oceania.

All the certified products are labeled before they are put on the market, the legislators said, noting that there is a loophole in the law that allows dishonest traders to market uncertified baby food as long as they label the products "baby food" or "powered milk for babies" without the word "formula."
Wung said the DOH has not granted certification to any brands of infant formula and follow-on formula from China.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATORS EXPRESS APPREHENSION ABOUT HIGH-SPEED RAILWAY SAFETY

TEXT.P: Legislators of both the ruling and opposition parties expressed apprehension Thursday that Taiwan's high-speed railway, scheduled to be launched by the end of October, may not be up to required safety standards.

At a meeting of the Legislative Yuan's Transportation Committee, legislators of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) told officials of the Ministry of Transportation and Communications that the scheduled opening of the high-speed railway in October should not be a decision based on political considerations.

The legislators indicated that their concern about the safety of the railway is based on their observations that the project's construction is seriously behind schedule, and that the Taiwan High-Speed Railway Corp. (THSRC) has run out of funds.
The THSRC has already delayed the scheduled launch of the high-speech train service twice -- from June 2003 to October 2005 and again to October this year.

Minister of Transportation and Communications Kuo Yao-chi gave her assurance at the legislature earlier this month that if the high-speed railway again fails to open as scheduled by the end of October, she will resign to take responsibility.

At the Transportation Committee meeting Thursday, KMT legislator Joanna Lei presented a document showing that inspections of Section C230 of the railway in Miaoli, southern Taiwan, found that the strength of the cement used for the project was not up to standards.
However, she added, instead of having the problem remedied for the sake of public safety, the THSRC was allowed to pay a fine.
DPP legislator Kuo Wen-chen reminded transportation officials that they should not allow political considerations to compromise the safety of the high-speed railway.
Kuo said he will be happy to see the railway to open as scheduled in October if its safety is not a concern.
"If delaying the opening of the railway service for another two months could make it safer, it will be all right with me," he said.
As of the end of March, the construction of the 345km railway linking Taipei and Kaohsiung -- Taiwan's two largest cities -- was about 95 percent complete.
When in operation, the train will run at 200 kph and could reduce the time for the journey between Taipei and Kaohsiung to 90 minutes.

The DPP government has been under fire for providing NT$308.3 billion (US$9.5 billion) in government loans to the THSRC without oversight, against the NT$130 billion capital invested by the company's five shareholders.

DOC.HEADLINE: TIME FOR TAIWANESE BUSINESSES TO INVEST IN INDIA: FORUM

TEXT.P: It is time for Taiwanese businesses to invest in India and learn more about the country, experts and officials said Thursday in a wide-ranging forum that discussed Taiwan-India trade exchanges.

"If you don't invest now, somebody else will, " said Gopal Srinivasan, Director of TVS Electronics Ltd., in the two-day forum titled "Seize the India Trend: International Forum on Taiwan-India Commercial Exchanges."

Taiwanese businesses can duplicate their success in the 1990s in China in India, which is regarded as the next "world factory" after China and one of the fastest-emerging economies in the world, said Vijay Gokhale, Director-General of India-Taipei Association, India's de facto embassy in Taiwan.

Gokhale said Taiwan's "Go South Policy" and India's "Look East Policy" are a perfect match as Taiwan looks to shake off its economic dependency on China while India is trying to bring in foreign investment.

It makes no sense that Taiwan's trade with India is less than 1 percent of its total trade, while its trade with China, the United States, Japan and the European Union -- the other four of the world's five largest economies -- all exceeded 10 percent, said Yu Shyi-kun, chairman of the Taiwan-India Cooperation Council (TICC).

"The reason for Taiwan to increase investment in India is not just for its cheap labor. It's for the excellent brains of the Indian work force, " said Ko Chen-en, president of Chung-hua Institution for Economic Research.

And it is better to invest in India sooner than later, since Japanese and Korean corporations such as Suzuki, Samsung, Hyundai Motors and LG Electronics have all made their moves and have enjoyed relative success, Srinivasan noted.
Stan Shih, founder of the Acer Group said in a keynote speech that "Taiwan is developing its knowledge economy and business innovation, both of which need a large-scale market to be successful."

TICC, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and the Taiwan ThinkTank organized the forum, which is being attended by more than 200 government officials, business representatives and scholars from India and Taiwan.
A total of 10 speeches covering areas such as auto components, textiles, medical services and electronics will be held Friday, following seven topical lectures delivered on the first day.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN OPENS SMALL TFT-LCD, LOW-END CHIP TECH INVESTMENT IN CHINA

TEXT.P: Taiwan announced Thursday that local businessmen can now invest in small-sized flat panel production and low-end semiconductor packaging and testing technology in China.

Joseph Wu, chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) -- Taiwan's top China policy planner -- announced that the government has decided to remove restrictions on investment in thin film transistor-liquid crystal displays (TFT-LCDs) of four inches and less in China and the export of low-end chip packing and testing technology to China under certain conditions.

Wu said the opening, which goes into effect immediately, was decided after the MAC completed lengthy discussions with relevant government agencies, including the Executive Yuan and the National Security Council, as well as the ruling Democratic Progressive Party.

Minister of Economic Affairs Hwang Ing-san made a similar announcement later in the day, saying that from Thursday, investment in such TFT-LCD production in China and exports of wire bond chip packaging and ELE testing technology to China will be removed from the government's "restricted" list.

Interested Taiwan companies can file their applications with the Ministry of Economic Affairs as long as they have operated identical businesses in Taiwan, can fully control their future investment in China and have a global marketing strategy, Hwang said.

He added that although these two categories of investment were removed from Taiwan government's restricted list, such investment is still considered "major" and "influential." Thus, he said, the investment plans filed by Taiwan companies to the Ministry of Economic Affairs will still have to be assessed and reviewed individually by a supra-ministerial screening ad hoc group.

DOC.HEADLINE: WORLD'S FIRST MANDARIN AUDIO WEB SITE INAUGURATED IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: A digital audio Web site using Mandarin was inaugurated Thursday in Taipei and its operators claim it to be the first of its kind in the world.

The Web site, www.audiopie.com, was created and maintained by National Chiao Tung University (NCTU) in Hsinchu which cooperates with several local publishing, broadcasting and technical companies to offer audio versions of books and magazines online.
Visitors can download audio products -- either for permanent use by paying a fee, or for temporary use by paying a monthly rental charge.
The Web site's operators said at least 30 audio books covering various fields will be made available online every month. All copyrights have been properly authorized.

The Web site is the brainchild of the NCTU Digital Creation Industry Development Center which was funded in 2003 with NT$100 million (US$3.13 million) donated by Stan Shih, founder of the PC giant Acer Group, with the purpose of promoting digital products in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER PLEDGES PRAGMATISM IN HANDLING CROSS-STRAIT AFFAIRS

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang said at a gathering with business leaders Thursday that the government will pragmatically handle the relationship between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

Proclaiming his confidence in Taiwan, Su said as long as the Taiwanese identity and policy initiatives are well-managed, good results will come of the government's trade and economic policies toward China.
The premier made the remarks while hosting a breakfast meeting with business leaders at the Executive Yuan, his first such meeting since becoming premier in March.

On the government's response to the 15-point consensus reached at the recent Kuomintang-Communist Party of China economic forum in Beijing, Su said that some of the proposed measures have already been implemented while others are under negotiation, adding "we've already received some positive response from the stock markets."

Theodore Huang, chairman of the Chinese National Association of Industry and Commerce, urged the government to take more constructive steps to upgrade from the "mini three links" to the "middle three links," and then to direct cross-strait transportation links.
Huang also urged the government to lift its ban on Taiwanese businesses investing more than 40 percent of their capital in China.

Hu Sheng-cheng, chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) under the Executive Yuan, responded by saying that direct transportation problems cannot be resolved unilaterally; Joseph Wu, chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council, said that the differences over charter flights have narrowed although it may take a little longer to settle them.
Business leaders hope to discuss more mid- to long- term development strategies during the Economic Sustainable Development Conference slated for June, Huang said.
Huang said if the domestic market could be more open and liberalized so that foreign investment would flood into Taiwan, Taiwan investors would not have to set up shop abroad.
"Developing Taiwan's economy, cracking down on crime, taking good care of minorities and the disadvantaged and leading a clean and competent government are my administrative priorities," Su said.

Other participants included Chen Wu-hsiung, chairman of the Chinese National Federation of Industries (CNFI); Wang Ling-in, chairman of the General Chamber of Commerce; Hsu Sheng-hsiung, chairman of the Taiwan Electrical and Electronic Manufacturers' Association; Day Sheng-tong, president of the National Association of Small and Medium-Size Enterprises; Morris Chang, chairman of Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Corp.; Douglas Hsu, chairman of Far Eastern Group; and Cheng Shen-chih, chairman of the Taiwan Financial Services Roundtable (TFSR).

DOC.HEADLINE: OUTGOING AIT DEPUTY CHIEF DECORATED

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian decorated the outgoing deputy head of the U.S. representative office in Taipei Thursday in recognition of his contribution to the promotion of relations between Taiwan and the United States.

Chen conferred the Order of Brilliant Star with Violet Grand Cordon on David J. Keegan, deputy director of the Taipei Office of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) , at a ceremony held at the Presidential Office.
Addressing the ceremony, Keegan said he was honored to receive the decoration.

Despite the substantial changes in Taiwan's social and political situation since his first visit to Taiwan 30 years ago, Keegan said, the Taiwan people's can-do spirit and vitality have remained unchanged.
Over the past three decades, Keegan recalled, he has come to Taiwan on numerous occasions and has witnessed the blooming of the country's opposition and its transformation into a liberal democracy.

During his stint as deputy director of the AIT Taipei Office from September 2003, Keegan said he has observed three nationwide elections, including the ferociously contested 2004 presidential election. Each of them, he said, manifested Taiwan's democratic gusto and dynamism.
Touching on bilateral relations, Keegan said he is convinced that the longstanding friendship between Taiwan and the United States will remain cordial.
AIT Taipei Office Director Stephen Young, Presidential Office Deputy Secretary-General Ma Yung-cheng and Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs Huang Lung-yuan were present at the ceremony.

DOC.HEADLINE: BBC ANCHOR STRESSES MEDIA'S `GATEKEEPING' RESPONSIBILITY

TEXT.P: The media should accommodate itself to modern technology and "citizen journalism, " while still being accountable to its "gatekeeping" responsibility, British Broadcasting Corporation (BBC) anchor Nik Gowing said in Taipei Thursday.

Because of modern technology such as mobile phones, handycams and the Internet, there is much more first-hand information coming to the media directly from citizens. The media needs to move with this trend but should still check and validate sources, said Gowing.

Gowing, who was invited by the British Chamber of Commerce in Taipei to deliver a speech at its monthly luncheon, has been the main anchor on BBC World, the BBC's 24-hour international TV news and information channel, since 1996.

In covering the South Asia tsunami, Hurricane Katrina's damage in the United States and the London Underground bombing, the media resorted to citizens to provide first-hand information and observations, he said, adding that following the bombings in London, the BBC received more than 1,000 images, 20 video clips, 3,000 text messages and 20,000 emails from London citizens relating to the event.
Nowadays, he said, citizens often provide more information following major news events than the media, which in turn provides more information than government agencies most of the time.

"The job of people like me or other BBC staff is to check and validate, " Gowing said. "The media needs to produce real-time reports and react quickly, but we'd rather wait a little bit longer before reporting as the validation is going on," he said.

News reporting today has "higher impact and shorter time frame" because of the information explosion and development of technology, which makes it even more important for the media to provide correct reporting, Gowing said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN READY TO HOST CHINESE TOURISTS: MAC

TEXT.P: Taiwan is ready to play host to Chinese tourists and can implement this policy at any moment, so long as cross-Taiwan Strait negotiations on the issue are completed, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Joseph Wu said Thursday.

Responding to media reports that China plans to allow its people to make sightseeing trips to Taiwan from July 1 this year, Wu said that although the Chinese authorities have on many occasions promised that they will talk with Taiwan on many issues, they had often reneged on their promises in the past.
Wu said he is not sure whether the latest report about China's plans to allow its citizens to make tourism trips to Taiwan from July can be materialized.

Nevertheless, he went on, he welcomes the notion of allowing the Chinese public to make tourism trips to Taiwan, since China remains a tightly controlled and censored society and the only way to allow the Chinese people to gain first-hand understanding of Taiwan is to have them visit Taiwan in person.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTEGRITY IS DPP'S PRIMARY CONCERN: DPP CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: Integrity is the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) primary concern and a key topic to be discussed at an upcoming DPP conference in May, DPP Chairman Yu Shyi-kun said Thursday.
Speaking on the sidelines of a forum on Taiwan-India exchanges, Yu said he hopes to help create a "charter based on integrity and self-discipline" for DPP members to abide by.

Yu's statement echoed Vice President Annette Lu's appeal Wednesday that the party should establish a written pledge of self-discipline -- a pact for its members -- and also that the party should make a response within 24 hours to any doubts raised by the opposition party or media about the integrity of DPP politicians.
The vice president's appeal will be brought up for discussion at a DPP conference on party reform May 7.
At the upcoming conference, Yu said that Vice President Lu will preside over the discussion of issues such as determining the DPP's core values and its image.

DOC.HEADLINE: LOOMING ENERGY CRISIS CHALLENGES DPP'S NUCLEAR-FREE POLICY: VP

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu said Thursday that progress in nuclear technology and a looming global energy crisis have posed new challenges to the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) nuclear-free homeland policy.
Lu made the remarks on the sidelines of a seminar on convincing Taiwan investors to invest in an industrial park development project in El Salvador.

The vice president was responding to a newspaper report that she told a DPP Central Standing Committee meeting Wednesday that the ruling party should review its anti-nuclear policy now that proponents claim that nuclear power has turned into "green energy."
Asked whether she supported the development of nuclear power, Lu clarified that she just wanted to raise the question for specialists to delve into the issue.

Faced with an emerging energy crisis, Lu suggested that the DPP catch up with global trends and face new threats in each different phase, even though building a nuclear-free homeland has always been one of the party's core advocacies.

Lu opined that the party should invite experts to explore the possibility of using nuclear power as a form of clean energy on grounds that technology in handling nuclear fuel waste has advanced and that the Kyoto protocol has limited the use of traditional energy resources.
But Lu made it clear that she was not making any comments on the fate of the fourth nuclear power plant under construction in Kungliao township, Taipei County.

Acknowledging that a possible energy shortage in the future has indeed posed a great challenge for the DPP, she stressed that "we will have to face up to the problem sooner or later" and that "we need to get more experts to study the issue across the board."

According to the vice president, both the DPP and the previous ruling Kuomintang have to jointly share responsibility regarding the fourth nuclear power plant, because it is an issue that goes beyond party affiliation.
"It's a problem lying ahead for all of us, and we must cooperate to find ways to resolve such a thorny issue," Lu said.

Meanwhile, Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) Chairman Hu Sheng-cheng said after a breakfast gathering called by Premier Su Tseng-chang with business community representatives that the fourth nuclear power plant is still being built and that an additional budget is expected to be approved soon by the Executive Yuan to carry out the construction project.

Hu promised that the government would pay the maximum attention to the fourth nuclear plant's safety following the completion of its construction, and gave his assurances that the plant would be allowed to operate only as long as its safety is fully guaranteed.

President Chen Shui-bian once ordered a halt to construction on the fourth nuclear power plant in October 2000 after coming to power in May that year. Although the plant's construction was restarted in 2001, the interruption caused an estimated NT$70 billion (US$2.2 billion) in business losses.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT FIRMLY OPPOSED TO AMENDING CONSTITUTION AGAIN

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang (KMT) reiterated Thursday that the party is firmly opposed to any proposal to amend the Constitution for an eighth time in order to increase the number of seats in the legislature to 164.

KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou, who also serves as Taipei mayor, pointed out that the Constitution was amended last year to halve the number of legislative seats to 113 from 225, beginning from the next legislature to be elected at the end of 2007.

"The KMT's position is crystal clear: We oppose any move to amend the Constitution again, " Ma said, adding that there is no justification for increasing the number of seats in the Legislative Yuan at this stage.
He said the KMT will be despised by voters if it agrees to such a move.

At a meeting of the KMT legislative caucus, KMT Secretary-General Chan Chun-po said most people in Taiwan are not interested in another constitutional amendment, but want the KMT to concentrate on issues that are most related to their livelihoods.
Chan said KMT legislators who do not follow the party line will be disciplined.

In a heated debate with Chan, maverick KMT Legislator Hsu Shu-po, who plans to introduce his version of the amendment in May, said he is not afraid of Chan's threat of disciplinary action. He urged party leaders not to interfere in the legislature's internal debate on the issue.

Although Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng claimed he will remain neutral on the issue, he said the issue is an "internal matter" of the Legislative Yuan and that he believes the proposal could be discussed.

Also commenting on the issue, Hsieh Kung-pin, spokesman for the People First Party (PFP), the second-largest opposition party in the legislature, said the PFP is also against amending the Constitution again and believes that some members of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party intend to use the move to push Taiwan toward de jure independence.

News reports Thursday said lawmakers from across the political spectrum have been quietly forming a "united front" in an attempt to change a provision in the Constitution to increase the number of seats in the legislature from 113 to 164 and replace the current presidential system of government with the Cabinet system, because many of them fear their chances of getting re-elected in 2007 will be lessened under the new "single constituency, two votes" system.

DOC.HEADLINE: PARTY'S GOAL OF NUKE-FREE HOMELAND UNSHAKEN: DPP HEAD

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) remains firm in its objective of building Taiwan into a land free of nuclear power, DPP Chairman Yu Shyi-kun said Thursday.
Yu made the remarks while fielding reporters' questions after taking part in a Taiwan-India business exchange seminar.

Although Yu said the DPP will continue striving toward that goal, he pointed out, however, that an individual case like the fourth nuclear power plant requires further study. He added that the Executive Yuan has the final say on the fate of the plant, which is still under construction.

The DPP chairman's remarks came after Vice President Annette Lu was quoted as having told a recent DPP Central Standing Committee meeting that the DPP should review its rigid anti-nuclear stance in the face of a simmering global energy crisis.

Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh also said recently in a national development conference that the government should continue carrying out the fourth nuclear power plant construction project as a short-term strategy to meet the country's demand for power.

Echoing Yu's view, DPP legislative caucus whip Chen Chin-jun said at a Legislative Yuan news conference that while the party seeks a nuclear-free Taiwan, the safety of the fourth nuclear power plant is still at issue and a primary concern of the DPP.

DPP lawmaker Yeh Yi-jin said although the Kyoto Protocol has been put in place to cut greenhouse gas emissions, she said this does not necessarily mean that the DPP will back off its nuclear-free homeland policy..

The DPP has never deviated from its anti-nuclear power stance and it will continue to keep a close watch on Taiwan's nuclear power plant operations, including the fourth plant, Yeh said, adding that the DPP's surveillance has nothing to do with implementing the Kyoto Protocol.

It would be putting the cart before the horse if the DPP turns to opt for even more damaging nuclear power due to the implementation of the Kyoto protocol, which aims at cutting greenhouse gas emissions across the world, she said.

Arguing that no one in the world would believe nuclear power is "green energy," DPP lawmaker Chao Yun-ching said it was "unthinkable" that construction on the fourth nuclear power plant was restarted and that the project needs additional funding to continue.

He asked the government to probe into possible corruption scandals behind the fourth nuclear power plant, insisting that the DPP, as an accountable party, should do so in response to public expectations.
The DPP government ordered a halt to the construction of the fourth nuclear power plant in Kungliao township, Taipei County in late 2000 after President Chen Shui-bian came to power in May that year.
Although construction resumed in 2001, the delay in the project caused estimated losses of NT$70 billion (US$2.2 billion) to the nation's coffers.

Meanwhile, a Taiwan Power Co. spokesman said the first phase of the fourth nuclear power plant's commercial operations is slated for July 2009. Commercial operations for its second phase are set for July 2010 prior to its scheduled completion in 2112, the spokesman added.

DOC.HEADLINE: IMAGES OF TAIWAN SOUGHT FOR NATIONAL GEOGRAPHIC PHOTO CONTEST

TEXT.P: Three images of Taiwan will be chosen to become part of a National Geographic magazine photography contest, a spokesman for the event said Thursday.

The spokesman said that photographers interested in entering the contest should submit their photographs between May 1 and June 30. Three images featuring Taiwan will be selected in July to become part of the magazine's worldwide competition.

Speaking at the event's opening ceremony, Government Information Office (GIO) Minister Cheng Wen-tsang said photography reflects the profundity of a country's culture and expressed hope that photographers will use their creativity to enrich Taiwan.
The top three winners will win prizes including NT$30,000 cash, souvenirs and trophies.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT PLANS TWO OVERSEAS TRIPS IN SECOND HALF OF YEAR

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian plans to make two overseas trips in the second half of this year, Presidential Office sources said Thursday.
Chen plans to attend a summit meeting of the African Union to be held in the Gambia in July and a forum of Taiwan and its South Pacific diplomatic allies scheduled for September, the sources said.
As to Chen's upcoming Latin America diplomatic tour, the sources said the Presidential Office will hold a news conference Monday to announce the itinerary and U.S. transit destinations.

According to the sources, the government is still discussing with U.S. authorities the possible transit cities. New York is a priority choice, the sources said, adding that Hawaii is not on the "dream" list.
Chen is scheduled to depart Taipei May 3 for Paraguay. He will later visit Costa Rica for the inauguration of President-elect Oscar Arias before returning to Taipei May 11.

Taiwan hopes that Chen will be able to make a stopover on the west coast or southern part of the United States on his way to Latin America and make a stopover in New York or on the U.S. west coast on his way back to Taiwan, according to a report from Washington, D.C.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT VOWS TO WARD OFF AVIAN FLU

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Thursday his administration will do its utmost to maintain Taiwan's status as an area free of avian influenza.
Chen made the pledge while meeting with visiting Burkina Faso Prime Minister Paramanga Ernest Yonli.
Taiwan recently sent a medical team to help with Burkina Faso's fight against avian flu after an outbreak in poultry was reported in the African state.
Chen said Taiwan will never hestitate to help other countries, inclduing its diplomatic allies, in epidemic control and prevention.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, April 28, or the first day of the fourth month of the Year of the Dog according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1442: King Edward IV, the Yorkist leader during the War of the Roses, is born. He was crowned king of England after defeating the Lancastrians at Mortimer's Cross and Towton in 1461.
1545: Yi Sun-shin, Korean admiral and national hero, is born.
1758: James Monroe, the fifth president of the United States, is born. His administration is noted for the acquisition of Florida in 1819, and for the proclaiming of the Monroe Doctrine in 1823, which declared that no foreign power would be allowed to colonize any part of the Americas.
1789: On a return trip from Tahiti in the South Pacific, mutinous crew members of the British transport ship Bounty set Captain William Bligh and 18 sailors adrift in an open boat. Bligh and his royal crew manage to reach Timor Island near Java on June 14 after sailing 3,500 miles.
1788: Maryland becomes the seventh state of the United States.
1876: Queen Victoria of Britain is declared Empress of India.
1902: The U.S. Senate passes an anti-Chinese bill.
1922: War between Wu Pei-fu of the Chihli faction and Chang Tso-lin of the Fengtien faction breaks out.
1922: Dr. Sun Yat-sen issues a manifesto urging the reunification of China by peaceful means.
1937: Saddam Hussein, president of Iraq since 1979, is born.
1945: Italian dictator Benito Mussolini is shot by his countrymen, who then string up his body head down.
1952: At his own request, Dwight D. Eisenhower is relieved of duty as Supreme Allied Commander in Europe. He is succeeded by Gen. Matthew Ridgway.
1952: The Treaty of Peace between the Republic of China and Japan is signed in Taipei by Foreign Minister George K.C. Yeh and Japan's special envoy, Isao Kawata.
1962: The Taiwan Television Enterprise, Ltd. is established in Taipei.
1963: Yang Chuan-kuang, the ROC's decathlon champion who won the first Olympic silver medal for his country on Sept. 6, 1960, sets a new world record in the sport in the United States with 9,121 points.
1963: Taiwan holds elections for the third Provincial Assembly.
1969: President Charles De Gaulle of France resigns and is succeeded by Georges Pompidou.
1975: Premier Chiang Ching-kuo is elected chairman of the Central Committee of the ruling Kuomintang.
1976: Delegates headed by Dr. Ku Cheng-kang, honorary president of the World Anti-Communist League, leave Taipei for Seoul and the Ninth General Assembly of the WACL.
1980: U.S. Secretary of State Cyrus Vance resigns.
1988: A Republic of China delegation attends the annual convention of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) in Manila.
1992: The Afghan government cedes power to Islamic guerrillas in Kabul, ending 14 years of armed resistance and civil war.
1992: Yang Chi-chang, a police officer, is killed in an explosion while trying to defuse a bomb placed by blackmailers near the McDonald's fast food branch on Minsheng East Road in Taipei.
1996: The Ministry of Economic Affairs announces that starting July 1, 1996, imports of another 1,609 categories of industrial commodities will be allowed into Taiwan from mainland China, marking the ROC government's largest ever relaxation of restrictions on mainland imports.
1998: David Hempleman-Adams, British explorer, reaches the geographic North Pole, becoming the first person to reach the Earth's northern magnetic and geographic poles.
2000: The Legislative Yuan passes an amendment to the Passport Law which extends the term of validity of Republic of China passports from the present six years to 10 years.
2001: Republic of China government spokesman Su Cheng-ping leaves for New York for a one-week speech tour of the United States.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A workman who wants to perfect his work first sharpens his tools. When you are living in a country, you should serve those nobles and ministers in that country who are men of moral worth, and you should cultivate the friendship of the gentlemen of that country who are men of moral worth."

DOC.HEADLINE: PARTY'S GOAL OF NUKE-FREE HOMELAND UNSHAKEN: DPP HEAD(repeat)

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) remains firm in its objective of building Taiwan into a land free of nuclear power, DPP Chairman Yu Shyi-kun said Thursday.
Yu made the remarks while fielding reporters' questions after taking part in a Taiwan-India business exchange seminar.

Although Yu said the DPP will continue striving toward that goal, he pointed out, however, that an individual case like the fourth nuclear power plant requires further study. He added that the Executive Yuan has the final say on the fate of the plant, which is still under construction.

The DPP chairman's remarks came after Vice President Annette Lu was quoted as having told a recent DPP Central Standing Committee meeting that the DPP should review its rigid anti-nuclear stance in the face of a simmering global energy crisis.

Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh also said recently in a national development conference that the government should continue carrying out the fourth nuclear power plant construction project as a short-term strategy to meet the country's demand for power.

Echoing Yu's view, DPP legislative caucus whip Chen Chin-jun said at a Legislative Yuan news conference that while the party seeks a nuclear-free Taiwan, the safety of the fourth nuclear power plant is still at issue and a primary concern of the DPP.

DPP lawmaker Yeh Yi-jin said although the Kyoto Protocol has been put in place to cut greenhouse gas emissions, she said this does not necessarily mean that the DPP will back off its nuclear-free homeland policy..

The DPP has never deviated from its anti-nuclear power stance and it will continue to keep a close watch on Taiwan's nuclear power plant operations, including the fourth plant, Yeh said, adding that the DPP's surveillance has nothing to do with implementing the Kyoto Protocol.

It would be putting the cart before the horse if the DPP turns to opt for even more damaging nuclear power due to the implementation of the Kyoto protocol, which aims at cutting greenhouse gas emissions across the world, she said.

Arguing that no one in the world would believe nuclear power is "green energy," DPP lawmaker Chao Yun-ching said it was "unthinkable" that construction on the fourth nuclear power plant was restarted and that the project needs additional funding to continue.

He asked the government to probe into possible corruption scandals behind the fourth nuclear power plant, insisting that the DPP, as an accountable party, should do so in response to public expectations.
The DPP government ordered a halt to the construction of the fourth nuclear power plant in Kungliao township, Taipei County in late 2000 after President Chen Shui-bian came to power in May that year.
Although construction resumed in 2001, the delay in the project caused estimated losses of NT$70 billion (US$2.2 billion) to the nation's coffers.

Meanwhile, a Taiwan Power Co. spokesman said the first phase of the fourth nuclear power plant's commercial operations is slated for July 2009. Commercial operations for its second phase are set for July 2010 prior to its scheduled completion in 2112, the spokesman added.

DOC.HEADLINE: IMAGES OF TAIWAN SOUGHT FOR NATIONAL GEOGRAPHIC PHOTO CONTEST

TEXT.P: (repeat)
Taipei, April 27 (CNA) Three images of Taiwan will be chosen to become part of a National Geographic magazine photography contest, a spokesman for the event said Thursday.

The spokesman said that photographers interested in entering the contest should submit their photographs between May 1 and June 30. Three images featuring Taiwan will be selected in July to become part of the magazine's worldwide competition.

Speaking at the event's opening ceremony, Government Information Office (GIO) Minister Cheng Wen-tsang said photography reflects the profundity of a country's culture and expressed hope that photographers will use their creativity to enrich Taiwan.
The top three winners will win prizes including NT$30,000 cash, souvenirs and trophies.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT PLANS TWO OVERSEAS TRIPS IN SECOND HALF OF YEAR(repeat)

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian plans to make two overseas trips in the second half of this year, Presidential Office sources said Thursday.
Chen plans to attend a summit meeting of the African Union to be held in the Gambia in July and a forum of Taiwan and its South Pacific diplomatic allies scheduled for September, the sources said.
As to Chen's upcoming Latin America diplomatic tour, the sources said the Presidential Office will hold a news conference Monday to announce the itinerary and U.S. transit destinations.

According to the sources, the government is still discussing with U.S. authorities the possible transit cities. New York is a priority choice, the sources said, adding that Hawaii is not on the "dream" list.
Chen is scheduled to depart Taipei May 3 for Paraguay. He will later visit Costa Rica for the inauguration of President-elect Oscar Arias before returning to Taipei May 11.

Taiwan hopes that Chen will be able to make a stopover on the west coast or southern part of the United States on his way to Latin America and make a stopover in New York or on the U.S. west coast on his way back to Taiwan, according to a report from Washington, D.C.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. EXPECTED TO REPLY TO PRESIDENT CHEN'S STOPOVER REQUEST SOON: MOFA
DOC.DATELINE: Abu Dhabi, April 28 (CNA) (By Lee Chia-fei and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Taipei and Washington should be able to reach an agreement soon on Taiwan's request that President Chen Shui-bian be allowed to make transit stops in the United States next week, Minister of Foreign Affairs Huang Chih-fang said Friday.

Huang said that Taiwan officially put forth the request on April 24 and that he believes the U.S. government should be able to understand the time pressure faced by Taiwan and will facilitate the request.
Huang made the remarks during an informal gathering with a group of Taiwan reporters during a visit to Abu Dhabi, United Arab Emirates.
President Chen is set to depart Taipei May 3 for Paraguay. He will later visit Costa Rica for the inauguration of President-elect Oscar Arias before returning to Taipei May 11.

Taiwan hopes that Chen will be able to make a stopover on the west coast or southern part of the United States on his way to Latin America and make a stopover in New York or on the U.S. west coast on his way back to Taiwan, according to diplomatic sources.

However, there have been media reports citing Raymond F. Burghardt, chairman of the American Institute in Taiwan, as saying that he is surprised that New York is on Taiwan's stopover wish list because it is not a convenient stop compared with other possible options such as Miami.

Huang would not comment on the reports, stressing that Taiwan maintains smooth communication with the United States and that both sides are still discussing details regarding Chen's stopover arrangements.
Huang noted that the U.S. government has established a set of administrative procedures in handling matters concerning Taiwan's requests for its leaders to make transit stops in the United States.
The Ministry of Foreign Affairs has explained to Washington that President Chen's plan to make stopovers in the United States is simple and involves no political motives, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN DEPUTY ENVOY TO WTO EXPECTED TO BE APPOINTED DEPUTY REP IN U.S.
DOC.DATELINE: Abu Dhabi, UAE, April 28 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's deputy representative to the World Trade Organization (WTO) headquarters, John C.C. Deng, will reportedly be appointed as the country's deputy representative to the United States, Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) officials said Friday.
Deng is expected to succeed Jaw-ling Joanne Chang, who resigned recently as Taiwan's second top representative to the United States, MOFA officials said.

MOFA officials speculated that Deng's appointment is aimed at enlisting his expertise in international business and trade affairs so as to facilitate the signing of a free trade agreement (FTA) between Taiwan and the United States.

Deng had been director of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Representative Office in Washington, D.C., the de facto Taiwan embassy in the U.S., and vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council before being appointed Taiwan's deputy representative to the WTO.
The vacancy to be left by Deng is expected to be filled by a Ministry of Economic Affairs official, MOFA officials said.

Since Minister of Foreign Affairs Huang Chih-fang assumed his post in January, he has been promoting an aggressive diplomatic strategy in a bid to score the greatest possible achievement on Taiwan's diplomatic fronts in the face of Beijing's heightening containment efforts against Taiwan, according to the MOFA officials.

Huang was instrumental in arranging for a partial personnel reshuffle in the MOFA's representative offices abroad recently, including MOFA Chief Secretary Chen Yung-chuo's replacement of Lee Tsai-fang, Taiwan's representative in South Korea; ROC Representative to the Netherlands Chang Siao-yue's promotion to vice minister of foreign affairs; and Vice Foreign Minister Michael Y. M. Kau's appointment as Taiwan's representative to the European Union.

Other changes in high-ranking posts at the MOFA's offices abroad will include those in the Netherlands, Malaysia, Israel and Finland, mostly due to retirement of representatives to these countries, according to MOFA officials.

New York Times: G.O.P. Senators Hurry to Quell Furor Over Gas
Senate Republicans tried on Thursday to get the upper hand in the escalating political battle over high gasoline prices by proposing a US$100 rebate for taxpayers and by suggesting that they might increase taxes on oil-industry profits. The Republican plan includes a provision that could levy a significant tax on oil company profits, a provision that President Bush promised to veto when a version appeared in a Senate bill last year. The proposal came on a day when Exxon Mobil reported a 7 percent gain in its first-quarter earnings.
Wall Street Journal: Intel Promises Sweeping Overhaul Amid PC Slowdown, Rival's Gains
Intel Corp., facing surprisingly stiff competition from its main rival and slowing computer sales, said it plans a sweeping restructuring of its operations after a 90-day internal review. The move suggested Intel management is taking seriously a humbling reversal of fortunes in recent months. Despite Intel's longstanding dominance in computer chips, its main rival, Advanced Micro Devices Inc., has made steady gains lately with technology improvements and aggressive marketing, while the market for personal computers has quickly cooled after one of Intel's best years ever.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT TO MOVE TO HAVE LAW AMENDED TO PROTECT RIGHT TO REFUSE TESTIMONY

TEXT.P: Members of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) legislative caucus said Friday they will move to have a law amended so as to allow journalists the right to refuse to testify in court.

Legislator Kao Si-po, the author of the amendment proposal, said the KMT caucus will move to have Article 182 of the Code of Criminal Procedure amended to ensure journalists' rights by "patching up any holes in the law."
The KMT caucus is so planning as the country is embroiled in a controversy about a reporter's right to refuse to give court testimony.

Kao Nien-yi, a United Daily News reporter, has been fined three consecutive days, NT$30,000 (US$937.5) each day, by the Taiwan High Court for refusing to reveal his sources for a news story that was part of a court hearing in the "Stock Vultures" case.

Fan Kuang-chun, secretary-general of the Judicial Yuan, said the previous day that the Yuan's Criminal Department will gather all relevant information before looking into whether the law should be amended to exempt people in certain professions from the requirements concerning disclosing information.
"But we'll be looking at the issue as a whole, not from the perspective of a specific case," Fan noted.

Article 182 of the Code of Criminal Procedure stipulates that a witness who is or has been a medical doctor, pharmacist, obstetrician, minister, lawyer, advocate, notary public, or accountant, or one who has been an assistant of such persons and who because of his occupation has learned secret matters relating to another may refuse to testify when he is questioned unless permission is obtained from the other person.
Journalism professionals are not included in the article.

DOC.HEADLINE: FIRST LADY TO SELL STOCKS AND GIVE MONEY TO CHARITIES

TEXT.P: First lady Wu Shu-chen will ask trust fund management companies to sell all the stocks she holds and then donate the profits to charity organizations and disadvantaged groups, officials from the Presidential Office department of public affairs said Friday.

Wu is making the move "based on her self-discipline in following the highest standard of morality, " the officials said, noting that after the sale is completed, the first lady will publicize the details.
According to the latest Control Yuan report disclosing the assets of public officials, Wu owns stocks with a total value of NT$48.32 million, all of which have been put into trust.

Stocks held by Wu include Fubon REITs No.1, Taiwan Cement, Nan Ya Plastics, United Microelectronics, Accton Technology, Nanya Technology, MediaTek, International Bank of Taipei, Hua Nan Financial Holdings, Mega Holdings and Faraday Technology.
Wu has recently been faced with allegations of wrongdoing, including receiving gift vouchers worth millions of New Taiwan dollars from an upscale department store.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT REJECTS 'ONE CHINA' PRINCIPLE

TEXT.P: Taiwan must not accept Beijing's "one China" principle because this will turn Taiwan into a part of the People's Republic of China, President Chen Shui-bian said in a recent interview with the Japanese daily Sankei Shimbun.

According to the transcript of the interview released Friday by the Presidential Office, Chen told the Japanese newspaper that he is welcome to visit Beijing and shake hands with Chinese President Hu Jintao as soon as he accepts Beijing's "one China" principle.
However, Chen said, he has not done so because he "represents the government of Taiwan and the collective interests of the 23 million people of Taiwan and must not sell out Taiwan for personal fame."
Chen stressed that as the popularly elected leader of the country, he must safeguard Taiwan's sovereignty, dignity and security.

"If I accept the 'one China' principle, it will mean that Taiwan is part of the People's Republic of China and Taiwan will become a local province and special administrative region of the People's Republic of China," Chen said.
"If I were to allow a democratic Taiwan to be annexed by a totalitarian China, I would go down in history as a sinner," he said.

Just like the United States which has been promoting the universal values of democracy and freedom and is expecting China to embrace democracy and freedom, Taiwan also hopes that the country's experience in democratic development will serve as a beacon leading China towards democratization, Chen said.
He pointed out that the majority of the people in Taiwan are opposed to "ultimate unification" between Taiwan and China.

"Perhaps the 23 million people in Taiwan will change their mind one day, but this will only be possible if the Chinese communists give up their one-party dictatorship and implement a true system of democracy, freedom, human rights and peace," he said.
The president reiterated that Taiwan is not against China or the Chinese people but instead the totalitarianism practised by China.
Chen noted that U.S. President George W. Bush has expressed his concern about freedom of religion, assembly, speech and the press in China during his recent meeting with Chinese President Hu Jintao.
The people of Taiwan fully enjoy these freedoms and do not want to lose these freedoms by being annexed by a totalitarian China, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened high and closed higher Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 35.56 points to close at 7,171.77.
The bourse opened at 7,172.31 and fluctuated between 7,184.37 and 7,103.87 during trading. A total of 4.62 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$132.97 billion (US$4.17 billion).

Three of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with machinery and electronics shares moving up the most at 1.3 percent, followed by foodstuff issues at 0.8 percent and paper and pulp issues at 0.5 percent.
