DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPOWER TO PUSH COMPLETION OF 4TH NUCLEAR POWER PLANT

TEXT.P: Newly sworn in Taiwan Power Company (Taipower) Chairman Chen Kuei-ming vowed Friday to press ahead with the construction of the Fourth Nuclear Power Plant to help secure clean and cheap electricity for the country.

At a swearing-in ceremony, Chen -- previously Taipower president, who was promoted to acting Taipower chairman after Taipower Chairman Hwang Ing-san was appointed minister of economic affairs in January -- said he will see to it that the plant is completed as soon as possible and at the lowest possible cost.
Chen said he will make sure the plant is built in accordance with the law and under the principles of safety and quality.

Hwang, who also addressed the ceremony, suggested that Taipower invite specialists from the International Atomic Energy Agency or the International Nuclear Regulatory Association to Taiwan to verify the safety of the plant and also point out areas that Taipower should correct to boost the plant's safe operations.

Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh said recently that Taiwan should continue developing nuclear power in the next one to two decades and that construction of the Fourth Nuclear Power Plant should not be further stalled.

Lee said that so long as radioactive waste is "properly handled," Taiwan basically faces no problems as regards nuclear safety protection, adding that the existing second and third nuclear power plants should continue to function, while the fourth should continue to be built.

He did not elaborate on what he meant by "properly handled." Taipower's nuclear waste dump on outlying Orchid island is already past capacity and the company has been unable to find anywhere else willing or capable of accepting its radioactive waste.

He speculated that Taiwan's dream of becoming a nuclear-free country will probably not come true for another 50 years, when optoelectronic technology and technologies of solar energy and other recyclable energy become truly mature.

After the Kyoto Protocol entered force in February 2005, the 1986 Nobel laureate in chemistry said the reduction of carbon dioxide emissions has become an imperative task globally and that Taiwan should not slack off in this effort. Consequently, he said, Taiwan should strive to lessen its reliance on coal and fossil fuel for energy so as to reduce emissions of greenhouse gases.

One of the first things the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) administration announced when it came to power in 2000 was a halt to the controversial fourth nuclear power plant project, drawing strong criticism from the opposition parties, which united in forcing the DPP administration to resume the plant's construction on Feb. 14, 2001.

DOC.HEADLINE: VIOLATORS OF DRUG, HEALTH FOOD REGULATIONS TO FACE STEEPER FINES

TEXT.P: Fines for violations of pharmaceutical and health food control regulations will be raised dramatically, according to the revised Pharmaceutical Affairs Act and Health Food Control Act that cleared the Legislative Yuan Friday.

Under the revised acts, non-pharmaceutical manufacturers and media that run misleading ads for their products will both face fines of up to NT$25 million (US$781,125). Ads for health food that claim medicinal effects will also face fines of up to NT$2 million.

In view of the fact that the media often run ads for non-pharmaceutical products or health food in which the medical effects are exaggerated, the Executive Yuan and ruling Democratic Progressive Party legislators worked out the revised act, as the government's past efforts in cracking down on bogus "medicines" are often ineffectual due to low fines.
Under the revised regulations, medicine traders and the media will be fined between NT$200,000 and NT$5 million if they run ads for pharmaceuticals that have not been approved by the government.
If they continue to run the ads despite warnings, they will be fined between NT$600,000 and NT$25 million, which is much higher than the present maximum of NT$300,000.

Meanwhile, for ads in which health food benefits are exaggerated, fines will be raised to up to NT$2 million from the present maximum of NT$1 million. In a more serious situation, licenses for the health food, as well as business and plant registration certificates, will also be revoked.

In addition, if there is any doubt about the effect of non-pharmaceutical health food products, the media must stop running ads immediately and must submit to the authorities upon demand the information of those who commission such ads.

DOC.HEADLINE: CIVIC GROUP LAUNCHES TAX REFUND CAMPAIGN

TEXT.P: The Alliance of Fairness and Justice urged taxpayers Friday to demand tax refunds to punish the government for wasting their money.

Citing data from the Ministry of Justice, alliance leader Chien Hsi-chieh said there are 147 public establishment projects costing a total of NT$40 billion (US$1.25 billion) that have been left unused around the country, most of which are parking lots, stadiums and activity centers, and all built at taxpayer expense.

In addition, the excessive benefits enjoyed by former presidents and vice presidents are wasting taxpayers NT$35 million per year, while the cars, drivers and service and security personnel for former presidents and vice presidents are costing the taxpayer an additional NT$68.5 million per year, Chien said.

Meanwhile, the unfair 18-percent deposit interest rate enjoyed by some retired civil servants, military personnel and public school teachers has cost the national coffers NT$30.77 billion, Chien said.
With the money that has been wasted amounting to NT$70.8 billion, each of the total of 4.97 million taxpaying households in Taiwan should get a refund of NT$14,216, Chien said.

He asked taxpayers to fill out tax refund application forms available at the alliance's Web site at www.justice.org.tw and mail them to the Ministry of Finance along with their income tax returns for this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPENNESS TO CHINA AIMED AT MAINTAINING COMPETITIVE EDGE: MOEA

TEXT.P: Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Shih Yen-shiang said Friday that the government's decision to lift restrictions on investment in small-sized flat panel and low-end chip packaging and testing industries in China is aimed at ensuring that Taiwan maintains its competitive edge.

Shih made the remarks at a Legislative Yuan session to which Economics Minister Hwang Ing-san and Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Joseph Wu were also invited to report on the government's policy of lifting restrictions on investment in China by domestic manufacturers of thin film transistor-liquid crystal displays (TFT-LCDs) of four inches and less as well as low-end semiconductor packaging and testing technologies.

Shih noted that the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) made the move after conducting a thorough competitiveness analysis on the production process of these products, stressing that the headquarters of the companies in Taiwan are responsible for high-level technology development, while their plants in China are in charge of low-end technology.

Shih revealed that the ministry estimates that the average investment in a small-sized flat panel plant will be about NT$500 million (US$15 million) , while that in a low-end chip packing and testing plants will be around NT$1 billion, which he did not classify as "major investments."

Noting that these two industries are labor intensive and therefore stand to benefit greatly from China's cheap labor costs, Shih said the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) will call a stop to the investment projects if they have a negative impact on Taiwan's manpower situation.

In addition, the executives that Taiwan companies will send to China will mostly be middle and low-level managers, and few high-level technicians will be sent, Shih said, adding that Taiwan is in short supply of developers of big-sized flat panels.
"The government has made the assessment on its lifting of restrictions on investment in China based on considerations of market opportunities and opening in good order," Shih stressed.
Meanwhile, Wu said the lifting of restrictions on investment in China in these two sectors is based on a 2004 consensus reached among various government agencies.
After prudent evaluation, the government believes that the time is ripe for the opening, Wu stressed.

DOC.HEADLINE: ALL-OUT EFFORTS TO BE MADE TO IMPROVE SOCIAL ORDER IN TAICHUNG

TEXT.P: The central government is to help improve social order in Taichung City, Minister of the Interior Lee Yi-yang said Friday.

A special forum on social order and security maintenance kicked off in the central city earlier that day, hosted by Taichung Mayor Jason Hu and attended by Lee and Hou Yu-ih, director-general of the National Police Agency, as well as academics, experts and officials of relevant authorities.

Taichung City's citizen satisfaction rate has lagged behind all other cities and counties in recent years, with deteriorating public order blamed as the key culprit. In this regard, Hou claimed, Taichung should be regarded as the key barometer for Taiwan's general social order.

Lee said that official research has found Taichung's public order has mostly been damaged by people from other cities and counties who commit crimes in the city, and that the population of lawbreakers is relatively larger than other places in Taiwan.

Considering that the city is in short of law-enforcement personnel, Lee said 500 additional police officers will be posted in the city this year, adding that 2,000 more policemen will be added in two years.

Noting that Premier Su Tseng-chang has gambled his political life on the improvement of social order, Hou pledged that his agency will do its utmost to help the Taichung city government build a safe living environment for its citizens.

DOC.HEADLINE: COA RELEASES 30 FARMING TECHNOLOGIES TO PRIVATE SECTOR

TEXT.P: Council of Agriculture (COA) officials announced today that 30 farming technologies invented by the COA's research laboratories will be released to the private sector to facilitate technical improvement in the agricultural sector.

According to the COA, the list includes improved technology for Agaricus Blazei Murill processing, the fast detection reagent for viral nervous necrosis on fish, farming plastic sheet retriever, the Tainan- 22 rice strain and the Kaohsiung-2 loofah.

A COA spokesman said Taiwan's research and development on agricultural techniques is mostly done by the government and that by transferring these techniques from the government to the private sector, companies can save costs on their own R&D laboratory, as well as making the prices for their products more competitive in the global market.

DOC.HEADLINE: EX-NHRI RESEARCHER RECEIVES AWARD FROM UNIVERSITY OF MINNESOTA

TEXT.P: Former researcher of National Health Research Institutes (NHRI) Yu Chung-yuan has received an excellent global leader award from the University of Minnesota, an NHRI official said Friday.
Yu, who left his job at the NHRI in late March, is a specialist in cervical cancer research. He is one of 20 foreign alumni of the university to receive the award.

The award was established in 2003 for foreign alumni who have made extraordinary contributions to their areas of specialization. Republic of China Ambassador-at-large Dr. Sun Ming-hsien was the first in Taiwan to receive the award.
Yu said through the NHRI that the prize represents recognition of his professional ability and that he will keep working in this field in the future.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMICS MINISTER URGES TAIPOWER TO USE SOLAR ENERGY

TEXT.P: Minister of Economic Affairs Hwang Ing-san expressed hope Friday that the Taiwan Power Company (Taipower) will join hands with other sectors in the development of the solar energy industry to reduce the nation's dependency on imported oil.

Speaking at the inauguration ceremony for new Taipower Chairman Edward K.M. Chen, Hwang urged Taipower to develop solar energy technology, saying that in view of soaring oil prices and Taiwan's heavy dependency on imported oil, Taipower needs to find a role in the solar energy industry.
Hwang also expressed hope that there will come a day when every household in Taiwan has its own solar energy equipment to help reduce peak power loads.
As for the persisting doubts about the safety of nuclear power plants, Hwang instructed Taipower to invite experts from international nuclear organization to help check their operations.
Chen for his part said he will do his best to make sure that nuclear plant construction goes on in accordance with budgets and schedules.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT OPENS NATIONAL AQUARIUM MUSEUM

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian presided Friday over a ceremony marking the opening of the "Waters of the World" museum -- the third section of the National Museum of Marine Biology and Aquarium --located in Taiwan's southernmost county of Pingtung.

Delighted and impressed with the virtual reality (VR) presentation of different water worlds around the globe from ancient times to the present, Chen said the museum is another example that not all build-operate-transfer (BOT) projects are rife with flaws and irregularities as some opposition politicians have claimed.
Chen noted that Taipei 101 -- the tallest building in the world -- is another BOT model that was a major project endorsed by him when he was Taipei mayor prior to 2000.
The "Waters of the World" museum is the first digitalized aquarium with VR presentations in the world.

After spending two years and two months, as well as NT$2.7 billion (US$84.4 million) , the museum has been constructed in a three-story building featuring four theme parks -- the Polar Region, the Kelp Forest, the Deep Sea and the Ancient Oceans.
In the Polar Region park, live penguins of different species are kept in a polar environment at a temperature of minus 6 degrees Celsius and water of 10 degrees Celsius.
In the Kelp Forest, real kelp flourishes in giant water tanks. The kelp grows from tiny spores at a speed of 50 cm per day in water. The tallest branch of kelp reaches 30 meters.
In the Deep Sea park, a giant VR sperm whale fights with a VR 18-meter squid in a deep sea teeming with luminous fish and other creatures.

In the Ancient Ocean park, creatures from 4.5 billion years ago are featured in a 4D marine theater, allowing the spectators to have a timeless and close-up experience of facing an ancient underwater world.
The National Museum of Marine Biology and Aquarium, which gets at least 2 million visitors a year, is the most important location for marine displays and education in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP CHIEF'S COMMENTS NOT AIMED AT DE-LINKING FIRST FAMILY FROM PARTY

TEXT.P: As leader of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , Chairman Yu Shyi-kun has to take responsibility for the whole party, including disputes arising from the first family, DPP spokesman Tsai Huang-liang said Friday.

Tsai made the remarks at a news conference in response to allegations that various DPP heavyweights were trying to cut links to President Chen Shui-bian to save the party's reputation and image after Yu said a day earlier that the first family should not hesitate to apologize to the public if it has done wrong.

Dismissing the speculation, Tsai claimed that Yu's comments were made to protect the DPP and the first family, whose image has been seriously damaged due to alleged involvement in several corruption scandals.

"All DPP members are in the same boat and no one can survive alone," Tsai said, insisting that "de-linking is not an issue for the DPP and the party needs to conduct self-examination and forge unity."

Tsai also hailed first lady Wu Shu-chen's decision to donate her earnings from mutual funds and stocks to charity, claiming that the DPP has always used the highest moral standards upon which to discipline itself.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONSTITUTIONAL AMENDMENTS SHOULD HEED PUBLIC OPINION: KMT CHIEF

TEXT.P: Any political party must take public opinion into account when promoting amendments to the Constitution, main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou said Friday.

Ma made the remarks while answering questions from reporters about a report a day earlier that a dozen lawmakers from both the ruling and opposition parties have jointly called for a fresh constitutional amendment to allow for an increase in the size of the Legislative Yuan from 113 to 164 seats in the 2007 general election.

Stressing that it is the whole party, not a party's legislative caucus, that should be in charge of handling the constitutional amendment issue, Ma said that the public will not accept a new proposal to increase the number of legislative seats only one year after a majority of lawmakers passed a constitutional amendment proposal to halve the scale of the Legislative Yuan from the current 225 members to 113.
The Taiwan people would not feel good about holding back from an approved constitutional amendment when it has not even been implemented, Ma pointed out.

Any KMT legislator is entitled to voice his or her viewpoint, but it is most important that he or she realizes that constitutional amendments are not an issue of major concern to the public at this time, Ma said, adding that the Taiwan people are now more concerned about improving their livelihoods.
Lawmakers, as representatives elected from their constituencies, have to pay heed to public opinion, he said.

Meanwhile, KMT Legislator Hsu Shu-po, who has publicly displayed support for launching a new constitutional revision to enlarge the next Legislative Yuan to 164 seats, claimed that he would consider leaving the KMT if the party ignores his idea.

In addition to Hsu, ruling Democratic Progressive Party lawmakers You Ching and Lin Cho-shui, People First Party (PFP) lawmakers Lee Hung-chun and Lu Hsueh-chang, Taiwan Solidarity Union lawmaker Ho Ming-hau and independent lawmaker Yen Chin-piao are among those who favor the constitutional amendment.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Friday, losing NT$0.01 to close at NT$31.913.
A total of US$1.431 billion changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at the day's high of NT$31.923 and hit a low of NT$31.83.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S LABOR COSTS MORE STABLE THAN SOUTH KOREA'S: CIER

TEXT.P: South Korea's hourly compensation costs have surged from 100 in 1990 to 311.6 for 2006 -- double Taiwan's level of 155.1, the Chung-Hua Institution for Economic Research (CIER) reported Friday in its latest weekly magazine on the international situation.

Citing the newest tallies released recently by the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics, CIER reported that South Korea made the largest increase in this category among 28 countries and areas surveyed. South Korea's 311.6 is also higher than Singapore's 198.6 and Hong Kong's 171.3 -- an indication that the country has to bear greater financial burden from workers' rising salaries, social insurance and retirement fees, CIER analyzed, pointing out that a hike in hourly compensation cost can negatively affect a country's economic growth rate and consumer product price increase rates.

In addition to South Korea and Singapore, Britain (196.0) , Portugal (195.7) and Ireland (186.4) also posted marked growth in hourly compensation costs, while Canada (131.2) , Sweden (136.6) , Finland (145.0) , Switzerland (146.6) and the United States (156.1) registered relatively smaller increases, according to the CIER weekly.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP LAWMAKERS BLAST TWO CABINET MINISTERS FOR TRIP TO ABU DHABI

TEXT.P: Two Cabinet ministers who have taken their families on a trip to Abu Dhabi to attend an inaugural ceremony for a new stopover for China Airlines -- Taiwan's main carrier -- should step down if their expenses were paid by the airline, legislators of the opposition People First Party (PFP) said Friday.

CAL added Abu Dhabi, capital of the United Arab Emirates, as a stopover on its Taipei-Vienna route, which has three flights per week. Minister of Foreign Affairs Huang Chih-fang, Minister of Transportation and Communications Kuo Yao-chi and four other transportation officials were invited to the inaugural ceremony as guests of honor.
While Huang brought his wife and son on the trip, Kuo was accompanied by her husband. They departed from Taipei April 25.
Legislators serving on the Transportation Committee of the Legislative Yuan were furious because Kuo gave them short notice requesting leave of absence from the committee meeting April 26.

PFP legislative caucus whip Lee Hung-chun demanded that the two Cabinet minsters explain who paid for their air tickets and hotel rooms and said that unless they can come up with clear evidence that they and their families accepted no favors for the trip from CAL, they should resign their Cabinet posts.

PFP legislator Liu Wen-hsiung noted that it is strange that the foreign minister is accompanied by his family rather than by Foreign Ministry officials who can speak Arabic or by the top executive of the Sino-Arabian Cultural and Economic Association.

Kuo's deputy, Tsai Duei, said the Bureau of Tourism under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications paid for the travel and hotel expenses for Kuo and four other officials, and that Kuo's husband paid his own expenses.

News reports from Abu Dhabi Friday quoted Huang's aides as confirming that CAL provided tickets for Huang and his wife, and that their son's tickets were paid for by themselves and upgraded to first class through a mileage accumulation plan.
As for their hotel expenses, the aides added, they will be paid by the government of the United Arab Emirates.
The aides explained that the foreign minister and his wife brought their young son on the trip because no one else could take care of him if he were left behind.

However, CAL's public relations director Sun Hung-wen denied in Taipei that CAL paid the travel expenses for any of the officials. He said CAL determined the ticket price through negotiations with officials at the two ministries.

DOC.HEADLINE: MINISTER'S HUSBAND PAID OWN EXPENSES TO ABU DHABI

TEXT.P: Minister of Transportation and Communications Kuo Yao-chi's husband paid his own expenses when he traveled with Kuo aboard a China Airlines (CAL) -- Taiwan's main carrier -- flight to Abu Dhabi Tuesday to mark the use of the United Arab Emirates capital as a new stopover on the carrier's Taipei-Vienna route.

Vice Minister of Transportation and Communications Tsai Duei issued the clarification Friday in the wake of reports that Kuo and Foreign Affairs Minister Huang Chih-fang took members of their family with them on the trip.

Tsai said the expenses of Kuo and four other ministry officials were paid by the Tourism Bureau, while Kuo's husband, Peng Kuang-hui, a professor at National Taipei University of Technology, paid his own way.
Asked why the two ministers took their family members with them, Tsai claimed it was because of the need for diplomatic protocol.

The trip was mainly to take part in the inaugural ceremony of CAL's use of Abu Dhabi as a new stopover on its Taipei-Vienna route and the ministry had no other information about other private itinerary.
Huang reportedly took his wife and son with him, but Tsai said that this should be explained by the Foreign Affairs Ministry.

CAL public relations officials said the airline did not pay for the trips by the minister and the officials and that their fares were negotiated with the Ministry of Transportation and Communications and the Ministry of Foreign Affairs. All private trips, including those by travel operators and accompanying reporters, are paid for by the individuals.
According to the travel operators, CAL tickets for economy class to Abu Dhabi are NT$29,880 and NT$69,880 for business class.

Meanwhile, the legislative caucus of the opposition People First Party (PFP) demanded Friday that CAL explain unequivocally whether it paid for the tickets and accommodation for the two ministers and their families, and that if so, they should resign immediately.

DOC.HEADLINE: FAMILY MEMBERS OF TAIWAN EMBASSY STAFF EVACUATED FROM SOLOMON ISLANDS

TEXT.P: A total of 10 dependents of Republic of China embassy and technical mission staff in the Solomon Islands were evacuated from the South Pacific island nation Friday, a Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) official said.

Lee Chuang-tung, director of MOFA's Department of East Asian and Pacific Affairs, said the situation in the Solomon Islands has largely returned to normal after recent turmoil, but as some schools and houses were burned down during the rioting, life there is difficult.
For this reason, eight of the dependents returned to Taiwan, while the other two headed for Australia, Lee said.
Embassy staff will stay at their posts, he added.
As for two Taiwanese families in the Solomon Islands, one has evacuated to Australia and the other has decided to stay, he said.

The Solomon Islands' capital of Honiara was racked by burning and looting -- mostly businesses owned by ethnic Chinese -- after its parliament elected Snyder Rini as prime minister April 18. The situation abated after Australia and New Zealand sent troops and police officers to maintain law and order.
Although the situation has stabilized, the MOFA issued a travel alert last Friday advising Taiwanese to refrain from going there for business or travel for the time being.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN `WATERMELON KINGDOM': AGRICULTURAL OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Taiwan can be described as a "watermelon kingdom" because of the wide variety grown here, a Council of Agriculture (COA) official said Friday.

Tsai Chin-chiang, secretary-general of the COA's Agriculture and Food Agency, noted that the watermelon production areas in Taiwan cover around 12,000 hectares, with annual production of around 300,000 tons of the fruit.
Taiwan boasts more than a dozen varieties of watermelon, and the fruit is available all year round. This year will be another banner year for the fruit, he added.

He said Taiwan has also developed different shapes of watermelon. In addition to the rounded ones, there are also oval and even square ones, with the square ones the most valuable, selling at up to NT$1,200 (US$37.5) per melon.

DOC.HEADLINE: INDIVIDUALS, GROUPS DECORATED WITH ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION AWARDS

TEXT.P: Two former chiefs of the Environmental Protection Administration (EPA), as well as 63 individuals and groups were decorated Friday by the administration with awards in recognition of their contribution to environmental protection.

During the award-presentation ceremony, EPA Minister Chang Kuo-lung described the award-winners as the hands that push forward Taiwan's practices in the environmental protection, saying that he hopes there will be an increasing number of Taiwanese people willing to join in the works to clean up the nation.

Former EPA chiefs Hou Lung-bin and Chang Juu-en, as well as former EPA deputy chief Tsai Ting-kuei, were awarded with medals for professional achievements including constructing a sound and efficient responding mechanism to environmental hazards, promoting a "zero waste" policy by carrying out garbage assortment and recycling, and pushing for exchanges with international environmental protection organizations.

Among the awarded groups, the Niushichi local culture and history promotion association of Nantou County, central Taiwan, was awarded for its weekly community-cleaning program aimed at attracting foreign and domestic tourists.

In addition, members of the association have vowed to keep the streets clear of dog feces after a Japanese couple who visited Puli township in the central county left in disgust, calling Taiwan "dirty," according to the EPA.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Profits, Prices Spur Oil Outrage; Exxon Mobil Posts First-Quarter Rise
Exxon Mobil Corp. reported $8.4 billion in first-quarter profit yesterday, as members of Congress outraged over high gasoline prices hastened to propose measures that would boost taxes on oil firms, open new areas to drilling and provide rebates to taxpayers but would not necessarily alter prices at the pumps.

DOC.HEADLINE: BILL REGARDING LOW-RADIATION NUCLEAR WASTE STORAGE APPROVED

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan approved Friday a bill that will govern the storage of the country's low-radiation nuclear waste.

Under the terms of the bill, the government should hold a plebiscite among the residents of the place where it wants to store the radioactive waste and the place should not be considered as a possible storage location in the future if most of the residents oppose the project.

Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Legislator Justin Huang, who initiated the plebiscite clause, said he was happy about the passage of the bill, although he was still opposed to the Executive Yuan's plan to tap the possibility of whether the state-owned Taiwan Power Co.'s (Taipower's) nuclear waste can be stored in Tawu village in eastern Taitung County. Huang was elected from Taitung County.
Taipower has dumped its low-radiation waste on outlying Orchid Island for many years, but increasing objections from residents has pushed it to choose another storage site.
Huang urged the government to respect the bill when choosing future sites.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAO TRIBE LIKELY TO ALLOW NUKE WASTE TO STAY ON ORCHID ISLAND

TEXT.P: Some indigenous Tao tribe people residing on Orchid Island have voiced willingness to allow Taiwan Power Company (Taipower) to continue depositing nuclear fuel waste on the island as long as relevant security measures are fully in place, an influential political figure said Friday.

The man, who requested anonymity, made the comments after the Legislative Yuan passed earlier that day a law on measures regulating sites for the disposal of nuclear waste -- which has long been a thorny issue in Taiwan amid growing awareness of the importance of environmental protection.

According to the official, the law's passage is a boon for Orchid Island as it will permit Taipower to relocate the nuclear fuel waste that is temporarily being stored on the island. According to law, a referendum is necessary for the government to make a final decision on a nuclear waste site.
But he said at least half of Orchid Island's residents have expressed a willingness to allow the waste to stay as long as security measures -- and monetary compensation to locals -- are well-heeded.

Those who have demanded Taipower relocate its nuclear waste from Orchid Island are just a small group of anti-nuclear power activists and local representatives who have used the issue for private gain, he opined.

If Taipower moved its nuclear waste from Orchid Island, more than half of local residents will be unable to pay electricity bills and national insurance fees that are currently being paid by the central government as quid pro quo for the island's accommodation of the nuclear-waste dump, he said.

Meanwhile, Taipower continues examining the 97.672 barrels of nuclear fuel waste stored on Orchid Island, and the whole task is estimated to be completed at the end of 2010 prior to an eventual relocation, a spokesman for the state-run public utility said.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT HEAD REITERATES 'FIVE NOES, FIVE DO'S' POLICY

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, who also serves as the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman, reiterated his "Five Noes, five do's" policy in cross-Taiwan Strait relations in a speech Friday.

Ma, who is expected to run in the 2008 presidential election as a "pan-blue alliance" candidate, said the "Five Noes, five do's" pledge will be the cornerstone of his and the KMT's policy once the party returns to power.

Ma delivered a speech titled "Embracing Chellenges Ahead: Ma Ying-jeou's Vision for Taipei and Taiwan" at a monthly European Chamber of Commerce in Taipei (ECCT) luncheon, attended by more than 180 ECCT members.
"The five noes has become the common denominator in Washington, Beijing and Taiwan," Ma said, adding he would admit he "borrowed" this from President Chen Shui-bian.

President Chen said in his May 2000 inaugural speech that as long as China promises not to use military force against Taiwan, he will not declare Taiwan independence, will not change the official name of the country, will not include the "state-to-state" theory in the Constitution, will not promote a referendum to change the cross-Taiwan Strait status quo, and will not abolish the the National Unification Council (NUC) and its guidelines.
But the "five do's" he and the KMT have been advocating are even more important for Taiwan's future development, Ma said.

For the "five do's," Ma suggested that both sides resume talks between governments; work toward military confidence-building measures; work toward the creation of a common market; try to achieve a "modus vivendi" -- a temporary agreement between contending parties prior to a final settlement -- on Taiwan's participation in international organizations; and accelerate cross-strait cultural and educational exchanges.

Ma expressed concern that by 2015 Taiwan could be left out and "economically marginalized" when 10 ASEAN countries, including China, Japan and South Korea establish the largest economic integration in the world, representing 2 billion people with a combined US$12 trillion GDP.
This is why he and the KMT will have a "pragmatic and open" approach in dealing with China and will begin to remove legal difficulties hampering exchanges between Taiwan and China, Ma said.
"We can't wait for another two years; otherwise Taiwan will lose its competiveness," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: HONG KONG CULTURAL WEEK LAUNCHED

TEXT.P: "Hong Kong Cultural Week," an exhibition celebrating Hong Kong's culture and heritage, was launched Friday in Taipei to encourage more Taiwanese tourists to visit Hong Kong this year.

The Hong Kong Cultural Week includes installations and cultural event information and will be held April 28 to May 11 at the Eslite Bookstore (Hsin-yi), said Jessica Huang, Director of the Hong Kong Tourism Board's (HKTB) Taipei branch office.

"Hong Kong is more than a shopper's paradise," said Huang. "The campaign wants to let Taiwanese people know about cultural events and heritage they can enjoy in Hong Kong. It's a celebration of Hong Kong's popular culture."

Between April 20 and May 7, visitors to Hong Kong will be able to experience four major traditional Hong Kong festivals first-hand: The birthday of Buddha, the birthday of Tam Kung, the birthday of Tin Hau and the Cheung Chau Bun Festival.

The Cheung Chau Bun Festival stands out in terms of uniqueness, Huang said. Youngsters dressed as mythological figures are held aloft on hidden rods in a parade. The procession ends at a temple where men and women clamber up a tower covered in buns to grab as many "lucky" ones off the top as possible.
Huang estimated the average number of Taiwanese tourists visiting Hong Kong during the month of festivities as somewhere between 180,000-190,000 -- an increase of 5,000 over other months.
The event is part of the "2006 Discover Hong Kong Year" campaign to boost Hong Kong tourism.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S.-TAIWAN MILITARY EXCHANGES INCREASING: OFFICIAL
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 28 (CNA) (By Jorge Liu and Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: Military exchanges between Taiwan and the United States are increasing, with 39 Taiwanese cadets studying at American military academies, a Republic of China military officer said Friday.

Chen Ching-chung, head of the ROC's military delegation stationed in the U.S., noted that these cadets are studying at America's foremost military academies, including the United States Military Academy (West Point) , the U.S. Naval Academy, the U.S. Air Force Academy, and the Virginia Military Institute.
Nine of them will graduate in May from American military schools and join the ROC's military forces to put into practice skills they learned at U.S. schools, Chen added.
Among the 39 cadets, Hung Wan-ting will become the first Taiwanese woman to graduate from West Point next year.

According to Chen, Hung -- who chose to further her study at West Point after graduating from the ROC Military Academy -- underwent the same physical training as men at West Point, without any preferential treatment. Hung's academic performance has been excellent and she has won much praise at the school, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S OSCAR-WINNING FILM DIRECTOR RETURNS HOME
DOC.DATELINE: Tainan, southern Taiwan, April 28 (CNA) (By Han Nai-kuo)

TEXT.P: Oscar-winning Taiwanese film director Ang Lee received a rousing welcome reception Friday when he made a public appearance in his hometown of Tainan, the city in southern Taiwan where he grew up.

Accompanied by his mother, Lee paid a courtesy call on Tainan Mayor Hsu Tain-tsair at his office and was greeted by city government officials donning cowboy hats in recognition of the fact that Lee won this year's Academy award for best director in Los Angeles for his film "Brokeback Mountain."
In addition to declaring April 28 as "Ang Lee Day" in Tainan, the mayor prepared a three-tier cake to celebrate the 80th birthday of Lee's mother.
The 51-year-old movie director said he is proud of Tainan and its culture, and that the warmth and comfort he feels in his hometown are so special to him.

During his hour-long stay at the city's administration center, Lee had his ID card renewed. When members of the public in the building recognized their hero, they swarmed around him, seeking his autograph and asking him to pose with them for photographs. Lee granted all their requests in his usual gentle manner.
When asked what birthday present he had given his mother, Lee said that his return home was the best gift.

"Brokeback Mountain," Lee's latest film, received a total of eight Oscar nominations -- the most of any movie this year -- and won three Oscars for best director, best adapted screenplay and best original score. The film is about a forbidden romance between two gay American cowboys.

Lee first won international fame for directing "The Wedding Banquet," which won the Golden Bear award at the 1993 Berlin Film Festival, and Best Film and Best Director citations at the 1993 Seattle International Film Festival. His 1994 film "Eat Drink Man Woman" was also a critical success.
His first English-language feature film, "Sense and Sensibility" (1995) was also critically acclaimed, followed by the success of another well-received film, "The Ice Storm" (1997).
"Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon," another film directed by Lee, won four Academy awards for best foreign-language film, best art direction, best cinematography and best original score in 2001.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT PEACE SHOULD BE BASED ON DEMOCRACY, EQUITABLE WEALTH: MA

TEXT.P: Peace and prosperity -- core values shared by both Taiwan and China -- should be established on a foundation of democracy and equitable wealth, Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou said Friday.

Receiving international scholars who arrived in Taipei to attend a forum on democracy, Ma -- who concurrently serves as chairman of main opposition Kuomintang -- said the best way for the two sides of the Taiwan Strait to maintain lasting peace and avoid war is if they are both democratic societies.

A democratic society still needs to narrow the gap between rich and poor in order to maintain domestic stability, Ma said, adding that without equitable wealth, a government may resort to war against its neighbors to divert attention from its internal problems.
Ma acknowledged that Taiwan's democratic system is still evolving, and that in terms of the quality of Taiwan's democracy and rule of law, there is still room for improvement.
The foreign participants in the forum were accompanied by Lung Ying-tai, a writer who also served 1999-2003 as Taipei City's top cultural minister, during their courtesy call on Ma.

Lung Ying-tai's cultural foundation is sponsoring the two-day forum, which opens in Taipei Saturday. Forum participants include scholars and commentators from the United States, Nicaragua, Japan, South Korea, the Philippines, Malaysia, China and Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT: KMT'S DIPLOMACY CANNOT INFRINGE ON TAIWAN'S SOVEREIGNTY

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said in a interview with the Japanese daily Sankei Shimbun Friday that he was not against recent China visits by opposition party Kuomintang Honorary Chairman Lien Chan, but that it was "absolutely unacceptable" if the party's diplomatic efforts infringed upon Taiwan's sovereignty or reduced Taiwan's position to that of a Chinese province.

President Chen told the Japanese newspaper that since only twenty-odd countries maintain diplomatic ties with Taiwan, any diplomatic efforts -- including those of city officials and political parties -- are welcome as long as they help to improve Taiwan's diplomatic standing.

Chen said, however, that Lien's China visit and his meeting with Chinese Communist Party leaders were not in Taiwan's best interest. If one speaks loudly in Taiwan about "One China, diferent interpretations" and then stays mum while meeting with the leader of China, it's really inappropriate, he added.

Knowing there is no such thing as a "1992 consensus" with China while insisting on having such an understanding is really inappropriate, Chen continued. The party's not only fooling itself, it's cheating other people, he said.

President Chen also expressed strong reservations about the timing of Lien's visit to China, saying that in the wake of China's passage of an "Anti-Secession" Law, Lien's visit only helps reduce the negative response of the international community. A visit like this only serves the interest of China's propaganda tactics, he added.
As for KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou's recent visit to the United States, Chen said Ma's talks about "One China, different interpretations" and "modus vivendi" proposal don't stand up to the challenge.

Chen said Ma and Lien may claim the "One China" they have in mind is the "Republic of China," but for the People's Republic of China, the ROC has not existed since 1949, so the PRC has no room for separate interpretations of "One China."

President Chen stressed that Taiwan is a sovereign country, that its future can only be decided by the free will of its 23 million people, and that any disputes or differences should be resolved through peaceful dialogue under the principles of sovereignty, democracy, peace and equality.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH SAYS BEEF IMPORTS TO CONTINUE, CITING U.S. 'QUALITY CONTROL FLAW'

TEXT.P: Faced with a lawmaker's demand to immediately halt U.S. beef imports after inspectors found bone fragments in a shipment Thursday, health authorities said Friday the incident reflected a flaw in quality control in some U.S. slaughterhouses and decided to ban only the U.S. company involved rather than all imports.

Hsiao Tung-ming, chief of the Bureau of Food Sanitation under the Department of Health (DOH), said Friday that the problematic batch of U.S. beef imports was shipped from Tyson Fresh Meats in Nebraska, one of 45 slaughterhouses allowed to sell beef to Taiwan.

The company has been expelled from the list, while the DOH has also asked the U.S. government to reinforce management regulation measures in their slaughterhouses and processing factories, Hsiao said.
Talking about the problematic imports, Hsiao said that "it does not pose a problem for food safety."

Quarantine inspectors at Chiang Kai-shek airport discovered rib bone fragments in three cases of imported chilled beef loins Thursday, the first incident of its kind since Taiwan conditionally reopened its market to U.S. beef imports Jan. 25.

According to DOH regulations, U.S. beef and related goods may be re-introduced into Taiwan only if they are: beef from animals raised in the U.S. and under 30 months of age; boneless beef without "risky parts or substance" attached -- such as bone marrow and encephalon; beef from slaughterhouses and processing factories approved by the U.S. Department of Agriculture; and beef certified by the USDA.
The beef may be banned again if imports to Taiwan don't meet the requirements, DOH officials declared at the time when their department gave the green light to reopen Taiwan's market to U.S. beef.

Citing Japan's move to re-impose a ban on U.S. beef imports Jan. 21 -- a few days after Taiwan gave the green light for re-entry -- after a "risky substance" was found in the beef, Legislator Lai Hsing-yuan of the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Party urged the DOH to follow Japan's model and not reopen its doors to U.S. beef shipments.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAVERICK KMT LAWMAKER GIVES UP BID TO EXPAND LEGISLATURE

TEXT.P: A maverick Kuomintang (KMT) legislator who attempted to convince his colleagues to increase the number of seats in the Legislative Yuan by amending the Constitution abandoned his efforts on Friday.

Hsu Shu-po said the press vilified his idea of increasing the number of legislative seats as "lawmakers' dirty trick to try to hang on to their jobs, " and that the issue could no longer be discussed rationally in the current political climate.

Instead, Su said, he would propose a change in the number of lawmakers chosen through elections and lawmakers appointed by the political parties in proportion to votes they garner in elections, while keeping the number of all lawmakers unchanged at 113.

Under his plan, the number of popularly elected seats would increase from 73 to 90, while the number of politically appointed lawmakers would decrease from 34 to 17, keeping the number of seats reserved for aboriginal lawmakers intact at 6.

In order to preempt criticism of a conflict of interest, Hsu said that once translated into constitutional amendments, his proposal would take effect only after 2011 -- four years after the lawmakers who vote for it have completed their terms.

Further, Hsu also called for the introduction of a Cabinet system through constitutional amendments, citing the opposition's criticism that the current government system -- a hybrid between Cabinet and presidential systems -- empowers the president to pull strings without being held accountable to the legislature.

Hsu's call for the legislature's expansion initially raised eyebrows among KMT leaders, with the party's Chairman Ma Ying-jeou asking KMT lawmakers not to back it, saying the public has grown weary of politicians' numerous attempts to tinker with the Constitution.

To seek support for his new proposal, Hsu met with KMT Honorary Chairman Lien Chan Friday and quoted Lien as saying afterwards that the KMT is not an authoritarian party, and its members should be given the freedom to air and discuss their views -- including proposals to change the Constitution.
Without naming Ma who doubles as Taipei mayor, Lien was cited by Hsu as saying that "It is not appropriate that a bunch of people at Taipei City Hall want to silence people with different ideas."

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN QUESTIONS CONSTITUTIONALITY OF REVISED TRUTH COMMITTEE STATUTE

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian signed into law Friday a revised statute to create a second investigative committee to probe the March 19, 2004 shooting of the president and Vice President Annette Lu, while expressing reservations about its constitutionality, according to a Presidential Office press release .

The press release said the president would order the revised statute be promulgated, as requested by the Legislative Yuan, on May 1, yet noted that "serious controversy" still surrounds the constitutionality of several of the statute's provisions, which should be solved by a Council of Grand Justices decision or a revision to the statute itself, the press release said.

The statute was crafted mainly by the opposition in the legislature who wish to form a committee to investigate the shooting on the eve of the 2004 presidential election -- which the opposition suspected to be a political scheme concocted to boost Chen's votes in the election.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, April 29, or the second day of the fourth month of the Year of the Dog according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1429: French military leader and heroine Joan of Arc enters Orleans, France, and defeats English forces. She was later tried for heresy and witchcraft and was burned at the stake in Rouen.
1661: Cheng Cheng-kung, also known as Koxinga, a national hero and one of the Ming loyalists and resistance fighters against foreign invasion, claims Taiwan from the Dutch and chooses Anping (present-day Tainan) as his capital, in the hope of returning to mainland China one day to restore the Ming dynasty.
1667: John Arbuthnot, Scottish physician and writer, is born. He was noted for his satirical anti-Whig pamphlets published in 1712 as "Law Is a Bottomless Pit" and later retitled "The History of John Bull."
1769: Arthur Wellesley, Duke of Wellington, English soldier and later the prime minister known as the Iron Duke, is born. He defeated Napoleon at Waterloo.
1818: Alexander II, the czar of Russia who emancipated the serfs in 1861, is born. He was assassinated in 1881 after severe repression of political opposition.
1863: William Randolph Hearst, American newspaper and magazine publisher, is born. Beginning with the San Francisco Examiner in 1887, he built the world's largest publishing empire, comprised of 28 major newspapers.
1901: Hirohito, the Japanese emperor who advocated the country's unconditional surrender that ended World War II, is born. He renounced his divine status in 1946.
1903: After Russia refuses to leave Manchuria when the troops of other foreign powers withdraw from Chinese territory, and prior to the outbreak of the Russo-Japanese War, Chinese students studying in Japan meet in Tokyo and set up a "Resist Russia" volunteer corps.
1937: American chemist Wallace Hume Carothers commits suicide just two months after he patented nylon.
1942: Japanese troops capture the Burmese town of Lashio, cutting off the Burma Road between China and India.
1945: U.S. forces in Germany liberate 32,000 victims of the Nazi death camp at Dachau, just northwest of Munich.
1946: Former Japanese leaders are indicted in Tokyo as war criminals.
1948: Li Tsung-jen is elected vice president of the Republic of China in the republic's fourth ballot.
1957: The first nuclear reactor goes into operation in the United States.
1969: Hsu Peh-yuen, governor of the Central Bank of China, is released from office and succeeded by Yu Kuo-hwa, the incumbent minister of finance.
1975: The last U.S. troops are evacuated from Saigon as thousands of foreigners and South Vietnamese are ferried out by helicopter from the roof of the American embassy.
1976: Edward Y. Kuan, ROC vice minister of foreign affairs, is named by the Executive Yuan as first ambassador to South Africa.
1976: The Sino-U.S. Seminar on Food Science and Nutrition opens in Taipei with 24 food scientists attending.
1980: Alfred Hitchcock, the British-born film director and the silver screen's master of suspense, dies in Los Angeles at the age of 80.
1985: The space shuttle Challenger is launched, and Dr. Wang Kan-chuen becomes the first Chinese American astronaut in space.
1992: Bolivian Vice President Luis Ossio Sanjines officiates at the inauguration of the Bolivian Commercial and Financial Representative Office in Taipei.
1993: Representatives of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) and its mainland counterpart, the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait, sign three agreements and a joint accord at a historic meeting in Singapore; the agreements and accord went into effect on May 29.
1996: On the third anniversary of the Koo-Wang cross-strait talks, SEF Chairman Koo Chen-fu appeals to mainland China not to postpone the second round of talks so that both sides can resume their pursuit of reunification.
1998: North Korea publishes an open letter by its leader Kim Jong-Il calling for unification with South Korea.
2000: Premier-designate Tang Fei checks out of Taipei Veterans General Hospital after fully recovering from surgery removing a benign thymoma on April 16.
2001: The Ministry of National Defense says that in accordance with relevant government laws, military generals on active service will not be allowed to travel to mainland China either for meetings or visits.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A workman who wants to perfect his work first sharpens his tools. When you are living in a country, you should serve those nobles and ministers in that country who are men of moral worth, and you should cultivate the friendship of the gentlemen of that country who are men of moral worth."

The first day of May 2006, commemorating the 103rd Labor Day in the country, is a regular holiday nationwide, the Department of Labor and Employment (DoLE) announced yesterday.

A MAKATI judge yesterday handed Justice Secretary Raul Gonzalez a stinging rebuff by refusing to downgrade rape charges against three of four US Marines, and the Americans added to the drama by refusing to enter a plea.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN REMAINS ON U.S. 'SPECIAL 301' WATCH LIST
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 28 (CNA) (By Wennie Chi and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The United States has kept Taiwan on its watch list for intellectual property rights (IPR) protection in 2006 while recognizing Taiwan's efforts to improve its IPR regime, according to the annual "Special 301" report released Friday by the Office of the U.S. Trade Representative (USTR).
"The United States looks to Taiwan to sustain the current level of commitment to making progress on IPR issues, and will continue to monitor further improvements," the report said.
The report noted that Taiwan has increased the number of raids and seizures of pirated optical media, counterfeit pharmaceuticals and counterfeit luxury goods.

Also, Taiwan has prosecuted the peer-to-peer Internet service Kuro and provided protection against unfair commercial use of undisclosed test and other data submitted by pharmaceutical companies, the report said.

However, Taiwan still needs to improve its efforts to combat the production of pirated optical media and proliferation of Internet piracy and to deal more effectively with unauthorized use of copyright materials on government and university computer networks, it said.

Also, Taiwan should strengthen IPR enforcement actions against piracy and counterfeiting and establish a specialized IP court and devote more resources and coordinated high-level government attention to combating IPR infringement, it said.

Other steps that Taiwan needs to take include strengthening border enforcement against transshipment of pirated and counterfeit goods, considering legislative amendments to address the liability of Internet service providers, implementing stronger criminal penalties for IPR infringement and extending the term of copyright protection for works and sound recordings, it said.
This year's "Special 301" report places 13 countries on the Priority Watch List and 34 countries on the lower level Watch List.
Taiwan was removed from the Priority Watch List in January 2005.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Straits Times: Stop evading the serious issues facing S' pore, PM tells opposition.
Primr Minister Lee Hsien Loong last night called on the opposition to stop evading the serious issues facing Singapore in his first rally speech of the election campaign.
The Lianhe Zaobao: PM Lee questions opposition's ability to deal with the challenges of nation.
Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong, also the Secretary-General of the People's Action Party (PAP), challenged opposition last night to be serious about what they stand for and not evade the real issues facing Singaporeans.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA REGRETS USTR'S DECISION TO KEEP TAIWAN ON '301' WATCH LIST

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said Saturday that it regrets that Taiwan has been kept on the Watch List in the 2006 Special 301 Report by the Office of the United States Trade Representative (USTR).
However, MOEA officials vowed that Taiwan will continue to make efforts in stepping up protection of intellectual property rights (IPRs).

The USTR said in the latest report that it recognizes Taiwan's efforts to improve its IPR regime but urges it to deal more effectively with the unauthorized use of copyright materials on government and university computer networks as well as combat the production of pirated optical media and the proliferation of Internet piracy.

The Intellectual Property Office under the MOEA said that it has taken the USTR's decision in stride, noting that regardless of whether Taiwan is on the list or not, the most important thing is to continue to strengthen IPR enforcement actions against piracy and counterfeiting.
The Bureau of Foreign Trade (BOFT) said that it will continue to coordinate related government agencies to upgrade IPR protection and inform the U.S. about its latest progress.
BOFT officials said that they hope the U.S. will address the efforts made by Taiwan and remove it from the list soon.
Taiwan was one of the 34 countries included in the Watch List, meriting bilateral attention to address the underlying IPR problems, according to the USTR.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT: Los Angeles Times: L.A. Authorities Brace for Huge Immigration Marches. Two immigrant rights demonstrations Monday in Los Angeles could each draw a half-million marchers or more, police said Thursday, as officials expressed concern about a major disruption of traffic, commerce and school.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAISUGAR NEEDS TO PRIVATIZE: PRESIDENT CHEN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Saturday that the state=run Taiwan Sugar Corp. (Taisugar) has to pursue the path of privatization.
President Chen made the remarks while attending the 60th anniversary celebrations held at the headquarters of the company in the southern Taiwan city of Tainan.
The president lauded the role that Taisugar has played in the country's economic development, calling it a "prime mover" behind Taiwan's economic miracle.
In the 1950s and 1960s, revenue from the company's sugar exports accounted for 79 percent of Taiwan's foreign currency reserve revenues, the president said.
With the changing times during the 1970s, Taisugar, the largest land holder in Taiwan, began offering land to companies in the high-tech sector.
Noting that "a machine can get rusted after 60 years of use and require repair of its parts, " the president said Taisugar must "repair itself" by diversifying.
"Only reforms will bring opportunities, " the president said, adding that competition among enterprises will not stop and that Taiwan must catch up with the world trend of privatization.
Taisugar Chairman Yu Cheng-hsien said that the company has been losing money in recent years and that its target for this year is to achieve the "impossible mission" of breaking even.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN OFFERS COURSES FOR OFFICIALS FROM DIPLOMATIC ALLIES

TEXT.P: Two courses offered by a Republic of China government fund to government officials from the ROC's diplomatic allies and other developing countries friendly toward Taiwan concluded recently, with 55 officials from 37 countries participating in the courses, an ROC official said Saturday.

The two courses regarding Taiwan's economic development and the development of its small and medium enterprises were held April 12-25 by the International Cooperation and Development Fund (ICDF) under the supervision of the ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs.

In addition to inviting experts in related fields to give lectures to these foreign students, the organizer also arranged many visits to Taiwan's various economic establishments to strengthen their learning.

The ICDF holds some 20 courses each year regarding trade, economy, agriculture, information technology and telecommunications for the ROC's diplomatic allies and friendly developing countries to help train talent in these countries, thus strengthening bilateral cooperation and substantial ties.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. REAFFIRMS SAFETY OF BEEF EXPORTS
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 28 (CNA) (By Wennie Chi and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The recent discovery of bone fragments in a shipment of U.S. beef to Taiwan is an isolated incident and does not indicate that U.S. beef products are unsafe, a U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) official said Friday.
The USDA has started an investigation into the case to check for any possible packaging negligence, USDA spokesman Ed Loyd told the Central News Agency.

Taiwan authorities impounded a shipment of U.S. beef after rib bone fragments were discovered in the product Thursday. With the beef found to have been processed by a factory in Nebraska of the leading U.S. meat supplier, Tyson Fresh Meats, Taiwan's Department of Health decided that no beef products from the company will be allowed to be exported to Taiwan in the future.

The incident came just three months after Taiwan reopened its market to U.S. beef under strict regulations that allow only imports of boneless beef from animals under 30 months of age, a measure aimed at protecting consumers against mad cow disease.

In January, a spine fragment was found in a shipment of U.S. beef exports to Japan, prompting the Japanese government to reinstate a ban on imports of the product, less than two months after a previous ban was lifted.

On this issue, Loyd said this latest case in Taiwan is different from the one in Japan because the spine is believed to contain risky tissues known to carry the bovine spongiform encephalopathy (BSE) virus.
Taiwan banned beef imports from the United States in December 2003 after the discovery in Washington State of a single case of BSE.

In April 2005, Taiwan lifted the import ban on U.S. boneless beef from animals under 30 months of age, but again suspended American beef imports June 25 that same year after a second case of mad cow disease was confirmed in the U.S. earlier that month.
The second ban was lifted on Jan. 25, 2006.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'SYMBOL OF EXCELLENCE' REGISTRATION OPENS

TEXT.P: The registration period for the annual government-sponsored "Symbol of Excellence" (SOE) awards for best product design as well as most innovative and highest quality "made in Taiwan" products kicked off Saturday, with all Taiwan companies invited to enter, Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) officials said.

The semi-official TAITRA instituted the SOE program under the Ministry of Economic Affairs' (MOEA's) commission in 1993 to recognize the most exceptional Taiwan products and companies based on several criteria including research and development, design and innovation, quality systems, and brand awareness.
The SOE has since developed into a globally recognized sign of quality and innovative thinking.

This year, the SOE program will be combined with the National Award of Excellence, with the winners, which will be decorated with National Gold (or Silver) Awards of Excellence, to serve as the representatives of the Taiwan manufacturing industry in the international market, according to the TAITRA.

The award-winning products are expected to gain the endorsement of Microsoft chairman Bill Gates, Intel chief executive officer (CEO) Andy Grove and former Hewlett-Packard CEO Carly Fiorina, all of whom have been invited by the TAITRA to publicize Taiwan's SOE products this year, the council officials said.
The SOE registration period will run through May 26, with detailed information available by calling the TAITRA at (02) 2725-5200, ext. 1327.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI ZOO EDUCATION CENTER TOILETS WIN AWARD

TEXT.P: The public toilets at Taipei Zoo's education center have been recognized as the best in Taiwan in the recreation category, an official of Taipei City Government's Environmental Protection Bureau (EPB) said Saturday.

At a ceremony to present awards to the top 15 public toilet administrators and cleaners in the city, Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou hailed the Taipei Zoo administration for its eco-friendly management by recycling rainwater to clean the rest rooms.
The EPB has since 2003 conducted public lavatory evaluations at department stores, restaurants, theaters, religious and recreational facilities around Taipei.
EPB Director Chen Yung-jen noted that Taipei Zoo's winning of the award may encourage other public toilet administrators to follow suit with similar eco-friendly practices.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONSUMERS' FOUNDATION PRESSES FOR BAN ON U.S. BEEF

TEXT.P: The Consumers' Foundation urged the government Saturday to restore its ban on U.S. beef and remove the products from shelves immediately following the discovery of bone fragments in a recent shipment to Taiwan.

Officials at the foundation said that the incident reflects the potential risks of U.S. beef and that Taiwan should take immediate action to protect local consumers just as the Japanese government has recently done.

The Department of Health (DOH) decided Friday that no beef products from the leading U.S. meat supplier Tyson Fresh Meats will be allowed to be exported to Taiwan, after rib bone fragments were discovered a day earlier in a shipment of beef from the company.

The incident came just three months after Taiwan reopened its market to U.S. beef under strict regulations that allow only imports of boneless beef from animals under 30 months of age, a measure aimed at protecting consumers against mad cow disease.

The DOH's decision to ban only beef products from the supplier is lenient compared with move taken by Japan, which reinstated a ban on U.S. beef imports after a spine fragment was found in a shipment to the country in January. The Japanese government made the move less than two months after a previous ban was lifted.

The Consumers' Foundation officials pointed out that bone fragments were also found in a shipment of U.S. beef to Hong Kong earlier this month and that Japan has requested the U.S. government to explain if there is any problem with the quality control of the U.S. meat industry in light of the reoccurrence of similar incidents.

They said U.S. beef is not safe for consumers because the United States has not established a comprehensive biodata system for cattle raised in the country, while less than one percent of the U.S. cattle have been examined for mad cow disease.
Taiwan banned beef imports from the United States in December 2003 after the discovery in Washington State of a single case of mad cow disease.

In April 2005, Taiwan lifted the import ban on U.S. boneless beef from animals under 30 months of age, but again suspended American beef imports June 25 that same year after a second case of mad cow disease was confirmed in the U.S. earlier that month.
The second ban was lifted on Jan. 25, 2006.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW SPENT FUEL STORAGE FACILITY TO BE ADDED AT 1ST NUCLEAR PLANT: AEC

TEXT.P: The Atomic Energy Council (AEC) said Saturday that a new spent nuclear fuel dry storage facility will be installed at the nation's first nuclear power plant in September 2009 to increase the plant's spent fuel storage capacity.

An AEC specialist said that as the present spent fuel pool of the nuclear plant will be filled to capacity by 2010, the extra storage facility, with at least 25 concrete vaults and a maximum capacity of 1,400 spent rods, is urgently needed.

According to AEC documents, the dry storage vault --surrounded by additional steel, concrete, or other material-- can provide radiation shielding to workers and to the neighborhoods around the plant. On average, the annual radioactive levels outside the facility will not exceed 0.05mSv, or one-twentieth the acceptable level according to health regulations.
A Taiwan Power Co. spokesman said the company will apply for the construction permit this July, and if all go as planned, the storage facility will be fully operational by September 2009.

DOC.HEADLINE: FIRST LADY TO UNVEIL DETAILS ON STOCK, FUND HOLDINGS SALE NEXT WEEK

TEXT.P: The details on the profits first lady Wu Shu-jen has made in selling all her stocks and mutual fund holdings will be unveiled next week, the Presidential Office reaffirmed Saturday.

The Presidential Office said the previous day that Wu, under fire for her alleged involvement in several corruption scandals, will sell all her stocks and mutual fund investments and donate the profits to charities and disadvantaged groups.
The first lady will publish the details concerning her profits and which groups or organizations will receive the money, according to the latest statement by the Presidential Office.

The statement came on the heels of Friday's comments by Legislator Chiu Yi of the opposition Kuomintang who claimed after checking the Control Yuan report disclosing the assets of the public officials that nearly NT$30 million of the profits the first lady made on the stock market had "vanished."

Chiu claimed that before Wu put her assets into trust in March 2004, she had stocks worth NT$4 million, five kinds of mutual fund holdings amounting to NT$58 million, and bank deposits totalling NT$15 million. In 2005, she had only one fund left worth around NT$19 million, as well as stocks worth NT$12 million, and bank deposits of roughly the same amount as the previous year.

In 2006, Wu owned stocks worth NT$4 million, Chiu speculated, adding that after the first lady sold her mutual fund holdings, she used the NT$40 million to invest in the Fubon REITs No.1 fund, and that her bank deposits amounted to only NT$1.2 million.

Quoting the Control Yuan report, Chiu speculated that in 2005, Wu disposed of four types of mutual funds and should have made nearly NT$40 million. Even if she bought stocks amounting to NT$8 million, her bank deposits did not show any marked increase, Chiu noted, questioning where all the money had gone.
The first family put its assets into trust in April 2004 after the first lady was attacked for improperly engaging in stock trading during the run-up to the 2004 presidential election.

DOC.HEADLINE: PUBLIC POWER KEY TO WINNING E.U. SUPPORT FOR WHO BID: SCHOLARS

TEXT.P: Taiwan needs to do a better job of utilizing public, societal and media influence to win the European Union's support for Taiwan's World Health Organization (WHO) bid, scholars said in a forum held in Taipei Saturday.

"With governmental efforts suffering nine straight years of setbacks due to China's obstruction, the political side of Taiwan's WHO bid is a stalemate, " said Wu Chih-chung, a Soochow University assistant professor who also serves as secretary-general of the European Union Study Association, the organizer of the forum.

The best way to turn things around is to increase the E.U.'s understanding of Taiwan through different channels -- non-governmental organizations, research and exchange groups, media reports, and various forms of bilateral exchanges, Wu said.

"Taiwan also has to replace 'sentiment' (from China's obstruction) with confidence, showing people what it can do with its advanced medical expertise and experience in fighting SARS and avian flu to make contributions to the WHO, " said Betty Chiu, an assistant researcher of the National Health Research Institutes.
The United States and Japan have publicly voiced their support for Taiwan's WHO bid, which is encouraging news, Wu said.

"That makes winning the E.U.'s support even more critical. And there's no way we can't do it. Taiwan is the E.U.'s fourth largest trading partner in Asia and 10th largest trading partner in the world, " he added.
China is obviously the No.1 reason why the E.U. does not support Taiwan's bid in public, Wu said.
"Almost everyone we talked to said they thought Taiwan should be in the WHO, but whenever we brought up the 'one China policy, ' there was almost total silence," Wu said.
In addition, Taiwan has to make clear its objective and build domestic consensus, noted Liu Fu-kuo, a National Chengchi University professor.

"Taiwan needs to make sure whether it wants to bid for observer status in the World Health Assembly (WHA) -- the WHO's governing body, or for full membership under the name Republic of China, or under the name Taiwan. This can affect Taiwan's strategy," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP CHAIR CLARIFIES STANCE ON CONSTITUTIONAL REFORM

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) chairman said Saturday that constitutional reform discussions should first focus on establishing clear and comprehensive concepts in order to avoid the problems arising from previous piecemeal reform and to set a clear direction on which government system should be adopted.

Yu Shyi-kun made the remarks after his opposition to increasing the number of seats in the next Legislative Yuan from the originally planned 113 to 164 drew strong criticism from members of his own party.

It has been reported that several lawmakers from the DPP and opposition parties are planning to present a constitutional amendment proposal in May to increase the number of seats in the next legislature from 113 to 164. The proposal would come only one year after the passage of a package of constitutional amendments, including halving the number of legislative seats from the current 225, extending the tenure of legislators from three years to four years, and adopting a "single seat, two ballots" legislative electoral system.

Yu stressed that people should not renege on their promise of constitutional reform and should focus on strategies to elevate Taiwan's competitiveness and administrative efficiency for the benefit of the 23 million citizens of the country.

"If the proposed increase in the number of seats in the legislature is for the benefit of individual legislators, this will affect the DPP's image, " Yu said, adding that as the chairman, he should be responsible for the party's image.

The DPP has long been calling for constitutional reform but has maintained an open attitude on what kind of government system -- namely a presidential system or a parliamentary system -- should be adopted, Yu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: 800 KG OF JUNK COLLECTED ON MT. HOHUAN IN CLEAN-UP ACTIVITY

TEXT.P: About 800 kilograms of junk was picked up during a clean-up activity on Mount Hohuan in the eastern county of Hualien Saturday, according to the Taroko National Park Administration (TNPA).
The collected junk and garbage included waste paper and discarded bottles, tires, iron plates, and even a dumped scooter, they added.
The officials urged mountain climbers not to litter so as to prevent damage to the local ecology.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN MINISTER'S UAE VISIT COVERED BY MAJOR ARAB NEWSPAPER

TEXT.P: Taiwan gained media exposure in the United Arab Emirates (UAE) with the publishing in the influential Arab dailty Khaleej Times of a story Friday on the just-concluded visit to the country by Taiwan's foreign affairs minister.

The report, appearing at the top of the third page of the daily along with a photo featuring Foreign Affairs Minister Huang Chih-fang chatting with Khaleej Times President Mohammed A. R. Galadari, conveyed Huang's remarks revealing that Taiwan has a great interest in boosting economic and trade links with the UAE.

Huang arrived in Abu Dhabi April 25 with his wife and son to attend a ceremony marking the inauguration of a new flight route of China Airlines (CAL) -- Taiwan's main carrier -- that includes a stop in the UAE capital. Huang returned to Taipei Saturday.
The Friday report cited Huang as saying that despite the absence of diplomatic ties between Taiwan and the UAE, Taiwan is still keen on forging economic and trade relations with the UAE.

The 26-year-old Khaleej Times, known for its outspoken reporting, is one of the widest circulating newspapers in the Gulf region. It's owner, the Galadari Group, runs businesses in a wide range of fields, including automobiles, medical equipment and real estate.
Meanwhile, upon Huang's return to Taiwan Saturday, he clarified his UAE trip was paid for by the ministry, and not by CAL as had been reported in the local media.

The legislative caucus of the opposition People First Party demanded Friday for an explanation of whether CAL paid for the tickets and accommodation for Huang and his family, and argued that if so, Huang should resign immediately.
"The visit was an official mission, " the minister noted, adding that he paid for his son's plane ticket out of his own pocket.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER VOWS NO MEDDLING WITH POWER RATE ADJUSTMENTS

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang said Saturday the Executive Yuan respects the existing electricity rate adjustment mechanism and will not interfere with Taiwan Power Co.'s forthcoming rate hike plan.

Nevertheless, Su said it is hoped that the state-owned power company will not give preferential treatment to industrial users at the expense of household users and will refrain from offering unfair incentives to high electricity-consuming industries.
Su made the remarks while attending a ceremony marking the company's 60th founding anniversary.
Over the past 23 years, Su said, Taiwan Power Co. (Taipower) has never raised electricity rates despite frequent surges in commodity and raw material prices and has even lowered power rates 11 times.

"As fossil fuel prices have risen by leaps and bounds, Taipower has toiled for years at maintaining its low electricity pricing policy. But with crude oil prices soaring past US$70 per barrel, it can no longer afford to do so. And this is why few people dare to pan Taipower bluntly when the company revealed its power rate adjustment plan earlier this month," Su said.

Under the current governance system, Su said, Taipower is eligible to draft a power rate adjustment plan which will then be subject to a review by a special commission to be assembled by the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA).
As power rate adjustment involves professional calculation, Su said the Executive Yuan will respect the MOEA commission's decision and will refrain from any administrative interference.
Taipower is expected to unveil a detailed power rate adjustment scale in mid-May.

Su didn't give any hint on the Taipower's possible adjustment range. Instead, he stressed that as households account for only a small portion of electricity consumption, Taipower should not unfairly raise household electricity rates while offering incentives for large industrial users.

With a view to making the domestic power rate pricing formula more reasonable and congruent with the energy-saving policy, Su said Taipower should not offer preferential incentives to high electricity-consuming industries.
