La Repubblica: Black smoke for three rounds of vote in elections of Senate and House speakers.
The Italian new parliament failed to elect speakers of the Senate and the House of Deputies Friday after three rounds of vote. The definitive vote outcome is expected Saturday.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVER 11,000 SMOKERS AROUND TAIWAN SIGN UP FOR QUIT & WIN ACTIVITY

TEXT.P: Over 11,000 people around Taiwan have signed up for international "quit smoking" activity as of Saturday, with two days left before the registration period ends, according to the non-profit John Tung Foundation (JTF).

The Quit & Win competition, held every two years, is the world's only quit smoking event approved by the World Health Organization. Participating countries hold the activity during the same one-month period, with those people who are able to quit being entered into a prize draw in their respective countries.

The top prize in the international event is US$10,000 in cash, with Taiwan having an additional draw with a top prize of NT$600,000 (US$18,804) , according to the JTF which has been promoting an anti-smoking campaign on the island.

The JTF organized a promotional activity Saturday at a mass rapid transport station in downtown Taipei to try to attract more Taiwan smokers to participate in the "win-win" competition -- winning both money and health.
The registration period ends May 1, with the activity commencing the following day. Those interested can visit the contest Web site at www.quitandwin.org.tw or call the JTF for more information.

DOC.HEADLINE: VP, DPP CHIEF DENY TRYING TO DISTANCE THEMSELVES FROM PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Both Vice President Annette Lu and Chairman Yu Shyi-kun of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) dismissed reports Saturday that they want to distance themselves from the embattled first family in consideration of their own political futures.

Lu, in a speech given in the southern Taiwan port city of Kaohsiung, noted that the media have recently prominently reported the alleged involvement of the Presidential Office, including first lady Wu Shu-jen, in a number of corruption scandals.
However, she said, the credibility of the media reports is in fact questionable, with less than 50 percent of the reports being true.
The public "can read them, but they should not trust them entirely, "she said.

She noted that reports have said that the heavyweights of the DPP, including herself, have tried to distance themselves from President Chen Shui-bian, who is struggling with low approval ratings in the wake of a spate of scandals.
The heavyweights, who have aspirations for presidency in the 2008 election, want to stay clear of Chen at a time when the DPP's approval ratings have also slipped along with Chen's, the reports said.

Yu, in a meeting with grass-roots DPP members in Hsinchu, northern Taiwan, said Saturdaythat all the DPP members are "on the same boat, " and as the head of the party, he will not shirk his responsibility for the sake of his own interests.

Yu was responding to questions about his recent remarks that the first family should not hesitate to apologize if it has had some lapse of judgment or done wrong, giving rise to speculation that the harsh remarks were aimed at distancing himself from the president.

He explained that as the regulations requiring ranking officials to put their assets into trust are still not comprehensive, he had said that even if Wu had bought or sold stocks after putting her assets into trust, a move criticized by some as inappropriate, she should apologize if she was involved in any wrongdoing.
Yu said that the profits the first family has raked up are not illegal and that the first family has expressed that it will donate all the profits to charities and disadvantaged groups.

He said that the public has judged the first family and the DPP by the highest moral standards but has failed to apply the same standards to the main opposition Kuomintang. Although the public judges the DPP by stricter standards, he said, the party will accept this and "reflect upon itself and continue to engage in reforms."

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT WARNS PUBLIC ABOUT CHINA'S UNITED FRONT TACTICS

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu on Saturday warned the Taiwan people about China's united front tactics, which she said include the preferential treatment Beijing has offered Taiwan during a recent forum co-sponsored by Taiwan's opposition Kuomintang and the Communist Party of China.
Lu made the warning in a speech to a group of domestic veterinarians at a farmer's association in Taoyuan County.
The vice president said that China's offer of tariff-free treatment for Taiwan agricultural products is a ploy to confuse the international community into thinking that Taiwan is a part of China.

While Beijing continues to deploy more and more missiles targeting Taiwan, it has at the same time tried to promote political integration across the Taiwan Strait through the boosting of economic exchanges, Lu said.
"Actually, China is engaged in six kinds of warfare against Taiwan, " including military, economic, diplomatic and psychological warfare, Lu said.

She also blamed the outbreaks of foot-and-mouth disease and severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) in Taiwan in the last few years, as well as the threat of avian flu, on China's lax epidemic control and the close exchanges between the two sides of the strait.

Regarding the huge amount invested in China by Taiwanese business people, Lu said this has been harmful to Taiwan, citing the example of South Korea, whose investment in China over the past 11 years she claimed has led to the loss of 210,000 jobs in South Korea and the creation of 1 million jobs in China.

The situation is similar in Taiwan, Lu said, adding that the relocating of Taiwan plants to China has not only caused increasing unemployment rate on the island but has also significantly hindered Taiwan's economic development.

Politically, Lu added, Beijing is adopting a three-phase strategy to promote the unification of China and Taiwan by declaring first that there is only one China in the world and then stressing that the People's Republic of China is the sole legitimate government of China.

Finally, she said, China's preferential treatment is undermining Taiwan's image by confusing many in the international community into thinking that Taiwan is a part of China. She urged the Taiwan public not to fall into Beijing's traps.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN CAREGIVERS TEND TO HAVE MORE PHYSICAL, MENTAL PROBLEMS: SURVEY

TEXT.P: Foreign caregivers tend to have more physical and mental problems than their local counterparts because of their heavy workload, according to a survey unveiled Saturday.

The survey was conducted by National Yangming University professor Yang Cheng-chang, who interviewed 481 female caregivers, including 212 local and 269 foreign caregivers, working in hospitals, nursing homes or family residences around the island.
Yang found that the foreign caregivers are 30 years of age on average, or 17 years younger than their local counterparts.

Although the foreign caregivers are younger and have a higher level of education, nearly half of them have not received related training, Yang said, adding that they are also more susceptible than their local counterparts to exploitation.
Nearly 60 percent of the foreign caregivers surveyed said that they work more than 12 hours a day and that they have to take on many different kinds of tasks in their jobs.

Among all the respondents, a higher ratio of foreign caregivers complained about having experienced headaches, dizziness, lower back pain or sore muscles. Six times more foreign caregivers than local caregivers complained of irregular menstrual period.
Yang said that in addition to having to work long hours for low pay, the foreign caregivers also have to deal with the language barrier and working in a strange land.
He suggested that the government pay more attention and show more concern for the physical and mental health of foreign caregivers in conducting its annual health checkups.

Yang said that he decided to carry out a study on the physical and mental health of female caretakers in Taiwan after an incident three years ago in which Liu Hsia, a wheelchair-bound writer, was beaten to death by her Indonesian caregiver who was later found to be mentally unstable.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ADVANCES IN COMBINED SERVICES OPERATIONS: EX-U.S. COMMANDER

TEXT.P: Taiwan's armed forces have made substantial progress in its combined services operations and defense capabilities, a retired U.S. admiral said in Taipei Saturday.
Former U.S. Pacific Command Commander Adm. Dennis C. Blair made the remarks in a speech delivered at a seminar on Taiwan's defense reform and combined services operation strategies.

Blair is in Taipei at the head of a delegation of U.S. active and retired military personnel to observe computerized war game simulation as part of this year's "Han Kuang 22" military exercise that began this week.
In the past few years, Blair said, Taiwan's annual "Han Kuang" series of military exercises has been devoted to honing combined services operation strategies and tactics.
According to Blair, the Taiwan military has made remarkable advances in its combined services operations and defense abilities.

Noting that Taiwan is basically in a defense posture, with China as its main potential enemy, Blair said Taiwan-developed combined services operational rules are only suited for Taiwan's specific needs.

In his view, Blair said Taiwan outpaces the United States in some combined services operations management methods. In Taiwan, both ballistic missile units and jet fighters are under the command of the Air Force, which requires its fighter pilots and air defense missile personnel to receive training together.

Blair said such an arrangement is an effective and highly efficient integration system. In the United States, combined services operations are undertaken by different military branches and require additional communications and training. According to Blair, the U.S. military has not been fully satisfied with the development of its combined services operation prowess.

Stressing that consistence, well-designed integrating procedures and well-trained personnel are key to successful combined services operations, Blair said there is still room for Taiwan to improve its military equipment, integrating procedures and training in combined services operations.
Meanwhile, Blair said he doesn't think that China could use military force to realize its goal of unifying the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

With China's present military might and possible U.S. support for Taiwan in the event of an attack from China, Blair said China is not likely to realize its unfiication goal by brute force at the moment.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN MINISTER MAY MEET WITH U.S. ENVOY ON TRANSIT REQUESTS

TEXT.P: Minister of Foreign Affairs Huang Chih-fang said Saturday that if necessary, he will meet with the U.S. representative in Taipei this weekend to discuss President Chen Shui-bian's U.S. layover plan.

Based on a tacit understanding with U.S. authorities, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) waited until after Chinese President Hu Jintao wrapped up his U.S. visit last week to file President Chen's request for transit stops during his upcoming Latin America visit.

The ministry informed Stephen Young, director of the Taipei Office of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT), April 24 of Chen's transit request. The ministry originally expected to receive a U.S. reply by Saturday morning. Much to its disappointment, the reply has failed to come as expected.
Given the longstanding friendship between the two countries, Huang said he doesn't think that the United States would make things hard for Taiwan.

"I'm convinced that the United States would understand Taiwan's situation and reach a consensus with us on President Chen's transit plan," Huang said, adding that if necessary, he will hold talks with Young on the issue Saturday or Sunday.
Chen is scheduled to depart Taipei May 3 for Paraguay. He will later visit Costa Rica for the inauguration of President-elect Oscar Arias before returning to Taipei May 11.

Taiwan hopes that Chen will be able to make a stopover on the west coast or southern part of the United States on his way to Latin America and make a stopover in New York or on the U.S. west coast on his way back to Taiwan, according to a previous report from Washington, D.C.
According to local media reports, New York is a priority choice and Hawaii is not on the "dream" list.
The Presidential Office is scheduled to announce the itinerary of Chen's forthcoming Latin America visit, including the U.S. transit destinations.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA PANS CHINA FOR CHOKING PREMIER'S HAITI VISIT

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) panned China Saturday over its obstruction of Premier Su Tseng-chang's planned visit to Haiti in mid-May.
President Chen Shui-bian originally designated Premier Su to serve as his special envoy to attend Haitian President-elect Rene Preval's inauguration scheduled for May 14.

However, Preval politely informed Taiwan's embassy in Haiti Saturday that China has pressured Haiti through U.N. channels not to invite Su to attend his inauguration. Otherwise, China threatened to retaliate when the U.N. Security Council discusses in August whether to extend the peacekeeping mission in Haiti.
As a permanent member of the U.N. Security Council, China can veto the council's decision.

For Haiti's security and future development, Preval suggested that Taiwan follow Japan in sending a lower-ranking official to attend his inauguration. Japan will send the chief secretary of its foreign ministry to attend the Preval's inauguration.
In his message, Preval also made the assurance that during his tenure, Haiti will maintain its diplomatic ties with Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: U.N. Agency Says Iran Falls Short on Nuclear Data
Iran has drastically curtailed cooperation with nuclear inspectors over the past month as it has sped forward with its nuclear enrichment, the International Atomic Energy Agency said Friday. Striking an unusually bleak tone in an e ight-page report requested by the Security Council, the United Nations nuclear agency also documented its increasing difficulty in monitoring Iran's activities, and Iran's refusal to answer questions about suspected links between its civilian program and its military one. For the first time, the agency stated that Iran had begun enriching uranium on a small scale, confirming Tehran's boasts.
Wall Street Journal: Creative Financing, Defying the Odds, Hedge Funds Bet Billions on Movies
For decades, movie studios have gladly accepted millions of dollars from a group of investors collectively dismissed as "dumb money": deep- pocketed dentists, oil tycoons and other wealthy individuals eager for a piece of the glamorous, but high-risk, game of film production. But the biggest influx of money in Hollywood these days is coming from sharks, not suckers: hedge funds, private-equity funds and investment banks. Over the past two years, these investors have provided more than US$4 billion in movie financing to the major film studios, perhaps the biggest flood of outside investment money ever. Their beneficiaries range from Walt Disney Co. and Sony Corp.'s Sony Pictures Entertainment to the actor Richard Gere, who is trying to raise more than US$50 million to finance a series of movies he wants to produce. The new players are doing more than just lending Hollywood money, as Wall Street has in the past. In a rapidly changing world of distribution, they are betting big on movies by claiming a share of the revenue after certain costs from movie tickets, DVDs, pay-television sales and related merchandise. While it's too soon to judge how the newcomers will fare, early indicators suggest that the returns may be modest at best.

DOC.HEADLINE: REPLACEMENT TO BE PICKED TO ATTEND HAITI'S PRESIDENTIAL INAUGURATION

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Sunday the government will select a pertinent official to replace Premier Su Tseng-chang to attend Haitian President-elect Rene Preval's inauguration.
President Chen Shui-bian originally designated Premier Su to serve as his special envoy to attend Preval's inauguration scheduled for May 14.

However, Preval politely informed Taiwan's embassy in Haiti Saturday that China has pressured Haiti through U.N. and other international channels not to invite Su to attend his inauguration. Otherwise, China threatened to retaliate when the U.N. Security Council deliberates in August whether to extend its peacekeeping mission in Haiti. As a permanent member of the U.N. Security Council, China can veto the council's decision.

For Haiti's security and future development, Preval suggested that Taiwan follow Japan in sending a lower-ranking official to attend his inauguration. Japan will send the chief secretary of its foreign ministry to attend the Preval's inauguration.
Terming himself a faithful friend of Taiwan, Preval made assurances in his message that Haiti will maintain its diplomatic relations with Taiwan during his tenure.
MOFA officials said the government fully understand Haiti's quagmire and will comply with its expectation by choosing a pertinent replacement to attend Preval's inauguration.
When the time is right, the officials said the ministry will also arrange for Premier Su to visit Taiwan's other diplomatic allies in the Caribbean region.
Meanwhile, the ministry panned China for choking Su's Haiti travel plan, saying its move has gravely impaired Haiti's national dignity and hurt Taiwan people's feelings.
Noting that Taiwan and Haiti have maintained diplomatic relations for more than half a century, the ministry said China's domineering attitude and bulling act will boomerang.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, April 30, or the third day of the fourth month of the Year of the Dog according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1770: David Thompson, the Canadian explorer who followed the Columbia River to its mouth in 1881 and mapped much of western Canada, is born in England.
1777: Karl Friedrich Gauss, the German mathematician and astronomer known for his contributions to algebra, differential geometry, probability theory and number theory, is born in Germany.
1789: George Washington is inaugurated as the first president of the United States in a ceremony at Federal Hall in New York.
1803: The United States buys Louisiana Territory and New Orleans from the French.
1893: Joachim von Ribbentrop, the German politician who was Adolf Hitler's foreign minister, is born.
1900: The republic of Hawaii cedes itself to the United States.
1909: Juliana, queen of the Netherlands from 1948, is born. She abdicated this day in 1980 in favor of her daughter Beatrix.
1919: The Paris Peace Conference allows Japan to take over Germany's prewar rights in China's Shantung Province, whereupon China leaves the conference.
1945: Adolf Hitler, the German dictator known as "Der Fuhrer" who reduced his country and much of Europe to ashes, commits suicide with his mistress Eva Braun after bidding farewell to the few aides remaining with him in his Berlin bunker hideaway.
1946: The national government of the Republic of China issues an order moving the national capital back to Nanking from Chungking.
1948: A total of 21 American nations sign the "Charter of Bogota," setting up the Organization of American States (OAS).
1957: Egypt reopens the Suez Canal to traffic.
1967: Muhammad Ali, who first won the world heavyweight boxing crown as Cassius Clay in 1964, is stripped of his title for refusing to be drafted into the U.S. armed forces.
1968: ROC President Chiang Kai-shek approves a set of "Guidelines for the Lives of Citizens" drafted by the National Committee of Chinese Cultural Renaissance Movement.
1973: U.S. President Richard Nixon accepts responsibility for the bugging that took place at the Watergate apartment complex in 1972.
1974: Adm. Maurice F. Weisner, commander in chief of the U.S. Pacific Fleet, arrives in Taipei for a four-day visit.
1975: The Vietnam War ends with South Vietnam's surrender to the communists after North Vietnamese tanks capture the Presidential Office in Saigon.
1977: Public and private buses begin joint operations in Taipei City.
1989: Finance Minister Shirley Kuo leads an ROC delegation to the 22nd annual Asian Development Bank meeting in Beijing.
1990: Elected ROC officials of all levels are permitted to make private visits to mainland China during recesses. Veterans who were stranded on the mainland after the nationalist government moved to Taiwan in 1949 are allowed to apply for resettlement in Taiwan.
1991: Cyclone hits Bangladesh, killing more than 125,000 people.
1991: ROC President Lee Teng-hui declares the termination of the Period of National Mobilization for Suppression of the Communist Rebellion, effective May 1. He abolishes the Temporary Provisions and promulgates the Additional Articles of the Constitution, also effective May 1.
1997: Trains collide at Rongchiawan Station in Yuehyang City, in mainland China's Hunan Province, killing 58 people and injuring hundreds of others.
1998: Secessionist rebels sign a permanent ceasefire with the Papua New Guinea government to end a nine-year rebellion on the South Pacific Island of Bougainville.
2000: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou inaugurates Taiwan's first tap water museum.
2001: The Second Asian Physics Olympiad concludes in Taipei after more than 10 days of competition with Seven gold medals, five silvers and 11 bronzes, as well as 16 honorary citations awarded to the winners.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "If a man takes no thought for the morrow, he will be sorry before the day is out."

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE PRESIDENT'S ACTIONS NOT AS GOOD AS WORDS: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang said Sunday that China has relentlessly strangled Taiwan's activities in the international community and that Chinese President Hu Jintao's actions are not as good as his words.

Commenting on China's obstruction of his planned visit to Haiti in mid-May, Su said Hu's promise to "let Taiwan have larger space to maneuver in the international community, " made during a meeting in Beijing with opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Honorary Chairman Lien Chan in mid-April has proved to be a bounced check in less than a month.
Su called for the Taiwan public to be more vigilant against the plots of Beijing, which he said has tried every possible means to oppress and contain Taiwan on the world stage.
President Chen Shui-bian has designated Su to serve as his envoy to attend Haitian President-elect Rene Preval's inauguration scheduled for May 14.

However, Preval informed Taiwan's embassy in Haiti Saturday that China has pressured Haiti through U.N. channels not to invite Su and has threatened to retaliate when the U.N. Security Council discusses in August whether to extend the peacekeeping mission in Haiti.
As a permanent member of the U.N. Security Council, China can veto the council's decision.

For Haiti's security and future development, Preval suggested that Taiwan follow Japan in sending a lower-ranking official to attend his inauguration. Japan will send the chief secretary of its Foreign Ministry to attend the Preval inauguration.
In his message, Preval also gave his assurance that during his tenure, Haiti will maintain its diplomatic ties with Taiwan.
The Ministry of Foreign Affairs said earlier in the day that the government will select a suitable official to replace Su at the inauguration.
Noting that Taiwan and Haiti have maintained diplomatic relations for more than half a century, ministry officials said China's domineering attitude and bullying will boomerang.

Meanwhile, Yeh Yi-chin, a ruling Democratic Progressive Party legislative caucus whip, said Beijing's efforts to contain Taiwan in the international community have not relented even slightly after the Lien-Hu meeting, during which the Chinese president said he will see to it that Taiwan is allowed more room on the world stage.

Yeh blasted the meeting has having proved meaningless and she called for the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT, the People First Party and the New Party not to harbor any illusions about Beijing any longer.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT URGED TO PROMULGATE AMENDED LAW FOR PROBE INTO 319 SHOOTING

TEXT.P: The legislative caucus of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) urged President Chen Shui-bian Sunday to sign and promulgate a newly passed amendment to provide for the establishment of a commission to probe the March 19, 2004 shooting of the president and the vice president.

The opposition-controlled legislature amended the Organic Statute for the 319 Shooting Truth Investigation Commission in early April in accordance with a ruling by the Council of Grand Justices that some clauses in the original version of the law were unconstitutional. The amendment was then submitted to the president for his signature.

At a press conference at the Legislative Yuan, KMT caucus whip Pan Wei-kang disclosed that instead of promulgating the amendment into law, the president again said last Friday that some clauses are still unconstitutional and should be either further amended or referred to the grand justices for their views on its constitutionality.

Pan claimed the president's move to block the legislation apparently shows that he "simply does not have a clear conscience" because, as the major victim of the 319 shooting, he should be the person most anxious to get to the bottom of the incident.

She said the legislature has already responded to the Council of Grand Justices by making necessary changes to the clauses in question, and that it is now up to the president to promulgate the amended law within 10 days from receiving it in accordance with Article 72 of the Constitution.
The KMT legislator said the president has no right to give instructions or ask the legislature to change the law again.

The statute is intended to provide a legal basis for the establishment of a 17-member commission to probe the shooting of Chen and Vice President Annette Lu on the eve of the 2004 presidential election.

In late 2004, the grand justices ruled that the original statute and a commission formed to investigate the March 19 shooting were unconstitutional because some articles in the statute would give the commission the same powers as those of prosecutors in carrying out investigations into the shooting and prosecuting those responsible.

The opposition legislators amended the statute, which would require that the commission's 17 members be recommended by the various political parties in proportion to the number of seats they hold in the legislature.

According to the amended law, legislators and members of the Control Yuan -- the highest watchdog body -- cannot serve on the commission, whose members should be impartial people equipped with the right expertise.

These members will be appointed by the Legislative Yuan speaker. If any party fails to recommend its own nominees, it will be seen as giving up its rights and the vacancies will be filled by nominations made by the commission's convener, subject to the approval of the legislature.

The commission will answer to the people only and will not be controlled by any government or law enforcement agencies. Its members will have the right to ask any organization to provide documents and evidence for its examination. Failure to cooperate could lead to a fine of up to NT$100,000.

After beginning its investigation, the commission will submit a written report to the Legislative Yuan and the Control Yuan every three months. If anyone is found to have committed a criminal offense, the commission will refer him or her to either public prosecutors or military prosecutors. The investigation is expected to be completed in six months.

The March 19 shooting occurred when the president and vice president were campaigning in a jeep in Tainan, southern Taiwan. The opposition believes the incident generated sympathy votes for Chen and Lu, helping them to win the election by a mere 29,500 votes.

It also suspects that the incident was staged, and their demand to form a commission to investigate the shooting has met strong opposition from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and its ally, the Taiwan Solidarity Union.

DOC.HEADLINE: AMENDING CONSTITUTION MAY NOT BE PANACEA FOR REFORM: KMT HEAD

TEXT.P: Amending the Constitution is not necessarily the cure-all for Taiwan's political reform, opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou said Sunday.

In a speech at a symposium titled "The Growth of Constitutional Democracy and Its Challenges," held by the National Policy Foundation at National Taiwan University, Ma said the Constitution should not be treated as a scapegoat for Taiwan's problems.
"There is no urgency for amending the Constitution. What's important is to observe and implement the Constitution," Ma said.
He pointed out that during the past 15 years, the Constitution has been amended seven times -- a rare phenomenon for any democratic country.

Ma said there are many burning issues that need to be addressed, including finding ways to prevent Taiwan's economy from being marginalized, to help less privileged people through their financial difficulties and prevent them from committing suicide, and to assist "credit card slaves" in solving their debt problems.
He blamed the multitude of problems plaguing Taiwan today on the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) failing to observe the Constitution and disregarding the spirit of democracy.

Ma promised that unlike the DPP, the KMT -- if it becomes the ruling party in 2008 but does not have a majority in the legislature -- will allow the opposition party that controls the legislature to nominate the premier.

The KMT chairman, who also serves as Taipei mayor, said the spirit of the Constitution is to allow the form of government to switch from the presidential system to the Cabinet system when the ruling party does not hold more than half of the seats in the legislature.

DOC.HEADLINE: GERMAN FIRM LOOKING FOR TAIWANESE OEM

TEXT.P: A leading German car accessory and component company is looking for Taiwanese manufacturers to produce their original equipment, a spokesman for the Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) said Saturday.

The spokesman said that Continental Corp., at the request of TAITRA, has joined other multinational companies that are considered heavy buyers of Taiwan products in searching for local trade partners. Its Asian procurement center will organize a conference Wednesday to find potential original equipment manufacturers (OEM) in Taiwan.
Continental Corp. employs 81,000 staff around the world. It has three departments -- tires, brake system and chassis components, and technical elastomers.
Continental's sales in 2005 reached 13.8 billion euros (US$11.32 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGAL AID FOUNDATION SERVES AS `NOT JUST A GOD'By Deborah Kuo

TEXT.P: CNA staff reporter

Taipei, April 30 (CNA) Writing from her home in Vietnam, Nguyen Thi Tham has told the attorneys who helped her gain access to legal aid in Taiwan after her left hand was badly injured in a factory accident that she has passed the college entrance exam to major in law.
"Now I have an opportunity to be a lawyer and help people who have had similar traumatic experiences to mine," she wrote.
When she was living in Taiwan, Nguyen, 22, was among the most socially disadvantaged people in Taiwan -- a foreign laborer.

In an interview with a cable TV station in Taipei after the accident in 2005, Nguyen said in her newly learned mandarin Chinese that "there were very few factories in Vietnam where I could work and make money, so I came to Taiwan hoping that I could contribute to the family as dad is too old to work, mom is illiterate and the only person to take care of father and my younger brother is studying at university and needs financial support."

In early 2004, she recalled, a labor brokerage company told her she could make a basic monthly wage of NT$15,840 (US$487) working in a Taiwan factory for eight hours a day. She flew to the southern port city of Kaohsiung with a happy heart and high expectations.

To her chagrin, she said, she was paid only a little over NT$7,000 per month, working 16 hours a day in a battery factory, and had to pay rent, water and electricity bills as well as her transportation costs.
Worried that with such a tiny wage she would never be able to repay the NT$160,000 brokerage fee that her family had borrowed so she could come to Taiwan, Nguyen decided to abscond from the factory.

She landed a job at a sheet metal factory in northern Taiwan, where the unscrupulous owner dared to hire absconded foreign workers. The owner agreed to pay her NT$15,000 a month and put her to work immediately, but without showing her how to operate the cutting and pressing machines.
A strong-willed girl, Nguyen thought that if other people could do it, so could she. So she stayed and worked.

The tragedy occurred three months later when a heavy part of a pressing machine dropped from a height directly on to her left hand smashing her fingers and pinning her for 30 minutes until she could be freed. "I cried and yelled, but the boss remained unmoved, saying only that he could not remove the machine," she said.

Nguyen had no health insurance and her boss demanded that she check out from the hospital two and a half days later. Unnerved and underrepresented, with her wounds beginning to fester, Nguyen was despondent until a Vietnamese friend told her to call Father Peter Van Hung Nguyen from a Vietnamese expatriate service office in Hsinchu operated by the Taiwan International Workers Association.

With Father Nguyen' s assistance, she returned to the hospital, where she received skin grafts. Father Nguyen said that had she not contacted his office for help, she would have been reported by her boss and would have been deported immediately because she was an illegal worker and a runaway.

Father Nguyen, who has handled several similar cases over the past few years and has consequently become the talk among Vietnamese expats in Taiwan, now sees more and more such workers in trouble and seeking his help. As a result, he said, he has been playing the role of a go-between in helping Vietnamese people seek redress from Taiwan's public offices, particularly the non-profit Legal Aid Foundation (LAF) financed by the Judicial Yuan.

He cooperated with LAF attorneys to win a lawsuit against the sheet metal factory owner and forced him to pay for Nguyen's medical bills, as well as compensation for her injuries, before she returned to Vietnam.
In the TV interview, Nguyen recalled that when she told her brother about her plight, he "wailed and howled on the other end of the phone."

Ah-hsiung is another case in which LAF attorneys helped to obtain justice and compensation for near-fatal workplace injuries. An aboriginal blue-collar worker in his early 40s, Ah-hsiung fell from a construction site about two stories high. His bare head hit iron bars scattered on the ground, leaving him brain damaged and in a coma from which he has not emerged. After he was declared a vegetable by the hospital, his boss deserted him.

Ah-hsiung was at least lucky enough to have his older brother and the brother's wife to take care of him. Financially strapped and physically exhausted because of the non-stop nursing Ah-hsiung required, the brother and his wife approached the LAF for help, mainly aimed at seeking justice and compensation from Ah-hsiung's boss.
The construction company owner paid Ah-hsiung's medical bills and compensation after he lost the lawsuit filed against him by a LAF attorney.
At the beginning of May 2005, a Vietnamese housemaid screamed for help at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport as she was being deported but refused to succumb to injustice.

When Father Nguyen was asked to come to the airport to translate for the young lady, who was unwilling to be deported, he unearthed one of the most scandalous crimes in Taiwan involving a labor brokerage company in Tainan.

The father-and-son management team of the brokerage company was accused of sexually assaulting each foreign maid they introduced to local households in southern Taiwan. The two men controlled the foreign maids by having them sign papers in Chinese, which the foreign nationals did not understand, with a line indicating that they are "willing to do anything for the person in charge" and by withholding their wages.

None of the victims dared to report them because they were afraid they would be deported if the scandal came to light. In addition, most of them came to Taiwan with debts and they could not afford to be deported and return home with no money. As of Sept. 5, 2005, the number of victims in the case had risen to 26, with the actual number believed to be as high as 40 or 50.
The LAF provided the victims with legal aid by filing lawsuits for them and demanding compensation for damages as well as payment of withheld salaries.
At the beginning of August 2004, the LAF received a phone call from Lanyu (Orchid) island saying that around 30 Lanyu villagers had not been paid their salaries.

Traveling to Taiwan proper is costly for the Lanyu people, most of whom are members of the aboriginal Tao tribe, and they were unable to go to Hualien, eastern Taiwan, where a LAF branch was established in April 2004. LAF attorneys from Taipei therefore decided to go to the small island.

During their two-day trip, they visited four villages around Lanyu and received 45 applications in regard to 34 labor disputes, seven land issues and four other controversies. Most of them were caused by the conflict of Tao customs with modern regulations.

"As I saw the Tao people diligently listening and trying to understand the concept of legal aid, anxiously completing the forms and trying to discuss their issues with us in their minimal Mandarin, I suddenly realized the value of our existence and of the foundation, " wrote an attorney in a report published in a LAF journal.

"Perhaps Lanyu needs a court that understands the Tao customs, or Lanyu can consider returning autonomy to the indigenous people to allow the elders to maintain order among themselves, " the attorney wrote.
The motto of the Legal Aid Foundation is to defend the people's rights to access the court system regardless of their financial conditions.

Describing the purposes of the foundation's establishment, which became operational in July 2004, LAF Secretary-General Jerry Cheng said that the provision of legal aid "helps people uphold their constitutionally protected rights to access the court system."

In July 1999, the National Judicial Reform Conference approved an agenda to promote the creation of a legal aid system in Taiwan. In the following two years, members of the Judicial Reform Foundation, the Taipei Bar Association and the Taipei Society formed an alliance to promote smooth passage of the Legal Aid Act.

The act was passed in December 2003 and promulgated by President Chen Shui-bian in early 2004. Under the act, the Legal Aid Foundation was established in April 2004, with the Executive Yuan promising to contribute NT$500 million (US$15.4 million) to the foundation each year and another NT$500 million for operational costs annually, in addition to the Judicial Yuan's annual appropriation.

In order to serve all the people around the country and enable everybody to have access to legal aid, the foundation has continued to increase the number of its branch offices nationwide -- from the inaugural five to 19 as of early 2006.

Because indigent people are often physically or mentally incapacitated or disturbed when they run into legal problems, Cheng said, when branch offices are established to help applicants complete their applications, the attorneys and staff members are required to serve in a friendly and approachable manner.

The establishment of the LAF and its branches has been good news for socially and financially disadvantaged groups, which include laborers, women, children and indigenous people, Cheng said, adding that when these groups of people need legal advice, representation in civil, administrative or criminal proceedings or assistance in the drafting of legal documents, they should contact the foundation for help.

The foundation has since committed to assisting disadvantaged persons in enforcing their constitutionally protected right of access to the court system by implementing the ideal of a "people's judiciary," thereby contributing to the building of a just society.

According to Hsu Yu-lan, an LAF director of general affairs, more than half of the country's lawyers -- about 2,300 -- have signed on as LAF volunteer attorneys. They work as "volunteers" because they are paid only about half or one-third of costs that otherwise would be charged for similar cases, Hsu said.

The foundation and its branches have accepted around 40,000 applications since its inception. Of the total, 16,834 applicants have been granted complete legal aid free of charge and 10,927 have been provided with free legal consultation.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Senate and House speakers elected.
Franco Marini and Fausto Bertinotti were elected speakers of the Senate and House of Deputies respectively Saturday in the show- down vote at the parliament after three rounds of ballots that failed to elect the parliamentary leaders a day earlier. The elections of Marini and Bertinotti paved the way for the center-left coalition "Union" leader Romano Prodi to form a new government.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW REAGENT FOR TB DEVELOPED

TEXT.P: An official from National Taiwan University Hospital (NTUH) announced Sunday that the hospital has developed a fast detection reagent for tuberculosis (TB).
Dr. Hseuh Po-Ren said the new reagent -- with an accuracy of 99.5 percent and a detection time of just three hours -- can provide great assistance in determining TB infection.
Hseuh noted that the fast reagent, which costs only several hundred NT dollars, is also much cheaper than the traditional method, which costs about NT$2,000.
In the past, the detection of TB usually took two months or more -- too long to prevent the spread of infection or treat the disease in the early stages.

DOC.HEADLINE: FLOOD PREVENTION CAMPAIGN TO BEGIN

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang urged the Water Resource Agency under the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) Sunday to integrate mobile water pumps and deploy them quickly where needed.
Su made the statement during a flood prevention inspection in Tainan County, southern Taiwan.
Su said that this year's flood prevention campaign starts Monday and he expressed hope that each local government will ensure that their pumps are ready for use.

Taiwan is hit by several typhoons every year on average and experiences torrential rain several times a year. These disasters cause average losses of more than NT$12.8 billion annually, according to a report made by Su at the Legislative Yuan in March.

In that report, Su said the government needs NT$116 billion (US$3.56 billion) to carry out flood-prevention projects. The first stage of the projects that begins this year and will run until the end of 2007, will need more than NT$30.96 billion.
Su said the projects include dredging and managing of major rivers in 21 counties and cities, construction of 115 district drainage systems and building five special seawalls.
Taiwan's flood-affected areas cover about 1,150 square kilometers of coastal land in Yilan, Taipei, Changhua, Yunlin, Chiayi, Tainan and Kaohsiung counties.

DOC.HEADLINE: ONE HUNDRED GROUPS SIGN UP TO SUPPORT 'SPANK OUT DAY'

TEXT.P: One hundred social groups in Taiwan signed up Sunday to support "International Spank Out Day" which was initiated in 1998 by EPOCH-USA to bring widespread attention to its desire to end physical punishment of children.

Members of the Taiwan civil groups, led by the Humanistic Education Foundation (HEF) , called for Taiwan parents and teachers not to spank their children or students, while offering educational information to parents and caregivers about non-violent discipline alternatives.

The group members suggested that instead of smacking upon a sudden impulse, make a phone call for educational consultation, exchange pithy formulas encouraging non-violent solutions, particularly during periods of anger, and seek supporting resources to help stop resorting to violence.

Minister of Education Tu Cheng-sheng, who was among several celebrities invited by the HEF to offer their "pithy formulas" to beef up April 30 "International Spank Out Day, " said: "Respect and understand children to avoid treating them violently."
Yu Lin, principal of the Tahchih Senior High School of Taipei, offered: "Giving the kids a big hand is better than giving them a smack."
Cheng Li-chun, chairwoman of the National Youth Commission, offered: "I understand what you mean, please don't spank me."
Former Democratic Progressive Party Legislator Tuan Yi-kang said: "One less child spanked, one more healthy spirit born."
Chin Heng-wei, editor-in-chief of Contemporary magazine said: "Whenever we spare the rod, we begin to become civilized."
Taipei Deputy Mayor Chin Pu-tsung said: "Hands are created to pass love, not to spank."
Public Television Service President Hu Yuan-hui said: "When the rod is spared, zero is the distance between parents and children."

HEF officials said that various countries around the world, including the United States, Hong Kong, Kenya, Cameroon, the United Kingdom, Canada, New Zealand, India and Sri Lanka, have held various events and programs every year to observe the "Spank Out Day, " which sometimes is also called "No Hitting Day, " "No Smacking Day" or "Day of Non-Violence for Children."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN INAUGURATES ASIA'S FIRST SUGAR INDUSTRY MUSEUM

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Sugar Industry Museum -- the first of its kind in Asia -- was inaugurated Sunday on an historical site of the state-run Taiwan Sugar Corporation's (Taisugar's) 105-year-old sugar mill in Chiaotou township in Kaohsiung County.

Kaohsiung County Magistrate Yang Chiu-hsing, Taisugar Chairman Yu Cheng-hsien, Chiaotou township head Hsu Chung-ming, Legislator Chao Liang-yen and several other business leaders took part in the museum's opening ceremony.
In his opening remarks, Yu said the museum is intended to let the people understand the history of Taiwan's sugar industry and its close relationship with Taiwan's economic development.
Yu said that entry to the museum in the next three months will be free. He added that the second and third stages of the construction project will turn the museum complex into a tourist resort.
Yang expressed the hope that the new addition to Kaohsiung County will attract more tourists, create a boom for local leisure industries and promote the development of indigenous arts and culture.

The museum complex covers 16 hectares. Inside the museum is a sugar mill that displays the machinery and entire sugar-making process, plus an audio-visal center for briefing visitors about the development of Taiwan's sugar industry. Next to the museum are 19 historical relics and a railway for transporting sugar cane and semi-finished products.
A village of arts will be built next to the museum to provide an environment where domestic and international artists can exercise their creative power.

Chiaotou Sugar Plant, set up in 1901 by the Japanese, was the first modern sugar mill in Taiwan. It became the leading industry in Taiwan for decades. In the 1950s and 1960s, sugar was Taiwan's No. 1 export, earning 74 percent of Taiwan's foreign currency revenue. The plant suffered hard times in the 1980s and closed shop in 1999.

DOC.HEADLINE: COA TO PUBLISH GUIDE ON TAIWAN'S CHICKEN CUISINE

TEXT.P: The Council of Agriculture (COA) , under the Executive Yuan, is promoting Taiwanese chicken by publishing a chicken-cuisine guide featuring restaurants around Taiwan that specialize in cooking chicken, a COA spokesman said Sunday.
The spokesman said the COA would welcome anyone wishing to contribute information regarding restaurants known for their chicken dishes, the spokesman said.
He said Taiwanese chicken still has a more-than 80 percent local market share because of its quality, despite the opening of the local market to foreign chicken since last year.

The spokesman added that Taiwanese chicken is appreciated because its flavor has not been spoiled by being repeatedly frozen and thawed during its transport from slaughterhouses to consumers' kitchens.

DOC.HEADLINE: LED CAR HEADLIGHT INVENTED
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 30 (CNA) (by Wu Jhe-hao and Zep Hu)

TEXT.P: An official of the Automotive Research and Testing Center (ARTC) in Changhua, central Taiwan said Sunday that research on a light-emitting diode (LED) car headlight is entering the final stages, with mass production expected to begin by July.

Huang Long-chou, general manager of the center, told CNA that the LED headlight has several advantages over the conventional type, including a 10-fold longer lifespan, 330 times faster to reach full brightness, and 50 percent less energy consumption.
Huang said the biggest challenge in the research and development was how to create an LED headlight that gave enough illumination without compromising the energy-saving feature.
Huang noted that the center is now working on a heat sink module prior to putting LED headlight into mass production.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT VOWS TO CUT OCCUPATIONAL INJURIES, DEATHS BY 30%

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian vowed Sunday to cut the country's rates of occupational injury and death by 30 percent within two years.

In a speech delivered at a meeting organized by the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) to improve workplace safety, the president dismissed the council's goal of cutting the rates by 20 percent within two years as "lukewarm."
He said the goal should be raised to 30 percent, as workplace safety is a basic right of laborers and one of the vital criteria for a civilized society.

Noting that he promised to lower the rate of occupational death by 40 percent during his term when he campaigned for president in 2000, the president proudly claimed that he had honored his promise, citing CLA statistics showing that laborer death from workplace incidents had declined from 77 people per million laborers in 2000 to 44 people per million laborers in 2004.
However, the president said, Taiwan in this regard is still lagging behind the developed countries such as Britain, which posted only seven deaths per million workers in 2004.
The president's promise is intended as a gift to the country's workers on the eve of Labor Day which falls May 1.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLITICAL WRANGLING FORESEEN OVER DIRECT CHINA LINKS BILLS

TEXT.P: Political wrangling between the opposition "pan blue alliance" and the ruling "pan green camp" is set to erupt at the Legislative Yuan as law amendments on opening direct transport links between Taiwan and China will be put to a vote May 2 after a four-month negotiation period has ended.

The vote will serve as a test of wisdom of the two camps, as the law revision is not only a matter of trade and business, it is also an issue of major concern that will touch on a delicate nerve among the Taiwan people, who are polarized by an independence versus unification dispute regarding Taiwan's future, according to observers.

While the pro-independence "pan green camp" of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) insists that Taiwan's sovereignty must be fully guaranteed if the two sides are to set up direct air and shipping links, the pro-unification "pan blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) demand that the government put aside the dispute and pragmatically devote its energy to two-way negotiations.

The "pan blue alliance" has vowed to resort to a public referendum should the government refuse to respond to the direct links issue after the law revision initiated by the KMT and the PFP clears the opposition-controlled Legislative Yuan.

The law amendment to the Statute Governing the Relations Between the People of the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area seeks to allow Taiwanese vessels to go to China and vice versa with Taiwan's permission. It also would remove a ban on foreign ships and aircraft plying between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

Many KMT and PFP lawmakers say that now is a good time to promote direct Taiwan-China transport links, as the DPP government is poised to open Taiwan to Chinese tourists and because Premier Su Tseng-chang has said tht he would consider putting in place some of the 15 overtures made by Beijing to Taiwan following an economic forum in Beijing last month between the KMT and the Communist Party of China.
Tseng Yung-chuan, head of the KMT Policy Coordination Committee, said that the "pan blue alliance" will seek a vote to determine the links issue if inter-party negotiations fail.

Urging the DPP government to respect public opinion and conduct rational negotiations with the "pan blue alliance" on the links, Tseng said that the KMT and the PFP will undoubtedly call a vote on the issue within this legislative session and that the Executive Yuan has to abide by the Legislative Yuan's decision.

Lu Hsueh-chang, a whip of the PFP legislative caucus, said that "there is no need to talk about" the issue now that the DPP and the TSU remain firmly opposed to setting up the links across the Taiwan Strait.
"A vote will be unavoidable to settle the issue as there is no room left for further negotiations," Lu said.

Meanwhile, DPP legislative caucus whip Chen Chin-jun expressed hope that the "pan blue alliance" will not dance to Beijing's tune by forcing the law amendment through the Legislative Yuan and asking the government to establish direct transport links with China under its "one China" precondition.

The links must be set up after the governments on the two sides have held talks on an equal footing, Chen said. "Taiwan's overall interests and national dignity must be fully safeguarded in such talks and the government will never accept Beijing's plot to make Taiwan one of its provinces," he added.

Chen called on the KMT and the PFP to refrain from ramming the law revisions through the Legislative Yuan, although he acknowledged that it is hard to stop the "pan blue alliance" from doing so as it controls a majority at the legislature.

Saying that the ruling DPP is still willing to hold negotiations with the "pan blue alliance" over the issue, he claimed that the two parties have to face the people's verdict if they disregard national security and dignity, and should even call a public referendum.

If the links issue is approved by the people in a referendum, the "DPP government has to accept the final result, " Chen said. But he warned the "pan blue alliance" that the independence-unification dispute will arise again no matter the outcome.

TSU legislative caucus whip David Huang said that his party objects to an irresponsible or rash establishment of direct transport links across the strait as the Executive Yuan has yet to submit a report of its impact on the domestic economy.
Huang made it clear that the TSU is unlikely to throw its support behind the far-reaching issue if the Executive Yuan does not provide a clear explanation to the public as to why it wants the links.
"Any open-door policy without adequate evaluation in advance is an imprudent and irrational act whose pros and cons cannot not be detected beforehand," Huang said.

As long as an assessment shows that setting up the links will not affect Taiwan's national security and will not hobble its economy, the TSU "would be willing to further discuss the issue," he claimed.

But Huang expressed disappointment with what he called the government's inactivity, because no relevant government officials were willing to give a report to the party's legislative caucus on the matter.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: U.S. Says It Fears Detainee Abuse in Repatriation
A long-running effort by the Bush administration to send home many of the terror suspects held at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, has been stymied in part because of concern among United States officials that the prisoners may not be treated humanely by their own governments, officials said. "The Pentagon has no plans to release any detainees in the immediate future, " said a Defense Department spokesman, Lt. Cmdr. Jeffrey Gordon of the Navy. He said the negotiations with foreign governments "have proven to be a complex, time-consuming and difficult process." The military has so far sent home 267 detainees from Guantanamo after finding that they had no further intelligence value and either posed no long-term security threat or would reliably be imprisoned or monitored by their own governments. Most of those who remain are considered more dangerous militants; many also come from nations with poor human rights records and ineffective justice systems.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP MULLING ANTI-CORRUPTION REGULATIONS ON PARTY PUBLIC OFFICERS

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) is contemplating tacking on to its party platform an anti-corruption chapter to boost the party's image, but this idea was getting the cold shoulder from a leading party lawmaker.

Tsai Huang-liang, director of the DPP Cultural and Communications Department said Sunday the chapter will incorporate three principles, including a ban on moonlighting by DPP lawmakers, a requirement for DPP public officials to put their assets into trust, and an avoidance of conflict of interests for them.
By public officials, Tsai said, it refers to the chiefs of rural and urban township, members of county and city council and other officials above their levels.

Tsai said the forbiddance on moonlighting was necessary after two DPP lawmakers who run hospitals respectively were indicted for overclaiming medicare fees through their hospitals from the national insurance Bureau.

He said DPP Chairman Yu Shyi-kun hopes the anti-corruption chapter which is to be hammered out by the party's Policy Coordination Committee will help clean the party's image and win back the public confidence in the party's integrity.
However, DPP lawmaker Chen Chin-jun, who is the whip of the party's legislative caucus, opposed this move, claiming it will only lend credit to critics' claims that DPP is ridden with corruption.

Noting that several government-initiated bills designed to ensure the integrity of elected public officials are pending in the legislature, Tsai said it is unnecessary for the DPP to compete with the government in laying down its own anti-corruption rules.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR MAY 1 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Monday, May 1:
10:00, A labor group will pretest what it claims as the government's discrimination against foreign laborers and Chinese people who married with local people.
15:00, Premier Su Tseng-chang will attend a ceremony marking the Labor Day at Holiday Inn Asiaworld Plaza in Taipei.
16:00, The councillors of the Council for Economic Planning and Development will hold a meeting at the council's Taipei headquarters.
16:30, the Ministry of Finance will hold a weekly news conference at its Taipei headquarters.
